<START/>


<TITLE>Vṛṣasārasaṃgrahaḥ</TITLE>
<HEADERTITLE>Vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe</HEADERTITLE>
%chapter 1

<startchapter-n="1"/>
<CHAPTER>prathamo 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>
<TRCHAPTER>Chapter One</TRCHAPTER>

<ANUSTUBH/>
%Is 'oṃ namaḥ śivāya' there?     
% \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa YES
% \msCa\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM[?]  have a Siddham symbol before oṃ
% \Ed: atha vṛsasārasaṃgrahaprārambha(ḥ)

<SUBCHAPTER>stutiḥ</SUBCHAPTER>

<TRSUBCHAPTER>Invocation</TRSUBCHAPTER>
<NOTANUSTUBH/> upajāti

<TEXT> anādimadhyāntam{ }anantapāraṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°ntam{ }ananta°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                 °ntam{ }anta° \msCbacorr\oo
                 <LEM>°pāraṃ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; °pāragaṃ \msNa\msNb\msNd\msKOa</APP>
                        %pāragaṃ \msNd\msBod
        <PARAL>\va Ł\compare\ \SDHU\ 10.6:$
                ādimadhyāntanirmuktaḥ svabhāvavimalaḥ prabhuḥ |
                sarvajñaḥ paripūrṇaś{ }ca śivo jñeyaḥ śivāgame ||</PARAL>

% \msBod also reads pāraga

<TEXT> susūkṣmam{ }avyaktajagatsusāram|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>susūkṣma°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                         śusukṣma° \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°vyakta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; °vya° \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>°jagatsusāram</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; °jagaśusāraṃ \msCc,
                                                                                      °jagatsurāsuraṃ \msNb,
                                                                                      °jagatasusāram \msNd</APP>
        <TR>Having bowed to the One who has no beginning, no middle part
        and no end, whose boundaries are limitless, who is very subtle and
        who is the unmanifest and fine essence of the world,
        and also to Indra, Brahmā and the other [gods], 
        I shall recite [the work called] `A Compendium on the 
        Essence of the Bull [of Dharma]'.</TR>


<TEXT> harīndrabrahmādibhir{ }āsamagraṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>harī°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\Ed; harīṃ \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>°bhir{ }āsamagraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msKOa\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                                °bhir{ }yat{ }samagraṃ \msM\ \unmetr, 
                                                                °bhir{ }osamagraṃ \msPaperC</APP>
% \vc °bhir{ }āptam{ }agraṃ ] \conj; °bhir{ }āsamagraṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\Ed, 
% °bhir{ }yat{ }samagraṃ \msM\ \unmetr
%Vicitrakarṇikāvadānoddhṛta p 80 and 328-329 samagraṃ, stem forms etc.!?

%index_voc: āsamagra
%index_metre: muta cum liquida br


<TEXT> praṇamya vakṣye vṛṣasārasaṃgraham||</TEXT> 1:1
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vṛṣa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCapcorr\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                         °vṛṣo \msCaacorr</APP>
        <LACUNA>ŁWitnesses used for this chapter:       \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 193v--195v,
                                                        \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 201v--203v,
                                                        \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 267r--270r,
                                                        \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 1v--3v,
                                                        \msNb\ exp.\thinspace 44, 43 lower and then upper leaf
                                                                              (1.62cd--2.22 are missing),
                                                        \msNc\  ff.\thinspace 209v--211v,
                                                        \msNd\  ff.\thinspace 227v--229v
                                                                                (collated only up to 1.15ab),
                                                        \msM\   ff.\thinspace 1r--3v,
                                                        \msKOa\ ff.\thinspace 1v--4r
                                                                                (collated only up to 1.16),
                                                        \msPaperA\ ff.\thinspace 204r--206r,
                                                        \msPaperC\ ff.\thinspace 206r--209r
                                                                                (collated only up to 1.15),
                                                        \Ed\ pp.\thinspace 580--585;
                                                        \mssCaCbCc\ = \msCa + \msCb + \msCc$</LACUNA>
                        % pranamya \msCc
                        %Łpāragaṃ$ in \msNa\msNb: the same extra syllable as in pāda d.
%index_metre: upajāti
%index_metre: vaṃśastha

        <NOTE>This verse echoes \VSS\ 20.3:<sep/>
                Łnādimadhyaṃ na cāntaṃ ca yan na vedyaṃ surair api$ | <br/>
                Łatisūkṣmo hy atisthūlo nirālambo nirañjanaḥ ||$ <sep/>
                This could suggest
                that Łpāda$ c above might be parallel with Łna vedyaṃ surair api$. 
                Perhaps understand Łasamagraṃ$ [Łvedyaṃ$] (`incompletely [known]).<sep/>
        ŁPāda$ a is also reminiscent of, among other famous passages, \BHG\ 11.19:
        <sep/>
        Łanādimadhyāntam anantavīryam$ 
                Łanantabāhuṃ śaśisūryanetram$ | <br/>
        Łpaśyāmi tvāṃ dīptahutāśavaktraṃ$ 
                Łsvatejasā viśvam idaṃ tapantam$ ||
        <sep/>
        See also \BHG\ 10.20cd:
        <sep/>
                Łaham ādiś ca madhyaṃ ca bhūtānām anta eva ca$ ||
        <sep/>
        A faint reference to the \BHG\ seems proper at the
        beginning of a work that claims to deliver a teaching 
        based on, but also to surpass, the \MBH\ (see following verses of the \VSS).<sep/>
        Compare also, e.g., \KURMP\ 1.11.237:
        <sep/>
                Łrūpaṃ tavāśeṣakalāvihīnam$
                        Łagocaraṃ nirmalam ekarūpam$ |<br/> 
                Łanādimadhyāntam anantam ādyaṃ$ 
                        Łnamāmi satyaṃ tamasaḥ parastāt$ ||
        <sep/>
        In general, to say that a god has no beginning and no end in a temporal or spacial sense is natural
        (Łanādi \dots\ antam$), but to have no `middle part' (Łmadhya$) in these senses is slightly less so.
        Thus the rather commonly occurring phrase Łanādimadhyāntam$ is probably a fixed expression usually 
        referring to a deity that is endless, eternal and immaterial. 
        As to which deity or what form of a deity this stanza refers to, one could argue that 
        it is Śiva, his name missing in Łpāda$ c, but the phrasing of the verse 
        is vague enough to keep the question somewhat open: the impersonal Brahman 
        might be another option, even more so if we look at verses 1.9--10, whose
        topic is Łbrahmavidyā$.


        <sep/>
        In Łpāda$ b Łjagat-susāraṃ$ is most probably not 
        to be interpreted as Łjagatsu sāraṃ$ (`the essence in the worlds').
        Another way to translate Łavyaktajagatsusāraṃ$ would be: 
        `who is the fine essence of the unmanifest world.'

        <sep/>
        Strictly speaking, Łpāda$ c is unmetrical, but it is better to 
        simply acknowledge here the phenomenon of `muta cum liquida', or rather,
        Łkrama$ licence, namely
        that syllables followed by consonant clusters such as 
        Łra, bra, hra, kra, śra, śya, śva, sva, dva$ can be treated as short (Łlaghu$).
        (See Introduction pp.~\pageref{muta}\thinspace ff.)
        Thus Łharīndrabrahmā$° can be treated as a regular beginning
        of an Łupajāti$ (\shortsyllable\ - \shortsyllable\ - -), the syllable 
        Łbra$ not turning the previous syllable long (Łguru$).

        <sep/>
        The reading Łāsamagraṃ$ in Łpāda$ c is suspect 
        (see a preliminary comment on this above),
        although the initial Łā-$ might convey some sort of
        completeness, meaning `all round'
        (see e.g. <citep>KaleHigherGrammar</citep><pnum>226</pnum>).
        The fact that we could perceive the ending of Łpāda$s a and b 
        (Łpāraṃ$--Łsāram$), as well as Łpāda$s c and d, as (in the 
        latter case, oddly) rhyming pairs (Łgraṃ$-Łgraham$)
        suggests that accepting the reading Łāsamagram$ could be 
        the right decision (as suggested by Alessandro Battistini).
        I translate this verse accordingly. \msM\ gives an exciting,
        albeit unmetrical, alternative (Łyat samagraṃ$), but
        this seems more of a guess than the correct reading.
        For some time I was considering emending Łāsamagraṃ$.
        The most tempting of all the possible options 
        (Łarcyam/arhyam/arghyam/īḍyam/āḍhyam/āptam agraṃ, āsamastaṃ$) 
        seemed to be Łāptam agraṃ$,
        meaning `appointed/received/respected [by Hari, Indra,
        Brahmā etc.] as the foremost one'. The fact that 
        the Łakṣara$s Łāsam$ and Łāptam$ look similar in most
        of the scripts used in the witnesses could support this
        conjecture. Łāptam$ could also
        possibly refer to the text itself, although then the
        syntax becomes slightly confusing: `I shall recite the
        ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ that was first received by Hari...' etc.
        Another candidate was Łāḍhyam agram$:
        `Having bowed to [Him] who contains/is rich with Hari, Indra, Brahmā
        etc.' I have not emended the text because it is difficult
        to know if there is any need for change and if there is, which reading 
        to chose. There was no consensus when this verse was discussed 
        in our extended Śivadharma reading group.

        <sep/>
        ŁPāda$ d seems hypermetrical, but it can be interpreted as a Łvaṃśastha$
        line, a change from Łtriṣṭubh$ to Łjagatī$ (as suggested by Dominic Goodall).</NOTE>

%index_biblio: Bhagavadgītā DONE (MBh)
%index_biblio: Kale Higher Grammar DONE
%index_biblio: Kūrmapurāṇa https://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.292688/page/n175/mode/2up?view=theater
%index_metre: muta cum liquida bra

<SUBCHAPTER>janamejayavaiśampāyanasaṃvādaḥ</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Dialogue of Janamejaya and Vaiśampāyana</TRSUBCHAPTER>
<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> śatasāhasrikaṃ granthaṃ sahasrādhyāyam{ }uttamam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°srikaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                 °srakaṃ \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>granthaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                  graṃtha \msKOa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sahasrādhyāyam{ }u°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC; 
                                                        sahaśradhyāyam{ }u° \msCc,
                                                        sahasrādhyāyar{ }u° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Having listened to the ŁBhāratasaṃhitā$ [i.e. the ŁMahābhārata$], the supreme book of 
              a hundred thousand [verses] and a thousand chapters (Ładhyāya$),</TR>
                        % satasāhaśrikaṃ \msCc

<TEXT> parva cāsya śataṃ pūrṇaṃ śrutvā bhāratasaṃhitām||</TEXT> 1:2
        <APP>\vc <LEM>parva cāsya</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msMpcorr; parvañ{ }cāsya \msCb,
                                 parvam{ }asya \msCc\msNd\msMacorr\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed, pūrva cāsya \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>śataṃ pūrṇaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                 ta \msCc, śataṃ pūrṇṇa \msKOa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>śrutvā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                 śraddhā \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>bhāratasaṃhitām</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msKOa;
                                         bhārasaṃhitā \msCc, bhāratasaṃhitaṃ \msNd, 
                                         nāradasaṃhitām \msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed</APP>
                                         % PaperMSA and C read nārada with Ed
        <PARAL>\vc Ł\compare\ \MBH\ 1.2.70ab:$ etat{ }parvaśataṃ pūrṇaṃ vyāsenoktaṃ mahātmanā</PARAL>
        <NOTE>The dialogue of Janamejaya and Vaiśampāyana makes up the outermost layer of the \VSS\ 
                (see Introduction p.~\pageref{structure}), mostly containing
                general Łdharmaśāstric$ material.
                <sep/>
                That the \MBH\ should contain a hundred thousand verses is hinted at, e.g., in line 19 of
                the Khoh Charter 2 of Śarvanātha, year 214 (Siddham Database IN00088; 
                Łuktañ ca mahābhārate śatasāhasryaṃ$ [understand °Łryāṃ$] Łsaṃhitāyāṃ$...).
                The hundred Łparvan$s of the ŁMahābhārata$ are listed in \MBH\ 1.2.33--70.
                Note the use of the singular (Łparva$) in connection with numerals (Łśataṃ$),
                one of the hallmarks of this text (see p.~\pageref{singularwithnumerals}).</NOTE>
        <TR>with all its hundred sections (Łparvan$),</TR>

%index_grammar: Newar: singular with inanimate and numbers, number after noun (parva)


%https://siddham.network/inscription/in00088)
%MS Add.2102 parvvam asya ta srutvā \lkārasaṃhitā
% On 100 parvans, see Schlingloff 1969. (Thanks to Kenji.)
% see also Bühler, Georg; Kirste, Johann  Title: Indian Studies, II: Contributions to the History of the Mahâbhârata. Publ.: Wien : F. Tempsky 1892 Description:   58 p. Series: Sitzungsberichte der Philosophisch-Historischen Classe der Kaiserlichen Akademie der Wissenschaften, 127, XII. p. 26: cites an inscription from Fleet Cor. Inscr. Ind. vol iii p. 137: "mahābhārate śatasāhasry[ā\lk]ṃ saṃhitāyāṃ" ('Khoh copper-plate inscription of the Mahārāja Śarvanātha, the year 214', pp. 135--139)


%index_biblio: Mahābhārata
<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> atṛptaḥ puna papraccha vaiśampāyanam{ }eva hi|</TEXT>
        <TR>Janamejaya remained unsatisfied. Listen attentively to</TR>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>atṛptaḥ puna papraccha</LEM> \eme;
                a<UNCL>tṛptaḥ pu</UNCL>\lk\lk praccha \msCa, 
                atṛptaḥ punaḥ papraccha \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc,
                atṛptaḥ punar{ }apracche \msCc,
                atṛptaḥ puna paḥpraccha \msNd,
                atṛptaḥ punaḥ papṛccha \msM,
                papraccha punar{ }atṛpto \msKOa,
                atṛptāḥ punaḥ papreccha \msPaperA,
                atṛpta punaḥ papraccha \msPaperC,
                atṛptā punaḥ papraccha \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vaiśampāyana°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                         vesampāyana° \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>My emendation from the unmetrical Łpunaḥ$ to the unusual, or rather, Middle Indic
                (<citep>EdgertonHybrid</citep><pnum>vol. 2, p. 347</pnum>),
                and Newar (<citep>JorgensenGrammar</citep><pnum>113</pnum>), Łpuna$ is based
                on the assumption that in the original the metre must have overridden 
                morphology, similarly to what may have happened in 8.44d (Mālinī metre):
                Łna bhavati punajanma kalpakoṭyāyute 'pi$, and in 12.151c (Sragdharā metre):
                Łgarbhāvāsaṃ na ca tvan na ca punamaraṇaṃ kleśam āyāsapūrṇam$.

                <sep/>
                For an unsatisfaction or dissatisfaction (Łatṛpti$) with previous 
                teachings in a somewhat similar manner to what
                Janamejaya experiences here, see, e.g., ŁNiśvāsa$ mūla 1.9:
                <sep/>
                Łvedāntaṃ viditaṃ deva sāṃkhyaṃ vai pañcaviṃśakam$ |<br/>
                Łna ca tṛptiṃ gamiṣyāmo hy ṛte śaivād anugrahāt$ ||
                <sep/>
                </NOTE>
        % CHECK \msCa\msCb
% atṛptaḥ puna paḥpraccha \msNd

<TEXT> janamejayena yat{ }pūrvaṃ tac{ }chṛṇu tvam{ }atandritam||</TEXT> 1:3
%index_grammar: instr + finite verb (ergative), Newari
%index_voc: puna (for punar)
%index_persons: Janamejaya
%index_persons: Vaiśampāyana

% janamejaya yat{ }pūrvaṃ\eme;
        <TR>what he asked Vaiśampāyana in the past.</TR>
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>janamejayena yat{ }pūrvaṃ</LEM> \msCapcorr\msCb\msNc\msNd\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                  janamejaye yat{ }pūrvaṃ \msCaacorr,
                  janmejayena yam{ }pūrvaṃ \msCc,
                  janamejayena yat{ }pūrva \msNa,
                  janamejayena yat{ }pū<UNCL>rva</UNCL> \msNb,
                  janmejayeṇa yat{ }pūrvaṃ \msM,
                  janmejayena ya\lac\ \msKOa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tac{ }chṛṇu tvam{ }a°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                 tac{ }chṛṇa tvam{ }a° \msCc, \lac\ ××××× \msNb, tac{ }chṛṇu svam{ }a° \msNd,
                                 ta śṛṇu tvam{ }a° \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>°tandritam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; °tandritaḥ \msCc\msNa,
                                                         \lac\ ××× \msNb</APP>
                        %\msCc chruṇa ... atandritaḥ CHECK
                  <NOTE>Vaiśampāyana, a Ṛṣi, disciple of Vyāsa, great-grandson to Arjuna,
                recited the \MBh\ at the snake sacrifice of 
                Janamejaya. This setting is an echo of the starting point of the \MBH, see \MBH\ 1.1.8ff.
                In fact the next few verses in the \VSS\ make it clear that the \VSS\
                picks up where the \MBH\ left off: Janamejaya has heard the whole \MBh\ from
                Vaiśampāyana, but he is eager to hear more, or rather a concise version
                of the Dharmic teachings of the \MBh.
                <sep/>
                It is tempting to emend Łpāda$ c to contain a \stemform\
                proper noun (Łjanamejaya$)
                in order to maintain the metre, 
                and note how the manuscripts struggle with this Łpāda$. 
                \Stemform\ nouns, Łprātipadika$s, abound in the \VSS: 
                see Introduction p.~\pageref{stemform}.
                On the other hand, the contracted/syncopated form Łjanmejaya$ occurs, 
                e.g., in \BHAGP\ 12.06.16 and \BRAHMAVP\ 4.14.41 and 46. (It is even
                lexicalised in \Monier) 
                The hypermetrical form Łjanamejayena$, and the construction finite verb + instrumental
                (Łpapraccha... janamejayena$), could be original; compare 1.8 and 4.75 below.
                Alternatively, 1.3cd could be taken as a separate, and elliptical,
                sentence standing for Łjanamejayena yac chrutaṃ pūrvaṃ tac chṛṇu$.</NOTE>
% MBh Ādiparvan: janamejayena pṛṣṭaḥ san brāhmaṇaiś ca sahasraśaḥ ..-.-.----.-..-.. CHECK śikhariṇī?
% janamejayasya rājarṣeḥ sarpasatre mahātmanaḥ ..-.-.----.--.-.. CHECK śikhariṇī?



<TEXT> janamejaya uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>janamejaya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                                 janmejaya \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Janamejaya spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> bhagavan{ }sarvadharmajña sarvaśāstraviśārada|</TEXT>
       <APP>\va <LEM>bhagavan{ }sa°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; 
                                                                bhacāvaṃ sa° \msCc, bhagava sa° \msNd,
                                                                bhagavaṃ sa° \msM\oo
                <LEM>°dharmajña</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                 °jña \msNa, °dharmajñaḥ \msNd</APP>
       <APP>\vb <LEM>°viśārada</LEM> \msCa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msPaperA; 
                                                °visāradaḥ \msCb\msCc\msNa\msKOa\msPaperC\Ed, °viśāradam \msM</APP>
       <PARAL>\vab Ł= \MBH\ 13.112.9ab$</PARAL>
        <TR>O venerable sir, O knower of the entire Dharma, O you who are well-versed in all the
                sciences (Łśāstra$)!</TR>

% Kenji says neuter Dharma
% Flo guhya dharma is a formula
<TEXT> asti dharmaṃ paraṃ guhyaṃ saṃsārārṇavatāraṇam||</TEXT> 1:4
        <APP>\vc <LEM>asti dharmaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; asti dharmaḥ \msCb, 
                                                        asti dharma \msCc\msM\msKOa, adharma \msNd\oo
             <LEM>paraṃ guhyaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNb\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                        paro guhya \msCb, paraṃ guhya \msCc\msNa, 
                                                        paraguhyaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°tāraṇam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                       °tāraṇā \msKOa</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łdharma$ as a neuter noun in Łpāda$ c and in the next verse.</NOTE>
                % Liṅgapurāṇa: bhavyaṃ pāśupataṃ nityaṃ saṃsārārṇavatārakam।। 1.108.18 ।।
        <TR>There is a supreme and secret Dharma [that brings about] liberation from the ocean of 
                        mundane existence (Łsaṃsāra$),</TR>

%index_grammar: gender, dharma neuter

% Vyāsa --> Vaiśampāyana --> Ugraśravas
<TEXT> dvaipāyanamukhodgīrṇaṃ dharmaṃ vā yad{ }dvijottama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dvaipāyana°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                dvepāyana° \msCc, 
                                                                vaisāṃpāyana° \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>°mukhodgīrṇaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\msPaperC;
                                                                °mukhodgīrṇa \msCc\msKOa,
                                                                °mudgīrṇṇa \msNd,
                                                                 mukhaṃ gīrṇṇaṃ \msMacorr, 
                                                                 mu<UNCL>khāṃ</UNCL> gīrṇṇaṃ \msMpcorr,
                                                                 mukhād{ }gīrṇaṃ \Ed</APP>
                <APP>\vb <LEM>dharmaṃ vā yad{ }dvi°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                dharmaṃ yat{ }tad{ }dvi° \msCb,
                                                dharmavat{ }ya dvi° \msCc\msKOa, dharma vā yad{ }dvi° \msNd,
                                                dharmavākyaṃ dvi° \msM\oo 
                  <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                         °ttamaḥ \msCc, °tamaḥ \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>The majority of the MSS consulted include a Łvā$ in Łpāda$ b, 
                and although \msCb's reading seems a bit smoother, that manuscript rarely gives superior readings.
                Therefore I have chosen Łdharmaṃ vā yad$, in which Łvā$ functions probably in a weak sense
                (`that is').
                That the secret Dharma Janamejaya is seeking is the one taught by Vyāsa Dvaipāyana, and
                thus no real options are involved here, becomes clear in 1.6cd.
                The reading of \msM\ in Łpāda$ b (Łdharmavākyaṃ$) is tempting but could be a later correction.</NOTE>
        <TR>that is, the Dharma that emerged from [Vyāsa] Dvaipāyana's mouth, O best of Brahmins.</TR>
%index_grammar: gender, dharma neuter

<TEXT> kathayasva hi me tṛptiṃ kuru yatnāt{ }tapodhana||</TEXT> 1:5
        <APP>\vc <LEM>hi me tṛptiṃ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                       hi me tṛpti \msNd\msKOa,
                                                                       prasādena \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>yatnāt{ }tapodhana</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; 
                                        yannāt{ }ta\lk\lk na \msCa,
                                        yatnā tapodhanaḥ \msCc, yatnā tapodhana \msNd,
                                        yatnan{ }tapodhana \msM, yaṃnāt{ }ta° \msKOa</APP>
        <NOTE>In general, \msM's readings here are unique but probably secondary: 
                Łhi me tṛptiṃ$ in Łpāda$ c seems more attractive than \msM's 
                Łprasādena$ because it echoes Łatṛptaḥ$ in 1.3a</NOTE>
        <TR>Teach [it] to me and help me find satisfaction at all cost, O great ascetic!</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>
<TRPAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> vaiśampāyana uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>vaiśampāyana uvāca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msMpcorr\msKOa\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                \om\ \msMacorr, vai || vaiśampāyana \msPaperC</APP>
        <TR>Vaiśampāyana spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> śṛṇu rājann{ }avahito dharmākhyānam{ }anuttamam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>rājann{ }a°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                 rājaṃn{ }a° \msNd, rājan{ }a° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°hito</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                °hitaṃ \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°khyānam{ }anuttamam</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; °khyānam{ }uttamam \msCb,
                                °khyānam{ }utamam \msCc, °dharmavyākhyānam{ }uttamaṃ \msNd\ \hypermetr,
                                 °kha\lac m{ }anuttamaṃ \msKOa,
                                 °khyānam{ }anuttamaḥ \msPaperA,
                                 °khyānam{ }uttamaḥ \msPaperC</APP>
        <TR>Listen with great attention, O king, to this unsurpassed narration of Dharma.</TR>
%index_metre: na-vipulā

<TEXT> vyāsānugrahasamprāptaṃ guhyadharmaṃ śṛṇotu me||</TEXT> 1:6
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°prāptaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                         °prāpta \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dharmaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                         °rmaṃ \msCc, °dharma \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>śṛṇotu</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                          śṛṇota \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>me</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                          mai \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Hear the secret Dharma that I received through the grace of Vyāsa.</TR>

% msKOa seems useless
% Acri's talk: 14-16th c. Old-Javanese Bhuvanakośa, ascetic: Nirartha...
<TEXT> anarthayajñakartāraṃ tapovrataparāyaṇam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°kartāraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                 °karttantaṃ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°vrata°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; 
                                                                 °prata° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°yaṇam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                        °yana \msCc, °yaṇaḥ \msNa, 
                                                        °yanaṃ \msNc, °<UNCL>yaṇaṃ</UNCL> \msNd</APP>

<TEXT> śīlaśaucasamācāraṃ sarvabhūtadayāparam||</TEXT> 1:7
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°cāraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                        °cāra \msKOa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°param</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; °nvitam \msCc\msNd\msKOa,
                                                                        °<UNCL>pa</UNCL>raṃ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>On Anarthayajña, the interlocutor of \VSS\ 1.9--10.2 and 19.1--21.22, and
               an important figure discussed in 22.3ff, as well as a concept (`nonmaterial sacrifice'),
               see <cite>KissVolume2021</cite> and Introduction p.~\pageref{anarthayajna_person}.</NOTE>

%index_biblio: Kiss 2021 (ŚDh volume)

<TEXT> jijñāsanārthaṃ praśnaikaṃ viṣṇunā prabhaviṣṇunā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°rthaṃ praśnaikaṃ</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °rthaṃ praśnekaṃ \msCa\msNd, 
                                        °rthapraśnekam \msCc\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed, °rthapraścaikaṃ \msM,
                                        °thapraśnaika \msKOa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>prabha°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                         prabhu° \msCc, prābha° \msNc</APP>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā
%index_grammar: instr + finite verb (ergative), Newari

<TEXT> dvijarūpadharo bhūtvā papraccha vinayānvitaḥ||</TEXT> 1:8
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dharo</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                               °\lk ro \msCa, °dharā \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°nvitaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                               °nvitaṃ \msCc\msNd\msM</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the syntax here involving the agent in the instrumental
              with a finite verb (ergative structure): Łviṣṇunā... dvijarūpadharo bhūtvā papraccha$.
              Compare 1.3.</NOTE>
                <TR>|F| Viṣṇu, the great Lord, assuming the form
                         of a twice-born [Brahmin], wanted to 
                         test [Anarthayajña, the ascetic yogin] who practised
                         nonmaterial sacrifices (Łanarthayajña$),
                         focused on his austerities and
                         observances, whose conduct was virtuous
                         and pure, and who was intent on compassion towards
                         all living beings; therefore he [Viṣṇu]
                         humbly asked him a question.</TR>

% śīla and vinaya sound Buddhist Kenji (KCs yes, but also wide-spread in the epics etc.)
% \msNc\ rāpadharo 
% \msNc\ <CANCELLED>paṃ</CANCELLED> papraccha 



<SUBCHAPTER>brahmavidyā</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Knowledge of Brahman</TRSUBCHAPTER>
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.581

<TEXT> [vigatarāga uvāca|* ]</TEXT>
        <TR>[Vigatarāga spoke:]</TR>

<TEXT> brahmavidyā kathaṃ jñeyā rūpavarṇavivarjitā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kathaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; katha \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>jñeyā</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC;
                                                         jñeyaṃ \msCb\msCc, jñeya \msNd, bhūyo \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°varṇa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC;
                                                         °varṇā° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°varjitā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                 °varjitaṃ \msCc, °varjitāḥ \msNc, \lac tā \msKOa</APP>
        <TR>How is the knowledge of the Brahman to be understood if it is devoid of 
                 form and colour?</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 405.jpg f. 202r
% CHECK kimu more deeply, also Altindische Syntax by Berthold Delbrück on kimu pp. 504--
<TEXT> svaravyañjananirmuktam{ }akṣaraṃ kimu tat{ }param||</TEXT> 1:9
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vyañjana°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC;
                                                         °vyajjana° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°muktam{ }akṣa°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperC\Ed; °mukta akṣa° \msCb\msKOa,
                                         °muktaṃ akha° \msNd, °muktaṃ akṣa° \msM, °mmuktaṃm{ }akṣa° \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kimu tat{ }param</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                         kim{ }ataḥ param \msCb\msCc,
                                                         kim{ }atat{ }paraṃ \msNb\msNd\msM</APP>
        <NOTE>The translation of this verse, and the reconstruction and interpretation
                        of Łpāda$ d, which is echoed in 1.10d, is slightly tentative.
                        I doubt if Łkimu$ could have the standard (Vedic) meaning `how much more/less'
                        here. Rather Łu$ is probably just an expletive. In general it seems that
                        this verse references the syllable Łoṃ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Why is that supreme syllable which is devoid of vowels and consonants the supreme one?</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Anarthayajña replied:</TR>

        %CHECK /gretil/stkal_au.htm.txt and Niśv kārikā
<TEXT> anuccāryam{ }asandigdham{ }avicchinnam{ }anākulam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>anuccārya°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                        anucārya° \msCc\msNc\msNd,
                                                                        antracāya° \msKOa</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°sandigdham{ }avicchinnam{ }anākulam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                      °vicchinnasandigdham{ }anākuna \msCc, °sandigdham{ }anacchinnam{ }anākulam \msNb, 
                                                °sandigdham{ }avicchinam{ }anākulaṃ \msKOa</APP>
        <TR>That syllable is not to be pronounced, is unquestionable, non-dividable, consistent,</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 182.jpg, f. 267v (not 237v as online shown)
<TEXT> nirmalaṃ sarvagaṃ sūkṣmam{ }akṣaraṃ kim{ }ataḥ param||</TEXT> 1:10
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°gaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; °ga \msKOa</APP>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°kṣaraṃ kim{ }ataḥ param</LEM> \msCb\msM; °kṣaraṃ kimu tatparam \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed, 
                                                °kṣaraṃ kim{ }atatparaṃ \msCc\msNd\msPaperC,
                                                °kṣara kim{ }ataḥ paraṃ \msKOa, 
                                                °kṣarāṅ{ }kam{ }atatparaṃ \msPaperA</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ d, I have chosen, somewhat randomly, Łkim ataḥ$ instead of Łkimu tat$,
              trying to make sense of 10.9--10.</NOTE>
        <TR>spotless, all-pervading and subtle: what could be higher than that?</TR>



<SUBCHAPTER>kālapāśaḥ</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Noose of death and time</TRSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>°rāga uvāca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\Ed; °rāgovāca \msNd</APP>
        <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR>

% CHECK śmaśāna rules, who ... Kane v4 p189ff and p222, but especially 227ff !
<TEXT> dehī dehe kṣayaṃ yāte bhūjalāgniśivādibhiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dehe kṣa°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNc; dehāt{ }kṣa° \msCb,
                                         dehakṣa° \msNa\msNb\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>yāte</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\Ed; yānte \msNd</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°jalāgniśivādibhiḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                         °jalāgniśivādibhi \msCc,
                                         °jalāgniṃ śi\lk dibhi \msNd, °jālādiśivādibhiḥ \msKOa</APP>
        <PARAL>\vb Ł\compare\ \KURMP\ 2.23.74:$ 
                atha kaścit{ }pramādena mriyate 'gniviṣādibhiḥ| 
                tasyāśaucaṃ vidhātavyaṃ kāryaṃ caivodakādikam||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>The word °Łśivā$° in Łpāda$ b is slightly suspect, and could be the result
                of metathesis, from °Łviṣā$° (`by poison'). Nevertheless, 
                jackals seems appropriate in this context, for they 
                are commonly associated with human corpses, death and the cremation ground
                (see e.g. <cite>Ohnuma2019</cite>). Furthermore, Łpāda$ b lists phenomena
                that cause the body to disintegrate, and not causes of death; thus the reading Łśiva$
                is probably correct.</NOTE>
        <TR>When the body disintegrates in the ground, in water, in fire, or [is torn apart] by jackals 
                        and other [animals],</TR>

% if you wanna cite with page number etc, do this: (see e.g. <citep>Ohnuma2019<pnum>123</pnum></citep>). 

%index_biblio: Kūrmapurāṇa
%index_biblio: Ohnuma 2019: Reiko Ohnuma. The Heretical, Heterodox Howl: Jackals in Pāli Buddhist Literature. Religions 2019, 10, 221.

<TEXT> yamadūtaiḥ kathaṃ nīto nirālambo nirañjanaḥ||</TEXT> 1:11
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dūtaiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                         °dūte \msCc\msNd\oo
                 <LEM>kathaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                          katha \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>nīto</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd; nītvā \msCc, nītaḥ \msM, nīte \msKOa,
                                                          nītā \msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nirālambo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\Ed; 
                                                                nirolayā \msPaperA, nirorainvo \msPaperC\oo
                 <LEM>nirañjanaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                        nirañjana \msCc, 
                                                        nirañja\lk\ \msKOa</APP>
        <TR>how is the supportless and spotless soul led [to the netherworld] by Yama's messengers?</TR>

% nirdeha not in Monier-Williams
<TEXT> kālapāśaiḥ kathaṃ baddho nirdehaś{ }ca kathaṃ vrajet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°pāśaiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                         °pāśe \msCc, °pāśai \msNd\oo
                 <LEM>baddho</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                 ba<UNCL>ddho</UNCL> \msCb, baddha \msNd</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>nirdehaś{ }ca</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msMpcorr\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                        nirdahaḥ sa \msCc, nirdehasya \msNd, 
                                                        nirdehan{ }ma \msMacorr, nidehaś{ }ca \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>vrajet</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; bhavet \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>The word Łkāla$ has, as usual, a double meaning here: Łkālapāśa$
                        is both Yama's noose, and also the limitations and bondage caused by time, 
                        as becomes clear at the discussion on the different time units in verses 1.18--30.</NOTE>
        <TR>How is it bound by the nooses of death [/ time] (Łkālapāśa$)? And if it is bodiless, how can it move?</TR>

%index_voc: nirdeha

<TEXT> svargaṃ vā sa kathaṃ yāti nirdeho bahudharmakṛt|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>svargaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                         svarga \msCc\msNd\msM, svāgaṃ \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>sa</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msNd\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                         saṃ \msNb\msM\oo
                 <LEM>yāti</LEM> \msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC; 
                                                         yānti \mssCaCbCc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nirdeho</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                         nideho \msKOa</APP>
        <TR>And how does the [soul of a] virtuous [person] (Łbahudharmakṛt$)
                     reach heaven if it has no body?</TR>
         % nirdehaḥ \msCc

%index_voc: nirdeha

% saṃśaya (m)
<TEXT> etan{ }me saṃśayaṃ brūhi jñātum{ }icchāmi tattvataḥ||</TEXT> 1:12
        <APP>\ve <LEM>etan{ }me saṃśayaṃ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                         etan{ }me saṃśaye \msNa, etan{ }me saṃśayo \msNb\msNd, 
                                         evaṃ vismayasaṃsaya \msKOa</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°tum{ }i\-cchāmi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                        °tum{ }i \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Łsaṃśaya$ seems to be treated as neuter in Łpāda$ e.</NOTE>
        <TR>This is my doubt. Teach me. I want to know the truth.</TR>


<PAGEBREAK/>
<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>anarthayajña uvāca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\Ed;
                                         \om\ \msNaacorr</APP>
        <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> atisaṃśayakaṣṭaṃ te pṛṣṭo 'haṃ dvijasattama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>atisaṃśayakaṣṭaṃ te</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msMpcorr\msPaperC;
                                atiśaṃsa\-<UNCL>ya</UNCL>kaṣṭan{ }te \msCa,
                                                atiśaṃsayaka\-ṣṭam{ }me \msCc\msMacorr\Ed, 
                                                atisaṃśayakaṣṭo mo \msNd, 
                                                atisaṃsayakaṣṭañ{ }ca \msKOa,
                                                atisaṃsayakaṣṭa\lk n{ }te pā \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dvijasattama</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                         ca dvijottamaḥ \msCc\msKOa, dvijasattamaḥ \msNd</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łte$ used for Łtvayā$ in Łpāda$ a. Alternatively, taking Łte$ as genitive, the line
                could be translated as: `I am being asked about a great 
                                problem of yours that originates in doubts\dots'</NOTE>
        <TR>You are asking me about an extremely doubtful 
                        and problematic matter, O truest of the twice-born.</TR>

%index_grammar: te used as tvayā

<TEXT> durvijñeyaṃ manuṣyais{ }tu devadānavapannagaiḥ||</TEXT> 1:13
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°jñeyaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; °jñeya \msCc\msNb\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>manuṣyais{ }tu</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                        manuṣaiś{ }ca \msCb, maṇukṣe<UNCL>ptu</UNCL> \msCc, 
                                                        manuṣyes{ }tu \msNd</APP>
        <TR>[This is a matter that] is difficult to understand by humans, and [even] by gods (Łdeva$), 
                        demons (Łdānava$) and serpents (Łpannaga$).</TR>

<TEXT> karmahetu śarīrasya utpatti nidhanaṃ ca yat|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>karma°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa;
                                         anarthayajña uvāca|| karma° \msCc\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°hetu</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                        °hetuḥ \msCb, °heṃtu \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>śarīrasya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                        śarīrasyaṃ \msCc, 
                                                        sa\lac <UNCL>sya</UNCL> \msKOa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>utpatti ni°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; 
                                                        utpatini° \msCc\msNd, utpattir{ }ni° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>ca yat</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                        ca yaḥ \msNb, yat \msNd</APP>
        <NOTE>The MSS give Łkarmahetu$ in Łpāda$ a overwhelmingly, which could work as a neuter
              Łbahuvrīhi$ compound picking up both a stem-form Łutpatti$ and Łnidhanaṃ$. 
              Łkarmahetuḥ$ (\msCb) is grammatically more correct, picking up the feminine Łutpatti$,
              but a neuter stem-form Łutpatti$ is unsurprising in this text.</NOTE>
        <TR>The cause of both the birth and death of the body is karma.</TR>

%index_grammar: gender, neuter for feminine

%folioinfo: \msKOa 6.jpg
<TEXT> sukṛtaṃ duṣkṛtaṃ caiva pāśadvayam{ }udāhṛtam||</TEXT> 1:14
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sukṛtaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; 
                                                  sukṛtakṛtan \msCc, sukṛta \msNd\oo
                 <LEM>caiva</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; vāpi \msNd\msKOa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>pāśa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; pāsā° \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>°hṛtam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                 °hṛtaḥ \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Good and bad deeds are called the two nooses.</TR>

<TEXT> tenaiva saha saṃyāti narakaṃ svargam{ }eva vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tenaiva</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                 teneva \msCc\msNd\oo
                 <LEM>saha saṃyāti</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                         saha sā yānti \msCc\msNd, saha sā yāti \msM, 
                                                        saha saṃyānti \msKOa, sahaṃ sa yāti \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>narakaṃ svarga°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; 
                                                   narakadurgga° \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>vā</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed; ca \msNa\msNd\msKOa</APP>
        <TR>[The soul] goes to hell or heaven [bound and led] by the same [nooses of Yama's messengers, or the karmas].</TR>

<TEXT> sukhaduḥkhaṃ śarīreṇa bhoktavyaṃ karmasambhavam||</TEXT> 1:15
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sukha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msKOa\msPaperA\Ed; sukhaṃ \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°duḥkhaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM; °duḥkha \msCc\msNb\msKOa\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>bhoktavyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed;
                                                                bhoktavya \msKOa\oo
                 <LEM>°sambhavam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; 
                                        °sambhavaḥ \msCc\msPaperA\msPaperC\Ed, °saṃbhāvāt \msKOa</APP>
        <TR>Happiness and suffering, both arising from karma, are to be experienced by the body.</TR>

<TEXT> hetunānena viprendra dehaḥ sambhavate nṛṇām|</TEXT>

        <TR>It is for this reason, O great Brahmin, that the human body is born.</TR>

%folioinfo \msPaperC\ 8299.jpg lower f.206v
<TEXT> yaṃ kālapāśam{ }ity{ }āhuḥ śṛṇu vakṣyāmi suvrata||</TEXT> 1:16
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>yaṃ kālapāśam{ }ity{ }āhuḥ</LEM> \eme; yaṃ kālapāśam{ }ity{ }āha \msCa\msCb\msNa, 
                                        kālapāseti satvāha \msCc, yaṃ kālapāśam{ }ity{ }āhu \msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed, 
                                        kālapāṣeti <UNCL>pastve</UNCL>ha \msM, 
                                        yāṃ kālapāsam{ }ity{ }āhu \msKOa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°vrata</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; °vrataḥ \msCb\msCc\msKOa</APP>
        <TR>Now learn about that which they call the noose of time (Łkālapāśa$), 
                        I shall teach you, O you of great observances.</TR>
% is āhuḥ an overcorrection?

        % msKOa collated only up to this point, MS continues
%folioinfo \msNa\ 195.jpg lower f. 2r
% lectio difficilior?
<TEXT> na tvayā viditaṃ kiñcij{ }jijñāsyasi kathaṃ dvija|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>viditaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; vidita \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>kiñcij{ }ji°</LEM> \msCb\msM; kiñcid{ }vi° \msCapcorr\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed,
                                                        kid{ }vi° \msCaacorr, 
                                                        kiñci ji° \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kathaṃ dvija</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed;
                                \lk\lk\lk\lk\lk\lk\lk\lk\lk  <UNCL>ma tvayā viditaṃ kiñcid{ }vijñāsyasi</UNCL> 
                                \cancelled\ kathaṃ dvija \msCc</APP>
         <NOTE>The variant Łjijñāsyasi$ seems to be the lectio difficilior as opposed to
                        Łvijñāsyasi$, but the latter could also work fine here.</NOTE>
        <TR>[If] you do not know anything, how could you start 
                               your investigation, O twice-born?</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 183.jpg, f. 268r(?)
%folioinfo \msPaperA\ 332.jpg upper, f. 204v 
<TEXT> kālapāśaṃ ca viprendra sakalaṃ vettum{ }arhasi||</TEXT> 1:17
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kālapāśaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; kālapāṣeti \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vettum{ }arhasi</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb;
                                                 vettum{ }ūhasi \msNc, vaktum{ }arhasi \msM\msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note how \msM\ (agreeing with two paper MSS, \msPaperA\ and \msPaperC, as well as \Ed) 
              gives a reading (Łvaktum arhasi$) that is clearly out
              of context. This confirms that while \msM\ comes up with interesting readings, 
              they are mostly to be ignored.</NOTE>
        <TR>O great Brahmin, you should know the noose of time (Łkālapāśa$) in its entirety.</TR>
        % ahasi \msCb?

<TEXT> kalākalitakālaṃ ca kālatattvakalāṃ śṛṇu|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kalā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; kālā° \msCc\msNaacorr\oo
                 <LEM>°kalita°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; °<UNCL>kanmita</UNCL>° \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>°kālaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; °kālaś{ }ca \msM\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kalāṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNb\msPaperA\Ed; °kalā \msCb\msNc, °vidhiṃ \msNa, °kalāḥ \msM</APP>
        <TR>Learn about time (Łkāla$) which is divided into digits (Łkalā$), [i.e. about]
                        the division[s] (Łkalā$) of the entity [called] time (Łkālatattva$).</TR>
% NOTE \msM and \Ed

<TEXT> truṭidvayaṃ nimeṣas{ }tu nimeṣadviguṇā kalā||</TEXT> 1:18
        <APP>\vc <LEM>truṭidvayaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNc\Ed; tuṭidvaya \msCb\msNb, tuṭidvayaṃ \msNa\msM, 
                                                                        truvidvayaṃ \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>°meṣas{ }tu</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                                 °mevas{ }tu \msCa, °meṣadvi° \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nimeṣadvi°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; nimeṣādvi° \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>1.18d and 1.19a are problematic in the light of 1.19b, which 
                        redefines Łkalā$ in harmony with the traditional
                        interpretation, see e.g. \Arthasastra\ 2.20.33: Łtrimśatkāṣṭhāḥ kalāḥ$.
                        <nocite>Arthasastra1969</nocite>
                        On divisions of time, see also, e.g., \MANU\ 1.64ff.
                        I have calculated 1.6 second for one Łkalā$ backwards, starting from one day (see 1.20ab).</NOTE>
        <TR>Two atomic units of time (Łtruṭi$) are one twinkling (Łnimeṣa$).
                     One digit (Łkalā$, cca. 1.6 second) is twice a twinkling.</TR>

%index_biblio: Arthaśāstra
%index_biblio: Manu

<TEXT> kalādviguṇitā kāṣṭhā kāṣṭhā vai triṃśatiḥ kalā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°guṇitā kāṣṭhā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °guṇitaṃ kāṣṭhā \msM, 
                                                       °guṇitaṃ kāṣṭhī \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kāṣṭhā vai triṃśatiḥ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; vai triṃśatā \msCb,
                                 kāṣṭhā vai triṃśati \msCc, kāṣṭhān{ }vai triṃśati \msM</APP>
        <TR>Two digits (Łkalā$) form one bit (Łkāṣṭhā$, 3.2 seconds).
                 Thirty bits (Łkāṣṭhā$) make one digit (Łkalā$?, 1.6 minutes).</TR>

        % Monier-Williams: kāṣṭhā:  a measure of time (= 1/30 Kalā, Mn. i, 64; Suśr.; 
        % = 1/12 Kalā, Jyot.; = 1/15 Laghu, = 1/225 Nāḍikā, = 1/450 Muhūrta, BhP. iii, 11, 7), MBh. i, 1292 &c.

<TEXT> triṃśatkalā muhūrtaś{ }ca mānuṣena dvijottama||</TEXT> 1:19
        <APP>\vc <LEM>muhūrtaś{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA;
                                                         muhūrtta \msCb, muhūrtañ{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>mānuṣena</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; mānu<UNCL>ṣaś{ }ca</UNCL> \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNcpcorr\msPaperA\Ed; °tamaḥ \msNb\msM, °ttamaḥ \msNcacorr</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łmānuṣena$ as Łmānuṣasaṃkhyayā$ (1.21d).</NOTE>
        <TR>Thirty digits (Łkalā$) make up one section (Łmuhūrta$, 48 minutes) 
                                in human terms, O great Brahmin.</TR>

        % 2 truṭi    = 1 nimeṣa
        % 2 nimeṣa   = 1 kalā?
        % 2 kalā     = 1 kāṣṭhā
        % 30 kāṣṭhā  = 1 kalā
        % 30 kalā    = 1 muhūrta 
        % 30 muhūrta = 1 day


<TEXT> muhūrtatriṃśakenaiva ahorātraṃ vidur{ }budhāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>muhūrta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; muhūrttā \msM, muhūrtaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°dhāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; °dhā \msPaperA</APP>
        <TR>Thirty sections (Łmuhūrta$) are known to the 
                        wise as one night and day [i.e. a full day].</TR>

<TEXT> ahorātraṃ punas{ }triṃśan{ }māsam{ }āhur{ }manīṣiṇaḥ||</TEXT> 1:20
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°rātraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °rātra \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°nīṣiṇaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °nīṣina \msM</APP>
        <TR>Thirty days and nights are taught by the wise to be one month.</TR>
        % punaḥ \msNa\msNb



%folioinfo \msNb\ 44.jpg lower
<TEXT> samā dvādaśa māsāś{ }ca kālatattvavido janāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>samā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; māsa \msCc, samā samāyā \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>°māsāś{ }ca</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; °māsaś{ }ca \msCc\Ed, māsāhuḥ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kāla°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\msPaperA\Ed; kalā° \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note how a verb (e.g. Łiti vadanti, iti prāhur$) is missing in Łpāda$s ab.</NOTE>
        <TR>One year is twelve months [according to] people who know the entity of time.</TR>

%index_grammar: nominative for genitive? or absence of verb

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.582
<TEXT> śataṃ varṣasahasrāṇi trīṇi mānuṣasaṃkhyayā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śataṃ</LEM>   \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM;        śata° \msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>mānuṣa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; māṇuṣya° \msCb\msCc\ \unmetr</APP>
        <TR>The time span of three hundred</TR>

%lacuna_start: msNb
<TEXT> ṣaṣṭiṃ caiva sahasrāṇi kālaḥ kaliyugaḥ smṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 1:21
        <APP>\ve <LEM>ṣaṣṭiṃ caiva</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc\msM; ṣaṣṭiṃ varṣa° \msNa\msPaperA, ṣaṣṭiś{ }caiva \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°yugaḥ</LEM>       \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA; °yuga \msM\Ed</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vo Ł\msNb\ omits verses 21ef--24ab$</LACUNA>
        <TR>and sixty thousand years by human counting is said to be the Kali age (Łkali\-yuga$).</TR>
        % \vo <LEM>(ṣaṣṭiṃŁ...$ saṃjñitaḥ)</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; 
                                        % \om\ <EYESKIP>from 21d to 24d</EYESKIP> \msNb
        % kālaf \msCa

<PAGEBREAK/>
<TEXT> dviguṇaḥ kalisaṃkhyāto dvāparo yuga saṃjñitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>dviguṇaḥ kalisaṃkhyāto</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; kalisaṃkhyās{ }tu dviguṇo \msM,
                                                                         dvigurṇaḥ kalisaṃkhyāto \msPaperA, 
                                                                         dviguṇā kalisaṃkhyāto \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>dvāparo yuga saṃjñitaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA;
                                                                dvāparaḥ yugaḥ saṃjñikam \msM, 
                                                                dvāpare yuga saṃjñitaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ noun Łyuga$ in Łpāda$ b metri causa,
              or rather the compound Łdvāparo-yuga-saṃjñitaḥ$
              (the end of Łdvāparo$ lengthened to avoid the metrical fault of two Łlaghu$s),
              and also \msM's unique but confused readings.</NOTE>
        <TR>The Dvāpara age is known to be twice as long as the Kali age.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form

<TEXT> tretā tu triguṇā jñeyā catuḥ kṛtayugaḥ smṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 1:22
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tretā</LEM>   \msCa\msCb\msNa\msPaperA\Ed;              tetrā \msCc\msM, tretrā \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>triguṇā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;  tṛguṇo \msM\oo
                 <LEM>jñeyā</LEM>   \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;  jñeyaḥ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°yugaḥ</LEM>  \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA; °yuga \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The Tretā age is thrice [as long], the Kṛta age four [times as long as the Kali age].</TR>

<TEXT> eṣā caturyugāsaṃkhyā kṛtvā vai hy{ }ekasaptatiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>hy{ }e°</LEM>   \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msM\msPaperA\Ed;   he° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°saptatiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °saptati \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the lengthened vowel in °Łyugā$ (metri causa).<sep/>
                The `figure' mentioned in this verse is the sum of the duration of the four Łyuga$s, 
                which makes up one Łmahāyuga$:
                         Kaliyuga      =   360,000 years,
                         Dvāparayuga   =   720,000 years,
                         Tretāyuga     =  1,080,000 years,
                         Kṛtayuga   =  1,440,000 years; altogether 3,600,000 years. 71 Łmahāyuga$s make up
               a Łmanvantara$ (= 255,600,000 years; cf. \Manu\ 1.79). 
               One Łkalpa$ is 14 Łmanvantara$s (= 3,578,400,000 years). 
               Ten thousand Łkalpa$s are one day of Brahmā, and his night is of the same length, which
               would make one full day of Brahmā 71,568,000,000,000 human years. See next verses and,
               e.g., <cite>GonzalezCosmic</cite>.</NOTE>
        <TR>This is the figure related to the four ages (Łyuga$). Multiplying it by seventy-one,</TR>

%index_metre: lengthening of vowel metri causa

<TEXT> manvantarasya caikasya jñānam{ }uktaṃ samāsataḥ||</TEXT> 1:23
        <APP>\vc <LEM>caikasya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNc\msMpcorr\msPaperA\Ed; \om\ \msNaacorr\msMacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ktaṃ</LEM>    \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;                °kta \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>See \VSS\ 21.34ff on Łkalpa$ etc.</NOTE>
        <TR>the knowledge about one time-span of a Manu (Łmanvantara$) has been briefly taught.</TR>

<TEXT> kalpo manvantarāṇāṃ tu caturdaśa tu saṃkhyayā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kalpo</LEM> \msCb; kalpa \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>manvanta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; 
                                                        nvanta° \msMacorr, maṃnvanta° \msMpcorr</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°daśa</LEM>     \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; °daśaṃ \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>saṃkhyayā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;      śaṃkṣayā \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>The accepted reading Łkalpo$ in Łpāda$ a is probably not original.</NOTE>
        <TR>One \ae on (Łkalpa$) is fourteen Łmanvantara$s in total.</TR>

%lacuna_end: msNb

<TEXT> daśa kalpasahasrāṇi brahmāhaḥ parikalpitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°āhaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; °āha \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>parikalpitam</LEM> \msCa\msNc; karikalpitam \msCb, parikalpitaḥ \msCc\msNb\msM\msPaperA\Ed,
                                                                         parikīrtitāḥ \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>\msM\ has a separator sign (|o|) at the end of Łpāda$ b, as if a section ended here.</NOTE>
        <TR>Brahmā's day (Łbrahmāhar$) is made up of ten thousand \ae ons (Łkalpa$).</TR>

%index_voc: brahmāhar (archaic?)

<TEXT> rātrir{ }etāvatī proktā munibhis{ }tattvadarśibhiḥ||</TEXT> 1:24
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°darśibhiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °darśibhi \msM</APP>
        <TR>[Brahmā's] night is of the same duration according to the wise who know the truth.</TR>


<TEXT> rātryāgame pralīyante jagat{ }sarvaṃ carācaram|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°game</LEM>      \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed;         °gama \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>pralīyante</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; pralīyate \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sarvaṃ ca°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;     sarvaś{ }ca° \msM</APP>
        <TR>When [Brahmā's] night falls, the whole moving and unmoving universe dissolves.</TR>

%index_grammar: plural verb for singular metri causa

<TEXT> ahāgame tathaiveha utpadyante carācaram||</TEXT> 1:25
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ahāgame</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; ahāga\lac\ × \msNb, 
                                        aharāgame \msM\ \unmetr, ahāgama \msPaperA, ahnāgame \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°padyante</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °padyaṃti \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>The plural form Łpralīyante$ in Łpāda$ a is metri causa for Łpralīyate$,
                perhaps also influencing Łutpadyante$ (for Łutpadyate$) in Łpāda$ d,
                which in turn is used here to avoid an iambic pattern
                (- - \shortsyllable\ - \shortsyllable\ - \shortsyllable\ -).
              Note a general lack of a sense of grammatical number (see p.~\pageref{number}).</NOTE>
        <TR>And when [his] daylight arrives, similarly, the moving and unmoving [universe] 
                is born here.</TR>

%index_grammar: plural verb for singular

<TEXT> parārdhaparakalpāni atītāni dvijottama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°rdha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; °rdhaṃ \msNb, °dha° \msPaperA</APP>
        <NOTE>On the definition of the numbers Łpara$ and Łparārdha$, see verses 1.31--35.</NOTE>
        <TR>One Łpara$ times Łparārdha$ [number of, i.e. 
                two hundred quadrillion times a hundred quadrillion] \ae ons (Łkalpa$)
                have passed [thus far], O great Brahmin.</TR>
% kalpāṇi \msNa

<TEXT> anāgataṃ tathaivāhur{ }bhṛgurādimaharṣayaḥ||</TEXT> 1:26
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°vāhur{ }bhṛ°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; 
                                                                °vāhu bhṛ° \msCc\msNb\msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°maharṣayaḥ</LEM>    \mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                                °mahayaḥ \msNaacorr, °marhaṣayaḥ \msNc, 
                                                                °maharṣibhiḥ \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the peculiar compound Łbhṛgu-r-ādi-maharṣayaḥ$, for
                                Łbhṛgvādimaharṣayaḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Bhṛgu and the other sages say that the future is the same [time span].</TR>

%index_grammar: sandhi bhṛgu-r-ādi-maharṣayaḥ

<PAGEBREAK/>
<TEXT> yathārkagrahatārendu bhramato dṛśyate tv{ }iha|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°ārka°</LEM>   \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msMpcorr\msPaperA\Ed; °ārkā° \msMacorr\oo
                 <LEM>°tārendu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;          °tāraindu \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>bhramato</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed;                bhumano \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>dṛśyate tv{ }iha</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                               dṛśyandiha \msCb, dṛsyate tv{ }ihaḥ \msCc,
                                                               dṛśyate tv{ }ihaḥ \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>Łbhramato$ in Łpāda$ b seems to stand for the neuter participle Łbhramat$.
                Alternatively, Łbhramato$ might mean `erroneously' (Łbhrama-tas$, abl.), but this would
                make the verse difficult to interpret.</NOTE>
        <TR>Just as the sun, the planets, the stars and the moon are perceived in
                this world as circling around,</TR>

%index_grammar: bhramato for bhramat (case confusion)

<TEXT> kālacakraṃ bhramitvaiva viśramaṃ na ca vidmahe||</TEXT> 1:27
        <APP>\vc <LEM>bhramitvaiva</LEM> \corr; bhramatvaiva \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed, 
                                                bhramatveva  \msCb\msNb\msM, bhramatveha \msCc,
                                                bhramatyaiva \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°śramaṃ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;
                                               °śramo \msNaacorr, °śrāman \msNb, °śrāmo \msM\oo
                 <LEM>vidmahe</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; vigrahe \msCb, vidyate \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>I have corrected Łbhramatvaiva$ to the standard form Łbhramitvaiva$, although the former
              might conceal a finite verb (Łbhramāmaḥ$?).</NOTE>
        <TR>we, wandering around riding the wheel of time (Łkālacakra$), can never have a rest.</TR>

<TEXT> kālaḥ sṛjati bhūtāni kālaḥ saṃharate punaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kālaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA; kāla \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\similar\ \UMS\ 12.34cd:$
                        kālaḥ pacati bhūtāni kālaḥ saṃharate prajāḥ</PARAL>
        <TR>Time creates living beings and time destroys them again.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 406.jpg f.202v
<TEXT> kālasya vaśagāḥ sarve na kālavaśakṛt{ }kvacit||</TEXT> 1:28
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kālasya</LEM>     \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msMpcorr\msPaperA\Ed; kālaḥsya \msMacorr\oo
                 <LEM>vaśagāḥ</LEM>     \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA;         vaśagā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kālavaśakṛ°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;          kālo vaśakṛ° \msM</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo \similar\ Ł\KURMP\ 1.11.32:$
                kālaḥ sṛjati bhūtāni kālaḥ saṃharate prajāḥ |
                sarve kālasya vaśagā na kālaḥ kasyacid{ }vaśe ||</PARAL>
        <TR>Everything is under the control of time. There is nothing that can bring time under control.</TR>


<TEXT> caturdaśa parārdhāni devarājā dvijottama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>devarājā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA;     devarāja \msM\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°ttama</LEM>   \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °ttamaḥ \msM</APP>
        <TR>Fourteen Łparārdha$ [fourteen hundred quadrillion] god kings, O Brahmin,</TR>
        % retain \Ed?
        % rddhāṇi \msNa

<TEXT> kālena samatītāni kālo hi duratikramaḥ||</TEXT> 1:29
        <PARAL>\vd Ł= \MBH\ 12.220.41d = \GARPUR\ 1.108.7d$</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Note that Łsamatītāni$ (neuter) most probably picks up Łdevarājāḥ$
                (masculine) in this verse, or rather Łdevarājā$ stands for
                Łdevarājānāṃ$ and Łsamatītāni$ picks up °Łparā\-rdhāni$. It is not clear to me
                what Łdevarāja$ (`god king') means exactly (Indra?).</NOTE>
        <TR>have passed with time, for time is difficult to overcome.</TR>

%index_grammar: gender

<TEXT> eṣa kālo mahāyogī brahmā viṣṇuḥ paraḥ śivaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kālo</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa;      kāla \msCc\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>brahmā viṣṇuḥ paraḥ</LEM> \msCb; brahmaviṣṇuparaḥ \msCa\msNc\msM\msPaperA,
                                                       brahmā viṣṇu paraḥ \msCc\msNa\msNb,
                                                       brahmaviṣṇupara \Ed\ \unmetr</APP>
        <TR>Time is [manifest] as a great yogin, as Brahmā, Viṣṇu and supreme Śiva,</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 184.jpg, f. 268v
<TEXT> anādinidhano dhātā sa mahātmā namaskuru||</TEXT> 1:30
        <TR>is beginningless and endless, is the Creator and the great soul. Pay homage [to Time].</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 413.jpg lower, f. 2r


<SUBCHAPTER>parārdhādi</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>ŁParārdha$ etc.: numbers</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> śrutaṃ vai kālacakraṃ tu mukhapadmaviniḥsṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śrutaṃ vai</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; śruto vaḥ \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°cakraṃ tu</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °cakrasya \msCc, °cakrat{ }tu \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>viniḥsṛtam</LEM> \corr; vinisṛtam \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed\ \unmetr</APP>
        <NOTE>I have corrected the unmetrical Łvinisṛtam$ in Łpāda$ b to Łviniḥsṛtam$.
              The reading of all manuscripts consulted, Łvinisṛtam$, 
              may be considered metrical if we interpret it, loosely, as Łvinisritam$.
              Read Łtvanmukhapadma$° (`your lotus mouth') over the Łpāda$-boundary?
              See, e.g., \SIVP\ 2.3.27.6ab:
                        Łtaj jñātvā nikhilaṃ devi śrutvā tvanmukhapaṃkajāt$.</NOTE>
        <TR>I have now heard about the `wheel of time' (Łkālacakra$) from [your] lotus mouth.</TR>

<TEXT> parārdhaṃ ca paraṃ caiva śrotuṃ vaḥ pratidīpitam||</TEXT> 1:31
        <APP>\vc <LEM>parārdhaṃ ca</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; 
                                                        <UNCL>pa</UNCL>rārddhaṃ ca \msCa,
                                                        parādhañ{ }ca \msMacorr, 
                                                        parārdhaṃñ{ }ce \msMpcorr\oo
                 <LEM>paraṃ caiva</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;                parāñ{ }caiva \msM\msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vaḥ</LEM>         \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msMacorr\msPaperA; naḥ \msMpcorr, yaḥ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°dīpitam</LEM>    \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;      °dīyatāṃ \msM</APP>
        <TR>[I wish] to hear about [the terms] Łparārdha$ and Łpara$ [mentioned above],
             as elaborated by you.</TR>
        <NOTE>        <sep/>
                  ŁPāda$ d is suspect and my translation tentative.
                  \msM's reading in Łpāda$ d (Łśrotuṃ naḥ pratidīyatāṃ$) might make sense 
                  (`give it back/repeat it for us to hear'), but it sounds forced,
                  as if the scribe tried to come up with a reading that he understood
                  better than Łśrotuṃ vaḥ pratidīpitam$, the reading of the majority of the witnesses,
                  which is in fact not easy to interpret.  One would expect a phrase meaning
                  `please tell me about these.' Finally, I have decided to take Łvaḥ$ as 
                  instrumental (`by you'). Still, a verb is missing.</NOTE>
                  I have finally chosen to interpret Łvaḥ$
                  as an ablative, separated Łprati$ from Łdīpita$° (as if Łvaḥ prati$ formed a unit),
                  and emended °Łdīpitam$ to °Łdīpitaḥ$.
% pratipādita?

%index_metre: ṛ -> ri (actually corrected)
%index_grammar: vaḥ (vaḥ prati?) as ablative (not in Oberlies) or rather instrumental 
%index_grammar: missing verb


<PAGEBREAK/>
%folioinfo \msCa\ 384.jpg
<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>anarthayajña uvāca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; \om\ \msNaacorr</APP>
        <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR>

%folioinfo \msNc\ 213.jpg upper, f. 210v
<TEXT> ekaṃ daśaṃ śataṃ caiva sahasram{ }ayutaṃ tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sahasra°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; sāhasra° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°yutaṃ</LEM>   \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed;  °tan \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>See a similar teaching of numbers in \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 3.2.91ff.</NOTE>
        <TR>One, ten, a hundred, a thousand, ten thousand (Łayuta$),</TR>

<TEXT> prayutaṃ niyutaṃ koṭim{ }arbudaṃ vṛndam{ }eva ca||</TEXT> 1:32
        <APP>\vc <LEM>pra°</LEM>        \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed;      pa° \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>koṭim{ }a°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\msPaperA\Ed;  koṭir{ }a° \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°rbudaṃ</LEM>     \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\msPaperA\Ed; °budaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>a hundred thousand (Łprayuta$), a million (Łniyuta$), ten million (Łkoṭi$),
             a hundred million (Łarbuda$), one billion (Łvṛnda$, 10<tothepowerof>9</tothepowerof>),</TR>
% I am just following the logic of 10x the previous one

<TEXT> kharvaṃ caiva nikharvaṃ ca śaṅku padmaṃ tathaiva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>nikharvaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;       nikharvaṃ tu \msNb, nisarvañ{ }ca \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śaṅku</LEM>        \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA; śaṃkha \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>padmaṃ</LEM>       \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;  padma \msM</APP>
                  <TR>ten billion (Łkharva$), a hundred billion (Łnikharva$), one trillion 
                         (Łśaṅku$, 10<tothepowerof>12</tothepowerof>), ten trillion (Łpadma$),</TR>
        <LACUNA>\vab ŁAfter these two pādas, \msPaperA\ inserts this:$
                                vṛndañ{ }caiva mahāvṛnda dviparo nantan{ }eva ca</LACUNA>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł = \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 3.2.101 $ </PARAL>
        <NOTE>Note that  \msPaperA\ inserts a line here. See apparatus.</NOTE>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 196.jpg upper f.2v
%lacuna_start: Ed
<TEXT> samudro madhyam{ }antaṃ ca parārdhaṃ ca paraṃ tathā||</TEXT> 1:33
        <APP>\vc <LEM>samudro</LEM>            \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; samudra° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>madhyam{ }antaṃ ca</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNaacorr\msM\msPaperA;         madhyamāntaṃ ca \msNapcorr, 
                                                                                          madhya<UNCL>mantañ{ }ca</UNCL> \msNb,
                                                                                          madhyam{ }antaś{ }ca \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>parārdhaṃ ca paraṃ tathā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA;  parārddhaparadveguṇām \msM</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vcd Ł\Ed\ omits 34cd--35 and then inserts this:$
                                vṛndañ{ }caiva mahāvṛnda dviparānantam{ }eva ca</LACUNA>

        % \vcd <LEM>(samudroŁ...$ tathā)</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; \om\ \Ed

        <NOTE>For Łanta$ meaning Łananta$, see 1.57. \msM's reading in Łpāda$ d
                        may be a result of an eyeskip to 1.34c.</NOTE>
        <TR>a hundred trillion (Łsamudra$), one quadrillion (Łmadhya$, 10<tothepowerof>15</tothepowerof>),
                           ten quadrillion (Ł[an]anta$), a hundred quadrillion (Łparārdha$), 
                           and two hundred quadrillion (Łpara$).</TR>
% \msM again is creative
%index_voc: ananta, anta as a number
<TEXT> sarve daśaguṇā jñeyāḥ parārdhaṃ yāvad{ }eva hi|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>sarve</LEM>     \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; sarvaṃ \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>parārdhaṃ</LEM> \msNc;                                parā<UNCL>rdha</UNCL> \msCa,
                                                                            parārdha \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msM\msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>yāvad{ }eva</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; daśadava \msPaperA</APP>
        <TR>Each should be known as powers of ten up to Łparārdha$.</TR>
                % jñeyāf \msCa
        %\vo <LEM>(sarveŁ...$ vidhīyate)</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; \om\ \Ed

<TEXT> parārdhadviguṇenaiva parasaṃkhyā vidhīyate||</TEXT> 1:34
        <APP>\vc <LEM>parārdha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\msPaperA;   parārdhaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°saṃkhyā</LEM>  \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; °sakhyā \msM</APP>
        <TR>The number corresponding to Łpara$ is double that of Łparārdha$.</TR>


%folioinfo \msPaperA\ 332.jpg lower, f. 205r 
%lacuna_end: Ed
<TEXT> parāt{ }parataraṃ nāsti iti me niścitā matiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM!>parāt{ }parataraṃ nāsti iti me niścitā matiḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNcpcorr\msPaperA\Ed;
                                parāt{ }parataraṃ nāsti iti me niścitā mati \msNa\msNcacorr,
                                parāparataran{ }nāsti iti me niścitā mati \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that \Ed\ inserts the line here that \msPaperA\ inserted above. See apparatus.</NOTE>
        <TR>There is no higher number than Łpara$. This is my firm conviction,</TR>

<TEXT> purāṇavedapaṭhitā mayākhyātā dvijottama||</TEXT> 1:35
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°veda°</LEM> \msCa\Ed; °vede \msCb\msCc\msNb\msNc\msPaperA,
                                          °vedā \msNa, °vedaiḥ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°khyātā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa; °khyātaṃ \msCc\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °tama \msM</APP>
        <TR>which is based on my readings of the Purāṇas and the Vedas 
                and [which I have now] taught [to you], O great Brahmin.</TR>

% vede would be bha-vipulā
%index_metre: na-vipulā

<PAGEBREAK/>

<SUBCHAPTER>brahmāṇḍam</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Brahmā's Egg: the Universe</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> brahmāṇḍaṃ kati vijñeyaṃ pramāṇaṃ jñāpitaṃ kvacit|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>brahmāṇḍaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; brahmāṇḍa \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>pramāṇaṃ jñāpitaṃ kvacit</LEM> \conj; pramāṇaṃ cāpitaṃ kvacit \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msPaperA\Ed,
                                                pramāñ{ }cāpitat kvacit \msNc, pramāṇañ{ }cāpitāṃ kati \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>The use of the singular next to numerals is one of the hallmarks of the \VSS\ 
                (see p.~\pageref{singularwithnumerals}). This means that Łpāda$ a may well refer to multiple Łbrahmāṇḍa$s.
                Nevertheless, in the light of \VSS\ 2.2d (Łpramāṇaṃ tasya vā kati$), I suspect that 
                the first question here could be rendered in slightly more standard Sanskrit as
                Łbrahmāṇḍasya pramāṇaṃ kati yojanāni vijñeyaṃ$.
                Łcāpitaṃ kvacit$ in Łpāda$ b in the witnesses is enigmatic.
                One may conjecture Łprāpitaṃ$ (perhaps: `is it available somewhere?'), 
                The intended form may have been Łjñātaṃ kenacit$ (`is it known by anyone?'),
                or Łjñāpitaṃ$ (`is it disclosed somewhere?'). I have chosen the latter,
                to which 1.37 below could be a reply. Of course, Łcāpitaṃ$ could be analysed as
                Łcāpi taṃ$ (possibly for Łcāpi tat$), but that would help little, unless we
                imagine that the question is `and where is it?' (Łcāpi tat kva$).

                </NOTE>
        <TR>What is the extent of Brahmā's Egg (Łbrahmāṇḍa$) [i.e. the universe]? Is it disclosed anywhere?</TR>
%index_check: prāpita 
%index_grammar: singular with numeral interrogative, Newar

<TEXT> kati cāṅguli{-}m{-}ūrdhveṣu sūryas{ }tapati vai mahīm||</TEXT> 1:36
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°rdhveṣu</LEM> \eme; °rdheṣu \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sūryas{ }ta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; ryo \msMacorr, śūryo \msMpcorr\oo
