                 <LEM>mahīm</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msM\msPaperA; mahī<UNCL>m </UNCL> \msCa, mahī \msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>My emendation of Łcāṅguli-mūrdheṣu$ to Łcāṅguli{-}m{-}ūrdhveṣu$ (with a hiatus-filler) 
              is based on Łūrdhvatas$ in 1.60d, which is part of the reply to the question posed in this line.
              In turn, Łaṅguli$ here triggered a conjecture in 1.60c.</NOTE>
        <TR>From how many finger's breadths high does the sun heat the earth?</TR>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.583
<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Anarthayajña spoke: </TR>

<TEXT> brahmāṇḍānāṃ prasaṃkhyātuṃ mayā śakyaṃ kathaṃ dvija|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>brahmā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; brahma° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>prasaṃkhyātuṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA; prasaṃsā tu \msNb, ca saṃkhyātuṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śakyaṃ ka°</LEM> \msNa\msNb\msPaperApcorr\Ed; śakyā ka° \mssCaCbCc\msNc, sakyāṅ{ }ka° \msM, 
                                                                        hyakyaṃ ka° \msPaperAacorr</APP>
        <NOTE>One would expect Łbrahmāṇḍāni$ in Łpāda$ a instead of Łbrahmāṇḍānāṃ$,
                but we should probably understand Łbrahmāṇḍānāṃ viśeṣān prasaṃkhyātuṃ...$, or rather,
                Łbrahmāṇḍasya viśeṣān prasaṃkhyātuṃ$.
                The structure noun in genitive + verb meaning `to tell' occurs also, e.g., in 4.69a.</NOTE>
        <TR>How could I enumerate [all the details of] Brahmā's Egg, O twice-born?</TR>
        % praśaṃsā is an interesting variant and it explains śakyā

%index_grammar: gen + telling

<TEXT> devās{ }te 'pi na jānanti mānuṣāṇāṃ ca kā kathā||</TEXT> 1:37
        <APP>\vc <LEM>devās{ }te</LEM>   \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; devatāpi \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>mānuṣāṇāṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; mānuṣārnañ{ }ca \msMacorr,
                                                                                       mānuṣānāñ{ }ca \msMpcorr</APP>
        <TR>Even the gods do not know, not to mention humans.</TR>


<TEXT> paryāyeṇa tu vakṣyāmi yathāśakyaṃ dvijottama|</TEXT>
        <TR>I shall teach [you], as far as I can, in due order and truthfully, that, O great Brahmin,</TR>
        % paryāyena \msNb\msM

<TEXT> brahmaṇā yat{ }purākhyāto mātariśvā yathā tathā||</TEXT> 1:38
        <APP>\vc <LEM>yat{ }purākhyāto</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yat{ }purākhyātaṃ \msM, 
                                                                        yat{ }prayāt{ }parāyākhyāto \msPaperA,
                                                                        yat{ }mamākhyāto \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Łcf. \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 3.4.58cd:$ 
                        brahmā dadau śāstram{ }idaṃ purāṇaṃ mātariśvane</PARAL>
        <NOTE>The claim that Brahmā taught Mātariśvan is confirmed in 1.62cd, and
                        also, e.g., in \BrahmandaPur\ 3.4.58cd (see the apparatus).</NOTE>
        <TR>which Mātariśvan was taught by Brahmā in the past.</TR>

<TEXT> śivāṇḍābhyantareṇaiva sarveṣām{ }iva bhūbhṛtām|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śivāṇḍā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; śivāṇḍa° \msMacorr, śivāṇḍe° \msMpcorr</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>sarveṣām{ }iva bhūbhṛtām</LEM> \conj; sarveṣām{ }iva bhūritāḥ \msCa\msCb\msNc,
                                                             sarveṣām{ }eva bhūritāḥ \msCc,
                                                             sarveṣām{ }iva bhūritā \msNa, sarveṣām{ }eva bhūriṇām \msNb,
                                                             sa<UNCL>rṣapā</UNCL> iva bhāvitā \msM,
                                                             sarveṣām{ }eva bhūrināḥ \msPaperA,
                                                             sarveṣām{ }eva bhūr{ }imāṃ \Ed</APP>

<TEXT> daśa nāma diśāṣṭānāṃ brahmāṇḍe kīrtitaṃ śṛṇu||</TEXT> 1:39
        <APP>\vc <LEM>diśā°</LEM>         \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed;  śivā° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>brahmāṇḍe</LEM>     \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; brahmaṇḍā \msM\oo
                 <LEM>kīrtitaṃ śṛṇu</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; ya ca kīrtitam \msCb, 
                                                                                        kīrttitā śṛṇu \msM</APP>
                   <NOTE>My conjecture in Łpāda$ b (Łbhūbhṛtām$) is based on the fact that the 
                   readings transmitted in the MSS seem unintelligible, and, more importantly, that
                   these names are said, in the subsequent verses, to belong to Łnāyaka$s (`chiefs, lords'),
                   a possible synonym of Łbhūbhṛt$ (`a king'). Also, it is a minute intervention.

                   In Łpāda$ c, understand Łdiśāṣṭānāṃ$ as Łdiśām aṣṭānāṃ$ or Łdigaṣṭakānāṃ$:
                   again, the use of the singular in the proximity of numbers is normal in the \VSS\ (Łdaśa nāma$).</NOTE>
          <TR>The ten names of all the [cosmic] rulers in each of the eight directions 
                    in Brahmā's Egg, [which is] inside Śiva's Egg (Łśivāṇḍa$), are being taught now, listen.</TR>

%index_grammar: singular after numbers, Newari inanimate


<PAGEBREAK/>
<SUBCHAPTER>bhūbhṛtāṃ nāmāni</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Names of the cosmic rulers</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>pūrvataḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>East</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> sahāsahaḥ sahaḥ sahyo visahaḥ saṃhato 'sabhā|</TEXT>
         <APP>\va <LEM>sahāsahaḥ</LEM>   \msNc;                     sāhāsaha \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\msPaperA\Ed\oo
                  <LEM>sahaḥ sahyo</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; sahaḥ sajñā \msCb, 
                                                                    saho sahyaḥ \msM, 
                                                                    sahaḥ sajño \msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>visahaḥ</LEM>     \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; visaha \msCc\msM, viṃsahaḥ \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>'sabhā</LEM>      \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;    sabhāḥ \msCb, sahā \msM, satā \msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <TR>[1] Sahā, [2] Asaha, [3] Saha, [4] Sahya, [5] Visaha, [6] Saṃhata, [7] Asabhā,</TR>
        <NOTE>Note that many of the names here and in the following verses are,
                in the absence of any close parallel passage, rather insecure.
                In order to avoid the repetition of the name Saha, I take the first name here
                as feminine; Asabhā seems also to be a feminine ruler's name. Later on there
                seem to come more feminine names (Tejā, Yamunā, Naganā, etc.), therefore it 
                might be correct to interpret some of the names as names of queens.
                What is clear here is that the list evokes the name Sahasrākṣa,
                one of the appellations of Indra, the guardian of the eastern direction.</NOTE>

<TEXT> prasaho 'prasahaḥ sānuḥ pūrvato daśa nāyakāḥ||</TEXT> 1:40
        <APP>\vc <LEM>prasaho</LEM>  \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA;  prasaheḥ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>prasahaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA;  prasa<UNCL>vaḥ</UNCL> \msCc, saprahaḥ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>sānuḥ</LEM>    \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msPaperA;                  sānu \msNc\msM\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>pūrvato</LEM>  \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA;  parvato \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[8] Prasaha, [9] Aprasaha, [10] Sānu: [these are] the ten Leaders in the East.</TR>
% sānuf \msCa % \msCb and \msCc have an avagraha before saprahaḥ/prasavaḥ

%index_grammar: numeral with plural! Newari

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>āgneye</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>South-East</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> prabhāso bhāsano bhānuḥ pradyoto dyutimo dyutiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>bhāsano</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM;                bhāsa\lac\ × \msCc, 
                                                                                  bhāṃsato \msPaperA,
                                                                                  bhāsato \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>bhānuḥ</LEM>  \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; bhānu \msCb\msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dyutimo</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM;                     dyutino \msNc\msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <TR>[1] Prabhāsa, [2] Bhāsana, [3] Bhānu, [4] Pradyota, [5] Dyutima, [6] Dyuti,</TR>

%index_stemma: \msNc \msPaperA \Ed?

<TEXT> dīptatejāś{ }ca tejāś{ }ca tejā tejavaho daśa|</TEXT>
         <APP>\vc <LEM!>dīptatejāś{ }ca tejāś{ }ca</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; dīptatejāś{ }ca tejaś{ }ca \msCb, 
                                                                                             dīptatejas tejaś{ }ca \msM\ \unmetr,
                                                                                             dīptatejaś{ }ca tejāś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tejā tejavaho</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;      tejatejayaha \msM</APP>
        <TR>[7] Dīptatejas, [8] Tejas, [9] Tejā, [10] Tejavaha: [these are] the ten</TR>

%index_check: tejā

%folioinfo \msNb\ 43.jpg upper (going backwards)
<TEXT> āgneye tv{ }etad{ }ākhyātaṃ yāmye śṛṇv{ }atha bho dvija||</TEXT> 1:41
        <APP>\ve <LEM>āgneye</LEM>         \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed;                      āgneya \msNc\msPaperA, 
                                                                                         āgnerye \msM\oo
                 <LEM>tv{ }etad{ }ā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; tv{ }ecam{ }ā \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>śṛṇv{ }atha</LEM>    \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; śṛṇutha \msM\oo
                 <LEM>dvija</LEM>          \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed;  dvijaḥ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>[rulers] in the direction of Agni [SE]. Now listen to [the names for]
                 Yama's region, O twice-born.</TR>
        <NOTE>Here, in the region of Agni, the names evidently evoke the image of flames.</NOTE>
% \msCb\ yāmya? 



<SUBSUBCHAPTER>yāmye</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>South</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> yamo 'tha yamunā yāmaḥ saṃyamo yamuno 'yamaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>yamo</LEM>    \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; yamā \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>saṃyamo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;     saṃyama \msM, 
                                                                             saṃyamā \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>yamuno</LEM>  \msCa\msCb\msNb\msPaperA;                yamano \msCc\msNc, 
                                                                             yumunā \msNa,
                                                                             yamato \msM, yamunā° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>yamaḥ</LEM>   \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;     yana \msM, 
                                                                             yāmaḥ \msPaperA\ \unmetr</APP>
        <TR>[1] Yama, [2] Yamunā, [3] Yāma, [4] Saṃyama, [5] Yamuna, [6] Ayama,</TR>

<TEXT> saṃyano yamanoyāno yaniyugmā yanoyanaḥ||</TEXT> 1:42
         <APP>\vc <LEM!>saṃyano yamanoyāno</LEM> \msNa; saṃyamo yamanoyāno \msCa\msCc\Ed, 
                                                        saṃyamo yamunoyāno \msCb\msNb,
                                                        saṃyamā yamano yāmo \msNc, 
                                                        yamiyugmā yano yānaḥ \msM,
                                                        saṃyamā yamano yāno \msPaperA</APP>
         <APP>\vd <LEM!>yaniyugmā yanoyanaḥ</LEM> \msNb; yaniyugmā nayo yanaḥ \msCa\msCc\msNa,
                                                         yaniyugmā nayo nayaḥ \msCb\msPaperA, 
                                                         yaniyugmā nayo yamaḥ \msNc,
                                                         daśamā yāmyam{ }āśṛtā \msM,
                                                         yaniyugmā nayonaya \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[7] Saṃyana, [8] Yamanoyāna, [9] Yaniyugmā, [10] Yanoyana.</TR>
        <NOTE>I have chosen the variant Łsaṃyano$ in Łpāda$ c only to avoid the repetition of
                        the name Łsaṃyama$, and the variant Łyanoyanaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d because I suspect that
                        most of the names here should begin with Łya$, except for Łayamaḥ$
                        in Łpāda$ b, which is little more than a guess in order to avoid the repetition of Łyamaḥ$.
                        All the name forms in this verse are to be taken as tentative. The only 
                        guiding light is the presence of Łya$, reinforcing a connection with Yama.</NOTE>
        % \va yāneṃ? \msCa 




<PAGEBREAK/>

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>nairṛte</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
% CHECK devanāgarī rṛ here is wrong in the xelatex pdf in AdishilaDev
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>South-West</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> nagajo naganā nando nagaro naga nandanaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>naganā nando</LEM>        \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                        nagajā nando \msCb,            
                                                        naganāgendra \msM,
                                                        nagano nado \msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>nagaro naganandanaḥ</LEM> \msNb\msMacorr\msPaperA; nagaroraganandanaḥ \msCa\msNc,
                                                     nagaro<UNCL>nagananda</UNCL>naḥ \msCb,
                                                     naga<UNCL>ro</UNCL>\lac ×× nandanaḥ \msCc,
                                                     nagarogaranandanaḥ \msNa, 
                                                     nagaro nananandanaḥ \msMpcorr, 
                                                     nagaronnaganandanaḥ \Ed</APP>
         <TR>[1] Nagaja, [2] Naganā, [3] Nanda, [4] Nagara, [5] Naga, [6] Nandana,</TR>
         <NOTE>Łnaga$ in Łpāda$ b is a \stemform\ noun metri causa.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

%folioinfo \msCc\ 185.jpg f.269r
<TEXT> nagarbho gahano guhyo gūḍhajo daśa tatparaḥ||</TEXT> 1:43
        <APP>\vc <LEM>nagarbho</LEM>     \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;      nṛgabho \msNb, nagarbha \msM\oo 
                 <LEM>gahano guhyo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA;    guhano guhya \msM, gahano guhye \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>gūḍhajo</LEM>      \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; guḍajo \msM\oo
                 <LEM>tatparaḥ</LEM>     \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; tatparam \msM</APP>
        <TR>[7] Nagarbha, [8] Gahana, [9] Guhya, [10] Gūḍhaja: [these are] the ten associated with 
                        [the South-West].</TR>
        <NOTE>Łtatparaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d is be another example of a singular form next to a number (see 1.39c above).
                  Note that the reconstruction of these names is tentative. What is clear here is that the
                  initials should be Łna$ and Łga$, probably suggesting a connection with Łnirṛti$, Łnaraka$s, and Łnāga$s.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: singular after numbers, but animate Newar


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>vāruṇe</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>West</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> vāruṇena pravakṣyāmi śṛṇu vipra nibodha me|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vāruṇena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA; vāruṇe ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śṛṇu</LEM>      \msNb\msM;                                    śṛṅge \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc,
                                    śṛ<UNCL>ṅge</UNCL> \msCc, mṛddhe <UNCL>pāpta</UNCL> \cancelled\ \msPaperA, mṛddhe \Ed</APP>
         <TR>I shall teach you [the names] in Varuṇa's region [in the west].
                           Listen, O Brahmin, learn from me.</TR>

<TEXT> babhraḥ setur{ }bhavodbhadraḥ prabhavodbhavabhājanaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>babhraḥ setur{ }bha°</LEM> \corr; babhraṃ setur{ }bha° \msCa\msCb,
                                             babhraṃ setu bha° \msCc, babhraḥ setu bha° \msNa, 
                                             babhraṃ sotur{ }bha° \msNb, babhra setur{ }bha° \msNc,
                                             babhrū setu bha° \msM, babhrūn{ }setur{ }bha° \msPaperA, 
                                             babhrūn{ }satur{ }bha° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>prabhavodbhava°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;   prabhavobhava° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°bhājanaḥ</LEM>       \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA; °bhājana \Ed</APP>
         <TR>[1] Babhra, [2] Setu, [3] Bhava, [4] Udbhadra, [5] Prabhava, [6] Udbhava, [7] Bhājana,</TR>
        % °bhadraf \msCa

<TEXT> bharaṇo bhuvano bhartā daśaite varuṇālayāḥ||</TEXT> 1:44
        <APP>\ve <LEM>bharaṇo</LEM> \msCb\msNc; bharaṇa \msCa\msNa, bharaṇāṃ \msCc\msPaperA\Ed,
                                                bharaṇā \msNb, bharaṇaḥ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>daśaite</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msPaperA\Ed;    daśete \msNc, daśaitā \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°layāḥ</LEM>  \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; °layā \msM\Ed</APP>
         <TR>[8] Bharaṇa, [9] Bhuvana, and [10] Bhartṛ:
                           these ten dwell in Varuṇa's region [in the west].</TR>
         <NOTE>Varuṇa upholds (Łbibharti/bharati$) the sky and the earth. This could be the reason why 
                  these names include Łbharaṇa$ and Łbhartṛ$.</NOTE>



<SUBSUBCHAPTER>vāyavye</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>North-West</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> nṛgarbho 'suragarbhaś{ }ca devagarbho mahīdharaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>nṛgarbho</LEM>      \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; nṛgabhā \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°garbhaś{ }ca</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\msPaperA;               °garbhāś{ }ca \msCc\msNa\msM\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>devagarbho</LEM>    \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; devagarbha \msM</APP>
        <TR>[1] Nṛgarbha, [2] Asuragarbha, [3] Devagarbha, [4] Mahīdhara,</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 414.jpg upper, f. 2v
<TEXT> vṛṣabho vṛṣagarbhaś{ }ca vṛṣāṅko vṛṣabhadhvajaḥ||</TEXT> 1:45
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°garbhaś{ }ca</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °garbhāś{ }ca \msNa, °garbhoś{ }ca \msM, 
                                                                   °śabhaś{ }ca \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vṛṣāṅko</LEM>  \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;     vṛṣāṃgo \msM\oo
                 <LEM>vṛṣabha°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; vṛṣa\lk ° \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>The connection between Łvṛṣa$ and the north-west or Vāyu is not evident to me. 
                In a tantric context, a western position is more standard for Łvṛṣa$, see e.g.
                <citep>Pancavaranastava</citep><pnum>40</pnum>.</NOTE>
        <TR>[5] Vṛṣabha, [6] Vṛṣagarbha, [7] Vṛṣāṅka, [8] Vṛṣabhadhvaja,</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 407.jpg f.203r
<TEXT> jñātavyaś{ }ca tathā samyag vṛṣajo vṛṣanandanaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>jñātavyaś{ }ca tathā samyag</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; 
                                                        vṛṣañjavṛṣanandaś{ }ca \msM,
                                                        jñānavāñ{ }ca tathā samya \msPaperA,
                                                        jñānavāñ{ }ca tathā satya° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>vṛṣajo vṛṣanandanaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; vṛṣanandanaḥ \msNa,
                                                                                         daśanāyaka vāyave \msM</APP>
        <TR>[9] Vṛṣaja, and [10] Vṛṣanandana: these are to be known properly</TR>

<TEXT> nāyakā daśa vāyavye kīrtitā ye mayā dvija||</TEXT> 1:46
        <APP>\vcd <LEM!>nāyakā daśa vāyavye kīrtitā ye mayā dvija</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msPaperA\Ed;
                        nāyakā daśa vāyavye kīrtitā ye mayā dvijaḥ \msCc\msNb,
                        nāyakā daśa vāyavye kīrtitā ya mayā dvija \msNc,
                        kīrtito yaṃ mayā dvipra yathā tathyena suvrataḥ \msM</APP>
        <TR>as the ten leaders in Vāyu's region [in the north-west], as I taught them, O twice-born.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note how \msM\ deviates here again in a significant way.</NOTE>


%index_grammar: numeral with plural! Newari


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>uttare</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>North</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> sulabhaḥ sumanaḥ saumyaḥ suprajaḥ sutanuḥ śivaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>sulabhaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; surabhaḥ \msPaperA\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>sumanaḥ</LEM>  \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; sumanāḥ \msNc, sumano \msM, sumana \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>saumyaḥ</LEM>  \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; somya \msM</APP>
        <TR>[1] Sulabha, [2] Sumana, [3] Saumya, [4] Supraja, [5] Sutanu, [6] Śiva,</TR>
        <NOTE>I prefer the form Łsumanaḥ$ to the more standard Łsumanāḥ$ (\msNc) in Łpāda$ a
              because it suits the slightly irregular language of the \VSS\ (see pp.~\pageref{language})
              and because the solitary reading of \msNc\ may well only be an attempt to
              standardise. It is also not inconceivable that Łsumanaḥ$ stands compounded 
              with Łsaumyaḥ$.</NOTE>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 385.jpg 
<TEXT> sataḥ satya layaḥ śambhur{ }daśa nāyakam{ }uttare||</TEXT> 1:47
         <APP>\vc <LEM>sataḥ satya</LEM> \corr; sata satya \mssCaCbCc\msNc\msPaperA, satyasatya \msNa, suta satya \msNb,
                                    sutaḥ satya \msM, sata satyā° \Ed\oo
                  <LEM>layaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\msPaperA\Ed; layaṃ \msNc</APP>
         <APP>\vcd <LEM>śambhur{ }da°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msPaperA\Ed; śambhu da° \msCc\msNa\msNc,
                                                                         śam<UNCL>bhuṃ</UNCL> da° \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°nāyakam{ }u°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA; °nāyaka u° \Ed</APP>
         <NOTE>Note how Łdaśa nāyakam$ (neuter singular for masculine plural)
                        could again be an example for the use of the singular 
                        next to a number in Łpāda d$. It seems that here it is the northern region
                        that is associated with Śiva, rather than the north-east, the Łīśāna$ direction, 
                        which is occupied by Brahmā in the next verse. 
                        (In a tantric context, Brahmā is sometimes associated with the north-east, see, e.g.,
                        <citep>Pancavaranastava</citep><pnum>39</pnum>.)
                        I have left Łsatya$ in \stemform.</NOTE>
         <TR>[7] Sata, [8] Satya, [9] Laya, [10] Śambhu: [these are] the ten leaders in the north.</TR>

%index_grammar: singular after numbers, also metri causa
%index_grammar: neuter for masculine

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>īśāne</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>North-East</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
%folioinfo \msNc\ 213.jpg lower, f. 211r
<TEXT> indu bindu bhuvo vajra varado vara varṣaṇaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vajra</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; vrajaḥ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°varṣaṇaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM; °\lk <UNCL>rśaṇam</UNCL> \msNc,
                                                                °darppaṇaḥ \msPaperA, 
                                                                °daryya ca \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[1] Indu, [2] Bindu, [3] Bhuva, [4] Vajra, [5] Varada, [6] Vara, [7] Varṣaṇa,</TR>
        <NOTE>I consider Łindu, bindu$ and Łvajra$ \stemform\ nouns.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form

<TEXT> ilano valino brahmā daśeśāneṣu nāyakāḥ||</TEXT> 1:48
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>ilano valino brahmā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; ilino valino brahmaḥ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>daśe°</LEM>               \msCa\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;                  daśai° \msCb\msCc\msNb, diśai° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>nāyakāḥ</LEM>             \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; nāyakā \msM</APP>
         <TR>[8] Ilana, [9] Valina, [10] Brahmā: [these are] the ten rulers in the Īśāna
                                    direction [i.e. in the north-east].</TR>
         <NOTE>The north-east seems to be occupied by Brahmā, and by rulers whose names should
                                    somehow evoke Brahmā's name.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: numeral with plural! Newari

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>madhyame</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Center</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> aparo vimalo moho nirmalo mana mohanaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>aparo vimalo moho</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; aparaḥ vimalā mohā \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>nirmalo ma°</LEM> \eme; nimalo ma° \msCa, nirmalonma° \msCb\msNc\msPaperA,
                                              nirmalotma° \msCc\Ed, nimalorma° \msNa\msNb, nirmalonma° \msM</APP>
        <TR>[1] Apara, [2] Vimala, [3] Moha, [4] Nirmala, [5] Mana, [6] Mohana,</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 196.jpg lower f.3r
<TEXT> akṣayaś{ }cāvyayo viṣṇur{ }varado madhyame daśa||</TEXT> 1:49
        <APP>\vc <LEM>akṣayaś{ }cāvyayo</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; akṣayāś{ }cāvyayo \msCc,
                                akṣayaś{ }cāvyayaṃ \msM, akṣayañ{ }cāvyayo \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>viṣṇur{ }va°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; viṣṇu va° \msCc\msNa\msM, rviṣṇur{ }va \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>madhyame daśa</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\msPaperA; madhyamo daśa \msCc\msNa, 
                                        varavarṣaṇaḥ \msNb, madhyamo daśaḥ \msM, madhyame daśaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[7] Akṣaya, [8] Avyaya, [9] Viṣṇu, [10] Varada: [these are] the ten [leaders] in the centre.</TR>
         <NOTE>Note that the last three lists above have been associated 
                           with Śiva, Brahmā and Viṣṇu, respectively, and here, in a layer
                           of the text that can be labelled Vaiṣṇava (see pp.~\pageref{structure}), it is Viṣṇu that
                           seems to occupy a central position. Łmana mohanaḥ$ (or Łnirmalonmana$) in Łpāda$ b may
                           sound like one single name, but we are forced to separate these two words
                           (Łmana$ being in \stemform\ metri causa) to arrive at a list of ten names.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa





<SUBSUBCHAPTER>parivārāḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Subordinates</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

% daśa-m-īśānāṃ        
<TEXT> sarveṣāṃ daśa{-}m{-}īśānāṃ parivāraśataṃ śatam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>sarveṣāṃ</LEM>       \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\msPaperA\Ed;   sarveṣā \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>daśam{ }īśānāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA; daśarīśānāṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>parivāra°</LEM>      \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed;   pari° \msCb, parivāraṃ \msNa</APP>
        <TR>Each of the ten rulers has a retinue of a hundred subordinates.</TR>
        <NOTE>I take Łdaśa-m-īśānāṃ$ as a split compound (Łdaśeśānāṃ$).
              It is conceivable that each of the above ninety rulers has ten subordinates, 
              therefore each group of ten rulers has a hundred subordinates altogether,
              but the original idea may have been that each one of the above ninety 
              rulers has a hundred subordinates. Alternatively, this verse may only refer to 
              the central group of ten rulers mentioned in 1.49, and each one of them has
              a hundred subordinates.</NOTE>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.584
<TEXT> śatānāṃ pṛthag{ }ekaikaṃ sahasraiḥ parivāritam||</TEXT> 1:50
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sahasraiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;  sahasrai \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°vāritam</LEM>  \msCa\msCb\msCcpcorr\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; °vāritā \msCcacorr, 
                                                                                    °vāritaḥ \msM, °vāritāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Each one of [these] hundred is surrounded by a thousand subordinates.</TR>
                              % sahasraif \msCa

<PAGEBREAK/>
<TEXT> sahasreṣu ca ekaikam{ }ayutaiḥ parivāritam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>ekaikam{ }a°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;          ekaikaṃ ma° \msCc\msNa\msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb  <LEM>parivāritam</LEM>  \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; parivāritaḥ \msM, parivāritamāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Each one of the thousand is surrounded by ten thousand [subordinates],</TR>
                             %ayutaif \msCa

<TEXT> ayutaṃ prayutair{ }vṛndaiḥ prayutaṃ niyutair{ }vṛtam||</TEXT> 1:51
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ayutaṃ</LEM> \Ed; ayutaiḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA, ayutai \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>prayutair{ }vṛndaiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msPaperA\Ed; prayutai vṛndaiḥ \msNc, 
                                                                                  prayutair{ }bhṛtya \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>prayutaṃ niyutair{ }vṛtam</LEM> \corr; prayutair{ }niyutair{ }vṛtaḥ \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc,
                        prayuter{ }niyutair{ }vṛtaḥ \msCc, prayutai niyutai vṛtaḥ \msNb,
                        prayutaḥ niyutaiḥ vṛtaḥ \msM, prayute niyutair{ }vṛtaḥ \msPaperA, prayutaṃ niyutair{ }vṛtaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>the ten thousand is surrounded by a multitude of a hundred thousand,
                 the hundred thousand by a million,</TR>
        <NOTE>We are forced to follow \Ed's reading in Łpāda$ c in order to make sense of this passage.
              My correction in Łpāda$ d is motivated by the same. Note that Łvṛnda$ is not a number in this line. 
              Elsewhere in this chapter Łvṛnda$ is the word that signifies `a billion.'</NOTE>
      %ayutaif ... vṛndaif \msCa

<TEXT> ekaikasya parīvāro niyutaḥ pṛthag{ }eva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>parīvāro</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA;             parivāra \msM\ \unmetr, 
                                                                                            parivāro \Ed\ \unmetr</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>niyutaḥ</LEM>  \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed;      niyuta \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>ca</LEM>       \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNcpcorr\msM\msPaperA\Ed; caḥ \msNcacorr</APP>
        <NOTE>It seems that Łpāda$s ab repeat what has been stated in 1.51cd.</NOTE>
        <TR>[that is] each one has a retinue of a million (Łniyuta$) [subordinates].</TR>

<TEXT> koṭibhir{ }daśakoṭyena ekaikaḥ parivāritaḥ||</TEXT> 1:52
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>koṭibhir{ }daśakoṭyena</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msPaperA\Ed; koṭibhi daśakoṭyena \msCb,
                                koṭibhir{ }daśakoṭyona \msNa\msNc, koṭibhir{ }daśakoṭyenaḥ \msNb,
                                koṭibhiḥ parivārāṇi koṭibhi daśakoṭikam \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>ekaikaḥ parivāritaḥ</LEM> \msCb\msNa\Ed; ekaikaḥ parivari<UNCL>taḥ</UNCL> \msCa, 
                                                ekaikaparivāritaḥ \msCc\msNb\msNc, ekaikaparivārāṇāṃ \msM,
                                                ekaikaḥ parivāritaṃ \msPaperA</APP>
% koṭibhiḥ \msCc
        <TR>[Then those] are surrounded by ten million (Łkoṭi$) [subordinates], 
                [they in turn] by a hundred million (Łdaśakoṭi$).</TR>
        <NOTE>°Łkoṭyena$ stands for °Łkoṭyā$ (thematisation).
                Note how the scribe of \msM\ gets confused at 1.52c due to an eyeskip and 
                fully regains control only at 1.54b.</NOTE>

%index_voc: koṭya for koṭi (thematisation)

%folioinfo \msPaperA\ 333.jpg upper, f. 205v 
<TEXT> daśakoṭiṣu ekaikaṃ vṛndavṛndabhṛtair{ }vṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>daśakoṭiṣu ekaikaṃ</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNb\msPaperA\Ed; daśakoṭīṣu ekaikaṃ \msCa\msNa\msNc, 
                                                                             daśakoṭyeṣu ekakaṃ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>vṛndavṛndabhṛtair{ }vṛtam</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb; vṛndavṛndavṛtair{ }vṛtaṃ \msNa,
                                                                       vṛndavṛndabhṛtai vṛtaṃ \msNc,
                                                                       vṛndravṛndeṣu ekaikaṃ \msM,
                                                                       vṛndavṛndavṛtair{ }vṛta \msPaperA,
                                                                       vṛndavṛndaṃ vṛtair{ }vṛtaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Each one of the hundred million is surrounded 
                        by a billion (Łvṛnda$) subordinates (Łbhṛta$).</TR>

<TEXT> vṛndavargeṣu ekaikaṃ kharvabhiḥ parivāritam||</TEXT> 1:53
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vṛndavargeṣu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; vṛndavargebhiḥ tai vṛtam \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>kharvabhiḥ parivāritam</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; kharvarbhiḥ parivāritam \msNc, 
                                                                         kharvābhiḥ parivārāṇi \msM, 
                                                                         kharvarbhiḥ parivārita \msPaperA,
                                                                         kharvarbhiḥ parivāritaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Each one in these groups of a billion (Łvṛnda$) is surrounded
                         by ten billion (Łkharva$) [subordinates].</TR>
% many times \msM reverses and rewrites two pādas... OR RATHER note how it swaps only 1.55b and c here

<TEXT> kharvavargeṣu ekaikaṃ daśakharvagaṇair{ }vṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>kharvavargeṣu ekaikaṃ</LEM>    \mssALL \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; kharvavargeva ekakam \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>daśakharvagaṇair{ }vṛtam</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msPaperA; daśakharvagaṇai vṛtam \msCb, 
                                                                                     daśakharvagaṇe vṛttaṃ \msNc,
                                                                                   daśakharveṣu ekaikaṃ daśakharvagaṇair{ }vṛtam \msM,
                                                                                   daśakharvagaṇair{ }vṛtaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Each in these groups of ten billion (Łkharva$) is surrounded by a
                         hundred billion (Łdaśakharva$).</TR>

<TEXT> daśakharveṣu ekaikaṃ śaṅkubhiḥ parivāritam||</TEXT> 1:54
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°kharveṣu</LEM>   \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\msPaperA\Ed; °garveṣu \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>parivāritam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; parivārita \msPaperA, parivāritaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Each of those hundred billion is surrounded by a trillion (Łśaṅku$) [deities].</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>
<TEXT> śaṅkubhiḥ pṛthag{ }ekaikaṃ padmena parivāritam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>pṛthag{ }ekaikaṃ</LEM> \eme; pṛthag{ }enaiva \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed, 
                                                   pṛthag{ }ainaiva \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°vāritam</LEM> \msNapcorr\msM; °vāritaḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed, °taṃ \msNaacorr</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that in Łpāda$ a Łśaṅkubhiḥ$ stands for Łśaṅkūṣu$ (instrumental for locative).</NOTE>
        <TR>Each of those one trillion is surrounded by ten trillion (Łpadma$).</TR>

%index_grammar: instr for loc

% sic °taḥ:
<TEXT> padmavargeṣu ekaikaṃ samudraiḥ parivāritam||</TEXT> 1:55
        <APP>\vd <LEM>samudraiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed;    samudaiḥ \msCa, damu<UNCL>daiḥ</UNCL> \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>°vāritam</LEM>  \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA; °vāritaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Each of those ten trillion is surrounded by a hundred trillion (Łsamudra$).</TR>

<TEXT> samudreṣu tathaikaikaṃ madhyasaṃkhyais{ }tu tair{ }vṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tathai°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; tathe° \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>madhyasaṃkhyais{ }tu tair{ }vṛtam</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msM\msPaperA;
                                                                madhyasakhyais{ }tu tai vṛtam \msNb,
                                                                madhyasakhyais{ }tu ter{ }vṛtaṃ \msNc,
                                                                madhye śaṅkhyāyutair{ }vṛtaḥ \Ed</APP>
         <TR>And each of those hundred trillion is surrounded by those whose
                                    number is one quadrillion (Łmadhya$).</TR>

<TEXT> madhyasaṃkhyeṣu ekaikam{ }anantaiḥ parivāritam||</TEXT> 1:56
        <APP>\vc <LEM>madhyasaṃkhyeṣu</LEM>     \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA;
                                                                 madhyasāṃkho ca \msM, madhye śaṃkheṣu \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>ekaikam{ }anantaiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                                 ekaikaṃ manataiḥ \msNc, ekaikaṃ anantai \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°vāritam</LEM>            \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA; °vāritaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Each of those quadrillion is surrounded by ten quadrillion (Łananta$).</TR>

<TEXT> ananteṣu ca ekaikaṃ parārdhaparivāritam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>parārdhaparivāritam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; parārdha\lac ××× ritam \msCc,
                    parārdhai parivāritam| ananteṣu ca ekaikaṃ parārdhaparivāritaṃ \msM, parārdhaiḥ parivāritaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Each of those ten quadrillion is surrounded by a hundred quadrillion (Łparā\-rdha$).</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 186.jpg f.269v
<TEXT> parārdheṣu ca ekaikaṃ pareṇa parivāritam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°vāritam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA; °vārivāritaṃ \msNb, °vāritaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Each of those hundred quadrillion is surrounded by two hundred quadrillion (Łpara$).</TR>

<TEXT> eṣa vai kathito vipra śakyaṃ sāṃkhyam{ }udīritam||</TEXT> 1:57
        <APP>\ve <LEM>kathito</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA; <UNCL>kathito</UNCL> \msNb, kathitā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>śakyaṃ</LEM>  \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed;  śakya \msCc, saṃkhyāṃ śakyaṃ \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>sāṃkhyam{ }u°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNb\msM; sākhyam{ }u° \msCb, syakhyam{ }u° \msNa,
                                                saṃkhyam{ }u \msNc, saṃkhyām{ }u° \msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <TR>This is how it is taught, O Brahmin. The enumeration [of the rulers of the Brahmāṇḍa] has been taught
                                         as much as it is possible.</TR>

NUMBERS:
1
10
100
1000
10,000                          10 thousand                   ayuta
100,000                         100 thousand                  prayuta
1,000,000                       a million                     niyuta
10,000,000                      10 million                    koṭi
100,000,000                     100 million                   arbuda
1,000,000,000                   one billio      10^9          vṛnda
10,000,000,000                  10 billion                    kharva
100,000,000,000                 100 billion                   nikharva
1,000,000,000,000               one trillion    10^12         śaṅku
10,000,000,000,000              10 trillion                   padma
100,000,000,000,000             100 trillion                  samudra
1,000,000,000,000,000           one quadrillion 10^15         madhya
10,000,000,000,000,000          10 quadrillion                [an]anta
100,000,000,000,000,000         100 quadrillion               parārdha
200,000,000,000,000,000         200 quadrillion               para



<SUBCHAPTER>pramāṇam</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Measurements</TRSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> pramāṇaṃ śṛṇu me vipra saṃkṣepād{ }bruvato mama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>pramāṇaṃ</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; praṇāmaṃ \msCa\msCb, pramāṇa \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>saṃkṣepād{ }bruvato</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msPaperA\Ed; saṃkṣepād{ }vadato \msCb,
                                                                                  saṃkhyepād{ }bruvato \msNc,
                                                                                  saṃkṣepa bruvato \msM</APP>
        <TR>Listen to me and learn about the measurements [of Brahmā's Egg], O Brahmin,
                     I shall teach [you] in a concise manner.</TR>
% gen with śru is okay
% LACUNA\vc ŁFolio 213v in \msParis\ ends with $saṃkṣepā Ł and the next folio, containing verses 1.60d--2.21ab CHECK, is missing.$/LACUNA

%lacuna_start: msParis
<TEXT> candrodaye pūrṇamāsyāṃ vapur{ }aṇḍasya tādṛśam||</TEXT> 1:58
        <TR>The body of the Egg is like that of [the moon] at moonrise
                 on the day of the full moon.</TR>
%index_metre: ra-vipulā

<TEXT> koṭikoṭisahasraṃ tu yojanānāṃ samantataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>koṭikoṭi°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; koṭīkoṭi° \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>yoja°</LEM>     \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed;      yāja° \msPaperA</APP>

%folioinfo \msM\ 414.jpg lower, f. 3r
<TEXT> aṇḍānāṃ ca parīmāṇaṃ brahmaṇā parikīrtitam||</TEXT> 1:59
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ca parīmāṇaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                                                ca parimāṇaṃ \msCb\ \unmetr,
                                                                                parimāṇañ{ }ca \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>brahmaṇā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; \lac\ ××× \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°kīrtitam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °kīrti<UNCL>tāḥ</UNCL> \msCc, °kīrtitaḥ \msNa\msM</APP>
        <NOTE>I suspect that the plural form Łaṇḍānāṃ$ is accidental and what is meant
              is a singular.</NOTE>
        <TR>The whole circumference of the Egg has been declared by Brahmā
                 to be ten million (Łkoṭi$) times a thousand times ten million Łyojana$s.</TR>



<PAGEBREAK/>
<TEXT> saptakoṭisahasrāṇi saptakoṭiśatāni ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°srāṇi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; °sraṇi \msPaperA</APP>
% saiva/sivadharma/01sdhs/sivadharmasastra.dn:kalpako.tisahasraa.ni kalpako.ti"sataani ca|| 5.118||

%folioinfo \msNb\ breaks off at 1.60d (1.60d--2.22 missing)
%lacuna_start: msNb
<TEXT> viṃśakoṭiṣv{ }aṅgulīṣu ūrdhvatas{ }tapate raviḥ||</TEXT> 1:60
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>viṃśakoṭiṣv{ }aṅgulīṣu</LEM> \conj; viṃśakoṭiṣu gulmeṣu \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed,
                                                          viṃśakoṭi vinā gulme \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>ūrdhvatas{ }ta°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; ūrdhva\lac\ ×× \msNb, ūrddhvato ta° \msM,
                                                                     uddhatas{ }ta° \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>raviḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA; ravi \Ed</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vcd ŁThe folio in \msNb\ ends with $ ūrdhva°, Łand the folios
                                that may have contained verses 1.60d--2.22 are missing.$</LACUNA>
        <TR>The Sun shines from the height of seven thousand seven hundred and twenty Łkoṭi$ finger's breadth.</TR>
        <NOTE>This verse is the reply to the question in 1.36cd, which contains the word Łaṅguli$:
              this hints at the possibility that the unintelligible Łgulmeṣu$ transmitted in most of the
              witnesses might be corrupted from Łaṅgulīṣu$; hence my conjecture, resulting
              in a Łra-vipulā$.</NOTE>

% about 772000 km, in reality: 150 million km
%index_metre: ra-vipulā

<TEXT> pramāṇaṃ nāma saṃkhyā ca kīrtitāni samāsataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>pramāṇaṃ nāma saṃkhyā ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; praṇāmaṃ nāma saṃkhyā ca \msCb, 
                                                        pramāṇenāṇañ{ }cama saṃkhyā\lk ta ca \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kīrtitāni</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; kīrttiyānāni \msPaperA</APP>
        <TR>The numbers pertaining to the measurements have been taught in brief.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note the mixture of different grammatical genders and numbers in this verse. 
              Understand Łpramāṇeṣu saṃkhyāḥ kīrtitāḥ samāsataḥ$ and 
              Łbrahmāṇḍānām aprameyānāṃ$, or Łbrahmāṇḍasyāprameyasya$, which is even metrical.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: gender and number confusion

% wants to say brahmāṇḍānām aprameyānāṃ?
<TEXT> brahmāṇḍaṃ cāprameyāṇāṃ lakṣaṇaṃ parikīrtitam||</TEXT> 1:61
        <APP>\vc <LEM>brahmāṇḍaṃ cā°</LEM> \msNa; brahmāṇḍaś{ }ca \msCa\msCb\msNc\msM\msPaperA, <UNCL>brahmāṇḍāś{ }cā</UNCL>° \msCc, 
                                                                brahmāṇḍāś{ }cā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°meyāṇāṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msM\msPaperA\Ed; °meyāṇā \msCb\msCc\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°kīrtitam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °kīrtitāḥ \msCc, °kīrttitaḥ \msM</APP>
        <TR>The characteristics of the unmeasurable Brahmāṇḍa[s] have been taught.</TR>



% SEE Rocher pp.41 ff, p45: 'The Western concept of a single, original purāṇa'... 'the Indian tradition itself suggests that originally there was but one purāṇa.' pp.46-47: Matsya's version is closest perhaps; p47: word purāṇa in the singular
<SUBCHAPTER>purāṇam</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Redactors of the Purāṇa[s]</TRSUBCHAPTER>
% purāṇāni? or aśī for aśīti 80?
<TEXT> purāṇāśīsahasrāṇi śatāni dvijasattama|</TEXT>
        <TR>O truest of the twice-born, the Purāṇa[s of] 8,000,000 [verses]</TR>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°sattama</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; \lac ×× maḥ  \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a should probably be analysed and interpreted as 
                        Łpurāṇam brahmaṇā kathitam$, or rather, Łpurāṇānām aśītisahasrāṇi śatāni ślokāni
                        brahmaṇā kathitāni$.
                        Alternatively, Łpāda$ a may have originally read Łpurāṇāni sahasrāṇi$,
                        and then the initial number of verses transmitted by Brahmā is
                        a hundred thousand. That the number refers to the number of Łśloka$s
                        transmitted is confirmed in 1.65d: Łviṃśatślokasahasrikam$.

              <sep/>
              In Łpāda$ d, either understand Łmātariśvā$ (nom.) as Łmātariśvānaṃ$ (acc.) or emend
              Łkathitaṃ$ to Łkathitaḥ$ in the sense `Mātariśvan was taught,' echoing 1.38cd:
              Łbrahmaṇā yat purākhyāto mātariśvā yathā tathā$.
                <sep/>
              On the idea that initially there was only one Purāṇa, see, e.g.,
              <citep>RocherPuranas1986</citep><pnum>41ff</pnum>.
                Compare the list in the \VSS\ to a list of twenty-eight Łvedavyāsa$s, from
                Brahmā to Vyāsa Dvaipāyana, in \VISNUP\ 3.3.10--19,
                taught by Parāśara, the twenty-sixth Łvyāsa$
                of this list and our text (in the numbering that I add here I follow
                the translation in <citep>Visnupurana_tr</citep><pnum>178--179</pnum>):
                <sep/>
                Łvedavyāsā vyatītā ye aṣṭāviṃśati sattama~|$ <br/>
                Łcaturdhā yaiḥ kṛto vedo dvāpareṣu punaḥ punaḥ~||$ <br/>
                Łdvāpare prathame vyastāḥ svayaṃ vedāḥ $[1]Ł svayaṃbhuvā~|$ <br/>
                Łdvitīye dvāpare caiva vedavyāsaḥ $[2]Ł prajāpati~||$ <br/>
                Łtṛtīye $[3]Ł cośanā vyāsaś caturthe ca $[4]Ł bṛhaspatiḥ~| $ <br/>
                [5]Ł savitā pañcame vyāsaḥ $[6]Ł mṛtyuḥ ṣaṣṭhe smṛtaḥ prabhuḥ~|| $ <br/>
                Łsaptame ca $[7]Ł tathaivendro $[8]Ł vasiṣṭhaś cāṣṭame smṛtaḥ~| $ <br/>
                [9]Ł sārasvataś ca navame $[10]Ł tridhāmā daśame smṛtaḥ~|| $ <br/>
                Łekādaśe tu $[11]Ł trivṛṣā $[12]Ł bhāradvājas tataḥ param~| $ <br/>
                Łtrayodaśe $[13]Ł cāntarikṣo $[14]Ł varṇī cāpi caturdaśe~|| $ <br/>
                [15]Ł trayyāruṇaḥ pañcadaśe ṣoḍaśe tu $[16]Ł dhanaṃjayaḥ~| $ <br/>
                [17]Ł kratuṃjayaḥ saptadaśe $[18]Ł ṛṇajyo 'ṣṭādaśe smṛtaḥ~|| $ <br/>
                Łtato vyāso $[19]Ł bharadvājo bharadvājāt tu $[20]Ł gautamaḥ~| $ <br/>
                Łgautamād uttamo vyāso $[21]Ł haryātmā yo 'bhidhīyate~|| $ <br/>
                Łatha haryātmano $[22]Ł venaḥ smṛto vājaśravās tu yaḥ~| $ <br/>
                Łsomaḥ śuṣmāyaṇas tasmāt $[23]Ł tṛṇabindur iti smṛtaḥ~|| $ <br/>
                [24]Ł ṛkṣo 'bhūd bhārgavas tasmād vālmīkir yo 'bhidhīyate~| $ <br/>
                Łtasmād asmatpitā $[25]Ł śaktir vyāsas tasmād $[26]Ł ahaṃ mune~|| $ <br/>
                [27]Ł jātukarṇo 'bhavan mattaḥ kṛṣṇadvaipāyanas $[28]Ł tataḥ~| $ <br/>
                Łaṣṭaviṃśatir ity ete vedavyāsāḥ purātanāḥ~||  $

                <sep/>
                Another relevant passage is \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 3.4.58cd--67 (\similar\ \VAYUP\ 2.41.58--67).
                Note how Tṛṇabindu is, perhaps by mistake, different from Somaśuṣma/Śuṣmāyaṇa here,
                but, more importantly, note Amitabuddhi of \VSS\ 1.75b appearing at the end of this list:
                <sep/>
                [1] Łbrahmā dadau śāstram idaṃ purāṇaṃ $[2]Ł mātariśvane~|| $  <br/>
                Łtasmāc $[3]Ł cośanasā prāptaṃ tasmāc cāpi $[4]Ł bṛhaspatiḥ~|   $  <br/>
                Łbṛhaspatis tu provāca $[5]Ł savitre tadanantaram~||   $  <br/>
                Łsavitā  $[6]Ł mṛtyave prāha mṛtyuś $[7]Ł cendrāya vai punaḥ~| $  <br/>
                Łindraś cāpi $[8]Ł vasiṣṭāya so 'pi $[9]Ł sārasvatāya ca~|| $  <br/>
                Łsārasvatas $[10]Ł tridhāmne 'tha tridhāmā ca $[11]Ł śaradvate~| $  <br/>
                Łśaradvāṃs tu $[12]Ł triviṣṭāya so $[13]Ł 'ntarikṣāya dattavān~|| $  <br/>
                [14]Ł carṣiṇe cāntarikṣo vai so 'pi $[15]Ł trayyāruṇāya ca~| $  <br/>
                Łtrayyāruṇād $[16]Ł dhanañjayaḥ sa vai prādāt $[17]Ł kṛtañjaye~|| $  <br/>
                Łkṛtañjayāt $[18]Ł tṛṇañjayo $[19]Ł bharadvājāya so 'py atha~|   $  <br/>
                [20]Ł gautamāya bharadvājaḥ so 'pi $[21]Ł niryyantare punaḥ~|| $  <br/>
                Łniryyantaras tu provāca tathā $[22]Ł vājaśravāya vai~|   $  <br/>
                Łsa dadau $[23]Ł somaśuṣmāya sa cādāt $[24]Ł tṛṇabindave~|| $  <br/>
                Łtṛṇabindus tu $[25]Ł dakṣāya dakṣaḥ provāca $[26]Ł śaktaye~| $  <br/>
                Łśakteḥ $[27]Ł parāśaraś cāpi garbhasthaḥ śrutavān idam~|| $  <br/>
                Łparāśarāj $[28]Ł jātukarṇyas tasmād $[29]Ł dvaipāyanaḥ prabhuḥ~|   $  <br/>
                Łdvaipāyanāt punaś cāpi $[30]Ł mayā prāptaṃ dvijottama~|| $  <br/>
                Łmayā caitat punaḥ proktaṃ $[31]Ł putrāyāmitabuddhaye~|   $  <br/>
                Łity eva vākyaṃ brahmādiguruṇāṃ samudāhṛtam~||$ 

                <sep/>
                The list of Łvedavyāsa$s in \LINPU\ 1.7.15--18 includes these twenty-five names:
                Kratu, Satya, Bhārgava, Aṅgiras, Savitṛ,
                Mṛtyu, Śatakratu, Vasiṣṭha, Sārasvata, Tridhāman,
                Trivṛta, Śatatejas, Tarakṣu, Āruṇi, Kṛtaṃjaya,
                Ṛtaṃjayo, Bharadvāja, Gautama, Vācaśravas, Tṛṇabindu,
                Rūkṣa, Śakti, Jātūkarṇya, Kṛṣṇa Dvaipāyana.</NOTE>


<TEXT> brahmaṇā kathitaṃ pūrṇaṃ mātariśvā yathātatham||</TEXT> 1:62
        <APP>\vc <LEM>pūrṇaṃ</LEM>    \msCa\msCc\msNa\msPaperA\Ed;              pūrve \msCb, pūrṇṇa \msNc, pūrvaṃ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>mātariśvā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;  mātariśva \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°tatham</LEM>   \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °tathā \msCc\msM</APP>
        <TR>were taught by [1] Brahmā to [2] Mātariśvan [= Vāyu] in their entirety, 
             in their true form.</TR>

%index_grammar: nominative for accusative

<TEXT> vāyunā pāda saṃkṣipya prāptaṃ cośanasaṃ purā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>saṃkṣipya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; saṃkṣipyaḥ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>prāptaṃ cośanasaṃ</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNc; prāptaṃ causanasaṃ \msCa\msPaperA, prāpta\lk ausanasaṃ \msCc,
                                           prāptāś{ }cośanasama \msM\ \unmetr, prāptaś{ }cośanasaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Vāyu abridged the verses and then gave [the Purāṇas] to [3] Uśanas.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ noun Łpāda$ twice in this verse and 
              the slightly odd grammatical structure in Łpāda$ b, (Łpurāṇaṃ$) Łprāptam uśanasam$ 
              (`the Purāṇa reached Uśanas'),
              as opposed to the solution in Łpāda$ d with Łprāptavān$.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

<TEXT> tenāpi pāda saṃkṣipya prāptavāṃś{ }ca bṛhaspatiḥ||</TEXT> 1:63
        <APP>\vc <LEM>saṃkṣipya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; saṃkṣipyaḥ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>prāptavāṃś{ }ca bṛhaspatiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; prāptadhañ{ }ca vṛhaspati \msM</APP>
        <TR>He [Uśanas] also abridged the verses, and [4] Bṛhaspati received them.</TR>


%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

%folioinfo \msCa\ 386.jpg
<TEXT> bṛhaspatis{ }tu provāca sūryaṃ triṃśatsahasrikam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sūryaṃ</LEM> \msCc\Ed; sūryas \msCa\msNa\msNc\msPaperA, sūrya \msCb\msM\oo
                 <LEM>triṃśatsa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; triṃśasa° \msCc\msM</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is a ma-Łvipulā$, or simply a Łpathyā$ if Łpra$ in Łprovāca$
              does not turn the previous syllable long (\mutacumliquida).</NOTE>
        <TR>Bṛhaspati taught 30,000 [verses] to [5] Sūrya [the Sun].</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā or muta cum liquida pr 

%folioinfo \msCb\ 408.jpg f.203v
<TEXT> pañcaviṃśatsahasrāṇi mṛtyuṃ prāha divākaraḥ||</TEXT> 1:64
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°viṃśatsahasrāṇi</LEM> \corr; °viṃśahasrāṇi \msCa,
                                            °viṃśasahasrāṇi \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA, °viśatsahasrāṇi \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>mṛtyuṃ prāha</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; mṛtyu prāhaḥ \msM</APP>
        <TR>Divākara [= the Sun] taught 25,000 [verses] to [6] Mṛtyu [Death].</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>
%folioinfo \msNc\ 214.jpg upper, f. 211v
<TEXT> ekaviṃśatsahasrāṇi mṛtyunendrāya kīrtitam| </TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°viṃśat°</LEM> \Ed; °viṃśa° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kīrtitam</LEM> \Ed; kīrtitaḥ \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNcpcorr\msM, kīrtitāḥ \msCc, 
                                                                                  kīrttita \msNcacorr, kīrtitaṃḥ \msPaperA</APP>
        <TR>Mṛtyu taught 21,000 [verses] to [7] Indra.</TR>

<TEXT> indreṇāha vasiṣṭhāya viṃśatślokasahasrikam||</TEXT> 1:65
        <APP>\vc <LEM>indre°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; inde° \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vasiṣṭhāya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msM\msPaperA\Ed; viśiṣṭhāya \msCb, vahiṣṭhāya \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>viṃśatślo°</LEM> \corr; viṃśaślo° \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed, viśaślo° \msCb, triṃśaślo° \msM</APP>
        <TR>Indra taught 20,000 verses to [8] Vasiṣṭha.</TR>

<TEXT> aṣṭādaśasahasrāṇi tena sārasvatāya tu|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>aṣṭādaśasahasrāṇi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                         āṣṭādaśasahasrāṇi \msNc, vasiṣṭhedaśasahasraṃ \msM</APP>
        <TR>And he[, Vasiṣṭha, taught] 18,000 [verses] to [9] Sārasvata.</TR>

<TEXT> sārasvatas{ }tridhāmāya sahasradaśa sapta ca||</TEXT> 1:66
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sārasvatas{ }tri°</LEM> \eme; sārasvatā tri° \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed, sārasvatās{ }tri° \msCb,
                                                        sārasvata tṛ° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°dhāmāya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; \om\ \msNaacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sahasradaśa</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; sahasrādaśa \msM</APP>
        <TR>Sārasvata [taught] 17,000 [verses] to [10] Tridhāma[n].</TR>


%folioinfo \Ed\ p.585
% for ṣoḍaśa...
<TEXT> ṣoḍaśānāṃ sahasrāṇi bharadvājāya vai tataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>bhara°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; bhāra° \msCc, sana° \msM</APP>
        <TR>[He taught] 16,000 verses to [11] Bharadvāja.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 197.jpg upper, f.3v
<TEXT> daśa pañcasahasrāṇi trivṛṣāya abhāṣata||</TEXT> 1:67
        <APP>\vd <LEM>abhāṣata</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msPaperA; a<UNCL>bhāṣata</UNCL> \msCc, abhāṣataḥ \msNc\Ed, mabhāsataḥ \msM</APP>
        <TR>[Bharadvāja] taught 15,000 verses to [12] Trivṛṣa.</TR>


<TEXT> caturdaśasahasrāṇi antarīkṣāya vai tataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>antarī°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; antari° \msM</APP>
        <TR>[Trivṛṣa] then [taught] 14,000 verses to [13] Antarīkṣa.</TR>

<TEXT> trayyāruṇiṃ sahasrāṇi trayodaśa abhāṣata||</TEXT> 1:68
        <APP>\vc <LEM>trayyāruṇiṃ</LEM> \corr; tryaiyāruṇi \msCa\msCb\msNa\msM\msPaperA, traiyāruṇi \msCc\Ed,
                                               tryaiyārūpini \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>abhāṣata</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNc\msPaperA; abhāṣataḥ \msCb, svabhāvata \msNa, mabhāsataḥ \msM,
                                                 hy{ }abhāṣata \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[Antarīkṣa] taught 13,000 [verses] to [14] Trayyāruṇi.</TR>

<TEXT> trayyāruṇis{ }tu viprendro dhanaṃjayam{ }abhāṣata|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>trayyāruṇi°</LEM> \corr; tryaiyāruṇi° \mssCaCbCc\msNc\msPaperA, traiyāruṇi° \msNa\Ed, tryairyāruṇi° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>viprendro</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; viprenda \msCc\msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dhanaṃjaya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; dhana° \msNaacorr\oo
                 <LEM>°bhāṣata</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA; °bhāṣataḥ \msCb\msM\Ed</APP>
        <TR>Trayyāruṇi, the great Brahmin, having abridged them again,</TR>

<TEXT> dvādaśāni sahasrāṇi saṃkṣipya punar{ }abravīt||</TEXT> 1:69
        <TR>taught 12,000 [verses] to [15] Dhanaṃjaya.</TR>

<TEXT> kṛtaṃjayāya samprāpto dhanaṃjayamahāmuniḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°muniḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °muṇi \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the odd structure in Łpāda$s ab: Łdhanaṃjayaḥ kṛtaṃjayāya samprāptaḥ$, 
              for a more standard  Łdhanaṃjayena (Łpurāṇam$) samprāpitaṃ kṛtaṃjayam$ 
              (`the Purāṇa was transmitted to Kṛtaṃjaya').</NOTE>
        <TR>Dhanaṃjaya, the great sage, handed [them] over to [16] Kṛtaṃjaya.</TR>

%index_grammar: odd structure, prāpta for prāpita

<TEXT> kṛtaṃjayād{ }dvijaśreṣṭha ṛṇaṃjayamahātmane||</TEXT> 1:70
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kṛtaṃjayād{ }dvi°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msPaperA\Ed; kṛtaṃjayā dvi° \msCb\msCc\msNc, dhanañjaya dvi° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°śreṣṭha</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA; °śreṣṭho \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>ṛṇaṃjaya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; ṛṇaṃjāya° \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>°mahātmane</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °mabhāśataḥ \msM</APP>
        <TR>[That recension was transmitted] from Kṛtaṃjaya, O best of the
                        twice-born, to [17] noble Ṛṇaṃjaya.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 187.jpg f.270r
<TEXT> ṛṇañjayāt{ }punaḥ prāpto gautamāya maharṣiṇe|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>prāpto</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA; prāptaḥ \msM, prāptau \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>maharṣiṇe</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; maharṣiṇaḥ \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>The structure of Łpāda$s ab is as odd as that of 1.70ab. What was
              intended is probably Łṛṇañjayena prāpitaṃ gautamāya$. Many of the
              syntactic oddities in this and other chapters might betray an influence
              of classical Newar. See pp.~\pageref{newar}.</NOTE>
        <TR>Then from Ṛṇaṃjaya it was given to [18] Gautama, the great sage,</TR>

<TEXT> gautamāc{ }ca bharadvājas{ }tasmād{ }dharyadvatāya tu||</TEXT> 1:71
        <APP>\vc <LEM>gautamāc{ }ca</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; gautamāś{ }ca \msNc\msPaperA, gautamena \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>bharadvājas{ }tasmād{ }dharyadvatāya</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc;
                                 bharadvāras{ }tasmād{ }dharyadvatāya \msCb, 
                                 bharadvāja tasmā haryadvatāya \msM, 
                                 bharadvājas{ }tasmād{ }dharyadvanāya \msPaperA,
                                 bharadvājas{ }tasmād{ }damyāddamāya \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The name Haryadvata in Łpāda$ d seem to be a variant on the attested forms
              Haryatvata and Haryātman (the latter is in the list of Łvedavyāsa$s in 
              \VISNUP\ 3.3.16--17, see note to 1.62 above).</NOTE>
        <TR>from Gautama to [19] Bharadvāja, from him to [20] Haryadvata.</TR>

<TEXT> rājaśravās{ }tataḥ prāptaḥ somaśuṣmāya vai tataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>rājaśravās{ }ta°</LEM> \eme; rājaśrava ta° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msPaperA\Ed, rājaśrave ta° \msNc, 
                                                                rājarṣava ta° \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>prāptaḥ soma°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; prāpta sāma° \msPaperA</APP>
        <NOTE>The syntax is again slightly odd here. The intention may have been
              Łprāpitaṃ rājaśravasā somaśuṣmāya... tatas tṛṇabindunā prāptam$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Then [21] Rājaśravas received it, then [22] Somaśuṣma.</TR>

<TEXT> somaśuṣmāt{ }tataḥ prāptas{ }tṛṇabindus{ }tu bho dvija||</TEXT> 1:72
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°śuṣmāt{ }ta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; °śuṣmā ta° \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>prāptas{ }tṛṇabindus{ }tu</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; 
                                        prā<UNCL>pta tṛ</UNCL>ṇabindus{ }tu \msCc, 
                                        prāptas{ }tṛṇavindun{ }tu \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>bho</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed; \om\ \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Then from Somaśuṣma [23] Tṛṇabindu received it, O twice-born.</TR>

%folioinfo: \msPaperA\ 333.jpg, f. 206r
<TEXT> tṛṇabindus{ }tu vṛkṣāya vṛkṣaḥ śaktim{ }abhāṣata|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vṛkṣaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; vṛkṣa \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°bhāṣata</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msPaperA; °bhāṣataḥ \msCc\msM\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>In other list of Łvedavyāsa$s, Tṛṇabindu hands the Purāṇas down to 
                        Ṛkṣa, Rūkṣa or Dakṣa (see note to 1.62 above). Łvṛkṣa$ in Łpāda$ a
                        is probably a corrupted form.</NOTE>
        <TR>Tṛṇabindu taught it to [24] Vṛkṣa, Vṛkṣa to [25] Śakti [the father of Parāśara].</TR>

<TEXT> śaktiḥ parāśaraṃ prāha jatukarṇāya vai tataḥ||</TEXT> 1:73
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śaktiḥ parāśaraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                 śaparāsara \msMacorr, śakti parāsara \msMpcorr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>jatu°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; tu° \msCb, jaṃtu° \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>The name Jatukarṇa may be a corrupted form of Jātū- or Jātukarṇa.</NOTE>
        <TR>Śakti taught it to [26] Parāśara, then [Parāśara] to [27] Jatukarṇa.</TR>

<TEXT> dvaipāyanaṃ tu provāca jatukarṇo maharṣiṇam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dvaipāyanaṃ tu</LEM> \eme; dvaipāyanas{ }tu \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA,
                                                                         dvaipāyanāya \Ed\ \unmetr</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>jatukarṇo maharṣiṇam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNapcorr\msNc; jatukarṇā maharṣiṇaḥ \msCc, 
                         jakarṇo maharṣiṇaṃ \msNaacorr, jaṃtukarṇṇamaharṣiṇā \msM, jatukarṇā mahaṣiṇa \msPaperA,
                                                        jatukarṇamaharṣiṇā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$s ab are a Łpathyā$ if Łpra$ in Łprovāca$
              does not turn the previous syllable long (\mutacumliquida).</NOTE>
        <TR>Jatukarṇa taught it to [28] [Vyāsa] Dvaipāyana, the great sage.</TR>

%index_metre: muta cum liquida pr
%index_metre: ma-vipulā
%index_grammar: Newar?

<TEXT> romaharṣāya samprāpto dvaipāyanamahāmuniḥ||</TEXT> 1:74
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°muniḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA; °muni \msM\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The syntax of Łpāda$s cd echoes that of 1.70ab above.</NOTE>
        <TR>Dvaipāyana, the great sage, gave it to [29] Romaharṣa.</TR>

%index_grammar: Newar

<TEXT> romaharṣeṇa provāca putrāyāmitabuddhaye|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°harṣeṇa</LEM> \msM; °harṣāya \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA, °harṣaṇāya \Ed</APP>
             %here msPaperA does not follow Ed 
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°buddhaye</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °buddhayaḥ \msM</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab \similar\ Ł\BRAHMANDAPUR\ 3.4.67ab:$
                mayā caitat{ }punaḥ proktaṃ putrāyāmitabuddhaye</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Romaharṣa is usually considered to be the same person as Sūta, disciple of Vyāsa Dvaipāyana.
                
              <sep/>
              In \BrahmandaPur\ 3.4.67ab (Łmayā caitat{ }punaḥ proktaṃ putrāyāmitabuddhaye$, see note to 
              1.62 above) Amitabuddhi is clearly the name (or epithet) of Romaharṣa's son. 
              This suggests that the reading Łromaharṣāya$ in some of the MSS
              in Łpāda$ a is a mistake for Łromaharṣaś ca$, or similar. MS \msM\ is either transmitting an
              otherwise syntactically problematic reading (Łromaharṣeṇa$) that is more 
              original than that in most other witnesses, or \msM's scribe is trying to correct the text.
              Supposing the former, in this case I accepted \msM's reading.</NOTE>
        <TR>Romaharṣa taught the Purāṇa[s] of 12,000 [verses], now fully revealed, to his son, [30] Amitabuddhi,</TR>

%index_grammar: ergative, Newar

%folioinfo \msM\ 415.jpg upper, f. 3v
<TEXT> daśa dve ca sahasrāṇi purāṇaṃ samprakāśitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>purāṇaṃ samprakāśitam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                   purāṇa samprakāśitāṃ \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that the extent of the transmitted text (12,000 Łśloka$s) has not changed since Trayyāruṇi
              (1.69).</NOTE>

<TEXT> mānuṣāṇāṃ hitārthāya kiṃ bhūyaḥ śrotum{ }icchasi||</TEXT> 1:75
        <APP>\ve <LEM>mānuṣāṇāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; manuṣāṇāṃ \msCb, mānuṣānā \msM\oo
                 <LEM>hitārthāya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; hityathāya \msM, hitāthayi \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>bhūyaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA; bhūya \msM\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE><sep/>
                Manuscripts \msCc\ and \msM\ place the Łiti$ of the colophon at the end of the last Łśloka$, before
                the Łdaṇḍa$s, thus: Łicchasīti$ ||O|| (\msCc) and Łicchasi iti$ ||o|| (\msM).
                Note also that \msM\ gives the number of Łśloka$s in this chapter, 77, which is close to
                the number of verses this critical edition has produced. The scribe of \msM\ struggled 
                with eyeskips in this chapter, therefore it seems unlikely that he himself
                counted the number of verses he had copied and arrived at this very figure.
                Rather, he copied the number from his exemplar.</NOTE>
        <TR>for the benefit of humankind. What else do you wish to know?</TR>

<TEXT> <COLOPHON>iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe brahmāṇḍasaṃkhyā nāmādhyāyaḥ prathamaḥ</COLOPHON></TEXT>
        <TRCOLOPHON>Here ends the first chapter in the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ called Description of Brahmā's Egg.</TRCOLOPHON>
        <APP> Ł\Colo:$ <LEM>nāmādhyāyaḥ prathamaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA;
                                                                nāmādhyāyaḥ prathamaḥ śloka 77 \msM,
                                                                nāma prathamo 'dhyāya \Ed</APP>
             %here msPaperA does not follow Ed 
% Pre Angkor K0359.txt: raamaayanapuraa.naabhyaam a"sesha.m bhaaratan dadat  Kengo (1 purāṇa?)

%END OF CHAPTER 1
