% https://www.academia.edu/5555495/The_description_of_%C5%9Aivapura_in_the_early_V%C4%81yu_and_Skandapur%C4%81%E1%B9%87a?auto=download
% Skandapurāṇa (also 1 purāṇa in Skandapurāṇa Kengo, Nirajan also Kambodian inscription, check Florinda's book), Vāyupurāṇa
% 
% ŚDhu 12.53 ff ! describing Śivaloka                                        
% 
% Also Yuko's article in our volume and 
% - Kirfel, Willibald. 1920. Die Kosmographie der Inder, nach den Quellen dargestellt. Bonn/Leipzig: Kurt Schroeder. Reprint: Hildesheim/Zūrich/New York: Georg Olms Verlag, 1990.
% 
% - ———. 1954. Das Purāṇa vom Weltgebäude (Bhuvanavinyāsa). Die kosmographischen Traktate der Purāṇa’s Versuch einer Textgeschichte. Bonner Orientalistischen Studien, Neue Serie, 1. Bonn: Selbstverlag des Orientalischen Seminars der Universität Bonn.
% 


<startchapter-n="2"/>
% chapter 2
%folioinfo \msCa\ 386.jpg
%folioinfo \msCc\ 187-188.jpg, 270r-270v   (end of chapter missing)
%folioinfo \msNc\ 214.jpg upper, line 5, f. 211v
%folioinfo \msM\ 415.jpg upper, f. 3v line 1
%lacuna_start: msM
                % (stopped collating it here)
% ŚDhu 12 CHECK
% Maybe CHECK Skandapurāṇa Revākaṇḍa RKS_52.1

<CHAPTER>dvitīyo 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>
<TRCHAPTER>Chapter Two</TRCHAPTER>

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> śrutaṃ mayā janāgreṇa brahmāṇḍasya tu nirṇayam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>janāgreṇa</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; janā\lac\ ×× \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>It is unlikely that Łjanāgreṇa$ picks up Łmayā$ (`by me, the best of men').
        Instead, I suppose that this instrumental could be understood as `through the best of man,' 
        or rather, simply taken as an ablative (`from the best of men').</NOTE>
        <TR>I have heard the description of Brahmā's Egg (Łbrahmāṇḍa$) from [you,] the best of men,</TR>
% śruto ... vinirṇṇayam \msM

%index_anarthayajna_ref_as: janāgra
%index_grammar: janāgreṇa, instr for ablative, Newari lack of ablative?

<TEXT> pramāṇaṃ varṇarūpaṃ ca saṃkhyā tasya samāsataḥ||</TEXT> 2:1
        <TR>its extent, colour, form, and the numbers associated with it, in a concise manner.</TR>
        <LACUNA>ŁWitnesses used for this chapter: \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 195v--197r,
                                             \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 203v--204v,
                                             \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 270r--270v (it breaks off at 2.21 and resumes at 3.30b),
                                             \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 3v--4v,
                                             \msNb\ exp.\thinspace 43 and 42 (sic!; it broke off at 1.60d and resumes at 2.23),
                                             \msNc\ ff.\thinspace 211v--213r,
                                             \Ed\ pp.\thinspace 585--588;
                                             \mssCaCbCc\ = \msCa + \msCb + \msCc $</LACUNA>


% no Viṣṇuloka mentioned here in this chapter
<TEXT> śivāṇḍeti tvayā prokto brahmāṇḍālayakīrtitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>brahmāṇḍā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; brahmāṇḍa \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The location where the Śivāṇḍa was mentioned is verse 1.39a above.</NOTE>
        <TR>You mentioned Śiva's Egg (Łśivāṇḍa$) as taught to be the receptacle of\linebreak Brahmā's Egg (Łbrahmāṇḍa$).</TR>

<TEXT> kīdṛśaṃ lakṣaṇaṃ jñeyaṃ pramāṇaṃ tasya vā kati||</TEXT> 2:2
        <APP>\vc <LEM>jñeyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; jñeyā \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kati</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; katiḥ \msCc</APP>
        <TR>What are its characteristics and how much is its extent?</TR>

<TEXT> kasya vā layanaṃ jñeyaṃ pramāṇaṃ vātra vāsinaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>layanaṃ jñeyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc; layanaṃ \msCb, lakṣaṇaṃ jñeyaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vāsinaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; vāsirānaḥ \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Łvā layanaṃ$ in Łpāda$ a may stand for Łvā-ālayanaṃ$, in the sense of Łvā-ālayaṃ$.
              The questions in this verse are most probably answered in verses 2.26--33, and if my
              interpretation is correct there, Łpramāṇaṃ vātra vāsinaḥ$ (understand Łvāsināṃ$) 
              and Łpāda$~c should refer to the number of inhabitants in the five regions of Īśāna, Tatpuruṣa, etc.,
              deities who are referred to here in Łpāda$s a and possibly d.</NOTE>
        <TR>And whose dwelling place is it? And [what] is the extent of the inhabitants thereof?</TR>
% pramāṇaṃm \msNc
        % lakṣaṇaṃ here also in msPaperA!

%index_voc: ālayana for ālaya (phs)

% Flo number of prajā as pramāṇaṃ vāsinaḥ (also trees?)
% Nirājan Niśvāsa also measures people: how tall are they/ is he CHECK

<TEXT> kā vā tatra prajā jñeyā ko vā tatra prajāpatiḥ||</TEXT> 2:3
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kā</LEM> \eme; ko \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc, kiṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>prajā jñeyā</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; pra<UNCL>jā</UNCL>\lac × yā \msCa</APP>
         <TR>What kind of subjects live there? And who is the ruler (Łprajāpati$) there?</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 387.jpg, f. 196r
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.586


<SUBCHAPTER>śivāṇḍasaṃkhyā</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Summary of the Śivāṇḍa</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> śivāṇḍalakṣaṇaṃ vipra na tvaṃ praṣṭum{ }ihārhasi|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>na tvaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; tatvaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°rhasi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; °hasi \msNc</APP>
        <TR>Please don't ask me about the characteristics of Śiva's Egg (Łśivāṇḍa$), O Brahmin.</TR>

<TEXT> daivatair{ }api kā śaktir{ }jñātuṃ draṣṭuṃ ca tattvataḥ||</TEXT> 2:4
        <APP>\vc <LEM>daivatai°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa; devatai° \msCc\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>śaktir</LEM> \msCa; śakti \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>How could even the gods have the power to really know and see Śiva's Egg?</TR>

%                     samuddhatam? (high) samāvṛtam? antarhitam? tirohitam? sam(ud)vṛtam??
%                     maybe guha as Skanda? CsK
<TEXT> agamyagamanaṃ guhyaṃ guhyād{ }api samuddhitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>agamyagamanaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; agamyagagahanaṃ \msCc, agamyagagamanaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>guhyā°</LEM> \msNc\Ed; guhā° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\oo
                 <LEM>samuddhitaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa; samraddhitaṃ \msNc, samṛddhidam \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\compare\ \LINPU\ 1.21.71ab:$ namo guṇyāya guhyāya agamyagamanāya ca</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Łsamuddhitam$ in Łpāda$ b is suspect. Emending it to Łsamuddhṛtam$ would not be 
              fully satisfactory, and the readings transmitted in the witnesses are problematic. 
              \msM, a MS not collated for this chapter, gives a confusing reading: Łsa<UNCL>murdhni</UNCL>dam$. 
              I doubt if \Ed's Łsamṛddhidam$ (`yielding success') is the correct reading.
              Perhaps Łsamudāhṛtam$ (`declared, talked about as'), or Łsamāvṛtam$ (`guarded') was meant.
              It is not inconceivable that Łagamyagahanaṃ$ in \msCc\ (and \msM\msPaperA;
              `it is inaccessible because of its depth') is original and
              is to be contrasted with Łsamuddhṛtam$ (`lofty'). One also wonders if
              Łguhād$ could be the right reading, and in what sense, in Łpāda$ b.</NOTE>
        <TR>The path leading to it is not to be trodden, it is more secret than any secret,
                         and it is lofty.</TR>

%WAS:
%samuddhṛtam \eme; samuddhitam \mssCaCbCc\msNa, samraddhitaṃ \msNc, samṛddhidam \Ed

% hitaṃ guhyatamaṃ loke mudrātantraṃ samuddhitam /
%tato "sau yuktimāṃ śrīmāṃ sahiṣṇurbālarūpiṇaḥ // Mmk_34.33 // 
%Manjusrimulakalpa 
%sam ud dhā  KENJI

%folioinfo \msNc\ 214.jpg lower, f. 212r
<TEXT> na prabhur{ }netaras{ }tatra na daṇḍyo na ca daṇḍakaḥ||</TEXT> 2:5
        <APP>\vc <LEM>prabhur{ }ne°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; prane° \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>daṇḍyo</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNc; daṇḍo \msCa\msCb, daṇḍyā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>daṇḍakaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; ṇḍakaḥ \msCbacorr, paṇḍakaḥ \msCbpcorr</APP>
        <TR>There is no master or servant there, nobody to be punished and no punisher.</TR>

% unmetr: duḥśīlavān
% nāsatyo... aśīlo?
<TEXT> na satyo nānṛtas{ }tatra suśīlo no duḥśīlavān|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>satyo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; satyau \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>tatra</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; tatrā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>no</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; \lac\ × \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>Strictly speaking Łduḥśīlavān$ in Łpāda$ b is unmetrical; understand or pronounce Łduśīlavān$.</NOTE>
        <TR>There are no truthful or untruthful people there, no moral or immoral people,</TR>

%index_voc: duḥśīlavān should be pronounced as duśīlavān metri causa
%index_metre: duḥśīlavān should be pronounced as duśīlavān metri causa

<TEXT> nānṛjur{ }na ca dambhitvaṃ na tṛṣṇā na ca īrṣyatā||</TEXT> 2:6
        <APP>\vc <LEM>nānṛjur{ }na</LEM> \eme; nāṛjur{ }nna \msCa\Ed, nāṛjur{ }na \msCb\msNc, 
                                                <UNCL>nāṛju na</UNCL> \msCc, nāṛjun{ }na \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>na tṛṣṇā na ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed;  na ca tṛṣṇā na \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>īrṣyatā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; īrṣyatāḥ \msCc, irṣyatā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Łīrṣyatā$ (for Łīrṣyā$, see 2.7a) is a form rarely attested.</NOTE>
        <TR>no crooked people, no hypocrisy, no thirst or envy.</TR>

%index_voc: īrṣyatā (rare)

<TEXT> na krodho na ca lobho 'sti na māno 'sti na sūyakaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>krodho</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; krodhau \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sūyakaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc; sūcakaḥ \msCb, steyakaḥ \Ed\ \unmetr</APP>
        <NOTE>Łna sūyakaḥ$ in Łpāda$ b stands for Łna asūyaka$ metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>There is no anger or greed there, no arrogance or discontent (Ł[a]sūyaka$),</TR>

%index_grammar: shortening of vowel metri causa

%folioinfo \msCb\ 409.jpg, f. 204r
%folioinfo \msCc\ 188.jpg, f. 270v
<TEXT> īrṣyā dveṣo na tatrāsti na śaṭho na ca matsaraḥ||</TEXT> 2:7
         <APP>\vd <LEM>śaṭho</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; ṣaṭho \msCc, śaṭhe \Ed\oo
                  <LEM>matsaraḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; matsarāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>no envy or hatred, no cheaters and no jealousy.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 197.jpg lower, f.4r
<TEXT> na vyādhir{ }na jarā tatra na śoko 'sti na viklavaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vyādhir{ }na</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; vyādhi na \msCc\msNc\oo
                 <LEM>jarā tatra</LEM> \msCb\msNc; jarās{ }tatra \msCa\msCc\msNa\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>viklavaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; viklava \Ed</APP>
        <TR>There is no disease, no aging, no grief and no agitation there,</TR>

<TEXT> nādhamaḥ puruṣas{ }tatra nottamo na ca madhyamaḥ||</TEXT> 2:8
        <TR>there are no inferior or superior people and there is nobody in-between.</TR>

<TEXT> notkṛṣṭo mānavas{ }tasmin{ }striyaś{ }caiva śivālaye|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>mānava°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; mā\lac × va° \msCa</APP>
        <TR>There are no privileged men or women there in Śiva's abode,</TR>

<TEXT> na nindā na praśaṃsāsti matsarī piśuno na ca||</TEXT> 2:9
        <APP>\vc <LEM>praśaṃsāsti</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; praśaṃsāś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <TR>no reproach or praise, no selfish or treacherous people.</TR>

<TEXT> garvadarpaṃ na tatrāsti krūramāyādikaṃ tathā|</TEXT>
        <TR>There is no pride or arrogance there, no cruelty or trickery and so on.</TR>

<TEXT> yācamāno na tatrāsti dātā caiva na vidyate||</TEXT> 2:10
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tatrāsti</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNc\Ed; tatrā \msNaacorr</APP>
        <TR>There are no beggars and no donors there.</TR>
%perhaps unnecessary apparatus entry

% anarthivraja(s)?
<TEXT> anarthī vraja tatrasthaḥ kalpavṛkṣasamāśritaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vraja ta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; vrajas{ }ta° \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the term Łanartī$ in Łpāda$ a: it might have something to do 
              with non-material sacrifice (Łanarthayajña$), the topic of chapter 11,
              and with our interlocutor Anarthayajña.</NOTE>
        <TR>Go without material desires (Łanarthin$). Being there you'll be resting under a wishing tree.</TR>
% vratataḥ? vrajan? Nirājan
% vrajya Kenji
% a pun on anarthayajña ?

<TEXT> na karma nāpriyas{ }tatra na kaliḥ kalaho na ca||</TEXT> 2:11
        <APP>\vc <LEM>karma nā°</LEM> \eme; karma na \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc, karmaṇā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kaliḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNcpcorr; kali \msNcacorr\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>My emendation in Łpāda$ c from Łna priyas$ (`no lover/husband') to Łnāpriyas$ (`no enemy') 
              might not be necessary but it seems more meaningful than the transmitted readings.</NOTE>
        <TR>There is no karma there and no enemy. No Kali age is there and there is no fighting.</TR>

<TEXT> dvāparo na ca na tretā kṛtaṃ cāpi na vidyate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>ca na tretā</LEM> \mssALL\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; ca na tretrā \msCa, ca tretā na \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kṛtaṃ cā°</LEM> \msCc\msNa; kṛtaś{ }cā° \msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>There is no Dvāpara age or Tretā or Kṛta.</TR>

<TEXT> manvantaraṃ na tatrāsti kalpaś{ }caiva na vidyate||</TEXT> 2:12
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>manvantaraṃ na tatrāsti</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; manvantatrāsti \msCc,
                                manvantarananta tatrāsti \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kalpaś{ }caiva</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; kalpaṃ caiva \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>On Łmanvantara$s and Łkalpa$s, see 1.22--23 above.</NOTE>
        <TR>There are no Manu-eras (Łmanvantara$) there and no \ae ons (Łkalpa$).</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> āhūtasamplavaṃ nāsti brahmarātridinaṃ tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>āhūta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; ābhūta° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>brahmarātridinaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; brahmarātridivas \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Łāhūtasamplava$ for the more widely attested form Łābhūtasamplava$ occurs, e.g.,
              in some MSS transmitting \SDHS\ 10.77 and 81 (see <cite>SDhS10_ed</cite>).</NOTE>
        <TR>No universal floods of destruction come, and there are no days and nights of Brahmā.</TR>

%index_voc: āhūtasamplava for the more common ābhūtasamplava
% brahmarātriṃdivaṃ would be standard 

<TEXT> na janmamaraṇaṃ tatra āpadaṃ nāpnuyāt{ }kvacit||</TEXT> 2:13
        <APP>\vc <LEM>janmamaraṇaṃ tatra</LEM> \msCc\msNa\Ed; janmaraṇaṃ tatra \msCa\msCb,
                                                janmamaraṇantrata \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>āpadaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; apadaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>There is no birth and death there and one never encounters catastrophes.</TR>

<TEXT> na cāśāpāśabaddho 'sti rāgamohaṃ na vidyate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>cāśāpāśa°</LEM> \msCb\msNcpcorr; ca sāyāśa° \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNcacorr\Ed\oo 
                 <LEM>°baddho</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; °ddho \msCc, °vṛddho \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°mohaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °moho \msCa</APP>
        <TR>Nobody is tied to the noose of hope and there is no passion or delusion.</TR>

<TEXT> na devā nāsurās{ }tatra na yakṣoragarākṣasāḥ||</TEXT> 2:14
        <APP>\vc <LEM>devā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; devo \msCb</APP>
        <TR>There are no gods and demons there and no Yakṣas, Serpents and Rākṣasas.</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 415.jpg lower, f. 4r
<TEXT> na bhūtā na piśācāś{ }ca gandharvā ṛṣayas{ }tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>gandharvā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc;  gandharvo \Ed</APP>
        <TR>There are neither Ghosts nor Piśācas, no Gandharvas and no Ṛṣis.</TR>

%                                       metri causa for garuḍa?
<TEXT> tārāgrahaṃ na tatrāsti nāgakiṃnaragāruḍam||</TEXT> 2:15
        <TR>There are no planets there, no Nāgas, Kiṃnaras or Garuḍa-like creatures.</TR>
% Monier: tārāgraha m. `star-planet', one of the 5 lesser planets exclusive of the sun and moon VarBṛS. lxix, 1.
% graha as demons Flo
% gāruḍa as birds? Kenji
% gāruḍa as a part. bird Nirājan

<TEXT> na japo nāhnikas{ }tatra nāgnihotrī na yajñakṛt|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>japo</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; jayo \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>nāhnikas{ }ta°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; nāhnika ta° \msCb</APP>
        <TR>There are no recitations or daily rituals there, nobody performs the Agnihotra and there are no sacrificers.</TR>


<TEXT> na vrataṃ na tapaś{ }caiva na tiryaṅnarakaṃ tathā||</TEXT> 2:16
        <APP>\vd <LEM>na tiryaṅnarakaṃ</LEM> \eme; nātiryannarakas \msCa\msCc\msNa,
                                 nātiryanarakan \msCb, nātriryaṃ narakas \msNc, na tīrthannarakan \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vd Ł\compare\ 19.49cd:$ visṛṣṭe tv{ }indriyagrāme tiryaṅnarakasādhanam</PARAL>
        <NOTE>The phrase of Łtiryaṅnaraka$ appears in \MBH\ 3.181.18ab: 
                Łaśubhaiḥ karmabhiḥ pāpās tiryaṅnarakagāminaḥ$. Here <cite>GanguliMBh</cite> translates Łtiryaṅ$ 
                separately as `in a crooked way,' but I suspect that in the \VSS\ Łtiryaṅnaraka$ has
                more to do with Łtiraggati$, being reduced to animal existence, being reborn as an animal or entering a 
                hell in animal form. 
                Cf. \MBH\ Suppl. 13.15.2615--16:<sep/>
                        Łnṛṣu janma labhante ye karmaṇā madhyamāḥ smṛtāḥ$ |<br/>
                        Łtiryaṅnarakagantāro hy adhamās te narādhamāḥ$ || <sep/>
                and \UMS\ 6.1:<sep/>
                        Łavamanyanti ye viprān sarvaloke namaskṛtān$ |<br/>
                        Łnarakaṃ yānti te sarve tiryagyoniṃ vrajanti ca~||$. 
                <sep/>I suspect that Łnātirya$° in the witnesses is only a scribal mistake for Łna tirya$°.</NOTE>
        <TR>There are no religious observances and no austerities and no `animal hell'.</TR>

% na naraka? Nirajan
% no animals no people in hells Francesco
% destinies? Francesco
% no rituals, but no hell so no risk Florinda
%Kenji:
%śīlavipattir hi sūpacīyamānamṛdumadhyādhimātrakramāṇāṃ pretatiryaṅnarakopapattiphalā vipākeyattāparicchedena pravartate / 
%Candrakirti_Catuhsatakatika , line 646 


<TEXT> tasyeśānasya devasya aiśvaryaguṇavistaram|</TEXT>
        <PARAL>\vc Ł\compare\ \MBH\ Suppl. 14.4.2743:$ aiśvaryaguṇasaṃpannāḥ krīḍanti ca yathāsukham, 
                              Łand \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 1.26.1:$ mahādevasya mahātmyaṃ prabhutvaṃ ca mahātmanaḥ |  
                                                            śrotum{ }icchāmahe samyag{ }aiśvaryaguṇavistaram ||</PARAL>
        <TR>Nobody would be able to tell the extent of the qualities of the god Īśāna's</TR>

<TEXT> api varṣaśatenāpi śakyaṃ vaktuṃ na kenacit||</TEXT> 2:17
        <NOTE>My translation of Łaiśvaryaguṇa$° is tentative. It could be taken as a Łdvandva$ compound
              (e.g. `supremacy and qualities'). The expression Łsarva$° or Łaṣṭaiśvaryaguṇopeta$
              occurs frequently, e.g. in \SIVP\ 7.2.8.28ab and \SKANDAP\ 55.30cd, and \SDHU\ 2.6, 79, 125, 127,
              with Łaiśvarya$ most probably referring to the eight Łsiddhi$s Łaṇiman, laghiman$ etc.
              De Simini (2016a, 386),<nocite>DeSiminiGods2016</nocite> e.g., translates Łsarvaiśvaryaguṇopetaḥ$ in \SDHU\ 2.127 as
              `endowed with all the qualities of lordship.'</NOTE>
        <TR>powers, not even in a hundred years.</TR>

% Liṅgapurāṇa 1:  vaktuṃ varṣaśatenāpi na śakyaṃ vistareṇa yat।। 27.1 ।।
% īśāna : 8 siddhis : see ŚDhU Florinda, (god confers them?)
% Kenji:
% agrajam /
% mūrtimantaṃ amūrtātmā viśvaṃ śaṃbhuḥ svayaṃbhuvaḥ /
% †aṇimā laghimā prāptir īśānaṃ jyotir avyayam† // 15 //
% MBh 12.291.15
% sarvataḥpāṇipādaṃ tat sarvatokṣiśiromukham /
% sarvataḥśrutimal loke sarvam āvṛtya tiṣṭhati (=ŚU 3. 16 ) // 16 //
% tam apy anupamātmānaṃ viśvaṃ śaṃbhuḥ prajāpatiḥ / 
% aṇimā laghimā prāptir īśāno jyotir avyayaḥ // MBh 12. 300. 13 


% hara-icchā-prabhavāḥ? only in \msNc so far
<TEXT> harecchāprabhavāḥ sarve paryāyeṇa bravīmi te|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>harecchāprabhavāḥ</LEM> \msNc; harecchaprabhavāḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa, harecchāprabhavā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Treat Łpāda$ a as if the object of Łbravīmi$.</NOTE>
        <TR>All are born by Hara's wish. I shall teach [them] to you one by one,</TR>

<TEXT> devamānuṣavarjyāni vṛkṣagulmalatādayaḥ||</TEXT> 2:18
        <APP>\vc <LEM>varjyāni</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; vajjñāni \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the gender confusion in this verse. In Łpāda$ c, °Łvarjyāni$ is suspect. 
                I take it as if it stood for Łvargāḥ/vargāṇi$, and not in the sense of `excluding,'
                because gods and people are in fact, albeit vaguely, mentioned below.</NOTE>
        <TR>gods and people, and trees, bushes, creepers, etc.</TR>

%index_grammar: case and gender confusion

<TEXT> parārdhadviguṇotsedho vistāraś{ }ca tathāvidhaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°guṇotsedho</LEM> \conj; °guṇocchedhā \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc, °guṇecchedhā \msCc, °guṇācchredhā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vistāraś{ }ca</LEM> \msNc; vistāraṃ ca \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°vidhaḥ</LEM> \msNc; °vidhā \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I understand Łpāda$ a as Łparārdhadviguṇa utsedho$, i.e. as an example of double Łsandhi$.
              On the other hand, °Łsedho$ is only my conjecture, and may refer to something else than the Śivāṇḍa.
              Note the number confusion in Łpāda$ d, and also that two Łparārdha$s is one Łpara$, 
              the highest possible number according to verses 1.34--35 above. The number may refer to
              any unit of length, but 2.23 below suggests that it is Łyojana$s.</NOTE>
        <TR>The height [of the Śivāṇḍa] is two Łparārdha$s, and [its] width is the same.</TR>

%index_grammar: double sandhi

<TEXT> anekākārapuṣpāṇi phalāni ca manoharam||</TEXT> 2:19
        <APP>\vc <LEM>anekākāra°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; anekāra° \msCa</APP>
        <TR>There are lovely flowers of different forms [there] and also lovely fruits.</TR>

%index_grammar: number confusion 
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.587
%                                        for aparāṇi
<TEXT> anye kāñcanavṛkṣāṇi maṇivṛkṣāṇy{ }athāpare|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>anye</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; bahu° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that both Łanye$ and Łapare$ here pick up neuter nouns (gender confusion).</NOTE>
        <TR>There are also golden trees and also gem trees,</TR>

%index_grammar: gender confusion 

% lists are less Pāṇini Kenji

% for maṇi-pravāla (Maṇipravāla: in the south: languages mixed with Sanskrit, Vaiṣṇava comm. Margherita)
% Monier: also N. of a work, pravāla also coral
<TEXT> pravālamaṇiṣaṇḍāś{ }ca padmarāgaruhāṇi ca||</TEXT> 2:20
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ṣaṇḍāś{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; ghaṇṭāś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ruhāṇi</LEM> \msCc; °ruhāni \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc, °sahāni \Ed</APP>
        <TR>coral gem thickets and ruby plants.</TR>

% See e.g. https://www.gemstoneuniverse.com/navratnagemstonesinlanguages.php

%folioinfo \msCa\ 388.jpg
<TEXT> svādumūlaphalāḥ skandhalatāviṭapapādapāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>svādu°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; svādhu° \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>°mūla°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; °mūlā \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°phalāḥ</LEM> \conj; °phalā \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>skandha°</LEM> \conj; skanda° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>My conjectures in Łpāda$s ab result in a compound spanning the c\ae sura, which
              may have been the reason why the line got corrupted.</NOTE>
        <TR>There are tasty roots and fruits and trees with creepers on their twigs.</TR>

%lacuna_end: msParis
%lacuna_start: msCc
<TEXT> kāmarūpāś{ }ca te sarve kāmadāḥ kāmabhāṣiṇaḥ||</TEXT> 2:21
        <TR>All are shape-shifters and they fulfill desires and they whisper seductively.</TR>
        <LACUNA>\vc ŁAfter $kāmarū°, Ł\msCc\ has two folios missing (ff.\ 271--272) and resumes only at 3.30b$</LACUNA>

% maybe Yakṣas in trees? they are shape-shifters (Giulia)
% check kalpadruma descriptions
% adopting trees Skandapurāṇa and Raghuvaṃśa... but not speaking
% Kristen real drumstick trees ?

<TEXT> tatra vipra prajāḥ sarve anantaguṇasāgarāḥ|</TEXT>
        <TR>There [in the Śivāṇḍa], O Brahmin, all the subjects are oceans of endless virtues.</TR>

<TEXT> tulyarūpabalāḥ sarve sūryāyutasamaprabhāḥ||</TEXT> 2:22
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°balāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; °varāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>They are all equally beautiful and strong, and they shine like millions of suns.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 43.jpg lower, ms resumes here
%lacuna_end: msNb
%folioinfo \msNc\ 215.jpg upper, f. 212v
<TEXT> parārdhadvayavistāraṃ parārdhadvayam{ }āyatam|</TEXT>
        <TR>[Śiva's Egg] is two Łparārdha$s long and two Łparā\-rdha$s wide,</TR>

<TEXT> parārdhadvayavikṣepaṃ yojanānāṃ dvijottama||</TEXT> 2:23
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dvaya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dva° \msNaacorr\oo
                 <LEM>vikṣepaṃ</LEM> \eme; vikṣepā \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc, vijñeyā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; °ttamaḥ \msNa</APP>
        <TR>and two Łparā\-rdha$s is its [vertical] extension, [measured] in Łyojana$s, O great Brahmin.</TR>

<TEXT> aiśvaryatvaṃ na saṃkhyāsti balaśaktiś{ }ca bho dvija|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>balaśaktiś{ }ca bho dvija</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc; 
                                        \om\ \msNaacorr, tava śaktiś{ }ca bho dvija \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$s ab are an echo of 2.17b.</NOTE>
        <TR>[Īśāna's] powers cannot be expressed by numbers, neither can [His] powerfulness, O twice-born.</TR>

<TEXT> adhordhvo na ca saṃkhyāsti na tiryañ{ }caiti kaścana||</TEXT> 2:24
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>adhordhvo na ca saṃkhyāsti</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msNaacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>na tiryañ{ }caiti kaścana</LEM> \msNapcorr\msNc;
                                                na tiryañ{ }ceti kaścana \msCa\msCb\msNb\Ed,
                                                na tiryaṃ ceti kaścana \msNaacorr</APP>
        <NOTE>Łkaścana$ in Łpāda$ d forces us to accept the reading in \msNapcorr\msNc\ (Łcaiti$),
              as opposed to Łceti$ in the remaining witnesses. Alternatively translate as
              '[The distances in Śiva's Egg] downwards and 
                upwards and horizontally cannot be expressed by numbers, some people say.'</NOTE>
        <TR>[In fact, the distances in Śiva's Egg] downwards and 
                upwards cannot be expressed by numbers.  Nobody can traverse through it.</TR>

% rdhvaṃ Kenji
% kaścana saṃkhyā? Nirajan


<TEXT> śivāṇḍasya ca vistāram{ }āyāmaṃ ca na vedmy{ }aham|</TEXT>
        <TR>[In reality,] I do not know the length and width of Śiva's Egg.</TR>
%                                 <GL> śivāṇḍa ca vistāra āyāma ca na vedmi aham </GL>

<TEXT> bhogam{ }akṣaya tatraiva janmamṛtyur{ }na vidyate||</TEXT> 2:25
        <APP>\vc <LEM>bhogam{ }akṣaya ta°</LEM> \eme; bhogam{ }akṣayas{ }ta° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\ \unmetr, 
                                                                bhogamayās{ }tu ta° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°mṛtyur{ }na</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °mṛtyu na \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ c is transmitted in an unmetrical form and with a gender problem in the witnesses
                (Łbhogam akṣayas$, including paper MS \msPaperA, not collated here),
                 hence my emendation using a \stemform\ noun,
                a phenomenon frequently seen in this text. But note that Łbhoga$ is normally masculine;
                there might be a hiatus-filler in-between: Łbhoga-m-akṣaya$.</NOTE>
%                        <GL> bhoga akṣaya tatra eva janman mṛtyu na vidyate </GL>
        <TR>Enjoyment is undecaying there, and there is no birth or death there.</TR>

% not a proper Łra-vipulā$ with the muta cum licence (tatraiva as SHORT-LONG). But not word-initial!
%index_grammar: gender confusion
%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge
%index_grammar: -m- hiatus-filler
%index_grammar: stem form noun

<TEXT> śivāṇḍamadhyam{ }āśritya gokṣīrasadṛśaprabhāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>prabhāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; prabhā \Ed</APP>
         <TR>In the centre of Śiva's Egg, [creatures] shine like cow's milk.</TR>

       1 Tatpuruṣa --> forward, East
       2 Aghora --> right, South
       3 Vāmadeva --> left, North
       4 Sadyojāta --> back, West
       5 Īśāna --> upper

%folioinfo \msNa\ 198.jpg upper, f.4v
<TEXT> parārdhaparakoṭīnām{ }īśānānāṃ smṛtālayaḥ||</TEXT> 2:26
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°śānānāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; °śānānā \msNb, °gānānāṃ \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>smṛtālayaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msNb\msNc; smṛtālaya \msCb, smṛtālayaṃ \msNa, smṛtālayā \Ed</APP>
         <TR>[It is] said to be the region (Łālaya$) of those belonging to Iśāna, 
                one and a half Łpara$ crore in number.</TR>
         <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ Łsmṛta$ in Łpāda$ d (cf. 2.29d).
               I understand Łīśānānāṃ$ as Łaiśānānāṃ$.
                <sep/>
               Īśāna is traditionally the upward-looking face of Śiva,
               his region is positioned in the centre here.
               Note that the somewhat cryptic third Łpāda$s here and in the coming verses
               may or may not refer to the number of creatures living in the given region. 
               They may tell us about the extent of the given region, although the numbers are much
               higher than what one would expect after verse 2.23.</NOTE>

%   and Łkoṭi/ī$ may or may not be a number here (and not a smaller region,
%   as e.g. in Łnarakakoṭayaḥ$ in 24.5) these figures are in contradiction to
%   what was taught in 2.23. Perhaps this is why in 2.25ab above Anarthayajña admits that he 
%   has no idea about the extent of the Śivāṇḍa. 

%index_grammar: stem form noun

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> bālasūryaprabhāḥ sarve jñeyās{ }tatpuruṣālaye|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°bhāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °bhā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>jñeyās{ }ta°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc; jñeyā ta° \msNa\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°ālaye</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °ālayaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>They are all like the rising sun in the region of Tatpuruṣa.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 410.jpg f. 204v
<TEXT> parārdhaparakoṭīnāṃ pūrvasyāṃ diśam{ }āśritāḥ||</TEXT> 2:27
        <APP>\vd <LEM>diśa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; diśi° \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>The genitive of Łparārdhaparakoṭīnāṃ$ is baffling here and in the coming verses,
              but I suspect that again the expression gives the number of subjects living in the given region.
              Łpūrvasyāṃ$ is meant to mean Łpūrvāṃ$ (cf. Łdakṣiṇāṃ, paścimāṃ$, and Łuttarāṃ$ in the next verses);
              note how \msNb\ tries to save the construction by reading Łdiśi-m-$.

              This verse conforms to the traditional view that Śiva's Tatpuruṣa-face
              is looking towards the eastern direction.</NOTE>
        <TR>They are one and a half Łpara$ crore in number, living in the east.</TR>

%index_voc: diśim? 

<TEXT> bhinnāñjanaprabhāḥ sarve dakṣiṇāṃ diśam{ }āśritāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°prabhāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °prabhā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dakṣiṇāṃ</LEM> \mssALLmsCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; dakṣiṇa° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>diśam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; diśim \msCb\Ed</APP>
        <TR>Everybody is like collyrium in the southern direction,</TR>
%  \vab \om\ \msCaacorr 

<TEXT> parārdhaparakoṭīnām{ }aghorālayam{ }āśritāḥ||</TEXT> 2:28
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ghorā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °dhorā° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°śritāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °śritā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the Aiśa form Łdiśiṃ$ in \msCb\ (see, e.g., <citep>KissBraYa</citep><pnum>83, \S 26</pnum>),
              and that Aghora is indeed usually south-facing.</NOTE>
        <TR>in the region of Aghora, one and a half Łpara$ crore in number.</TR>

%index_voc: diśi

<TEXT> kundenduhimaśailābhāḥ paścimāṃ diśam{ }āśritāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>paścimāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; paścimā \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>diśa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; diśi° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°śritāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °śritā \Ed</APP>
        <TR>In the western direction, they are like jasmine, the moon, like snowy rocks.</TR>

% sandhi-bridge?        sadya-m-iṣṭālayaḥ
<TEXT> parārdhaparakoṭīnāṃ sadya{-}m{-}iṣṭālayaḥ smṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 2:29
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sadyamiṣṭā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; sadyamiṣṭvā° \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>smṛtaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; smṛtāḥ \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the Aiśa form Łdiśiṃ$ in \msNc\ in Łpāda$ b.
              In Łpāda$ d, we may presuppose the presence of a Łsandhi$-bridge: Łsadya-m-iṣṭālayaḥ$.
              Sadyojāta is traditionally associated with the western direction.</NOTE>
        <TR>Sadyojāta's lovely region is [home] to one and a half Łpara$ crore [people].</TR>

%index_voc: diśi
% Himālaya CsD 
%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

<TEXT> kuṅkumodakasaṃkāśā uttarāṃ diśam{ }āśritāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>uttarāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; uttarā \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>diśam</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; diśim \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the Aiśa form Łdiśiṃ$ in \msCa\ in Łpāda$ b.</NOTE>
        <TR>In the northern direction, they are like saffron in water.</TR>

<TEXT> parārdhaparakotīnāṃ vāmadevālayaḥ smṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 2:30
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°layaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; °laya \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Vāmadeva is traditionally associated with the western direction.</NOTE>
        <TR>Vāmadeva's region is [home] to one and a half Łpara$ crore [people].</TR>

%index_voc: diśi

<TEXT> īśānasya kalāḥ pañca vaktrasyāpi catuṣkalāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kalāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; kalā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>catuṣkalāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; catuṣtake \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Īśāna has five parts (Łkalā$), [his Tatpuruṣa] face has four.</TR>

<TEXT> aghorasya kalā aṣṭau vāmadevās{ }trayodaśa||</TEXT> 2:31
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vāmadevā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; vāmadeva° \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note how Łvaktrasya$ should refer to Śiva's Tatpuruṣa-face, 
                given that the text lists Śiva's five faces: Īśāna, Tatpuruṣa, Aghora, Vāmadeva, Sadyojāta.</NOTE>
        <TR>Aghora has eight, and there are thirteen Vāmadeva[-Łkalā$]s.</TR>

<TEXT> sadyaś{ }cāṣṭau kalā jñeyāḥ saṃsārārṇavatārakāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>jñeyāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; jñeyā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>saṃsārā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCbpcorr\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; saṃsā° \msCbacorr</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łsadyaś$ in Łpāda$ a for Łsadyasaś$ or Łsadyojātasya$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Sadyojāta has eight parts. These parts, altogether thirty-eight,</TR>

<TEXT> aṣṭatriṃśat{ }kalā hy{ }etāḥ kīrtitā dvijasattama||</TEXT> 2:32
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°triṃśat{ }ka°</LEM> \corr; °triṃśaka° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>hy{ }etāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; jñeyāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°sattama</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; °sattamaḥ \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <TR>which\linebreak liberate us from the ocean of existence, have been taught, O truest Brahmin.</TR>

<TEXT> saṃkhyā varṇā diśaś{ }caiva ekaikasya pṛthak{ }pṛthak|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>saṃkhyā varṇā</LEM> \msCb\msNc; saṃkhyā varṇṇo \msCa\msNb, saṃkhyā vaṇṇā \msNa, saṃdhyā varṇā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>ekaikasya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNb\msNc\Ed; aikaikasya \msCb\msNa</APP>
        <TR>Those who explore the truth should know the numbers, the colours, and</TR>

<TEXT> pūrvoktena vidhānena bodhavyās{ }tattvacintakaiḥ||</TEXT> 2:33
        <APP>\vd <LEM>bodhavyās{ }ta°</LEM> \eme; bodhavyā ta° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>directions associated with each one [of Śiva's faces] in the way taught above.</TR>

<TEXT> śivāṇḍagamanākṛṣṭyā śivayogaṃ sadābhyaset|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°kṛṣṭyā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\Ed; kṛṣṭā \msNa\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>yogaṃ sadābhyaset</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; yoga samabhyaset \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>°Łākṛṣṭyā$ (`because of being drawn to' or `with the intention of') in Łpāda$ a might be corrupt.
              Perhaps understand °Łākṛṣṭaḥ$ (`he who is attracted to').</NOTE>
        <TR>If one has the intention to go to the Śiva's Egg, one should practise\linebreak Śiva-yoga regularly.</TR>
% Fra maybe corrupt
% Florinda: he should practise it with this intention?

<TEXT> śivayogaṃ vinā vipra tatra gantuṃ na śakyate||</TEXT> 2:34
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°yogaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °yoga \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Without Śiva-yoga, O Brahmin, it is impossible to go there.</TR>
        %Similar teaching in ŚDhU 12.232

<TEXT> aśvamedhādiyajñānāṃ koṭyāyutaśatāni ca|</TEXT>

<TEXT> kṛcchrāditapa sarvāṇi kṛtvā kalpaśatāni ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°tapa</LEM> \Ed; °tapaḥ \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\ \unmetr</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łkṛcchrāditapa sarvāṇi$ as Łkṛcchrāditapāṃsi sarvāṇi$. It can be 
              considered an instance of the use of a \stemform\ noun.
              On the specific penance called Łkṛcchra$, which involves having to sleep
              in a sitting position, see, e.g., <citep>KaneHistory</citep><pnum>120</pnum>.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form noun

<TEXT> tatra gantuṃ na śakyeta devair{ }api tapodhana||</TEXT> 2:35
        <APP>\ve <LEM>śakyeta</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; śakyaita \msCb, śakyete \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>devai°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; deve° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°dhana</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dhanam \msCb</APP>
        <TR>[Even] by [performing] millions of sacrifices such as the Aśvamedha,
                 or by performing all the difficult austerities such as the Łkṛcchra$ for a hundred Łkalpa$s,
                 it is impossible to get there even for the gods, O great ascetic.</TR>


<TEXT> gaṅgādisarvatīrtheṣu snātvā taptvā ca vai punaḥ|</TEXT>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.588
<TEXT> tatra gantuṃ na śakyeta ṛṣibhir{ }vā mahātmabhiḥ||</TEXT> 2:36
        <APP>\vc <LEM>gantuṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; gantu \msNb\msNc\oo
                 <LEM>śakyeta</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; śakyante \Ed</APP>
         <TR>By [merely] bathing and performing austerities at all the sacred places such as the Gaṅgā,
                  even the honorable Ṛṣis will not be able to get there.</TR>
% Kenji maybe mahātmabhiḥ is different category

<TEXT> saptadvīpasamudrāṇi ratnapūrṇāni bho dvija|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dvīpa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; °dīpa° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°samudrāṇi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °samudrāya \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab ŁCf. \SDHU\ 2.104:$ triḥ pradatvā mahīṃ pūrṇāṃŁ...$</PARAL>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 389.jpg
<TEXT> dattvā vā vedaviduṣe śraddhābhaktisamanvitaḥ|</TEXT>

%index_metre: na-vipulā

<TEXT> tatra gantuṃ na śakyeta vinā dhyānena niścayaḥ||</TEXT> 2:37
        <APP>\ve <LEM>gantuṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; gantu \msNb, gaṃntu \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>śakyeta</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; śakyante \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Or [even] by donating the oceans of the seven islands with all their gems to a Veda expert, O Brahmin,
             with faith and devotion, one will not be able to go there without meditation. [This is a] certainty.</TR>

<TEXT> svadehān{ }māṃsam{ }uddhṛtya dattvārthibhyaś{ }ca niścayāt|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>svadehān{ }māṃsa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; svadehāt{ }māṃsa° \msNc, svadehātmāṃ sa° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>For examples of legends that involve donating one's own flesh, see \VSS\ 17.37--40 (Uśīnara, Alarka).
              See also 6.26.</NOTE>
        <TR>He who carves out flesh from his own body and gives it without hesitation to those who are in need of it,</TR>

<TEXT> svadāraputrasarvasvaṃ śiro 'rthibhyaś{ }ca yo dadet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°svaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °sva \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Examples of people donating family members include \VSS\ chapter 12 (Vipula giving away his wife),
              and 17.41 (Sudāsa's story).</NOTE>
        <TR>or he who gives away his wife, his son and his possessions or his own head to those in need,</TR>

%folioinfo \msNc\ 215.jpg lower, f. 213r
<TEXT> na tatra gantuṃ śakyeta anyair{ }vāpi suduṣkaraiḥ||</TEXT> 2:38
        <APP>\ve <LEM>na tatra gantuṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; na tatra gantuṃ na \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°duṣkaraiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °duṣkṛtaḥ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>or he who [performs] other difficult deeds, will not be able to go there [by merely doing these].</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<TEXT> yajñatīrthatapodānavedādhyayanapāragaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dāna°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; °dānaṃ \msNa, °dānai \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°pāragaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °pāragāḥ \msCa\msNb</APP>
        <TR>He who has completed the sacrifices, the pilgrimages,
             the austerities, the donations, the study of the Vedas,</TR>

%folioinfo \msParis\ 416.jpg
<TEXT> brahmāṇḍāntasya bhogāṃs{ }tu bhuṅkte kālavaśānugaḥ||</TEXT> 2:39
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>brahmāṇḍāntasya bhogāṃs{ }tu</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; 
                                        brahmāṇḍāntasya bhogās{ }tu \msNb,
                                        brahmāṇḍāt{ }tasya bhogās{ }tu \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>bhuṅkte</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; <UNCL>bhuṅkte</UNCL> \msNc, bhuktvā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°gaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed; °gāḥ \msNaacorr</APP>
        <TR>will experience [only] those enjoyments that Brahmā's Egg offers, still being
                             subject to time and death.</TR>


<PAGEBREAK/>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 42.jpg (sic, and only one side in this image) (A10/5)
<TEXT> kālena samapreṣyeṇa dharmo yāti parikṣayam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dharmo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; dharme \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Notice the \mutacumliquida\ in Łpāda$ a: Łsamapre$° renders as short-short-long.
              I take Łsamapreṣyena$ as if it read Łsampreṣito$, picking up Łdharmo$; otherwise
              it is difficult to make sense of it.</NOTE>
        <TR>Dharma decays tossed forward by time.</TR>

% Kenji spent equally? 
% servant? Flo preṣya

%index_grammar: licence pr  muta cum liquida

<TEXT> alātacakravat{ }sarvaṃ kālo yāti paribhraman|</TEXT>
       <NOTE>As Kenji Takahashi pointed out to me, <cite>Fitzgerald_Alatacakra2012</cite> is
             a good starting point to understand the implication of Łalātacakra$, 
             `a single, rapidly twirled torch creat[ing] the illusion of an apparently real, continuous circle'
             (ibid., p. 777).  The function of Łsarvaṃ$ in Łpāda$ a becomes clear only if
              we understand Łparibhraman$ in a causative sense (for Łparibhramayan$).</NOTE>
        <TR>Time flies moving everything round and round like a circle of burning coal.</TR>

%index_grammar: simplex for causative

<TEXT> traikālyakalanāt{ }kālas{ }tena kālaḥ prakīrtitaḥ||</TEXT> 2:40
        <APP>\ve <LEM>°kalanāt{ }kāla°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °kalanā kāla° \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Time is called Łkāla$ because of the waves (Łkalana$) 
                 of the three divisions of time [past, present, future].</TR>
        <NOTE>One cannot help noticing that this verse would be in a more fitting context after verse 1.30,
              at the end of a section on Łkāla$. On the other hand, it leads us to the next topic, Dharma,
              smoothly.</NOTE>

<TEXT> <COLOPHON>iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe śivāṇḍasaṃkhyā nāmādhyāyo dvitīyaḥ</COLOPHON></TEXT>
        <TRCOLOPHON>Here ends the second chapter in the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ called Description of Śiva's Egg.</TRCOLOPHON>
        <APP> Ł\Colo:$ <LEM>nāmādhyāyo dvitīyaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc;
                                                                nāmādhyāya dvitīyaḥ \msNb,
                                                                nāma dvitīyo 'dhyāyaḥ \Ed</APP>
%END OF CHAPTER 2

<startchapter-n="3"/>
%chapter 3: 
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.588
% COLLATED: \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed
% \msCc\ : missing folio(s), restarts at ahiṃsā paramo yajñaḥ 3.30c
%folioinfo \msNa\ 198.jpg upper, f. line 6
%folioinfo \msNb\ 42.jpg
%folioinfo \msNc\ 215.jpg lower, f. 213r
%folioinfo \msM\ 416.jpg upper, f. 4v line 4 
%folioinfo \msParis\ 416.jpg line 1, f. line  
<CHAPTER>tṛtīyo 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>
<TRCHAPTER>  Chapter Three </TRCHAPTER>

<SUBCHAPTER>dharmapravacanam</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Exposition of Dharma</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR>

% Judit "he is talking about vṛṣa, also why do we talk about dharma"
% abrupt start, although dharma has just been mentioned, so Judit is wrong, I think:
% vṛṣa 
%folioinfo \msNa\ 198.jpg lower, f.5r
<TEXT> kimarthaṃ dharmam{ }ity{ }āhuḥ katimūrtiś{ }ca kīrtyate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>āhuḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; āhu \Ed</APP>
        <LACUNA>ŁWitnesses used for this chapter: \msParis\ exp.\thinspace 215r--215v (breaks off after 3.14d and resumes at 4.8a),
                                             \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 197r--198v,
                                             \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 204v--206r,
                                             \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 273r--273v (broke off at 2.21 and resumes at 3.30b),
                                             \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 4v--6r,
                                             \msNb\ exp.\thinspace 42, 47 (upper), 48 (lower),
                                             \msNc\ ff.\thinspace 213r--214v,
                                             \Ed\ pp.\thinspace 588--591;
                                        \mssCaCbCc\ = \msCa + \msCb + \msCc $</LACUNA>
        <TR>Why do they call it Dharma? And how many embodiments (Łmūrti$) is it known to have?</TR>
        <NOTE>For the correct interpretation of Łpāda$ a, namely to decide whether these questions
                focus on the bull of Dharma (`Why do they call the bull Dharma?') 
                or Dharma itself/himself (`Why is Dharma called Dharma?'), see 
                the end of the previous chapter, where Łdharma$ was mentioned (2.40b),
                and to which the present verse is a reaction, i.e. the focus is not so much the bull
                but Dharma. Compare also \MBH\ 12.110.10--11:
                <sep/>
                Łprabhāvārthāya bhūtānāṃ dharmapravacanaṃ kṛtam$ |<br/>
                Łyat syād ahiṃsāsaṃyuktaṃ sa dharma iti niścayaḥ$ ||<br/>
                Łdhāraṇād dharma ity āhur dharmeṇa vidhṛtāḥ prajāḥ$ |<br/>
                Łyat syād dhāraṇasaṃyuktaṃ sa dharma iti niścayaḥ$ ||<br/>
                <sep/>
                Note the similarities of the above passage from the \MBH\ with this present \VSS\ chapter:
                the phrase Łdharma ity āhur$,
                the fact that the present chapter from verse 18 on is actually a chapter on Łahiṃsā$,
                and that the etymological explanation involves the word [Łā$]Łdhāraṇa$ in
                both cases. These have led me to think that in Łpāda$s ab of the verse in the \VSS\
                it is Dharma that is the focus of the inquiry, as in the \MBH, and not the bull.

                </NOTE>


% katipāda vṛṣo? 
<TEXT> katipādavṛṣo jñeyo gatis{ }tasya kati smṛtāḥ||</TEXT> 3:1
        <APP>\vd <LEM>smṛtāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; smṛtā \msCb, smṛtaḥ \Ed</APP>
                 <NOTE>Understand Łpāda$ d as Łgatayas tasya kati smṛtāḥ$. I have accepted
                        Łsmṛtāḥ$ because this plural at the end of the phrase
                        signals that Łgatis$ is meant to be plural,
                        similarly to what happens in 3.6cd (Łtasya patnī... mahābhāgāḥ$).
                        On this, see p.~\pageref{number} in the Introduction.
                        On Dharma as a bull, see Introduction, pp.~\pageref{bull}.</NOTE>
        <TR>It is known as a bull: how many legs does it have? How many are its paths?</TR>

%index_grammar: singular after numbers, Newari inanimate

<TEXT> kautūhalaṃ mamotpannaṃ saṃśayaṃ chindhi tattvataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kautūhalaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; kautuhala \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>mamotpannaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; samotpannaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>saṃśayaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; saśayaṃ \msCa</APP>
        <TR>I have become curious [about these questions]. Put an end to my doubts for good.</TR>

<TEXT> kasya putro muniśreṣṭha prajās{ }tasya kati smṛtāḥ||</TEXT> 3:2
        <TR>Whose son is [Dharma], O best of sages? How many children does he have?</TR>

%index_anarthayajna_ref_as: muniśreṣṭha

%folioinfo \msCb\ 411.jpg, 205r
<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR>

% -i can be added to roots Nirajan also -t ! maybe two meanings CHECK
% dhātu def Marco png Abhyaṅkar 
% atha vidyā vider dhātos tac ca jñānaṃ śivātmakam | tasya dānaṃ mahādānaṃ sarvadānottamottamam || 1 Florinda
% Kenji: For Nirukta of dharma, see Deeg 165 , Xsaṃhitā 7.26.5, Deeg 1995

% Kenji
% ŚDhU 10.51: dhyai cintāyāṃ smṛto dhātuḥ śivacintā muhur muhur
<TEXT> dhṛtir{ }ity{ }eṣa dhātur{ }vai paryāyaḥ parikīrtitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <NOTE>For similar Purāṇic passages on the etymology of Łdharma$, see the apparatus to
              this verse.

              The insertion `[of] the [same]' in my translation solves the problem of a noun (Łdhṛti$) seemingly
              being considered a verbal root (Łdhātu$) here.
              For similar passages with nominal stems apparently being treated as Łdhātu$s, see, e.g., 
                                                \VAYUP\ 3.17cd:
                        Łbhāvya ity eṣa dhātur vai bhāvye kāle vibhāvyate$;
                                                \VAYUP\ 3.19cd (= \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 1.38.21ab):
                        Łnātha ity eṣa dhātur vai dhātujñaiḥ pālane smṛtaḥ$;
                                                \LINPU\ 2.9.19:
                Łbhaja ity eṣa dhātur vai sevāyāṃ parikīrtitaḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Well, Łdhṛti$ (`firmness'), [of] the [same] verbal root [as Łdharma$], 
                                        is said to be [its] synonym.</TR>

<TEXT> ādhāraṇān{ }mahattvāc{ }ca dharma ity{ }abhidhīyate|| </TEXT> 3:3
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ādhāraṇān{ }ma°</LEM> \msParis\msCa\msNb; ādhāraṇāt{ }pa° \msCb, ādhāraṇāt{ }ma° \msNa\msNc, ādhāreṇa ma° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>ity{ }abhidhīyate</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; i<UNCL>ty{ }abhidhīyate</UNCL> \msParis,
                                                                                 ity{ }avidhīyate \msCb\msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\compare\ \LINPU\ 1.10.12cd--13ab:$
                        dhāraṇārthe mahān{ }hy{ }eṣa dharmaśabdaḥ prakīrtitaḥ ||
                        adhāraṇe 'mahattve ca adharma iti cocyate |
               \vo\ Ł\compare\ \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 1.32.29:$
                        dhāraṇārtho dhṛtiś{ }caiva dhātuḥ śabde prakīrtitaḥ |
                        adhāraṇāmahattve ca adharma iti cocyate ||
                    Ł\compare\ \VAYUP\ 1.59.28:$
                        dhāraṇā dhṛtir{ }ity{ }arthād{ }dhātor{ }dharmaḥ prakīrtitaḥ |
                        adhāraṇe 'mahattve ca adharma iti cocyate ||
                    Ł\compare\ \MATSP\ 145.27:$  
                        dharmeti dhāraṇe dhātur{ }mahatve caiva ucyate|
                        ādhāraṇe mahattve vā dharmaḥ sa tu nirucyate|</PARAL>
        <TR>It is called Łdharma$ because it supports (ŁāDHĀRaṇa$) and because it is great (ŁMAhattva$).</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ breaks off here, 416.jpg lower image is Dharmaputrikā 4.22-39); 
%folioinfo \msM\ broke off, 417.jpg upper is Dharmaputrikā 4.39-55 
<TEXT> śrutismṛtidvayor{ }mūrtiś{ }catuṣpādavṛṣaḥ sthitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°smṛtidvayor{ }mūrtiś{ }ca°</LEM> \msCa; °smṛtidvayo mūrttiś{ }ca° \msParis\msCb\msNb,
                                                                        °smṛtidvayo mūrtti ca° \msNa\msNc, 
                                                                        °smṛtir{ }dvayo mūrtiś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°vṛṣaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; °vṛṣa \msNc</APP>
        <TR>The four-legged Bull is the embodiment of both Śruti and Smṛti.</TR>

% stem form?
% compound? Judit caturāśramadharmaḥ
<TEXT> caturāśrama yo dharmaḥ kīrtitāni manīṣibhiḥ||</TEXT> 3:4
        <APP>\vc <LEM>caturā°</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; cāturā° \msCa\msNc</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare\ 4.74 below:$
                catuṣpādaḥ smṛto dharmaś{ }caturāśramam{ }āśritaḥ|
                gṛhastho brahmacārī ca vānaprastho 'tha bhaikṣukaḥ||</PARAL>


        <TR>It is Dharma as made up of the four disciplines (Łāśrama$).</TR>
% Śivapurāṇa:
% śuddhasphaṭikasaṃkāśo vṛṣabhaḥ sarvasundaraḥ ||
% yo dharma ucyate vedaiḥ śāstraiḥ siddhamaharṣibhiḥ ||54||
% tam ārūḍho mahādevo vṛṣabhaṃ dharmavatsalaḥ||
% śuśubhe 'tīva devarṣisevitaḥ sakalair vrajan ||55||

% only 3 āśramas here ! Judit ; CsK: maybe taṃ santo... is the fourth?
% Olivelle Āśrama p55: "Elsewhere also in the same dialogue the author affirms "the unity of all the āśramas with
% respect to their end" (12.262.34) and calls the āśramas the four feet of dharma (12.262.19,21)."
%         ŚDh-Umāmaheśvarasaṃvāda 10.61–36 dealing with dharma as the bull whose four legs represent the four yugas.
% https://sacred-texts.com/hin/m12/m12b097.htm#fn_765 Ganguli footnote !
% https://ia800200.us.archive.org/33/items/mahabharatakris03ganggoog/mahabharatakris03ganggoog.pdf    the book itself Ganguli
% 
        <NOTE>A similar image of the legs of the Bull of Dharma being the four Łāśrama$s 
                (and not three, as it may seem, at least according to
                <citep>OlivelleAsrama</citep><pnum>55</pnum> and
                <citep>GanguliMBh</citep><pnum>Śāntiparvan CCLXX</pnum>) 
                is hinted at \MBH\ 12.262.19--21: 
                <sep/>
               Łdharmam ekaṃ catuṣpādam āśritās te nararṣabhāḥ$ |<br/>
               Łtaṃ santo vidhivat prāpya gacchanti paramāṃ gatim$ ||<br/>
               Łgṛhebhya eva niṣkramya vanam anye samāśritāḥ$ |<br/>
               Łgṛham evābhisaṃśritya tato 'nye brahmacāriṇaḥ$ ||<br/>
               Łdharmam etaṃ catuṣpādam āśramaṃ brāhmaṇā viduḥ$ |<br/>
               Łānantyaṃ brahmaṇaḥ sthānaṃ brāhmaṇā nāma niścayaḥ$ ||
        <sep/>
        On the more frequently quoted interpretation of the four legs, see 
        <citep>OlivelleAsrama</citep><pnum>235</pnum>, a translation of \MANU\ 1.81--82:
        `Dharma and truth possess all four feet and are whole during the Kṛta yuga, 
        and people did not obtain anything unrighteously (Ładharmeṇa$). 
        By obtaining, however, Łdharma$ has lost one foot during each of the other Łyuga$s 
        and righteousness (Łdharma$) likewise has diminished by one quarter due to theft, 
        falsehood, and deceit.'
        <sep/>
        Understand Łpāda$s c and d as Łcatvāri āśramāṇi kīrtitāni dharmo manīṣibhiḥ$ or
                Łyo dharmaḥ kīrtitaś caturāśramāṇi manīṣibhiḥ$ or 
                Łyo dharmaś caturāśramaḥ kīrtito manīṣibhiḥ$. Judit Törzsök suggested
                that Łcaturāśrama$ and Łdharmaḥ$ may be interpreted as a split compound here.</NOTE>

% gati as karmic places you can end up
<TEXT> gatiś{ }ca pañca vijñeyāḥ śṛṇu dharmasya bho dvija|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vijñeyāḥ</LEM> \eme; vijñeyaḥ \msParis\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed, \om\ \msCb</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vab Ł\msCb\ reads here $ gatiś{ }ca pautrāś{ }ca anekāś{ }ca babhūva ha,
                        Łskipping to 3.7cd, omitting 3.5--7ab.$</LACUNA>
        <NOTE>Note the use of the singular next to a number in Łpāda$ a, as in 3.1d, and that
        Łvijñeyāḥ$ is an emendation from Łvijñeyaḥ$ following the logic of 3.1d.</NOTE>
        <TR>And the paths of Dharma are five. Listen, O Brahmin:</TR>

%index_grammar: singular after numbers, Newari inanimate

<TEXT> devamānuṣatiryaṃ ca narakasthāvarādayaḥ||</TEXT> 3:5
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°mānuṣa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °mānuṣi° \msParis</APP>
        <TR>[existence as] gods, men, animals, [existence in] hell 
                        and [as] vegetables, etc.</TR>
        <NOTE>Łtirya$ seems to be an acceptable nominal stem in this text for Łtiryañc$. See,
                e.g., 4.6a: Łdevamānuṣatiryeṣu$.  °Łādayaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d seems superfluous,
                the verse having already listed five items.</NOTE>

<TEXT> brahmaṇo hṛdayaṃ bhittvā jāto dharmaḥ sanātanaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>brahmaṇo</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; \om\ \msCb, brāhmaṇo \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>bhittvā</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; vittvā \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dharmaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; dharma \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\compare\ \DEVIP\ 4.59cd:$ brahmaṇo hṛdayāj{ }jātaḥ putro dharma iti smṛtaḥ \oo 
                    Ł\compare\ also \MBH\ 1.60.40ab:$ brahmaṇo hṛdayaṃ bhittvā niḥsṛto bhagavān{ }bhṛguḥ</PARAL>
        <TR>Eternal Dharma was born after splitting Brahmā's heart.</TR>

<TEXT> tasya patnī mahābhāgā trayodaśa sumadhyamāḥ||</TEXT> 3:6
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°madhyamāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the use of the singular in Łpāda$s cd. I have left Łsumadhyamāḥ$ as the
                manuscripts transmit it: it signals the presence of the plural. One might consider 
                correcting Łmahābhāgā$ to Łmahābhāgās$, but cf. p.~\pageref{number} on grammatical number.
                In sum, understand Łtasya patnyo mahābhāgās trayodaśa sumadhyamāḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>He has beautiful wives, thirteen in number, with nice waists.</TR>

%index_grammar: singular after numbers, Newari but animate!, AND: last element has proper ending

% trust see Dharmaśāstra, see Brick's Lakṣmīdhara
% Śraddhā etc.?! Nirājan
<TEXT> dakṣakanyā viśālākṣī śraddhādyā sumanoharāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°ākṣī</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; \om\ \msCb, °ākṣi \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°ādyā</LEM> °ādyā \msParis\msNb\msNc\Ed; °āḍhyā \msCa, \om\ \msCb, °āḍhyāḥ \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°harāḥ</LEM> \msNb\Ed; °harā \msParis\msCa\msNc,  \om\ \msCb, °\lk <UNCL>māḥ</UNCL> \msNa</APP>
        <TR>They are Dakṣa's daughters, [called] Śraddhā and so on. They have huge eyes and they are beautiful.</TR>

%index_grammar: singular for plural, Newari animate, last element has ending 
% see rejected endings

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.589
<TEXT> tasya putrāś{ }ca pautrāś{ }ca anekāś{ }ca babhūva ha|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM!>tasya putrāś{ }ca pautrāś{ }ca anekāś{ }ca babhūva ha</LEM> \msParis\msCa\msNb;
                        gatiś{ }ca pautrāś{ }ca anekāś{ }ca babhūva ha Ł(eyeskip to 3.5a)$ \msCb,
                        tasya putrāś{ }ca yotrāś{ }ca anekāś{ }ca babhūva ha \msNa\msNc,
                        tasya putrā anekāś{ }ca tathā pautrā babhūvahaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Numerous sons and grandsons were born to him.</TR>

<TEXT> eṣa dharmanisargo 'yaṃ kiṃ bhūyaḥ śrotum{ }icchasi||</TEXT> 3:7
        <NOTE>Łśraddhāḍhyāḥ$ in Łpāda$ b is an attractive lectio difficilior (`they were rich in faith/devotion'), but I have finally 
                decided to accept the easier and better-attested Łśraddhādyā$[Łḥ$].
                (Note that in fact the wives' names start with Śraddhā in 3.9.)
                Again, the plural forms °Łādyāḥ$ could have been applied. I have chosen
                Łsumanoharāḥ$ in Łpāda$ b because the pattern singular-singular-(singular)-plural,
                i.e. having the required plural ending only at the end of the noun phrase,
                seems to be natural in the language of the \VSS. 
        Note the use of a singular verb instead of the required the plural in Łpāda$s cd,
        Łbabhūva ha$ perhaps being a phonetic and metrically `adjusted' equivalent, so to say, of Łbabhūvuḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>This is the nature of Dharma. What more do you wish to hear?</TR>

         %MMW on Dakṣa:
         %``daughters of whom 27 become the Moon's wives, forming the lunar asterisms, and 13 
         %[or 17 BhP.; or 8 R.] those of Kaśyapa, becoming by this latter the mothers 
         %of gods, demons, men, and animals, while 10 are married to Dharma, Mn. ix, 128f.'' CHECK

%index_voc: babhūva ha for babhūvuḥ metri causa, singular for plural


<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>vigatarāga uvāca</LEM> \msCb\msNapcorr\msNc\Ed; vigatarāga u \msParis\msCa\msNb, \om\ \msNaacorr</APP>
        <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR>
        % indication of a connection between \msCa\ and \msNb? Probably not. It's the end of the line in \msNb, but not in \msCa, 
        % so maybe \msCa\ copied \msNb? (See also \msParis\ here.)

% Judit would go for tebhyaḥ
% yā patnī... etc structure there ? Judit
<TEXT> dharmapatnī viśeṣeṇa putras{ }tebhyaḥ pṛthak{ }pṛthak|</TEXT>
       % \vb <LEM>tābhyaḥ</LEM> \eme; tebhyaḥ \msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed
        <NOTE>I could have emended Łtebhyaḥ$ to the correct feminine form Łtābhyaḥ$,
              suspecting that it is only the result of some early confusion
                brought about by Łputras$, but Łtebhyaḥ$ might be original, and
                it even might mean '[hear] about them.'
                Note again the use of the singular (nominative) for the plural (accusative) in Łpāda$s ab.
                Alternatively, emend Łdharmapatnī$ to Łdharmapatnīr$ (plural accusative) and 
                Łputras$ to Łputrān$ to make them work with Łśrotum icchāmi$.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: singular for plural, Newari last element has ending
%index_grammar: tebhyaḥ as masculine for feminine (corruption only?) Newari
%index_grammar: nominative for accusative

<TEXT> śrotum{ }icchāmi tattvena kathayasva tapodhana||</TEXT> 3:8
        <TR>I would like to hear about Dharma's wives truly and 
                 about each one of the sons born to them. Teach me, O great ascetic.</TR>

%index_anarthayajna_ref_as: tapodhana


<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> śraddhā lakṣmīr{ }dhṛtis{ }tuṣṭiḥ puṣṭir{ }medhā kriyā lajjā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>lakṣmīr{ }dhṛtis{ }tuṣṭiḥ</LEM> \msCa; 
                                lakṣmī dhṛtis{ }tuṣṭiḥ \msParis\msNc,
                                lakṣmīr{ }dhṛtis{ }tuṣ \msCb,  
                                lakṣmī ddhṛtir{ }ddhṛtis{ }tuṣṭiḥ \msNaacorr, 
                                lakṣmīr{ }ddhṛtis{ }tuṣṭiḥ \msNapcorr, 
                                lakṣmīṃ dhṛti tuṣṭiḥ \msNb,
                                lakṣmī dhṛtis{ }tuṣṭī \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>puṣṭir{ }me°</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; puṣṭi me° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>lajjā</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; lajā \msNa</APP>
        <TR>[Dharma's wives are] [1] Śraddhā (`Faith'), [2] Lakṣmī (`Prosperity'), [3] Dhṛti (`Resolution'), 
        [4] Tuṣṭi (`Satisfaction'), [5] Puṣṭi\linebreak (`Growth'), [6] Medhā (`Wisdom'), 
        [7] Kriyā (`Labour'), [8] Lajjā (`Modesty'),</TR>
        <NOTE>Note how Łlajjā$ in Łpāda$ b makes the line unmetrical.

        For Dharma's thirteen wives and their sons, see, e.g., \LINPU\ 1.5.34--37 (note the 
                       similarity between the first line and \VSS\ 3.6cd--7ab above):
        <sep/>
       Łdharmasya patnyaḥ śraddhādyāḥ kīrtitā vai trayodaśa$ |<br/>
       Łtāsu dharmaprajāṃ vakṣye yathākramam anuttamam$ ||<br/>
       Łkāmo darpo 'tha niyamaḥ saṃtoṣo lobha eva ca$ |<br/>
       Łśrutas tu daṇḍaḥ samayo bodhaś caiva mahādyutiḥ$ ||<br/>
       Łapramādaś ca vinayo vyavasāyo dvijottamāḥ$ |<br/>
       Łkṣemaṃ sukhaṃ yaśaś caiva dharmaputrāś ca tāsu vai$ || <br/>
       Łdharmasya vai kriyāyāṃ tu daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca$ |<br/>
       Łapramādas tathā bodho buddher dharmasya tau sutau$ ||</NOTE>

%index_metre: unmetrical at end of line

<TEXT> buddhiḥ śāntir{ }vapuḥ kīrtiḥ siddhiḥ prasūtisambhavāḥ||</TEXT> 3:9
        <APP>\vc <LEM>buddhiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; buddhi \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>siddhiḥ prasūtisambhavāḥ</LEM> \conj; siddhiś{ }cābhūtisambhavāḥ \msParis,
                                        siddhiś{ }cābhūtisambhavā \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc, 
                                        siddhiś{ }cātisambhavā \msCb, siddhiś{ }ca bhūtisambhavā \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[9] Buddhi (`Intelligence'), [10] Śānti (`Tranquillity'), 
                [11] Vapus (`Beauty'), [12] Kīrti (`Fame'), [13] Siddhi (`Success'),
                 [all] born to Prasūti[, Dakṣa's wife]. </TR>
        <NOTE> <sep/>

                 Łprasūtisambhavāḥ$ in Łpāda$ d is a rather bold conjecture that can be supported by two facts:
                        firstly, the readings of the manuscripts are difficult to make sense of and thus are
                                         probably corrupt; secondly, a corruption from the name Prasūti,
                                         traditionally the name of Dakṣa's wife, to Łābhūti$
                                         is relatively easily to explain, Łsū$ and Łbhū$ being close enough in some scripts 
                                         (e.g. in \msCa) to cause confusion. Another option would be to accept 
                                         Ābhūti as the name of Dakṣa's wife.
                <sep/>
                         For Prasūti being Dakṣa's wife in other sources,
                         see, e.g., \LINPU\ 1.5.20--21 (but also note the presence of the name Sambhūti):
                                <sep/>
                               Łprasūtiḥ suṣuve dakṣāc caturviṃśatikanyakāḥ$ |<br/>
                               Łśraddhāṃ lakṣmīṃ dhṛtiṃ puṣṭiṃ tuṣṭiṃ medhāṃ kriyāṃ tathā$ ||<br/>
                               Łbuddhi lajjāṃ vapuḥ śāntiṃ siddhiṃ kīrtiṃ mahātapāḥ$ |<br/>
                               Łkhyātiṃ śāntiś ca saṃbhūtiṃ smṛtiṃ prītiṃ kṣamāṃ tathā$ ||</NOTE>


%folioinfo \msCa\ 390.jpg
% stem form?
<TEXT> śraddhā kāmaḥ suto jāto darpo lakṣmīsutaḥ smṛtaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kāmaḥ</LEM> \msNa; kāma° \msParis\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc, dharma° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Śraddhā's son is Kāma (`Desire'). Darpa (`Pride') is said to be Lakṣmī's son.</TR>
        <NOTE>Understand Łśraddhā$ as a \stemform\ noun for Łśraddhāyāḥ$ (gen./abl., cf. 3.11a).
              Alternatively, take Łśraddhā$ and Łsuto$ as elements of a split compound, and understand
              Łśraddhāsuto jātaḥ kāmaḥ$.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form noun, or split sandhi

<TEXT> dhṛtyās{ }tu niyamaḥ putraḥ saṃtoṣas{ }tuṣṭijaḥ smṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 3:10
        <PARAL>\vo ŁSee a passage similar to \VSS\ 3.10--13,
        e.g., in \KURMP\ 1.8.20 ff.:$
        śraddhāyā ātmajaḥ kāmo darpo lakṣmīsutaḥ smṛtaḥ |
        dhṛtyās{ }tu niyamaḥ putras{ }tuṣṭyāḥ saṃtoṣa ucyate || 
        puṣṭyā lābhaḥ sutaś{ }cāpi medhāputraḥ śrutas{ }tathā | 
        kriyāyāś{ }cābhavat{ }putro daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca ||  
        buddhyā bodhaḥ sutas{ }tadvad{ }apramādo vyajāyata | 
        lajjāyā vinayaḥ putro vapuṣo vyavasāyakaḥ ||  
        kṣemaḥ śāntisutaś{ }cāpi sukhaṃ siddhir{ }ajāyata |
        yaśaḥ kīrtisutas{ }tadvad{ }ity{ }ete dharmasūnavaḥ ||   
        kāmasya harṣaḥ putro 'bhūd{ }devānando vyajāyata |  
        ity{ }eṣa vai sukhodarkaḥ sargo dharmasya kīrtitaḥ ||</PARAL>
        <TR>Dhṛti's son is Niyama (`Rule'). Saṃtoṣa (`Satisfaction') is Tuṣṭi's son.</TR>

<TEXT> puṣṭyā lābhaḥ suto jāto medhāputraḥ śrutas{ }tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>lābhaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc; lābha° \msNa\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>jāto</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msParis</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°putraḥ</LEM> \eme; °putra \msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>śruta°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; śruti° \msParis, śrata° \msCb</APP>
        <TR>To Puṣṭi was born a son [called] Lābha (`Profit'). Medhā's son is Śruta (`Sacred Knowledge').</TR>

<TEXT> kriyāyās{ }tv{ }abhavat{ }putro daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca||</TEXT> 3:11
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tv{ }abhavat{ }putro</LEM> \eme; tv{ }abhayaḥ putro \msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc, tūbhayaḥ putrau \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>daṇḍaḥ</LEM> \corr; daṇḍe \msCa\msNaacorr daṇḍa° \msParis\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed, daṇḍo \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>ca</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; tu \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\similar\ \LINPU\ 1.70.295ab:$kriyāyām{ }abhavat{ }putro daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca;
                    Ł\similar\ \KURMP\ 1.8.22cd:   $kriyāyāś{ }cābhavat{ }putro daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca;
                    Ł\compare\ \LINPU\ 1,5.37:     $dharmasya vai kriyāyāṃ tu daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca</PARAL>
        <TR>Kriyā's sons are Daṇḍa (`Punishment') and Samaya (`Law').</TR>
        <NOTE>I have emended Łabhayaḥ$ to Łabhavat$ in Łpāda$ c, following the relevant line in the \KURMP\ cited 
                        in the apparatus to this verse
                        (Łkriyāyāś cābhavat putro daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca$) and also \LINPU\ 1.5.37 quoted also 
                        in the apparatus, allotting only two sons to Kriyā. Thus I don't think
                        that Kriyā is supposed to have a son called Abhaya (`Freedom from danger'; \BHAGP\ 4.1.50ab 
                        claims that Dayā had a son called Abhaya:
                        Łśraddhāsūta śubhaṃ maitrī prasādam abhayaṃ dayā$).
                        Nevertheless, in a number of sources Kriyā actually has three sons, 
                        see, e.g., \VISNUP\ 1.7.26ab,
                        where they are named as Daṇḍa, Naya and Vinaya:
                                Łmedhā śrutaṃ kriyā daṇḍaṃ nayaṃ vinayam eva ca$. 
                        Perhaps read Łkriyāyās tu nayaḥ putro$ in Łpāda$ c? Compare \VAYUP\ 1.10.34cd
                                        (Łkriyāyās tu nayaḥ prokto daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca$) 
                                with \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 1.9.60ab (Łkriyāyās tanayau proktau damaś ca śama eva ca$).</NOTE>


%folioinfo \msNc\ 216.jpg upper, f. 213v
<TEXT> lajjāyā vinayaḥ putro buddhyā bodhaḥ{ }sutaḥ smṛtaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>lajjāyā vinayaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; lajjāyāḥ vinaya° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sutaḥ smṛtaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sutaḥ \lk\lk\ \msCa, sutaḥs{ }tathā \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Lajjā's son is Vinaya (`Discipline'), Buddhi's son is Bodha (`Intelligence').</TR>

% Nirajan: maybe this is an extra line
% sudhiyaḥ might go with lajjāyāḥ Törzsök
<TEXT> lajjāyāḥ sudhiyaḥ putra apramādaś{ }ca tāv{ }ubhau||</TEXT> 3:12
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sudhiyaḥ</LEM> \Ed; sudhiya \msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\oo
                 <LEM>putra</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; putraḥ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>apramāda°</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; apramādā° \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>In a very similar passages in \KURMP\ 1.8.20 ff., Apramāda is Buddhi's son and 
                 Lajjā has only one son, Vinaya. In the above verse (\VSS\ 3.12), Łsudhiyaḥ$ (for Łsudhīḥ$) may only be 
                        qualifying Łapramāda$, thus Lajjā may have two sons: Vinaya and the wise Apramāda.
                        Alternatively, Łpāda$s cd might be a extra line inserted accidentally.</NOTE>
        <TR>Lajjā has two [more] sons: Sudhiya[/Sudhī] (`Wise') and Apramāda (`Cautiousness').</TR>


<TEXT> kṣemaḥ śāntisuto vindyād{ }vyavasāyo vapoḥ sutaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vapoḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; vapo \msNa</APP>
        <TR>Kṣema (`Peace') is to be known as Śānti's son, Vyavasāya (`Resolution') is Vapus' son.</TR>

<TEXT> yaśaḥ kīrtisuto jñeyaḥ sukhaṃ siddher{ }vyajāyata|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>siddhe°</LEM> \msParis\msCb\msNa\msNb; siddhi \msCa\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>vyajāyata</LEM> \msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa; vyajāyate \msNb\Ed, vyajāyataḥ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>Yaśas (`Fame') is Kīrti's son, Sukha (`Joy') was born to Siddhi.</TR>

<TEXT> svāyambhuve 'ntare tv{ }āsan{ }kīrtitā dharmasūnavaḥ||</TEXT> 3:13
        <APP>\ve <LEM>svāyambhuve</LEM> \msParis\msCa\msNa\msNc; svāyambhuvo \msCb, svayambhuve \msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>'ntare tv{ }āsan</LEM> \conj; 'ntare tvāsi \msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa, 
                                'ntare tv{ }āsīt \msNb, 'ntare tv{ }āsaṃ \msNc, 'ntar{ }evāsi \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[This is how] the sons of Dharma in the [Łmanvantara$] era of Svāyambhuva [Manu] were known.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note that Łsukhaṃ$ in Łpāda$ d is probably meant to be masculine (Łsukhaḥ$), but e.g. in the 
                \KURMP\ passage quoted above it is also neuter. For the emendation in Łpāda$ e, 
                see \MATSP\ 9.2cd: 
                <sep/>
                                      Łyāmā nāma purā devā āsan svāyambhuvāntare$,
                <sep/>
                and \BHAGP\ 6.4.1:      
                <sep/>
                                      Łdevāsuranṛṇāṃ sargo nāgānāṃ mṛgapakṣiṇām$ | <br/>
                                      Łsāmāsikas tvayā prokto yas tu svāyambhuve 'ntare$ ||</NOTE>


<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> mūrtidvayaṃ kathaṃ dharmaṃ kathayasva tapodhana|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dharmaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; ddharma \msNc, dharmaḥ \Ed</APP>
                <TR>How come Dharma has two embodiments? Tell me, O great ascetic.</TR>

%index_anarthayajna_ref_as: tapodhana

% dubious knowledge? Florinda
% insecurity of my knowledge Judit
% after \msParis\ atī-, the next folio (417.jpg) starts with 4.8a...
%lacuna_start: msParis
<TEXT> kautūhalam{ }atīvaṃ me kartaya jñānasaṃśayam||</TEXT> 3:14
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kautūhala°</LEM> \mssALL\msParis\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kotūhala° \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>°tīvaṃ me</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °tīva me \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kartaya</LEM> \eme; kīrtaya \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°saṃśayam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; °saṃśayaḥ \msCb\msNb</APP>
                <TR>I am extremely intrigued. Cut my doubts concerning [this] knowledge.</TR>
        <LACUNA>\vc ŁIn \msParis, folio 215v ends with$ kautūhalam{ }atī Łand the next available
                      folio side (217r) starts with$ tyam{ }iṣṭagatiḥ proktaṃ Ł in 4.8a. Thus one folio (f. 216),
                      containing 3.14d--4.7, is missing.$</LACUNA>
        <NOTE>Note Łdharma$ as a neuter noun and the form Łatīvaṃ$ for Łatīva$ metri causa. 
        My emen\-dation from Łkīrtaya$ (`declare') to Łkartaya$ (`cut') was influenced by the combination
        of Łchindhi$ and Łsaṃśaya$, often with Łkautūhala$, elsewhere in the \VSS:
                3.2ab: Łkautūhalaṃ mamotpannaṃ saṃśayaṃ chindhi tattvataḥ$; 
                10.10cd: Łkautūhalaṃ mahaj jātaṃ chindhi saṃśayakārakam$;
                15.2ab: Łetat kautūhalaṃ chindhi saṃśayaṃ parameśvara$. 
                The reading Łkīrtaya$ may have been the result of the influence of Łkīrtitā$ in 3.13f above.</NOTE>


<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> śrutismṛtidvayor{ }mūrtir{ }dharmasya parikīrtitā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śruti°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; śrutiḥ \msCb\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°dvayor{ }mūrtir{ }dha°</LEM> \msCa; °dvayo mūrti dha° \msCb\msNa\msNb, °dvayī mūrti dha° \msNc, 
                                                                                        °dvayor{ }mūrti dha° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kīrtitā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; °kīrttitaḥ \msNb, kīrttitāḥ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>Dharma's embodiment is said to consist of Scripture (Łśruti$) and Tradition (Łsmṛti$).</TR>
        <NOTE>The reading °Łdvayī$ in \msNc\ in Łpāda$ a is attractive, but
                it could well be only an attempt to improve upon the text.
                The emendation in Łpāda$ c is based on parallel passages in \MANU\ and the \MATSP\
                (see the apparatus).

              As for Dharma being based on Łśruti$ and Łsmṛti$, see, e.g., \MANU\ 2.10:
                        <sep/>
                        Łśrutis tu vedo vijñeyo dharmaśāstraṃ tu vai smṛtiḥ$ |<br/>
                        Łte sarvārtheṣv amīmāṃsye tābhyāṃ dharmo hi nirbabhau$ ||
                        <sep/>
              In Olivelle's translation (<citeyear>OlivelleManu</citeyear>, 94):
                `\thinspace ``Scripture'' should be recognized as ``Veda,'' and ``tradition''
                        as ``Law Treatise.'' These two should never be called into question in any matter,
                        for it is from them that the Law shines forth.'</NOTE>

<TEXT> dārāgnihotrasambandha ijyā śrautasya lakṣaṇam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°bandha i°</LEM> \eme; °baddha i° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc, °bandha i° \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>śrautasya</LEM> \eme; śrotasya \msCa\msCb\msNc, śrautrasya \msNa, srotrasya \msNb, śrutasya \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\compare\ \MANU\ 3.171ab:$dārāgnihotrasaṃyogaṃ kurute yo 'graje sthite; 
                        Łand also \MATSP\ 142.41:$ 
                        dārāgnihotrasambandham{ }ṛgyajuḥsāmasaṃhitāḥ|
                        ityādibahulaṃ śrautaṃ dharmaṃ saptarṣayo 'bruvan||</PARAL>
        <TR>The characteristics of the Śrauta [tradition] are an association with a wife [i.e.\ marriage] and with
                         the fire ritual, and sacrifice.</TR>


<TEXT> smārto varṇāśramācāro yamaiś{ }ca niyamair{ }yutaḥ||</TEXT> 3:15
        <APP>\ve <LEM>smārto</LEM> \eme; smārta \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcdef\ Ł \similar\ \MBH\ Suppl. 1.36.10: 
                                $dānāgnihotram{ }ijyā ca śrautasyaitad{ }dhi lakṣaṇam|
                                smārto varṇāśramācāro yamaiś{ }ca niyamair{ }yutaḥ||
                         \similar\ Ł\MATSP\ 145.30cd--31ab:
                                $dārāgnihotrasambandham{ }ijyā śrautasya lakṣaṇam|
                                smārto varṇāśramācāro yamaiś{ }ca niyamair{ }yutaḥ||
                         \similar\ Ł\BRAHMANDAPUR\ 1.32.33cd--34ab:$
                                dārāgnihotrasambandhād dvidhā śrautasya lakṣaṇam|
                                smārto varṇāśramācārair{ }yamaiḥ sa niyamaiḥ smṛtaḥ||</PARAL>
        % CHECK how to refer to \MBh\ Suppl.
        <TR>The Smārta [tradition focuses on] the conduct (Łācāra$) of the social classes (Łvarṇa$) 
                  and disciplines (Łāśrama$) which is connected to rules and regulations (Łyama-niyama$).</TR>
        <NOTE>
        
        To state that the Smārta tradition is connected to Łyama$s and Łniyama$s and the Łāśrama$s and
