        then to discuss these at length (principally in chapters 3--8 and 11) can be seen 
                                as a clear self-identification with the Smārta tradition.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

% Niśvāsamukha. (1.52cd-55)
% laukikaṃ sampravakṣyāmi yena svargam vrajanti te |
% kūpavāpīgṛhodyāna [——] tha maṇḍapāḥ |
% dānatīrthopavāsāni vratāni niyamāni ca ||
% bhakṣābhakṣaparīhārañ japahoman tathārcanam |
% jalāgnibhṛgupāto hi tathānaśanam eva ca ||
% vidyamānanivṛttiś ca guruvṛddhābhipūjanam |
% laukikaṃ kathitaṃ hy etad vaidikañ cāturāśramam ||


%folioinfo \msNa\ 199.jpg upper, f.5v
%folioinfo \msT\ starts here 3997.jpg
<SUBCHAPTER>yamaniyamabhedaḥ</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Yama and Niyama rules</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> yamaś{ }ca niyamaś{ }caiva dvayor{ }bhedam{ }ataḥ śṛṇu|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>niyama°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; niyamai° \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a should be understood as Łyamaniyamayoś$, but the author of this line
                may have tried to avoid the metrical fault of having two short syllables 
                in second and third position. Note how all witnesses read Łmādhūrya$ 
                in Łpāda$ e instead of Łmādhurya$. The former may have been
                acceptable originally in this text. ŁPāda$ e is a Łma-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Now hear the classification of both the Łyama$ and Łniyama$ rules.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 47.jpg upper (the lower leaf contains some text that I cannot identify)
<TEXT> ahiṃsā satyam{ }asteyam{ }ānṛśaṃsyaṃ damo ghṛṇā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°m{ }ānṛśaṃsyaṃ</LEM> \eme; °m{ }anṛśaṃsyo \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed, °m{ }ānṛśaṃsyā \msNc</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\similar\ \MBH\ 12.8.17ab:$ ahiṃsā satyavacanam{ }ānṛśaṃsyaṃ damo ghṛṇā
                \vo Ł\similar\ \VDHU\ 3.233.203: 
                        $ānṛśaṃsyaṃ kṣamā satyam{ }ahiṃsā ca damaḥ spṛhā |
                        dhyānaṃ prasādo mādhuryaṃ cārjavaṃ ca yamā daśa ||</PARAL>
        <NOTE><sep/>
                As noted above, this is the beginning of a long section in our text
                that describes the Łyama-niyama$ rules, reaching up to the end of chapter eight. 
                The title given in the colophon of the next chapter, chapter four, namely Łyamavibhāga$,
                would fit this locus better than the beginning of that chapter, which 
                commences with a discussion on the second of the Łyama$s, Łsatya$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Non-vio\-lence, truthfulness, refraining from stealing, absence of hostility, self-re\-straint, taboos,</TR>


<TEXT> dhanyāpramādo mādhuryam{ }ārjavaṃ ca yamā daśa||</TEXT> 3:16
        <APP>\ve <LEM>dhanyā°</LEM> \Ed; dhanyaḥ \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc, dhyanyaṃ \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>mādhurya°</LEM> \Ed; mādhūrya° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>ārjavaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; ārjavaś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <TR>virtue, avoiding mistakes, charm, sincerity: these are the ten Łyama$s.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<TEXT> ekaikasya punaḥ pañcabhedam{ }āhur{ }manīṣiṇaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°m{ }āhur{ }ma°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; °m{ }āhu ma° \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ a, Łpañca$ and Łbheda$ may be typeset as two separate words since
              the use of the singular after numbers is one of the hallmarks of the text 
              (see p.~\pageref{number}).</NOTE>
        % \Ed punar
        <TR>The wise say that there are five subclasses to each.</TR>

<TEXT> ahiṃsādi pravakṣyāmi śṛṇuṣvāvahito dvija||</TEXT> 3:17
        <APP>\vd <LEM>śṛṇuṣvā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; śṛṇuṣva° \msNa\msNb</APP>
        <TR>I shall teach you about non-violence and the other [Łyama$-rules]. Listen carefully, O twice-born.</TR>

%index_grammar: singular after numbers? Newar




<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣv{ }ahiṃsā (1)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>First Yama-rule: non-violence</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>pañcavidhā hiṃsā</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Five types of violence</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> trāsanaṃ tāḍanaṃ bandho māraṇaṃ vṛttināśanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>bandho</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; baddho \msNb, bandha \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Frightening and beating [other people], tying [someone] up, killing,
            and the destruction of [other people's] livelihood:</TR>

% Flo: CHECK parallels for 5 types
<TEXT> hiṃsāṃ pañcavidhām{ }āhur{ }munayas{ }tattvadarśinaḥ||</TEXT> 3:18
        <APP>\vc <LEM>hiṃsāṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc; hiṃsā \msCb\msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°vidhām{ }āhu°</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNc; °vidham{ }āhu° \msCa,
                                        °vidhāny{ }āhu° \msNb, °vidha prāhu° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>violence is said by the wise who see the truth to be of [these] five types.</TR>

% TĀḌANA PEOPLE
<TEXT> kāṣṭhaloṣṭakaśādyais{ }tu tāḍayantīha nirdayāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kāṣṭhaloṣṭa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; kā<UNCL>ṣṭha</UNCL>\lac\ ×× \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>nirdayāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; nirdayā \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Cruel people beat [other people] with sticks, clods of earth [i.e. they stone them], 
                       with whips and other [objects] in the everyday world.</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.590
        %                            capital/corporal punishment? (emend to vadham?) metri causa
<TEXT> tatprahāravibhinnāṅgo mṛtavadhyam{ }avāpnuyāt||</TEXT> 3:19
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°bhinnāṅgo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °bhinnāṅgā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°vadhyam{ }avā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °vadhyavavā° \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the use of the singular (°Łāṅgo$... Łavāpnuyāt$) in Łpāda$s cd 
              referring back to the plural agents of the previous sentence.
              Most probably, °Łvadhyam$ is to be understood as °Łvadham$ and the form 
              Łvadhyam$ serves only to avoid two Łlaghu$ syllables in Łpāda$ d.
              (See the word Łvadha$ in the next three verses.)</NOTE>
        <TR>Their bodies broken by the same blows, they receive the capital punishment.</TR>
% vadha:  (in law) capital or (more commonly) corporal punishment, Mn.


% BANDHA PEOPLE
<TEXT> baddhvā pādau bhujoraś{ }ca śirorukkaṇṭhapāśitāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>bhujoraś{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc; bhujauraś{ }ca \msNa\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śirorukkaṇṭha°</LEM> \eme; śirorukaṇṭha° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc, śiroruḥ kaṇṭha° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łbhujoraś ca$ in Łpāda$ a as Łbhuje,
              urasi ca$, in this case with an instance of double sandhi,
              and in \stemform: Łbhuje urasi ca$ \rightarrow\ Łbhuja urasi ca$ 
              \rightarrow\ Łbhujorasi ca$ \rightarrow\ Łbhujoraś ca$.
              Alternatively, understand it as a compound (Łbhujorasi$). 
              In Łpāda$ b, my emendation is only one of the possible interpretations. We might accept
              Łśiroru$° as consisting of Łśira$ + Łūru$ (`head and thigh'), or emend it 
              to Łśiroraḥ$° for Łśira$ + Łuraḥ$ (`head and chest'). Also note my conjecture
              in Łpāda$ d, without which this Łpāda$ is difficult to interpret.</NOTE>
        <TR>[Others] tie up [people] at their feet, arms and chest.
                 [These,] hung by their hair and neck,</TR>

<TEXT> anāhatā mriyanty{ }evaṃ vadho bandhanajaḥ smṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 3:20
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>anāhatā mriyanty{ }evaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; anāhata mriyaṃty{ }eṣa \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°najaḥ smṛtaḥ</LEM> \conj; °najāḥ smṛtāḥ \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb,
                                                                 °najāḥ smṛtā \msNc, °naja smṛtaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>die in this way without being wounded. 
                        This is the capital punishment for tying up [other people].</TR>
        % The conjecture in and translation of Łpāda$ d are tentative. but I believe that we
        %        should understand it as Łvadho bandhajanānāṃ smṛtaḥ$. (Or Łvadho bandhanajaḥ smṛtaḥ$?? Or rather
        %        Łvadhyā bandhajanāḥ smṛtāḥ$ ??)
% Judit for bandhanajaḥ smṛtam

<PAGEBREAK/>

% TRĀSANA PEOPLE
<TEXT> śatrucaurabhayair{ }ghoraiḥ siṃhavyāghragajoragaiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°caurabhayair{ }ghoraiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °corabhayai ghorai \msNb</APP>
        <TR>He who frightens [other people] with the terrible danger of enemies and thieves,
                 with lions, tigers, elephants or snakes,</TR>

<TEXT> trāsanād{ }vadham{ }āpnoti anyair{ }vāpi suduḥsahaiḥ||</TEXT> 3:21
        <APP>\vd <LEM>anyair{ }vāpi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; anye cāpi \msNc</APP>
        <TR>or by other horrors, will be executed.</TR>

% VṚTTINĀŚANA PEOPLE   
<TEXT> yasya yasya hared{ }vittaṃ tasya tasya vadhaḥ smṛtaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>hared{ }vi°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; hare vi° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vadhaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; vadha \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Perhaps understand Łvadhaḥ$ in Łpāda$ b as Łvadhyaḥ$ metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>He who robs somebody's money is to be punished by the same person.</TR>

<TEXT> vṛttijīvābhibhūtānāṃ taddvārā nihataḥ smṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 3:22
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°bhibhūtānāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °vibhūtānāṃ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>taddvārā ni°</LEM> \conj; tadvārān{ }ni° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc, taddvārān{ }ni° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>My translation of the second line of this verse reflects a conjecture (Łtaddvārā$)
              understood as connected to both Łpāda$ c and Łnihataḥ$ in Łpāda$ d.
              The plural genitive in Łpāda$ c and the instrumental Łtaddvārā$ are perhaps to be taken as 
              plural instrumentals: °Łbhibhūtais tair$.</NOTE>
        <TR>He is [to be] struck down by those whose livelihood got damaged by him.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 411.jpg, 205r
% MĀRAṆA PEOPLE
<TEXT> viṣavahniśaraśastrair{ }māyāyogabalena vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°śastrair{ }māyā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; °śastrai mā° \msNc, °śastrair{ }mmayā° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[Those who kill other people] with poison, fire, arrows, swords, or by the force of 
                                magic or yoga,</TR>

%index_metre: sa-vipulā

<TEXT> hiṃsakāny{ }āhu viprendra munayas{ }tattvadarśinaḥ||</TEXT> 3:23
        <APP>\vc <LEM>hiṃsakāny{ }āhu vi°</LEM> \msCb\msNb\msNc; 
                                hiṃsakāny{ }āhur{ }vi° \msCa\msNa\ \unmetr, hiṃsakety{ }āhu vi° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>are called murderers by the sages who see the truth, O great Brahmin.</TR>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is a Łsa-vipulā$.
                Note how elliptical this verse is and that Łhiṃsakāni$ is neuter although it refers to 
                people, perhaps implying Łbhūtāni$. Alternatively, take Ły$ in Łhiṃsakāny$ as a 
                rather unusual sandhi-bridge (Łhiṃsakān-y-āhu$), or simply delete this Ły$. 
                Note also that Łāhu$ stands for Łāhur$ metri causa.</NOTE>


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>ahiṃsāpraśaṃsā</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Praise of non-violence</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> ahiṃsā paramaṃ dharmaṃ yas{ }tyajet{ }sa durātmavān|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>paramaṃ dharmaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; paramaṃ dharma \msNb, paramo dharmaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tyajet{ }sa durātmavān</LEM> \msCb\msNc\Ed; tyajec{ }cha durātma\lk\ \msCa, tyajet{ }sudurātmavān \msNa,
                                tyajet{ }sa durātmanam \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Non-violence is the highest Dharma. He who abandons it is a wicked person.</TR>

% Śaiva Utopia p15

%folioinfo \msCa\ 391.jpg
<TEXT> kleśāyāsavinirmuktaṃ sarvadharmaphalapradam||</TEXT> 3:24
        <NOTE>Note Łdharma$ as a neuter noun in Łpāda$ a and that °Łvinirmuktaṃ$ and
                        °Łpradam$ are neuter accordingly.</NOTE>
        <TR>It is free of pain and trouble, it yields the fruits of all [other] Dharmic teachings [in itself].</TR>

<TEXT> nātaḥ parataro mūrkho nātaḥ parataraṃ tamaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°taraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCbpcorr\msNa\msNb\msNc; °tan \msCbacorr\Ed</APP>
        <TR>There is no bigger fool than one [that abandons it]. There is no bigger mental darkness
                                [than the abandonment of non-violence].</TR>

<TEXT> nātaḥ parataraṃ duḥkhaṃ nātaḥ parataro 'yaśaḥ||</TEXT> 3:25
        <NOTE>Note that Łparataro$ is masculine in Łpāda$ d, picking up a neuter Ł'yaśaḥ$.
        This phenomenon is probably the result of Ł'yaśaḥ$ resembling a masculine noun ending in Ł-aḥ$
        and also of the metrical problem with a grammatically correct Łnātaḥ parataram ayaśaḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>There is no greater suffering or greater infamy.</TR>

<TEXT> nātaḥ parataraṃ pāpaṃ nātaḥ parataraṃ viṣam|</TEXT>
        <TR>There is no greater sin or a more effective poison.</TR>

<TEXT> nātaḥ paratarāvidyā nātaḥ paraṃ tapodhana||</TEXT> 3:26
        <APP>\vd <LEM>paraṃ tapodhana</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; para tapodyamāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ d is slightly suspect. 
                The vocative Łtapodhana$ usually refers to Anarthayajña in these
                passages, and not to Vigatarāga, as here.  The text may have read Łnātaḥ paratamo 'dhanaḥ$ 
                (`There is no bigger loss of wealth') or possibly something starting with
                Łnātaḥ paraṃ tapo ...$ (`There is no greater\dots\ of austerity').
                Perhaps Łnātaḥ paraṃ tapo'ntakam$ (`There is no greater destroyer of penance')?</NOTE>
        <TR>There is no greater ignorance, there is nothing worse, O great ascetic.</TR>

% Judit: it is ok
% Kengo likes adhanaḥ 
% tapodhana is ok for Vigatarāga? Florinda

%folioinfo \msNc\ 216.jpg lower, f. 214r
<TEXT> yo hinasti na bhūtāni udbhijjādi caturvidham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>yo hinasti na</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; yo na hinsanti \msNb, yo hi nāsti na \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>udbhijjādi</LEM> \eme; udbhijādi \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed, udbhijāni \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°vidham</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; °vidhiṃ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>He who does not harm [any of] the four types of living beings, beginning with plants,</TR>
% udbhidādi is another possibility ('a plant')

<TEXT> sa bhavet{ }puruṣaḥ śreṣṭhaḥ sarvabhūtadayānvitaḥ||</TEXT> 3:27
        <APP>\vc <LEM>puruṣaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; puruṣa° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>is the best person, because he has compassion for all creatures.</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>
       % dayān \msCa\Ed
<TEXT> sarvabhūtadayāṃ nityaṃ yaḥ karoti sa paṇḍitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dayāṃ nityaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\Ed; °dayā nityaṃ \msCb\msNb, °dayā nitya \msNc</APP>
        <TR>He who always has compassion for all creatures is the [true] Paṇḍit.</TR>

<TEXT> sa yajvā sa tapasvī ca sa dātā sa dṛḍhavrataḥ||</TEXT> 3:28
        <APP>\vc <LEM>yajvā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; yajyā \msNb</APP>
        <TR>He is the [true] sacrificer, the [true] ascetic, he is a [real] donor, one with a firm vow.</TR>

<TEXT> ahiṃsā paramaṃ tīrtham{ }ahiṃsā paramaṃ tapaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>paramaṃ tī°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; paran{ }tī° \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Non-violence is the supreme pilgrimage place. Non-violence is the highest austerity.</TR>
% Ł\similar\ MBh 13.117.37cd: $ ahiṃsā paramaṃ dānam{ }ahiṃsā paramaṃ tapaḥ

%folioinfo \msCc\ resumes here in 189.jpg, f. 273r (sic!) with ramaṃ sukham  (3.30b) 
%lacuna_end: msCc
<TEXT> ahiṃsā paramaṃ dānam{ }ahiṃsā paramaṃ sukham||</TEXT> 3:29
        <TR>Non-violence is the highest donation. Non-violence is the highest joy.</TR>
        <PARAL>\vo ŁThis and the following verses are similar to MBh 13.117.37--38$</PARAL>
        <LACUNA>\vd Ł\msCc\ resumes here in exp.\ 189, f. 273r (sic!) with $ramaṃ sukham</LACUNA>
        % See also Umā 3.43ff and the same in the Lalitavistara
        % Śivadharmottatra 3 is similar when talking about jñānayoga Florinda

<TEXT> ahiṃsā paramo yajñaḥ ahiṃsā paramaṃ vratam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>yajñaḥ</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNb\Ed; yajñar \msCa, yajña \msNa\msNc</APP>
        <TR>Non-violence is the supreme sacrifice. Non-violence is the supreme religious observance.</TR>

<TEXT> ahiṃsā paramaṃ jñānam{ }ahiṃsā paramā kriyā||</TEXT> 3:30
        <APP>\vc <LEM>paramaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; paramo \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>paramā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; paramāṃ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Non-violence is supreme knowledge. Non-violence is the supreme ritual.</TR>

<TEXT> ahiṃsā paramaṃ śaucam{ }ahiṃsā paramo damaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>(ahiṃsāŁ...$ damaḥ)</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \om\ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Non-violence is the highest purity. Non-violence is the highest self-restraint.</TR>

<TEXT> ahiṃsā paramo lābhaḥ ahiṃsā paramaṃ yaśaḥ||</TEXT> 3:31
        <APP>\vc <LEM>lābhaḥ</LEM> \msNc; lābha \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed, lābho \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>paramaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; paramā \msNa</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vcd ŁAfter pādas cd, \Ed\ inserts this: $ahiṃsā paramā kīrti ahiṃsā paramo damaḥ,
                 Łwhich is not to be found in \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\ (or in
                 paper MS \msPaperA)$</LACUNA>
        <TR>Non-violence is the highest profit. Non-violence is the greatest fame.</TR>

<TEXT> ahiṃsā paramo dharmaḥ ahiṃsā paramā gatiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dharmaḥ</LEM> \msNa\msNc; dharma \msCa\msCb\Ed, dharmo \msCc, dha\lac\ × \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>ahiṃsā paramā gatiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; \lac\ ×××××××× \msNb, ahiṃsā paramo gatiḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Non-violence is the supreme Dharma. Non-violence is the supreme path.</TR>
        % \vab = Mahāsubhāṣitāsaṃgraha 4082ab
        % \vab \similar\ Umāmaheśvarasaṃvāda 3.43cd 

        %                                   paramo \Ed
<TEXT> ahiṃsā paramaṃ brahma ahiṃsā paramaḥ śivaḥ||</TEXT> 3:32
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>ahiṃsā paramaṃ brahma</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed;
                                <UNCL>ahiṃsā paramaṃ brahma</UNCL> \msNb, ahiṃsā paraṃmaṃ brahma \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Łśiva$ in Łpāda$ d may or may not refer to the deity Śiva. The last sentence may simply
              mean: `Non-violence is the supreme good.'</NOTE>
        <TR>Non-violence is the supreme Brahman. Non-violence is supreme Śiva.</TR>




<SUBSUBCHAPTER>māṃsāhāraḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Meat-consumption</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> māṃsāśanān{ }nivarteta manasāpi na kāṅkṣayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>māṃsāśanān{ }ni°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\Ed; mānsāśana ni° \msCc,
                                māṃsāśanan{ }ni° \msNa, mansāsanan{ }ni° \msNb, <UNCL>māṃsaśānān{ }ni</UNCL>° \msNc</APP>
        <TR>One should refrain from meat-consumption. One should not even desire it mentally.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 199.jpg lower, f.6r
<TEXT> sa mahat{ }phalam{ }āpnoti yas{ }tu māṃsaṃ vivarjayet||</TEXT> 3:33
        <APP>\vd <LEM>māṃsaṃ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa; māṃsa \msNb\Ed, māsaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>He who abandons meat will receive a great reward.</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> svamāṃsaṃ paramāṃsena yo vardhayitum{ }icchati|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°māṃsena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °māsena \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vardhayitu°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; varddhayati \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł = \MBH\ 13.116.14ab and 13.116.34ab \similar\ \UUMS\ 2.48cd:
                         $svamāṃsaṃ paramāṃsena yo dehe vṛddhim{ }icchati</PARAL>
        <NOTE>See \UUMS\ chapter two for a similar section on meat-consumption. 
              The present verse is a variant on \MANU\ 5.52 (see apparatus).</NOTE>
        <TR>He who wishes to nourish his own flesh with the flesh of other [beings],</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ resumes here 417.jpg lower, f. 6r
        % arca \Ed
<TEXT> anabhyarcya pitṝn{ }devān{ }na tato 'nyo 'sti pāpakṛt||</TEXT> 3:34
        <APP>\vc <LEM>pitṝn</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; pitṛn \msCc\Ed, <UNCL>pitṝn</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tato 'nyo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tad{ }anyo \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\similar\ \MANU\ 5.52 (Olivelle's edition):$ 
                svamāṃsaṃ paramāṃsena yo vardhayitum{ }icchati |
                anabhyarcya pitṝn{ }devān{ }na tato 'nyo sty{ }apuṇyakṛt ||</PARAL>
        <TR>outside of worshipping the ancestors and the gods, is the biggest sinner of all.</TR>

%index_ref: Manu

% madhuparka : `honey-mixture' in Śaiva Utopia p.37
<TEXT> madhuparke ca yajñe ca pitṛdaivatakarmaṇi|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°daivata°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °devata° \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>This verse is a variant of \MANU\ 5.41.</NOTE>
        <TR>During the honey-mixture offering (Łmadhuparka$) and during a sacrifice, during rituals 
                                                for the ancestors and the gods:</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ here ends 47.jpg upper (the lower leaf contains some text that I cannot identify)
<TEXT> atraiva paśavo hiṃsyā nānyatra manur{ }abravīt||</TEXT> 3:35
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>atraiva paśavo hiṃsyā</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNc\Ed; 
                                        atraiva paśavo hiṃsā \msCb, atraiva paśavo hiṃsyān \msNa,
                                                        \lac\ ×××××××× \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>nānyatra manur{ }abravīt</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; 
                                        \lac ××<UNCL>tra manur{ }abravīt</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\similar\ \MANU\ 5.41 (Olivelle's edition):$
                        madhuparke ca yajñe ca pitṛdaivatakarmaṇi|
                        atraiva paśavo hiṃsyā nānyatrety{ }abravīn{ }manuḥ||</PARAL>
        <TR>only in these cases are animals to be slaughtered and not in any other case.
                                                [This is what] Manu taught.</TR>

%index_ref: Manu
% Aśoka says sg. similar Sathya

%folioinfo \msNb\ 48.jpg lower sic!
<TEXT> krītvā svayaṃ vāpy{ }utpādya paropahṛtam{ }eva vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>krītvā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; kṛtvā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°py{ }utpādya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °py{ }utpādyā° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°hṛta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °hita° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>vā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ca \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Should he buy it or procure it himself or should it be offered by others,</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<TEXT> devān{ }pitṝṃś{ }cārcayitvā khādan{ }māṃsaṃ na doṣabhāk||</TEXT> 3:36
        <APP>\vc <LEM>pitṝṃś{ }cārcayitvā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; pitṝś{ }cārcayitvā \msNb, pitṛś{ }cārpayitvā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>māṃsaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; māsaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>This verse is \MANU\ 5.32.</NOTE>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł= \MANU\ 5.32 (in Olivelle's critical edition; other editions read$
                         paropakṛta° Łin pāda b)$</PARAL>
        <TR>if he eats meat, he will not sin if he first worships the gods and the ancestors.</TR>

<TEXT> vedayajñatapastīrthadānaśīlakriyāvrataiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°śīla°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °śala° \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°vrataiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °vra<UNCL>taḥ</UNCL> \msCb</APP>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.591
<TEXT> māṃsāhāranivṛttānāṃ ṣoḍaśāṃśaṃ na pūryate||</TEXT> 3:37
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vṛttānāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °vṛttānā \msNb, °vṛttīnāṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>na</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ta \msCb</APP>
        <TR>[People who perform] Vedic sacrifices and austerities, and [visit] sacred places,
        donate, [those who are of] good conduct, [perform] rituals and [keep] religious vows,
        [but eat meat] will not [be able to] enjoy even the sixteenth part of [such rewards that those]
        people [receive] who have given up meat.</TR>
        <NOTE>As for Łpāda$ d, see a similarly phrased comparison in \MANU\ 2.86:
                <sep/>
                       Łye pākayajñās catvāro vidhiyajñasamanvitāḥ$ |<br/>
                       Łsarve te japayajñasya kalāṃ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīm$ ||
                <sep/>
               In Olivelle's translation (<citeyear>OlivelleManu</citeyear>, 99):
              `The four types of cooked oblations along with the sacrifices 
               consisting of prescribed rites---all these are not worth a sixteenth part 
               of the sacrifice consisting of soft recitation.'</NOTE>

%MMW gava: in comp. before a word beginning with a vowel
<TEXT> mṛgāḥ parṇatṛṇāhārād{ }ajameṣagavādibhiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va  <LEM>parṇa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; paṇṇa° \msNa, parṇā° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°hārād{ }a°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNbpcorr\msNc\Ed; °hārā a° \msCb\msNa, °hād{ }a° \msNbacorr</APP>

<TEXT> sukhino balavantaś{ }ca vicaranti mahītale||</TEXT> 3:38
        <TR>Deer and goats, sheep, cows and other [animals] wander in the world
                 happily and in great strength [just] from eating leaves and grass.</TR>

<TEXT> vānarāḥ phala{-}m{-}āhārā rākṣasā rudhirapriyāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°hārā rā°</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb; °hārād{ }rā° \msCa\msCc\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łphalam āhārā$ as Łphalāhārā$ (Ł-m-$ is a sandhi-bridge).</NOTE>
        <TR>Monkeys eat fruits, Rākṣasas prefer blood.</TR>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

% Kenji Pāṇini does not like bhojin?
<TEXT> nihatā rākṣasāḥ sarve vānaraiḥ phalabhojibhiḥ||</TEXT> 3:39
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°bhojibhiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °bhogibhiḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>This verse clearly refers to the story of the ŁRāmāyaṇa$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The fruit-eating monkeys defeated all the Rākṣasas.</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> tasmān{ }māṃsaṃ na hīheta balakāmena bho dvija|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>māṃsaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; māsaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>hīheta</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; hīyeta \msNa\msNb</APP>
        <TR>Therefore one should not crave meat in the hope of gaining strength, O Brahmin,</TR>

% ākāśa = saṃkāśa? Judit  or kāma for kāśāt? 
% guṇākarṣāt pull the string with force Judit KCs
% ākāṅkṣa? Flo
% want to have strings CsK
<TEXT> balena ca guṇākarṣāt{ }parato bhayabhīruṇā||</TEXT> 3:40
        <APP>\vc <LEM>guṇākarṣā°</LEM> \conjTorzsok; guṇākāśā° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, guṇā kuryā° \Ed</APP>
       <TR>in order to be able to draw a bow with force,
                        or out of fear of the danger coming from the enemy.</TR>
        <NOTE>Łguṇākāśāt$ in Łpāda$ c is difficult to interpret and 
                Łguṇākarṣāt$ is a conjecture by Judit Törzsök which fits the context well,
                although the polysemy of Łguṇa$ may allow for other solutions.</NOTE>
%        <sep/>
%        Verses 3.40--42 may be echoing \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 216.64--66:
%        <sep/>
%                      Ł māṃsān miṣṭataraṃ nāsti bhakṣyabhojyādikeṣu ca |
%                        tasmān māṃsaṃ na bhuñjīta nāsti miṣṭaiḥ sukhodayaḥ || 
%                        gosahasraṃ tu yo dadyād yas tu māṃsaṃ na bhakṣayet |
%                        samāv etau purā prāha brahmā vedavidāṃ varaḥ ||
%                        sarvatīrtheṣu yat puṇyaṃ sarvayajñeṣu yat phalam |
%                        amāṃsabhakṣaṇe viprās tac ca tac ca ca tatsamam ||$.

% REVISE
% samīhayā Flo even if others make sacrificies Judit agrees
<TEXT> ahiṃsakasamo nāsti dānayajñasamīhayā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°yajñasamīhayā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; °dharmasamīhayā \msCc,
                                                °yajñasamīhayāḥ \msNc, °dharmasamīhaya \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the variant °Łdharma$° in both \msCc\ and \Ed\ in Łpāda$ b.
                ŁPāda$s ab are reminiscent of \SDHS\ 11.92: <sep/>
                                Łahiṃsaikā paro dharmaḥ śaktānāṃ parikīrtitam$ |<br/>
                                Łaśaktānām ayaṃ dharmo dānayajñādipūrvakaḥ$ ||
                <sep/>
                On the above verse see also <citep>SaivaUtopia</citep><pnum>15--16</pnum>.</NOTE>
        <TR>By wishing to make donations and perform sacrifices no one will become comparable 
                to someone who refrains from violence.</TR>

<TEXT> iha loke yaśaḥ kīrtiḥ paratra ca parā gatiḥ||</TEXT> 3:41
        <APP>\vc <LEM>yaśaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ya<UNCL>śaṃ</UNCL> \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>parā gatiḥ</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNc; <UNCL>parā gatiḥ</UNCL> \msCa, 
                                                parāṅgatim \msCb\msNb, parāṃ gatiḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[Such a person will have] fame and glory in this world and the supreme path in the other.</TR>

% referring back to prev verse Judit
%folioinfo \msCa\ 392.jpg
<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
%        -  -  -   . . -  . -  .    .  . -   -  -  . -   -  . -
<TEXT> trailokyaṃ maṇiratnapūrṇam{ }akhilaṃ dattvottame brāhmaṇe</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>trailokyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; trailokya \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>akhilaṃ dattvottame brāhmaṇe</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                        a<UNCL>khilaṃ</UNCL>\lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\ \msCa, akhilaṃ dattottame brāhmaṇe \msNa</APP>
        <PARAL>\va Ł\SDHS\ 11.91:$
                   trailokyam{ }api yo dadyād{ }akhilaṃ ratnapūritam |
                   caret{ }tapāṃsi sarvāṇi na tattulyam{ }ahiṃsayā ||</PARAL>

% Nirajan koṭīyajña! is a ritual CHECK koṭihoma
% it is also a tīrtha! CsK                        
%       - - -  . . -  . -  .   .  . -   -  -  .  -  -  . -
<TEXT> koṭīyajñasahasrapadmam{ }ayutaṃ dattvā mahīṃ dakṣiṇām|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>koṭīyajñasahasrapadmam</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\  \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>mahīṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; mahī \msCc</APP>

%       -   - -   .  . -  . - . . .  -   -  -  . -  - . -
<TEXT> tīrthānāṃ ca sahasrakoṭiniyutaṃ snātvā sakṛn{ }mānava</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°koṭi°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °koṭī° \Ed\ \unmetr\oo
                 <LEM>snātvā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; snā ' \msCb</APP>
% all read mānava actually, my correction of the sandhi

%      - -     -  .  . -?   . -  . . . -    -  - .  -  -  . -
% unmetrical
<TEXT> etatpuṇyaphalam{ }ahiṃsakajanaḥ prāpnoti niḥsaṃśayaḥ||</TEXT> 3:42
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°phalam{ }ahiṃsa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °phalaṃ tv{ }ahiṃsa° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>niḥsaṃśayaḥ</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msCa, niḥsaṃśaya\lk\ \msCb, niḥsaṃśayaṃ \Ed</APP>
        % nissaṃśayaḥ \msCc, niḥsaṃśayaḥ \msNa
        <TR>A person who refrains from violence will gain,
                 no doubt about it, the [same] meritorious rewards
                 that others would get by donating the three worlds filled with jewels and 
                 gems in their entirety to an excellent Brahmin,
                 by [performing] a thousand times ten trillion (Łpadma$)
                 times ten thousand (Łayuta$) Łkoṭīyajña$ sacrifices,
                 by donating the earth [to a priest] as sacrificial fee,
                 and by bathing [at] a thousand times ten million times a million (Łniyuta$) 
                                                sacred places at once.</TR>

        <NOTE>Metre: Łśārdūlavikrīḍita$. 
                Note that the second syllable of Łphalam$ in Łpāda$ d is treated as long: this
                happens often at word-boundaries in this text (see p.~\pageref{muta}); and 
                note how \msNc\ aims to restore the metre by inserting Łtv$ after its Łphalaṃ$.
                On Łpadma$ meaning `ten trillion', and on other words for numbers, see 1.31--35. 
                <sep/>
                Łkoṭīyajña$ in Łpāda$ d may refer to a special kind of sacrifice, 
                mostly known as Łkoṭihoma$ in the Purāṇas and in inscriptions 
                (see, e.g., <citep>Fleming2010</citep><pnum>and 2013</pnum><nocite>Fleming2013</nocite>).
                It involves a hundred fire-pits 
                and a hundred times one thousand Brahmins (hence the name `the ten-million sacrifice').
                See, e.g., \BHAVP\ Łuttaraparvan$ 4.142.54--58:
                <sep/>
                           Łśatānano daśamukho dvimukhaikamukhas tathā$ |<br/>
                           Łcaturvidho mahārāja koṭihomo vidhīyate$ || <br/>
                           Łkāryasya gurutāṃ jñātvā naiva kuryād aparvaṇi$ |<br/>
                           Łyathā saṃkṣepataḥ kāryaḥ koṭihomas tathā śṛṇu$ ||<br/>
                           Łkṛtvā kuṇḍaśataṃ divyaṃ yathoktaṃ hastasaṃmitam$ |<br/>
                           Łekaikasmiṃs tataḥ kuṇḍe śataṃ viprān niyojayet$ ||<br/>
                           Łsadyaḥ pakṣe tu viprāṇāṃ sahasraṃ parikīrtitam$ |<br/>
                           Łekasthānapraṇīte 'gnau sarvataḥ paribhāvite$ || <br/>
                           Łhomaṃ kuryur dvijāḥ sarve kuṇḍe kuṇḍe yathoditam$ |<br/>
                           Łyathā kuṇḍabahutve 'pi rājasūye mahākratau$ ||
                        <sep/>
                Note \SDHS\ 10.91 (see apparatus), a statement on Łahiṃsā$ which is
                similar to the present verse.</NOTE>

%index_metre: long syllable at end of word
%index_metre: śārdūlavikrīḍita
%Peter Bisschop studied the kotihoma CHECK

%folioinfo \msNc\ 217.jpg upper, f. 214v
<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> <COLOPHON>iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe ahiṃsāpraśaṃsā nāmādhyāyas{ }tṛtīyaḥ</COLOPHON></TEXT>
        <APP> Ł\Colo:$ <LEM>nāmādhyāyas{ }tṛtīyaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; nāmādhyāyas{ }tṛtīya \msNc,
                        nāmas{ }tṛtīyo 'dhyāyaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TRCOLOPHON>Here ends the third chapter in the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ called Praise of Non-violence.</TRCOLOPHON>
%END OF CHAPTER 3


%folioinfo \msCc\ 190.jpg, f. 273v(? probably OK, the folio does read 273, thus also online)

        %%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
        % great emphasis on ahiṃsā, longest section in the yama rules

% Balogh article on yati ! Asked him, no solution; same in Paramārthasevā...

<startchapter-n="4"/>
%folioinfo \msCa\ 392.jpg
%folioinfo \msCb\ 413.jpg
%folioinfo \msCc\ 190.jpg
%folioinfo \msNa\ 199.jpg lower, f.6r line 5
%folioinfo \msNb\ 48.jpg lower
%folioinfo \msNc\ 217.jpg upper line 1, 214v
%folioinfo \msM\ 417.jpg lower, f. 6r line 4 
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.591

%chapter 4: 
<CHAPTER>caturtho 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>
<TRCHAPTER> Chapter Four </TRCHAPTER>

<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣu satyam (2)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Second Yama-rule: truthfulness</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
                <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR>
% \msM\ omits this anarthayajña uvāca (again) see start of chapter 12
        <LACUNA>ŁWitnesses used for this chapter: \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 198v--201v,
                                              \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 206r--208v,
                                              \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 273v--277r,
                                              \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 6r--9r,
                                              \msNb\ exp.\thinspace 48--50 (lower--upper),
                                              \msNc\ ff.\thinspace 214v--217r,
                                              \Ed\ pp.\thinspace 591--597;
                                        \mssCaCbCc\ = \msCa + \msCb + \msCc$</LACUNA>

% also etymology (Flo)
<TEXT> sadbhāvaḥ satyam{ }ity{ }āhur{ }dṛṣṭapratyayam{ }eva vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>sadbhāvaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; sadbhāva° \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>satyam{ }ity{ }āhur{ }dṛ°</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; satya<UNCL>m{ }i</UNCL>\-ty{ }āhu dṛ° \msCa,
                                satyam{ }ity{ }āhu dṛ° \msCc, satyām{ }ity{ }āhur{ }dṛ° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°pratyaya°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; °pratya° \msCc, °pratyeya° \msNc, pratyakṣa° \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\va Ł\similar\ \MBH\ 12.288.45d:$ 
                        sadbhāvaḥ satyam{ }ucyate 
                   Ł\compare\  also \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 3.3.86ab:$
                        asadbhāvo 'nṛtaṃ jñeyaṃ sadbhāvaḥ satyam{ }ucyate </PARAL>
        <TR>The state of being real (Łsad-bhāva$) is called truth (Łsat-ya$).
            Alternatively, it is also a certainty (Łpratyaya$) that originates in perception (Łdṛṣṭa$).</TR>
% see 15.7

% Oberhammer Lucas
% Kenji check satya in Yogasūtra (satyā)
<TEXT> yathābhūtārthakathanaṃ tat{ }satyakathanaṃ smṛtam||</TEXT> 4:1
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>yathābhūtārthakathanaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; 
                                                      yathābhūtārtha \msCcacorr,
                                                      yathābhūtārthanaṃ kta \msCcpcorr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tat{ }satyakathanaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                        tat{ }satyakathakaṃ \msCb,
                                                        kathanaṃ smṛtaṃ \msCcacorr,
                                                        <UNCL>satyaka ja</UNCL>kathanaṃ smṛtaṃ \msCcpcorr</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\compare\ \SDHS\ 11.105:$ 
                svānubhūtaṃ svadṛṣṭaṃ ca yaḥ pṛṣṭārthaṃ na gūhati|
                yathābhūtārthakathanam{ }ity{ }etat{ }satyalakṣaṇam||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Compare \SDHS\ 11.105:
                <sep/>
                 Łsvānubhūtaṃ svadṛṣṭaṃ ca yaḥ pṛṣṭārthaṃ na gūhati$ |<br/>
                 Łyathābhūtārthakathanam ity etat satyalakṣaṇam$ ||
                <sep/>
                 Translation in <citep>SaivaUtopia</citep><pnum>p.~124</pnum>:
                `If one does not conceal a matter one is asked about, whether
                 it was experienced by oneself or witnessed with one's own eyes,
                 but gives an account of things as they happened, this is the definition of `truth.' '
                This verse makes it tempting to emend Łsatyakathanaṃ$ to Łsatyalakṣaṇaṃ$ in \VSS\ 4.1d, but 
                I rather take the \VSS\ verse to introduce two views on truth: one philosophical,
                and one ordinary that relates to the moral aspect of truthfulness.
                Also consider the commentator's remark on the same verse in the \SDHS\ 
                (11.105; <citep>SaivaUtopia</citep><pnum>p.~124 n.~181 and p.~143</pnum>):
                Łyathābhūtārthakathane prāṇivadhaprāptāv asatyasya sādhutvāt para pīḍāvinirmuktam eva satyam ity āha$.
                Translation ibid.: `\dots\ he states that [speech is] truth
                only as long as it is devoid of harm of others, for untruth is good when giving an
                account of something as it really happened will result in the slaughter of a living
                creature.'</NOTE>
        <TR>Relating things in a way that corresponds to reality is called `speaking the truth.'</TR>

%index_metre: na-vipulā

% Ed kroṣa 
<TEXT> ākrośatāḍanādīni yaḥ saheta suduḥsaham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°tāḍanā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °nāḍanā° \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>suduḥsaham</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sudusahaṃ \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Łsuduḥsaham$ (singular) in Łpāda$ b picks up °Łādīni$ (plural) in Łpāda$ a.</NOTE>
        <TR>He who endures severe abuse and beating etc.</TR>

%index_grammar: singular for plural, Newari? 

% ŚDh 11.82 Nirajan
<TEXT> kṣamate yo jitātmā tu sa ca satyam{ }udāhṛtam||</TEXT> 4:2
        <APP>\vd <LEM>satyam{ }udāhṛtam</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; 
        <UNCL>satya</UNCL>m{ }u<UNCL>dā</UNCL>hṛtam \msCa</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare\ \SDHS\ 11.82:$
                ākruṣṭas{ }tāḍito vāpi yo nākrośen{ }na tāḍayet |
                vāgādy{ }avikṛtaḥ svasthaṃ kṣāntir{ }eṣā sunirmalā ||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>The Ł-m$ in Łsatyam$ may be a sandhi-bridge and the phrase may refer to a
              masculine subject (`a truthful person') thus: Łsa ca satya-m-udāhṛtaḥ$.
              Compare with \SDHS\ 11.82 (see apparatus), which is a definition of
              forbearance (Łkṣānti$).</NOTE>
        <TR>and resists [giving\linebreak away secrets], his self being conquered,
            is said to be [an example of] truth[ful\-ness].</TR>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

% CHECK ŚDh (??)
<TEXT> vadhārtham{ }udyataḥ śastraṃ yadi pṛccheta karhicit|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dyataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dyata \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>śastraṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; satya \msCb\Ed, śastra \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>karhicit</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\Ed; karhacit \msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łudyataḥ$ (nom.) in an active sense (`holding/lifting').</NOTE>
        <TR>If one is being interrogated at any time with a sword lifted to strike him down,</TR>

<TEXT> na tatra satyaṃ vaktavyam{ }anṛtaṃ satyam{ }ucyate||</TEXT> 4:3
        <APP>\vc <LEM>satyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; satya \msCb\Ed</APP>
        <TR>in this case the truth is not to be spoken, and a lie can be called truth.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<PAGEBREAK/>

% ŚDh (??)
<TEXT> vadhārhaḥ puruṣaḥ kaścid{ }vrajet{ }pathi bhayāturaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°turaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °tura \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>`being killed' is not the most obvious translation for
              Łvadhārhaḥ$ in Łpāda$ a, but the context suggests that it is not
              a person who `deserves death' that may have been intended.</NOTE>
        <TR>A person who is walking on the road and is afraid of being killed</TR>

<TEXT> pṛcchato 'pi na vaktavyaṃ satyaṃ tad{ }vāpi ucyate||</TEXT> 4:4
        <APP>\vc <LEM>pṛcchato</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; pṛcchate \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tad{ }vāpi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; tad{ }api \msNb</APP>
        <TR>should not reply to [people who are potentially dangerous] even if they ask him. 
                        This is also called truth[fulness].</TR>
% pṛcchato gen. he should not answer he who is afraid Judit
% vadhārha as a innocent person... Flo Judit
% ŚDh 11 comm Nirajan on asat! p. 9



<NOTANUSTUBH/> upajāti
%       .  -  . -  .?   . . -   . -  .  
<TEXT> na narmayuktam{ }anṛtaṃ hinasti</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>hinasti</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc; hi nāsti \msCc\msNa\Ed</APP>

%index_metre: long syllable at end of word

%       -    - .  - -     .  . - . - -
<TEXT> na strīṣu rājan{ }na vivāhakāle|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>rājan{ }na</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; rāja na \msCc, rājyaṃ na \msNa</APP>

%        -  -  . -  -  .  . - . - -  
<TEXT> prāṇātyaye sarvadhanāpahāre</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°tyaye</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °tyaje \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°pahāre</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °prahāre \msCc\msNb</APP>

%       -  - . -   -  .    . - . -  -
<TEXT> pañcānṛtaṃ satyam{ }udāharanti||</TEXT> 4:5
        <TR>A lie does not hurt when it is connected with joking,
        with women, O king, at the time of marriage,
        at the departure from life and when one's entire wealth is about to be taken away.
        They call these five kinds of lies truths.</TR>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\similar\ \MBH\ 1.77.16:$ na narmayuktaṃ vacanaṃ hinasti na strīṣu rājan{ }na vivāhakāle|
                                               prāṇātyaye sarvadhanāpahāre pañcānṛtāny{ }āhur{ }apātakāni||;
                           Ł\MBH\ 12.159.28:$ na narmayuktaṃ vacanaṃ hinasti na strīṣu rājan{ }na vivāhakāle|
                                               na gurvarthe nātmano jīvitārthe pañcānṛtāny{ }āhur{ }apātakāni||;
                             Ł\MATSP\ 31.16:$ na narmayuktaṃ vacanaṃ hinasti na strīṣu rājan{ }na vivāhakāle|
        ŁAbhidharmakośabhāṣya 24114--24117 (introduced by $ mohajo mṛṣāvādo yathāhaŁ):$
                                               na narmayuktam{ }anṛtaṃ hi nāsti na strīṣu rājan{ }na vivāhakāle|
                                               prāṇātyaye sarvadhanāpahāre pañcānṛtāny{ }āhur{ }apātakāni|| Łetc.$</PARAL>
        <NOTE>This Łupajāti$ verse appears in countless sources, beginning with 
              the \MBH\ (see the apparatus). All versions 
              contain a vocative addressing a king, which is out of context in the \VSS, the addressee being Vigatarāga,
              i.e. Viṣṇu disguised as a Brahmin. The redactors did not notice or did not care about this
              small inconsistency. Note the metrical licence that allows the last syllable
              of °Łyuktam$ to count as long (see p.~\pageref{short2long}).
              The reading with Łanṛtaṃ$, as opposed to Łvacanaṃ$, in Łpāda$ a, can be found 
              in the apparatus of the \MBH\ critical edition.</NOTE>

%index_metre: upajāti
%index_metre: -m a- long

% anṛtam in the apparatus in the MBh critical edition, and also in the Kumbhakona ed.
% Lingapurāṇa 01/090.txt:  31:        na dharmayuktamanṛtaṃ hinastīti manīṣiṇaḥ।। 90.9 ।।




<ANUSTUBH/>
% tirya is a word in this text
<TEXT> devamānuṣatiryeṣu satyaṃ dharmaḥ paro yataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°mānuṣa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °mānuṣya° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM!>satyaṃ dharmaḥ paro yataḥ</LEM> \msCb\msCc; satyaṃ dharmaḥ payataḥ \msCa,
                        satyaṃ dharma paro yataḥ \msNa\msNc, satyadharma paro yataḥ \msNb, satyadharmaparāyaṇaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Since truth is the supreme Dharma in [the world of] gods, humans and animals,</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 200.jpg upper, f. 6v
%folioinfo \msM\ 418.jpg upper, f. 6v  
<TEXT> satyaṃ śreṣṭhaṃ variṣṭhaṃ ca satyaṃ dharmaḥ sanātanaḥ||</TEXT> 4:6
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śreṣṭhaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; śreṣṭha \msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>variṣṭhaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; variṣṭhamvariṣṭhamvañ{ }ca \msCbacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>satyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; satya° \msCb\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>dharmaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; dharma \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>truth is the best, the most preferable. Truth is the eternal Dharma.</TR>

<TEXT> satyaṃ sāgaram{ }avyaktaṃ satyam{ }akṣayabhogadam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>satyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; satya \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>satyam{ }akṣayabhogadam</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; satyaṃm{ }akṣayabhogadam \msCb\msCc,
                                satyam{ }akṣayate naraṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Truth is an unmanifest ocean. Truth yields imperishable pleasures.</TR>
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.592

% yat sthāna Judit Kenji CHECK
<TEXT> satyaṃ potaḥ paratrārthaṃ satyaṃ panthāna vistaram||</TEXT> 4:7
        <APP>\vc <LEM>potaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; pota \msNa, proktaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>panthāna vistaram</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yaj{ }jñānavistaram \Ed</APP>
        yanthāna° OR pasthāna° ? \msCa\msCb\msCc\msNa
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ d is slightly problematic because it is difficult to ascertain if some of the
               MSS actually read Łpanthāna$ or Łpasthāna$ (or Łyasthāna$).  I suspect that Łpanthāna$ 
               is a \stemform\ noun formed (metri causa)
               to stand for an irregular nominative of Łpathin$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Truth is a ship bound for the other world. Truth is the wide path.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form noun?

% iṣṭa as sacrificed? (CsK: don't think so)
<TEXT> satyam{ }iṣṭagatiḥ proktaṃ satyaṃ yajñam{ }anuttamam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°ṣṭagatiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °<UNCL>ṣṭā</UNCL>gatiḥ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Truth is said to be the desired path. Truth is the supreme sacrifice.</TR>

<TEXT> satyaṃ tīrthaṃ paraṃ tīrthaṃ satyaṃ dānam{ }anantakam||</TEXT> 4:8
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tīrthaṃ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa; tīrtha \msNb\msNc, tīrthāt \Ed</APP>
%The repetition of Łtīrthaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c is sightly suspect. Cf., e.g., \MATSP\ 22.79ab:
%                 Łsatyaṃ tīrthaṃ dayā tīrthaṃ tīrtham{ }indriyanigrahaḥ$.
        <TR>Truth is a pilgrimage place, a supreme pilgrimage place. Truth is endless donation.</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> satyaṃ śīlaṃ tapo jñānaṃ satyaṃ śaucaṃ damaḥ śamaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>satyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; satya \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śamaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; śamam \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Truth is virtue, austerity, knowledge. Truth is purity, self-control, and\linebreak tranquillity.</TR>

<TEXT> satyaṃ sopānam{ }ūrdhvasya satyaṃ kīrtir{ }yaśaḥ sukham||</TEXT> 4:9
        <APP>\vc <LEM>satyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; saṃtyaṃ \msCb, satya \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sukham</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; sukhaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vc Ł\similar\ \VARP\ 193.36cd:$ satyaṃ svargasya sopānaṃ pārāvārasya naur{ }iva</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Considering a similar line in the \VARP\ (193.36cd, see the apparatus), one 
              wonders if the slightly odd Łūrdhvasya$ in Łpāda$ c is not a corrupt form of 
              Łsvargasya$ somehow.</NOTE>
        <TR>Truth is the ladder [that leads] upwards. Truth is fame and glory and happiness.</TR>

<TEXT> aśvamedhasahasraṃ ca satyaṃ ca tulayā dhṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°sahasraṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °sahasrasya \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tulayā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; tulyayā \msCc</APP>
        <TR>[When] a thousand Aśvamedha sacrifices and truth are measured on a pair of scales,</TR>

<TEXT> aśvamedhasahasrād{ }dhi satyam{ }eva viśiṣyate||</TEXT> 4:10
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°sahasrād{ }dhi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °sahasrā hi \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>eva</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; evaṃ \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł = \MBH\ 1.69.22 = \MBH\ Suppl. 13.20.330 = \MARKP\ 8.42 = \VDHU\ 3.265.7
                       \similar\ \MBH\ 12.156.26 (pāda d reads $ satyam{ }evātiricyateŁ) \similar\ \VDH\ 55.6 
                           (pāda d reads$ satyam{ }etad{ }viśiṣyateŁ)$;
                   Ł\compare\ \SDHS\ 11.107:$
                        aśvamedhāyutaṃ pūrṇaṃ satyañ{ }ca tulitaṃ purā|
                        aśvamedhāyutāt{ }satyam{ }adhikaṃ bahubhir{ }guṇaiḥ||</PARAL>
        <TR>truth indeed surpasses a thousand Aśvamedha sacrifices.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 48.jpg ends with this line
<TEXT> satyena tapate sūryaḥ satyena pṛthivī sthitā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>sūryaḥ satyena pṛthivī sthitā</LEM> \msNa\msNc; sū<UNCL>ryaḥ sa</UNCL>tyena pṛthi sthitāḥ \msCa,
                                sūryaḥ satyaina pṛthivī sthitā \msCb, sūrya satyena pṛthivī sthitāḥ \msCc,
                                sūrya <UNCL>satye</UNCL> \lac\ ××× vī sthitā \msNb, sūryaḥ satyena pṛthivī sthitāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>In general, see sections similar to \VSS\ 4.11--17 on Łsatya$ in \MBH\ 12.192.63--72,
                \RevKhS\ 91.68--70, \VDH\ 55.1ff, \VDHU\ 3.265.1ff, etc.</NOTE>
        <TR>The Sun shines because of truth. The Earth stays in place by truth.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 48.jpg upper              for satyena?
<TEXT> satyena vāyavo vānti satye toyaṃ ca śītalam||</TEXT> 4:11
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vāyavo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; vātyavo \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>satye</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; satyāt \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\similar\ \VARP\ 193.37:$ 
                        sūryas{ }tapati satyena vātaḥ satyena vāti ca|  
                        agnir{ }dahati satyena satyena pṛthivī sthitā|| 
                   Ł\similar\ \VDHU\ 3.265.4cd--5ab:$
                        satyena vāyur{ }abhyeti satyenābhāsate raviḥ || 
                        satyena cāgnir{ }dahati svargaṃ satyena gacchati | </PARAL>
        <NOTE>Here in \VSS\ 4.11d, and several times below, Łsatye$ is probably 
                                to be taken as standing for Łsatyena$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The winds blow because of truth. Water has a cooling effect through truth.</TR>

%index_grammar: locative (-e) for instrumental

%index_grammar: without licence it is iambic (WHAT?), satye for satyena?

% what is the logic; Flo: Śiva instructing him?
<TEXT> tiṣṭhanti sāgarāḥ satye samayena priyavrataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>sāgarāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sāgarā \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>samayena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; satyena ca \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ b, Łsamayena priyavrataḥ$, probably stand for Łsamayena priyavratasya$ although
              it is unclear to me what exactly Łsamaya$ refers to here.
        <sep/>

        For the story of Priyavrata, Manu's son, in which he wanted to turn nights into days by 
        circling aroung Mount Meru in a chariot, and by this produced the seven oceans,
        see, e.g., \BHAGP\ 5.1.30--31: 
        Łyāvad avabhāsayati suragirim anuparikrāman bhagavān ādityo
         vasudhātalam ardhenaiva pratapaty ardhenāvacchādayati, tadā hi [priyavrataḥ]
         bhagavadupāsanopacitātipuruṣaprabhāvas tad anabhinandan samajavena
         rathena jyotirmayena rajanīm api dinaṃ kariṣyāmīti saptakṛtvas 
         taraṇim anuparyakrāmad dvitīya iva pataṅgaḥ |
         ye vā u ha tadrathacaraṇanemikṛtaparikhātās te sapta sindhava āsan
         yata eva kṛtāḥ sapta bhuvo dvīpāḥ |$.
        </NOTE>
        <TR>The oceans exist by the truthful encounter with Priyavrata.</TR>

%index_grammar: locative (-e) for instrumental
%index_persons: Priyavrata

        % (see translation on pp.640 ff)

% Is the Bhāgavatapurāṇa not too late? Priyavrata not in the epics. Mentioned in the Devībhāgavata/mahāpurāṇa
%Cf.\ Purāṇic Encyclopedia, s.v. Łpriyavrata$:
%``Priyavrata once circled round Meru in his chariot. As
%if competing with the Sun Priyavrata started his circling
%along with sunrise and ended it at sunset. He did so
%seven days making nights look like day and the sun
%appear dim and faded. The Sun was dejected and it
%was at the request of the Trimūrtis that Priyavrata
%stopped his circumambulation. It was the path of Priyavrata's
%circling for seven days that later became the seven
%oceans of Purāṇic fame. (Yuddha Kāṇḍa, Kamba Rāmāyaṇa).''


%Ṛgveda
%RV_10.085.01.1{20} satyenottabhitā bhūmiḥ sūryeṇottabhitā dyauḥ
%RV_10.085.01.2{20} ṛtenādityāstiṣṭhanti divi somo adhi śritaḥ
%RV_10.085.02.1{20} somenādityā balinaḥ somena pṛthivī mahī
%RV_10.085.02.2{20} athonakṣatrāṇāmeṣāmupasthe soma āhitaḥ

%        satye for satyena?
% he kept his word? Nirajan (watchman) CsK?
% vañchana Judit but stays in truth
<TEXT> satye tiṣṭhati govindo balibandhanakāraṇāt||</TEXT> 4:12
        <TR>Govinda abides in truth because He [as Vāmana] stopped [Mahā]Bali [in spite of the 
                        fact that this was achieved by a trick].</TR>
        <NOTE><sep/>
        
        ŁPāda$s cd: for a somewhat similar reference to the story of Mahābali, see, e.g., \VAMP\ 65.66:
        <sep/>
        Łevaṃ purā cakradhareṇa viṣṇunā$ 
        Łbaddho balir vāmanarūpadhāriṇā$ |<br/>
        Łśakrapriyārthaṃ surakāryasiddhaye$ 
        Łhitāya viprarṣabhagodvijānām$ || </NOTE>


%index_mythical_figures: Govinda
%index_mythical_figures: Bali (Mahābali)

<PAGEBREAK/>

%                             śaśibhās is moonlight
<TEXT> agnir{ }dahati satyena satyena śaśinaś{ }caraḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>satyena satyena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\Ed; satyena \msNaacorr\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śaśinaś{ }caraḥ</LEM> \conj; saśi<UNCL>bhācaraḥ</UNCL> \msCa, 
                                                   śa<UNCL>si</UNCL>\lk caraḥ \msCb,
                                                   sa śirā varaḥ \msCc, 
                                                   śaśir{ }ācaraḥ \msNa\msNb\msNc,
                                                   śaśibhāṣkaraḥ \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vc Ł\similar\ \VARP\ 193.37cd:$ 
                agnir{ }dahati satyena satyena pṛthivī sthitā</PARAL>
        <PARAL>\vd Ł\compare\ \VARP\ 155.30cd:$
                        satyena sūryas{ }tapati somaḥ satyena rājate;
                 Ł\compare\ \LAKSMINARS\  1.345.50ab:$
                        satyena sūryas{ }tapati candraḥ satyena vardhate|
                Ł\compare\ \MBH\ Suppl. 13.587:$
                        mucukundena māndhātrā hariścandreṇa cābhibho|
                        satyaṃ vadata māsatyaṃ satyaṃ dharmaḥ sanātanaḥ|
                        hariścandraś{ }carati vai divi satyena candravat||</PARAL>
                <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a might as well be a reference to a story mentioned in \MANU\ 8.116:
                <sep/>
              Łvatsasya hy abhiśastasya purā bhrātrā yavīyasā$ |<br/>
              Łnāgnir dadāha romāpi satyena jagataḥ spaśaḥ$ ||
                <sep/>
              Olivelle's translation (<citeyear>OlivelleManu</citeyear>, 311): 
             `Long ago when Vatsa was accused by his younger brother, 
              Fire, the world's spy, did not burn a single hair of his because he told the truth.'
              Olivelle's note on this verse (ibid. 311) reads:
              `Vatsa was accused by his brother of being the son of a Śūdra woman and thus not 
              a pure Brahmin. Vatsa went through fire to prove his pedigree. See ŁPañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa$
              14.6.6.'

              Since Łśaśi$ (instead of Łśaśin$) is a possible stem in this text, 
              Łśaśir ācaraḥ$ (\msNa\msNb\msNc) in Łpāda$ b could be acceptable here,
              perhaps standing metri causa for the compound Łśaśicaraḥ$.
              Nevertheless, I have chosen to conjecture Łśaśinaś caraḥ$, now preferring it
              to my previous conjecture, Łśaśinā caraḥ$.
              Other possibilities, suggested by Judit Törzsök and other colleagues, include Łśaśibhāskaraḥ$, 
              Łśaśigocaraḥ$, Łśiśiro 'caraḥ$, and Łśiśirāmbhasaḥ$. Similar passages quoted in the apparatus
              suggest that the Moon vaxes, or shines, by truth (Łsatyena vardhate$/Łrājate$).
              Compare also a passage in the \MBH\ (quoted in the apparatus) that 
              compares Hariścandra, renowned for his truthfulness, to the Moon, 
              using the verb Łcarati$. These passages seem to support a reading close to
              my conjecture.</NOTE>
        <TR>Fire burns according to truth. The Moon's course is [governed] by truth.</TR>

% Judit goes for śaśinā caraḥ
%Kengo: śaśer ācāraḥ or avacaraḥ, śaśibhāskarau (Judit likes it: candra, sun and fire)
%śaśigocara Nirajan
% Flo sg. for star, or ācaret, candratāraka
%On koṭihoma there is something in Sanderson 2003, Śaiva Religion among the Khmers (I), p382 Marco
%Marco 'bhā' as a star or asterism
%Judit:
%esetleg samaya = limit / boundary? Merthogy kijelölte a szekerével a 7 kontinenst 
%és a tengereket. [Wilson... nem hiszem CsK]
%Amugy a 13 kemény dolog. Ezeket ajanlom még 
%śaśibhāskaraḥ (Az ed.) merthogy candrasūrya elôfordul feliratban is,
%        mint witness to the truthfulness of the agreement
%Vagy
%        śiśiro ’caraḥ = śiśira hegy (acara = acala) mert utana hegyek vannak
%Vagy
%        śiśirāmbhasaḥ/ śiśiro ’mbhasaḥ for śiśiram ambhas, a hideg viz mint fentebb, de most a tûz mellett

%folioinfo \msCc\ 191.jpg
% see also Törzsök Murari vol. p36
<TEXT> satyena vindhyās{ }tiṣṭhanti vardhamāno na vardhate||</TEXT> 4:13
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vindhyās{ }tiṣṭhanti</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc;
                        vindhyas{ }tiṣṭhanti \msCb\msNb, vindhyā tiṣṭhanti \msCc, tiṣṭhate vindhyo \Ed</APP>
        <TR>It is because of truth that the Vindhya mountain stands in place and that
                although it was growing, it is not growing [anymore].</TR>
        <NOTE><sep/>

        While it is not clear if Łpāda$s ab refer to specific legends or not,
        Łpāda$s cd hint at the story of Agastya and the Vindhya mountain (as pointed out to me
        by Judit Törzsök):
        Vindhya became jealous of the Sun's revolving around Mount Meru, and when the Sun 
        refused him the same favour, he decided to grow higher and obstruct the Sun's movement.
        As a solution to this situation, Agastya asked Vidhya to bend down to make 
        it easier for him to reach the south and to remain thus until he retured. 
        Vindhya agreed to do what Agastya asked him but Agastya never returned. 
        See \MBH\ 3.102.1--14 (see the word Łsamaya$ in verse 13 in this passage, and compare it to \VSS\ 4.12b):
                <sep/>
                         Łyudhiṣṭhira uvāca$ |<br/>
                         Łkimarthaṃ sahasā vindhyaḥ pravṛddhaḥ krodhamūrchitaḥ$ |<br/>
                         Łetad icchāmy ahaṃ śrotuṃ vistareṇa mahāmune$ ||<br/>
                         Łlomaśa uvāca$ |<br/>
                         Ładrirājaṃ mahāśailaṃ meruṃ kanakaparvatam$ |<br/>
                         Łudayāstamaye bhānuḥ pradakṣiṇam avartata$ ||<br/>
                         Łtaṃ tu dṛṣṭvā tathā vindhyaḥ śailaḥ sūryam athābravīt$ |<br/>
                         Łyathā hi merur bhavatā nityaśaḥ parigamyate$ |<br/>
                         Łpradakṣiṇaṃ ca kriyate mām evaṃ kuru bhāskara$ ||<br/>
                         Łevam uktas tataḥ sūryaḥ śailendraṃ pratyabhāṣata$ |<br/>
                         Łnāham ātmecchayā śaila karomy enaṃ pradakṣiṇam$ |<br/>
                         Łeṣa mārgaḥ pradiṣṭo me yenedaṃ nirmitaṃ jagat$ ||<br/>
                         Łevam uktas tataḥ krodhāt pravṛddhaḥ sahasācalaḥ$ |<br/>
                         Łsūryācandramasor mārgaṃ roddhum icchan paraṃtapa$ || 5 ||<br/>
                         Łtato devāḥ sahitāḥ sarva eva; sendrāḥ samāgamya mahādrirājam$ |<br/>
                         Łnivārayām āsur upāyatas taṃ; na ca sma teṣāṃ vacanaṃ cakāra$ ||<br/>
                         Łathābhijagmur munim āśramasthaṃ; tapasvinaṃ dharmabhṛtāṃ variṣṭham$ |<br/>
                         Łagastyam atyadbhutavīryadīptaṃ; taṃ cārtham ūcuḥ sahitāḥ surās te$ ||<br/>
                         Łdevā ūcuḥ$ |<br/>
                         Łsūryācandramasor mārgaṃ nakṣatrāṇāṃ gatiṃ tathā$ |<br/>
                         Łśailarājo vṛṇoty eṣa vindhyaḥ krodhavaśānugaḥ$ ||<br/>
                         Łtaṃ nivārayituṃ śakto nānyaḥ kaś cid dvijottama$ |<br/>
                         Łṛte tvāṃ hi mahābhāga tasmād enaṃ nivāraya$ ||<br/>
                         Łlomaśa uvāca$ |<br/>
                         Łtac chrutvā vacanaṃ vipraḥ surāṇāṃ śailam abhyagāt$ |<br/>
                         Łso 'bhigamyābravīd vindhyaṃ sadāraḥ samupasthitaḥ$ || 10 ||<br/>
                         Łmārgam icchāmy ahaṃ dattaṃ bhavatā parvatottama$ |<br/>
                         Łdakṣiṇām abhigantāsmi diśaṃ kāryeṇa kena cit$ ||<br/>
                         Łyāvadāgamanaṃ mahyaṃ tāvat tvaṃ pratipālaya$ |<br/>
                         Łnivṛtte mayi śailendra tato vardhasva kāmataḥ$ ||<br/>
                         Łevaṃ sa samayaṃ kṛtvā vindhyenāmitrakarśana$ |<br/>
                         Ładyāpi dakṣiṇād deśād vāruṇir na nivartate$ ||<br/>
                         Łetat te sarvam ākhyātaṃ yathā vindhyo na vardhate$ |<br/>
                         Łagastyasya prabhāvena yan māṃ tvaṃ paripṛcchasi$ || 14 ||</NOTE>

                        % search for 'vindhya iva vardha' Kenji
                        %tiṣṭhan tu? Kengo

%index_metre: ma-vipulā
%index_geo: Vidhya mountain


<TEXT> lokālokaḥ sthitaḥ satye meruḥ satye pratiṣṭhitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°lokaḥ</LEM> \Ed; °loka \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\oo
                 <LEM>sthitaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; sthiḥ \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>satye</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; satyaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>meruḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; meru \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>The [mythical] Lokāloka mountains are located in truth. Mount Meru stands by truth.</TR>
%folioinfo \msCa\ 393.jpg

%index_geo: Lokāloka mountains
%index_geo: Meru

<TEXT> vedās{ }tiṣṭhanti satyeṣu dharmaḥ satye pratiṣṭhati||</TEXT> 4:14
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vedās{ }ti°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; devās{ }ti° \msCb, vedā ti° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>satye</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dharme \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>pratiṣṭhati</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; pratiṣṭhiti \msNcacorr, pratiṣṭhitaḥ \msNcpcorr</APP>
        <TR>The Vedas abide in truth. Dharma is rooted in truth.</TR>

<TEXT> satyaṃ gauḥ kṣarate kṣīraṃ satyaṃ kṣīre ghṛtaṃ sthitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>gauḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; gau \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>kṣīraṃ satyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kṣītyaṃ \msCbacorr, ksī\lk  nityaṃ \msCbpcorr</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kṣīre ghṛtaṃ sthitam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; kṣīraṃ ghṛtaṃ sthitam \msCc, kṣīre ghṛta sthitam \msNb,
                                                                kṣīraṃ sthitaṃ ghṛtam \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The milk a cow yields is truth. Ghee in milk is present as truth.</TR>

<TEXT> satye jīvaḥ sthito dehe satyaṃ jīvaḥ sanātanaḥ||</TEXT> 4:15
        <APP>\vc <LEM>satye jīvaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; satye jīva \msNc, satyaṃ jīva \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>jīvaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; jīva \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Łsatye$ (for Łsatyena$?) in Łpāda$ c may also stand for Łsatyaṃ$: `The soul dwells in the body as truth.'</NOTE>
        <TR>The soul dwells in the body by truth. The eternal soul is truth.</TR>

<TEXT> satyam{ }ekena samprāpto dharmasādhananiścayaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>satyam{ }ekena</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; satyam{ }ekaina \msCb, satyem{ }ekena \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dharma°</LEM> \Ed; dharmaḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°niścayaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °niścaḥ \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>Or: `If truth alone (Łekena$) is obtained, Dharma is surely accomplished.'</NOTE>
        <TR>If truth is obtained by somebody (Łekena$), he/she will be one for whom Dharma is surely accomplished.</TR>

<TEXT> rāmarāghavavīryeṇa satyam{ }ekaṃ surakṣitam||</TEXT> 4:16
        <APP>\vd <LEM>satyam{ }ekaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; satyem{ }ekaṃ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>surakṣitam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; surikṣitam \msCb, surakṣitaḥ \msNa</APP>
        <TR>By the heroism of Rāma Rāghava, the only truth was well-guarded.</TR>

%index_persons: Rāma Rāghava

% go for evaṃ?
<TEXT> evaṃ satyavidhānasya kīrtitaṃ tava suvrata|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>evaṃ satya°</LEM> \msCb; etat{ }satya° \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>suvrata</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc; suvrate \msCb\msNb, suvra<UNCL>taḥ</UNCL> \msCc, suvrataṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Thus have [I] taught the rules of truth to you, O virtuous one,</TR>
% for kīrtanam Kengo (but then tava is problematic)

<TEXT> sarvalokahitārthāya kim{ }anyac{ }chrotum{ }icchasi||</TEXT> 4:17
        <TR>to favour the whole world. What else do you wish to hear?</TR>
% Marco maybe pāda c goes with pāda d 



<PAGEBREAK/>

<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣv{ }asteyam (3)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Third Yama-rule: refraining from stealing</TRSUBCHAPTER>

%folioinfo \msNc\ 217.jpg lower, f. 215r
<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> na hi tṛptiṃ vijānāmi śrutvā dharmaṃ tavāpy{ }aham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tṛptiṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; tṛpti \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>vijānāmi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; vināmi \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>śrutvā dharmaṃ tavāpy{ }aham</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                         śru dharman{ }tavāpy{ }aham \msCa,
                                                         dharmaṃ śrutvā tathāpy{ }aham \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>It is not inconceivable that Łtava$ is meant to carry the sense of the ablative
               (`I can't have enough of learning about Dharma from you').</NOTE>
        <TR>I can't have enough of learning about [this teaching of] your[s on] Dharma.</TR>

%index_grammar: genitive as ablative (tava)?

<TEXT> upariṣṭād{ }ato bhūyaḥ kathayasva tapodhana||</TEXT> 4:18
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dhana</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °dhūna \msCa, °dhanaḥ \msCb\msNc</APP>
        <TR>Teach me further than this, O great ascetic.</TR>

%index_anarthayajna_ref_as: tapodhana


<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> steyaṃ śṛṇv{ }atha viprendra pañcadhā parikīrtitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kīrtitam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °kīrttitām \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Now listen to [my teaching about] stealing, O great Brahmin, 
                                which is taught to be of five kinds.</TR>

<TEXT> adattādānam{ }ādau tu utkocaṃ ca tataḥ param|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>utkocaṃ ca tataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tkoca tataḥ \msCb, utkocaṃ cānṛtaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Firstly, [listen to] theft, then bribery,</TR>
        <NOTE>`Theft' (Ładattādāna$): literally `taking what has not been given.'</NOTE>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 414.jpg
<TEXT> prasthavyājas{ }tulāvyājaḥ prasahyasteya pañcamam||</TEXT> 4:19
        <APP>\ve <LEM>tulāvyājaḥ</LEM> \msCb\msNc\Ed; tulāvyāja \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°sahya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °sahye \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°steya</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °stena \msCa\msNc\oo
                 <LEM>pañcamam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; pañcamaḥ \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ °Łsteya$ in Łpāda$ f.</NOTE>
        <TR>cheating with weights, cheating with scales, and the fifth kind, robbery.</TR>
% prasahyacaura = (m.) ‘violent thief’, a robber, plunderer, [L.] MMW

%index_grammar: stem form noun

% is dhṛṣṭa OK? phps dṛṣṭa = evident (crime)?
<TEXT> dhṛṣṭaduṣṭaprabhāvena paradravyāpakarṣaṇam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dhṛṣṭaduṣṭa°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; dhṛṣṭadumna° \msCb, dhṛtaduṣṭa° \msCc, dṛṣṭaduṣṭa° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°karṣaṇam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °karṣaṇa \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>My impression is that Łprabhāva$ in Łpāda$ a stands for Łbhāva$, Łduṣṭabhāva$ (`vicious')
              being a common expression.</NOTE>
        <TR>When somebody's wealth is taken away by an impudent and wicked person,</TR>

% gender (probably not a bahuvrīhi?)
<TEXT> vāryamāṇo 'pi durbuddhir{ }adattādānam{ }ucyate||</TEXT> 4:20
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vāryamāṇo 'pi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vāryamāno vi° \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>The implications of Łvāryamāṇo$ in Łpāda$ c are unclear to me, therefore
              my translation is tentative. One could consider emending to Łvāryamāṇāpi$,
              possibly suggesting that `it is a wicked thought (Łdurbuddhi$) even if suppressed (Łvāryamāṇa$).'</NOTE>
        <TR>it is called theft, even if that fool is prevented [from committing the\linebreak crime].</TR>
% duburddhir \msNc
% if remains unnoticed? Marco
% Nirajan even if restrained

% typical feature that with a śṛṇu-type line a 3-line śloka is formed
<TEXT> utkocaṃ śṛṇu viprendra dharmasaṃkarakārakam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>utkocaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; utkoca \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>viprendra</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; vidrendra \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°saṃkara°</LEM> \msCc\msNa; °śaṅkara° \msCa\msCb\msNb, °sakara° \msNc, °saṃhāra° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°kārakam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °kārakaḥ \msNa</APP>
        <TR>O great Brahmin, listen to bribery, which causes confusion in Dharma.</TR>

<TEXT> mūlyaṃ kāryavināśārtham{ }utkocaḥ parigṛhyate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>mūlyaṃ</LEM> \conj; mūla \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°vināśārtha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed; °vinārtha° \msNaacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°tkocaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °tkocaṃ \msNb, °tkoca \Ed</APP>
                <NOTE>Note that Łmūlyaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c is a conjecture for Łmūla$. It is partly based on 
                      a relevant passage in the \Mitaksara\ (ad \YajnS\ 2.176cd):
                      Łpaṇyasya krītadravyasya yan mūlyaṃ dattam, bhṛtir vetanaṃ kṛtakarmaṇe dattam$\dots\ 
                      Łutkocena kāryapratibandhanirāsārtham adhikṛtebhyo dattam$\dots\ </NOTE>
        <TR>A sum of money taken in order to dismiss a lawsuit is a bribe.</TR>
% Judit could be more general: duty? maybe except it, 'obligation' Florinda

% MMW: kārya - to be imposed (as a punishment), [Mn. viii, 276 and 285]
%Judit: "Sztem inkabb: when a sum of money is given to make as if something did not happen. (kenôpénz a rendôrnek: itt ugye nem is volt gyorshajtas) or: to avoid that something should happen (pl. birsag)" CsK: I took kārya as punishment, fine
% kārya is also 'lawsuit'
% Mitākṣarā:
% ayam arthaḥ: paṇyasya krītadravyasya yan mūlyaṃ dattam, bhṛtir vetanaṃ kṛtakarmaṇe dattam, tuṣṭyā bandicāraṇādibhyo dattam, snehād duhitṛputrādibhyo dattam, pratyupakārata upakṛtavate pratyupakārarūpeṇa dattam, strīśulkaṃ pariṇayanārthaṃ kanyājñātibhyo yad dattam, yac cānugrahārtham adṛṣṭārthaṃ dattaṃ tad etat saptavidham api dattam eva na pratyāharaṇīyam | bhayena bandigrāhādibhyo dattam, krodhena putrādibhyo vairaniryātanāyānyasmai dattam, putraviyogādinimittaśokāveśena dattam,
% utkocena kāryapratibandhanirāsārtham adhikṛtebhyo dattam

%folioinfo \msM\ 418.jpg lower, f. 7r  
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.593
%           asau shd be acc. (\msM\ has steya)
<TEXT> tena cāsau vijānīyād{ }dravyalobhabalāt{ }kṛtam||</TEXT> 4:21
        <APP>\vef <LEM>vijānīyād{ }dra°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vijānīyā dra° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Therefore this [also] should be considered as such 
                [i.e.\ as stealing because] it is committed out of greed for material goods.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note Łasau$ in Łpāda$ e as an accusative form (for Łamum$ or Ładaḥ$). It is not unlikely that 
              Łtena$ is a corruption from Łstena$, and the Łpāda$ may have originally read 
              Łstenaṃ taṃ ca vijānīyād$ (`he should be known as a thief'), or similar (cf. 4.22c below). 
              \msM\ (f. 7r) reads Łtena steya vijānīyād$ here.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: nominative for accusative (asau)? Corruption?

<TEXT> prasthavyāja-upāyena kuṭumbaṃ trātum{ }icchati|</TEXT>
        <TR>[Even if] somebody wants to protect a family by the method of cheating with weights,</TR>

%index_grammar: lack of internal sandhi (prasthavyāja-upāyena)

<TEXT> taṃ ca stenaṃ vijānīyāt{ }paradravyāpahārakam||</TEXT> 4:22
        <APP>\vc <LEM>taṃ ca stenaṃ</LEM> \msCa; tañ{ }ca stena \msCb,
                                so 'pi tena \msCc\Ed, taṃ ca steyaṃ \msNa, tañ{ }ca teya \msNb, tañ{ }ca tena \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°hārakam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNapcorr\msNc\Ed; °hārakaḥ \msCc, °hārakā \msNaacorr °hārakāḥ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>that person should be considered a thief, because he takes away other people's wealth.</TR>


<TEXT> tulāvyāja-upāyena parasvārthaṃ hared{ }yadi|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>parasvārthaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc; parasvārtha \msCb\msNb, parasyārthaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>hared{ }yadi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; hared{ }yati \msCb</APP>
        <TR>If somebody takes away somebody else's belongings
                                         by the method of cheating with scales,</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 200.jpg lower, f.7r
<TEXT> cauralakṣaṇakāś{ }cānye kūṭakāpaṭikā narāḥ||</TEXT> 4:23
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kūṭakāpaṭikā</LEM> \msNb; <UNCL>ku</UNCL>ṭakā yaṭikā \msCa, kūṭakāyaṭikā \msCb\msCc\msNaacorr\msNc,
                                         kūṭakāryaṭikā \msNapcorr\Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\compare\ \UMS\ 8.3cd:$ kūṭakāpaṭikāś{ }caiva satyārjavavivarjitāḥ</PARAL>
        <NOTE>I take Łanye$ in Łpāda$ c rather liberally, and as connected to
              Łpāda$s ab, because I suspect that this verse introduces one single
              category, albeit using clumsy syntax.</NOTE>
        <TR>that person is another kind of a deceitful swindler (Łkūṭa-kāpaṭika$) 
            having the characteristics of thieves.</TR>

%index_grammar: singular-plural confusion 

<TEXT> durbalārjavabāleṣu cchadmanā vā balena vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°rjava°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °java° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>cchadmanā</LEM> \Ed; cchanmanā \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb, cchatmānā \msNc</APP>
        <TR>If someone, by deceit or by force, snatches away the wealth</TR>

<TEXT> apahṛtya dhanaṃ mūḍhaḥ sa cauraś{ }cora ucyate||</TEXT> 4:24
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>mūḍhaḥ sa</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; mūḍhās{ }sa \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>cauraś{ }cora</LEM> \msNc; coraś{ }cora \msCa\msCc\msNb\Ed, caura cora \msCb, cauraś{ }caura \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>It is possible that Łpāda$ d read differently originally, 
              e.g., Łsa coraś cora ucyate$, meaning `that thief is [rightly] called a thief'.</NOTE>
        <TR>of weak and honest people and simpletons, that morally corrupt usurper is [simply] a thief.</TR>

%lacuna_start: Ed
<TEXT> nāsti steyasamaṃ pāpaṃ nāsty{ }adharmaś{ }ca tatsamaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>steya°</LEM> \msNa\msNc; tena \msCa, stena° \msCb\msCc\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°samaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °samaṃ \msCc</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vo ŁThis verse is missing in \Ed.$</LACUNA>
        <TR>There is no sin equal to stealing. There is no crime (Ładharma$) equal to it.</TR>

%folioinfo: \msCc\ 192.jpg, f. 274v
<TEXT> nāsti stenasamākīrtir{ }nāsti stenasamo 'nayaḥ||</TEXT> 4:25
        <APP>\vc <LEM>stena°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; tena \msCc, steya° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°samā°</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNb; °samo \msCa\msNa\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>stena°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\Ed; steya° \msNa\msNc</APP>
        <TR>There is no ill-fame comparable to that of being a thief. 
                There is no bad-conduct comparable to being a thief.</TR>

%lacuna_end: Ed
<TEXT> nāsti steyasamāvidyā nāsti stenasamaḥ khalaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>steya°</LEM> \msNa\msNc\Ed; stena° \mssCaCbCc\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°samā</LEM> \msCc\msNb; °samo \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>stena°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb; steya° \msNa\msNc, tena \Ed</APP>
        <TR>There is no greater ignorance than stealing. There are no bigger rouges than thieves.</TR>

<TEXT> nāsti stenasama ajño nāsti stenasamo 'lasaḥ||</TEXT> 4:26
        <APP>\vc <LEM>stena°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc; steya° \msCc\msNa\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°sama</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed\ \unmetr; °samaṃ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>ajño</LEM> \msCb; ajña\lk\ \msCa, ajña \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, ajñaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>stena°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb; steya° \msCc\msNa\msNc, tena \Ed </APP>
        <NOTE>Note the peculiar sandhi in Łpāda$ c (°Łsama ajño$), which still leaves the Łpāda$ 
              a Łsa-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>There is nobody as ignorant as a thief. There is no lazy person that is comparable to a thief.</TR>

%index_metre: sa-vipulā
%index_grammar: sandhi

<TEXT> nāsti stenasamo dveṣyo nāsti stenasamo 'priyaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>stena°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb; steya° \msCc\msNa\msNc, tena \Ed </APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>stena°</LEM> \msNb; steya° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>There is nobody as detestable as a thief. There is nobody disliked as much as a thief.</TR>

<TEXT> nāsti steyasamaṃ duḥkhaṃ nāsti steyasamo 'yaśaḥ||</TEXT> 4:27
