        <APP>\vc <LEM>steya°</LEM> \msCc; stena° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb, stenya° \msNc, tena \Ed </APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>steya°</LEM> \msCc\msNc; stena° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb, tena \Ed </APP>
        <NOTE>Note how Łstena$ and Łsteya$ are used interchangeably (or chaotically)
                        in the above passages in the MSS to denote both `thief' and 'theft/stealing'.
                         The scribe of \msNc\ ends up writing Łstenya$ in 4.27e.</NOTE>
        <TR>There is no greater suffering than stealing. There is no greater disgrace than theft.</TR>
% infamy for ayaśaḥ Judit no problem with gender in this text


<PAGEBREAK/>


<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<LONGVERSELINES/>
%        -   -  -   . . -     .    -  . . . -    -  -  .    -  -  . -
<TEXT> pracchanno hriyate 'rtham{ }anyapuruṣaḥ pratyakṣam{ }anyo haret</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>pracchanno</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; prasthanno \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>'rtham{ }anyapuruṣaḥ</LEM> \msCb\msNc;
                                         vittam \msCa\msNaacorr\msNb,
                                         citta \msCc, ca vittam{ }athavā \msNapcorr\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>pratyakṣam{ }anyo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; pratyakṣam{ }ano \msCb,
                                         pratyakṣyam{ }anye \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Some [thieves] take away [other people's] wealth in disguise, some in broad daylight.</TR>
        <NOTE>Metre Łśārdūlavikrīḍita$. It appears that Łhriyate$ in Łpāda$ a is to be taken as an active verb (Łharate$).
                 Note also how \msCb\ and \msNc\ read the same here against the other witnesses.</NOTE>
% important as far \Ed is concerned
% look at \msNapc again (is it a modern hand?) mathavā is probably another hand ('ca' not so?)

%       -  - -      . . - . -    .       .  . -   - - .  -  -  . -
<TEXT> nikṣepād{ }dhanahāriṇo 'nya{-}m{-}adhamo vyājena cānyo haret|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>nikṣepād{ }dhana°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa; nikṣepā dhana° \msCc\msNb\msNc, nikṣepātraya° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°hāriṇo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °hāriṇyo \msCb, °hāriṇā \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>'nyam{ }adhamo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; 'nyam{ }adhano \msCc, 'nyavidhayo \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>cānyo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; cānyā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>haret</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; hare \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>Take °Łhāriṇo$ in Łpāda$ b as singular and Łm$ in Ł'nya-m-adhamo$ as a sandhi-bridge.
              Alternatively, read as plural: °Łhāriṇo 'nya adhamo$\dots\ </NOTE>
        <TR>Other wicked people take money from deposits, and some people steal through fraud.</TR>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

% nikṣepa as pawn ? Judit 
% vyāja is interest? Nirajan (Arthaśāstra)
%Tr. by R. Shamasastry (1956):
%2.6.10: mūlyaṃ bhāgo vyājī parighaḥ kḷptam rūpikam atyayaś cāyamukham|
%`Capital (mūla), share (bhāga), premia (vyāji), parigha[2](?), fixed taxes (kḷpta), premia on coins (rūpika[3]) and fixed fines (atyaya) are several forms of revenue (āyamukha, i.e. the mouth from which income is to issue).'
%2.6.22: vikriye paṇyānām arghavṛddhir upajā, mānaunmānaviśeṣo vyājī, krayasaṃgharṣe vārdhavṛddhiḥ - ity āyaḥ ||
%`The rise in price of merchandise due to the use of different weights[6] and measures in selling is termed vyājī; the enhancement of price due to bidding among buyers is also another source of profit.'
%vyāji = 'Transaction tax ' ( https://www.gktoday.in/gk/kautilyas-system-of-tax-administration ) 


%      -  -  -   . . -  . - . .  . - -  -  . -     -   . -
<TEXT> anye lekhyavikalpanāhṛtadhanā <crux>anyo hṛtād{ }vai hṛtā</crux></TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>anye lekhya°</LEM> \corr; anyā lekha° \msCb\msCc,
                                 anyo le<UNCL>khya</UNCL>° \msCa, anyo lekhya° \msNa\msNb\msNc, anyollekhya \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°dhanā anyo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dhanyo \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>hṛtād{ }vai</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; hṛtad{ }vai \msNa, hṛtād{ }ve \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>The second half of Łpāda$ c is difficult to reconstruct.</NOTE>
        <TR>Some gather wealth by forging documents, others steal from stolen money[?].</TR>
% anyo lekhya keep it Judit
% forging copperplates is a big topic Kengo! (Flo: Solamon has a chapter on it)

%folioinfo \msCa\ 394.jpg
%     unmetr: 
%       -  -    - .  . -  . -   . . . -!       - -  .  -  -    . -
<TEXT> anyaḥ krītadhano 'paro dhayahṛta ete jaghanyāḥ smṛtāḥ||</TEXT> 4:28
        <APP>\vd <LEM>anyaḥ krītadhano</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; anya krītadhano \msNc, anāśrītadhanaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>'paro dhayahṛta</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNb; paro dhayahyata \msCb, paro dhana<UNCL>hṛta</UNCL> \msNa, 
                                             parodhaprahṛta \msNc, madā hy{ }apahṛtaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>jaghanyāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; jaghanyaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The translation of Łpāda$ d is mostly guesswork. Tentatively, I take Łkrīta$ as Łkrītaka$ (`a purchased son', see
              \MANU\ 9.174). Łdhayahṛta$ makes little sense to me. Florinda De Simini suggested that
              Łdhaya$ might stand for Łdaya$, which in turn may stand for Łdāya$ (`inheritance') metri causa.
              Lacking any better solution, I supplied these in my translation, marked with question marks.
              Note also the metrical licence that the last syllable of Łdhayahṛta$ counts as long.</NOTE>
        <TR>Some people's wealth is from purchased [children?] (Łkrīta$).
                 Others take away others' inheritance[?]. These are considered the vilest.</TR>
% kīrtidhana?? 'paro? 'dhamahṛta? dhaya as an infant?
%vikrīṇīte ya ātmānaṃ svatantraḥ san narādhamaḥ  /
%sa jaghanyataras teṣāṃ naiva dāsyāt pramucyate  // Nar_5.35 //
% dāya for daya metri causa Florinda Dāyabhāga

%index_metre: śārdūlavikrīḍita
%index_metre: long syllable at end of word -m a- long, actually -a a-






% stenan \msCa
%folioinfo \msNb\ 48.jpg upper ends with this line (the sequence is lower - upper | lower - upper)
%        - -!-  .  .  -  .    -  .  . . -   -  -   . - -    . -
<TEXT> stenatulya na mūḍham{ }asti puruṣo dharmārthahīno 'dhamaḥ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>stenatulya</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\ \unmetr; steyastulya \msCc,
                         steyatulya \msNa\ \unmetr, tena tulya \msNb\ \unmetr, stenastulya \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>For some time I was wondering if one should accept \Ed's reading Łstenastulya na mūḍham asti$ 
                as a metri causa version of Łstenatulyo na mūḍho 'sti$; see a similar case of a nominative ending
                inside of compound in Łpāda$ c below. One major concern remained:
                the accepted reading would be of an edition that rarely emerges as 
                the sole transmitter of the best reading. Another possible solution could be 
                to emend to Łstenaṃtulya$\dots, meaning `there is no bigger foolishness than theft',
                but then the second part of Łpāda$ a is difficult to connect. In the end,
                I decided to go for the most widely attested reading (Łstenatulya$),
                which is unmetrical.

                <sep/> </NOTE>
        <TR>There is no bigger idiot than a thief, who is a wicked person without Dharma and
            financial gain (Łartha$).</TR>
% Judit go for unmetrical version?
% stenam ? CsabaK/Judit

%index_grammar: sandhi a-m-a instead of o '

%folioinfo \msNb\ 49.jpg lower
<TEXT> yāvaj{ }jīvati śaṅkayā narapateḥ saṃtrasyamāno raṭan|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>yāvaj{ }jīvati</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yāvat{ }taj{ }jīvati \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°pateḥ</LEM> \msCb\msNb\msNc; °patiḥ \msCa\msCc\msNa\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>saṃtrasyamāno raṭan</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; saṃtrāsyamāno śaṭhaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vo ŁThe lower folio side in exposure 49 in \msNb\ is rather blurred and seems to be partly erased,
                        therefore all the readings in this MS for verses 4.29--46 are rather uncertain,
                        even if not indicated explicitly.$</LACUNA>
        <TR>As long as he lives, he trembles in fear of the king, wailing.</TR>

%        -  -  - . .  -  . -  . . . -    -  - .  -  - . -
<TEXT> prāptaḥśāsana tīvrasahyaviṣamaṃ prāpnoti karmeritaḥ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>prāptaḥ°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; prāpta° \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°sahya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; \lac\ ×× \msNb, °sadya° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°viṣamaṃ</LEM> \eme; °viṣamaḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed, \lac\ ××× \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>karmeritaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; karme<UNCL>rita</UNCL> \msCa,
                                         \lac ××<UNCL>ritaḥ</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Having received his punishment, he gets into severe and [in]tolerable
                                 difficulties, propelled by [his] karma.</TR>
        <NOTE>Understand Łprāptaḥśāsana tīvrasahyaviṣamaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c as Łprāptaśāsanas tīvram asahyaṃ ca viṣamaṃ prāpnoti$.
                Alternatively, understand Łtīvrasahya$° as Łduḥsahya$°.
                The actual reading of \msCa, Łprāptaś$, lost in the process of normalization and standing
                        in contrast with that of all other MSS that read Łprāptaḥ$, may suggest
                        a doubling of the Łś$ of Łśāsana$ metri causa.
                        More likely is that a licence of having a nominative ending inside of a compound
                        is applied here, as may have been the case above in Łpāda$ a.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: nominative inside compound

% REVISE Judit: MSS prāptaśśāsana? CHECK yes: \msCa no: \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb

% unmetr                            !
%       - - -   . . -  .  - .  . . -    -  - .  -  - . -
<TEXT> kālena mriyate sa yāti nirayam{ }ākrandamāno bhṛśam||</TEXT> 4:29
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nirayam{ }ākrandamāno</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa; <UNCL>nira</UNCL>yam{ }ākrandamā<UNCL>no</UNCL> \msNb, 
                                                               nirayaṃ sa krandamāno \msNc, niyamam{ }ākrandramāno \Ed</APP>
        <TR>When his time comes, he dies and goes to hell, weeping vehemently.</TR>



%index_metre: śārdūlavikrīḍita


<PAGEBREAK/>

<LONGVERSELINES/>
<TEXT> nītvā durgatikoṭikalpa nirayāt{ }tiryatvam{ }āyānti te</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>nirayāt{ }tiryatva°</LEM> \msCb\msNa; nirayān{ }tiryatva° \msCa, nirayā tiryatva° \msCc, 
                       ni<UNCL>rayā\-t{ }tiryatva</UNCL>° \msNb, nirayān{ }tiryakṣa° \msNc, nirayān{ }tiryaktva° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Having spent ten million \ae ons of suffering,
                                 they emerge from hell to the state of animal existence.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ °Łkalpa$ for °Łkalpaṃ$ metri causa in Łpāda$ a.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form noun
%index_voc: tiryatva

<TEXT> tiryatve ca tathaivam{ }ekaśatikaṃ prabhramya varṣārbudam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tiryatve</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; <UNCL>tiryatve</UNCL> \msNb, tiryaktvaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>tathaivam{ }ekaśatikaṃ</LEM> \msCb; tathaikam{ }ekaśatikaṃ \msCa\msNa\msNc,
                        tathaikam{ }ekaśatika \msCc, <UNCL>tathai</UNCL>kam{ }ekaśatikaṃ \msNb, tathaikam{ }ekasakikaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°bhramya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; °bhrāmya \msNa, \lac ×\csa mya \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>varṣārbudam</LEM> \msNcpcorr; varṣāmbudam \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNcacorr, varṣāmbudaḥ \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ c, Łtathaivam$, or Łtathaikam$, and Łekaśatikaṃ$ are suspect.</NOTE>
        <TR>Similarly, they roam about in animal existence for a hundred and one times ten million years.</TR>

%index_voc: tiryatva

%       - -  -   .    . -  . -  .  . . -   - -   . - - . -
<TEXT> mānuṣyaṃ tad{ }avāpnuvanti vipule dāridryarogākulaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc  <LEM>mānuṣyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                 mānuṣya \msCb\ \unmetr, <UNCL>mānuṣya</UNCL> \msNb\ \toplost\oo
                 <LEM>vipule</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; vipu<UNCL>la</UNCL> \msNb\ \toplost, vipulaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>dāridrya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; \lk ri\lk\ \msNb, dāridhra° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Then they reach the status of human existence on earth which is full of poverty and disease.</TR>
        <NOTE>I understand Łvipule$ as Łvipulāyāṃ$, Łvipulā$ appearing in \Amara\ 2.1.7 as a synonym of
                        Łdhātrī$, `earth.' It is difficult to interpret it otherwise.
                        This is still problematic because both human and
                        animal existence takes place on earth, thus, if Łtiryatva$ (i.e. Łtiryaktva$) 
                        indeed means `animal existence,' there is no contrast between Łpāda$s b and c as
                        regards location. As for Łtiryaktva$, see, e.g., \MANU\ 12.40:
                        <sep/>
                                Łdevatvaṃ sāttvikā yānti manuṣyatvaṃ ca rājasāḥ$ |
                                Łtiryaktvaṃ tāmasā nityam ity eṣā trividhā gatiḥ$ ||
                        <sep/>
              It is not unlikely that the original form of Łdāridryarogākulam$ was Łdāridryarogākule$,
              picking up Łvipule$.</NOTE>

% Nirajan vipule in an extended family? still a punishment
% kule ? CsK

%folioinfo \msNc\ 218.jpg upper, f. 215v
%       -  -     -  . . - .  -  .  . . -    -   -  . -   -  . -
<TEXT> tasmād{ }durgatihetu karma sakalaṃ tyaktvā śivaṃ cāśrayet||</TEXT> 4:30
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tasmād{ }du°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; tasmā du° \msCc, <UNCL>tasmā du</UNCL>° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>cāśrayet</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; cāśrat \msNa</APP>
        <TR>Then abandoning all one's karmas, the causes of suffering, one seeks refuge in Śiva.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note the switch from plural to singular in Łpāda$ d (Łāśrayet$).</NOTE>


%index_metre: śārdūlavikrīḍita


<NORMALVERSELINES/>




<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣv{ }ānṛśaṃsyam (4)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Fourth Yama-rule: absence of hostility</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> aṣṭamūrtiśivadveṣṭā pitur{ }mātuś{ }ca yo dviṣet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°śiva°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °śivaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>The one who is hostile towards the eight-formed Śiva, he who hurts his mother or father,</TR>

<TEXT> gavāṃ vā atither{ }dveṣṭā nṛśaṃsāḥ pañca eva te||</TEXT> 4:31
        <APP>\vc <LEM>gavāṃ vā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; avām{ }vā \msCb, \lk\lk <UNCL>m{ }vā</UNCL> \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>atither{ }dve°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; atithidve° \msCc, atithe dve° \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nṛśaṃsāḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb; nṛśaṃsā \msCb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łpitur$ and Łmātur$ used as accusative forms in Łpāda$ b, or rather,
                        understand Łpitur mātuś ca yo dveṣṭā$, i.e. Łdviṣet$ is
                        metri causa for Łdveṣṭā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>he who is hostile towards cows or guests: these are the five types of hostile people.</TR>

%index_grammar: genitive for accusative or dveṣṭā for dviṣet metri causa
%index_grammar: absence of sandhi inside pāda (gavāṃ vā atither dveṣṭā)

<TEXT> aṣṭamūrtiḥ śivaḥ sākṣāt{ }pañcavyomasamanvitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°mūrtiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °mūrti° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°nvitaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °nvitāḥ \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <TR>Śiva, when manifest (Łsākṣāt$), has eight form, possessing the five elements (Łvyoman$),</TR>
% MW: aṣṭamūrti (m.) ‘eight-formed’, a N. of Śiva (as identified with the five elements, mind, egotism, and Prakṛti [matter]; or, according to the opening of the Śakuntalā, with the five elements, the sun and moon and the sacrificing priest), [MBh. iii, 1939]; [Ragh. &c.] 

%index_voc: vyoman as five elements

<TEXT> sūryaḥ somaś{ }ca dīkṣaś{ }ca dūṣakaḥ sa nṛśaṃsakaḥ||</TEXT> 4:32
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sūryaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa; <UNCL>sūrya</UNCL>° \msNb\msNc, sūrya° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>dīkṣa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; <UNCL>dī</UNCL>\lk\ \msNb, dīkṣu° \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare\ \SDHS\ 12.17:$
                mūrtayo yāḥ śivasyāṣṭau tāsu nindāṃ vivarjayet |
                guroś{ }ca śivabhaktānāṃ nṛpasādhutapasvināṃ ||</PARAL>
        <TR>and the Sun, the Moon, and the sacrificer. [He who] disgraces [any of these] is a hostile person.</TR>
        <NOTE>Törzsök has suggested emending Łsa nṛśaṃsakaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d to Łtannṛṃśakaḥ$. I don't think that it is
              inevitably necessary. I think that Łpāda$s a-c form a list that is meant to be in the genitive, understanding
              \dots\ Łity eteṣāṃ dūṣakaḥ sa nṛśaṃsakaḥ$ or similar.  This is clumsy but in a way that is
              more than possible within the style of this text.

              I have not been able find any other attestation of Łvyoman$ meaning the five elements. Perhaps it is meant
              to mean Łvyomādi$ (`the atmosphere/sky and the other four elements'). 
        
                For Śiva of eight forms, see, e.g., ŁŚakuntalā$ 1.1:
        <sep/>
                        [1] Łyā sṛṣṭiḥ sraṣṭur ādyā vahati$ [2] Łvidhihutaṃ yā havir$ [3] Łyā ca hotrī$<br/>
                        [4, 5] Łye dve kālaṃ vidhattaḥ$ [6] Łśruti-viṣaya-guṇā yā sthitā vyāpya viśvam$ |<br/>
                        [7] Łyām āhuḥ sarva-bīja-prakṛtir iti yayā prāṇinaḥ prāṇavantaḥ$ [8]<br/>
                        Łpratyakṣābhiḥ prapannas tanubhir avatu vas tābhir aṣṭābhir īśaḥ$ ||
        <sep/>
                 Here the eight Łmūrti$s, or rather, Łtanu$s, are: 
                        [1] Łjala$, [2] Łagni$, [3] Łhotrī$ (`the form that sacrifices'), [4 + 5] Łsūrya$ + Łcandra$,
                        [6] Łākāśa$, [7] Łbhūmi$, [8] Łvāyu$.

                For a similar interpretation of Łaṣṭamūrti$, see, e.g., 
                \Isanasiva\ 2.29.34 (Łmantrapāda$; note Łyajamāna$ for our Łdīkṣa$):
                <sep/>
                                        Łkṣmā-vahni-yajamānārka-jala-vāyv-indu-puṣkaraiḥ$ |<br/>
                                        Łaṣṭābhir mūrtibhiḥ śambhor dvitīyāvaraṇaṃ smṛtam$ ||
                <sep/>
                (For Łpuṣkara$ as `sky, atmosphere', see, e.g., \Amara\ 1.2.167:
                        Łdyodivau dve striyām abhraṃ vyoma puṣkaram ambaram$.)

                A closely related Aṣṭamūrti-hymn appears in \Nisvmukh\ 1.30--41 (I owe thanks to Nirajan Kafle
                        for drawing my attention to this); see <citep>KafleNisvasaBook</citep><pnum>62, 63, 116, 119</pnum>. 
                        Kafle notes that this hymn is closely parallel to some passages in the ŁPrayogamañjarī$ (1.19--26),
                        the ŁTantrasamuccaya$ (1.16--23), and the ŁĪśānaśivagurudevapaddhati$ (Łkriyāpāda$ 26.56--63). 
                                       See also \TAKI\ s.v. Łaṣṭamūrti$.</NOTE>

% tannṛ°] \emeTorzsok; sa nṛ° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed

%index_grammar: clumsy

<TEXT> pitākāśasamo jñeyo janmotpattikaraḥ pitā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°karaḥ pitā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °karapitāḥ \msCc, °<UNCL>karaḥ pitā</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <TR>The father is to be considered similar to the [element] sky, he is the cause of one's birth.</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 419.jpg upper, f. 7v  
%                    = sūrya?
<TEXT> pitṛdaivata<crux>m{ }ādiś{ }cam{ }ānṛśaṃsa tamanvitaḥ</crux>||</TEXT> 4:33
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°daivata°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °devata° \msCb, \lk vata° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°diś{ }cam{ }ānṛśaṃsa tamanvitaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb;
                                 °dityam{ }anṛśaṃsa tamanvitaḥ \msCc\msNb,
                                 °diśca anṛśaṃsa tamānvitaḥ \msNa, 
                                 °diścam{ }anṛśaṃsa tamānvitaḥ \msNc, 
                                 °dityam{ }mānṛśaṃsa tato 'nvitaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>It is difficult to restore Łpāda$s cd, although the general meaning of this line is
              predictable. Some questions remain. Is Łāditya$ a good reading or is Łmātṛ$ hidden in
              Łdaivata-mādiśca$? Is Łānṛśaṃsa$ right or was it Łnṛśaṃsa$ that was meant by the author of this line?
              Does Łtamanvitaḥ$ (or Łtamānvitaḥ$) has anything to do with Łtamas$ (`darkness')?</NOTE>
        <TR>One should not be hostile to a father, god\dots[?].</TR>
% maybe a verb at the ending Kengo
% ādṛtya ? Nirajan mā nṛśaṃset? Nirajan
% tamo'nvitaḥ : Judit is doubtful about it
% ādi seems better Judit

<TEXT> pṛthvyā gurutarī mātā ko na vandeta mātaram|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>pṛthvyā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc; <UNCL>pṛthvyā</UNCL> \msCc\msNa, pṛthvī \msNb, 
                                                                pṛthvyāṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vandeta</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vandena vandeta \msCb, vandyeta \msCc</APP>
        <TR>The mother is more venerable than the earth. Who would not praise a mother?</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 415.jpg, 207r
%folioinfo \msCc\ 193.jpg, f. 275r
% syntax
<TEXT> yajñadānatapovedās{ }tena sarvaṃ kṛtaṃ bhavet||</TEXT> 4:34
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sarvaṃ</LEM> \eme; sarva \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>By that [praise], sacrifices, donations, austerities and [the study of] the Vedas, all will
                        be completed.</TR>

<TEXT> gāvaḥ pavitraṃ maṅgalyaṃ devatānāṃ ca devatāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>pavitraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; <UNCL>pavitra</UNCL> \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>maṅgalyaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa; māṅgalyaṃ \msCc\msNc\Ed, <UNCL>maṅgalyaṃ</UNCL> \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>devatāḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc; daivatāḥ \msNa, <UNCL>devatāḥ</UNCL> \msNb, devatā \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\va Ł\similar\ \VISNUS\ 23.57c:$ gāvaḥ pavitramaṅgalyaṃ (goṣu lokāḥ pratiṣṭhitā)\oo
                Ł\compare\ also \MBH\ Suppl. 13.15.33:$ gāvaḥ pavitraṃ paramaṃ goṣu lokāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ 
                Łand \AGNIP\ 291.1cd:$ gāvaḥ pavitrā māṅgalyā goṣu lokāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ</PARAL>
        <TR>Cows are an auspicious blessing, they are the gods of the gods.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<TEXT> sarvadevamayā gāvas{ }tasmād{ }eva na hiṃsayet||</TEXT> 4:35
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°smād{ }eva</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °smād{ }uva \msCb, °smād{ }gāvaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vc Ł= \VDHU\ 3.291.25c$</PARAL>
        <TR>Cows contain in themselves all the gods. That is exactly why one should not hurt them.</TR>

<TEXT> jātamātrasya lokasya gāvas{ }trātā na saṃśayaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>jātamātrasya lokasya</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; satasātasya \msCbacorr,
                                                        satasātasya nokasya \msCbpcorr,
                                                        jātamātra<UNCL>sya lokasya</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the number confusion in the phrase Łgāvas trātā$, for Łgāvas trātāras$. Alternatively,
              this line might try to echo \Harivamsa\ 45.30ab: 
                Łtrātavyāḥ prathamaṃ gāvas trātās trāyanti tā dvijān$ 
               (`First the cows should be protected. When protected, they protect the Brahmins').</NOTE>
                <TR>Cows are the protectors of the world as if the world were their new-born [calf], 
                                        there is no doubt about it.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 201.jpg upper, f.7v
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.594
<TEXT> ghṛtaṃ kṣīraṃ dadhi mūtraṃ śakṛtkarṣaṇam{ }eva ca||</TEXT> 4:36
        <APP>\vd <LEM>śakṛt{ }ka°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; kṣat{ }ka° \msCb, <UNCL>śakṛt{ }ka</UNCL>° \msNb</APP>
                <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare\ \SDHU\ 12.92ff$</PARAL>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ c is a Łsa-viplulā$. 
              The use of Łkarsaṇa$ in Łpāda$ d, most probably in the sense of `collecting,' is slightly odd.</NOTE>
        <TR>Collecting [the five products of the cow, the Łpañcagavya$,] 
                        ghee, milk, curd, and [the cow's] urine and dung [is auspicious].</TR>

%index_metre: sa-vipulā

% tṛṇāni khādanti vasanty{ }araṇye pibanti toyāny{ }aparigrahāṇi|
% duhyanti bāhyanti punanti pāpaṃ gavāṃ rasair{ }jīvati jīvalokaḥ|| 92||
% kutas{ }teṣāṃ hi pāpāni yeṣāṃ gṛham{ }alaṅkṛtaṃ|
% satataṃ bālavatsābhir gobhiḥ śrībhir iva svayaṃ|| 93||
% ye kurvanti gavāṃ bhaktiṃ tṛṇatoyapradānataḥ|
% praṇasaṃrohanādyaiś{ }ca gavāṃ lokaṃ vrajanti te|| 94||
% tṛṇatoyapradeśeṣu nītvā yatnena mātaraḥ|
% ye rakṣanti sadā gopāḥ śivaloke vrajanti te|| 95||
% ye śivāya guror{ }vāpi gāṃ prayacchanti bhaktitaḥ|
% te modanti śiveloke bhogaiḥ kalpāyutan{ }narāḥ|| 96||
% nivedya gorasaṃ bhakatyā śivāya śivayogine|
% sarvān{ }kāmān{ }avāpnoti śivalokam{ }ito gataḥ|| 97||
% ihalokasukhārthāya paralokahitāya ca|
% sarvasvenāpi gāntasmād{ }ādadīta vipaścitaiḥ|| 98||
% aho sumahadāś{ }caryam{ }aho suṣṭhu subhāṣitaṃ|
% yat{ }pavitraś{ }ca mṛṣṭaś{ }ca goraso buddhivarddhanaḥ|| 99||
% gomatā nirjitāḥ lokā vṛtāśāgomatārjitāḥ|
% gomatā nirjitaḥ svargaḥ samastaṃ gomatā jitaṃ|| 100||
% gāvo bandhur{ }manuṣyāṇāṃ gāvaś{ }ca dhanam{ }uttamaṃ|
% gāvo yeṣāṃ gṛhe na syur{ }abandhur{ }iva tadgṛhaṃ|| 101||
% spṛṣṭvā tu gāvaḥ śamayanti pāpaṃ datvā tu gāvas{ }tridivaṃ nayanti|
% saṃrakṣitāś{ }copanayanti vittaṃ gobhir{ }nna tulyaṃ dhanama sti kiñcit|| 102||
% sampannam{ }aśnāti dadāti nityaṃ pāpāpahaṃ mitravivarddhanaṃ ca|
% sa eva cārthaḥ paribhujyate ca gobhir{ }nna tulyaṃ dhanam{ }asti kiñcit|| 103||
% tṛṇāni śuṣkāṇi vane caritvā pītvā ca toyāny{ }amṛtaṃ sravanti|
% yad{ }gomayādyaiś{ }ca punanti lokān{ }gobhir{ }nna tulyan{ }dhanam{ }asti kiñcit|| 104||
% sa eva loke paramaḥ pavitro gavāṃ rasaḥ puṣṭi vivarddhanaś{ }ca|
% aśnāti nityaṃ vividhānnayuktāmiṣṭañ{ }ciraṃ yena śiva prasādāt|| 105||
% gomātṛśālāṃ yaḥ kuryāt sudṛḍhāmiṣṭakāmayīṃ ||
% mṛtpiṇḍakāṣṭhākuḍyaṃ vā satkapāṭārgalānvitāṃ || 12.106 ||
% sapidhānairgavākṣaiś ca caturbhiḥ samalaṅkṛtāṃ ||
% paścāt kuḍyaṃ ca kartavyam uccair eva gavākṣakaṃ || 12.107 ||
% supakkvair vaṃśavidalaiḥ kaṭaṃ kṛtvā samaṃdṛḍhaṃ ||
% gavām adhaḥ pradātavyaṃ yena mūtram adho vrajet || 12.108 ||
% gomayaṃ taṅgavākṣaiś ca kṣiptvā dūraṃ punar nnayet ||
% vikīrya bhasmanā sarvaṃ dhūpayīta samantataḥ || 12.109 ||
% kṛśavṛddhāturāṇāṃ ca pṛthagbhāvaṃ prakalpayet ||
% pṛthak ca bālavatsānām itareṣāṃ pṛthagbhavet || 12.110 ||
% damyānaḍvāha ya prāṇāṃ (vṛṣāṇāṃ) vasatiṃ kalpayet pṛthak ||
% gāḥ (gāvaḥ) svapanti sukhenaiva vasanti ca ramanti ca || 12.111 ||
% rudro brahmā ca viṣṇuś ca gośālāyāṃ sadā yajet ||
% vinyasya pūrvavadanāṃ paścāt kuḍayagavākṣake || 12.112 ||
% % SEE ŚDhU 12.89 (Yuko) ! CHECK
% saṃhārūḍhāṃ mahādurgāṃ pañca nandādimātaraḥ ||
% vighneśaṃ somanandiṃ ca pūrvādārabhya vinyaset || 12.113 ||
% nadyubhaya taṭāśvattha vilvavalmīkamṛttikāṃ ||
% pañcagavyena saṃyojya devān piṇḍaiḥ prakalpayet || 12.114 ||
% dvāraśākhāgavākṣābhyāṃ mṛdākāryau suśobhanau ||
% nandīśvaramahākālau vṛṣaṃ coccair vahiḥ sthitaṃ || 12.115 ||
% yādṛśo'yaṃ vṛṣendraḥ syāt sarvāvayavaśobhanaḥ || 
% taddarśanānubhāvena gavāṃ syustādṛśāḥ prajāḥ || 12.116 ||
% aṣṭamyāṃ snāpanaṃ kṛtvā bhojanaṃ ca prakāmataḥ ||
% svasti vācyaṃ tataś cāgre pradhānāṅgāmpraveśayet || 12.117 ||
% iti yaḥ kārayed bhaktyā gomātṛgṛhamīdṛśaṃ ||
% sa vidhūyāśu pāpāni śivaloke mahīyate || 12.118 ||


<NOTANUSTUBH/> upajāti
%       -  - . -   -  . . -  . - -    
<TEXT> pañcāmṛtaṃ pañcapavitrapūtaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°pavitrapūtam</LEM> \msCc\msNa\Ed; °pavitrapūtana \msCa\ \unmetr,
                        °pavitraṃ \msCb\ \unmetr, °pavitrapūta \msNb,
                        °pavitrapūtaṃnaṃ \msNc\ \unmetr</APP>

%       -  -  . -  -   . . -   . - - 
<TEXT> ye pañcagavyaṃ puruṣāḥ pibanti|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°gavyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °gavyā \msCc, °<UNCL>gavyāṃ</UNCL> \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>puruṣāḥ</LEM>  \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; puruṣā \msCc, puruṣaḥ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>pibanti</LEM>  \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vivanti \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>The five Łpavitra$s can be the five Łbrahmamantras$, see, e.g., \TAKIII\ s.v. Łpavitra$ 1.</NOTE>
        <TR>People who drink the five products of the cow,
                 the five nectars, purified by the five Pavitras,</TR>

%       -  - . -  -  .   . -   .  -  -
<TEXT> te vājimedhasya phalaṃ labhanti</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>labhanti</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; bhavanti \msCc</APP>
        <TR>will obtain the fruits of a horse sacrifice, </TR>

%       .    -  . -    -  .    . -  . - -  
<TEXT> tad{ }akṣayaṃ svargam{ }avāpnuvanti||</TEXT> 4:37
        <APP>\vd <LEM>svarga°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sva° \msCb</APP>
        <TR>and then reach the undecaying heavens.</TR>

%index_metre: upajāti

<TEXT> gobhir{ }na tulyaṃ dhanam{ }asti kiṃcid</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>gobhir{ }na tu°</LEM> \msNc; na gobhis{ }tu° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\ \unmetr, na gāvatu° \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\va Ł= \SDHU\ 12.102d, 103d, 104d; $ 
                   Ł\compare\ \MBH\ 13.51.26cd:$ gobhis{ }tulyaṃ na paśyāmi dhanaṃ kiṃcid{ }ihācyuta</PARAL>
        <TR>There is no wealth comparable to a cow.</TR>

<TEXT> duhyanti vāhyanti bahiś{ }caranti|</TEXT>
        <NOTE>Note that Łduhyanti$ and Łvāhyanti$ are supposed to be understood as passive,
              as in the similar verse in \SDHU\ 12.92 (see apparatus).</NOTE>
        <TR>They yield milk, they carry things, they roam under the sky.</TR>
        % ŚDhU 12 comm: duhyanti duhyante kṣīraṃ vāhyanti vāhyante bhāraṃ atra karmmakarttṛkatvan 
                      %  draṣṭavyaṃ punanti pañcagavyadvāreṇa jagacchodhayanti
<PAGEBREAK/>
% Nirajan wild cows?

<TEXT> tṛṇāni bhuktvā amṛtaṃ sravanti</TEXT>
        <TR>Feeding on grass, they issue nectar.</TR>

<TEXT> vipreṣu dattāḥ kulam{ }uddharanti||</TEXT> 4:38
        <APP>\vd <LEM>dattāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; <UNCL>dattā</UNCL> \msCc, dattā \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare\ \SDHU\ 12.92:$
                        tṛṇāni khādanti vasanty{ }araṇye pibanti toyāny{ }aparigrahāṇi|
                        duhyanti vāhyanti punanti pāpaṃ gavāṃ rasair{ }jīvati jīvalokaḥ||</PARAL>
        <TR>When given to Brahmins, they deliver the family [from Łsaṃsāra$ or the suffering experienced in hell].</TR>

%index_metre: upajāti

<TEXT> gavāhnikaṃ yaś{ }ca karoti nityaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>gavāhnikaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; gavāṃhnikaṃ \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>yaś{ }ca karoti</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yaḥ prakaroti \Ed</APP>
        <TR>He who feeds the cows daily,</TR>

<TEXT> śuśrūṣaṇaṃ yaḥ kurute gavāṃ tu|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>gavāṃ tu</LEM> \msCb\msNc; gavān{ }tu \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb, gavānām \Ed</APP>
      % aseṣa/asaiṣa \msCa
        <TR>he who serves the cows,</TR>

% unmetr
<TEXT> aśeṣayajñatapadānapuṇyaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°tapa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °<UNCL>tapa</UNCL>° \msNb, °japa° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Strictly speaking, Łpāda$ c is unmetrical. The second syllable of Łyajña$ counts as
              long (see Introduction p.~\pageref{short2long}).</NOTE>

        %index_metre: long syllable at end of word

%       .  -     . -   -    . . -  . -  -  
<TEXT> labhaty{ }asau tām{ }anṛśaṃsakartā||</TEXT> 4:39
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>labhaty{ }asau tām{ }anṛśaṃsakartā</LEM> \eme;
                      labhaty{ }asau tam{ }anṛśaṃsakartā \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc,
                         labhaty{ }asau bham{ }anṛśaṃsakarttā \msCa,
                                 labhaty{ }asau tam{ }anṛtaṃ sa karttā \msCc,
                                 bhavaty{ }asau dharmam{ }aśeṣakartā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Although the accusative with °Łkartā$ in Łpāda$ d is still not optimal, my 
              emendation of Łtam$ to Łtām$ at least restores the metre and improves 
              upon the meaning of the sentence. Alternatively, as suggested by Törzsök,
              Łtaṃ$ could be understood as Łtad$, picking up Łpuṇyaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c,
              but in this way any reference to cows here is only implied.</NOTE>
        <TR>he who is kind to her [i.e. to the cow], will obtain the merits of all sacrifices,
                 austerities and donation.</TR>


%index_metre: upajāti

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> atithiṃ yo 'nugaccheta atithiṃ yo 'numanyate|</TEXT>
        <NOTE>Note the peculiar active verb forms Łanugaccheta$ and Łanupūjyeta$.
              On this formation, see a remark about \Nisvmul\ 2.8 in <citep>NisvasaGoodall</citep><pnum>247</pnum>:
                        `We have assumed that Łpūjyeta$ is intended to mean Łpūjayet$ and is
                        perhaps a contraction of Łpūjayeta$.'</NOTE>
        <TR>He who looks after a guest, he who respects a guest,</TR>
                % Nirajan: follows Dharmasūtras , accompany

<TEXT> atithiṃ yo 'nupūjyeta atithiṃ yaḥ praśaṃsate||</TEXT> 4:40
        <APP>\vd <LEM>praśaṃsate</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; praśaṃsyate \msCc</APP>
        <TR>he who worships a guest, he who praises a guest,</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 395.jpg
<TEXT> atithiṃ yo na pīḍyeta atithiṃ yo na duṣyati|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>na pīḍyeta</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; na gaccheta (Łeyeskip to 4.40c$) \msCc,
                                                 <UNCL>na pī</UNCL>\lk\lk\ \msNb, nipīḍyeta \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>atithiṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; atiṃ \msCc, \lk\lk\lk\ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>na duṣyati</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; nuduṣyati \msCb, \lk\ duṣyati \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>On the form Łpīḍyeta$, see previous note.</NOTE>
        <TR>he who does not harm a guest, he who does not commit a fault towards a guest,</TR>

<TEXT> atithipriyakartā yaḥ atitheḥ paricārakaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>atithi°</LEM> \msCa\msNa; atithiṃ \msCb\msCc\msNc\Ed, ati<UNCL>thiṃ</UNCL> \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°priya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; priyaḥ \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>yaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; yar \msCa, ya \msNa</APP>
                        % second time of r being a sandhi bridge?
        <TR>he who keeps the guest happy, he who attends to the needs of a guest,</TR>

<TEXT> atitheḥ kṛtasaṃtoṣas{ }tasya puṇyam{ }anantakam||</TEXT> 4:41
        <APP>\ve <LEM>atitheḥ</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNc; atithi° \msCa\msNa\msNb, atithiṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vef <LEM>°saṃtoṣas{ }tasya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °saṃtā yasya \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>puṇya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; pūna° \msNc</APP>
        <TR>he who makes a guest satisfied: his merits are endless.</TR>

<TEXT> āsanenārghapātreṇa pādaśaucajalena ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°ārgha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °ārdhya° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°pātreṇa</LEM> \conj; °pādyena \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>My conjecture in Łpāda$ a (°Łpātreṇa$ for °Łpādyena$) is inspired by the fact that 
                in the MSS Łpāda$ b seems to awkwardly repeat what °Łpādyena$ in Łpāda$ a signifies.</NOTE>
        <TR>He should offer [the guest] a seat, a vessel with water-offering, and 
                                water for washing his feet,</TR>
                                        % argha is for the hands (Dominic when reading HCC 29.141

<TEXT> annavastrapradānair{ }vā sarvaṃ vāpi nivedayet||</TEXT> 4:42
        <APP>\vc <LEM>annava°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; annam{ }va° \msCc, <UNCL>anna</UNCL>va° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nivedayet</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; pradāpayet \Ed</APP>
        <TR>or gifts of food and clothes, or all [of these].</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> putradārātmano vāpi yo 'tithim{ }anupūjayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dārātmano</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °<UNCL>dārā</UNCL>tmano \msCa, °dārātmako \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°pūjayet</LEM> \msCa\msNa\Ed; °pūjyate \msCb\msCc\msNb, °pūjate \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>I analyse Łpāda$ a as if it read Łputradārair ātmano$ (Łputradāraiḥ$ being a
                common expression). Another solution would be to emend to °Łātmanā$,
                and thus to include the possibility of sacrificing one's own life for the guest.
                <sep/>
                For the requirement that one should in certain circumstances 
                part with his wife or son, or his own life,
                for the benefit of someone else, see \VSS\ 2.38, and the narrative in \VSS\ chapter 12
                which tells about a Brahmin giving away his own wife to a guest.
                Note that in fact \VSS\ 4.44cd below echoes verse 37cd in the above mentioned chapter 12
                (see the apparatus).</NOTE>
        <TR>He who worships the guest by [offering him] his own son or wife</TR>

<TEXT> śraddhayā cāvikalpena aklībamānasena ca||</TEXT> 4:43
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śraddhayā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; śraddhāyā \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>cāvikalpena</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; cāpi kalpena \msCa</APP>
        <TR>with willingness, without hesitation, and with a brave heart,</TR>

<TEXT> na pṛcched{ }gotracaraṇaṃ svādhyāyaṃ deśajanmanī|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°caraṇaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °pravaraṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>deśajanmanī</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; deśajanmanā \msCa</APP>
        <PARAL> Ł\vab = \UUMS\ 10.7ab = \UMS\ 6.11ab \similar\ \MBH\ 13.62.18ab:
                $na pṛcched{ }gotracaraṇaṃ svādhyāyaṃ deśam{ }eva vā</PARAL>
        <TR>and does not ask [the guest about his] lineage, Vedic affiliation (Łcaraṇa$), 
                                        studies, country or birth,</TR>

<TEXT> cintayen{ }manasā bhaktyā dharmaḥ svayam{ }ihāgataḥ||</TEXT> 4:44
        <APP>\vc <LEM>cintayen{ }ma°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; cittayet{ }ma° \msCb, cintayet{ }ma° \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°gataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °gatāḥ \msCc, ga<UNCL>tam</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\compare\ 12.37cd: $dvijarūpadharo dharmaḥ svayam{ }eva ihāgataḥ</PARAL>
        <TR>and imagines mentally, with devotion, that it is Dharma himself who has come to visit,</TR>

<TEXT> aśvamedhasahasrāṇi rājasūyaśatāni ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°sūya°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; °sūrya° \msCb\msCc, °sū<UNCL>rya</UNCL>° \msNb</APP>
        <TR>[will obtain all the fruits of] thousands of Aśvamedha sacrifices and hundreds 
                                        of Rājasūya sacrifices,</TR>

<TEXT> puṇḍarīkasahasraṃ ca sarvatīrthatapaḥphalam||</TEXT> 4:45
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°tapaḥ°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °tapa° \msNc\ \unmetr</APP>
        <TR>a thousand Puṇḍarīka sacrifices and the fruit of [visiting] all the pilgrimage places and
                [performing] all the austerities;</TR>
                        % tapas at the tīrthas? Florinda
       % See \MBH\ Supp 14.4.1624 ff:
       %                         <skt>
       %                         bhagavān uvāca|
       %                         śṛṇuṣvāvahito rājan puṣpāṇi prītikṛnti me|
       %                         kumudaṃ karavīraṃ ca caṇakaṃ campakaṃ tathā||
       %                         mallikājātipuṣpaṃ ca nandyāvartaṃ ca nandikam|
       %                         palāśapuṣpapatrāṇi dūrvā bhṛṅgakam eva ca||
       %                         vanamālā ca rājendra matpriyāṇi viśeṣataḥ|
       %                         sarveṣām api puṣpāṇāṃ sahasraguṇam utpalam||
       %                         tasmāt padmaṃ tathā rājan padmāt tu śatapatrakam|
       %                         tasmāt sahasrapatraṃ tu puṇḍarīkaṃ tataḥ param||
       %                         <b>puṇḍarīkasahasrāt</b> tu tulasī guṇato 'dhikā|</skt>

<TEXT> atithir{ }yasya tuṣyeta nṛśaṃsamatam{ }utsṛjet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>nṛśaṃsamatam{ }utsṛjet</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc; nṛśaṃsamata utsṛjet \msCb, 
                             nṛśaṃsakamamam{ }utsṛjet \msCc, nṛsasamatam{ }utsṛjet \msNb, na saṃśaya samaśnute \Ed</APP>
        <TR>he whose guest is satisfied [and] he who can abandon the sentiment of cruelty,</TR>
% See also Vāyupurāṇa 1.23.105ff

%folioinfo \msCc\ 194.jpg, f. 275v
%folioinfo \msNb\ 49.jpg upper
<TEXT> sa tasya sakalaṃ puṇyaṃ prāpnuyān{ }nātra saṃśayaḥ||</TEXT> 4:46
        <NOTE>The demonstrative pronoun Łtasya$ in Łpāda$ c may refer to the guest:
              `he will obtain all his [i.e. the guest's] merits,' hinting at some sort of karmic exchange.
                Nevertheless, I think rather that Łtasya$ points to the merits one can obtain by the rituals listed 
                in the previous verse. This is suggested by passages such as the following:
                <sep/>
                \MBH\ Suppl. 13.14.379--380:
                <sep/>
                       Łahany ahani yo dadyāt kapilāṃ dvādaśīḥ samāḥi$ | <br/>
                       Łmāsi māsi ca satreṇa yo yajeta sadā naraḥ$ ||  <br/>
                       Łgavāṃ śatasahasraṃ ca yo dadyāj jyeṣṭhapuṣkare$ |  <br/>
                       Łna taddharmaphalaṃ tulyam atithir yasya tuṣyati$ || <br/>
                <sep/>
                 \BRAHMAVP\ 3.44--46:
                <sep/>
                        Łatithiḥ pūjito yena pūjitāḥ sarvadevatāḥ$ | <br/>
                        Łatithir yasya saṃtuṣṭas tasya tuṣṭo hariḥ svayam$ || <br/>
                        Łsnānena sarvatīrtheṣu sarvadānena yat phalam$ |   <br/>
                        Łsarvavratopavāsena sarvayajñeṣu dīkṣayā$ ||  <br/>
                        Łsarvais tapobhir vividhair nityair naimittikādibhiḥ$ |   <br/>
                        Łtad evātithisevāyāḥ kalāṃ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīm$ ||</NOTE>
        <TR>will obtain all the merits of the above, there is no doubt about it.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNc\ 218.jpg lower, f. 216r
<TEXT> <crux>na gatim{ }atithijñasya</crux> gatim{ }āpnoti karhacit|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>na gatim{ }a°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc; na tithim{ }a° \msCc\Ed, na gati nā° \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>karhacit</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; karhicit \msCa\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Something has gone wrong with Łpāda$s ab and I am unable to reconstruct the
                meaning. The translation tries to reflect what is actually transmitted.
                The line may have begun with something like Łnāgatātithyavajña$°
                (`he who despises a guest that has arrived will not\dots'). I have accepted
                Łkarhacit$ for standard Łkarhicit$ in Łpāda$ b because it is attested in Buddhist texts,
                see <citep>EdgertonHybrid</citep><pnum>s.v. Łkarhacid$</pnum>, and 
                because the readings support it overwhelmingly, unlike in 4.3b above.</NOTE>
        <TR>One will never reach a path that is the path of one who 
            knows his guest.[?]</TR>


%folioinfo \msM\ 419.jpg lower, f. 8r  
<TEXT> tasmād{ }atithim{ }āyāntam{ }abhigacchet{ }kṛtāñjaliḥ||</TEXT> 4:47
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°yānta°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °yānti° \msCc</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł= \VAYUP\ 2.17.8 = \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 2.15.8 
                        \similar\ \SDHU\ 4.44ab:$
                        tasmād{ }atithim{ }āyāntam{ }anugacchet{ }kṛtāñjaliḥ</PARAL>
        <TR>Therefore one should go up to the arriving guest with respectfully joined palms.</TR>

<TEXT> saktuprasthena caikena yajña āsīn{ }mahādbhutaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>saktu°</LEM> \eme; śanku° \msCa\msCb, śaṃktu° \msCc, śaktu° \msNa\msNc, śakthu° \msNb, śakti° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>caikena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; cekena \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>āsīn{ }mahādbhutaḥ</LEM> \corr; āsīn{ }mahadbhutaḥ \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb, āsī mahadbhutaḥ \msCc, 
                                               āsīt{ }mahādbhutaḥ \msNc, āsīn{ }mahadbhutam \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>This verse is a reference to the story related by a mongoose in \MBH\ 14.92--93: 
                A Brahmin who practises the vow of gleaning (Łuñcha$) and his family
                receive a guest. They feed the guest with the last morsels of the little food
                they have. In the end, the guest reveals that he is in fact Dharma (14.93.80cd) and as 
                a reward the family departs to heaven. The noble act of the poor Brahmin and his family
                is depicted as yielding greater rewards than Yudhiṣṭhira's grandiose horse-sacrifice. 
                (See an analysis of this story in <cite>TakahashiUnca</cite>.)

        </NOTE>
        <TR>By one Łprastha$[, a small unit of weight] of coarsely ground grains</TR>

<TEXT> atithiprāptadānena svaśarīraṃ divaṃ gatam||</TEXT> 4:48
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dānena</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °prādānena \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sva°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; <UNCL>sa</UNCL>° \msNc, sa° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°gatam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °gataḥ \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>We would be forced to accept the reading of \Ed\ in Łpāda$ d (Łsaśarīro$) 
                if the expression were in the masculine (Łdivaṃ gataḥ$). This would make sense
                and it would also echo expressions occuring, e.g., in the \MBH:
                3.164.33cd: Łpaśya puṇyakṛtāṃ lokān saśarīro divaṃ vraja$;
                14.5.10cd: Łsaṃjīvya kālam iṣṭaṃ ca saśarīro divaṃ gataḥ$.
                It is tempting to emend accordingly, but instead I have retained 
                Łsvaśarīraṃ divaṃ gatam$, and I interpret it in a general way.</NOTE>
        <TR>given to a guest, an extremely wonderful sacrifice was performed,
                and his body [i.e. the protagonist in his mortal form] reached heaven.</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> nakulena purādhītaṃ vistareṇa dvijottama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °ttamam \msCc, °ttamaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The mongoose related [this story in the ŁMahābhārata$] in the past in detail, O great Brahmin,</TR>

<TEXT> viditaṃ ca tvayā pūrvaṃ prasthavārttā ca kīrtitā||</TEXT> 4:49
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kīrtitā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; kīrtitam \msCc, kīrtitāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>and you must know it already. The story of the Łprastha$ is well-known.</TR>
% https://www.sacred-texts.com/hin/m14/m14090.htm (= etext 14.92.1 ff.)

<TRPAGEBREAK/>

<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣu damaḥ (5)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Fifth Yama-rule: self-restraint</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> dama eva manuṣyāṇāṃ dharmasārasamuccayaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dharmasāra°</LEM> \eme; dharmaḥ sāra° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, dharmabhāra° \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vb Ł\compare, e.g., \MBH\ Suppl. 14.4.2477: $śrotum{ }icchāmi kārtsnyena dharmasārasamuccayam</PARAL>
        <TR>Self-restraint is in itself the distilled essence of Dharma for man.\linebreak</TR>
% see MBh e.g. maybe quote some for support
% a work called dharmasārasamuccaya:
% http://catalogue-old.ngmcp.uni-hamburg.de/mediawiki/index.php/C_44-8(7)_S%C4%81rasamuccaya

<TEXT> damo dharmo damaḥ svargo damaḥ kīrtir{ }damaḥ sukham||</TEXT> 4:50
        <APP>\vc <LEM>svargo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; svarga \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kīrtir{ }da°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\Ed; kīrti da° \msCc\msNa\msNc</APP>
        <TR>Self-re\-straint is Dharma, self-restraint is heaven, 
                 self-restraint is fame, self-re\-straint is happiness.</TR>

%                                              damaḥs \msCc
<TEXT> damo yajño damas{ }tīrthaṃ damaḥ puṇyaṃ damas{ }tapaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>damas{ }tī°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dama tī° \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Self-restraint is sacrifice, self-restraint is a pilgrimage-place, 
                 self-restraint is merit, self-restraint is religious austerity.</TR>

<TEXT> damahīna{-}m{-}adharmaś{ }ca damaḥ kāmakulapradaḥ||</TEXT> 4:51
        <APP>\vd <LEM>damaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; dama \msCc, damaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>kāma°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; kāmaṃ \msNc</APP>
         <NOTE>I suspect that the final Łm$ in Łdhamahīnam$ in Łpāda$ c is a hiatus-filler.
                 Understand Łdhamahīno 'dharmaś ca$.
                 Łkāmakulapradaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d is slightly suspect.
                 It may have originally read Łsarvakāmapradaḥ$ (`fulfilling all desires') or
                 Łkulakāmapradaḥ$ (`fulfilling the desires of the family').
                 \SDHS\ 4.28b reads Łsarvakāmasukhapradam$, which opens up further possibilities.</NOTE>
        <TR>If one has no self-restraint, one is a sinner (Ładharma$), 
                 [while] self-restraint yields a multitude of desired objects.</TR>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

% unmetr!
<TEXT> nirdamaḥ kari mīnaś{ }ca pataṅgabhramaramṛgāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°damaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dama \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°bhramara°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed\ \unmetr; °bhrama<UNCL>rā</UNCL>° \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łkari$ for Łkarī$ metri causa, and the end of Łpāda$ b, °Łmṛgāḥ$, which 
                        should be treated metrically as if it read °Łmrigāḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The elephant, the fish, the moth, the bee, and the deer are without self-restraint.</TR>
% nirdama is a rare word, but it's in the Harivaṃśa:
% tava sapta vṛṣā gopa nirdamāḥ sasyaghātakāḥ HV_App.I,12.55

%index_metre: unmetrical at end of line and ṛ -> ri
%index_voc: nirdama is rare?
%index_grammar: shortening metri causa

%folioinfo \msNa\ 201.jpg lower, f.8r
<TEXT> tvag{ }jihvā ca tathā ghrāṇā cakṣuḥ śravaṇam{ }indriyāḥ||</TEXT> 4:52
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ghrāṇā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ghrāṇaṃ \msCb, ghrāṇa \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ndriyāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °ndriyaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The senses are the skin, the tongue, the nose, the eye, and\linebreak the ear.</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.595

<TEXT> durjayendriyam{ }ekaikaṃ sarve prāṇaharāḥ smṛtāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sarve</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sarva° \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>°harāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °harā \Ed</APP>
                <TR>Each of these sense faculties are hard to conquer and 
                        all are known to be fatal [if unconquered].</TR>

<TEXT> damaṃ yo jayate 'samyag{ }nirdamo nidhanaṃ vrajet||</TEXT> 4:53
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vrajet</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vraje\lac\ × \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>The only way to make sense of Łpāda$s cd is to supply and Łavagraha$ before
              Łsamyag$. Otherwise some text may have dropped out here.</NOTE>
        <TR>If one masters self-restraint in a less than proper way,
                 one remains unrestrained and will die.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 417.jpg, f. 207v
<TEXT> mṛge śrotravaśān{ }mṛtyuḥ pataṅgāś{ }cakṣuṣor{ }mṛtāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>mṛge</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; mṛgo \msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>śrotra°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; śotra° \msCc, śrota° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°vaśā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °vacaśā° \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>pataṅgāś{ }ca°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; pataṅgā ca° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°ṣor{ }mṛtāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; °so mṛtāḥ \msCc, °ṣo mṛtāḥ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>In the case of the deer, death comes about because of hearing [when, e.g., hunters use buck grunts].
                 Moths die because of their eyes [as they are attracted to the light of a lamp].</TR>

%index_grammar: loc/gen for abl cakṣusor
% Alessandro: 'sajāla' hunting; imitate sounds? śyainika śāstra? "hunters shouting" try to frighten the deer?

<TEXT> ghrāṇayā bhramaro naṣṭo naṣṭo mīnaś{ }ca jihvayā||</TEXT> 4:54
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ghrāṇayā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ghrātayā \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>naṣṭo naṣṭo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; naṣṭo \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Bees perish because of their smelling [as they are attracted to smells],
                 fish because of their tongues [when attracted by the bait].</TR>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare\ \BUDDHACARITA\ 11.35:$ 
               gītair{ }hriyante hi mṛgā vadhāya rūpārtham{ }agnau śalabhāḥ patanti| 
               matsyo giraty{ }āyasam{ }āmiṣārthī tasmād{ }anarthaṃ viṣayāḥ phalanti||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>My comments in square brackets in the translation are tentative. See
              a verse from the \Buddhacarita\ (11.35) in the apparatus that may have been
              the inspiration for this verse in the \VSS. In Johnston's translation
              (<citeyear>Buddhacarita</cite>, II. 157):
              `For deer are lured to their destruction by songs, moths fly into the fire
              for its brightness, the fish greedy for the bait swallows the hook;
              therefore the objects of sense breed calamity.'</NOTE>

%See also Harśacarita 3:
%māndhātā mārgaṇavyasanena saputrapautro rasātalamagāt|
%purukutsaḥ kutsitaṃ karma tapasyannapi mekalakandhakāyāmakarot|
%etc.

<PAGEBREAK/>

% melasse Alessandro
<TEXT> sparśena ca karī naṣṭo bandhanāvāsaduḥsahaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°saduḥsahaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °saduḥsaha \msCb, °sudussahaḥ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁMātaṅgalīlā$ 11.1 may shed some light on elephants dying in captivity:
               <sep/>
               Łvānyas tatra sukhoṣitā vidhivaśād grāmāvatīrṇā gajā baddhās tīkṣṇakaṭūgravāgbhir$
               Łatiśugbhīmohabandhādibhiḥ | udvignāś ca manaḥśarīrajanitair duḥkhair atīvākṣamāḥ$
               Łprāṇān dhārayituṃ ciraṃ naravaśaṃ prāptāḥ svayūthād atha$ ||
               <sep/>
                In Edgerton's translation (<citeyear>EdgertonElephant</citeyear>, 92): 
               <sep/>
                `Forest elephants who dwell there happily and by
                the power of fate have been brought to town in bonds, afflicted by harsh, bitter, cruel words,
                by excessive grief, fear, bewilderment, bondage, etc., and by sufferings of mind and body,
                are quite unable for long to sustain life, when from their own herds they have come into
                the control of men.'</NOTE>
        <TR>The elephant perishes because of touch, not tolerating to be kept in fetters.</TR>
% Trautmann on elephants Flo

<TEXT> kiṃ punaḥ pañcabhuktānāṃ mṛtyus{ }tebhyaḥ kim{ }adbhutam||</TEXT> 4:55
        <APP>\vc <LEM>punaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCapcorr\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; puna \msCaacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tebhyaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tebhya \Ed</APP>
        <TR>How much more true it is for those who enjoy all five [senses]!
                 Why should death come as a surprise for them?</TR>


<TEXT> purūravo 'tilobhena atikāmena daṇḍakaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>purūravo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; purorave \msCc, pururavā° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>tilobhena atikāmena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tikāmena atilobhena \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>daṇḍakaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; puṇḍakaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>We may treat Łpurūravo$ in Łpāda$ a as a \stemform\ 
                 noun or thematised stem, or imagine that the
                 original reading was Łpurūravā$° with double sandhi:
                 Łpurūravās ati$° \rightarrow\ Łpurūravā ati$° \rightarrow\ Łpurūravāti$°.

                 ŁPāda$ a may refer to the following passage in the \MBH\ (1.70.16--18, 20ab):
         <sep/>
                                 Łpurūravās tato vidvān ilāyāṃ samapadyata$ | <br/>
                                 Łsā vai tasyābhavan mātā pitā ceti hi naḥ śrutam$ || <br/>
                                 Łtrayodaśa samudrasya dvīpān aśnan purūravā$  | <br/>
                                 Łamānuṣair vṛtaḥ sattvair mānuṣaḥ san mahāyaśā$  || <br/>
                                 Łvipraiḥ sa vigrahaṃ cakre vīryonmattaḥ purūravā$  | <br/>
                                 Łjahāra ca sa viprāṇāṃ ratnāny utkrośatām ap$  || <br/>
                                       [\dots] <br/>
                                 Łtato maharṣibhiḥ kruddhaiḥ śaptaḥ sadyo vyanaśyata$ |
        <sep/>
                        `The wise Purūravas was born to Ilā. We heard that Ilā 
                           was both his mother and his father. 
                           The great Purūravas ruled over thirteen islands of the ocean
                           and, though human, he was always surrounded by superhuman beings.
                           Intoxicated with his power, Purūravas quarrelled with some Brahmins  
                           and robbed them of their wealth even though they were protesting. [...]
                           Therefore, cursed by the great Ṛṣis, he perished.'
        <sep/>
        See also \BUDDHACARITA\ 11.15 (Aiḍa = Purūravas):
                 <sep/>
                 Łaiḍaś ca rājā tridivaṃ vigāhya$ 
                 Łnītvāpi devīṃ vaśam urvaśīṃ tām$ | <br/>
                 Łlobhād ṛṣibhyaḥ kanakaṃ jihīrṣur$ 
                 Łjagāma nāśaṃ viṣayeṣv atṛptaḥ$ ||
        <sep/>
              In Johnston's translation (<citeyear>Buddhacarita</cite>, II. 152):
        <sep/>
              `Although the royal son of Iḍā penetrated the triple heaven and brought
               the goddess Urvaśī into his power, he was still unsatisfied with the 
               objects of sense and came to destruction in his greedy desire to seize
               gold from the ṛṣis.'
        <sep/>
                For Daṇḍa(ka)'s story, see \RAMAYANA\ 7.71.31 ff.:
                Daṇḍa meets Arajā, a beautiful girl, in a forest and rapes her. As a consequence,       
                her father, Śukra/Bhārgava, destroys Daṇḍa's kingdom, which thus
                becomes the desolate Daṇḍaka-forest.</NOTE>
        <TR>Purūravas [perished] by excessive greed, Daṇḍaka by excessive desire,</TR>

<TEXT> sāgarāś{ }cātidarpeṇa atimānena rāvaṇaḥ||</TEXT> 4:56
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sāgarā°</LEM> \eme; sagara° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed, sāgara° \msCc</APP>
        <PARAL>\vd Ł\compare\ \MAHASUBHS\ 563cd:$
                        vinaṣṭo rāvaṇo laulyād{ }ati sarvatra varjayet</PARAL>
        <TR>Sagara's sons by excessive pride, Rāvaṇa by excessive haughtiness,</TR>
        <NOTE>
                <sep/>
                For two versions of the destruction of
                Sagara's sons (note emendation in Łpāda$ c), 
                who were chasing the sacrificial horse of their father's Aśvamedha sacrifice,
                and by doing so disturbed Kapila's meditation, and who in turn burnt them to ashes,
                see \MBH\ 3.105.9 ff. and \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 2.52--53.

                <sep/>
                As for Rāvaṇa's haughtiness,
                especially the fact that he chose to be invincible by all creatures except humans,
                and its consequences,
                one should recall the story of the \RAMAYANA\ and Rāvaṇa's destruction brought about by Rāma therein.</NOTE>

% gretil/mbh1_18uḥtmṭxt-03,105.024a             tataḥ pūrvottare deśe samudrasya mahīpate
% gretil/mbh1_18uḥtmṭxt-03,105.024b*0522_01     vidāryamāṇāṃ pṛthivīṃ sāgarair baladarpitaiḥ
% gretil/mbh1_18uḥtmṭxt:03,105.024c             vidārya pātālam atha saṃkruddhāḥ sagarātmajāḥ
% gretil/mbh1_18uḥtmṭxt-03,105.024e             apaśyanta hayaṃ tatra vicarantaṃ mahītale
% gretil/mbh1_18uḥtmṭxt-03,105.025a             kapilaṃ ca mahātmānaṃ tejorāśim anuttamam


% atimāṇena \msCb
% rāvanaḥ \msNc

%folioinfo \msCa\ 396.jpg
<TEXT> atikrodhena saudāsa atipānena yādavāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>atipānena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; atipāpena \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Saudāsa by excessive anger, the Yādavas by excessive drinking,</TR>
        <NOTE>Saudāsa (note the sandhi between the two Łpāda$s),
                also known as Kalmāṣapāda, hit Śakti, Vasiṣṭha's son, with a whip because
                the latter did not give way to him, and as a consequence Śakti cursed Saudāsa:
                Saudāsa had to roam the world as a Rākṣasa for twelve years. 
                See \MBH\ 1.166.1ff.

                <sep/>
                As for the end of the Yādavas, see the short ŁMausalaparvan$ of the \MBH\ (canto 16):
                cursed by the sages Viśvāmitra, Kaṇva and Nārada, and seeing menacing omens,
                the Yādavas take to drinking in Prabhāsa and destroy each other.</NOTE>

% check Saudāsa's death

<TEXT> atitṛṣṇāc{ }ca māndhātā nahuṣo dvijavajñayā||</TEXT> 4:57
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>atitṛṣṇāc{ }ca māndhātā</LEM> \conj;
                                        atitṛṣṇā ca māndāto \msCa,
                                        atitṛṣṇā ca māndhāto \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc,
                                        atitṛṣṇā ca mandhāto \msNb,
                                        atitṛṣṇā ca mānāc{ }ca ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nahuṣo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; naghuṣo \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Māndhātṛ by excessive desire, Nahuṣa by contempt for Brahmins,</TR>
        <NOTE><sep/>Most probably, Łatitṛṣṇā$ in the MSS stands for Łatitṛṣṇāt$ (intending Łatitṛṣṇayā$),
                and the forms Łmāndhāto$/Łmandhāto$ in \msCb\ stand for Łmāndhātā$ (nominative of Łmāndhātṛ$).
                I have corrected these in spite of the fact that the authors' knowledge about Māndhātṛ's story may
                come from \DIVYAV\ 17, where it sometimes appears to be an a-stem noun (Łmāndhāta$).
                Łdvijavajñayā$ in Łpāda$ d stands for Łdvijāvajñayā$ metri causa.

                <sep/>
                Māndhātṛ was born from his father's body who, being excessively thirsty once,
                had drank some decoction prepared for ritual purposes and as a result become pregnant with him.
                Nevertheless, \BUDDHACARITA\ 11.13 suggests that Māndhātṛ himself was still unsatisfied
                with wordly objects even after he had obtained half of Indra's throne:
        <sep/>
                                Łdevena vṛṣṭe 'pi hiraṇyavarṣe$ 
                                Łdvīpān samagrāṃś caturo 'pi jitvā$ |  <br/> 
                                Łśakrasya cārdhāsanam apy avāpya$
                                Łmāndhātur āsīd viṣayeṣv atṛptiḥ$ ||
        <sep/>
              In Johnston's translation (<citeyear>Buddhacarita</cite>, II. 151):
        <sep/>
              `Though the heavens rained gold for him and though he conquered the whole
              of the four continents and won half the seat of Śakra, yet Māndhātṛ's longing
              for the objects of sense remained unappeased.'
        <sep/>
                In fact, as Monika Zin points out (<citep>ZinMandhatar</citep><pnum>149</pnum>),
                Māndhātṛ/Māndhāta's rise and fall is a very popular theme
                in the `Narrative Art of the Amaravati School': 
                `Statistics show that in the Amaravati School the most frequently represented narrative is
                  the story of King Māndhātar, which appears 47 times.'
 
                <sep/>
                Nahuṣa was elevated to the position of Indra for a period of time and he also wanted
                to take Śacī, Indra's wife. Indra instructed Śacī to tell Nahuṣa to 
                harness some Ṛsis to a vehicle and use this vehicle to take Śacī. 
                Agastya, one of the Ṛṣis, was insulted even further by Nahuṣa, therefore
                he cursed Nahuṣa, who then fell from the vehicle. See \MBH\ 12.329.35ff and
                a verse in the \BUDDHACARITA\ (11.14) that follows the one about Māndhātṛ:
        <sep/>
                                             Łbhuktvāpi rājyaṃ divi devatānāṃ$ 
                                                Łśatakratau vṛtrabhayāt pranaṣṭe$ | <br/>
                                             Łdarpān maharṣīn api vāhayitvā$ 
                                                Łkāmeṣv atṛpto nahuṣaḥ papāta$ ||
        <sep/>
              In Johnston's translation (<citeyear>Buddhacarita</cite>, II. 151):
        <sep/>
        `Although he enjoyed sovereignty over the gods in heaven, when Śatakratu hid himself
         for fear of Vṛtra, and though out of wanton pride he made the great ṛṣis carry him,
         yet Nahuṣa fell, being still unsatisfied with the passions.'</NOTE>

        % See Zin ibid. p. 151:
        % ''The story [e.g. ŁDivyāvadāna$ XVII, see more sources in fn. 17 of this article] 
        % relates that Māndhātar was a miraculously born <skt>cakravartin</skt> with Seven
        % Jewels who could cause rain to fall so that his subjects could prosper; not usual rain, but rain
        % of coins, of grain or of cloth. By virtue of his moral strength alone, Māndhātar conquered the world---
        % without any weapons. He conquered all the countries on earth, then Uttarakuru,
        % Pūrvavideha and Aparagodānīya, after which he set out to conquer the heavens. When he was
        % traversing from one abode of the gods to the next (Nāgas, Sadāmattas, Mālādharas, etc.)
        % groups of gods pledged obeisance to him and immediately marched in front of his troops.
        % Māndhātar reached the splendid city of the Trayastriṃśa gods atop Sumeru, where Indra, in
        % the meeting-hall, bequeathed to him half of his own seat and half of his heavenly realm.
        % Māndhātar then ruled together with Indra for an unimaginable period of time during which 36
        % Indras changed. One day, shortly after he won a battle against the Asuras, a sinful thought
        % came to his mind: why should he rule alongside Indra? It was he, after all, who won the war,
        % not Indra - he was better and should, therefore, rule alone.
        % At that very moment Māndhatar fell from heaven, down to his former realm, became sick and died.
        % Shortly before his death, he preached a sermon to his subjects in which <i>gātha</i>s 
        % from the <i>Dhammapada</i> (186--187) appear...''

%index_metre: shortening of vowel metri causa
%Buddhacarita:
%
%samudravastrām api gām avāpya  
%        pāraṃ jigīṣanti mahārṇavasya 
%lokasya kāmair na vitṛptir asti  
%         patadbhir ambhobhir ivārṇavasya  // 11.12 //
%
%devena vṛṣṭe 'pi hiraṇyavarṣe  
%        dvīpān (samagrāṃś C samudrāṃś ) caturo 'pi jitvā
%śakrasya cārdhāsanam apy avāpya  
%        *māndhātur* āsīd viṣayeṣv atṛptiḥ  // 11.13 //
%
%bhuktvāpi rājyaṃ divi devatānāṃ   
%        śatakratau vṛtrabhayāt pranaṣṭe
%darpān maharṣīn api vāhayitvā  
%        kāmeṣv atṛpto *nahuṣaḥ* papāta  // 11.14 //
%
%aiḍaś ca rājā tridivaṃ vigāhya    [= Purūravas]
%        nītvāpi devīṃ vaśam urvaśīṃ tām
%lobhād ṛṣibhyaḥ kanakaṃ jihīrṣur  
%        jagāma nāśaṃ viṣayeṣv atṛptaḥ  // 11.15 //
%
%baler mahendraṃ nahuṣaṃ mahendrād   
%        indraṃ punar ye nahuṣād upeyuḥ
%svarge kṣitau vā viṣayeṣu teṣu  
%        ko viśvased bhāgyakulākuleṣu  // 11.16 //
%MBh 12:
%Unto her Indra then said, Go and say
%unto Nahusha that he should come to thee on a vehicle never used before,
%viz., one unto which some Rishis should be harnessed, and arriving at
%thine in that state he should wed thee. Indra has many kinds of vehicles
%that are all beautiful and charming. All these have borne thee. Nahusha,
%however, should come on such a vehicle that Indra himself had not
%possessed. Thus counselled by her lord, Sachi left that spot with a
%joyous heart. Indra also once more entered the fibres of that
%lotus-stalk. Beholding the Queen of Indra come back to heaven, Nahusha
%addressed her saying, The time thou hadst fixed is over. Unto him Sachi
%said what Indra had directed her to say. *Harnessing a number of great
%Rishis unto the vehicle he rode, Nahusha set out from his place for
%coming to where Sachi was living.* The foremost of Rishis, viz., Agastya,
%born within a jar, of the vital seed of Maitravaruna, beheld those
%foremost of Rishis insulted by Nahusha in that way. Him Nahusha struck
%with his foot. Unto him, Agastya said,--Wretch, as thou hast betaken
%thyself to a highly improper act, do thou fall down on the Earth. Be
%olong as the Earth and her hills continue. As soon as these words were
%uttered by the great Rishi, Nahusha fell down from that vehicle. The
%three worlds once more became master-less. The deities and the Rishis
%then united together and proceeded to where Vishnu was and appealed to
%him for bringing about the restoration of Indra. Approaching him, they
%said,--O holy one, it behoveth thee to rescue Indra who is overwhelmed by
%the sin of Brahmanicide. The boon-giving Vishnu replied unto them,
%saying,--Let Sakra perform a Horse-sacrifice in honour of Vishnu. He will
%then be restored to his former position. The deities and the Rishis began
%to search for Indra, but when they could not find him, they went to Sachi
%and said unto her,--O blessed lady, go unto Indra and bring him here.
%transformed into a snake and do thou continue to live in that form as
%
%Mahāsubhāṣitasaṅgraha:
%MSS_0560-1 atidarpe hatā laṅkā atimāne ca kauravāḥ /<BR>
%MSS_0560-2 atidāne balir baddhaḥ sarvam atyantagarhitam //<BR>
%MSS_0561-1 atidākṣiṇyayuktānāṃ śaṅkitānāṃ pade pade /<BR>
%MSS_0561-2 parāpavādibhīrūṇāṃ na bhavanti vibhūtayaḥ //<BR>
%MSS_0562-1 atidānād dhataḥ karṇas tv atilobhāt suyodhanaḥ /<BR>
%MSS_0562-2 atikāmād daśagrīvas tv atisarvatra varjayet //<BR>
%MSS_0563-1 atidānād balir baddho naṣṭo mānāt suyodhanaḥ /<BR>
%MSS_0563-2 vinaṣṭo rāvaṇo laulyād ati sarvatra varjayet //<BR>
%MSS_0564-1 atidānād balir baddho hy atimānāt suyodhanaḥ /<BR>
%MSS_0564-2 atikāmād daśagrīvo hy ati sarvatra garhitaḥ //<BR>
%MSS_0565-1 atidāne balir baddho atimāne ca kauravāḥ /<BR>
%MSS_0565-2 atirūpe hṛtā sītā sarvam atyantagarhitam //<BR>
%MSS_0566-1 atidīrghajīvidoṣād vyāsena yaśo'pahāritaṃ hanta /<BR>



% kosa/vacaspatyam.txt: \textbf{atidāna} na° atiśayitaṃ dānam prā° sa°

% sandhi
<TEXT> atidānād{ }balir{ }naṣṭa atiśauryeṇa arjunaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°r{ }naṣṭa</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °r{ }naṣṭo \msCb, naṣṭo \msCc</APP>
        <PARAL>\va Ł\compare\ \MAHASUBHS\ 563ab:$
                        atidānād{ }balir{ }baddho naṣṭo mānāt{ }suyodhanaḥ</PARAL>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is most probably a reference to Mahābali's promises made to Vāmana that caused his own fall. 
                The ultimate cause of Arjuna' death while the Pāṇḍavas were on the way to the underworld 
                was summarised by Yudhiṣṭhira thus (\MBH\ 17.2.21ab):
                <sep/>
                       Łekāhnā nirdaheyaṃ vai śatrūn ity arjuno 'bravīt$ | <br/>
                       Łna ca tat kṛtavān eṣa śūramānī tato 'patat$ ||
                <sep/>
                `Arjuna claimed that he could destroy the enemy in one single day. He failed to do so.
                  He was a boaster, that is why he fell.'</NOTE>
        <TR>[Mahā]bali perished by excessive donations, Arjuna by excessive heroism,</TR>

%index_grammar: lack of sandhi metri causa

<TEXT> atidyūtān{ }nalo rājā nṛgo goharaṇena tu||</TEXT> 4:58
        <APP>\vc <LEM>atidyūtān{ }nalo</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc; atidyūtān{ }naro \msCb\msNa, atikhyātān{ }nalo \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nṛgo go°</LEM> \Ed; nṛgaṅ{ }go° \msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc, nṛgaṃ go° \msCb\msNa</APP>
        <TR>King Nala by excessive gambling, Nṛga by taking a cow.</TR>
        <LACUNA>\vo ŁAfter this verse, \Ed\ adds:$
                        tasmād{ }dama sadā sa rakṣet ati sarvatra varjayet
                Ł(understand:$ tasmād{ }damaṃ sadā rakṣet ati sarvatra varjayet Ł)$;
                Ł\compare\ \MAHASUBHS\ 563cd:$
                        vinaṣṭo rāvaṇo laulyād{ }ati sarvatra varjayet </LACUNA>
        %``Therefore one should always preserve Self-restraint and should always avoid excessiveness.''
% SEE Maṇicūḍāvadāna tr. Ren Yuan (pdf) page 67 !!! %%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
        % PaperMS A1341 does not have this extra line:
        /home/csaba/mmedia/images/scan/saiva/sivadharmacorpus/mss_florinda/newari/ngmpp/paper_mtm/A 1341-06/DSCN0337.JPG
        % PaperMS C107-7 does not have this extra line either:
        /home/csaba/mmedia/images/scan/saiva/sivadharmacorpus/mss_florinda/newari/ngmpp/paper_mtm/C 107-07_scribe_of_a1341?/DSCN8306.JPG
        % PaperMS C57-5 does not have it either (4182.jpg)
        % Not in PaperMS B219-3 (3819.jpg) last but one line
                <NOTE>
                        <sep/> 
                        King Nala was an expert in the game of dice but once he lost his kingdom to Puṣkara.
                        See, e.g., \MBH\ 3.56.1ff. 

                <sep/>
                       As for Nṛga, see \MBH\ 14.93.74: 
                <sep/>
                       Łgopradānasahasrāṇi dvijebhyo 'dān nṛgo nṛpaḥ$ | <br/>
                       Łekāṃ dattvā sa pārakyāṃ narakaṃ samavāptavān$ ||
                <sep/>
                         `King Nṛga had donated thousands of cows to the twice-born.
                         By giving away one single cow that belonged to someone else, 
                         he fell into hell.'</NOTE>


<NOTANUSTUBH/> upajāti
<TEXT> damena hīnaḥ puruṣo dvijendra</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>hīnaḥ puruṣo dvijendra</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; 
                                hīna puruṣo dvijendra \msNb, hīnaṃ puruṣaṃ dvijendraḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[For] a person who is without self-restraint, O great Brahmin,</TR>

<TEXT> svargaṃ ca mokṣaṃ ca sukhaṃ ca nāsti|</TEXT>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ b: Łsvarga$ and Łmokṣa$ are usually masculine in standard Sanskrit.</NOTE>
        <TR>there is no heaven, liberation or happiness.</TR>

%index_grammar: gender
%index_grammar: nominative for genitive

        -  - .  -  -!. . -  . - -
<TEXT> vijñānadharmakulakīrtināśa</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°nāśa</LEM> \msCb; °nāśo \Ed °nāma \msCa\msCc\msNa, °naśca \msNb, °nāgā \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>The majority of the witnesses suggest that Łpāda$ c ends in a \stemform\ noun (°Łnāśa$),
                although a singular masculine nominative (as in \Ed) may work.
                This Łpāda$ is unmetrical, or rather it applies the licence of a word-final
                short syllable being counted as potentially long (°ŁdharMA$°; see p.~\pageref{short2long}). </NOTE>

%index_metre: long syllable at end of word
%index_grammar: stem form noun

% unmetr:
<TEXT> bhavanti vipra damayā vihīnāḥ||</TEXT> 4:59
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vipra</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNaacorr\msNb\Ed; viprā \msNapcorr\msNc\oo
                 <LEM>damayā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dayā \msCbacorr</APP>
        <TR>O Brahmin, people without self-restraint 
                        are the destruction of knowledge, Dharma, family and fame.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note how Łviprā$ in Łpāda$ d is probably an attempt in some MSS to restore the metre.
                This Łpāda$ is also unmetrical, or rather the licence of a word-final
                short syllable being counted as potentially long is applied again (ŁviPRA$).</NOTE>

%index_metre: upajāti
%index_metre: long syllable at end of word

<PAGEBREAK/>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 195.jpg, f. 276r
<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣu ghṛṇā (6)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Sixth Yama-rule: taboos</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> nirghṛṇo na paratrāsti nirghṛṇo na ihāsti vai|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>nirghṛṇo</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb; nighṛṇo \msCc\msNc, nirghṛṇa \msNaacorr, 
                                nirghṛ<UNCL>ṇe</UNCL> \msNapcorr, nirghṛṇe \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>nirghṛṇo</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNaacorr\msNb; nighṛṇo \msCc\msNc, nirghṛṇe \msNapcorr\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The implications of Łpāda$s ab are not crystal clear to me. Perhaps:
              such a person has no right for existence in society and has no place in heaven.</NOTE>
        <TR>A person without taboos does not exists either in this or the other world.</TR>

<TEXT> nirghṛṇe na ca dharmo 'sti nirghṛṇe na tapo 'sti vai||</TEXT> 4:60
        <APP>\vc <LEM>nirghṛṇe</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\Ed; nighṛṇe \msCc\msNa\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nirghṛṇe</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; nighṛṇe \msCc\msNc</APP>
        <TR>If one has no taboos, one cannot have Dharma or religious austerity.</TR>
% in a person Judit he has no... aversion 
% Judit likes 'taboo'

<TEXT> parastrīṣu parārtheṣu parajīvāpakarṣaṇe|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°jīvāpakarṣaṇe</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °jīvāparkaṇe \msCb, °jīvopakarṣaṇe \Ed</APP>
        <TR>These five should be treated as taboo:
            women who are not depending on oneself, others' wealth, taking away others' lives,</TR>

<TEXT> paranindāparānneṣu ghṛṇāṃ pañcasu kārayet||</TEXT> 4:61
        <APP>\vc <LEM>paranindā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; parani\-nda\lk\ \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>°parānneṣu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °parāṃneṣu \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>ghṛṇāṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; ghṛṇā \msCc\msNb\Ed</APP>
        <TR>hurting others and [consuming] others' food.</TR>

<TEXT> parastrī śṛṇu viprendra ghṛṇīkāryā sadā budhaiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>ghṛṇī°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ghṛṇā \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Listen, O great Brahmin. The wise should always treat women who are not 
                        dependent on oneself as taboo,</TR>

<TEXT> rājñī viprī parivrājā svayoniparayoniṣu||</TEXT> 4:62
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vrājā</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc; °vrājī \msNa\msNb, °vrājyā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°para°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °paśu° \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>The translation of Łparayoni$ in Łpāda$ d is tentative.</NOTE>
        <TR>[be she] a queen, a Brahmin's wife, a wandering religious mendicant, 
                        a relative or of another caste.</TR>
% Judit parastrī might be the first category and then rājñī ... ?

%folioinfo \msM\ 420.jpg upper, f. 8v  
% corr to anyad?
<TEXT> parārthe śṛṇu bhūyo 'nya anyāyārtha{-}m{-}upārjanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>anyāyā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; anyayā° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°rjanam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °rjjavam \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vb Ł\compare\ \BHG\ 16.12:$
                āśāpāśaśatair{ }baddhāḥ kāmakrodhaparāyaṇāḥ|
                īhante kāmabhogārtham{ }anyāyenārthasaṃcayān||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Although Ł'nya$ in Łpāda$ a could be interpreted several ways (e.g. Łanye$ for Łanyasmin$, 
              or taken to be the first element of a compound: Łanya-anyāyārtha-$),
              I think that Łbhūyo 'nyat$ is a fixed expression meaning `something/anything more.' 
              See, e.g., \BHG\ 7.2cd:
              Łyaj jñātvā neha bhūyo 'nyaj jñātavyam avaśiṣyate$.
              Understand Łpāda$ b as a compound (Łanyāya-artha-upārjanam$). 
              See cheating with scales mentioned in 4.23.</NOTE>
        <TR>Listen further to something else, with regards to others' wealth.
                 [It may include] gaining wealth through unlawful means,</TR>
% Judit anyāyārtha is the first thing
% Fra maybe pāda b works fine
% Bhagavadgītā anyāyena ... CHECK Nirājan
% Kengo rather 'anya' ?
% anye for anyasmin Judit or compound (also Kengo's idea) 

<TEXT> āḍhaprasthatulāvyājaiḥ parārthaṃ yo 'pakarṣati||</TEXT> 4:63
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°tulā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °tula° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°rthaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; °rtha \msCc, °<UNCL>rtha</UNCL> \msNb, °rthe \msNc</APP>
        <TR>when somebody takes away other people's wealth by cheating with
                 weights of one Łāḍha[ka]$ or a Łprastha$ and with scales.</TR>
