<TEXT> jīvāpakarṣaṇe vipra ghṛṇīkurvīta paṇḍitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vipra</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vi<UNCL>pra</UNCL> \msCa, vipre \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>ghṛṇī°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ghṛṇāṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>O Brahmin, the wise should regard taking away lives as taboo,</TR>
% they meant 'ghṛṇāṃ kurvīta' Judit 

<TEXT> vanajāvanajā jīvā vilagāś{ }caraṇācarāḥ||</TEXT> 4:64
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vanajāvanajā</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; 
                        vanajāva\lk jā \msCbacorr, vanajā va<UNCL>ni</UNCL>jā \msCbpcorr, vanaja vinajā \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>vilagāś{ }caraṇācarāḥ</LEM> \corr; 
                        vilagācaraṇācarāḥ \msCa\msCb\msNc, vilagocaragocaraḥ \msCc\Ed, vilagocaragocarāḥ \msNa,
                                                        <UNCL>vilagācara</UNCL>ṇācarāḥ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ d, I take Łcaraṇācarāḥ$ as standing for Łcarācarāḥ$ (Łcara-acarāḥ$) metri causa.
              Alternatively, one may understand it as Łcaraṇacarāḥ$ (metri causa), 
              meaning `those who move on their feet,' perhaps as opposed to snakes (Łbilaga$ or Łbilaṃga$).
              Neither solution is fully satisfactory. Note that this Łpāda$ also involves a small correction.</NOTE>
        <TR>[be they] wild or domesticated living beings, serpents, plants and animals.</TR>

% vihagācaraṇācarāḥ?
% bilaga ! Nirājan bilaṃgama serpent 
% walk on their feet Judit 

<PAGEBREAK/>

%folioinfo \msNc\ 219.jpg upper, f. 216v
<TEXT> paranindā ca kā vipra śṛṇu vakṣye samāsataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vakṣye</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; vakṣyā \Ed</APP>
        <TR>And what is the hurting of others? Listen, O Brahmin, I shall tell you briefly.</TR>

<TEXT> devānāṃ brāhmaṇānāṃ ca gurumātātithidviṣaḥ||</TEXT> 4:65
        <LACUNA>\vcd ŁThese two pādas are illegible in \msNb$</LACUNA>
        <NOTE>Note Łmātā$ as a \stemform\ in Łpāda$ d.</NOTE>
        <TR>He who is hostile to the gods, Brahmins, the guru, a mother, and guests [hurts others].</TR>

%index_voc: mātā as stem 

%folioinfo \msNb\ 50.jpg lower
<TEXT> parānneṣu ghṛṇā kāryā abhojyeṣu ca bhojanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>abhojyeṣu</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; abhojye \msCb</APP>
        <TR>As regards other people's food, eating together with people whose food
                        is not to be accepted (Łabhojyeṣu$) is taboo,</TR>

% any association with alcohol
<TEXT> sūtake mṛtake śauṇḍe varṇabhraṣṭakule naṭe||</TEXT> 4:66
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śauṇḍe</LEM> \msNa; sauṇḍye \msCa\msCc\msNc, śoṇḍye \msCb, <UNCL>sauṇḍe</UNCL> \msNb, sauṇḍo \Ed</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vo ŁThis verse is mostly illegible in \msNb$</LACUNA>
        <TR>[e.g.] after birth or death [in a family], in case of vendors of alcohol,
                or a family having lost their caste, and in the case of a [member of the] Naṭa [caste of dancers].</TR>
% kule ... bahuvrīhi individual
        <NOTE>One should probably understand Łśauṇḍe$ in Łpāda$ c as Łśauṇḍike$, `a distiller,' or, alternatively,
                it may be corrupted from Łṣaṇḍhe$, `a eunuch'; see both in \VasDh\ 14.1--3:
                <sep/>
                Łathāto bhojyābhojyaṃ ca varṇayiṣyāmaḥ$ |
                Łcikitsaka-mṛgayu-puṃścalī-ḍaṇḍika-stenābhiśastar-ṣaṇḍha-patitānām annam abhojyam$ |
                Łkadarya-dīkṣita-baddhātura-soma-vikrayi-takṣa-rajaka-śauṇḍika-sūcaka-vārdhuṣika-carmāvakṛntānām$ || etc.
                <sep/>
                It is translated by Olivelle (<citeyear>OlivelleDharmasutras</citeyear>, 285) as:
                        `Next we will describe food that is fit and food that is
                        unfit to be eaten [\dots] The following are unfit
                        to be eaten: food given by a physician, a hunter, a harlot, a law
                        enforcement agent, a thief, a heinous sinner [...] a
                        eunuch, or an outcaste; as also that given by a miser, a man
                        consecrated for a sacrifice, a prisoner, a sick person, a man who
                        sells Soma, a carpenter, a washerman, a liquor dealer, a spy, an
                        usurer, a leather worker\dots'
                <sep/>
                In support of reading Łṣaṇḍhe$, one might consult \MANU\ 3.239:
                <sep/>
                        Łcāṇḍālaś ca varāhaś ca kukkuṭaḥ śvā tathaiva ca$ |<br/>
                        Łrajasvalā ca ṣaṇḍhaś ca nekṣerann aśnato dvijān$ ||
                <sep/>
                Translated by Olivelle (<citeyear>OlivelleDharmasutras</citeyear>, 120) as:
                <sep/>
                        `A Cāṇḍāla, a pig, a cock, a dog, a menstruating woman, or a eunuch must not
                         look at the Brahmins while they are eating.'</NOTE>

% check sauṇḍa as a jāti ṣaṇḍha ! Judit but also śuṇḍa -- śauṇḍa : connected to bar more likely
% notable examples


<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<LONGVERSELINES/>
% °susakta°?
%      - -  -  .  . - .  - .  . . -   -  -   . -  -   . -
<TEXT> ete pañcaghṛṇāsu saktapuruṣāḥ svargārthamokṣārthino</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°puruṣāḥ</LEM> \msNc; °puruṣaḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°rthino</LEM> \eme; °rthinaḥ \msNcpcorr, °rthināṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed, °rthinā \msNcacorr</APP>
        <TR>Those people who stick to the five kinds of taboo [and thus] 
                        seek heaven, wealth and liberation,</TR>
% maybe svargātha - seeking heaven Judit 
% end of line was -aḥ

%                       śakta \msCa
% phps without avagraha?
<TEXT> loke 'nindanam{ }āpnuvanti satataṃ kīrtir{ }yaśo'laṃkṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>'nindanam{ }āpnuvanti</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; 
                        'nindanavāpnuvanti \msCc, nandanavāyuvānti \Ed</APP>
%                  °kṛtāḥ \eme; °kṛtam \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed
        <NOTE>Understand Łkīrtir-yaśo$° as Łkīrtiyaśo$° ('r' being an intrusive consonant here metri causa), 
              as in 5.20b below. Alternatively, emend to Łkīrtiṃ yaśo'laṃkṛtām$.</NOTE>
        <TR>will reach eternal faultlessness in this world, embellished with fame and glory.</TR>

%index_grammar: r as a sandhi bridge?
%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

%        -  - -  .! . -    . -   .  .  . -  - -   .  -  -   . -
<TEXT> prajñābodhaśrutiṃ smṛtiṃ ca labhate mānaṃ ca nityaṃ labhed</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°śrutiṃ</LEM> \msNc; °śruti° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>nityaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; nitya \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ c, note the \mutacumliquida\ that allows °Łbodhaśrutiṃ$°
              to scan as - \shortsyllable\ \shortsyllable\ - , the consonant cluster 
              Łśr$ not turning the previous syllable long.</NOTE>
        <TR>[A person like that] will obtain wisdom, intelligence, [knowledge of] the Śruti and Smṛti traditions,
                 and honour forever.</TR>
% end of line was labhet

%index_metre: muta cum liquida licence śr:

<TEXT> dākṣiṇyaṃ sabhavet{ }sa āyuṣa paraṃ prāpnoti niḥsaṃśayaḥ||</TEXT> 4:67
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sa āyuṣa</LEM> \eme; samāyuṣa \mssCaCbCc\msNc, samāyuṣaḥ \msNa\ \unmetr,
                                <UNCL>samāyuṣa</UNCL> \msNb, sa mānuṣa \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>niḥsaṃśayaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; nisaṃśayaḥ \msNa</APP>
        <TR>Kindness will arise and he will obtain an extra long life, no doubt.</TR>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ d has several problems. I take Łsabhavet$ as standing for Łsambhavet$ metri causa,
              and I had to emend Łsamāyuṣa$ to Łsa āyuṣa$ to make sense of it.
              Understand Łāyuṣa$ as Łāyuḥ$ (metri causa), otherwise accept \Ed's Łsa mānuṣa$.
              Also consider correcting Łniḥsaṃśayaḥ$ to Łniḥsaṃśayam$.</NOTE>

%index_metre: śārdūlavikrīḍita

<NORMALVERSELINES/>


<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣu pañcavidho dhanyaḥ (7)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Seventh Yama-rule: five kinds of virtue</TRSUBCHAPTER>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 202.jpg upper, f.8v
<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> caturmaunaṃ catuḥśatruś{ }caturāyatanaṃ tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>caturmaunaṃ ca°</LEM> \corr; caturmaunaś{ }ca° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed, caturmoṇaś{ }ca° \msCc,
                                                        <UNCL>caturmaunaś{ }ca</UNCL>° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°tuḥ{ }śatruś{ }ca°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                        °tuśatru ca° \msCc, °tuḥ{ }śatru ca° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°turāyatanaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °<UNCL>tu</UNCL>rāyatanaṃ \msCa, 
                                                                  °<UNCL>turāyatanam</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <TR>The four cases of observing silence, [victory over] the four enemies, the four 
                        sanctuaries,</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.596
% stem form? vidhi? vidhy ucyate? or vidhā? or accept \Ed?
<TEXT> caturdhyānaṃ catuṣpādaṃ pañcadhanyavidhocyate||</TEXT> 4:68
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°pādaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; °pādaḥ \msNa, \lk\lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>pañcadhanya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dhanyapañca° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łpāda$ d as Łpañcavidho dhanya ucyate$.</NOTE>
        <TR>the four meditations, and the four-legged [Dharma] are called the five ways of being virtuous.</TR>

%index_grammar: clumsy

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> caturmaunasya vakṣyāmi śṛṇuṣvāvahito bhava|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°maunasya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °monasya \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the genitive with a verb meaning `to tell' in Łpāda$ a, similarly to 1.37a and \verify\
                (See p.~\pageref{tellplusgen}).</NOTE>
        <TR>I shall tell you about the four cases of observing silence. Listen, be attentive.</TR>

%index_grammar: gen + telling

<TEXT> pāruṣyapiśunāmithyā sambhinnāni ca varjayet||</TEXT> 4:69
        <APP>\vc <LEM>pāruṣya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; pāruṣyaṃ \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°piśunā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °piṇḍānā° \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\compare\ \DIVYAV\ 186.21:$
                    ārya, kim{ }ebhiḥ karma kṛtam{ }yenaivaṃvidhāni duḥkhāni pratyanubhavantīti? 
                    sa kathayati| ete prāṇātipātikā adattādāyikāḥ kāmamithyācārikā mṛṣāvādikāḥ paiśunikāḥ pāruṣikāḥ 
                    saṃbhinnapralāpikā abhidhyālavo vyāpannacittā mithyādṛṣṭikāḥ|;
                    Ł\compare\ \DHARMP\ 1.31cd--32ab:$
                        mithyā piśunasambhinnapāruṣyavacanāni ca||
                        jalpataḥ sambhavanty{ }ete tasmān{ }maunaṃ praśasyate|</PARAL>
         <NOTE>Compare the four types of Łmauna$ taught here with the five types of
              Łmaunavrata$, as the ninth Niyama-rule, in \VSS\ 8.25--33 below.
              Similar lists on Łmauna$ are often found in Buddhist texts:
              see references, e.g., in <cite>EdgertonHybrid</cite> s.v. 
              Łpaiśunika$ and Łsaṃbhinnapralāpa$.
              See also the relevant \DIVYAV\ 186.21, as well as \DHARMP\ 1.31cd--32ab 
              quoted in the apparatus.</NOTE>
        <TR>One should avoid violent and slanderous [words], lies, and idle [talk].</TR>
% piśunā : informing against, betraying [MBh.];

<TEXT> kāmaḥ krodhaś{ }ca lobhaś{ }ca mohaś{ }caiva caturvidhaḥ| </TEXT>
        <TR>The fourfold enemy [made up of] desire, anger, greed and delusion</TR>

% 05uma/umamahesvarasamvada.dn:  2403:    kāmakrodhaśca lobhaśca rāgo dveṣaśca pañcamam|^M
% 05uma/umamahesvarasamvada.dn-  2404-    mahābhogāśca ityete dehe ṣaḍvṛṣalāḥ smṛtāḥ|| 20.4||^M
% 06uttarottara/uttarottara.txt: 1007:    kāmakrodhaś ca lobhaś ca mohaś caiva tu kutra vā

% carvidhaḥ \msCbacorr

%https://encyclopediaofbuddhism.org/wiki/Arhat: 'The Tibetan term for arhat was translated by meaning from Sanskrit. This translation, dgra bcom pa, means "one who has destroyed the foes of afflictions".[21] Thus the Tibetan translators also understood the meaning of arhat to be ari-hanta.'

<TEXT> catuḥśatrur{ }nihantavyaḥ so 'rihā vītakalmaṣaḥ||</TEXT> 4:70
        <APP>\vc <LEM>catuḥśatrur{ }ni°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\Ed; catuśatru ni° \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>so 'rihā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; srorihā \msCb, sarvathā \Ed</APP>
        <TR>is to be destroyed. He who destroys [these] enemies will become sinless.</TR>
% Judit 14 ...
        <NOTE>Possible direct sources for the idea that Łkāma$ is an enemy to be defeated or avoided include
                \BUDDHACARITA\ 11.17:
        <sep/>
        Łcīrāmbarā mūlaphalāmbubhakṣā$ 
        Łjaṭā vahanto 'pi bhujaṃgadīrghāḥ$ |<br/> 
        Łyair nānyakāryā munayo 'pi bhagnāḥ$ 
        Łkaḥ kāmasaṃjñān mṛgayeta śatrūn$ ||
        <sep/>
              In Johnston's translation (<citeyear>Buddhacarita</cite>, II. 152):
        <sep/>
              `Who would seek after the enemies known as the passions, by whom
               even sages were undone, despite their bark-dresses, their diet
               of roots and water, their coils of hair long as snakes, and their
               lack of worldly interests.'
        <sep/>
        See also \BHG\ 3.37--43 on Łkāma$ as an enemy.
        As for Łarihā$ in Łpāda$ d, the notion that a saint is a `destroyer of the enemies' 
        [that are evil states of mind] (Łarihanta/arahanta$)
        in Jainism, but less so in Buddhism, is discussed in 
        <citep>GombrichWhat2013</citep><pnum>57--58</pnum>.</NOTE>

% Brahmavihāras go back to the upaniṣads
%folioinfo \msCa\ 397.jpg
<TEXT> caturāyatanaṃ vipra kathayiṣyāmi tac{ }chṛṇu|</TEXT>
        <TR>I shall teach you the four sanctuaries. Listen, O Brahmin.</TR>

% Yogasūtra - Buddhism?
<TEXT> karuṇā muditopekṣā maitrī cāyatanaṃ smṛtam||</TEXT> 4:71
        <APP>\vc <LEM>mudito°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; muditau° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>cāyatanaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; cāyatana \msCa, cāyata<UNCL>na</UNCL> \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>This verse teaches the four Buddhist Łbrahmavihāra$s under the label
              Łcatur\-āyatana$. Therefore the word Łāyatana$ seems to be a synonym of Łvihāra$ here,
              and its use a way of appropriating it, turning the list into a Brahmanical one,
              unless the two terms are simply mixed up.</NOTE>
        <TR>Compassion, sympathy in joy, indifference, and benevolence are the four sanctuaries.</TR>

%index_buddhism: caturāyatana (brahmavihāras)

%                could this use of the term Łāyatana$ for the four Buddhist 
%                Łbrahmavihāra$s have been influenced by the following passage in the Dharmasamuccaya (date?)?
%                        <skt>mokṣasyāyatanāni ṣaṭ |
%                        apramādas tathā śraddhā vīryārambhas tathā dhṛtiḥ |
%                        jñānābhyāsaḥ saṃtāśleṣo mokṣasyāyatanāni ṣaṭ ||1.3||
%                        nava śāntisamprāptihetavaḥ |
%                        dānaṃ śīlaṃ damaḥ kṣāntir maitrī bhūteṣv ahiṃsatā |
%                        karuṇāmuditopekṣā śāntisamprāptihetavaḥ ||1.4||</skt>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 417.jpg f.208r
%folioinfo \msCc\ 196.jpg f.276v
<TEXT> caturdhyānādhunā vakṣye saṃsārārṇavatāraṇam|</TEXT>
        <TR>I shall now teach you the four meditations,
                 which will liberate you from transmigration.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ Łdhyāna$ in °Łdhyānādhunā$ (for °Łdhyānam adhunā$) in Łpāda$~a.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form noun

<TEXT> ātmavidyābhavaḥ sūkṣmaṃ dhyānam{ }uktaṃ caturvidham||</TEXT> 4:72
        <APP>\vc  <LEM>°bhavaḥ</LEM> \msCb\msCcpcorr\msNa\msNb\msNc; °bhava \msCa\msCcacorr, °bhavaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>sūkṣmaṃ dhyā°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; 
                                        sūkṣmā<UNCL>nyā</UNCL>° \msCb,
                                        sū<UNCL>kṣma</UNCL>dhyā° \msCc, sūkṣmadhyāna° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd  <LEM>°nam{ }uktaṃ caturvidham</LEM> \msCc\msNb; °nam{ }uktaś{ }caturvidham \msCa,
                                                                      °nam{ }uktaś{ }caturvidhaḥ \msCb\msNa, 
                                                                      °nam{ }uktaṃ caturvidhiṃ \msNc, °nayajñaś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Meditation is taught to be fourfold: of the Self, Łvidyā$, Łbhava$ [= Śiva] 
                                        and the subtle one (Łsūkṣma$).</TR>

% Judit                         the kalās?
<TEXT> ātmatattvaḥ smṛto dharmo vidyā pañcasu pañcadhā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>smṛto</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; smṛtā \msCc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>dharmo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dhanyā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>This verse is difficult to interpret. ŁPāda$s a to d should define Łātman$, Łvidyā$, 
              Łbhava$ (i.e. Śiva), and Łsūkṣma$, objects of meditation, respectively.
              In Łpāda$ a, Łdharmo$ is suspect: it may be the result of
              an eyeskip to Łpāda$ a of the next verse. ŁPāda$ b might refer to Łtattva$s in an ontological
              system of 25 Łtattva$s.</NOTE>
        <TR>The Łtattva$ of the Self is Dharma. ŁVidyā$ is in the five in a fivefold way.</TR>
% Dharma is eyeskip?

<TEXT> ṣaṭtriṃśākṣaram{ }ity{ }āhuḥ sūkṣmatattvam{ }alakṣaṇam||</TEXT> 4:73
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>āhuḥ sū°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ā\lk\lk\ \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ c seems a reference to a tantric 36-Łtattva$ ontological system,
              in striking contrast with the 25-Łtattva$ system described in \VSS\ chapter 20.
              Compare the rather similar Łdhyānayajña$ section in \VSS\ 6.7ff, in which
              five types of meditations are taught. See analysis on pp. Intro \verify.</NOTE>
        <TR>They call the thirty-sixth the imperishable one [Śiva].
                        The subtle Łtattva$ has no attributes.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form noun

% CHECK again the bull is the āśramas
<TEXT> catuṣpādaḥ smṛto dharmaś{ }caturāśramam{ }āśritaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>dharmaś{ }ca°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; dharma ca° \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°śritaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °śritāḥ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>The four-legged [bull] is said to be Dharma [as] it rests on the four
           disciplines (Łāśrama$),</TR>

<TEXT> gṛhastho brahmacārī ca vānaprastho 'tha bhaikṣukaḥ||</TEXT> 4:74
        <APP>\vd <LEM>bhaikṣukaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; bhakṣakaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł = \MBH\ 12.234.13ab \similar\ \MBH\ 14.4513ab etc. $
                \vo Ł\compare\ 3.4 above:$
                śrutismṛtidvayor{ }mūrtiś{ }catuṣpādavṛṣaḥ sthitaḥ|
                caturāśrama yo dharmaḥ kīrtitāni manīṣibhiḥ||</PARAL>
        <TR>[those of] the householder, the chaste one, the forest-dweller and the mendicant.</TR>
        % vāṇa \msCc
        % found these parallels with python software

<TEXT> dhanyās{ }te yair{ }idaṃ vetti nikhilena dvijottama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>yair{ }idaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; yer{ }idaṃ \msCb\msCc\oo
                 <LEM>vetti</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; veti \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the ergative syntax with the plural instrumental (Łyair$) and a singular active verb.</NOTE>
        <TR>Virtuous are those who know these thoroughly, O great Brahmin.</TR>

%index_grammar: ergative, Newari?

<TEXT> pāvanaṃ sarvapāpānāṃ puṇyānāṃ ca pravardhanam||</TEXT> 4:75
        <APP>\vd <LEM>pravardhanam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; pravardhanaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[They will experience] the purification of all sins and the growth of merits.</TR>

<TEXT> āyuḥ kīrtir{ }yaśaḥ saukhyaṃ dhanyād{ }eva pravardhate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dhanyād{ }eva</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dharmād{ }eva \Ed</APP>
        <TR>One's life-span, fame and glory, and happiness grow only through virtue (Łdhanya$).</TR>

<TEXT> śāntiḥ puṣṭiḥ smṛtir{ }medhā jāyate dhanyamānave||</TEXT> 4:76
        <APP>\vc <LEM>puṣṭiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \lk ṣṭiḥ \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>smṛtir{ }medhā</LEM> \\mssALLmsCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; smṛti medhā \msCc\msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°mānave</LEM> \eme; °mānavaḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Emending °Łmānavaḥ$ to °Łmānave$ might err by overcorrection, and °Łmānavaḥ$ may have originally
              been felt like a genitive (`for a person\dots').</NOTE>
        <TR>In a virtuous person piece, prosperity, tradition (Łsmṛti$) and intelligence will arise.</TR>




<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣv{ }apramādaḥ (8)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Eighth Yama-rule: avoiding mistakes</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> pramādasthāna pañcaiva kīrtayiṣyāmi tac{ }chṛṇu|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°sthāna</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb; °sthānaṃ \msCb\msNc\Ed\ \unmetr\oo
                 <LEM>pañcaiva</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; pañcaivaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kīrtayiṣyāmi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; kīrtiyiṣyāmi \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ noun in Łpāda$ a (°Łsthāna$) metri causa, and also 
                        that this \stemform\ noun may function as a singular noun
                        next to a number (Łpañca$), a frequently seen phenomenon in this text.</NOTE>
        <TR>There are five areas of making serious mistakes. I shall teach them to you, listen.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form noun
%index_grammar: singular after numbers? Newari, numeral follows noun

% ṅgaṇāgamam \msCc
<TEXT> brahmahatyā surāpānaṃ steyo gurvaṅganāgamam|</TEXT>
        <PARAL>\vcdef Ł\similar\ \MBH\ Suppl. 12.30:$
                    brahmahatyāṃ surāpānaṃ steyaṃ gurvaṅganāgamam|
                    mahānti pātakāny{ }āhuḥ saṃyogaṃ caiva taiḥ saha||
                    Ł \similar\ \MANU\ 11.55 (in Olivelle's edition):$
                    brahmahatyā surāpānaṃ steyaṃ gurvaṅganāgamaḥ|
                    mahānti pātakāny{ }āhuḥ saṃsargaś{ }cāpi taiḥ saha||
                Ł\compare\ also \YAJNS\ 3.228:$
                        brahmahā madyapaḥ stenas{ }tathaiva gurutalpagaḥ|
                        ete mahāpātakino yaś{ }ca taiḥ saha saṃvaset|| </PARAL>
        <TR>Murdering a Brahmin, drinking alcohol, stealing, having sex with the guru's wife:</TR>

% brahmahatyā surāpānaṃ steyaṃ gurvaṅganāgamaḥ ।168.024            purana/agni-puranam/168.txt

%folioinfo \msM\ 420.jpg lower, f. 9r  
<TEXT> mahāpātakam{ }ity{ }āhus{ }tatsaṃyogī ca pañcamaḥ||</TEXT> 4:77
        <NOTE><sep/>
              See the apparatus to the Sanskrit text for very similar verses in the \MBH, \MANU\ and 
              the \YAJNS, and note how Łpāda$ f slightly deviates from \MANU\ 11.55, which is translated in
                <citep>OlivelleManu</citep><pnum>217--218</pnum> as: 
                        `Killing a Brahmin, drinking liquor, stealing, and having sex with an elder's  
                         wife---they call these ``grievous sins causing loss of caste''; 
                         and so is establishing any links with such individuals.'</NOTE>
        <TR>they call these grievous sins. The fifth is when one is connected with them
                [i.e. with these sins or with people involved in these sinful acts].</TR>

<TEXT> anṛtaṃ ca samutkarṣe rājagāmī ca paiśunaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>samutkarṣe</LEM> \eme; samutkarṣaṃ \msCa\msNa, 
                                         samutka<UNCL>rṣa</UNCL> \msCb,
                                         samutkarṣa \msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>rāja°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; rājñī° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>A lie concerning one's superiority, a slander that reaches the king's ear,</TR>
% Judit concerns the king 
% Flo Pañcatantra jackal etc.
% anṛte ca samutkarṣo rājagāmi ca paiśunaṃ ।168.025            purana/agni-puranam/168.txt

<TEXT> guroś{ }cālīkanirbandhaḥ samāni brahmahatyayā||</TEXT> 4:78
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°nirbandhaḥ</LEM> \eme; °nirbaddhaḥ \msCb\msNc, nibaddhas \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb, nirvaddhas \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>brahmahatyayā</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; bra\lk\lk \lk yā \msCa</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo \similar\ Ł\MBH\ 5.40.3 and \MANU\ 11.56:$
                 anṛtaṃ ca samutkarṣe rājagāmi ca paiśunam|
                 guroś{ }cālīkanirbandhaḥ samāni brahmahatyayā||
                Ł\similar\ \VISNUS\ 37.1--4 \similar\ \AGNIP\ 168.25$</PARAL>
        <NOTE>This verse being a quotation of \MANU\ 11.56, my translation 
              is based on <citep>OlivelleManu</citep><pnum>218</pnum>.
              On lies and slander (or `malignant speech,' Łpiśuna$), see also \VSS\ 4.69 and 8.25--28.</NOTE>
        <TR>and false accusations against an elder are equal to killing a Brahmin.</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> brahmojjhaṃ vedanindā ca kūṭasākṣī suhṛdvadhaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>brahmojjhaṃ</LEM> \eme; brahmo ṛg° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, brahma ṛg° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>suhṛd{ }vadhaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; sakṛd{ }budhaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>This verse continues quoting \MANU. ŁPāda$ a in the witnesses may actually be no more than the result of 
              misreading of the syllable Łjjha$ in \MANU\ 11.57. Note the variant Łbrahmojjhaṃ vedanindā ca$
              in both the `Northern' and `Southern' transmissions in Olivelle's critical edition 
              of \MANU\ (<citep>OlivelleManu</citep><pnum>847</pnum>).</NOTE>
        <TR>Abandoning the Vedas, reviling the Vedas, being a false witness, murdering a friend,</TR>
% brahmo is strange form
% Brahma veda = Atharvaveda Nirajan 

<TEXT> garhitānādyayor{ }jagdhiḥ surāpānasamāni ṣaṭ||</TEXT> 4:79
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°nādyayor{ }jagdhiḥ</LEM> \eme; °nnañ{ }ca yo jagdhis \msCa, °nnañ{ }ca yo jagdhi \msCb,
                                 °nnañ{ }ca yodvignaḥ \msCc, °nnaṃ ca yo jagdhiḥ \msNa, °nnaṃ ca yo jagdhiḥ \msNb,
                                 °nnañ{ }ca yo jave \msNc, °nnaś{ }ca yo vipraḥ \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo \similar\ Ł\MANU\ 11.57:$
                        brahmojjhatā vedanindā kauṭasākṣyaṃ suhṛdvadhaḥ|
                        garhitānādyayor{ }jagdhiḥ surāpānasamāni ṣaṭ||
                Ł\compare\ \YAJNS\ 3.229:$
                        gurūṇām{ }adhyadhikṣepo vedanindā suhṛdvadhaḥ|
                        brahmahatyāsamaṃ jñeyam{ }adhītasya ca nāśanam||</PARAL>
        <TR>eating unfit or forbidden food are six [deeds that are] equal to drinking alcohol.</TR>

<TEXT> retotsekaḥ svayonyāsu kumārīṣv{ }antyajāsu ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>svayonyāsu</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sutonyāsu \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Sexual intercourse with a female relative, with an unmarried girl,
                 with women of the lowest castes,</TR>
% Judit like in tantric text : śiroddeśa from śirodeśa, keep it, it does not mean ut-! originally phps some gemination
% retaḥsekaḥ svayonyāṣu kumārīṣvantyajāsu ca ।168.028            purana/agni-puranam/168.txt

<TEXT> sakhyuḥ putrasya ca strīṣu gurutalpasamaḥ smṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 4:80
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sakhyuḥ</LEM> \eme; sakhya \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed, \lk\lk\ \msNb, sa<UNCL>khyu</UNCL> \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>putrasya ca strīṣu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; 
                                                \lk\lk\lk\lk\lk\lk\ \msNb, putrīṣu cāstrīṣu \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°samaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; \lk\lk\ \msNb, °sama \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo \similar\ Ł\MANU\ 11.59:$
                                retaḥsekaḥ svayonīṣu kumārīṣv{ }antyajāsu ca|
                                sakhyuḥ putrasya ca strīṣu gurutalpasamaṃ viduḥ||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>The text, and my emendation in Łpāda$ c, still follow \MANU\ (11.59).</NOTE>
        <TR>with the wife of a friend or of one's own son are said to be equal to violating the guru's bed.</TR>
% Flo Śivadharmaśāstra/Śivadharmottara Manu quotations are better/more Manu, more faithful
                % sakhyuḥ putrasya ca(3) strīṣu gurutalpasamaṃ viduḥ ॥168.028            purana/agni-puranam/168.txt

<TEXT> nikṣepasyāpaharaṇaṃ narāśvarajatasya ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>nikṣepa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; nikhepa° \msCb, <UNCL>nikṣepa</UNCL>° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>narāśvarajatasya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; narāṇāṃ svajanasya \msCb, 
                                                        <UNCL>narāśvarajatasya</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Stealing deposits, people, horses, silver,</TR>
        %        nikṣepasyāpaharaṇaṃ narāśvarajatasya ca ।168.027            purana/agni-puranam/168.txt

%folioinfo \msNc\ 219.jpg lower, 217r
% manīnāṃ \msCb
<TEXT> bhūmivajramaṇīnāṃ ca rukmasteyasamaḥ smṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 4:81
        <APP>\vd <LEM>rukmasteya°</LEM> \eme; <UNCL>rūgya</UNCL>\lk ya° \msCa,
                                rugmasteya° \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc, \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb, hṛtasteya° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°samaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; saḥ \msCbacorr, °sama \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł= \MANU\ 11.58 $</PARAL>
        <NOTE>This is \MANU\ 11.58. I have emended Łrugma$° to Łrukma$° in Łpāda$ d, although
              Łrugma$° is attested in a great number of Southern MSS and one Śāradā MS in
               <citep>OlivelleManu</citep><pnum>847</pnum>.</NOTE>
        <TR>land, diamonds, or gems are said to be equal to stealing gold.</TR>
%nikṣepasyāpaharaṇaṃ narāśvarajatasya ca|
%bhūmivajramaṇīnāṃ ca rukmasteyasamaṃ smṛtam||
% Nirajan rugma might be acceptable
% bhūmivajramaṇīnāñca rukmasteyasamaṃ smṛtaṃ ॥168.027            purana/agni-puranam/168.txt

<TEXT> catvāra ete sambhūya yat{ }pāpaṃ kurute naraḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>ete</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; <UNCL>ete</UNCL> \msNb, eva \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>sambhūya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; saṃbhūyo \msCc, <UNCL>saṃbhūyo</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Since a man commits sin if [any of these] four [i.e. Łbrahmahatyā, surāpāna, stena, gurvaṅganāgama$],
                 occurs,</TR>

<TEXT> mahāpātaka pañcaitat tena sarvaṃ prakāśitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°pañcaitat</LEM> \corr; °pañcaitan \mssCaCbCc\Ed, °pañcaite \msNa,
                                              °pañcaitam \msNb, °pañcetan \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Perhaps understand Łpāda$ c as Łetan mahāpātakapañcakaṃ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>therefore all the five grievous sins have been explained.</TR>

<TEXT> pañcapramādam{ }etāni varjanīyaṃ dvijottama||</TEXT> 4:82
        <APP>\ve <LEM>°mādam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °māda \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>varjanīyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; varjanīyo \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the confusion of number and gender: understand Łpañca pramādāḥ etā varjanīyāḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>These five kinds of mistakes are to be avoided, O great Brahmin.</TR>

%index_grammar: gender

<PAGEBREAK/>
<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣu mādhuryam (9)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Ninth Yama-rule: charm</TRSUBCHAPTER>

% on kāyavāg etc. see Manu 12.3
% Törzsök
<TEXT> kāyavāṅmanamādhuryaś{ }cakṣur{ }buddhiś{ }ca pañcamaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>manamādhuryaś{ }ca°</LEM> \eme; °manasā dhūryaś{ }ca° \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc,
                                                        °mana<UNCL>mā</UNCL>dhūryaś{ }ca° \msCb,
                                                       °mana\lk dhūrya\lk ° \msNb, °manasā bhūyaś{ }ca° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kṣur{ }buddhi°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; °kṣu buddhi° \msCc\msNa, \lk\lk \lk\  \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>My emendation from °Łmanasā dhūryaś$ to °Łmana-mādhuryaś$ is based on the fact that following the list
                of Łyama$s in 3.16, we need some reference to Łmādhurya$ here and that it is easy to see how this
                 corruption came about: °Łmano-mādhurya$° would be unmetrical, hence the form °Łmana-mādhurya$;
                        °Łmana-mā$° is easily corrupted to °Łmanasā$° (not to mention the fact 
                        that Łmanasā$ comes up in the next verse). 
                        In addition, we need five items in this line because of Łpañcamaḥ$.
                        As always, I correct Łmādhūrya$ to Łmādhurya$, although it seems that 
                        the former is acceptable in this text. 
                        I did not correct Łmādhuryaś$ to Łmādhuryaṃ$ because of the corresponding
                        Łpañcamaḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>[Charm has five types:] bodily, verbal and mental charm, 
                        [charm of] the eyes and [of one's] thoughts as fifth.</TR>

<TEXT> saumyadṛṣṭipradānaṃ ca krūrabuddhiṃ ca varjayet||</TEXT> 4:83
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dānaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; \lk\lk\ \msNb, °dānaś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°buddhiṃ ca</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc; buddhiś{ }ca \msCb, °dṛṣṭiṃ ca \msCc\Ed, \lk\lk \lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Giving [others] a friendly glance [is commendable] and one should avoid cruel thoughts.</TR>

<TEXT> prasannamanasā dhyāyet{ }priyavākyam{ }udīrayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>prasanna°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; <UNCL>prasanna</UNCL>° \msNb, prasaṃna° \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$s cd of the previous verse, and Łpāda$s ab of the present one cover
              four categories of the above: Łcakṣurmādhurya$, Łbuddhimādhurya$, Łdṛṣṭimādhurya$ and Łvāgmādhurya$.
              This suggests that what follows is on Łkāyamādhurya$.</NOTE>
        <TR>One should meditate with a tranquil mind and should speak [to other people using] gentle words.</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.597
\msNa\ 202.jpg lower, f.9r
<TEXT> yathāśaktipradānaṃ ca svāśramābhyāgato guruḥ||</TEXT> 4:84
        <APP>\vc <LEM>yathā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yasya \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°dānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °dātaś \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>svāśramā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; svāsamā° \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°gato</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °sato \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Emending Łpāda$ d to Łsvāśramābhyāgate gurau$ would make the line smoother.</NOTE>
        <TR>[When] respectable people arrive at one's own hermitage,
                       [one should] present them with as many gifts as one can,</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 197.jpg, f. 277r
<TEXT> indhanodakadānaṃ ca jātavedam{ }athāpi vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>indhano°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; itvano° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>jāta°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; jā° \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łjātavedam$ in Łpāda$ b as Łjātavedasam$ or Łjātavedāḥ$,
                or rather as belonging to the compound °Łdānaṃ$: Łjātavedodānaṃ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>with gifts of fire-wood, water and fire.</TR>

<TEXT> sulabhāni na dattāni indhanāgnyudakāni ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sulabhāni na</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; surabhāni ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dakāni</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °<UNCL>ta</UNCL>kāni \msNb</APP>
        <TR>[If] fire-wood, fire and water are easily available [but] are not given [as gift]</TR>

<TEXT> kṣute jīveti vā noktaṃ tasya kiṃ parataḥ phalam||</TEXT> 4:85
        <APP>\ve <LEM>kṣute</LEM> \conj; kṣutaṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, śataṃ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>For Łpāda$ e, see an Āryāgīti verse in the \MAHASUBHS\ (2558): 
        <sep/>
                Łamṛtāyatām iti vadet pīte bhukte kṣute ca śataṃ jīva$ |<br/>
                Łchoṭikayā saha jṛmbhāsamaye syātāṃ cirāyurānandau$ ||
        <sep/>
                `When eating or drinking, one should say: ``May it turn into nectar!''; 
                 and after sneezing: ``Live for a hundred years!''
                 By snapping the thumb and forefinger when yawning, there will be long life and happiness.'</NOTE>
        <TR>or [if the phrase] `Live [for a hundred years]!' is not uttered when [somebody]
                sneezes, what reward could there be for such a person in the afterlife?</TR>




<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣv{ }ārjavam (10)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Tenth Yama-rule: sincerity</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> pañcārjavāḥ praśaṃsanti munayas{ }tattvadarśinaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>pañcārjavāḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; pañcārjavaḥ \msCc, \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb, pañcārjavā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>praśaṃsanti</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc; praśasanti \msNa\Ed, <UNCL>prasasanti</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>°Łārjavāḥ$ should be in the accusative, therefore it is to be taken as feminine (rather than neuter) or as
               an irregular form for °Łārjavāni$. I have emended Łpāratoṣikam$ to Łpāritoṣikam$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The sages who see the truth praise five types of sincerity.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 398.jpg
% pāratoṣika also pāritoṣika as salary
<TEXT> karmavṛttyābhivṛddhiṃ ca pāritoṣikam{ }eva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>karma°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; \lk rmma° \msCa, <UNCL>kammā</UNCL>° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°vṛttyābhivṛddhiṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc;
                                °vṛttibhivṛddhiñ{ }ca \msNb, °vṛtyābhivṛddhiś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>pāritoṣika°</LEM> \eme; pāratoṣika° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>A sincere person does not rejoice in prosperity arising from the operation of karma or by a reward,</TR>

<TEXT> strīdhanotkocavittaṃ ca ārjavo nābhinandati||</TEXT> 4:86
        <APP>\ve <LEM>strīdhanotkoca°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; strīdhanaṅgo ca \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°vittaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °vittiñ{ }ca \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>ārjavo nā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; ārjavañ{ }ca \msCc, ārjjavenā° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>My translation of the categories listed here is tentative, the only guiding light being
              that, if the first line is right, there should be five of them. In addition, I have tried to
              find categories that seem to be, more or less, in conflict with `sincerity' or `straightness.'</NOTE>
        <TR>in riches from women, from property, and bribery.</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> ārjavo na vṛthā yajña ārjavo na vṛthā tapaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM!>ārjavo na vṛthā yajña ārjavo na vṛthā tapaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; \om\ \msNaacorr,
                                                 ārjavo na vṛthā yajña ārjavo na vṛthā tapa \msNapcorr,                  
                                                 ārjavo na vṛthā yajñaś{ }cārrjavo na vṛthā tapaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>If one is not sincere, sacrifice is in vain. If one is not sincere, austerity is in vain.</TR>

<TEXT> ārjavo na vṛthā dānam{ }ārjavo na vṛthāgnayaḥ||</TEXT> 4:87
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>(ārjavoŁ...$ vṛthāgnayaḥ)</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \om\ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>If one is not sincere, donation is in vain. If one is not sincere, [sacrificial] fires are in vain.</TR>
%I thank Nirajan Kafle for helping me interpret this verse.

<TEXT> ārjavasyendriyagrāmaḥ suprasanno 'pi tiṣṭhati|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>(ārjava°Ł...$ tiṣṭhati)</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \om\ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°grāmaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; °grāmāt \msCc\msNb, °grāmāḥ \msNa</APP>
        <TR>The sense faculties of a sincere person are firm even when he is delighted.</TR>
% apitiṣṭhati in one word? Nirajan Śaṅkara bhāṣya to Bṛhadāraṇyaka

<TEXT> ārjavasya sadā devāḥ kāye tasya caranti te||</TEXT> 4:88
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tasya caranti</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ta\lk\lac ×× nti \msCa, tasya ramanti \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The gods are always present in the body of a sincere person.</TR>


<NOTANUSTUBH/> mālinī
<TEXT> iti yamapravibhāgaḥ kīrtito 'yaṃ dvijendra</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>yamapravibhāgaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc; yamavibhāgaḥ \msCc,
                                yamapraribhāgaḥ \msNa, niyamaparibhāgaḥ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>dvijendra</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; narendra \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ a °Łpra$° does not make the previous syllable long: this is the phenomenon of
                `muta cum liquida,' or \mutacumliquida, one of the hallmarks of the \VSS, 
                that is, syllables such as Łtra, pra, bra, dra$ do not necessarily make the 
                previous syllable long.</NOTE>
        <TR>Thus has been taught this section on the Yama-rules, O great Brahmin.</TR>

%index_metre: licence pr muta cum liquida 

%                                       taṃ? tat in \msCc
<TEXT> iha parata sukhārthaṃ kārayet{ }taṃ manuṣyaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°yet{ }taṃ manuṣyaḥ</LEM> \corr; °yet{ }tan{ }manuṣyaḥ \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed, °yet{ }ta manuṣyaḥ \msCb,
                                                                 °yet{ }tat{ }manuṣyaḥ \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ b, Łparata$ most probably stands for Łparatra$ or Łparataḥ$ metri causa. 
              We may correct it to Łparatra$, presupposing the presence of the \mutacumliquida.</NOTE>
        <TR>Humans should follow them to reach happiness here and in the other world.</TR>

<TEXT> duritamalapahārī śaṅkarasyājñayāste</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>durita°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; irita° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°pahārī</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °palapahārī \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°jñayāste</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °jñayāte \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>°Łmalapahārī$ in the MSS stands either for °Łmalāpahārī$ or °Łmalaprahārī$ metri causa. 
                I could have chosen to emend it to °Łmalaprahārī$ again 
                applying the \mutacumliquida,
                but I decided not to because Łapahārin$, Łapahāra$, 
                Łapahāraka$ are used in the text very frequently. 
                See also 8.44c, which contains a very similar expression:
                Łsakalamalapahāre dharmapañcāśad etat$.</NOTE>
        <TR>One will remove the filth of sins, and shall by Śaṅkara's command</TR>

 % should it not be cchatra? unmetr...  eme: pravartā (pravartṛ)
% cakravartā 
% ekāṭapattra Nirajan like my pravṛtṛ
<TEXT> bhavati pṛthivibhartā hy{ }ekachatrapravartā||</TEXT> 4:89
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°vartā</LEM> \conj; °vṛttā \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc, °vṛttāḥ \msNa\Ed</APP>
        <TR>become a ruler of the world [that he subjugates] under one royal umbrella.</TR>
% एकातपत्रं जगतः 

%index_metre: mālinī

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> <COLOPHON>iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe yamavibhāgo nāmādhyāyaś{ }caturthaḥ</COLOPHON></TEXT>
        <APP> Ł\Colo:$ <LEM>nāmādhyāyaś{ }caturthaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                         nāmaś{ }caturtho 'dhyāyaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TRCOLOPHON>Here ends the fourth chapter in the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ called Section on the Yama-rules.</TRCOLOPHON>

%END OF CHAPTER 4
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%




%lacuna_end: msM


<startchapter-n="5"/>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.597
%folioinfo \msCa\ 398.jpg l2
%folioinfo \msCb\ 418.jpg l1
%folioinfo \msCc\ 197.jpg l3
%folioinfo \msNa\ 202.jpg lower f.9r line 3
%folioinfo \msNb\ 50.jpg upper l3
%folioinfo \msNc\ 219.jpg lower l4, f. 217r
%folioinfo \msM\ 420.jpg lower, f. 9r line 5 
%chapter 5
<CHAPTER>pañcamo 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>
<TRCHAPTER> Chapter Five </TRCHAPTER>


<SUBCHAPTER>niyamāḥ</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The Niyama-rules</TRSUBCHAPTER>
<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>vigatarāga uvāca</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed;
                                              vigata<UNCL>rāga uvā</UNCL>ca \msCa</APP>
        <LACUNA>ŁWitnesses used for this chapter: \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 201v--202r,
                                                  \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 208v--209r,
                                                  \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 277r--278r,
                                                  \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 9r--9v,
                                                  \msNb\ exp.\thinspace 50 (upper) and 51 (lower),
                                                  \msNc\ ff.\thinspace 217r--218r,
                                                  \msM\ ff.\thinspace 9r--10r,
                                                  \Ed\ pp.\thinspace 597--599;
                                                  \mssCaCbCc\ = \msCa + \msCb + \msCc$</LACUNA>
        <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR>


<NOTANUSTUBH/> mālinī
<TEXT> kathaya niyamatattvaṃ sāmprataṃ tvaṃ viśeṣād</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kathaya ni°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; kathayati \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°tattvaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; taṃ \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>sāmprataṃ tvaṃ viśeṣād</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; tvāṃ vaśeṣāt \msCb,
                                     sāṃprata tvaṃ viseṣāt \msCc\msNb, sāmprataṃ tvaṃ viśeṣā \msM</APP>
        <TR>Now teach me the true nature of the Niyama-rules in detail.</TR>
% all but \msM read viśeṣāt

%folioinfo \msM\ 421.jpg upper, f. 9v 
<TEXT> amṛtavacanatulyaṃ śrotukāmo gato 'smi|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°vacanatulyaṃ śro°</LEM> \msM; vadanatulyaṃ śro° \msCa\msCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed,
                                                    vadanatulyāṃ śro° \msCb, 
                                                    vadana<UNCL>tulyaṃ śro</UNCL> tulyaṃ sro° \msNaacorr\oo
                 <LEM>°kāmo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °kāmā \msM\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Most witnesses read Łamṛtavadana$° in Łpāda$ b. This is slightly odd in the sense of `speech,' the meaning
              required here, therefore I follow \msM\ here.  One wonders if it is not Łamṛtasvādana$ or
              °Łsvadana$ (`tasting nectar') what was meant originally. I translate the phrase in question as if it read
               Łamṛtatulyavacanaṃ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>I have become desirous to hear [your] teaching that is comparable to ambrosia.</TR>

<TEXT> prakṛtidahanadagdhaṃ jñānatoyair{ }niṣiktam</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dahana°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; °vadana° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°dagdhaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dagdha \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°r{ }niṣiktam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °r{ }vimuktam \msCb, °r{ }niśiktaḥ \msM</APP>
        <TR>Tell [me] more (Łapara vada$), [to me who had been]
                 burnt by the fire of materiality (Łprakṛti$), 
                 [but is now] sprinkled with the water of knowledge,</TR>
        % toyai nisiktam \msCc

<TEXT> apara vada{-}m{-}atajjñaṃ nāsti dharmeṣu tṛptiḥ||</TEXT> 5:1
        <APP>\vd <LEM>apara°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\msMpcorr\Ed; aparaṃ \msNa\ \unmetr, ara° \msMacorr\oo
                 <LEM>m{-}atajjñaṃ nāsti</LEM> \conj; matajñā nāsti \msCapcorr\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM,
                                                        tajñā nāsti \msCaacorr,
                                                                 matajñā<UNCL>nnā</UNCL>sti \msCc, 
                                                                <UNCL>me</UNCL> \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb,
                                                                 °na tajjñān{ }nāsti \Ed\oo
         <LEM>dharmeṣu tṛptiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; me dharmatṛptiḥ \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>The first half of Łpāda$ d is difficult to interpret safely. Łapara vada$ (`tell me more') might be original,
              with Łapara$ in \stemform. The phrase Łmatajñā$ is now emended to Ł-m-atajjñaṃ$,
              containing a hiatus break and making the line metrical.
              Otherwise it could be emended to Łmatajña$ (with the last syllable taken as long) 
              and translated as a vocative (`O knower of the doctrine').
              Note \msM's reading for the end of the line (Łme dharmatṛptiḥ$).</NOTE>
        <TR>and is ignorant of [the topic]. One can't have enough of the [teaching on] Dharmas (Łnāsti dharmeṣu tṛptiḥ$).</TR>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge
%index_metre: mālinī


<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>anartha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; artha° \msM</APP>
        <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR>

<NOTANUSTUBH/> mālinī
<TEXT> śravaṇasukham{ }ato 'nyat{ }kīrtayiṣye dvijendra</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°sukha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; °mukha° \msNaacorr\oo 
                 <LEM>°m{ }ato 'nyat</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °m{ }ato 'nya \msNb,
                                                         °m{ }ato nyaḥ \msM, °m{ }ano 'nyat \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>kīrta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\msM\Ed; kīrti° \msNa\msNb</APP>
        <TR>I shall teach you something else that is nice to hear, O best of the twice-born.</TR>

<TEXT> niyamakalaviśeṣaḥ pañca pañca prakāraḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°viśeṣaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; viśe\lk\ \msCa, °viśeṣa \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>prakāraḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\Ed; pakāraḥ \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>My suspicion is that °Łkala$° in Łpāda$ b stands for Łkalā$ metri causa. </NOTE>
        <TR>The [ten] individual Niyamas are fivefold [each].</TR>


        % grammar metre for munyabhīṣṭaṃ metri causa
<TEXT> hariharamunibhīṣṭaṃ dharmasāraṃ dvijendra</TEXT>
        <NOTE>Similarly, °Łmunibhīṣṭaṃ$ is metri causa, for °Łmunyabhīṣṭaṃ$ (`dear to the sages').</NOTE>
        <TR>It is the essence of Dharma, dear to Hari, Hara and the sages, O great Brahmin,</TR>

%index_metre: i+a = i  metri causa (for ya)

<TEXT> kalikaluṣavināśaṃ prāyamokṣaprasiddham||</TEXT> 5:2
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°vināśaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; °vināśa° \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ d, Łprāya$° is suspect. Compare with 6.1c: Łdharmamokṣaprasiddhyarthaṃ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>the destruction of the impurity of the Kali age, known as almost liberation.</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>


<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> śaucam{ }ijyā tapo dānaṃ svādhyāyopasthanigrahaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>ijyā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; ījyā \msCc\msNb\msM\oo
                 <LEM>dānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; dāna° \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Purification, sacrifice, penance, donation, Vedic study, the restraint of sexual desire,</TR>

<TEXT> vratopavāsamaunaṃ ca snānaṃ ca niyamā daśa||</TEXT> 5:3
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°pavāsa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °pravāṣa° \msM</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł = \LINPU\ 1.8.29cd--30ab = \VDHU\ 3.233.202$</PARAL>
        <NOTE>See this verse in \LinPu\ 1.8.29cd--30ab and \VDhU\ 3.233.202.</NOTE>
        <TR>religious observances, fasting, observing silence, and bathing: these are the ten Niyamas.</TR>
    % daṣa \msCb




<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣu śaucam (1)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>First Niyama-rule: purity</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> tatra śaucādinirdeśaṃ vakṣyāmīha dvijottama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°nirdeśaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\msM\Ed; °niyamaṃ \msNa, °rddeśaṃ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>From among these, now I shall tell you the particulars of purification [first], and [then] the others.</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.598
% sg. dropped out here?
<TEXT> śārīraśaucam{ }āhāro mātrā bhāvaś{ }ca pañcamaḥ||</TEXT> 5:4
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śārīra°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; śarīra° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°śaucam{ }āhāro</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °śauca\lk hāro \msCa,
                                                                                 °srotam{ }āhāra \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>mātrā bhāvaś{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; mātrā bhāvaṃ ca \msCa,
                                                                                 <UNCL>sātrābhā</UNCL>vaś{ }ca \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>The following passages deal with Łśārīraśauca$ (5.5--9) and Łāhāraśauca$ (5.10--16), 
              therefore Łpāda$ c is probably correct, 
              and \msM's reading (Łśārīrasrotam āhāra$) seems wrong. 
              Even if we could interpret Łpāda$ d with any certainty, there
              is one element missing in this list of allegedly five items. 
              Something must have dropped out here.
              Oddly enough, the chapter stops after teaching the second type of purity,
              Łāhāraśauca$, so we are left without a clue.
              \MBH\ Suppl. 14.4.3229--3230 is not very helpful either: 
        <sep/>
              Łmanaḥśaucaṃ karmaśaucaṃ kulaśaucaṃ ca bhārata$ | <br/>
              Łśarīraśaucaṃ vākśaucaṃ śaucaṃ pañcavidhaṃ smṛtam$ ||</NOTE>
        <TR>[1] Bodily purity, [2] [purity of] food, [3] [purity of] the household[?] (Łmātrā$), 
                 [4] [purity of] character[?] (Łbhāva$), and the fifth, [5]...?</TR>
        % bhāvas ca \msCc
        % mbh_14_u.htm.txt-9819-14,096.015d@004_3229      manaḥśaucaṃ karmaśaucaṃ kulaśaucaṃ ca bhārata<BR>
        % mbh_14_u.htm.txt:9820:14,096.015d@004_3230      śarīraśaucaṃ vākśaucaṃ śaucaṃ pañcavidhaṃ smṛtam<BR>




<SUBSUBCHAPTER>śarīraśaucam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Purity of the Body</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
%folioinfo \msCc\ 198.jpg
<TEXT> tāḍayen{ }na ca bandheta na ca prāṇair{ }viyojayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tāḍayen{ }na</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; tāḍaye na \msNc\msM\oo
                 <LEM>bandheta</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; bandhena \msM</APP>
        <TR>He should not beat, tie or kill [any living being].</TR>
% prāṇai \msCc

<TEXT> parastrīparadravyeṣu śaucaṃ kāyikam{ }ucyate||</TEXT> 5:5
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dravyeṣu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °draveṣu \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>śaucaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\Ed; śauca \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>kāyikam{ }ucyate</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\Ed; kāyikam{ }umucyete \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the application of the \mutacumliquida\ in Łpāda$ c: the first syllable
              of Łdravyeṣu$ does not make the previous syllable heavy.</NOTE>
        <TR>[This and] purity concerning others' wives and property is called bodily purity.</TR>

%index_metre: licence dr muta cum liquida 

%folioinfo \msNc\ 220.jpg upper, f. 217v
<TEXT> śrotraśaucaṃ dvijaśreṣṭha gudopasthamukhādayaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śrotra°</LEM> \msM; śrota° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>gudopastha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM; gudoprastha° \msNc, gudāpastha° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The cleanliness of the ears, O great Brahmin, and of the anus, the loins, the mouth etc. 
                [also contributes to bodily purity].</TR>

<TEXT> mukhasyācamanaṃ śaucam{ }āhāravacaneṣu ca||</TEXT> 5:6
        <APP>\vc <LEM>mukhasyā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; mukhasthā° \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>śaucam{ }ā°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; śaucaṃm{ }ā° \msCb\msNb, śauca ā° \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°vacaneṣu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °vaṣaneṣu \msM</APP>
        <TR>The purity of the mouth [comes from] sipping water before eating and speaking.</TR>

<TEXT> mūtraviṣṭāsamutsarge devatārādhaneṣu ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°viṣṭā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °viṣṭa° \msNb\msM</APP>
        <TR>After the emission of urine and f\ae ces, and before the worship of gods,</TR>

<TEXT> mṛttoyais{ }tu gudopasthaṃ śaucayīta vicakṣaṇaḥ||</TEXT> 5:7
        <APP>\vc <LEM>mṛttoyais{ }tu</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; <UNCL>mṛ</UNCL>\lk\lk \lk\ \msCa, 
                                                      mṛtoyais{ }tu \msCb\msM, mṛttoyes{ }tu \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°pasthaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °pastha \msCc\Ed, °pasthaḥ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>śaucayīta</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; śaucaye ca \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the peculiar verb form Łśaucayīta$ (for a more standard Łśocayeta$). \msM's Łśaucaye$[Łc$] Łca$
              may be close to an original reading.</NOTE>
        <TR>the wise one should clean his anus and his loins with clay and water.</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> ekopasthe gude pañca tathaikatra kare daśa|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°pasthe</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °pastha° \msCc\msNb\msM\oo
                 <LEM>gude</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; gudo \msCc\msNb, guda \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tathaikatra</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tathaika<UNCL>tra</UNCL> \msCb,
                                                                   tathaikatre \msM, tathaikaś{ }ca \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>daśa</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; daśaḥ \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>In essence, this verse is \MANU\ 5.136. Olivelle's notes on this verse read:
                `Łon one hand:$ within the context the meaning is clear: ``one hand'' refers to the left
                 hand, with which the person applied the earth and water to the penis and anus. All purifications
                 below the navel are carried out using the left hand. Variant reading: ``on the left hand.''\thinspace '
                 (<citep>OlivelleManu</citep><pnum>287</pnum>.)</NOTE>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\similar\ \MANU\ 5.136:$ ekā liṅge gude tisras{ }tathaikatra kare daśa|
                                              ubhayoḥ sapta dātavyā mṛdaḥ śuddhim{ }abhīpsatā||</PARAL>
        <TR>One [portion of clay] for the loins, five for the anus, ten for one hand,</TR>
% \msCc\ and \msNb\ seem to go together, see also above
% comm: left hand?


<TEXT> ubhayoḥ sapta dātavyā mṛdaḥ śuddhiṃ samīhatā||</TEXT> 5:8
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ubhayoḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ubhaya \msM\oo
                 <LEM>dātavyā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; dātavyo \msCc\Ed, dātavya \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>mṛdaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; mṛtaḥ \msNa\msM, mṛdā \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>śuddhiṃ samīhatā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa; śuddhisamīhayā \msCc, śu<UNCL>ddhi</UNCL> samīhatā \msNb,
                                      śuddhiḥ samīhatā \msNc, śuddhi samīhatā \msM, śuddhiṃ samāhitā \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[then] seven [portions] of clay are to be applied for both [hands] by him who wishes cleanliness.</TR>



%folioinfo \msNa\ 203.jpg upper
<TEXT> etac{ }chaucaṃ gṛhasthānāṃ dviguṇaṃ brahmacāriṇām|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>etac{ }chaucaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM; cetac{ }hauca \msCc\Ed, eta\lk\lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°guṇaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; °guṇa \msCc</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\similar\ \MANU\ 5.137:$
                etac{ }chaucaṃ gṛhasthānāṃ dviguṇaṃ brahmacāriṇām|
                triguṇaṃ syād{ }vanasthānāṃ yatīnāṃ tu caturguṇam||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>This verse corresponds to \MANU\ 5.137.</NOTE>
        <TR>This is the purification for the householder (Łgṛhastha$).
            It is twice as much for the chaste one (Łbrahmacārin$),</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 51.jpg lower
<TEXT> vānaprasthasya triguṇaṃ yatīnāṃ tu caturguṇam||</TEXT> 5:9
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vānaprasthasya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vānaprasthe tu \msM\oo
                <LEM>tri°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; dvi° \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \mutacumliquida\ in Łpāda$ c: Łtr$ does not turn the previous syllable heavy and 
              the Łpāda$ becomes a Łna-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>three times as much for the forest-dweller (Łvānaprastha$), 
            and four times as much for the ascetic (Łyati$).</TR>

%index_metre: tri muta cum liquida licence na-vipulā
%index_metre: muta cum liquida tr


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>āhāraśaucam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Purity of the food</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> āhāraśaucaṃ vakṣyāmi śṛṇuṣvāvahito bhava|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°śaucaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °śauca \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śṛṇuṣvāvahito</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; śṛṇu<UNCL>ṣvāva</UNCL>\lk\lk\ \msCa,
                                                                       śṛṇuṣvavahito \msNb</APP>
        <TR>I shall teach you the rules of purity concerning food. Listen, pay great attention.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-viplulā

%folioinfo \msCa\ 399.jpg
<TEXT> bhāgadvayaṃ tu bhuñjīta bhāgam{ }ekaṃ jalaṃ pibet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°kaṃ jalaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °kodakaṃ \msM\oo
                 <LEM>pibet</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; pibe \msCb</APP>
        <TR>One should eat [as much] food [that fills] two quarters [of the stomach] 
            and drink water [that fills] one quarter.</TR>

<TEXT> vāyusaṃcāradānārthaṃ caturtham{ }avaśeṣayet||</TEXT> 5:10
        <APP>\ve <LEM>°cāradānārthaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °caradānārthaṃ \msM, °cāraṇārthāya \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\similar\ Śaṅkara's commentary ad \BHG\ 6.16:$
                                uktaṃ hi | 
                                ardhaṃ savyañjanānnasya tṛtīyam{ }udakasya ca| 
                                vāyoḥ saṃcaraṇārthaṃ tu caturtham{ }avaśeṣayet||;
                   Ł\compare\ \ASTANGHR\ 8.46cd--47ab:$
                                             annena kukṣer{ }dvāv{ }aṃśau pānenaikaṃ prapūrayet|| 
                                             āśrayaṃ pavanādīnāṃ caturtham{ }avaśeṣayet|;
                   Ł\compare\ \SANNYASUP\ 59:$
                                             āhārasya ca bhāgau dvau tṛtīyam{ }udakasya ca| 
                                             vāyoḥ saṃcaraṇārthāya caturtham{ }avaśeṣayet||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Śaṅkara quotes a similar verse in his commentary ad \BHG\ 6.16 (see apparatus).
                 It translates as:
                `Half is for saucy food, the third part for water, but in order to be able to move the air,
                 one should leave the fourth part [empty].' This verse and one in the \SANNYASUP\ (see apparatus) have
                 Łsaṃcaraṇārthaṃ tu$ and Łsaṃcaraṇārthāya$, respectively, where our verse in the \VSS\ has Łsaṃcāradānārthaṃ$.
                 It would be tempting to emend but the \VSS\ version more or less works fine, therefore 
                 there is no need to alter the text.</NOTE>
        <TR>In order to give passage to the air, one should save the remaining quarter.</TR>


<PAGEBREAK/>

<TEXT> snigdhasvādurasaiḥ ṣaḍbhir{ }āhāraṣaḍrasair{ }budhaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°svādurasaiḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °svā\lk rasaiḥ \msNb, °svādurasaṃ \msM, °svādarasaiḥ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°hāraṣaḍrasair{ }bu°</LEM> \msCb\Ed; °hārasadravair{ }bu° \msCa\msNa\msNc,
                                        °hārasadravai bu° \msCc, °hāraṣaḍrasai bu° \msNb, °hāre sadravad{ }bu° \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>The readings may suggest that Łpāda$ b contains Łsadrava$ or maybe Łsudrava$, but it is difficult to make
              sense of the sentence. We are lacking a verb; Łāhāra$ might be wrong for Łāharet$ (see \msM).
              The Āyurvedic implications of this clumsy verse are not crystal clear to me.
              What is clear is that traditionally there are
              six basic flavours or `juices' in food. See, e.g. \BHELAS\ 1.28.1:
              <sep/>
                        Łyad bhakṣayati bhuṅkte vā vidhivac cāpi mānavaḥ$ |<br/>
                        Łanyac ca kiñcit pibati tat sarvaṃ ṣaḍrasānvitam$ ||
              <sep/>
                        `All that a human eats or enjoys according to the rules, and furthermore all 
                          that he or she drinks, is endowed with the six flavours.'
              <sep/>
               To repair Łpāda$s ab, one should perhaps imagine that the intended meaning was that the
               six flavours/juices should be present in a harmonious proportion in a wise man's food. 
               Cf. \BHELAS\ 3.1.1:
               <sep/>
                         Łśarīraṃ dhārayantīha ṣaḍrasāḥ samam āhṛtāḥ$ |<br/>
                         Łato 'nyathā vikārāṃs tu janayanti śarīriṇām$ ||
               <sep/>
                        `The six flavours will support the body in this world when brought to a balanced state.
                          Otherwise they will produce defects to people.'</NOTE>
        <TR>[By] the wise one['s applying] the six soft and sweet juices, [which are] the six flavours in food,</TR>

<TEXT> dhātuvaiṣamyanāśo 'sti na ca rogāḥ sudāruṇāḥ||</TEXT> 5:11
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vaiṣamyanāśo 'sti</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                      °<UNCL>dai</UNCL>ṣamya\-nāśāsti \msCb, °vaiśamya nasyāsti \msM, °vaiṣamya naśyanti \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>rogāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; roga \msM\oo
                 <LEM>sudāruṇāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; svadāruṇāḥ \msM, sudāruṇaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>On Łdhātuvaiṣamya$, the balanced state of the bodily constituents Łpitta$, 
              Łkapha$ and Łvāyu$, see, e.g., \CARAKA\ 1.9.4:
        <sep/>
                          Łvikāro dhātuvaiṣamyaṃ sāmyaṃ prakṛtir ucyate$ | <br/>
                          Łsukhasaṃjñakam ārogyaṃ vikāro duḥkham eva ca$ ||
        <sep/>
                          `The imbalance of the Łdhātu$s means defects. Balance is said to be natural.
                            Health is happiness, defects are suffering.' See also \VSS\ 9.2 below.</NOTE>
        <TR>the disturbances of the constituents (Łdhātu$) will disappear 
            and the terrible illnesses will not arise.</TR>
% vaiśamya \msCa\msCc, daiśamya? \msCb

% Olivelle: Manu p.340 note to Manu 11.57 abhakṣya is forbidden, abhojya is unfit food
<TEXT> abhakṣyaṃ ca na bhakṣeta apeyaṃ na ca pāyayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>abhakṣyaṃ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; \lk\lk \lk\ \msNb, abhakṣaṃ \msM\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>ca na bhakṣeta</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; na ca bhakṣetaḥ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>na ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM; ca na \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand the causative Łpāyayet$ as simplex.</NOTE>
        <TR>He should not eat what is forbidden and he should not drink what is forbidden.</TR>

%index_grammar: causative for simplex

<TEXT> agamyaṃ na ca gamyeta avācyaṃ na ca bhāṣayet||</TEXT> 5:12
        <APP>\vc <LEM>gamyeta</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; gamyetaḥ \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>avācyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; avācaṃ \msCc</APP>
        <TR>He should not go where he is not allowed to and he should not say what is improper.</TR>

<TEXT> laśunaṃ ca palāṇḍuṃ ca gṛñjanaṃ kavakāni ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>palāṇḍuṃ</LEM> \Ed; palaṇḍuṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\msM, palaḍuṃ \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kavakāni</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; ca kacāni \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\similar\ \MANU\ 5.5ab: $ laśunaṃ gṛñjanaṃ caiva palāṇḍuṃ kavakāni ca</PARAL>
        <TR>He should avoid garlic, onion, Łgṛñjana$ onion, mushrooms,</TR>

<TEXT> gauraṃ ca sūkaraṃ māṃsaṃ varjayec{ }ca vidhānataḥ||</TEXT> 5:13
        <APP>\vc <LEM>gauraṃ ca</LEM> \eme; gorasva \msCa\msNb, goraś{ }ca \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\msM, gauraś{ }ca \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>māṃsaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; māṃsaḥ \msM, māsaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vidhānataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vidhānat \msM</APP>
        <TR>buffalo meat, and pork, following the rules.</TR>

<TEXT> chattrākaṃ viḍvarāhaṃ ca gomāṃsaṃ ca na bhakṣayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>chattrākaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; chattrāka \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>viḍva°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msM\Ed; vidva° \msNa\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>gomāṃsaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; gomāñ \msCbacorr</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\compare\ \MANU\ 5.19ab:$ chatrākaṃ viḍvarāhaṃ ca laśunaṃ grāmakukkuṭam </PARAL>
        <TR>He should not eat Łchattrāka$ mushrooms, village hog, and cow flesh.</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 421.jpg lower, f. 10r 
<TEXT> caṭakaṃ ca kapotaṃ ca jālapādāṃś{ }ca varjayet||</TEXT> 5:14
        <APP>\vc <LEM>caṭakaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; caṭakām \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°pādāṃś{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; jālapādañ{ }ca \msM</APP>
        <TR>He should also avoid sparrows, pigeons, and water-birds.</TR>
% pādāś \msNcacorr (corr in diff hand)

                                %    suka \msCa
<TEXT> haṃsasārasacakrāhvakukkuṭān{ }śukaśyenakān|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°cakrāhva°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °cakrāhvā° \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kukkuṭān{ }śu°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; °kukkuṭā śu° \msNa, °kukkuṭāṃ śu° \msNb, °kurkuṭā śu° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°śyenakān</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNc\Ed; °śonakān \msCb, °śyenakā \msNa, °śyenakāṃ \msNb, °śyenakam \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that in Łpāda$ b the first syllable of Łśyenakān$
              does not turn the previous syllable, Łśu$, heavy (\mutacumliquida).</NOTE>
        <TR>He should also avoid [eating] geese, cranes, Łcakravāka$ birds, cocks, parrots, and hawks,</TR>
        % śyenakāṃ \msCc

%index_grammar: muta cum liquida licence pāda b śy!

<TEXT> kākolūkaṃ balākaṃ ca matsyādīṃś{ }cāpi varjayet||</TEXT> 5:15
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>kākolūkaṃ balākaṃ ca</LEM> \msCb\msNc; kākolūka<UNCL>sva</UNCL>\lk\lk ñ{ }ca \msCa,
                                                        kākolūkabalākaṃ ca \msCc\msNa\msM\Ed, 
                                                        <UNCL>kākolūkaṃ balākaṃ ca</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>matsyādīṃś{ }cāpi varjayet</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; matsyādīni ca varjaye \msM</APP>
        <TR>crows, owls, herons, fish etc.</TR>

<TEXT> amedhyāṃś{ }cāpavitrāṃś{ }ca sarvān{ }eva vivarjayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>amedhyāṃś{ }cāpavitrāṃś{ }ca</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc;
                                                                 <UNCL>amedhyāś{ }cāpavitrāṃś{ }ca</UNCL> \msNb, 
                      amedhyāś{ }ca pavitrāś{ }ca \msM, amedhyaś{ }cāpavitrāṃś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>sarvān{ }eva vivarjayet</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sarvāny{ }etāni varjayet \msM</APP>
        <TR>He should avoid everything that is ritually impure or polluted.</TR>

<TEXT> śākamūlaphalānāṃ ca abhakṣyaṃ parivarjayet||</TEXT> 5:16
        <TR>He should also completely avoid those vegetables, roots and fruits, that are prohibited.</TR>

<TEXT> mānaveṣu purāṇeṣu śaivabhāratasaṃhite|</TEXT>
        %\vb <LEM>śaive</LEM> \eme; śaiva° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ b, since °Łsaṃhite$ is not a correct locative of °Łsaṃhitā$, 
              instead of emending to Łśaive bhāratasaṃhite$, we may take the compound 
              as a Łsamāhāra\-dvandva\-samāsa$ in the neuter locative.</NOTE>
        <TR>In the books of Manu, in the Purāṇas, in Śaiva texts, 
            and in the ŁBhāra\-ta\-saṃ\-hitā$ (i.e. the ŁMahābhārata$),</TR>
% \msM has a lot of EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEs here after mānaveṣu

<TEXT> kīrtitāni viśeṣeṇa śaucācāram{ }aśeṣataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>viśeṣeṇa</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; maśeṣeṇa \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the gender and number confusion between Łkīrtitāni$ and °Łācāram$ in Łpāda$s cd.
              This and the next verse sound as if the author had been aware of the fact that he 
              left the remaining three categories of purity (see 5.4) unexplained.</NOTE>
        <TR>the practice of purity is definitely expounded in great detail.</TR>

%index_grammar: gender

%folioinfo \msCc\ 199.jpg
<TEXT> tvayā jijñāsito 'smy{ }adya saṃkṣiptaḥ kathito mayā||</TEXT> 5:17
        <APP>\ve <LEM>jijñāsito</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM; jijñāsano \msNc, jijñāsato \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°kṣiptaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °kṣipya \msCb, °kṣipta \msNb\msM\oo
                  <LEM>kathito</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; kathitaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Now that you have asked me [about it], I taught it [to you] in a condensed form.</TR>
%                                         °kṣiptax \msCa ?

<TEXT> satyavādī śucir{ }nityaṃ dhyānayogarataḥ śuciḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°vādī</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °vādi \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°rataḥ śucir</LEM> \msCa\msCb\Ed; °rataḥ śuci \msCc\msNc, rataḥ śucin \msNa\msNb, °rata śuci \msM</APP>
        <TR>He who speaks the truth is pure. He who engages in yogic meditation is pure.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 419.jpg
<TEXT> ahiṃsakaḥ śucir{ }dānto dayābhūtakṣamā śuciḥ||</TEXT> 5:18
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ahiṃsakaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ahiṃsaka \msCb\msM\oo 
                 <LEM>śucir{ }dānto</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; śuci dānto \msCc\msNc\msM, śucir{ }dāntau \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°bhūta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °bhuta° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>śuciḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; śuci \msM</APP>
        <NOTE>My impression is that Łdayābhūtakṣamā$ in Łpāda$ d may stand for Łbhūtadayā kṣamā$ (Łbhūtadayā$ occurring in
                1.7 and 3.27--28), and I translate accordingly.</NOTE>
        <TR>He who avoids violence and is restrained is pure. 
                 Compassion towards living beings and patience is purity.</TR>

<TEXT> sarveṣām{ }eva śaucānām{ }arthaśaucaṃ paraṃ smṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°śaucaṃ paraṃ smṛtam</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; °śaucaṃ para smṛtam \msCb\msCc,
                                                                       °śauca para smṛtaḥ \msM,
                                                                       °śaucayanaṃ smṛtaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\similar\ \MANU\ 5.106:$
                        sarveṣām{ }eva śaucānām{ }arthaśaucaṃ paraṃ smṛtam|
                        yo 'rthe śucir{ }hi sa śucir{ }na mṛdvāriśuciḥ śuciḥ||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$s a-d are quoting \MANU\ 5.106 (in most witnesses, unmetrically); it is translated by
              Olivelle (<citeyear>OlivelleManu</citeyear>, 144) as:
                `Purifying oneself with respect to wealth, tradition tells us, is the highest of all
                purifications; for the truly pure man is the one who is pure with respect to wealth, not
                the one who becomes pure by using earth and water.'</NOTE>
        <TR>Of all the [ways of] purification, material purification is taught to be the highest.</TR>

<TEXT> yo 'rthe hi śuciḥ sa śucir{ }na mṛdvāriśuciḥ śuciḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>yo 'rthe hi śuciḥ sa śucir{ }na</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc\ \unmetr; 
                                yo 'rthe hi śuciḥ sa śuci na \msNa\msNb,
                                yo rthe śuci hi sa śuddhi \msM,
                                yo 'rthe hi suśucir{ }vipra na \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°śuciḥ śuciḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; śuci śuciḥ \msNb, °śuci śuci \msM, °śuciḥ śuci \Ed</APP>
        <TR>For he who is pure with regards to material things is truly pure,
                and not the one who [only] uses clay and water [i.e. the one who performs only ordinary baths].</TR>

%index_metre: unmetrical

<TEXT> kāyavāṅmanasāṃ śaucaṃ sa śuciḥ sarvavastuṣu||</TEXT> 5:19
        <APP>\ve <LEM>vāṅmanasāṃ śaucaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vāṅmaṇasā śuddhi \msM</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>śuciḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; śuci \msCc\msM\oo
                 <LEM>vastuṣu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; vastuṣuḥ \msNc, vastuśu \msM</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vcd Ł\Ed\ adds here, after pādas cd:$ śaucāśaucavidhir{ }jñātvā mucyate sarvakilbiṣāt</LACUNA>
        <TR>When purification pertains to the body, to speech and to the mind, he is pure in all respects.</TR>
        % addition not in PaperMS B219-3 (3821.jpg)

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.599

<PAGEBREAK/>

<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<LONGVERSELINES/>
% stem form x 2
%       -  - -  . .  -  . - . .  . -? - -  . -  -  . -
<TEXT> śaucāśaucavidhijñamānava yadi kālakṣaye niścayaḥ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śaucāśauca°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; śaucāśuca \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>yadi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; yadiḥ \msM\oo
                 <LEM>kālakṣaye niścayaḥ</LEM> \msNaacorr\msNc;
                      kālakṣayair{ }niścayaḥ \msCa\msCb\msNapcorr,
                      kālakṣayen{ }niścayaḥ \msCc\msNb,
                      kālakṣayāniścayaḥ \msM,
                      kālakṣayetiś{ }ca yaḥ \Ed</APP>

%index_metre: long syllable at end of word at caesura

%       -   -  -  .    .  - . -  .  . . -   -  -     . -   -  . -
<TEXT> saubhāgyatvam{ }avāpnuvanti satataṃ kīrtir{ }yaśo'laṅkṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kīrtir{ }yaśo°</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kīrtiyaśo° \msCa\msCc \unmetr, kīrtiryaṣā° \msM\oo
                <LEM>°laṃkṛtam</LEM> \msM; °laṅkṛtaḥ \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed, °lakṛtaḥ \msCb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vb Ł\similar\ 4.67b above:$
                        loke 'nindanam{ }āpnuvanti satataṃ kīrtir{ }yaśo'laṃkṛtam</PARAL>

%        -  -   - . . -  .  -  . . . -   -   -  . -   - . -
<TEXT> prāptaṃ tena ihaiva puṇyasakalaṃ saddharmaśāstreritaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>saddharma°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ya dharma° \msM\oo
                 <LEM>°eritam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; °oditaḥ \Ed</APP>

%       - -  -  .  . -  .       - . . . -    -  - .  -  -  . -
<TEXT> jīvānte ca paratra{-}m{-}īhitagatiṃ prāpnoti niḥsaṃśayam||</TEXT> 5:20
% gatiṃ? (gatif \msCa)
        <APP>\vd <LEM>paratra{-}m{-}īhita°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                         paratramīhata° \msM, pavitram{ }īhita° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°gatiṃ</LEM> \eme; °gatiḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>niḥsaṃśayam</LEM> \msCa\msNb\msNc; niḥsaṃśayaḥ \msCb\msCc\msNa\msM\Ed</APP>
        <TR>If a person who knows the rules of purity and impurity is determined to destroy aging, 
                he will surely gain attractiveness, eternally embellished with glory and fame.
                He has obtained here in this world all the merits that the books on true Dharma teach, 
                and at the end of his life he will undoubtedly reach the desired path in the other world.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ noun °Łmānava$ metri causa and
                the second syllable of Łyadi$ as a long syllable at the c\ae sura in Łpāda$ a 
                (see \msM's reading). In place of the plural Łāpnuvanti$ one 
                would expect a verb in the singular, and Łkīrtir$ is metri causa 
                for a compounded \stemform\ (Łkīrti$°) in Łpāda$ b.
                Note also the sandhi-bridge Ł-m-$ in Łparatra-m-īhita$° in Łpāda$ d. 
                Compare with 4.67b above.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> <COLOPHON>iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe śaucācāravidhir{ }nāmādhyāyaḥ pañcamaḥ</COLOPHON></TEXT>
<APP> Ł\Colo:$ <LEM>°vidhir{ }namā°</LEM> \msCa; °vidhināmā° \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\msM, <UNCL>viṃdhi</UNCL>nāmā° \msNb, °vidhir{ }nāma \Ed\oo
                        <LEM>°dhyayaḥ pañcamaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °dhyāyaḥ pañcamaḥ śloka 25 \msM,
                                                                                        pañcamo 'dhyāyaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TRCOLOPHON>Here ends the fifth chapter in the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ called Method of Purification.</TRCOLOPHON>
%END OF CHAPTER 5

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%





%msM (stopped collating it again)



<startchapter-n="6"/>
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.599
%folioinfo \msCa\ 399.jpg
%folioinfo \msCb\ 419.jpg f. 209r line 2
%folioinfo \msCc\ 199.jpg f. 278r line 3
%folioinfo \msNa\ 203.jpg upper, f. 9v line 6
%folioinfo \msNb\ 51.jpg lower, line 5
%folioinfo \msNc\ 220.jpg lower, line 1, f. 218r
%folioinfo \msM\ 421.jpg lower, f. 10r line 4
%chapter 6
<CHAPTER>ṣaṣṭho 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>
<TRCHAPTER> Chapter Six </TRCHAPTER>

<NORMALVERSELINES/>
