% CHECK Śivadharmottara 3.12-15 !!

<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣv{ }ijyā (2)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Second Niyama-rule: sacrifice</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<ANUSTUBH/>
% [anarthayajña uvāca|*]
% [Anarthayajña spoke:]

<TEXT> atha pañcavidhām{ }ijyāṃ pravakṣyāmi dvijottama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°m{ }ijyāṃ</LEM> \msCb; °m{ }ījyāṃ \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; °ttamaḥ \msNb\msNc</APP>
        <LACUNA>ŁWitnesses used for this chapter: \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 202r--203r,
                                              \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 209r--209v,
                                              \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 278r--279r,
                                              \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 9v--10v,
                                              \msNb\ exp.\thinspace 51 (lower--upper) -- 52 (lower),
                                              \msNc\ ff.\thinspace 218r--218v,
                                              \Ed\ pp.\thinspace 599--601;
                                              \mssCaCbCc\ = \msCa + \msCb + \msCc$</LACUNA>
        <TR>[Anarthayajña continued:] Now I shall teach you the five types of sacrifice (Łijyā$),
                 O best of the twice-born,</TR>

<TEXT> dharmamokṣaprasiddhyarthaṃ śṛṇuṣvāvahito dvija||</TEXT> 6:1
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°mokṣaprasiddhyarthaṃ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc; °mokṣaprasiddhyartha \msNa\msNb, 
                                                        °mokṣeśasiddhyarthaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>dvija</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; bhava \Ed</APP>
        <TR>for success in Dharma and liberation. Listen carefully, O Brahmin.</TR>
        % CHECK BhG on arthayajña

<TEXT> arthayajñaḥ kriyāyajño japayajñas{ }tathaiva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>arthayajñaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa; anarthayajñaḥ \msCb,
                                                         arthayajña \msNb\msNc, arthayajña° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Material sacrifice, sacrifice through work, sacrifice through recitation,</TR>

<TEXT> jñānaṃ dhyānaṃ ca pañcaitat{ }pravakṣyāmi pṛthak{ }pṛthak||</TEXT> 6:2
        <APP>\vc <LEM>jñānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; jñāna \msCc\msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the singular Łetat$ after a number (see Introduction p.~\pageref{number}).

              Compare this list of five to the somewhat similar \BHG\ 4.28:
              <sep/>
               Łdravyayajñās tapoyajñā yogayajñās tathāpare$ | <br/>
               Łsvādhyāyajñānayajñāś ca yatayaḥ saṃśitavratāḥ$ ||
              <sep/>
              \SDHU\ chapter 3 can be also relevant since it uses the terms
              Łjapayajña$, Łjñānayajña$, and Łdhyānayajña$. 
              See also \SDHU\ 1.10 (\msCa\ f.\thinspace 42v l.~4):
              <sep/>
              Łkarmayajñas tapoyajñaḥ svādhyāyo dhyānam eva ca$ | <br/>
              Łjñānayajñaś ca pañcaite mahāyajñāḥ prakīrtitāḥ$ ||
              <sep/>
              Note how this definition of the five Łmahāyajña$s in the \SDHU\ 
              is different from the one, e.g., in \MANU\ 3.69--71
              (Łbrahma$°, Łpitṛ$°, Łdaiva$°, Łbhauta$°, and Łnṛyajña$).</NOTE>
        <TR>knowledge and meditation: I shall teach you these five one by one.</TR>

% also UMS? 

%index_grammar: singular after numbers, Newari


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>arthayajñaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Material sacrifice</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> agnyupāsanakarmādi agnihotrakratukriyā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>agni°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; <UNCL>a</UNCL>\lac\ × \msCa, \lk\lk\ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°kriyā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °kriyāḥ \msCb\msCc</APP>
        <TR>Material sacrifice includes the following: 
                the domestic ritual fire worship etc., the public performance of the ritual of Agnihotra,</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 400.jpg
%folioinfo \msNa\ 203.jpg lower, f. 10r
% maybe accept aṣṭakā
<TEXT> aṣṭakā pārvaṇī śrāddhaṃ dravyayajñaḥ sa ucyate||</TEXT> 6:3
        <APP>\vc <LEM>pārvaṇī</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; parvaṇī \msCb, <UNCL>parvaṇī</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°yajñaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °yajña \msCc, \lk\lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>By somewhat overtranslating the items in this list, I want to emphasise that
              the text introduces three categories of sacrifical rituals well-known from
              the time of the Gṛhyasūtras and Śrautasūtras: those of the domestic or Łaupāsana$ fire (Łgṛhyakarman$),
              the Śrauta rituals such as the Agnihotra, and the Smārta Łpākayajña$s, such as the Łaṣṭakā$, 
              the Łpārvaṇī$ and the Łśrāddha$. For a mention of the Łpākayajña$s in a manner similar to 
              our Łpāda$s cd here, see, e.g., a verse in the \Diksottara\ quoted 
              in <citep>NisvasaGoodall</citep><pnum>275</pnum>:
              <sep/>
                        Łaṣṭakāḥ pārvaṇī śrāddhaṃ śrāvaṇy āgrāyaṇī tathā$ | <br/>
                        Łcaitrī cāśvayujī caiva pākayajñāḥ prakīrtitāḥ$ ||~178~||
              <sep/>
              For an earlier list of Łpākayajña$s, see \GAUTDHS\ 1.8.19: 
                <skt>aṣṭakā pārvaṇaḥ śrāddham śrāvaṇy\-āgrahāyaṇī\-caitry\-āśvayujīti sapta pākayajñasamsthāḥ</skt>.</NOTE>
        <TR>[and the so-called Łpākayajña$s such as] 
                 the Aṣṭakā oblation, the Pārvaṇī oblation, and the ancestral ritual (Łśrāddha$).</TR>




<SUBSUBCHAPTER>kriyāyajñaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Sacrifice through work</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> ārāmodyānavāpīṣu devatāyataneṣu ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°yataneṣu</LEM> \msCb\msCc\Ed; °layaneṣu \msCa\msNa\msNc, °yata\lk\lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Sacrifice through work means constructing (Łsaṃskāra$)</TR>

<TEXT> svahastakṛtasaṃskāraḥ kriyāyajña sa ucyate||</TEXT> 6:4
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°hasta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; \lk\lk\ \msNb, °hastaiḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>a grove, a park, a pond, or a temple with one's own hands.</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>japayajñaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Sacrifice through recitation</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> japayajñaṃ tato vakṣye svargamokṣaphalapradam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°yajñaṃ tato</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °yajñaṃ tapo \msCb °yajñas{ }tato \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Next I shall teach you the sacrifice through recitation, 
                the bestower of the fruits of heaven and liberation.</TR>

<TEXT> vedādhyayana kartavyaṃ śivasaṃhitam{ }eva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vedā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; adā° \msNb</APP>
        <TR>One should recite the Vedas, Śaiva collections,</TR>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ Łvedādhyayana$ in Łpāda$ c metri causa. 
              There are several possible interpretations for Łpāda$s d and e.
              Łśivasaṃhitam$ could mean `Śaiva texts and the [Bhārata]saṃhitā,'
              i.e. the \MBh;
              see 5.17b above: Łśaivabhāratasaṃhite$. Alternatively, it
              may mean `the collection of Śaiva teachings.'
              As for Łitihāsapurāṇaṃ$, it is most probably a dvandva compound, most probably
              denoting the \MBh\ (but perhaps not the 
              \Ramayana, contrary to claims such as that, e.g., in 
              <citep>SocialLiteraryHistoryDharma</citep><pnum>34, n.~6</pnum>),
              and the Purāṇas. In case Łsaṃhitam$ in Łpāda$ d means the \MBh,
              Łitihāsapurāṇaṃ$ could in general mean `histories and legends.'
              In the light of 8.1--6, where Łitihāsa$ clearly means the \MBh,
              and Purāṇas are mentioned separately, this is unlikely. 
              In my translation, I have left these terms untranslated.
              For the debate on what Łitihāsa$ is, see, e.g., <cite>ReadingFifthVeda</cite> and
              <cite>BaileyPuranas</cite>. 
              
              Both Łśivasaṃhitam$ and Łitihāsapurāṇaṃ$ should be interpreted as
              being part of the compound in Łpāda$ c: Łśiva\-saṃhitādhyayanaṃ$ and 
              Łitihāsapurāṇādhyayanaṃ$. 

              See Łjapayajña$ mentioned, e.g., in \BHG\ 10.25c (Łyajñānāṃ japayajño 'smi$) 
              and \MANU\ 2.86 (Łvidhiyajñāj japayajño viśiṣṭo daśabhir guṇaiḥ$).</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

%folioinfo \msNb\ 50.jpg upper 
<TEXT> itihāsapurāṇaṃ ca japayajñaḥ sa ucyate||</TEXT> 6:5
        <APP>\ve <LEM>°purāṇaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °purāṇaś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°yajñaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °yajña \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Itihāsas and Purāṇas: this is called sacrifice through recitation.</TR>


% see ŚDhU 3 for 5 yajñas
<SUBSUBCHAPTER>jñānayajñaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Sacrifice through knowledge</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

%folioinfo \msM\ 422.jpg upper, f. 10v 
<TEXT> idaṃ karma akarmedam{ }ūhāpohaviśāradaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>karma</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; kramam \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[He who can decide if] `this is [proper] action; the other is improper action'
                 because he is knowledgeable about reasoning pro and contra,</TR>

<TEXT> śāstracakṣuḥ samālokya jñānayajñaḥ sa ucyate||</TEXT> 6:6
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°cakṣuḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °cakṣu \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°yajñaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °yajña \msCc, °<UNCL>yajñas</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>For the expression Łśāstracakṣuḥ$, see, e.g., \BRAHMAP\ 24.21:
              <sep/>
                        Łtena yajñān yathāproktān mānavāḥ śāstracakṣuṣaḥ$ | <br/>
                        Łkurvate 'harahaś caiva devān āpyāyayanti te$ ||
              <sep/>
        In G. P. Bhatt's translation (<citeyear>BrahmapuranaTr1</citeyear>, 126):
               `Day by day men with the sacred scriptures as their guides
                perform sacrifices in the manner they have been laid down and thereby nourish the gods.'</NOTE>
        <TR>and conducts investigations with his eyes on the Śāstras, is called
                        [a person performing] sacrifice through knowledge.</TR>


%folioinfo \msCc\ 200.jpg f. 278v
<SUBSUBCHAPTER>dhyānayajñaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Sacrifice through meditation</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> dhyānayajñaṃ samāsena kathayiṣyāmi te śṛṇu|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°yajñaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °yajña \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <TR>I shall teach you concisely about sacrifice through meditation. Listen to me.</TR>

<TEXT> dhyānaṃ pañcavidhaṃ caiva kīrtitaṃ hariṇā purā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>dhyānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\Ed; dhyāna \msNa\msNc</APP>
        <TR>Meditation was taught by Hari in the past as of five kinds.</TR>

% unmetr
<TEXT> sūryaḥ somo 'gni sphaṭikaḥ sūkṣmaṃ tattvaṃ ca pañcamam||</TEXT> 6:7
        <APP>\ve <LEM>somo</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc; somā° \msCb\msNb\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM!>sūkṣmaṃ tattvaṃ ca pañcamam</LEM> \msCb;
                                sūkṣmaṃ ta<UNCL>tva</UNCL>\lac ×× ñcamam \msCa, 
                                sūkṣmatattvaṃ ca pañcamaḥ \msCc\msNa\msNb,
                                sūkṣmaṃ tattvañ{ }ca pañcamaḥ \msNc,
                                sūkṣmāṃ tattvaś{ }ca pañcamam \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>For an analysis of this fivefold method of meditation, and this ancient-looking
              Łtattva$-system, see Intro \verify, and compare with 
              \VSS\ 4.72--73, and the similar teaching in \VSS\ 22.19--28
              and \DHARMP\ 4.5--14. ŁPāda$ e is unmetrical, or possibly an
              exceptional expansion of the \mutacumliquida, the
              syllable Łspha$° not turning the previous syllable long,
              and thus making the Łpāda$ a Łna-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>[Meditation on] the Sun, the Moon, Fire, Crystal and the subtle Łtattva$ as fifth.</TR>

<TEXT> sūryamaṇḍalam{ }ādau tu tattvaṃ prakṛtir{ }ucyate|</TEXT>
        <TR>First it is the Sun [that should be meditated upon], which is said to be Łprakṛti-tattva$.</TR>

%       mudhye \msNa
<TEXT> tasya madhye śaśiṃ dhyāyet{ }tattvaṃ puruṣa ucyate||</TEXT> 6:8
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śaśiṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; śaśi \msNb, śaśiṃn \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>dhyāyet{ }ta°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dhyāye ta° \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the thematised form Łśaśiṃ$ for Łśaśinaṃ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>He should visualize the Moon in its centre: that Łtattva$ is said to be Łpuruṣa$.</TR>

%index_grammar: -in -- -i (śaśi)

<TEXT> candramaṇḍalamadhye tu jvālām{ }agniṃ vicintayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>jvālām{ }agniṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; jālām{ }agni \msNc</APP>
        <TR>In the centre of the Moon's disk, he should visualise a flame, a fire.</TR>

<TEXT> prabhutattvaḥ sa vijñeyo janmamṛtyuvināśanaḥ||</TEXT> 6:9
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°tattvaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc; °tatva \msNa, °tatvaṃ \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°nāśanaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °nāśanam \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <TR> That is said to be Łprabhu$-Łtattva$, the destroyer of [the circle of] birth and death.</TR>

% stem form?
<TEXT> agnimaṇḍalamadhye tu dhyāyet{ }sphaṭika nirmalam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dhyāyet{ }sphaṭika</LEM> \msCapcorr\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; dhyāyet{ }sphaṭi \msCaacorr,
                                        dhyāye sphaṭika \msCc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°malam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\Ed; °malaḥ \msNa, °<UNCL>malaḥ</UNCL> \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ Łsphaṭika$ in Łpāda$ b metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>In the centre of the ring of Fire, he should visualize a spotless crystal.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

<TEXT> vidyātattvaḥ sa vijñeyaḥ kāraṇam{ }ajam{ }avyayam||</TEXT> 6:10
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tattvaḥ sa</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; ta<UNCL>tvan</UNCL>\lac\ × \msCa, tatva sa \msCc, tatvaṃ sa \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°jam{ }avyayam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °m{ }avyayaṃ \msCc</APP>
        <TR>That is said to be Łvidyā$-Łtattva$, the never-born, imperishable cause.</TR>

%index_metre: two laghus

<TEXT> vidyāmaṇḍalamadhye tu dhyāyet{ }tattvam{ }anuttamam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>dhyāyet{ }ta°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dhyāye ta° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>In the centre of the disk of Łvidyā$, he should visualize the highest Łtattva$,</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.600
<TEXT> akīrtitam{ }anaupamyaṃ śivam{ }akṣayam{ }avyayam|</TEXT>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\DHARMP\ 4.14ab: $ akīrtitam{ }anaupamyaṃ pañcamaṃ śivamaṇḍalam</PARAL>
        <TR>never-heard, unparalleled, undecaying and imperishable Śiva.</TR>

<TEXT> pañcamaṃ dhyānayajñasya tattvam{ }uktaṃ samāsataḥ||</TEXT> 6:11
        <APP>\ve <LEM>°yajñasya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °yajñañ{ }ca \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>samāsataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; sanātanaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The fifth Łtattva$ of the sacrifice through meditation has been taught in short.</TR>



<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> ekaikasya tu tattvasya phalaṃ kīrtaya kīdṛśam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tu</LEM> \conj; tri° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, hi \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The reading Łtritattvasya$ in Łpāda$ a in the MSS is a problem 
              because we have just finished a section mentioning five Łtattva$s. 
              (This was probably noticed by \Ed, hence printing Łhi$ for Łtri$°.)
              My conjecture (Łtu$) is based on the assumption that Łtri$ is ofter written as Łtṛ$ 
              in Nepalese MSS (e.g. in \msM\ at this point) and that Łtṛ$ may then easily get corrupted to Łtu$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Teach me, what are the fruits of [reaching] each Łtattva$?</TR>

<TEXT> kāni lokāḥ prapadyante kālaṃ vāsya tapodhana||</TEXT> 6:12
        <APP>\vc <LEM>lokāḥ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc; lokā \msCb\msCc\msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>prapadyante</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; pra\lk\lk\lk\ \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dhana</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °dhanaḥ \msCb\msNc</APP>
        <TR>Which worlds can be attained and how much time [can one spend there], O great ascetic?</TR>
        %                             lokāf \msCa

%index_anarthayajna_ref_as: tapodhana

% Look at Dharmaputrikā 4.1-4, which gives a similar list of dhyeyas and/or for the jīva        
<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> brahmalokaṃ tu prathamaṃ tattvaprakṛticintayā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>prathamaṃ tattva°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc; 
                                                    \om\ \msNaacorr, prathamaṃ tattvaṃ \Ed\oo
                  <LEM>prakṛticintayā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ca kṛticintaya \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łpāda$s ab as Łbrahmalokaṃ prathamatattvacintayā prakṛtitattvacintayā$. 
              One might take Łprathamaṃ$ adverbially (`firstly': Łprathamaṃ brahmalokaṃ prakṛtitattvacintayā$),
              but in the next verses, the ordinal numbers (Łdvitīyaṃ, tṛtīyaṃ, pañcamaṃ$)
              always refer to the Łtattva$s. ŁPāda$ a is a Łna-vipulā$ if the 
              muta cum liquid licence is applied and the syllable Łpra$° does not
              turn the previous syllable long.</NOTE>
        <TR>Through meditation on the first Łtattva$, Łprakṛti$, [one can reach] Brahmaloka.</TR>

%index_metre: pra muta cum liquida licence na-vipulā

<TEXT> kalpakoṭisahasrāṇi śivavan{ }modate sukhī||</TEXT> 6:13
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sukhī</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; sukham \Ed</APP>
        <TR>He will rejoice [there] happily like Śiva for millions of \ae ons.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 420.jpg f. 209v
<TEXT> dvitīyaṃ tattva puruṣaṃ dhyāyamāno mṛto yadi|</TEXT>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ Łtattva$ in Łpāda$ a metri causa (Łna-vipulā$).</NOTE>
        <TR>If one dies while meditating on the second Łtattva$, Łpuruṣa$,</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

<TEXT> viṣṇulokam{ }ito yāti kalpakoṭyayutaṃ sukhī||</TEXT> 6:14
        <APP>\vc <LEM>yāti</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yānti \Ed</APP>
        <TR>one will depart from this world and go to Viṣṇuloka, [and will dwell there] happily for billions of \ae ons.</TR>

<TEXT> prabhutattvaṃ tṛtīyaṃ tu dhyāyamāno mariṣyati|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°tattvaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °tatva \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>tṛtīyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tṛtīyas \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>dhyāyamāno mariṣyati</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dhyāya\lk\lk \lk riṣyati \msCa,
                                                        dhayāyāmāno mariṣyati \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Should one die while meditating on the third, the Łprabhu-tattva$,</TR>

% !! Narahari 
<TEXT> śivaloke vasen{ }nityaṃ kalpakoṭyayutaṃ śatam||</TEXT> 6:15
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śivaloke</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; śivaloka \msCb, rudraloke \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>vasen{ }ni°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vase ni° \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°yutaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °yuta \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>\Ed\ changes Łśivaloka$ to Łrudraloka$, probably for more contrast with
              Łsadāśiva$ in 6.16 and Łśivatattva$ in 6.17, but this is not
              Naraharinath's intervention since \msPaperA, a paper MS close to his sources,
              also reads Łrudraloka$ (on \msPaperA, see p.~\pageref{msPaperAdesc}).</NOTE>
        <TR>one can live in Śivaloka continuously for a hundred billion \ae ons.</TR>

<TEXT> vidyātattvāmṛtaṃ dhyāyet{ }sadāśivam{ }anāmayam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°tattvāmṛtaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °tatvamṛtan \msCc, °tattvāmataṃ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ a, Łamṛta$ is suspect. It may qualify the world of Sadāśiva (`immortal') and 
              then Łvidyātattva$ is in \stemform. Alternatively, since this verse is the only one in
              this list of worlds (6.13--17) without an ordinal number, Łamṛtaṃ$ may mean `four' or possibly `fourth,'
              as suggested by Monier-Williams and Apte in their dictionaries. This meaning would fit in nicely.
              In addition, dying has been mentioned above, thus Łamṛtaṃ$ might be a corrupted form of 
              a participle from the verbal root Łmṛ$ (Łmṛyan$ or Łmaran$?): e.g., 
              Łvidyātattvaṃ mṛyan dhyāyet$\dots\ (`should he meditation upon Vidyātattva while dying...').</NOTE>
        <TR>If one visualizes the nectar of Łvidyā-tattva$, [i.e.] Sadāśiva, 
                        one can reach [His] diseaseless,</TR>

<TEXT> akṣayaṃ lokam{ }āpnoti kalpānāntaparaṃ tathā|| </TEXT> 6:16
        <APP>\vc <LEM>akṣayaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; akṣaya° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>imperishable world [and can live there] well beyond endless \ae ons.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNc\ 221.jpg upper, f. 218v
<TEXT> pañcamaṃ śivatattvaṃ tu sūkṣmaṃ cātmani saṃsthitam|</TEXT>
        <TR>The fifth one, the subtle Łśiva-tattva$ dwells in the Self.</TR>

<TEXT> na kālasaṃkhyā tatrāsti śivena saha modate||</TEXT> 6:17
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ c is a Łma-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>There is no counting of time there and he will be rejoicing [there] together with Śiva.</TR>


<NOTANUSTUBH/> sragdharā
<LONGVERSELINES/>
%       -  -   - -  . -  -   . . .  .  .  . -  -  . -   - . -  -
<TEXT> pañcadhyānābhiyukto bhavati ca na punarjanmasaṃskārabandhaḥ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°yukto</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °yu\lk\ \msCa\ \toplost, °yuktau \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \om\ \msCb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>punarjanma°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 puna<UNCL>ja</UNCL>nma° \msCa\ \toplost, punajanma° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>[If] he practises the five meditations, there will be no 
                rebirth and no more fetters of transmigration.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 401.jpg
%       -  -  -  -    . -   -?  . . . . . . -    -   . - -  . -  -
<TEXT> jijñāsyantāṃ dvijendra bhavadahanakaraḥ prārthanākalpavṛkṣaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>jijñāsyantāṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNb\msNc\Ed; jijñāsyatāṃ \msCb\msNa\ \unmetr, jijñāsyantā \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note how a plural passive imperative form (Łjijñāsyantāṃ$) stands for the singular
                (Łjijñāsyatāṃ$) metri causa, or rather, since probably the five types of
                meditation are meant, the singulars in Łpāda$ b are somewhat
                out of context. Note also that the last syllable of
                Łdvijendra$ (at the c\ae sura) counts here as long: this phenomenon of a word-ending
                syllable becoming long by position is common in the \VSS\ (see p.~\pageref{short2long} ff).</NOTE>
        <TR>O excellent Brahmin, [the five meditation] should be learnt.
            [They] burn away existence, a wishing tree of desires.</TR>

%index_metre: long syllable at end of word at caesura

%       -  -! - - .  -  -      . . .  . .  .  -  - . -  - . - -
<TEXT> janmenaikena muktir{ }bhavati kimu na vā mānavāḥ sādhayantu</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>janmenaikena</LEM> \msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; janmanaikena \msCa\msCc\msNa\ \unmetr\oo
                 <LEM>muktir{ }bh°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; mukti bh° \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>na vā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; bhavā \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>mānavāḥ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; mānamānavāḥ \msCb, mānavā \msCc, mānava \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The non-standard Łjanmena$ in Łpāda$ d seems superior to Łjanmanā$ for it
               preserves the metre.</NOTE>
        <TR>Liberation will come within one single birth. Why should people not master [these meditations that]</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 201,jpg f. 279r
%folioinfo \msNa\ 204.jpg upper, f. 10v
%        -  -  -     - . - -   . . . . . . -    -  . -  - . - - 
<TEXT> pratyakṣān{ }nānumānaṃ sakalamalaharaṃ svātmasaṃvedanīyam||</TEXT> 6:18
        <APP>\vd <LEM>pratyakṣā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; pratyakṣa° \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°vedanīyam</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb; °vedanīyaḥ \msCa\msCc\msNc, °vedanīya \Ed</APP>
        <TR>destroy all impurities perceptibly, not only by inference,
            [since they] are to be experienced by one's own Self.</TR>


%folioinfo \msM\ breaks off at the end of 422.jpg upper, f. 10v, after °haraṃ, it resumes at the colophon of VSS 8 with 'aṣṭamaḥ'

<NORMALVERSELINES/>
<ANUSTUBH/>

<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣu tapaḥ (3)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Third Niyama-rule: penance</TRSUBCHAPTER>

% cf. Manu 12.3ff
<TEXT> mānasaṃ tapa ādau tu dvitīyaṃ vācikaṃ tapaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°tapa</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °tapam \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The first type of penance is mental penance, the second is verbal penance,</TR>

<TEXT> kāyikaṃ ca tṛtīyaṃ tu manovākkarma tatparam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>kāyikaṃ ca tṛtīyaṃ tu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                         mānasaṃ tapa ādau tu \msNb\ Ł(eyeskip)$ </APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>manovākkarma</LEM> \msCa\msNc\Ed; manokkarma \msCb, mmanovākarma° \msCc, manovākkāya° \msNa\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°param</LEM> \msCc; °paraḥ \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The reading Łmanovākkāya$° (\msNa\msNb) in Łpāda$ d is probably secondary, influenced by
              such common expressions as, e.g., Łmanovākkāyakarmabhiḥ$ in \YAJNS\ 1.27d.</NOTE>
        <TR>the third is the bodily one, the next one is the one which is [characterised by] 
                 both mental and verbal action.</TR>

<TEXT> kāyikaṃ vācikaṃ caiva tapo miśraka pañcamam||</TEXT> 6:19
        <APP>\ve <LEM>kāyikaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; kāyika \msNa</APP>
        <TR>The fifth type of penance is a mixture of the bodily and the verbal ones.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ Łmiśraka$ in Łpāda$ f metri causa.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

% saumya° ?
<TEXT> manaḥsaumyaṃ prasādaś{ }ca ātmanigraham{ }eva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°saumyaṃ</LEM> \msNc; °saumya° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed, °saum<UNCL>ya</UNCL>° \msCc\ \toplost\oo 
                 <LEM>prasādaś{ }ca</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc; prasādaṃ ca \msCb\Ed, pradānaś{ }ca \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Gentleness of the mind, calmness, self-control,</TR>

<TEXT> maunaṃ bhāvaviśuddhiś{ }ca pañcaitat{ }tapa mānasam||</TEXT> 6:20
        <APP>\vc <LEM>maunaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; mauna\lk  \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°śuddhiś{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °śuddhiṃ ca \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>pañcaitat</LEM> \msCa\msNb\msNc; pañcaite \msCb\msNa, pañcetat \msCc, pañcaitan \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\similar\ \MBH\ 6.39.16 (\BHG\ 17.16):$
                manaḥprasādaḥ saumyatvaṃ maunam{ }ātmavinigrahaḥ|
                bhāvasaṃśuddhir{ }ity{ }etat{ }tapo mānasam{ }ucyate||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Again, we can see the use of the singular (Łetat$) next to numbers; note also 
              the \stemform\ Łtapa$ in Łpāda$ d metri causa.
              This verse is a paraphrase of \MBH\ 3.39.16 (\BHG\ 17.16; see text in the
              apparatus).</NOTE>
        <TR>observing silence, and the purification of one's state of mind:
                        mental penance comprises these five.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa
%index_grammar: singular after numbers, Newari

<PAGEBREAK/>

% blurred lines in ed.:
<TEXT> anudvegakarā vāṇī priyaṃ satyaṃ hitaṃ ca yat|</TEXT>
        <TR>Verbal penance is taught as speech that causes no anxiety, which is kind, true and useful,</TR>

<TEXT> svādhyāyābhyasanaṃ caiva vācikaṃ tapa ucyate||</TEXT> 6:21
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°bhyasanaṃ caiva</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °bhyasana\lk\lk\ \msCa,
                                                                             °bhyasa<UNCL>naṃ</UNCL> caiva \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\similar\ \MBH\ 6.39.15cd (\BHG\ 17.15):$
                                 anudvegakaraṃ vākyaṃ satyaṃ priyahitaṃ ca yat|
                                 svādhyāyābhyasanaṃ caiva vāṅmayaṃ tapa ucyate||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>This verse is a variant of \MBH\ 6.39.15 (\BHG\ 17.15; see it in the apparatus).</NOTE>
        <TR>and it includes also the practice of recitation.</TR>


<TEXT> ārjavaṃ ca ahiṃsā ca brahmacaryaṃ surārcanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>ārjavaṃ ca ahiṃsā ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ārjavatvam{ }ahiṃsāś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°caryaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °carya \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>Bodily penance is taught as follows:</TR>

<TEXT> śaucaṃ pañcamam{ }ity{ }etat{ }kāyikaṃ tapa ucyate||</TEXT> 6:22
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śaucaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; śauca \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare\ \MBH\ 6.39.14 (\BHG\ 17.14):$
                         devadvijaguruprājñapūjanaṃ śaucam{ }ārjavam|
                         brahmacaryam{ }ahiṃsā ca śārīraṃ tapa ucyate||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>This verse seems to be a paraphrase of \MBH\ 6.39.14 (\BHG\ 17.14; see it in the apparatus).</NOTE>
        <TR>honesty, harmlessness, chastity, the worship of gods, and purity as the fifth.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 52.jpg lower 
<TEXT> iṣṭaṃ kalyāṇabhāvaṃ ca dhanyaṃ pathyaṃ hitaṃ vadet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>iṣṭaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; iṣṭa \msCc\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°bhāvaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °bhāvaś \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>pathyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; satyaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[Penance] which is a mixture of the mental [and the verbal] is
                 taught by the great sages to be these five:</TR>

<TEXT> manomiśraka pañcaitat{ }tapa uktaṃ maharṣibhiḥ||</TEXT> 6:23
        <APP>\vc <LEM>mano°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; mana° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>pañcaitat</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; pañcetat \msNc, pañcaitān \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>tapa uktaṃ maharṣibhiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tapam{ }uktaṃ mahirṣibhiḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the use of the singular (Łetat$) next to a number, and the \stemform\
              noun in Łpāda$ c.</NOTE>
        <TR>he should speak [about things that are] agreeable, of a noble character, virtuous, 
                                         salutary, and useful.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa
%index_grammar: singular after numbers

<TEXT> svasti maṅgalam{ }āśīrbhir{ }atithigurupūjanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°śīrbhi°</LEM> \msCa\Ed; °śībhi° \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°tithi°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °tithiṃ \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\compare\ \SDHS\ 11.79:$
                namaskārābhivādeṣu svastimaṅgalavācakaiḥ|
                śivaṃ bhavatu sarvatra prabrūyāt{ }sarvakarmasu||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>See \SDHS\ 11.73--79 (and <citep>SaivaUtopia</citep><pnum>91--93 and 120--121</pnum>) 
                                for a somewhat similar discussion on `kind speach.'</NOTE>
        <TR>[Penance] in which bodily [and verbal actions] mix is taught by the great-souled ones to be these five:</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.601
<TEXT> kāyamiśraka pañcaitat{ }tapa uktaṃ mahātmabhiḥ||</TEXT> 6:24
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°miśraka</LEM> \mssALL\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °\lk\lk ka \msCa, °mityaśraka \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>pañcaitat</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; pañcaitan \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tapa uktaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tapam{ }uktaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>benediction, greetings, blessings, and the worship of the guest and the guru.</TR>

<TEXT> maṇḍūkayogī hemante grīṣme pañcatapās{ }tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>grīṣme</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; gṛṣme \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\similar\ \MBH\ Suppl. 15.801:$
                                maṇḍūkaśāyī hemante grīṣme pañcatapā bhavet
                    Ł\similar\ \UMS\ 6.26ab:$maṇḍūkayogo hemante grīṣme pañcatapās{ }tathā;
                    Ł\compare\ \SDHSAMGR\ 9.32ab:$
                        abhrāvakāśyaṃ śītoṣṇe pañcāgnir{ }jalaśāyitā</PARAL>
%Nisv Mukha: śītātapāvakāśādi pañcāgnirjalaśāyitā|| 4.28||%
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$s a and c are Łma-vipulā$s.</NOTE>
        <NOTE>\Manu\ 6.23 mentions three kinds of penance that correspond to three seasons:
                <sep/>
                        Łgrīṣme pañcatapās tu syād varṣāsv abhrāvakāśikaḥ$ | <br/>
                        Łārdravāsās tu hemante kramaśo vardhayaṃs tapaḥ$ ||
                <sep/>
                Translated in <citep>OlivelleManu</citep><pnum>149</pnum> as:
                `[He should] surround himself with the five fires in the summer; live in the open air during the rainy season;
                  and wear wet clothes in the winter---gradually intensifying his ascetic toil.'
                  This and \SDHSAMGR\ 9.32ab (quoted in the apparatus) may suggest that being 
                  a `frog-yogin' could be the same as wearing wet clothes or standing in water for a long time.
                A footnote to \MBH\ 12.309.9 in the Kumbakonam edition of the 
                \MBH\ (<cite>MBhKumbakonaEd</cite>) suggests otherwise:
                Łmaṇḍūkavat pāṇipādaṃ saṅkocya nyubjaḥ śete iti maṇḍūkaśāyī$. (`The word `frog-sleeper' means
                somebody who sleeps like a frog, with his hands and feet withdrawn and with his back humped.') </NOTE>
        <TR>[Being] a [so-called] frog-yogin in the winter, or one with the five fires in the summer,</TR>

%purana/mahAbhAratam/kumbhakonam/13/010.md-avaak"siraastu yo lambedudavaasa.m ca yo vaset ।      kk-13-01-010-011a  
%purana/mahAbhAratam/kumbhakonam/13/010.md:ma.n.duuka"saayii ca naro labhate cepsitaa.m gatim ॥  kk-13-01-010-011c  

<TEXT> abhrāvakāśo varṣāsu tapaḥsādhanam{ }ucyate||</TEXT> 6:25
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vakāśo</LEM> \eme; °vakāśe \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tapa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; tapa \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>sādhanam{ }u°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; sādhana u° \msCb\msCc\msNb</APP>
        <TR>or having the clouds [i.e. the open sky] for shelter in the rainy season:
                         these are called accomplishments of penance.</TR>

<TEXT> svamāṃsoddhṛtya dānaṃ ca hastapādaśiras{ }tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; <UNCL>dāna</UNCL> \msNb\ \toplost, dānaś \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ Łsvamāṃsa$ in Łpāda$ a for the accusative.</NOTE>
        <TR>Carving out his own flesh as a donation, or 
                [offering his own] hand, feet and head,</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form

<TEXT> puṣpam{ }utpādya dānaṃ{ }ca sarve te tapasādhanāḥ||</TEXT> 6:26
        <APP>\vc <LEM>dānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dānaś \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tapa°</LEM> \Ed; tapaḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\ \unmetr</APP>
        <NOTE>The translation of Łpāda$ c is tentative, but Łpuṣpa$ as `blood' does 
              occur in tantric texts (see, e.g., \SYM\ 16.49). \VSS\ 17.37--38 teaches
              blood donation:
        <sep/>
                        Łdevī uvāca$ |<br/>
                        Łsvamāṃsarudhiraṃ dānaṃ dānaṃ putrakalatrayoḥ$ |<br/>
                        Łkiṃ praśasyaṃ mahādeva tattvaṃ vaktum ihārhasi$ ||<br/>
                        Łmaheśvara uvāca$ |<br/>
                        Łsvamāṃsarudhiraṃ dānaṃ praśaṃsanti manīṣiṇaḥ$ |<br/>
                        Łśrūyatāṃ pūrvavṛttāni saṃkṣipya kathayāmy aham$ ||
        <sep/>
                        `Devī spoke: Are one's own flesh and blood and one's son and wife praised as donation,
                         O Mahādeva?  Tell me the truth please.
                         Maheśvara spoke: The wise praise one's own flesh and blood as donation.
                         Let's hear the old legends, I shall tell you briefly.'</NOTE>
        <TR>or drawing [his own] blood (Łpuṣpa$) as a donation: all these are accomplishments of penance,</TR>

<TEXT> kṛcchrātikṛcchraṃ naktaṃ ca taptakṛcchram{ }ayācitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kṛcchrātikṛcchraṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed;
                                         kṛcchrādikṛcchra \msCc, kṛcchrātikṛcchra \msNb, kṛcchātikṛcchaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°yācitam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °yācitaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is a Łma-vipulā$s.</NOTE>
        <TR>[as also] the `painful penance' and the `extremely paniful one', [eating only] at night,
                 the `hot and painful' and [the one in which only food obtained] without
                 solicitation [can be eaten],</TR>

<TEXT> cāndrāyaṇaṃ parākaṃ ca tapaḥ sāṃtapanādayaḥ||</TEXT> 6:27
        <APP>\vc <LEM>cāndrāyaṇaṃ parākaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc; cāndrāyanaṃ parākaṃ \msCb, 
                                                        candrāyaṇaṃ parākaṃ \msNa, cāndrāyaṇavarākaś \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>tapaḥ sāṃtapanādayaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; tapasāntapanādayaḥ \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>For short descriptions and the loci classici of these penances, see, e.g.,
                 <citep>KaneHistory</citep><pnum>v. 4, 130--152</pnum>.
              For Łnakta$/Łnaktānna$, see \VSS\ 8.22 below and, e.g., 
              \SDHS\ chapter 10 (<cite>SDhS10_ed</cite>), and for Łayācita$, \VSS\ 8.23 below.</NOTE>
        <TR>the Łcāndrāyaṇa$ and Łparāka$ penances, the Łsāṃtapana$, etc.</TR>



<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<LONGVERSELINES/>
%                        sumanasā?
%       - - -   . .  -  . -  . . . -   -  - . -   -   . -
<TEXT> yenedaṃ tapa tapyate sumanasā saṃsāraduḥkhacchidam</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tapa ta°</LEM> \Ed; tapas{ }ta° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\ \unmetr\oo
                 <LEM>°manasā</LEM> \eme; °manasaḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note my emendation in Łpāda$ a (Łsumanasā$ from Łsumanasaḥ$) and that
              in order to restore the metre, I accepted \Ed's \stemform\ Łtapa$.</NOTE>
        <TR>He who performs with a well-disposed mind this penance that puts
                 an end to the suffering caused by transmigration (Łsaṃsāra$),</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

%      - - - .  . -  .  -  . . . -      -   -  . -     -    . -
<TEXT> āśāpāśa vimucya nirmalamatis{ }tyaktvā jaghanyaṃ phalam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>nirmalamati°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; nirmalarmati° \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>jaghanyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; jagat{ }yaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ °Łpāśa$ in Łpāda$ b metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>abandoning the trap of hope, with a spotless mind, giving up the lowest rewards</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

<TEXT> svargākāṅkṣyanṛpatvabhogaviṣayaṃ sarvāntikaṃ tatphalaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°kāṅkṣya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °kāṃkṣa° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>sarvāntikaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sarvārttikaṃ \msCb</APP>
        <TR>[such as] wishing for heaven and being a king and having enjoyments for the senses,
               that man will experience the ultimate (Łsarvāntika$) reward that</TR>

<TEXT> jantuḥ śāśvatajanmamṛtyubhavane tanniṣṭhasādhyaṃ vahet||</TEXT> 6:28
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°bhavane</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °bhavene \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°sādhyaṃ vahet</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °<UNCL>sādhyam</UNCL>\lk\lk\ \msCa, 
                                                  °sādhya vahet \msCb, °sādhyaṃ vadet \Ed</APP>
        <TR>in this home of eternal births and deaths accomplishes their cessation.</TR>

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> <COLOPHON>iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe ṣaṣṭho 'dhyāyaḥ</COLOPHON></TEXT>
        <TRCOLOPHON>Here ends the sixth chapter in the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$.</TRCOLOPHON>
% sic in \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc
%END OF CHAPTER 6

<NORMALVERSELINES/>

<startchapter-n="7"/>
%chapter 7
%folioinfo \msCa\ 401.jpg, f.203r line 6
%folioinfo \msCb\ 420.jpg, f.209v line 6
%folioinfo \msCc\ 201.jpg, f.279r line 5
%folioinfo \msNa\ 204.jpg upper, f.10v
%folioinfo \msNb\ 52.jpg lower
%folioinfo \msNc\ 221.jpg upper line 6, f. 218v
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.601
<ANUSTUBH/>
<CHAPTER>saptamo 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>
<TRCHAPTER> Chapter Seven </TRCHAPTER>


<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣu dānam (4)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Fourth Niyama-rule: donation</TRSUBCHAPTER>

% tathaivāhuḥ?
<TEXT> dānāni ca tathety{ }āhuḥ pañcadhā munibhiḥ purā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tathety{ }āhuḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; tathaity{ }āhuḥ \msCb\msNa</APP>
        <LACUNA>ŁWitnesses used for this chapter: \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 203r--204r,
                                              \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 209v--210v,
                                              \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 279r--280v,
                                              \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 10v--11v,
                                              \msNb\ exp.\thinspace 52 (lower--upper) -- 53 (lower),
                                              \msNc\ ff.\thinspace 218v--219v,
                                              \Ed\ pp.\thinspace 601--603;
                                              \mssCaCbCc\ = \msCa + \msCb + \msCc$</LACUNA>
        <TR>In the past the wise declared that, again, there were five kinds of donation.</TR>

<TEXT> annaṃ vastraṃ hiraṇyaṃ ca bhūmi godāna pañcamam||</TEXT> 7:1
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vastraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; vastra \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Łtathety$ in Łpāda$ a is suspicious and my translation of it (`again') is tentative and
                        is supposed to refer back to the fact that all Łyama$s so far have been 
                        devided into five types.  Note how Łannaṃ$, Łvastraṃ$, Łhiraṇyaṃ$ and 
                        Łbhūmi$ (the latter treated as neuter, or given in \stemform) 
                        are all meant to go with °Łdāna$ (again, in \stemform, metri causa).</NOTE>
        <TR>Donation of food, clothes, gold, land, and the fifth, donation of cows.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

% godāna and bhūmidāna and vastradāna in ŚDhŚ 12.41ff CHECK \verify



<SUBSUBCHAPTER>annadānam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Donation of food</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 421.jpg, f.210r
<TEXT> annāt{ }tejaḥ smṛtiḥ prāṇaḥ annāt{ }puṣṭir{ }vapuḥ sukham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>annāt{ }tejaḥ smṛtiḥ prāṇaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb; annāt{ }tejaḥ smṛtiḥ prāṇa \msNaacorr, 
                                                        annāt{ }tejaḥ smṛti prāṇaḥ \msNc,
                                                        annād{ }bhavanti bhūtāni \Ed</APP>
        <TR>From food [come] energy, memory, the vital breath, growth, body, happiness.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 202.jpg, f.279v 
%folioinfo \msNc\ 221.jpg lower, f. 219r
<TEXT> annāc{ }chrīḥ kānti vīryaṃ ca annāt{ }sattvaṃ ca jāyate||</TEXT> 7:2
        <APP>\vc <LEM>annāc{ }chrīḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; annāc{ }chrī \msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>kānti vīryaṃ ca</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb; kāntir{ }vīryañ{ }ca \msCa\msNc\ \unmetr, 
                                                                        kāntivīrśyañ{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>annāt{ }sattvaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                         annā satvañ{ }ca \msCc, annāt{ }sattvaś{ }ca \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>jāyate</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; jāya\lk\  \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ noun Łkānti$ metri causa in Łpāda$ c.</NOTE>
        <TR>From food arise grace and beauty, heroism, strength.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

%folioinfo \msCa\ 402.jpg
<TEXT> annāj{ }jīvanti bhūtāni annaṃ tuṣṭikaraṃ sadā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>annāj{ }jī°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\Ed; annā jī° \msCb\msCc\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>annaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; annāṃ \msCc, annā \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°karaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °karaḥ \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>Living beings live on food. Food always satisfies.</TR>

%\msCa\ darpaḥ'
<TEXT> ānnāt{ }kāmo mado darpaḥ annāc{ }chauryaṃ ca jāyate||</TEXT> 7:3
        <APP>\vc <LEM>darpaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb; darppa \msCb\msNc, darppo \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>annāc{ }chauryaṃ ca</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNc; annāt{ }sauryañ{ }ca \msCb\msNa\msNb,
                                                                 annāc{ }chauryaś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <TR>From food arise desire, rapture, pride, and valour.</TR>

<TEXT> annaṃ kṣudhātṛṣāvyādhīn{ }sadya eva vināśayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>annaṃ kṣu°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNapcorr\msNc; annā kṣu° \msCc\msNaacorr, annāt{ }kṣu° \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°vyādhīn{ }sa°</LEM> \msCb\msNc; °vyādhān{ }sa° \msCa\msCc\msNb, °vādhān{ }sa° \msNa,
                                                                                        °vyādhā sa° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vināśayet</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; viśayet \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Food drives away hunger and thirst and disease instantly.</TR>

<TEXT> annadānāc{ }ca saubhāgyaṃ khyātiḥ kīrtiś{ }ca jāyate||</TEXT> 7:4
        <TR>From donations of food arise beauty, fame, and glory.</TR>

<TEXT> annadaḥ prāṇadaś{ }caiva prāṇadaś{ }cāpi sarvadaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>annadaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; annada \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>prāṇadaś{ }cāpi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; prāṇaś{ }cāpi \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>sarvadaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sarvadāḥ \msCc</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\similar\ \SDHU\ 1.27:$
                annadaḥ prāṇadaḥ proktaḥ prāṇadaś{ }cāpi sarvadaḥ|
                tasmād{ }annapradānena sarvadānaphalaṃ labhet||
                \similar\ Ł\MBH\ suppl 14.4.2285--86:$
                annadaḥ prāṇado loke prāṇadaḥ sarvado bhavet|
                tasmād{ }annaṃ viśeṣeṇa dātavyaṃ bhūtim{ }icchatā||
                  \similar\ Ł\NARADAP\ 1.13.71:$
                annadaḥ prāṇadaḥ proktaḥ prāṇadaś{ }cāpi sarvadaḥ|
                sarvadānaphalaṃ yasmād{ }annadasya nṛpottama||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>See some similar verses from the \SDHU, the \MBH, and the \NARADAP\ in
              the apparatus.</NOTE>
        <TR>He who donates food donates life. He who donates life donates everything.</TR>
% 02sdhu/sivadharmottara_b.dn:  2524:  annadaḥ prāṇadaḥ proktaḥ prāṇadaś cāpi sarvadaḥ|^M

% CHECK Haracaritacintāmaṇi 30.50ff and ŚDhu 7.27 etc.!
% Also MBh! 

%folioinfo \msNa\ 204.jpg lower, f.11r
<TEXT> tasmād{ }annasamaṃ dānaṃ na bhūtaṃ na bhaviṣyati||</TEXT> 7:5
        <APP>\vd <LEM>bhūtaṃ</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \lac × tan \msCa, bhūte \msCb, bhūto \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł = \SDHU\ 7.31cd \similar\ \MBH\ 13.62.6ab: 
                                        $annena sadṛśaṃ dānaṃ na bhūtaṃ na bhaviṣyati</PARAL>
        <TR>Therefore nothing is equal to the donation of food, nothing was, nothing will be.</TR>




<SUBSUBCHAPTER>vastradānam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Donation of clothes</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

%                               means śriyam api? kriyām api?
<TEXT> vastrābhāvān{ }manuṣyasya śriyād{ }api parityajet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°bhāvān{ }ma°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\Ed; °bhāvāt{ }ma° \msNa\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śriyād{ }api</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; priyād{ }api \msCb, śriyā vāpi \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ b is difficult to interpret securely. I translate it as if reading
              Łśrīs tam api parityajet$ or Łśriyāpi parityajyate$. Consider also \BRAHMAP\ 220.139:
              <sep/>
                         Łvastrābhāve kriyā nāsti yajñā vedās tapāṃsi ca$ |<br/>
                         Łtasmād vāsāṃsi deyāni śrāddhakāle viśeṣataḥ$ ||
              <sep/>
                        `If one has no clothes, there is no ritual, no worship, no Vedas or penance.
                         Therefore clothes should be donated, especially at the time
                         of a Śrāddha ritual.'</NOTE>
        <TR>In the absence of [proper] clothes, a man will also lose his fortunes.</TR>

<TEXT> vastrahīno na pūjyeta bhāryāputrasakhādibhiḥ||</TEXT> 7:6
        <TR>A person without clothes may not be respected by his wife, son, friends, etc.</TR>

<TEXT> vidyāvān{ }sukulīno 'pi jñānavān{ }guṇavān{ }api|</TEXT>
        <TR>Be it a learned person from a good family or an intelligent and virtuous person,</TR>

<TEXT> vastrahīnaḥ parādhīnaḥ paribhūtaḥ pade pade||</TEXT> 7:7
        <TR>without clothes everybody is subdued and humiliated on every occasion</TR>

<TEXT> apamānam{ }avajñāṃ ca vastrahīno hy{ }avāpnuyāt|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°vajñāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °vajñaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°hīno</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °hī \msCb</APP>
        <TR>because a man without clothes receives contempt and disrespect.</TR>

<TEXT> jugupsati mahātmāpi sabhāstrījanasaṃsadi||</TEXT> 7:8
        <TR>Even if he is a great soul, he will wish to avoid the court, women, and the assembly.</TR>

<TEXT> tasmād{ }vastrapradānāni praśaṃsanti manīṣiṇaḥ|</TEXT>
        <TR>Therefore the wise praise donations of clothes.</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.602
<TEXT> na jīrṇaṃ sphuṭitaṃ dadyād{ }vastraṃ kutsitam{ }eva vā||</TEXT> 7:9
        <APP>\vc <LEM>jīrṇaṃ sphuṭitaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; jīrṇasphaṭitaṃ \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kutsitam{ }eva vā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; kutsitam{ }eva ca \msCc, kutsitmeva vā \msNc</APP>
        <TR>One should not give away old, torn or dirty clothes.</TR>

<TEXT> navaṃ purāṇarahitaṃ mṛdu sūkṣmaṃ suśobhanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sūkṣmaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; sūkṣma \msCc, śuklaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[Clothes] should be donated [only if they are] new, not worn,
                 soft, delicate and beautiful,</TR>
% ŚDhŚ 4 (maybe not in the Nepalese MSS; \msCa\ seems to read °ṇasahitan): CHECK
% atra tatra gataḥ kuryāḥ puṇyaṃ śaileṣṭakāmayam |
% navaṃ purāṇarahitaṃ tasyāṃ kuryāchivālayam ||

<TEXT> susaṃskṛtya pradātavyaṃ śraddhābhaktisamanvitam||</TEXT> 7:10
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dātavyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dātavya \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°samanvitam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed; °taṃ \msNaacorr</APP>
        <TR>nicely ornamented, and in good faith and with devotion.</TR>
% Brick ? on śraddhā in dāna, also mīmāṃsā stuff?
% tr. as 'in good faith'? (Kengo) CHECK

<TEXT> śraddhāsattvaviśeṣeṇa deśakālavidhena ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°sattva°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °sa ca° \Ed</APP>

<TEXT> pātradravyaviśeṣeṇa phalam{ }āhuḥ pṛthak{ }pṛthak||</TEXT> 7:11
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare\ \MANU\ 7.86--87 (the latter usually labelled as an additional verse):$
                        pātrasya hi viśeṣeṇa śraddadhānatayāiva ca| 
                        alpaṃ vā bahu vā pretya dānasya phalam{ }aśnute||
                        deśakālavidhānena dravyaṃ śraddhāsamanvitam|
                        pātre pradīyate yat{ }tu tad{ }dharmasya prasādhanam||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>It seems that Łvidhena ca$ stands for Łvidhinā ca$ or rather Łvidhānena$ metri causa in Łpāda$ b.</NOTE>
        <TR>They say that the reward [of donation/generosity] is in every case dependent on the
                particular [donor's] willingness and character, the choice of place and time, and on
                the particular recipient and material.</TR>

<TEXT> yādṛśaṃ dīyate vastraṃ tādṛśaṃ prāpyate phalam|</TEXT>
        <TR>The reward received will be similar to the clothes donated.</TR>

<TEXT> jīrṇavastrapradānena jīrṇavastram{ }avāpnuyāt|</TEXT>
        <TR>By donating old clothes, one would receive old clothes [as a reward].</TR>

<TEXT> śobhanaṃ dīyate vastraṃ śobhanaṃ vastram{ }āpnuyāt||</TEXT> 7:12
        <APP>\vef <LEM!>śobhanaṃ dīyate vastraṃ śobhanaṃ vastram{ }āpnuyāt</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                                                 \om\ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>By donating beautiful clothes, one would receive beautiful clothes [as a reward].</TR>


<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<LONGVERSELINES/>
%folioinfo \msNb\ 52.jpg upper
%       -  -     -   .  . -  . -    . . . -  - -  .  -  - . -
<TEXT> dadyād{ }vastra suśobhanaṃ dvijavare kāle śubhe sādaraṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dvijavare kāle śubhe</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dvijayine ekāśubhaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ Łvastra$ in Łpāda$ a metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>Should one bestow very beautiful clothes on a Brahmin 
                        at an auspicious time, respectfully,</TR>
        <NOTE>`on a Brahmin' (in Łpāda$ a): literally, `on a person who is first among the twice-born'
                                (Łdvijavare$).</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa
%index_metre: śārdūlavikrīḍita

%        -  -  -!   . . -   .  - .  .  . -  - -   .  -  -  . -
<TEXT> saubhāgyam{ }atulaṃ labheta sa naro rūpaṃ tathā śobhanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>naro</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; daro \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>The final syllable of Łsaubhāgyam$ in Łpāda$ b counts as long by licence; see, e.g., 5.20 and 6.18b.
              This time the c\ae sura is not involved.</NOTE>
        <TR>he [i.e. the donor] will receive unequalled attractiveness and a beautiful appearance.</TR>

%index_metre: long syllable at end of word 
%index_metre: śārdūlavikrīḍita

<TEXT> tasmin{ }yāti suvastrakoṭi śataśaḥ prāpnoti niḥsaṃśayaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tasmin{ }yāti</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; ta<UNCL>smā</UNCL>n{ }yāti \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>suvastra°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; sa vastra° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°saṃśayam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc; °saṃśayaḥ \msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łtasmin yāti$ in Łpāda$ c as Łtasmin yāte$ (metri causa);
             °Łkoṭi$ is treated as neuter or as a \stemform\ (also metri causa).</NOTE>
        <TR>When he departs, he will be given hundreds of millions of items of nice clothes, no doubt about that.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa (or neuter)
%index_metre: śārdūlavikrīḍita

<TEXT> tasmāt{ }tvaṃ kuru vastradānam{ }asakṛt{ }pāratrikotkarṣaṇam||</TEXT> 7:13
        <APP>\vd <LEM>dānam{ }asakṛt{ }pā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; dānasat{ }pā° \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Therefore do donate clothes often. It is the way up to the other world.</TR>

%index_metre: śārdūlavikrīḍita


<NORMALVERSELINES/>

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>suvarṇadānam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Donation of gold</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> suvarṇadānaṃ viprendra saṃkṣipya kathayāmy{ }aham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °dāna \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <TR>O great Brahmin, now I shall teach you about the donation of gold in a concise manner.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<TEXT> pavitraṃ maṅgalaṃ puṇyaṃ sarvapātakanāśanam||</TEXT> 7:14
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°pātaka°</LEM>  \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °pāpaka° \msCa</APP>
        <TR>It is a pure, auspicious and meritorious [act] and it washes off all sins.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 203.jpg, f.280r
<TEXT> dhārayet{ }satataṃ vipra suvarṇakaṭakāṅgulim|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kaṭakāṅgulim</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °ka\lk\lk gulim \msCa, °kaṭakāṅgulam \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>I suspect that Łaṅguli$ is used in Łpāda$ b in the sense of Łaṅgulīya$ (`finger-ring').</NOTE>
        <TR>Should one always wear a golden bracelet or ring, O Brahmin,</TR>

<TEXT> mucyate sarvapāpebhyo rāhuṇā candramā yathā||</TEXT> 7:15
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł= 22.38 below = a line inserted after \MBH\ 1.56.18 in some manuscripts as indicated in 
                    the critical edition$</PARAL>
        <TR>he will be freed of all sins, just as the moon is freed from [the demon] Rāhu [after an eclipse].</TR>
% CHECK if all MSS actually read rāhunā

<TEXT> dattvā suvarṇaṃ viprebhyo devebhyaś{ }ca dvijarṣabha|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>suvarṇaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; suvarṇa \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°rṣabha</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °rṣabhaḥ \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is a Łma-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>If a person donates gold to Brahmins or gods, O excellent Brahmin,</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<TEXT> tuṭimātre 'pi yo dadyāt{ }sarvapāpaiḥ pramucyate||</TEXT> 7:16
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tuṭi°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; truṭi° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°mātre</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; °mātro \msNa\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>sarvapāpaiḥ pramucyate</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                 sarvapāpaiḥ sa mucyate \msCa, sarvapāpai pramucyate \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The form Łtuṭi$ as a widespread variant of Łtruṭi$, see, e.g., (Old) \SKANDAP\ 27.14:
               <sep/>
               Łkāñcanaṃ tuṭimātraṃ vā yo dadyād bahu vā mama$ | <br/>
               Łtasya haimavate śṛṅge dadāni gṛham uttamam$ ||</NOTE>
        <TR>even if it is only in a minute quantity, he will be freed of all sins.</TR>

<PAGEBREAK/>

% units of measure:
<TEXT> raktimāṣakakarṣaṃ vā palārdhaṃ palam{ }eva vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>raktimāṣaka°</LEM> \msNcacorr; rantimāṣaka° \msCa, rattimāṣaka° \msCb\msNa\msNcpcorr, 
                                                        rantimmānsaka° \msCc, rattimānsaka° \msNb, rattimāṣaka° \Ed </APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°rdhaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; °ddha \msCc\msNa\msNb</APP>
        <TR>[The amount can be just] one Łrakti$, a Łmāṣaka$, a Łkarṣa$, half a Łpala$ or a Łpala$:</TR>
% raktikā  f. Abrus Precatorius (its seed or grain is used as a weight = 1/6, 1/7, or 2/15 Māṣaka), ŚārṅgS.
% karṣa  mn. a weight of gold or silver (= 16 Māṣas = 80 Rettis = 1/4 Pala = 1/400 of a Tulā = about 176 grains troy
 in common use 8 Rettis are given to the Māṣa, and the Karṣa is then about 280 grains troy), Suśr.


<TEXT> evam{ }eva phalaṃvṛddhir{ }jñeyā dānaviśeṣataḥ||</TEXT> 7:17
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°vṛddhir{ }jñeyā</LEM> \msCa\Ed; °vṛddhi jñeyā \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb, °vṛrddhi jñeyā \msNc</APP>
        <TR>this is exactly how the increase in the [size of the corresponding] reward will be, 
                                in proportion to the properties [i.e.\ amount] of the donation.</TR>
        <NOTE>I suspect that Łphalaṃ vṛddhir$, or Łphalaṃvṛddhir$, stands for 
              Łphalavṛddhir$ (Łphalasya vṛddhiḥ$) metri causa, meaning `the increase of the reward.'
              Łrakti$, Łmāṣaka$, Łkarṣa$, and Łpala$ are units of weight.</NOTE>





<SUBSUBCHAPTER>bhūmidānam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Donation of land</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> sarvādhāraṃ mahīdānaṃ praśaṃsanti manīṣiṇaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dhāraṃ</LEM> \msCb; °dhāra° \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°dānaṃ praśaṃsanti</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 dā\lk <UNCL>nam{ }pra</UNCL>\lac × santi \msCa</APP>
        <TR>The wise praise the donation of land as the basis of everything [else].</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 403.jpg, f.204r
<TEXT> annavastrahiraṇyādi sarvaṃ vai bhūmisambhavam||</TEXT> 7:18
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sarvaṃ vai</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sarvaṃ <UNCL>ve</UNCL> \msCa\ \toplost</APP>
        <TR>Food, clothes, gold etc., all these originate in land.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNc\ 222.jpg upper, f. 219v
<TEXT> bhūmidānena viprendra sarvadānaphalaṃ labhet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°phalaṃ labhet</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNbpcorr\Ed;
                                                 °lalaṃ bhavet \msNbacorr, °laṃ bhavet \msNc</APP>
        <TR>O Brahmin, one can obtain all the rewards of donation by donating land.</TR>

<TEXT> bhūmidānasamaṃ vipra yady{ }asti vada tattvataḥ||</TEXT> 7:19
        <TR>If there is anything that equals the donation of land, O Brahmin, you should definitely tell me.</TR>

<TEXT> mātṛkukṣivimuktas{ }tu dharaṇīśaraṇo bhavet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°muktas{ }tu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °muktis{ }tu \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°śaraṇo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; °śaraṇa \msNc, °śaraṇāṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[Humans] have the earth as their abode as soon as they get out of the mother's womb.</TR>

<TEXT> carācarāṇāṃ sarveṣāṃ bhūmiḥ sādhāraṇā smṛtā||</TEXT> 7:20
        <NOTE>I take Łsādhāraṇā$ as one word, but it is possible that the intention of the author
                        was Łsā dhāraṇā$ in two words, in fact meaning Łsādhāraḥ$ (Łsā ādhāraḥ$, `it is the basis').</NOTE>
        <TR>Land is said to be common to all that are mobile and immobile.</TR>

<TEXT> ekahastaṃ dvihastaṃ vā pañcāśac{ }chatam{ }eva vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>ekahastaṃ</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; ekahasta° \msCa\msCc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>Be it [only a land of] one forearm, two forearms, fifty or a hundred,</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 205.jpg upper, f.11v
<TEXT> sahasrāyutalakṣaṃ vā bhūmidānaṃ praśasyate||</TEXT> 7:21
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>bhūmidānaṃ praśasyate</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; bhūmidāna praśasyate \msCb, 
                        pañcāśac{ }chatam{ }eva vā| sahāyutalakṣam{ }vā bhūmidaṃ praśasyate \msNb\ Ł(eyeskip)$</APP>
        <TR>a thousand, ten thousand, a hundred thousand, donation of land is held in great esteem.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 422.jpg, f.210v
<TEXT> ekahastāṃ ca yo bhūmiṃ dadyād{ }dvijavarāya tu|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°hastāṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °hastañ{ }ca \msCb\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dadyād{ }dvi°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dadyā dvi° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>He who donates [as much as] a piece of land of one forearm to a Brahmin</TR>

<TEXT> varṣakoṭiśataṃ divyaṃ svargaloke mahīyate||</TEXT> 7:22
        <TR>will enjoy a billion divine years in heaven.</TR>

<TEXT> evaṃ bahuṣu hasteṣu guṇāguṇi phalaṃ smṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>guṇāguṇi°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; guṇāgaṇi° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I think that Łguṇāguṇi$, or perhaps Łguṇaguṇi$ (which would be unmetrical, containing
                        two Łlaghu$s in both the second and third syllables of the Łpāda$), should refer to the idea
                        that, e.g., the donation of a piece of land of 2 × 2 Łhasta$s would result in 
                        twice, or four times, Łkoṭiśata$ years in heaven, Łguṇa$ generally meaning `times.' 
                        I take Łguṇā$° as referring to the size of the land donated, and °Łguṇi$[Łn$] as 
                        `amounting to that many times,' but this is only a guess, 
                        and it would need to be supported by some similar passage, other than 7.17 above.</NOTE>
        <TR>Thus in case of [donating] many forearms [of land], the reward is said to be 
                        proportional to the properties [of the land].</TR>

<TEXT> śraddhādhikaṃ phalaṃ dānaṃ kathitaṃ te dvijottama||</TEXT> 7:23
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dhikaṃ</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb; °dhika° \msCa\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °ttamaḥ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>O Brahmin, I have taught you about the rewards of donation that is made in good faith.</TR>
        <NOTE><sep/>
                I suspect that Łpāda$ c is an awkward attempt at saying Łśraddhādhikadāna(sya) phalaṃ$.</NOTE>

%index_syntax: split compound in pāda c

<PAGEBREAK/>

% rāmena \msCc\msNa\msNb
<TEXT> jāmadagnyena rāmeṇa bhūmiṃ dattvā dvijāya vai|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>jāmadagnyena</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNc; jāmadagnye\lk\ \msCa, jāmadagnena \msCc\msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>rāmeṇa</LEM> \msCb\msNc\Ed; \lk\lk ṇa \msCa, rāmena \msCc\msNa\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dattvā dvi°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dadyād{ }dvi° \msCb</APP>
        <TR>[Paraśu]rāma, the son of Jamadagni, having donated land to the Brahmin [Kaśyapa],</TR>
        <NOTE>See a summary of the corresponding episodes in the \MBH\ in 
                    <citep>PuranicEnc</citep><pnum>570--571</pnum>, s.v. Paraśurāma:
                <sep/>
                                `To atone for the sin of slaughtering even
                                innocent Kṣatriyas, Paraśurāma gave away all his
                                riches as gifts to brahmins. He invited all the brahmins
                                to Samantapañcaka and conducted a great Yāga there.
                                The chief Ṛtvik (officiating priest) of the Yāga was
                                the sage Kaśyapa and Paraśurāma gave all the lands
                                he conquered till that time to Kaśyapa. Then a platform 
                                of gold ten yards long and nine yards wide was
                                made and Kaśyapa was installed there and worshipped.
                                After the worship was over according to the instructions
                                from Kaśyapa the gold platform was cut into pieces
                                and the gold pieces were offered to brahmins.

                                When Kaśyapa got all the lands from Paraśurāma he
                                said thus:---``Oh Rāma, you have given me all your
                                land and it is not now proper for you to live in my
                                soil. You can go to the south and live somewhere on
                                the shores of the ocean there.'' Paraśurāma walked
                                south and requested the ocean to give him some land to
                                live.'</NOTE>

<TEXT> āyur{ }akṣayam{ }āptaṃ tu ihaiva ca dvijottama||</TEXT> 7:24
        <APP>\vd <LEM>ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; hi \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE><sep/>
              Note that without applying the \mutacumliquida\ (Łca dvi$°), 
              Łpāda$ d would be iambic and thus metrically problematic.</NOTE>
        <TR>obtained eternal life in this very world, O excellent Brahmin.</TR>

%index_grammar: iambic, but not with dvi muta cum liquida licence
%index_metre: muta cum liquida dv


%folioinfo \Ed\ p.603

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>godānam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Donation of cows</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

%lacuna_start: msNb
% unmetr 
<TEXT> hemaśṛṅgāṃ raupyakṣurāṃ cailaghaṇṭāṃ dvijottama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°śṛṅgāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; °śṛṅgaṃ \msNa, \om\ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>raupya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; ropyaṃ \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°kṣurāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; °khurāṃ \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vab ŁOmitted in \msNb$</LACUNA>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\similar\ \VAGMATI\ 17.33ab:$
                        hemaśṛṅgāṃ raupyakhurāṃ cailaghaṇṭāvalambinīm|</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Łkṣura$ in Łpāda$ a is a known variant of the better-attested Łkhura$.
              ŁPāda$ a is unmetrical.</NOTE>
        <TR>[A cow] with golden horns, silver hooves, garment and bell, O Brahmin,</TR>

%lacuna_end: msNb
<TEXT> viprāya vedaviduṣe dattvānantaphalaṃ smṛtam||</TEXT> 7:25
        <APP>\vd <LEM>dattvānanta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dattvānta° \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare, e.g., \MBH\ 7.58.18:$
                tathā gāḥ kapilā dogdhrīḥ sarṣabhāḥ pāṇḍunandanaḥ|
                hemaśṛṅgī rūpyakhurā dattvā cakre pradakṣiṇam||
                      Łand \BHAVP\ Uttara 12.25:$
                hemaśṛṃgīṃ raupyakhurāṃ saghaṃṭāṃ kāṃsyadohanām| 
                mahādevāya gāṃ dadyād{ }dīkṣitāya dvijāya vai||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ c is a Łna-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>when given to a Veda-knowing Brahmin, [produces] rewards that are said to be endless.</TR>

%index_metre: na-vipulā


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>dānapraśaṃsā</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Praise of donation</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>


<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<LONGVERSELINES/>
%       - -   - . . -    . -  . .  . -   -  - . - -   . -
<TEXT> dānābhyāsarataḥ pravartanabhavāṃ śakyānurūpaṃ sadā</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°rūpaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °rūpa \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>I am unable to interpret Łpravartanabhavāṃ$ in Łpāda$ a and
              I suspect that Łśakyānurūpaṃ$ in the same Łpāda$ stands for Łśaktyanurūpaṃ$ metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>Always rejoicing in the practice of giving, \dots, as far as one's capacities go,</TR>

<TEXT> annaṃ vastrahiraṇyaraupyam{ }udakaṃ gāvas{ }tilān{ }medinīm|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°raupya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °ropya° \msCb, °<UNCL>raupya</UNCL>° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>gāvas{ }tilān{ }me°</LEM> \eme; gāvas{ }tilām{ }me° \msCa\msCc\msNc, gāvas{ }tilā me° \msCb\msNa,
                                                gāvan{ }tilā me° \msNb, gāvas{ }tilaṃ me° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>one should give food, clothes, gold and silver, water, cows, sesame seeds, land,</TR>

% cchatra would be unmetrical
<TEXT> dadyāt{ }pādukachattrapīṭhakalaśaṃ pātrādyam{ }anyac{ }ca vā</TEXT>
                 <LEM>pātrādyam{ }anyac{ }ca vā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
        <APP>\vc <LEM>dadyāt{ }pā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; dadyā pā° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>pātrādyam{ }anyac{ }ca vā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                         patrādyam{ }anyac{ }ca vā \msCb, pātreṣu labdheṣu vai \Ed</APP>
        <TR>sandals, parasols, seats, jars, cups, or anything else.</TR>

<TEXT> śraddhādānam{ }abhinnarāgavadanaṃ kṛtvā mano nirmalam||</TEXT> 7:26
        <APP>\vd <LEM>śraddhādāna°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dattvādāna° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Łabhinnarāgavadanaṃ$ in Łpāda$ d is suspect. Perhaps °Łvandanaṃ$ was meant 
              (`unconditioned affection and adoration').</NOTE>
        <TR>By giving in good faith (Łśraddhādānaṃ kṛtvā$), with words of unconditioned affection,
            one's mind [becomes] spotless.</TR>


<PAGEBREAK/>



<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<LONGVERSELINES/>
<TEXT> dānād{ }eva yaśaḥ śriyaḥ sukhakarāḥ khyātim{ }atulyāṃ labhed</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>yaśaḥ</LEM> \msCb\msNc\Ed; yaśa \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>sukhakarāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNcacorr\Ed; sukhakara \msNcpcorr\oo
                 <LEM>khyātim{ }atulyāṃ</LEM> \eme; khyātiś{ }ca tulyaṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>labhed</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; bhavet \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I suspect that Łkhyātiś ca tulyaṃ$ in the MSS stands for Łkhyātim atulyāṃ$ (`and unequalled fame') and
              that it is not a clumsy attempt to restore the metre, but rather a later correction gone wrong.
              I have emended the phrase believing that the second (last) syllable of Łkhyātim$ may be treated as Łguru$.
              See the same licence applied in non-Łanuṣṭubh$ verses above,
              e.g., in 5.20a, 6.18b, 7.13b (just before Łatula$).</NOTE>
        <TR>Glory and fortune that makes us happy come about only by donations, and one can gain unequalled fame.</TR>

<TEXT> dānād{ }eva nigarhaṇaṃ ripugaṇe ānandadaṃ saukhyadam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>nigarhaṇaṃ</LEM> \msCapcorr\msCc\msNa\Ed; nirhaṇaṃ \msCaacorr, nivarhaṇaṃ \msCb\msNc,
                                                                 nigarhana \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°gaṇe ānandadaṃ saukhyadam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                        °gaṇai ānandadaṃ saukhyadam \msCc,
                                                        °gaṇaiś{ }cānandasaukhyapradam  \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Only from donations will reproach [exercised by] the enemy [turn into] pleasure and happiness.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 204.jpg, f.280v
%       - -     -  . . -   . - .    . . -   -  -  .  - -     .  -
<TEXT> dānād{ }ūrjayatā prasādam{ }atulaṃ saubhāgya dānāl{ }labhed</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>dānād{ }ūrjayatā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; dānād{ }ūrjayatāṃ \msNa, dānād{ }du° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>prasāda°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; prāsāda° \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>saubhāgya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; saugāgya \msCb, saubhāgyaṃ \Ed\ \unmetr\oo
                 <LEM>dānāl{ }labhed</LEM> \msCb\Ed; dānaṃ labhet \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>I doubt if \Ed's reading in Łpāda$ c, Łdurjayatā$ (`invincibility') were better than Łūrjayatā$ transmitted in
              all the MSS consulted. While Łūrjayatā$ is still problematic, it is not inconceivable that it
              stands for Łūrjatā$ meaning most probably `being powerful, strength, vigour.' Also, note here
              the \stemform\ noun Łsaubhāgya$ metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>Vigour and unequalled graciousness come from donation.
                One can reach attractiveness thought donations.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa 

<TEXT> dānād{ }eva anantabhoga niyataṃ svargaṃ ca tasmād{ }bhavet||</TEXT> 7:27
        <APP>\vd <LEM>dānād{ }eva</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dānād{ }ova \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°niyataṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °niyata \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łsvargaṃ$ as a neuter noun, and the \stemform\ °Łbhoga$ metri causa in Łpāda$ d. 
              The lack of sandhi between Łeva$ and Łananta$° helps restore the metre.</NOTE>
        <TR>Endless enjoyments surely come only from donations, and heaven is [reached] also because of it.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa 
%index_grammar: lack of sandhi metri causa



<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<TEXT> dānād{ }eva ca śakralokasakalaṃ dānāj{ }janānandanaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śakralokasakalaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; śatrulokasakalaṃ \msNa, śakralokam{ }atulaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>dānāj{ }ja°</LEM> \mssALL\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dānā ja° \msCa, dānārja° \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>°Łlokasakalaṃ$ in Łpāda$ a is suspect and \Ed's silent emendation (°Łlokam atulaṃ$) is
               not without reason. This line may contain two general statements, the 
               first perhaps saying that by donation even Indra's world can be acquired or reached.
                Nevertheless I suspect that there is a hidden reference to a myth, perhaps
                that of Dadhīca, who gave his bones to Indra to help him defeat Vṛtra. 
                See \VSS\ 17.47:
                <sep/>
                 Łdadhīciḥ svatanuṃ dattvā vibudhānāṃ varānane$ | <br/>
                 Łbhuktvā lokān kramāt{ }sarvān śivaloke pratiṣṭhitaḥ$ ||
                <sep/>
        `Dadhīci gave the gods his own body, O Varānanā. Enjoying all the worlds in due order, 
        he is now living in Śivaloka.'
</NOTE>
        <TR>Śakra [conquered] the whole world by donations only. 
                                Donations make people happy.</TR>

<TEXT> dānād{ }eva mahīṃ samasta bubhuje samrāḍ{ }mahīmaṇḍale|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dānād{ }eva</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dāned{ }eva \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>mahīṃ samasta</LEM> \conj; mahīsamāsu \msCb\msCc, mahīṃ samāṃsu \msCa\msNa\msNc,
                                                 mahī samasta \msNb, mahīyasāṃ sa \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>samrāḍ{ }ma°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; saṃmrāḍ{ }ma° \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>One could translate Łpāda$ b as a general statement (`A universal monarch\dots),
              but again I suspect here a reference to a specific person (the son of Citraratha by Ūrṇā?) and 
              a specific legend.  The perfect form Łbubhuje$, and the next Łpāda$, at least point to this direction.</NOTE>
        <TR>Samrāj enjoyed all the land in the world only because of donations.</TR>

<TEXT> dānād{ }eva surūpayonisubhagaś{ }candrānano vīkṣyate</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>surūpa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; svarūpa° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°yonisu°</LEM> \msNb\Ed; °yonis{ }su° \msCa °yoniḥ su° \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°bhagaś{ }ca°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc; °bhaga ca° \msCb\msNa\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°ndrānano</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; °ndrānane \msCc\msNb, °ndrānanau \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>vīkṣyate</LEM> \msCb\msCc; vīkṣate \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc, vikṣate \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>My translation of Łpāda$ d is also tentative. I take Łsurūpayonisubhaga$ as
              Łsurūpa-suyoni-subhaga$. Unfortunately, the reference to any specific legend
              escapes me. Perhaps the reference is to Brahmā's boon to Tārakāsura,
              which ultimately was the cause of Skanda's birth.</NOTE>
        <TR>Skanda appears as handsome and fortunate, and has a good family only 
                        because of donations.</TR>

\msNb\ 53.jpg lower
%       - -    - . . - . -   . . .  -    - - .  -  -  .  -
<TEXT> dānād{ }eva anekasambhavasukhaṃ prāpnoti niḥsaṃśayam||</TEXT> 7:28
        <APP>\vd <LEM>niḥsaṃśayam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc; nisaṃśayaḥ \msCc, niḥsaṃśayaḥ \msNa\Ed, nissayaḥ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>One can reach happiness that lasts countless births only through donations,
                                                there is no doubt about that.</TR>


<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> <COLOPHON>iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe dānapraśaṃsādhyāyaḥ saptamaḥ</COLOPHON></TEXT>
        <TRCOLOPHON>Here ends the seventh chapter in the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ called Praise of Donations.</TRCOLOPHON>
        <APP> Ł\Colo:$ <LEM>°praśaṃsādhyāyaḥ saptamaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; 
                                °praśaṃsādhyāyaḥ samāptaḥ \msCb,
                                °praśaṃsā saptamo 'dhyāyaḥ \Ed</APP>
%END OF CHAPTER 7

<NORMALVERSELINES/>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 53.jpg lower, f.?, line 1
%folioinfo \msNc\ 222.jpg upper, line 5, f. 219v
