%folioinfo \Ed\ p.603

% Read this chapter with Judit Törzsök in Oct 2021 in Naples
<startchapter-n="8"/>
<CHAPTER>aṣṭamo 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>
<TRCHAPTER> Chapter Eight</TRCHAPTER>

<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣu svādhyāyaḥ (5)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Fifth Niyama-rule: study</TRSUBCHAPTER>

% in this chapter \Ed and \msCc seem close
%chapter 8
<ANUSTUBH/>
% kāryaṃm \msNa
% CHECK spelling
% \msKOa omits kāryam
<TEXT> pañcasvādhyāyanaṃ kāryam{ }ihāmutra sukhārthinā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°svādhyāyanaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                 °svādhyayanaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°mutra</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis; °mūtra \msPaperA\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°rthinā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °rthināṃ \msNb</APP>
        <LACUNA>ŁWitnesses used for this chapter: \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 204r--205v,
                                                  \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 210v--211v,
                                                  \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 280v--282r,
                                                  \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 11v--13r,
                                                  \msNb\ exp.\thinspace 53 (lower) -- 54 (lower),
                                                  \msNc\ ff.\thinspace 219v--221r,
                                                  \msParis\ exp.\thinspace 426--428,
                                                  \msPaperA\ ff.\thinspace 213r--214v,
                                                  \Ed\ pp.\thinspace 603--606;
                                                  \mssCaCbCc\ = \msCa + \msCb + \msCc$</LACUNA>
        <NOTE>The form Łsvādhyāyana$, for the more standard Łsvādhyayana$,
              does occur in several, typically Buddhist, texts. See, e.g., 
              the ŁMahāpratisarā-mahāvidyārājñī$ (<citep>HidasMahapratisara</citep><pnum>153</pnum>):
              Łmahāyānodgrahaṇa\-likhana\-vācana\-paṭhana\-svādhyāyana\-śravaṇa\-dhāraṇā\-bhi\-yuktānāṃ 
              pari\-pālikeyaṃ mahādhāraṇī$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Five kinds of study are to be pursued by those who wish to
                        be happy in this life and in the other.</TR>

%index_grammar: Newari singular after number?
% Malamud on svādhyāya maybe CHECK

% \msKOa: saivasaṅkhyā purāṇañ ca smārta  bhāratasaṃhitā !
<TEXT> śaivaṃ sāṃkhyaṃ purāṇaṃ ca smārtaṃ bhāratasaṃhitām||</TEXT> 8:1
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śaivaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                         <UNCL>śai</UNCL>laṃ \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>sāṃkhyaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                         śāṃkhya \msCc, sākhyaṃ \msNa\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>smārtaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; smārta \msCc\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>bhāratasaṃhitām</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                 bhāratasaṃhitāḥ \msNa, bhārattasaṃhitāṃ \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Supply an active verb such as Ładhīyāt$ for Łpāda$s cd.</NOTE>
        <TR>[One should study] Śaiva [teachings], Sāṃkhya [philosophy], the Purāṇa[s],
                the Smārta [tradition] and the ŁBhāratasaṃhitā$ [i.e. the ŁMahābhārata$].</TR>

% \msKOa: saivatatvaṃ vicintata saivāpāsupatadvaye
<TEXT> śaive tattvaṃ vicinteta śaivapāśupatadvaye|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śaive </LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; śaivai \msCb\msParis, śaivaṃ \msPaperA\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>tattvaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed; °tattva \msParis</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śaiva°</LEM> \msParis; śaivaḥ \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc, śaivāḥ \msCc\msPaperA\Ed, śaivā \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°dvaye</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °ye \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>The reading Łśaivaṃ$ in Łpāda$ a (\msPaperA\Ed) could be smoother than 
              the better attested one (Łśaive$).  Łśaivapāśupatadvaye$ in Łpāda$ b is weakly attested
              but I think that only this reading yields the appropriate meaning.
              One could also emend to Łśaivatattvaṃ$ in Łpāda$ a; compare 8.3a.</NOTE>
        <TR>As far as the Śaiva tradition is concerned, he should reflect on the truth 
            in both Śaiva and Pāśupata [teachings].</TR>

%\msKOa:atravistarata  prokta  tatva sārasamucaye 
<TEXT> atra vistarataḥ proktaṃ tattvasārasamuccayam||</TEXT> 8:2
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°sārasamuccayam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; 
                                °sāraṃ samuccayam \msNa, °sāraṃ samudyayaṃ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>In those teachings the whole essence of truth is taught extensively.</TR>
% or in this work?

%\msKOa:saṃkhyātatvaṃ tu saṃkhyeṣu bodhavya   tatva cintakaiḥ
<TEXT> saṃkhyātattvaṃ tu sāṃkhyeṣu boddhavyaṃ tattvacintakaiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>saṃkhyātattvaṃ tu</LEM> \msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA;
                                       saṃ<UNCL>khyā</UNCL>\lk\lk\lk\ \msCa, saṃkhyātattvaṃ \msCb, 
                                       śāṅkhyātatvaṃ tu \msCc, sakhyatatvan{ }tu \msNb, saṃkhyātattva tu \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>sāṃkhyeṣu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; sakhyeṣu \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Those who reflect on the truth (Łtattva$) can grasp the truth of enumeration
                [of ontological principles/reality levels] (Łsaṃkhyātattva$) from Sāṃkhya [texts].</TR>
% boddhavyan \msCa\msCb\msNa\msParis, bodhavyaṃ CHECK \msCc\msPaperA, bodhavyan \msNb

%folioinfo \msCa\ 404.jpg
%\msKOa: same reading
<TEXT> pañcatattvavibhāgena kīrtitāni maharṣibhiḥ||</TEXT> 8:3
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°tattva°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                 °tatvā° \msCb, \om\ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ d, Łkīrtitāni$ picks up an implied Łtattvāni$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The great sages taught [those twenty-five] Łtattva$s [of Sāṃkhya] as being in groups of five.</TR>
% vibhāgeṇa \msCc

%folioinfo: \msPaperA\ 341.jpg upper
%\msKOa:            koṣa                   ta
<TEXT> purāṇeṣu mahīkoṣo vistareṇa prakīrtitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <TR>In the Purāṇas it is the layers of the world that are described extensively.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNc\ 222.jpg lower, 220r
%\msKOa:āyoyaśca      tiryañ ca          sam  aveśayet
<TEXT> adhordhvamadhyatiryaṃ ca yatnataḥ sampraveśayet||</TEXT> 8:4
        <APP>\vc <LEM>adhordhva°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; adhordhvaṃ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°madhya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °madha° \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>yatnataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; yatnata \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>sampraveśayet</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA;
                                                                         samprabodhayet \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that Łtirya$ seems to be an acceptable nominal stem in this text for Łtiryañc$. 
              I understand the causative form Łsampraveśayet$ as non-causative.
              \Ed's silent emendation to Łsamprabodhayet$ is understandable since to `enter' these realms
              the study of the Purāṇas makes little sense, at least when taken literally.
              Kengo Harimoto has suggested emending to Łsampradeśayet$.</NOTE>
        <TR>One can definitely enter [the realms] below, above, in the middle, and horizontally.</TR>

% Vedic oblique (Acri)
% Judit centre and all around ! CHECK; so all are directions

%index_voc: tirya

%folioinfo \msNa\ 205.jpg lower, f.12r 
%\msKOa:smārta varṇṇasamācāra  dharmāṇyāyapravarttakaṃ
<TEXT> smārtaṃ varṇāśramācāraṃ dharmanyāyapravartanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>smārtaṃ varṇā°</LEM> \msCa; tasmārttam{ }varṇṇā° \msCb,
                                        smārtavarṇā° \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA\Ed, 
                                        smārttaṃ varṇṇa° \msParis</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dharma°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; dharmaṃ \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°vartanam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA;
                                                         °va\lk naṃ \msParis, °vartana \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Compare Łpāda$s ab with 3.15cd:
                        Łsmārto varṇāśramācāro yamaiś ca niyamair yutaḥ$. 
              The term Łsmārta$ seems to be used here in the sense of Dharmaśāstra.</NOTE>
        <TR>The Smārta [tradition] deals with the conduct of the social classes (Łvarṇa$) and
                disciplines (Łāśrama$), and with the procedures of Dharma and lawsuits (Łnyāya$).</TR>

%\msKOa:                    grāhya    tatva asahitaḥ
<TEXT> śiṣṭācāro 'vikalpena grāhyas{ }tatra aśaṅkitaḥ||</TEXT> 8:5
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śiṣṭā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\Ed; śiṣṭa° \msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>°cāro</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\msPaperA;
                                 °cāra° \msCc\Ed,
                                 °cārā \msNa,
                                 °cā<UNCL>ro</UNCL>° \msParis</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>grāhyas{ }tatra aśaṅkitaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                         grāhyas{ }ta\lk\lk\lk ṅkitaḥ \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>The Łavagraha$ in Ł'vikalpena$ is not to be found in the witnesses and has
                been supplied. The form Łaśaṅkitaḥ$ is less then perfect here,
                and may have been intended as an ablative (Łaśaṅkā-taḥ$), as suggested by Judit Törzsök,
                or adverbially (Łaśaṅkitam$), or even more probably as a loosely added subject (for 
                Łaśaṅkitena$).</NOTE>
        <TR>Good conduct is to be gathered from it without hesitation, with certainty.</TR>

%index_grammar: lack of sandhi in pāda d

%\msKOa: same reading
<TEXT> itihāsam{ }adhīyānaḥ sarvajñaḥ sa naro bhavet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°jñaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °jña \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>As it is clear from 8.1d, what is primarily meant by Łitihāsa$ is the \MBh.
              Compare \VSS\ 6.5.</NOTE>
        <TR>A man who studies the Itihāsa [i.e. the \MBh] will become omniscient.</TR>

%\msKOa: same reading
<TEXT> dharmārthakāmamokṣeṣu saṃśayas{ }tena chidyate||</TEXT> 8:6
        <TR>[All his] doubts about religious duty (Łdharma$), finanicial gain (Łartha$), 
                               carnal desires (Łkāma$) and liberation (Łmokṣa$) will be eliminated.</TR>



<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣv{ }upasthanigrahaḥ (6)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Sixth Niyama-rule: sexual restraint</TRSUBCHAPTER>

%\msKOa:paṃcoprasthavinigraha sṛṇuyāvaṃhito dvija !
<TEXT> śṛṇuṣvāvahito vipra pañcopasthavinigraham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°graham</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                 °gra<UNCL>haḥ</UNCL> \msNa</APP>
        <TR>Listen with great attention, O Brahmin, to 
                        the five [spheres of] sexual restraint.</TR>

%\msKOa:striyovā garhitaḥsvargaḥ svayaṃmuktiś  ca kīrtyate
<TEXT> striyo vā garhitotsargaḥ svayaṃmuktiś{ }ca kīrtyate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>garhitotsargaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\msParis;
                                                 garhitas{ }sarggaḥ \msCc, garhito vipra \msNa,
                                                 garhito svargaḥ \msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>svayaṃ°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; svaya° \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>kīrtyate</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                         kī<UNCL>rtsya</UNCL>te \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Women, forbidden ejaculation, and masturbation are mentioned [in this context, as well as]</TR>
% NOTE vā phps to avoid iambic Judit; szerintem nem, mert így is pathyā

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.604
%\msKOa: same reading
<TEXT> svapnopaghātaṃ viprendra divāsvapnaṃ ca pañcamaḥ||</TEXT> 8:7
        <APP>\ve <LEM>°ghātaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA;
                                                         °ghāta \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>offence while sleeping, O Brahmin, and fantasising, as fifth.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>striyaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Women</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
%\msKOa:agamyastrī divārsyase dharmapatnī   ca  vā bhavet
<TEXT> agamyā strī divā parve dharmapatny{ }api vā bhavet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>strī divā parve</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPaperA; 
                                \lk  divā parvve \msCa, \lk\lk \lk  parve \msParis, strī divāpūrve \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°patny{ }api</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                °patnī pi \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łparve$ as Łparvani$ (thematisation of the stem in Ł-an$).<sep/>
              Compare \MANU\ 11.175 (Olivelle's edition and translation, <citeyear>OlivelleManu</citeyear>):
                <sep/>
                         Łmaithunaṃ tu samāsevya puṃsi yoṣiti vā dvijaḥ$ | <br/>
                         Łgoyāne 'psu divā caiva savāsāḥ snānam ācaret$ ||
                <sep/>
                `If a twice-born has sexual intercourse with
                  a man or a woman in an ox-cart, on water,
                  or during the day, he should bathe with his clothes on.'
                <sep/>
                     Compare also \MANU\ 3.45 (Olivelle's edition and translation):
                <sep/>
                         Łṛtukālābhigāmī syāt svadāranirataḥ sadā$ |<br/>
                         Łparvavarjaṃ vrajec caināṃ tadvrato ratikāmyayā$ ||
                <sep/>
                `Finding his gratification always in his wife, he should have sex 
                  with her during her season. Devoted solely to her, he may go to 
                  her also when he wants sexual pleasure, except on the days of the moon's change.'</NOTE>
        <TR>A woman is not to be approached sexually in the daytime and 
            on the four nights of the changes of the Moon (Łparvan$),
            even if she is one's lawful wife. </TR>
% ask Judit, e.g. on SYM 6.48cd:
% grāmadharmaṃ sadā varjyaṃ vāsare, siddhim icchatā (also TSBh)
% Tantric Comm volume Törzsök, p. 215

%index_grammar: thematization (parve)

%\msKOa:viruddhastrī na bhavetavarṇṇavarṇṇabhraṣṭādhikāma ca
<TEXT> viruddhastrīṃ na seveta varṇabhraṣṭādhikāsu ca||</TEXT> 8:8
        <APP>\vc <LEM>viruddhastrīṃ na</LEM> \msPaperA; viruddhastrī na \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc,
                                 viruddhastrī ni° \msNa\msParis, dviruddhāstrīn{ }na \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dhikāsu ca</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msParis\msPaperA; °dhikāsu ta \msCc, °dikāṣu ca \msNb, 
                                                        °vikāṣu ca \msNc, °pikāsu ca \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE><sep/>
              The nominative °Łstrī$ in Łpāda$ c in most witnesses may 
              be the result of an eyeskip to Łstrī$ in Łpāda$ a. Note how the paper MS
              is the only one transmitting a fully correct form.</NOTE>
        <TR>One should not have sex with a woman who is taboo or
            with one that has lost her class (Łvarṇa$) or
            is [of a] superior [Łvarṇa$ than oneself].</TR>
% maybe ādikāsu?
% CHECK Manu

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>garhitotsargaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Forbidden ejaculation</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> ajameṣagavādīnāṃ vaḍavāmahiṣīṣu ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°meṣa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °meya° \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand °Łādīnāṃ$ in Łpāda$ a as standing for a locative,</NOTE>
        <TR>Intercourse with goats, sheep, cows, mares, and buffalo-cows</TR>

%index_grammar: genitive for locative

<TEXT> garhitotsargam{ }ity{ }etad{ }yatnena parivarjayet||</TEXT> 8:9
        <NOTE>and °Łsargam$ as neuter nominative (instead of °Łsargaḥ$) or, alternatively,
               understand Łpāda$ c with a hiatus bridge: Łgarhitotsarga-m-ity etad$.</NOTE>
        <TR>is called forbidden ejaculation, which is to be avoided at all cost.</TR>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

%folioinfo \msCb\ 423.jpg, f.211r
%folioinfo \msCc\ 205.jpg, f.281r 
<SUBSUBCHAPTER>svayaṃmuktiḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Masturbation</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> ayonikaṣaṇā vāpi apānakaṣaṇāpi vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>ayoni°</LEM> \conj; anyonya° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°kaṣaṇā</LEM> \msCa\msNa; °karṣaṇā \msCb\msCc\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kaṣaṇāpi</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa; °karṣaṇāpi \msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The conjecture in Łpāda$ a (Łayoni$° from Łanyonya$°) involves minimal intervention 
                and makes the sentence much more meaningful than the transmitted version. (Consider also Łayonya$°.)
              Compare \MANU\ 11.174 (Olivelle's edition and translation):
        <sep/>
                Łamānuṣīṣu puruṣa udakyāyām ayoniṣu$ | <br/>
                Łretaḥ siktvā jale caiva kṛcchraṃ sāṃtapanaṃ caret$ ||
        <sep/>
                'If someone ejaculates his semen in non-human females, in a man, in a
                menstruating woman, in any place other than the vagina, or on water, he should
                perform the Sāntapana penance...'</NOTE>
        <TR>Rubbing himself against something else than a female sexual organ or rubbing his anus</TR>
% Judit maybe go for ayoni
% a-apāna, without an anus Acri

<TEXT> svayaṃmuktir{ }iyaṃ jñeyā tasmāt{ }tāṃ parivarjayet||</TEXT> 8:10
        <APP>\vc <LEM>svayaṃmukti°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                                 svayamukti° \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>jñeyā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                                 jñeyāṃ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tasmāt{ }tāṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA;
                                         tasmāt{ }taṃ \msCc, tasmārttā \msNb, tasmāt{ }strī \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE><sep/>
               The variant Łstrī$ for Łtāṃ$ in Łpāda$ d in \Ed\ may be an example of
               silent interventions made by Naraharināth in his edition.</NOTE>
        <TR>are called masturbation (Łsvayaṃmukti$), therefore these are to be avoided.</TR>


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>svapnaghātam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Offence while sleeping</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> svapnaghātaṃ dvijaśreṣṭha aniṣṭaṃ paṇḍitaiḥ sadā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>svapnaghā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParispcorr\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                 svapnajā° \msParisacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>paṇḍitaiḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                 paṇḍitai \msCc, paṇḍiteḥ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>Offence while sleeping, O best of Brahmins, has always been [considered] undesirable by 
                                the learned.</TR>

%folioinfo \msParis\ (Paris MS) 427.jpg
<TEXT> svapne strīṣu ramante ca retaḥ prakṣarate tataḥ||</TEXT> 8:11
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ramante</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\Ed; ramakṣante \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>prakṣarate</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA; praskhalatas \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>tataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; tata \msCc</APP>
        <TR>[If] one enjoys women while dreaming, his semen will issue.</TR>

%mṛgayākṣo divāsvapnaḥ parivādaḥ striyo madaḥ
%tauryatrikaṃ vṛthāṭyā ca kāmajo daśako gaṇaḥ // Manu_7.47


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>divāsvapnam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Daydreaming</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> divāśayaṃ na kartavyaṃ nityaṃ dharmapareṇa tu| </TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>divāśayaṃ na</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; 
                                        divāśayen{ }na \msNa, divāsayānaṃ \msNb, divāśāyaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>nityaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; nitya \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°pareṇa tu</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                         °parena tu \msCa, °pareṇa ca \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>It is not crystal clear why `sleeping by day' or `daydreaming/fantasising' should count as
              one of the offences against sexual restraint. A line may have dropped out here.</NOTE>
        <TR>Sleeping by day should always be avoided by those who are intent on Dharma.</TR>

% a line dropped out?

<TEXT> svargamārgārgalā hy{ }etāḥ striyo nāma prakīrtitāḥ||</TEXT> 8:12
        <APP>\vc <LEM>hy{ }etāḥ</LEM> \msNc; hy{ }etā \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msParis\msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>striyo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA; strīyo \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°kīrtitāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °kīrtitā \msNc</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\compare\ \PADMAP\ 1.13.395cd:$ parityajadhvaṃ dārāṇi svargamārgārgalāni ca</PARAL>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$s cd are clumsy and out of context. They would fit verse 8.8 better.</NOTE>
        <TR>These women are called `the bolts [that block the gate to] the path to heaven.'</TR>



<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣu vratapañcakam (7)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Seventh Niyama-rule: religious observances</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> mārjārakabakaśvānagomahīvratapañcakam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>mārjārakabakaśvānagomahīvrata°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msParis;
                         mārjārabakabaśvānagomahīvrata° \msNb,
                         mārjārakavakaśvānagomahīveka° \msPaperA,
                         mārjārakaś{ }ca śvānāś{ }ca gomahīvaka \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[Hear about] the five religious observances [called]
            the cat, the heron, the dog, the cow, and the earth.</TR>


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>mārjārakavratam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Cat observance</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

% °viṣṭhāmūtra would be pathyā
<TEXT> svaviṣṭhamūtraṃ bhūmīṣu chādayed{ }dvijasattama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°viṣṭha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA; °viṣṭā° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°mūtraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °mūtra° \msCb\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note °Łviṣṭha$° for Łviṣṭhā$ metri causa in Łpāda$ c (Łma-vipulā$).
                Alternatively, read Łsvaviṣṭhāmūtra bhūmīṣu$ (Łpathyā$ with
                \stemform\ noun).</NOTE>
        <TR>He buries his own urine and f\ae ces in the ground, O truest Brahmin.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<TEXT> sūryasomānumodanti mārjāravratikeṣu ca||</TEXT> 8:13
        <APP>\ve <LEM>°modanti</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA; °ṣādanti \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ Łsūryasoma$ for Łsūryasomau$ (Łsūryasomāv anu$°) in Łpāda$ e. 
                It is not entirely clear why cats would rejoice seeing the Sun and the Moon.
                Perhaps this remark refers to the fact that cats can be active both
                in the daytime and at night.</NOTE>
        <TR>[Practitioners] rejoice [seeing] the sun and the moon when performing the cat observance.</TR>
% They can look at sun and they do look at moon Florinda

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa 

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>bakavratam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Heron observance</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> bakavac{ }cendriyagrāmaṃ suniyamya tapodhana|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tapodhana</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msParis; 
                                        tapodhanaḥ \msNc, tapodhanam \msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <TR>O great ascetic, one should suppress all one's senses like a heron,</TR>
% uncl ba uncl \lk  vacce° 

%Manu
%37041:Manu4.192c/ na bakavratike pāpe na-a.vedavidi dharmavit ||
%37060:Manu4.196c[197ṃc]/ śaṭho mithyāvinītaś ca bakavratacaro dvijaḥ ||
%37062:Manu4.197a[198ṃa]/ ye bakavratino viprā ye ca mārjāraliṅginaḥ |

<TEXT> sādhayec{ }ca manastuṣṭiṃ mokṣasādhanatatparaḥ||</TEXT> 3:14
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sādhayec{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                                sādhaye ca \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>manastuṣṭiṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; 
                                                                manastuṣṭi° \msCb\msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°sādhana°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; 
                                                               °sāna° \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Cranes are compared to ascetics here probably because of the similarity of
                their posture when relaxing standing on one leg to ascetics performing penance 
                standing on one leg (such as the ascetic, and a cat, depicted on the 
                famous relief in Mahabalipuram). More specifically, herons apply `meditation,' so to say,
                when fishing, as Olivelle (<citeyear>OlivelleManu</citeyear>, 298) 
                points out commenting on \MANU\ 7.106a (Łbakavac cintayed arthān$),
                quoting Bhāruci's explanation ad loc.:
                `Just as naturally in order to catch a mass of fish who are safe in 
                 their water-fort the `heron' finds an effective means to take them 
                 by employing meditation, after dedicating himself to the task, so 
                 the king should not be despondent realizing that if one employs
                 abundant thought on one's affairs even aims very difficult to achieve are attained.'
                 (Łyathā abdurgāśrayaṃ matsyabalaṃ svabhāvatas tadgrahaṇārthaṃ bakaḥ paryupāsanayā$
                  Łtadgrahaṇopāyaṃ dhyānayogād āsādayati, evam arthacintābhiyogātiśayena suduṣprāpā$
                  Łapy arthā āsādyanta iti matvā na nirvedaṃ gacchet$ |)</NOTE>
        <TR>and should cultivate the peace of the mind, focusing on achieving liberation.</TR>


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>śvānavratam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Dog observance</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> mūtraviṣṭhe na bhūmīṣu kurute dhunadaṃ sadā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>mūtraviṣṭhe na</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA; 
                                                mūtraviṣṭe ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dhunadaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA;
                                                                 śvānadaḥ \msNa, chādanaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Łdhunadaṃ$ (`barking'?) in Łpāda$ b may not be the intended form;
              perhaps understand Łdhunanaṃ$ (related to Łdhvanana$), 
              or emend to Łdhvananaṃ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>[In this case the practitioner] does not [bury] his urine 
            and f\ae ces in the ground, and he barks constantly.</TR>

<TEXT> tuṣyate bhagavān{ }śarvaḥ śvānavratacaro yadi||</TEXT> 8:15
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śarvaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                         sarvaḥ \msCb\msNb, savvaḥ \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>A possible expanation for Śiva being satisfied with an ascetic practising 
              this observance is that Śiva's Bhairava form often has a dog as his mount. See, e.g.,
              <citep>BakkerWorld2014</citep><pnum>232--233</pnum> on a 5-6th-century 
              image of Bhairava and a dog carved in rock at Muṇḍeśvarī Hill not far from Vārāṇasī.
          <sep/>
              The so-called dog observance has ancient roots. Its practitioner, the Łkukkuravatika$
              appears in <skt>Majjhimanikāya</skt> 2.1.7, in the <skt>Kukkuravatiyasutta</skt>, 
              alongside with a practitioner of the Łgovrata$ (Łgovatika$), an observance
              that comes up in the next verse in the \VSS:
              Łevaṃ me sutaṃ. ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā koliyesu viharati haliddavasanaṃ nāma koliyānaṃ nigamo.$
              Łatha kho puṇṇo ca koliyaputto govatiko, acelo ca seniyo kukkuravatiko yena$
              Łbhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu...$
               See <citep>AcharyaBull</citep><pnum>127--128</pnum>. Acharya 
               summarises the <skt>Kukkuravatiyasutta</skt> thus:
               `The <skt>Kukkuravatiyasutta</skt> from the <skt>Majjhimanikāya</skt> (II.1.7) 
                presents a Łgovatika$ together with a Łkukkuravatika$. They are observing 
                their vows, and have adopted the behaviour of a bull and a dog respectively. 
                The Buddha tells them that as they are cultivating bullness and dogness, 
                the state of mind of these animals, they will go to hell or become reborn as animal.
                They are alarmed at this and take refuge in the Buddha.'</NOTE>
        <TR>Lord Śarva [i.e. Śiva] is satisfied when one practises the dog observance.</TR>
% Judit: śmaśāna both?  

%Bisschop, Peter 2018. “Vedic Elements in the Pāśupatasūtra,” in Farnah, Indo-Iranian and Indo-European Studies in Honor of Sasha Lubotsky (Ann Arbor/New York: Beech Stave Press), 1–12.


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>govratam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Cow observance</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> mūtravarco na rudhyeta sadā govratiko naraḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°varco</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA;
                                                         °vacco \msCb\msNa, °varcā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>govratiko</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                 \lk\lk tiko \msCa</APP>
        <TR>A man practising the Cow Observance should never hold back his urine and f\ae ces.</TR>
% ruddhyeta  \mssCaCbCc\Ed

<TEXT> bhīmas{ }tuṣṭikaraś{ }caiva purāṇeṣu nigadyate||</TEXT> 8:16
        <APP>\vc <LEM>bhīmas{ }tu°</LEM> \msCc\msNb\Ed;
                                 bhīmatu° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msParis,
                                 bhimas{ }tu° \msPaperA</APP>
        <TR>This is a terrifying [observance] that gives satisfaction, [as] stated in the Purāṇas.</TR>
        <NOTE>I prefer reading Łbhīma$ and Łtuṣṭi$° as two separate words, the first
                one either in \stemform\ (\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msParis) or as Łbhīmas$ (\msCc\msNb\Ed)
                or Łbhīmaṃ$ (\eme), to reading these two words as a compound because
                of the following Łcaiva$.
                I suspect that both Łbhīma$ and Łtuṣṭikara$ refer to the Łvrata$, rather than its practitioner,
                but I have not emended  Łbhīmas tuṣṭikaraś$ to Łbhīmaṃ tuṣṭikaraṃ$
                because Łvrata$ appears as a masculine noun, e.g., in 8.17d below.

              Acharya (<citeyear>AcharyaBull</citeyear>, 116--118) gives a number of significant clues about the origins 
              of this observance. After exploring its links to Pāśupatas, 
              he quotes <skt>Jaiminīyabrāhmaṇa</skt> 2.113, which contains the phrase 
              Łyatra yatrainaṃ viṣṭhā vindet tat tad vitiṣṭheta$, in Acharya's translation:
              `Wherever he feels the urge to evacuate f\ae ces, right there he should evacuate.'
              This is an instruction in a Vedic text that is close to what the \VSS\ teaches above.
              Incidentaly, the <skt>Jaiminīyabrāhmaṇa</skt> adds:
              Łtena haitenottaravayasy e$[Łva$] Łyajeta$
              (translated by Acharya as: 
              `One should perform this [sacrifice] in the ﬁnal years of one's life').</NOTE>


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>mahīvratam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Earth observance</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
% dārayanno \msCa 
<TEXT> kuddālair{ }dārayanto 'pi kīlakoṭiśataiś{ }citaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kuddālair{ }dārayanto</LEM> \msNa\msParis\Ed;
                               kuddālair{ }dārayanno \msCa, kuddārai dārayanto \msCb,
                               kudārai dārayantā \msCc, kuddālai ddārayām{ }āsa \msNb,
                               kuddālai dārayanto \msNc, kuddālai <UNCL>ddhāra</UNCL>yanto \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>kīlakoṭiśataiś{ }citaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis;
                                         kīṭakoṭīśatair{ }api \msCc\msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <TR>Splitting [the earth] with spades and laid out on hundreds of pointed wedges:</TR>
        <NOTE>While Łdārayanto$ as an active participle in the masculine nominative is acceptable
                as an irregular form, the precise interpretation of Łpāda$s a and b is still problematic,
        therefore my translation of this verse is tentative and the description seems too condensed to be
        intelligible. Kengo Harimoto suggested that \msCc\ and \Ed\ might be transmitting
        the correct reading, and then the reference would be to soil 
        piled up by millions of insects (Łkīṭakoṭi$°), instead of points of
        wedges (Łkīlakoṭi$°). Nevertheless, now I think that the reference point could
        be Bhīṣma's dying scene in the \MBH, where the great warrior is lying on a bed of hundreds of arrows: 
        <skt>sa śete śaratalpastho medinīm aspṛśaṃs tadā</skt>: `Then he lay there on his bed of arrows,
        without touching the ground' (\MBH\ 6.115.8ab). The word Łcita$ is used in the same context in 
        \MBH\ 12.47.4ab: <skt>vikīrṇāṃśur ivādityo bhīṣmaḥ śaraśataiś citaḥ</skt>: 
        `Bhīṣma, laid on a hundred arrows, was like the Sun with its scattered rays of light.'
        If this interpretation of \VSS\ 8.17 is correct, the observance described here may require
        one to dig the ground, install wedges, and lie on them, in the manner of fakirs.
        The reference to the Earth in Łpāda$ c may have been inspired by lines such as \MBH\
        6.115.11cd: <skt>rarāsa pṛthivī caiva bhīṣme śāṃtanave hate</skt>:
        `The Earth cried out when Bhīṣma, the son of Śaṃtanu, was killed.'

         In \BHAVP\ 4.121, called `The Description of eighty-five observances' (Łvratapañcāśītivarṇana$),
         we find this on Łmahīvrata$:
                <sep/>
               Łdadyāt triṃśatpalād ūrdhvaṃ mahīṃ kṛtvā tu kāṃcanīm$ |<br/>
               Łkulācalādrisahitāṃ tilavastrasamanvitām$ || 152 || <br/>
               Łtiladroṇopari gatāṃ brāhmaṇāya kuṭuṃbine$ | <br/>
               Łdinaṃ payovratas tiṣṭhed rudraloke mahīyate$ || 153 || <br/>
               Łetan mahīvrataṃ proktaṃ saptakalpānuvartakam$ |<br/>
                <sep/>
        A tentative translation of this passage would go as follows: `One should donate a golden [model of] Earth
        that weighs more than thirty Łpala$s (appr. one kilogram), showing the chief mountain-ranges,
        together with [donations of] sesamum seeds and clothes, the sesamum seeds [weighing] more than
        a Łdroṇa$ (appr. ten kilograms), to a householder Brāhmin. One should keep the milk-observance 
        [i.e. subsisting on nothing but milk] for one day, and one will have fun in Rudraloka.
        This is called the Earth Observance whose range is seven \ae ons.' (I take the values for weights
        from <citep>OlivelleManu</citep><pnum>997</pnum>.) \MATSP\ 101.52 gives similar instructions, 
        as do the descriptions of the Łdharāvrata$ and the Łśubhadvādaśī$ observances in 
        <citep>KaneHistory</citep><pnum>v. 5, 321 and 429</pnum>.
        The \VSS's Łmahīvrata$ seems different, and more in line with 
        the somewhat transgressive and wild, perhaps Pāśupata-oriented, nature of the
        four preceding observances.</NOTE>

<TEXT> kṣamate pṛthivī devī evam{ }eva mahīvrataḥ||</TEXT> 8:17
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°vrataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °vrata \msNc</APP>
        <TR>Goddess Earth bears [this] patiently. This is exactly how one can practise the earth vow.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 53.jpg upper
<TEXT> vratapañcakam{ }ity{ }etad{ }yaś{ }careta jitendriyaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>jitendriyaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; dvijendriyaḥ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>He who practises these five religious observances with his senses subdued</TR>

% msKOa iva lokaṃ
<TEXT> sa cottamam{ }idaṃ lokaṃ prāpnoti na ca saṃśayaḥ||</TEXT> 8:18
        <NOTE>Note the neuter Łidaṃ$ picking up the normally masculine Łlokaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c,
              and that the same Łidaṃ$ would make more sense if the interlocutor were a deity, e.g.,
              Śiva, referring to his abode, and not Anarthayajña, the ascetic. 
              Perhaps emend to Łparaṃ$, as suggested by Florinda De Simini.</NOTE>
        <TR>will, without doubt, reach this superior world [i.e. heaven?].</TR>



<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣv{ }upavāsaḥ (8)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Eighth Niyama-rule: eating restrictions</TRSUBCHAPTER>
% Cf. Śivadharmaśāstra 10

<TEXT> śeṣānnam{ }antarānnaṃ ca naktāyācitam{ }eva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>śeṣānnam{ }antarānnaṃ ca</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\msParispcorr; 
                                śeṣāṇām{ }antarāṇāñ{ }ca \msCc\Ed,
                                śeṣānnam{ }annarānnaṃ ca \msNa,
                                śeṣānnam{ }arānnaṃ ca \msParisacorr,
                                śeṣāṇam{ }antarāṇāñ{ }ca \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>naktāyācita°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                         nakta<UNCL>yā</UNCL>cita° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA; vā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note how this category of Łniyama$-rules was called Łupavāsa$ (`fasting') 
              in 5.3c above but how in fact Łupavāsa$ is just the fifth 
              subcategory withing this group of eating restrictions.</NOTE>
        <TR>Eating leftovers, [not] eating in-between [breakfast and dinner], 
            eating [only] at night, eating food obtained without solicitation,</TR>
% msParispc in a different hand

%folioinfo \msCa\ 405.jpg
<TEXT> upavāsaṃ ca pañcaitat{ }kathayiṣyāmi tac{ }chṛṇu||</TEXT> 8:19
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>pañcaitat{ }ka°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                 pañcaite ka° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>and fasting: listen, I shall teach you these five.</TR>

%index_grammar: singular after numbers, Newari


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>śeṣānnam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Eating leftovers</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> vaiśvadevātithiśeṣaṃ pitṛśeṣaṃ ca yad{ }bhavet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°śeṣaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °śeṣāṃ \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is a Łsa-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>[He who eats] the leftovers belonging to all the gods, to guests, and to the ancestors,</TR>

%index_metre: sa-vipulā

<TEXT> bhṛtyaputrakalatrebhyaḥ śeṣāśī vighasāśanaḥ||</TEXT> 8:20
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vighasāśanaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb; vighasāsanam \msCb, vighasāṣinaḥ \msCc, 
                                vighaśāsanaḥ \msNc, vighasāśa<UNCL>naḥ</UNCL> \msParispcorr,
                                ghasāśana \msParisacorr, vighasāsanaḥ \msPaperA, viṣasāsanaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>he who eats the leftovers (Łśeṣāśin$) of servants, sons and wives, is [called in general]
                        the one who consumes the remains of food (Łvighasāśana$).</TR>



<SUBSUBCHAPTER>antarānnam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>[Not] eating in-between breakfast and dinner</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> antarā prātarāśī ca sāyamāśī tathaiva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>antarā prātarāśī</LEM> \eme; antarā prāntarāśī \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc, 
                                antarā <UNCL>kranta</UNCL>rāśī \msNb, 
                                antārā prā<UNCL>tta</UNCL>rāśī \msParis,                
                                antamā prāntarāśī ca \msPaperA,  antasamprāntarāśī \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sāyamāśī</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis; sāyamāśīn \msCa, 
                                        nāyamāśī \msPaperA, niyamāśī \Ed</APP>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 206.jpg upper, f.12v 
<TEXT> sadopavāsī bhavati yo na bhuṅkte kadācana||</TEXT> 8:21
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vāsī bhavati</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; 
                                        °vāsī ca bhavati \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kadācana</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; kadācanaḥ \msCc</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd \similar\ Ł\MBH\ 12.214.9:$ 
                                antarā prātarāśaṃ ca sāyamāśaṃ tathaiva ca|
                                sadopavāsī ca bhaved yo na bhuṅkte kathaṃcana|| 
                    \similar\ Ł\MBH\ 13.93.10:$
                                antarā sāyamāśaṃ ca prātarāśaṃ tathaiva ca|
                                sadopavāsī bhavati yo na bhuṅkte 'ntarā punaḥ||</PARAL>
                <NOTE>My translation here follows the parallel verse in the \MBH\ and 
                      is based on the one in <cite>GanguliMBh</cite>. 
                      The syntax of the version here in the \VSS\ is less
                      smooth than that in the \MBH, and the \VSS's reading Łprāntarāśī$ 
                      definitely required an emendation.</NOTE>
                <TR>If he fasts between having breakfast and dinner,
                    he will be regarded as one who is always fasting.</TR>


%folioinfo \msNc\ 223.jpg upper, f. 220v
<SUBSUBCHAPTER>naktānnam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Eating [only] at night</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> na divā bhojanaṃ kāryaṃ rātrau naiva ca bhojayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>bhojanaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; nojanaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; tu \msCb, \om\ \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>bhojayet</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; kārayet \msNb</APP>
        <TR>One should eat neither in the daytime nor in the evening,</TR>

%folioinfo: \msPaperA\ 341.jpg lower
<TEXT> naktavele ca bhoktavyaṃ naktadharmaṃ samīhatā||</TEXT> 8:22
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vele ca</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msParis\msPaperA;
                                 °velā ca \msCb, °velo ca \msNc, °vele va \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dharmaṃ samīhatā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msParis;
                                 °dharmasamīhatā \msCc\msNb, °dharmmasamīhitā \msPaperA, 
                                 °dharmmaḥ samīhitaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note °Łvele$ for °Łvelāyāṃ$ in Łpāda$ c. On Łnaktabhojana$, see \SDHS\ 10.</NOTE>
        <TR>one should eat [only] at midnight (Łnaktavelā$) if he wishes to follow the practice of [eating only at] 
                 night (Łnaktadharma$).</TR>

%index_grammar: masculine locative for feminine locative (vele for velāyāṃ)


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>ayācitānnam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Eating food obtained without solicitation</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> anārabhya ya āhāraṃ kuryān{ }nityam{ }ayācitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>anārabhya ya</LEM> \conj; anārambhasya \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kuryān{ }ni°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; kuryā ni° \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Łanārambhasya$ (`of someone who has not yet started/initiated') in Łpāda$ a seems suspect, hence
              my conjecture (Łanārabhya ya$) that involves mininal intervention and yields better sense.
              I take Łayācitam$ in Łpāda$ b adverbially.</NOTE>
        <TR>He who consumes food without ever initiating [the donation], without asking for it,</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 206.jpg, f.281v 
<TEXT> parair{ }dattaṃ tu yo bhuṅkte tam{ }ayācitam{ }ucyate||</TEXT> 8:23
        <APP>\vc <LEM>parair{ }dattaṃ tu</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msParis\msPaperA;
                                                parai dattañ{ }ca \msCc, parai dattan{ }tu \msNb,
                                                parair{ }dantan{ }tu \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tam{ }ayāci°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; nam{ }ayāci° \msParisacorr\msPaperA, 
                                        <UNCL>tam{ }a</UNCL>yāci° \msParispcorr</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the accusative with the passive in Łpāda$ d (Łtam... ucyate$).</NOTE>
        <TR>and eats [only] that which has been given by others 
                 is called [one who eats] unsolicited [food].</TR>



<SUBSUBCHAPTER>upavāsaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Fasting</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.605
<TEXT> bhakṣyaṃ bhojyaṃ ca lehyaṃ ca coṣyaṃ peyaṃ ca pañcamam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>bhakṣyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; bhakṣya \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>For a detailed discussion of the categories Łbhakṣya, bhojya, lehya$ and Łcoṣya$,
                        see <citep>KafleNisvasaBook</citep><pnum>245, n. 534</pnum>. 
                        See also \SDHU\ 8.13:
                <sep/>
                        Łbhakṣyaṃ bhojyaṃ ca peyaṃ ca lehyaṃ coṣyaṃ ca picchilam |$ <br/>
                        Łiti bhedāḥ ṣaḍannasya madhurādyāś ca ṣaḍguṇāḥ$ ||</NOTE>
        <TR>Chewable and unchewable food, food to be sipped or sucked or 
                 drunk, as the fifth [category]:</TR>

<TEXT> na kāṅkṣen{ }nopayuñjīta upavāsaḥ sa ucyate||</TEXT> 8:24
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kāṅkṣen{ }no°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                 kāṅkṣe no° \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°yuñjīta</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNb\msPaperA; °\lk\lk ta \msCa,
                                 °yañjīta \msCb, °bhujīta \msNc, °bhuñjīta \msParis\Ed</APP>
         <APP>\vd <LEM>°vāsaḥ sa</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msParis\Ed; °vāsa sa \msNb, °vāsasya \msNc,
                                                        °vāsaṃḥ sa \msPaperA</APP>
        <TR>if one does not long for and does not consume [any of the above],
                 that is called fasting (Łupavāsa$).</TR>



<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣu maunavratam (9)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Ninth Niyama-rule: observing silence</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> mithyāpiśunapāruṣyatīkṣṇavāg{ }apralāpanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°pāruṣya°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis; °saṃbhinnā \msCc, 
                                                        saṃbhinnāṃ \msPaperA, °yābhinnā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°tīkṣṇavāg{ }a°</LEM> \conj; °spṛṣṭavāg{ }a° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis,
                                                    pṛṣṭavāk{ }a° \msCc\msPaperA,
                                                    pṛṣtevāk{ }a° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Łpāruṣya$ seems to be the correct reading in Łpāda$ a, as opposed
                to \msCc's Łsaṃbhinnā$, because in the following 
                a short section on the category of Łpāruṣya$ is coming up (in 8.28).
                As far as the readings Łspṛṣṭavāg$ and Łpṛṣṭavāg$ are concerned, I suppose 
                Łpṛṣṭavāg$ is not inconceivable (as suggested by Judit Törzsök), 
                for in 8.29 it is, in a way, questions that are given as relevant examples. 
                Another possibility, as suggested by Kengo Harimoto, could be Łmṛṣāvāg$ (`lying'),
                although this does not fully fit the corresponding examples.
                All in all, I conjectured Łtīkṣṇavāg$ here, relying on 8.29.
                As it will become clear below, Łapralāpa$ stands for Łasatpralāpa$.
                Compare the five types of Łmaunavrata$ taught here with the four types of
                Łmauna$, as part of the seventh Yama-rule, in \VSS\ 4.68--69 above.</NOTE>
        <TR>One who is steady in his religious observances should observe silence 
                        with regards these five:</TR>

<TEXT> maunapañcakam{ }ity{ }etad{ }dhārayen{ }niyatavrataḥ||</TEXT> 8:25
        <APP>\vc <LEM>maunapañcaka°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb; maunaṃ pañcaka° \msCc\msNa\msNc\msPaperA\Ed,
                                                         maunam{ }pañca° \msParis\oo
                 <LEM>°ty{ }eta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParispcorr\msPaperA\Ed; °ty{ }e° \msParisacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°rayen{ }ni°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA; °rayan{ }ni° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>deceitful speech, malignant speech, insult, abusive speech, and babble.</TR>



<SUBSUBCHAPTER>mithyāvacanam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Deceitful speech</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> asambhūtam{ }adṛṣṭaṃ ca dharmāc{ }cāpi bahiṣkṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dṛṣṭaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; dṛṣṭa<UNCL>ñ{ }ca</UNCL> \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dharmāc{ }cāpi</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis;
                                                                 dharmaś{ }cāpi \msCc\msPaperA, dharmaṃ cāpi \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>bahiṣkṛtam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msParis; bahiṣkṛtaḥ \msCc\Ed, nahiṣkṛtaṃ \msNb,
                                                                     bahiskṛtaṃḥ \msPaperA</APP>
        <TR>Fictitious [speech], [speech about] unknown [things], 
             [speech about things] outside the range of Dharma,</TR>

<TEXT> anarthāpriyavākyaṃ yat tan{ }mithyāvacanaṃ smṛtam||</TEXT> 8:26
        <APP>\vc <LEM>anarthā°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis; anartha° \msCc\msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°vākyaṃ yat{ }tan{ }mi°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msParis\msPaperA;   
                                                vaktāra taṃ mi° \msCc,
                                                vākya yat{ }tan{ }mi° \msNb,
                                                vākyaṃ yan{ }tan{ }mi° \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>smṛtam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; smṛtaḥ \msCb</APP>
        <TR>meaningless and unfriendly speech: these are called deceitful speech.</TR>



<SUBSUBCHAPTER>piśunaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Malignancy</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
% parastrīn \msCa\msNa
<TEXT> paraśrīṃ nābhinandanti parasyaiśvaryam{ }eva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>paraśrīṃ nā°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msParis; parastrī nā° \msCc\msPaperApcorr\Ed,
                                                 parastrīn{ }nā° \msNb, parastrī śrī nā° \msPaperAacorr\oo
                 <LEM>°bhinandanti</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                                 °bhinanti \msCb, °bhinnandanti \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>parasyaiśvarya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                 parasaiśvarya° \msCb</APP>
        <TR>One who does not rejoice in others' fortune or in others' power,</TR>
% plural - singular

<TEXT> aniṣṭadarśanākāṅkṣī piśunaḥ samudāhṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 8:27
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°darśanā°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msParis\Ed; °da<UNCL>bbha</UNCL>nā° \msCc, °darśanāṃ \msNb,
                                                                        °daśanā° \msPaperA</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>piśunaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; piśuna \msCc</APP>
        <TR>one who would like to see something disadvantageous [for others] is called somebody 
                utters malignant speech.</TR>
% kárörvendés !
% mean? Kengo
% darṣanā \msCb


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>pāruṣyam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Insult</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> mṛtamātā pitā caiva hānisthānaṃ kathaṃ bhavet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>mṛta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParisacorr\msPaperA\Ed; mṛtā \msParispcorr</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°sthānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °sthāna \msCb\msCc</APP>
        <TR>`[May your] mother and father be dead! How come you fail?</TR>

<TEXT> bhuṅkṣva kāmam{ }amṛṣṭānāṃ pāruṣyaṃ samudāhṛtam||</TEXT> 8:28
        <APP>\vc <LEM>bhuṅkṣva</LEM>\msNc\msParis; bhuktva \msCa, bhuktvā \msCb\msCc,
                                                bhuṃ<UNCL>kṣa</UNCL> \msNa, bhukṣa \msNb, 
                                                bhu<UNCL>kta</UNCL> \msPaperA, bhuktā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>kāmam{ }amṛṣṭānāṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\msParis\Ed; kamam{ }asṛṣṭānāṃ \msCb,
                                                kāmasusamṛṣtānāṃ \msCc, 
                                                kāmam{ }umṛṣtānā \msNb, 
                                                pāruṣyamṛṣṭanā \msPaperA</APP>
        <NOTE>My translation of Łpāda$ b, or rather of the whole verse, is tentative.
              I am not at all certain that I understand correctly what these abusive phrases imply.
              Should we read Łhā niṣṭhā na kathaṃ bhavet$ (`Oh how could [you] avoid death?') in Łpāda$ b?</NOTE>
        <TR>Enjoy the love of unclean women!' [These are] called insult.</TR>

% external bad things? VS -- >

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>tīkṣṇavāk</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Verbal abuse</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> hṛdi na sphuṭase mūḍha śiro vā na vidāryase|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>sphuṭase</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; sphuṭaya \msNb</APP>
        <TR>`[Why] don't you burst in your heart, stupid? [Why] don't you break your head?'</TR>

<TEXT> evamādīny{ }anekāni tīkṣṇavādī sa ucyate||</TEXT> 8:29
        <TR>[If one utters] these or similar [curses], he is said to be using verbal abuse.</TR>



<SUBSUBCHAPTER>asatpralāpaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Babble</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> dyūtabhojanayuddhaṃ ca madyastrīkatham{ }eva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°yuddhaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA; °yuddhaś \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°katha°</LEM> \msNb\msNc; °kaṣa° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msParis, °karṣa° \msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I take °Łkatham$ in Łpāda$ b as an alternative nominative form of °Łkathā$ metri causa and as 
                belonging to all the categories here thus:
                Łdyūtakathā, bhojanakathā, yuddhakathā, madyakathā, strīkathā$.
                There are various definitions of Łasatpralāpa$, of which the most
                useful for understanding this verse is perhaps
                Siṃhabhūpāla's (\RasarnavaSK\ 3.382--383):
                Łasambaddhakathālāpo 'satpralāpa itīritaḥ$ (`Relating something incoherent is called
                Łasatpralāpa$.') This is illustrated with an incoherent and illogical verse from the play
                ŁVīrabhadravijṛmbhaṇa$. It is possible that what the author of this section
                in the \VSS\ had in mind was boasting about these categories or 
                boastful speech while engaging in activities in connection with them.</NOTE>
        <TR>Stories about gambling, food, fights, drinking, and women</TR>
% talk at time of gambling? Florinda (empty talk?)
%atha asat-pralāpaḥ:
%asambaddha-kathālāpo 'sat-pralāpa itīritaḥ ||3.382||
%yathā vīrabhadravijṛmbhaṇe, naṭaḥ:
%patnī parilambi-kucā tanayā mama danturāpi taruṇa-vayāḥ |
%krīḍā-kapir asti gṛhe tad ahaṃ nāṭya-prayoga-marmajñaḥ ||SRs_3.383||
% atra naṭena svakīya-nāṭya-prayoga-marmajñatve hetutayā kathitānāṃ krīḍā-kapi-sad-bhāvādīnām asambaddhatvād ayam asat-pralāpaḥ |
%"Now: asatpralāpa:
% Illogical prattling is called asatpralāpa ||3.382||
% For example in the Vīrabhadravijṛmbhaṇa the actor says:
% 'My wife has sagging breasts, my daughter is young, although ugly,
%  and there is a performing monkey at home: that's why I know the weak points of a theatrical performance.'
% Here the actor states that the reason for his knowing the weak points of a theatrical performance is the existence of a performing monkey etc. Since there is no coherence/logical connection here, this is asatpralāpa."
% (quasi-incoherent rambling)

% mūrkhajanasannikarṣe hitamapi yatra prabhāṣate vidvān /</l>
% na ca gṛhyate 'sya vacanaṃ vijñeyo 'satpralāpo 'sau // BhN_18.119 //</l>


%index_syntax: split compound

<TEXT> asatpralāpaḥ pañcaitat{ }kīrtitaṃ me dvijottama||</TEXT> 8:30
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>pañcaitat{ }kī°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                         pañcaite kī° \msNb, pañcetat{ }kī° \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>me</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA; te \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE><sep/>
              Note the use of the singular next to a number in Łpāda$ c and
              understand Łme$ in Łpāda$ d as Łmayā$.  The latter usage appears in the epics,
              see <citep>OberliesEpicSkt</citep><pnum>102--103 (4.1.3)</pnum>.</NOTE>
        <TR>are five [examples of] babble. [Thus] have I taught [reasons for observing
                silence], O excellent Brahmin.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā
%index_grammar: singular after numbers, Newari
%index_grammar: me for mayā (Oberlies 4.1.3 [pp. 102--103])

%folioinfo \msCb\ 424.jpg, f.211v
<TEXT> maunam{ }eva sadā kāryaṃ vākyasaubhāgyam{ }icchatā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kāryaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; kāryā \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vākya°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msParis\Ed; vākyaṃ \msCc\msNb\msPaperA\oo
                 <LEM>°saubhāgya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °saubhārya° \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Those who long for eloquent speech should always observe silence.</TR>

%folioinfo \msParis\ (Paris MS) 428.jpg
<TEXT> apāruṣyam{ }asambhinnaṃ vākyaṃ satyam{ }udīrayet||</TEXT> 8:31
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°bhinnaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA; °bhinna \msCc, °digdhaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>One should speak true words without insult and idle talk.</TR>

<TEXT> yas{ }tu maunasya no kartā dūṣitaḥ sa kulādhamaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dūṣitaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA; dūṣita \msCc, bhūṣitaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>He who does not observe silence is defiled and is the black sheep of the family.</TR>


% janme janme is very Aiśa: Niśvāsa, Brahmayāmala
<TEXT> janme janme ca durgandho mūkaś{ }caivopajāyate||</TEXT> 8:32
        <APP>\vc <LEM>janme janme</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msPaperA\Ed; janma janma \msCa\msNb\msNc\msParis\oo
                 <LEM>durgandho</LEM> \msCa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA;
                                         duggandho \msCb, durgandhā \msCc, dugandho \msNa, dṛgandho \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The form Łjanme$ for Łjanmani$ often occurs in Śaiva tantras as a 
                typically Aiśa phenomenon.
                See, e.g., \NISVNAYA\ 1.86a and \BRAYA\ 45.8b, 452a, 559a.
                Thematisation of stems in Ł-an$ occurs also in the epics, see 
                <citep>OberliesEpicSkt</citep><pnum>88 (3.10)</pnum>.</NOTE>
        <TR>For a number of rebirths, [his mouth] will stink and he will become mute.</TR>

                %see <citep>NisvasaGoodall</citep><pnum>114 and 191</pnum>)
                %(Łjanme janme vimūḍhātmā$, 
                %see <citep>KissBraYa</citep><pnum>83 and 128ff</pnum>).
                %(the last one reads Łjanme janme tu yā jātiṃ$, 


<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<LONGVERSELINES/>
%       -  -      - .? . -   . -  .  . .  -   -  - .  -  -  . -  
<TEXT> tasmān{ }maunavrataṃ sadaiva sudṛḍhaṃ kurvīta yo niścitaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tasmān{ }mau°</LEM> \msCc\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                         \lk\lk t{ }mau° \msCa, tasmāt{ }mau° \msCb\msNa\oo
                 <LEM>sadaiva</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msParis\Ed; sadeva \msCc\msNc\msPaperA, sudaitya \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>kurvīta yo niścitam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed;
                                                        kurvanti yen{ }niścitam \msCc\msNa, 
                                                        kurvanti yo{ }nniścita \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \mutacumliquida\ in °Łvrataṃ$: 
              the last syllable of Łmauna$° counts as light.</NOTE>
        <TR>Therefore the speech of a person who observes silence always [at the proper time], firmly,
            with resolution,</TR>

%index_metre: muta cum liquida vr
%index_grammar: muta cum liquida licence vr / unmetrical

        %               \msCa\                 sabhān
<TEXT> vācā tasya alaṅghyatā ca bhavati sarvāṃ sabhāṃ nandati|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>alaṅghyatā ca</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msParis; alaṃghyatāñ{ }ca \msCc\msNc\msPaperA\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>sarvāṃ sabhāṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; sarvā sabhā \msCb\msNc,
                                                                sarvaḥ sabhān \msCc, sarvā subhā \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ b, understand Łnandati$ in a causative sense, or accept the
              reading Łsarvā sabhā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>will become inviolable and [it will cause] everybody in the assembly to rejoice,</TR>
% maybe vācas Judit
% tasya bhavati alaṅghyatā


<TEXT> vaktrāc{ }cotpalagandham{ }asya satataṃ vāyanti gandhotkaṭāḥ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vaktrāc{ }cotpalagandham{ }asya</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\msParisacorr\msPaperA;
                       vaktraṃ cotpalam{ }asya \msCc, vaktraṃ cotpalagandham{ }asya \msNa,
                       vaktraṃ cotpala<UNCL>ga</UNCL>ndham{ }asya \msNb,
                       vaktrāś{ }cotpalagandham{ }asya \msParispcorr,
                       vaktrāc{ }cotaragandham{ }asya \Ed</APP>
        <TR>and the fragrance of lotuses [and other kinds of] rich fragrances will constantly
            blow from his mouth.</TR>

<TEXT> śāstrānekasahasraśo giri naraḥ proccāryate nirmalam||</TEXT> 8:33
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°sahasraśo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis\msPaperA\Ed; °sahasrāśo \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>°malam</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msParis; °malaḥ \msCb\msCc\msPaperA\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>To make sense of Łpāda$ d, we are forced to take Łśāstra$ as a \stemform\ noun 
                and Łnaraḥ$ as a (regular) genitive from Łnṛ$. 
                (I thank Judit Törzsök for this interpretation.)</NOTE>
        <TR>Thousands of faultless Łśāstra$s will be declared in the words of this person.</TR>
