<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> atiguhyam{ }idaṃ praśnaṃ pṛṣṭaḥ snehād{ }dvijottama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>snehād{ }dvi°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; snehā dvi° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>This question is an extremely deep secret.
                 [Now that you] ask [me], O excellent Brahmin,</TR>

<TEXT> bravīmi vaḥ purāvṛttaṃ nandinā kathito 'smy{ }aham||</TEXT> 10:2
        <APP>\vd <LEM>'smy{ }aham</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; smṛham \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>On the syntax of Łpāda$ d, see pp.~\pageref{kathita} ff.</NOTE>
        <TR>I shall teach you, out of fondness, an ancient legend that Nandi told me.</TR>

<TEXT> nandikeśvara uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>nandi°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; nandī° \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the change of speaker here: Nandikeśvara is also the main
              interlocutor of the \SDHS\ and the \SDHSAMGR.
              This verse marks the beginning of the layer that can be labelled Śaiva
              (see pp.~\pageref{structure} ff).
              On Nandi/Nandin/Nandikeśvara not being Śiva's bull, see
              <cite>bhattacharya_nandin_1977</cite> and pp.~\pageref{bull} ff. above.</NOTE>
        <TR>Nandikeśvara spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> kailāsaśikhare ramye siddhacāraṇasevite|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kailāsa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; kailāśe \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł \compare\ MBh 12.327.18cd:$ merau girivare ramye siddhacāraṇasevite </PARAL>
        <TR>On the beautiful peak of Mount Kailāsa, which is
                 frequented by Siddhas and celestial singers (Łcāraṇa$),</TR>

<TEXT> tatrāsīnaṃ śivaṃ sākṣād{ }devī vacanam{ }abravīt||</TEXT> 10:3
        <TR>Devī asked Śiva, who was sitting there in his manifest form (Łsākṣāt$).</TR>
% abravīta \msNc

<TEXT> devy{ }uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Devī spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> bhagavan{ }devadeveśa sarvabhūtajagatpate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°deveśa</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °deśa \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°pate</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed; °patim \msNaacorr</APP>
        <TR>O Lord, Lord of the chiefs of the gods, O ruler of all beings and of the whole world,</TR>

<TEXT> praṣṭum{ }icchāmy{ }ahaṃ tv{ }ekaṃ dharmaguhyaṃ sanātanam||</TEXT> 10:4
        <APP>\vc <LEM>dharma°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; dha<UNCL>rmaṃ</UNCL> \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>It is not unlikely that in Łpāda$ d, Łsanātanam$ was intended to refer to
              Łdharma$° (`eternal Dharma'), or that Łdharmaguhya$ should be corrected
              to Łdharmaṃ guhyaṃ$ (`\dots~ask you about the secret and eternal Dharma').</NOTE>
        <TR>I would like to ask you about an eternal secret concerning Dharma,</TR>
% \msNa has an interesting character after dharma

<TEXT> atitīrthaṃ paraṃ guhyaṃ saṃsārād{ }yena mucyate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°tīrthaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °tīrtha \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>guhyaṃ saṃsārād{ }yena mucyate</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; 
                                <UNCL>ga</UNCL>\lac × <UNCL>saṃ</UNCL>sārād{ }yena mucyate \msNb</APP>
        <TR>about the transcendental and highly secret pilgrimage place at which one
                 can be liberated from mundane existence (Łsaṃsāra$).</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 55.jpg upper
<TEXT> manuṣyāṇāṃ hitārthāya brūhi tattvaṃ maheśvara||</TEXT> 10:5
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°śvara</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °śvaraḥ \msCc</APP>
        <TR>O Maheśvara, teach me the truth for the benefit of mankind.</TR>


<TEXT> maheśvara uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Maheśvara spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> ko māṃ pṛcchati taṃ praśnaṃ muktvā tvām{ }eva sundari|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>taṃ praśnaṃ</LEM> \msNa\msNb; tat{ }praśna \msCa\msCb, tat{ }praśnaṃ \msCc\Ed, 
                                                                taṃ praśna \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>muktvā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; muktā \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Who else could ask me that question except for you, O Sundarī?</TR>

<TEXT> śṛṇu vakṣyāmi taṃ praśnaṃ devair{ }api sudurlabham||</TEXT> 10:6
        <APP>\vc <LEM>taṃ praśnaṃ</LEM> \msNc; tat{ }praśnaṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed</APP>
        <TR>Listen, I shall expound that question, which is difficult to grasp even for the gods.</TR>

<TEXT> kurukṣetraṃ prayāgaṃ ca vārāṇasīm{ }ataḥ param|</TEXT>
        <TR>If one gets to know Kurukṣetra, Prayāga, Vārāṇasī,</TR>

<TEXT> gaṅgāgniṃ somatīrthaṃ ca sūryapuṣkaramānasam||</TEXT> 10:7
        <APP>\vc <LEM>gaṅgāgniṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb; gaṅgāgni \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, gaṅgā'gni° \Ed </APP>
        <TR>Gaṅgā, Agni[tīrtha], Somatīrtha, Sūrya[tīrtha], Puṣkara, Mānasa,</TR>

<TEXT> naimiṣaṃ bindusāraṃ ca setubandhaṃ suradraham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>naimiṣaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; nemisa \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°bandhaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °bandha° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°draham </LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °hradaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łbindusāraṃ$ for Łbindusaras/°saraṃ/°sarasaṃ$ metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>Naimiṣa, Bindusaras, Setubandha, Suradraha,</TR>

%index_metre: lengthtening of vowel metri causa (bindusāraṃ)

<TEXT> ghaṇṭikeśvaravāgīśaṃ jñātvā niścayapāpahā||</TEXT> 10:8
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vāgīśaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; \lac ×<UNCL>gīśa</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>niścayapāpahā</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 niśca<UNCL>ya</UNCL>\lk\lk\lk\  \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>Although some of these toponyms are difficult to identify and some may refer to
              southern locations (e.g. Setubandha), in general they suggest a North Indian focus.
              See details on the pilgrimage places in this chapter on pp.~\pageref{provenance} ff.</NOTE>
        <TR>Ghaṇṭikeśvara, and Vāgīśa, one will certainly be able to destroy one's sins.</TR>


%folioinfo \Ed\ p.611
%folioinfo \msCa\ 410.jpg
<TEXT> umovāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Umā spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> evamādi mahādeva pūrvavat{ }kathitāsmy{ }aham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kathitā°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc; kathito \msCb\msNb\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I take Łpūrvavat$ in Łpāda$ b as if used in the sense of Łpūrvaṃ$ (`previously'),
              and Łeteṣāṃ$ in Łpāda$ d as Łeteṣu$.  It would also be possible to take Łeteṣāṃ$
              in 10.9d and Łjñānamātreṇa$ in 10.10b as connected (`by the 
              mere knowledge of them'; actually, one should understand 
              Łsvargabhogapradānāṃ tīrthānām eteṣāṃ$),
              but the former solution, namely taking Łeteṣāṃ$ as Łeteṣu$,
              seems to work also in 10.14, where again a genitive (Łteṣāṃ$) 
              may stand for a locative (Łteṣu$). On the syntax of Łpāda$ b,
              see p.~\pageref{kathita}.</NOTE>
        <TR>I have been taught this previously, O Mahādeva.</TR>

%index_grammar: genitive for locative

<TEXT> svargabhogapradaṃ tīrtham{ }eteṣāṃ suranāyaka||</TEXT> 10:9
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>tīrtham{ }e°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; tīrthaṃm{ }e° \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>suranāyaka</LEM> \msCapcorr\msNa\msNc; suranāka \msCaacorr, suranāyakam \msCb\msCc\msNb\Ed</APP>
        <TR>[Which is] the pilgrimage place that yields all kinds of enjoyment, O Suranāyaka?</TR>

<TEXT> kathaṃ mucyeta saṃsārāj{ }jñānamātreṇa īśvara|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kathaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; katha \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>jñāna°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; jñāta° \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>īśvara</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; ceśvara \msNa</APP>
        <TR>[And] how is one liberated from mundane existence by merely knowing [the pilgrimage places], O Īśvara?</TR>

%index_grammar: lack of sandhi in pāda d

<TEXT> kautūhalaṃ mahaj{ }jātaṃ chindhi saṃśayakārakam||</TEXT> 10:10
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>kautūhalaṃ mahaj{ }jātaṃ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\Ed; kautūhalam{ }ma<UNCL>ho</UNCL>j{ }jātaṃ \msNa, 
                                kauhalam{ }mahaj{ }jātaṃ \msNbacorr,
                                kau<UNCL>tū</UNCL>halam{ }mahaj{ }jātaṃ \msNbpcorr,
                                kotūhalaṃ mahaj{ }jātaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°kārakam</LEM> \Ed; °kāraka \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc, °kārakaḥ \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>We are forced to agree with \Ed's printing °Łkārakam$ in Łpāda$ d because
              all the other readings seem out of context, whether they refer to Śiva
              in the vocative or nominative.</NOTE>
        <TR>Cut [this] great curiosity arising [in me] that causes doubt.</TR>

<TEXT> rudra uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Rudra spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> kiṃ na jānāmi tat{ }tīrthaṃ sulabhaṃ durlabhaṃ ca yat|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>jānāmi</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb; jānā<UNCL>mi</UNCL> \msNaacorr, jānā<UNCL>si</UNCL> \msNapcorr, 
                                                                                jānāsi \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>durlabhaṃ ca</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\Ed; dulabhañ{ }ca \msCb\msNc, dullabhañ{ }ca \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łsevīnāṃ$ for Łsevināṃ$ in Łpāda$ c metri causa.
             <sep/>My translation here is slightly tentative and is fashioned to make sense
              in light of what is coming: the praise of internalised pilgrimage places,
              contrasting them with real, external pilgrimage places.</NOTE>
        <TR>How could I not know [the difference between] that pilgrimage place that is easy to reach 
                 and that which is difficult to reach?</TR>

<TEXT> sulabhaṃ gurusevīnāṃ durlabhaṃ tad{ }vivarjayet||</TEXT> 10:11
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>sulabhaṃ gurusevīnāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                    \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk vīnāṃ \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°varjayet</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; °varjaye \msNa, °varjanāt \Ed</APP>
        <TR>It is easy to reach for those who serve their guru. One can abandon the one
                 which is difficult to reach.</TR>

%index_metre: lengthening of vowel metri causa
% dulabhaṃ \msNc


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>kurukṣetram</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Kurukṣetra</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> kuruḥ puruṣa vijñeyaḥ śarīraṃ kṣetra ucyate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kuruḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; guruḥ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>puruṣa</LEM> \Ed; puruṣaḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\ \unmetr, puruṣo \msNc\ \unmetr</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śarīraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; śarī<UNCL>ra</UNCL> \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>kṣetra ucyate</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; kṣetram{ }ucyate \msNa</APP>
        <PARAL>\vb Ł\compare\ \BHG\ 13.1:$
                        idaṃ śarīraṃ kaunteya kṣetram{ }ity{ }abhidhīyate|
                        etad{ }yo vetti taṃ prāhuḥ kṣetrajña iti tadvidaḥ||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ b, one could apply \msNa's reading that has the standard neuter nominative form Łkṣetram$
              as opposed to the form transmitted in all other witnesses (Łkṣetra$) but
              the latter might be original, influenced by the \stemform\ Łpuruṣa$ in Łpāda$ a.</NOTE>
        <TR>ŁKuru$- [in Kurukṣetra] is to be known as the soul (Łpuruṣa$), 
                        -Łkṣetra$ as the body.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa 
%index_geo: Kurukṣetra

%folioinfo \msNa\ 208.jpg lower, f.15r
<TEXT> śarīrasthaṃ kurukṣetraṃ sarvatīrthaphalapradam||</TEXT> 10:12
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°sthaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °stha \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°kṣetraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °kṣetra \msNc</APP>
        <TR>Kurukṣetra that is in the body yields the fruits of [visiting] all pilgrimage places.</TR>
% Which BhG commentator started to talk about Kurukṣetra being in the body?

<TEXT> sarvayajñaphalāvāptiḥ sarvadānaphalāni ca|</TEXT>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\similar\ \UMS\ 21.48cd:$
                                sarvayajñaphalāvāptiḥ sarvadānaphalaṃ labhet</PARAL>
        <TR>[And there will be] the obtaining of the fruits of all sacrifices,
                        the fruits of all [possible] donations,</TR>


% cīrṇṇaṃn \msCa
<TEXT> sarvavratatapaś{ }cīrṇaṃ tatphalaṃ sakalaṃ bhavet||</TEXT> 10:13
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tatphalaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; tatphala \msNc</APP>
        <TR>and all the fruits of all religious observances and penance performed.</TR>

<TEXT> evam{ }eva phalaṃ teṣāṃ tīrthapañcadaśeṣu ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tīrthapañcadaśeṣu</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; tīrthampaṃcadaśaiṣu \msCb</APP>
        <TR>This is how the fruits [are said to be also] in the case of those fifteen
                pilgrimage places [from Kurukṣetra to Vāgīśa]. </TR>

%index_grammar: genitive for locative?

%folioinfo \msCc\ 212.jpg 
% for anaghaṃ? or accept \msNb?
<TEXT> anaghānaṃ mahāpuṇyaṃ mahātīrthaṃ mahāsukham||</TEXT> 10:14
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>anaghānaṃ mahāpuṇyaṃ</LEM> \msCb\msNc; \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk puṇya \msCa,
                                anapyām{ }mahāpuṇyaṃ \msCc\ \hypermetr,
                                anadhyānaṃ mahāpuṇyaṃ \msNa, adhvānan{ }tu mahāpuṇyaṃ \msNb,
                                snānadhyānaṃ mahāpuṇyaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Łanaghānaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c is problematic. It may simply stand for Łanaghaṃ$ (`faultless').
              That is how I translate it. Originally it may have involved a \stemform\ adjective:
              Łanaghaitan$ (Łanagha + etad$).</NOTE>
        <TR>[Kurukṣetra,] the great and faultless pilgrimage place is extremely auspicious and pleasant.</TR>



<TEXT> devy{ }uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Devī spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> atīva romaharṣo me jāto 'sti tridaśeśvara|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>atīva</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; avīva \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>'sti</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; smi \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>tridaśeśvara</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; tridaśeśvaraḥ \msCc, tri\lac × śeśvara \msNb</APP>
        <TR>I am extremely thrilled, O Tridaśeśvara.</TR>

<TEXT> sulabhaṃ sukaraṃ sūkṣmaṃ śrutvā tuṣṭiś{ }ca me gatā||</TEXT> 10:15
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tuṣṭiś{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; tuṣṭiñ{ }ca \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>gatā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; gatāḥ \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>We could read Łśrutvātuṣṭiś$ (i.e. Łśrutvā-atuṣṭiś$) in Łpāda$ d
              (`hearing this, my discontent is gone'), but interlocutors in this
              text usually want to hear more when they are still unsatisfied, and
              hungry for more teaching. See, e.g., <cite>KissVolume2021</cite>.
              (Or shall we read Łśrutvātuṣṭiś ca me 'gatā$, `hearing this my
              discontent has not yet disappeared'?)</NOTE>
        <TR>Hearing about that which is easy to obtain, easy to perform, and is subtle,
                 my contentment has left me [that is, I want to hear more].</TR>

%folioinfo \msNc\ 225.jpg lower, f. 223r
%folioinfo \msM\ 424.jpg lower, f. 16r 
<TEXT> caturdaśa paro bhūyaḥ kathayasva manoharam|</TEXT>
        <NOTE>Note again the use of the singular next to numbers (Łcaturdaśa \dots\ manoharam prayāgādi$),
              a frequent phenomenon in this text.</NOTE>
        <TR>Teach me further about the remaining fourteen pleasant [pilgrimage places],</TR>

%index_grammar: singular after numbers, Newari

<TEXT> prayāgādi pṛthaktvena tattvatas{ }tu sureśvara||</TEXT> 10:16
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tattvatas{ }tu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed; tatvata \msNaacorr</APP>
        <TR>Prayāga and the others, one by one, as they really are, O Sureśvara.</TR>





<SUBSUBCHAPTER>prayāgo vārāṇasī ca</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Prayāga and Vārāṇasī</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> rudra uvāca|*</TEXT>

<TEXT> suṣumnā bhagavatī gaṅgā iḍā ca yamunā nadī|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>suṣumnā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; suṣumṇā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>bhagavatī gaṅgā</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\ \unmetr;
                                                 bhagavatī ga\lk\ \msCa, bhavatī gaṅgā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>There seems to be only two yogic tubes mentioned 
              here (and in 10.20--21, and 11.21): Suṣumnā and Iḍā, instead 
              of the more usual triad of Iḍā, Piṅgalā, 
              and Suṣumnā. This is strikingly similar to
              what we see in the archaic yoga of the \NISVNAYA, 
              see 
              <citep>NisvasaGoodall</citep><pnum>33--34</pnum>.
              According to 
              <citep>BaroisDhP</citep><pnum>23 and 46</pnum> 
              the case is similar in the \DHARMP.
              This is slightly doubtful because a third tube, 
              called Turyā, is mentioned immediately after
              Iḍā and Suṣumnā in \DHARMP\ 4.57: 
        <sep/>
                Łiḍā vāmā suṣumnā ca dve nāḍī nāsikāśrite$ | <br/>
                Łbhruvor madhye parā nāḍī tajjñais turyeti kīrttitā$ ||
        <sep/>
            It is also possible that the third tube is there, 
            as Prayāga, in our obscure \VSS\ 10.17cd,
            which may want to say that at the confluence of 
            the Gaṅgā/Suṣumnā and the Yamunā/Iḍā,
            there is the internalised pilgrimage place, 
            or tube, called Prayāga.
         Compare \MBH\ Suppl. 6.3A.41--44:
        <sep/>
        Łiḍā bhagavatī gaṅgā piṅgalā yamunā nadī$ |<br/>
        Łtayor madhye tṛtīyā tu tat prayāgam anusmaret$ ||<br/>
        Łiḍā vai vaiṣṇavī nāḍī brahmanāḍī tu piṅgalā$ |<br/>
        Łsuṣumṇā caiśvarī nāḍī tridhā prāṇavahā smṛtā$ ||
        <sep/>
         Note that Yamunā has not been mentioned as 
         a Łtīrtha$ in \VSS\ 10.7--8 above.
        See also \HYP\ 3.110:
        <sep/>
        Łiḍā bhagavatī gaṅgā piṅgalā yamunā nadī$ | <br/>
        Łiḍāpiṅgalayor madhye bālaraṇḍā ca kuṇḍalī$ ||
 
        Note also \Ed's attempt to make Łpāda$ a metrical.</NOTE>
        <TR>The Suṣumnā[-tube] is the Honourable Gaṅgā, Iḍā[-tube] 
                     is the river Yamunā.</TR>

% maybe Bhāgmatī?
%index_geo: Yamunā

% srotovahā?
<TEXT> etāḥ srotovahā nadyaḥ prayāgaḥ sa vidhīyate||</TEXT> 10:17
        <APP>\vc <LEM>etāḥ srotovahā</LEM> \eme; etā śrotavahā \msCa\msNc\Ed, 
                                        ete śrotāvahā \msCb\msCc, etā śrotravahā \msNa\msNb</APP>
                <TR>[At the confluence of] these surging rivers is [the pilgrimage place] called Prayāga.</TR>
                % a line dropped out?

%index_geo: Prayāga


<TEXT> dakṣiṇā vāruṇī nāsā vāmanāsā asi smṛtā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dakṣiṇā</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dakṣi<UNCL>ṇaṃ</UNCL> \msCa, dakṣiṇaṃ \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>vāruṇī</LEM> \msNapcorr\msNc\Ed; varuṇī \msCa\msCc\msNaacorr\msNb, varuṇā \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°nāsā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °nā \msCb\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>This verse most probably describes the spot between the eyebrows as an
                internalised pilgrimage place.</NOTE>
        <TR>The right nostril is [the river] Vāruṇī, the left nostril is known as [the river] Asi.</TR>
% \msCb and \msNb often go together

% internal sandhi! 
<TEXT> vāruṇā-asimadhyena tena vārāṇasī smṛtā||</TEXT> 10:18
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>vāruṇā-asimadhyena</LEM> \Ed; varuṇā asimadhyena \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc,
                                                vāruṇan{ }nāsamadhyeta \msCc,
                                                varuṇa asimadhyena \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Because [it is] at the confluence of Vāruṇā and Asi,
                        [the city/internalised pilgrimage place there] is known as Vārāṇasī.</TR>
% vārānasī \msNc

%index_geo: Vārāṇasī

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>gaṅgā</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Gaṅgā</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> ākāśagaṅgā vikhyātā tasyāḥ sravati cāmṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tasyāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; tasmā \msCc, tasyā \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>This verse may describe a bodily location such as the soft palate as an
              internalised pilgrimage place.</NOTE>
        <TR>[There is] the famous ethereal Gaṅgā. The nectar of immortality issues from her</TR>

<TEXT> ahorātram{ }avicchinnaṃ gaṅgā sā tena ucyate||</TEXT> 10:19
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tena</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; te \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>The word Łgaṅga$ is interpreted here as an intensive form from the root\verbalroot{Łgam$},
              related to the better-attested intensive stems Łjaṅgam$ and Łganīgam$ (see the latter two, e.g., in 
              <citep>WhitneyGrammar</citep><pnum>§1003</pnum>).</NOTE>
        <TR>day and night uninterruptedly. That is why [this internalised pilgrimage place] is called Gaṅgā.</TR>

%index_geo: Gaṅgā

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>somatīrtham</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Somatīrtha</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> somatīrtham{ }iḍā nāḍī kiṅkiṇīravacihnitā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°tīrtham{ }iḍā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °tīrtha iḍā \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kiṅkiṇī°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ciñcinī° \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°rava°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °ravi° \msCbacorr, °rāva° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°cihnitā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °cihnikā \msCc, °cihnatā \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that Iḍā has already been identified as the Yamunā in 10.17b.</NOTE>
        <TR>Somatīrtha is the tube Iḍā. It is characterised by the ringing of small bells.</TR>

<TEXT> taṃ tu śrutvā na saṃdehaḥ sarvapāpakṣayo bhavet||</TEXT> 10:20
        <APP>\vc <LEM>taṃ tu</LEM> \corr; <UNCL>tan{ }tu</UNCL> \msCa, tan{ }tu \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed, 
                                                                                ta<UNCL>t{ }tu</UNCL> \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>na saṃdehaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; varāroheḥ \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Upon hearing that [ringing], all of one's sins will be destroyed.</TR>

%index_geo: Somatīrtha

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>sūryatīrtham</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Sūryatīrtha</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> sūryatīrthaṃ suṣumnā ca nīravāravasaṃyutā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°tīrthaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °tīrtha \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>suṣumnā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; suṣumṇā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>nīravā°</LEM> \Ed; vīravā° \msCa\msCc, cīravā° \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°yutā</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; °yutam \msCb\msCc, °yutāṃ \msNb</APP>
         <NOTE>Suṣumnā has already been identified as the Gaṅgā in 10.17a.</NOTE>
%Łnīravā-rava$ in Łpāda$ b probably stands for Łnīrava-rava$ metri causa.
        <TR>Sūryatīrtha is the [tube] Suṣumnā, the one that emits a soundless thunder.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 428.jpg 
<TEXT> śrutimātrād{ }vimucyeta pāparāśir{ }mahān{ }api||</TEXT> 10:21
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°mātrā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °mātā° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>One is liberated by merely hearing it, even if one has mountains of sin.</TR>

%index_geo: Sūryatīrtha

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>agnitīrtham</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Agnitīrtha</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
% Prāṇāgnihotra (Muktabodha, line 129): somatīrthamagnitīrthaṃ śarīre tu sadāsthitam | 
% but Agnitīrtha also in MBh and Purāṇas, see also Purāṇic Enc

<TEXT> agnitīrthārjunā nāḍī brahmaghoṣamanoramā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°rjunā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °junā \msCc, °rjunaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°ramā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; °ramāḥ \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Łagnitīrtha$ is most probably in \stemform\ in Łpāda$ a.
              <sep/>  
              I am not aware of any yogic teachings that involve a Łnāḍī$ called Łarjunā$.
              Maybe Łaruṇā$ or Łvaruṇā$ was meant? A Łvāruṇī nāḍī$ does occur in 
              some texts, such as the \YogasikhaU\ (5.26, <citep>YogaUpanisads</citep><pnum>444</pnum>), 
              the \Hatharatnavali\ (4.34--35, <citep>RootsOfYoga</citep><pnum>5.1.10</pnum>), 
              and the \Sivasamhita\ (2.15, ibid. 5.2.4). On the other hand,     
              `red' (Łaruṇa$) would be an appropriate label for Agnitīrtha,
              not to mention that fact that it is a synonym of Łpiṅgala$, 
              the name of the Łnāḍī$ that is conspicuously missing in this chapter
              and in 11.21.</NOTE>
        <TR>Agnitīrtha is the Arjuna tube. It is charming because of the hum of 
                        Veda recitation.</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.612
<TEXT> tat{ }tad{ }akṣaram{ }ākarṇya amṛtatvāya kalpate||</TEXT> 10:22
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°karṇya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °rṇya \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kalpate</LEM> \msCb\msNc\Ed; ka\lk \lac\ × \msCa, kalpyate \msCc\msNa\msNb</APP>
        <TR>Upon hearing this or that syllable, one's share  will be immortality.</TR>

%index_geo: Agnitīrtha



<SUBSUBCHAPTER>puṣkaram</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Puṣkara</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> puṣkaraṃ hṛdi madhyastham{ }aṣṭapattraṃ sakarṇikam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°pattraṃ</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; \lk\lk\ \msCa, °patra \msCc\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°karṇikam</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \lk\lk\lk\  \msCa, °karṇikām \Ed</APP>
%        \vab Łillegible in $ \msCa
        <NOTE>Łhṛdi$ was probably meant to be nominative, as in 10.27, 
              here potentially compounded with Łmadhyastham$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Puṣkara is a lotus with eight petals and a pericarp in the centre of the heart.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem hṛdi?

<TEXT> cintayet{ }sūkṣma tanmadhye janmamṛtyuvināśanam||</TEXT> 10:23
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sūkṣma</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; <UNCL>sūkṣma</UNCL> \msCa, sūkṣmaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>On Łsūkṣma$ (here in \stemform\ metri causa), see \CHECK.</NOTE>
        <TR>One should visualize the Subtle One in its centre. It will destroy birth and death.</TR>
% tatmadhye \msNc

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa 
%index_geo: Puṣkara

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>mānasam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Mānasa</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> mānasasaramadhyasthaṃ sa haṃsaḥ kamalopari|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>mānasa°</LEM> \msCb\msNa; <UNCL>mānasa</UNCL> \msCa, mānasaṃ \msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sa haṃsaḥ</LEM> \conj; sahaṃsa° \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed, sahasaṃ \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łmānasasara$° in Łpāda$ a as Łmānasasaro$° (metri causa).
              To make sense of this verse, especially the masculine nominatives in
              Łpāda$s cd, I have conjectured Łsa haṃsaḥ$ for what seems to 
              a compound: Łsahaṃsakamalopari$. I suspect Łpāda$ a to qualify, clumsily,
              Łkamala$ in Łpāda$ b. Other possibilities include Łsahaṃsa$° meaning
              `with the syllables HAṂ and SA on it.' 

              The association of Lake Mānasa on Mount Kailāsa with lotuses, and especialy with geese or swans, is
              well-known. See, e.g., \MBH\ 6.114.90ff: Gaṅgā sends the great sages, who inhabit
              Lake Mānasa in the form of geese, to visit the dying Bhīṣma.
              Although the interpretation of this verse, which obviously refers to an internalised
              form of this pilgrimage place, is still problematic, the goose/swan
              most probably signifies to the soul.</NOTE>
        <TR>That goose on a lotus in the middle of the Mānasa lake</TR>

<TEXT> salīlo līlayācārī parataḥ parapāragaḥ||</TEXT> 10:24
        <APP>\vc <LEM>salīlo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; salīlā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>parataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; parata \msNb</APP>
        <TR>is playful, acting gracefully, rising far beyond the other shore.</TR>

%index_geo: Mānasa (lake/tīrtha)

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>naimiṣam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Naimiṣa</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> naimiṣaṃ śṛṇu deveśi nimiṣā pratyayo bhavet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>nimiṣā pratyayo bhavet</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; nimi pratyayo bhavet \msCb,
                                             ni\lac ×<UNCL>ṣo</UNCL> pratyayo <UNCL>bhavet</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Listen to Naimiṣa, O Deveśī. It yields assurance in a moment.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 56.jpg lower
<TEXT> samyag{ }chāyāṃ nirīkṣeta ātmāno vā parasya vā||</TEXT> 10:25
        <APP>\vd <LEM>ātmano</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \lk nmano \msCa, svātmāno \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>parasya vā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; parasya ca \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>This obscure verse (coupled with the next one) might have something to do with a type of
              meditation, Łchāyādhyāna$, mentioned in \NISVUTTARA\ 5.6:
        <sep/>
             Łtattvadhyānaṃ prathamakaṃ chāyādhyānaṃ dvitīyakam$ |<br/>
             Łghoṣadhyānan tṛtīyan tu lakṣadhyānañ caturthakam$ ||
        <sep/>
                   Later on in the same text (5.12 and 16), this meditation on `the shadow of the 
                   soul/Łpuruṣa$' is mentioned again.
                   \NISVUTTARA\ 5.16 states that 
                   `[f]ocussing on[?] one's awareness on [one's] ``shadow'' (Łchāyācittam$),
                    one will see the soul (Łpumān$ = Łpumāṃsam$?) in the sky (Łviyatstham$).
                           Practising in this way, one attains success and becomes Śiva.' 
                           (Translation from <citep>NisvasaGoodall</citep><pnum>391</pnum>.)
                          The Sanskrit reads:
        <sep/>
                         Łchāyācittaṃ samālambya viyatsthaṃ paśyate pumān$ |<br/>
                         Łevam abhyasyamānas tu siddhyate ca śivo bhavet$ ||
        <sep/>
                          But as the editors of the \NISV\ put it with reference to the
                          four elements of meditation given there:
                           `[v]ery little of this is clear and almost nothing is certain'
                           (<citep>NisvasaGoodall</citep><pnum>389</pnum>).</NOTE>
        <TR>One can observe the shadow of one's own and others' soul properly.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ jpg.411
<TEXT> āyatam{ }aṅgulīmātraṃ nimiṣākṣiḥ sa paśyati|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>āyatam{ }aṅgulī°</LEM> \conj; āyatapy{ }aṅgulī° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb,
                                                āyātapy{ }aṅgulī° \msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°mātraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; °mātra \msNc, °madhye \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kṣiḥ</LEM> \eme; °kṣi \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$s ab involve an emendation and a conjecture, without which it is
              difficult to understand this line.</NOTE>
        <TR>He will see [the soul's] length with his eyes shut as one finger-breadth.</TR>

<TEXT> dṛṣṭvā pratyayam{ }evaṃ hi naimiṣajñaḥ sa ucyate||</TEXT> 10:26
        <APP>\vd <LEM>naimiṣajñaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; naimisaṃjñaḥ \msCb, naimiṣajña \msCc</APP>
        <TR>When one has seen the proof thus, one is called the knower of Naimiṣa.</TR>

%index_geo: Naimiṣa


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>bindusaraḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Bindusaras</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> tīrthaṃ bindusaraṃ nāma śṛṇu vakṣyāmi sundari|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tīrthaṃ bindu°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tīrtham{ }indu° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand °Łsaraṃ$ in Łpāda$ a as °Łsaro$ (thematisation).</NOTE>
        <TR>Listen, O Sundarī, I shall teach you the pilgrimage place called Bindusaras.</TR>

%index_voc: sara for saras (thematisation)

<TEXT> dehamadhye hṛdi jñeyaṃ hṛdimadhye tu paṅkajam||</TEXT> 10:27
        <APP>\vc <LEM>hṛdi jñeyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msCb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare\ \NISVK\ 5.55:$
                eteṣāṃ nādamadhye tu śivaṃ tatra vyavasthitaḥ|
                hṛdayaṃ dehamadhye tu tatra padmaṃ vyavasthitam||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Take Łhṛdi$ as a nominative in Łpāda$ c and possibly also in Łpāda$ d (and see 10.23a).</NOTE>
        <TR>The heart is to be known to be located in the centre of the body.
                 In the centre of the heart, there is a lotus.</TR>


%index_grammar: stem hṛdi?

<TEXT> karṇikā padmamadhye tu binduḥ karṇikamadhyataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°madhye</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dhye \msCa, °padhye \msNa</APP>
        <TR>There is a pericarp in the centre of the lotus, and the subtle sonic matter (Łbindu$)
                                in the centre of the pericarp.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 213.jpg 
<TEXT> bindumadhye sthito nādaḥ sa nādaḥ kena bhidyate||</TEXT> 10:28
        <APP>\vc <LEM>bindumadhye</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; <UNCL>bindu</UNCL>\lk\lk\ \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>bhidyate</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; <UNCL>vi</UNCL>dyate \msCa, vidyate \msCc</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare\ \NISVK\ 5.56:$
                karṇikā padmamadhye tu akāraṃ tasya madhyataḥ|
                tasya madhye viniṣkrāntaṃ nādaṃ paramadurlabham||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>For a general discussion on Łnāda$ and Łbindu$, see, e.g., \TAKIII\ s.v. Łnāda$.
              Our text considers the internalised manifestation of the pilgrimage place Bindusaras
              to be Łbindu$, or subtle sonic matter.</NOTE>
        <TR>In the centre of the subtle sonic matter (Łbindu$), there is the subtle sound (Łnāda$).
                How is that subtle sound (Łnāda$) divided?</TR>


<TEXT> ukāraṃ ca makāraṃ ca bhittvā nādo vinirgataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>ukāraṃ ca makāraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ukāraś{ }ca makāraś \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł= \NISVK\ 5.57ab$</PARAL>
        <TR>The subtle sound (Łnāda$) departs divided by the sounds U and M.</TR>

<TEXT> taṃ viditvā viśālākṣi so 'mṛtatvaṃ labheta ca||</TEXT> 10:29
        <APP>\vd <LEM>so 'mṛtatvaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; somyatatvaṃ \msCc, somatatvaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; vā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>\VSS\ 10.27--29ab seem to paraphrase \NISVK\ 5.55--57ab.</NOTE>
        <TR>Realizing that [subtle sound], O Viśālākṣi, one can obtain immortality.</TR>


%index_geo: Bindusaras

%folioinfo \msNa\ 209.jpg upper, f.15v
<SUBSUBCHAPTER>setubandham</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Setubandha</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<NOTANUSTUBH/> sragdharā
<LONGVERSELINES/>
%       -   -  -  - . -   -   . . . . . . -   - . - -  . - -
<TEXT> vakṣye te setubandhaṃ duritamalaharaṃ nādatoyapravāhaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>te</LEM> \mssALL\msCapcorr\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msCaacorr, haṃ \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°bandhaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °bandhūṃ \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>°toya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °toyaṃ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>I shall teach you Setubandha, which sports a current whose water of subtle sound (Łnāda$) 
                                cleanses you of the dirt of your sins.</TR>

<TEXT> jihvākaṇṭhorakūlā svaragaṇapulināvartaghoṣā taraṅgā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kaṇṭhora°</LEM> \conj; °kaṇṭhoru° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>svara°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; sura° \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that °Łkaṇṭhora$° is a conjecture based on the context: this line
                        speaks about sounds and the production of sounds. For this,
                        Łuraḥ$/Łura$ (`chest') seems better that Łūru$ (`thigh').
              It is not evident at first sight why Łpāda$s b and c stick to feminine endings. I take this
              as qualifying an implied Łnadī$, partly because the similarly structured 10.33 below
              explicitly mentions Łnadī$. Some of the compounds here are inverted or split:
              understand Łāvartaghoṣā taraṅgā$ as Łghoṣāvartataraṅgā$, 
              Łkumbhīrāghoṣamīnā$ as Łaghoṣakumbhīramīnā$, and 
              Łbhīmanakrā visargā$ as Łvisargabhīmanakrā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>[It is a river whose] banks are the tongue, the throat, and the chest, and
                 its sandbanks are the group of vowels (Łsvara$). It is wavy with its whirlpools 
                 of voiced consonants (Łghoṣa$).</TR>

<TEXT> kumbhīrāghoṣamīnā daśagaṇamakarā bhīmanakrā visargā</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°mīnā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °mānā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>daśa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \lk\lk\ \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>visargā</LEM> \mssCaCbCc; visargāḥ \msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>Voiceless consonants (Łaghoṣa$) are its crocodiles and fish, 
                 the ten verbal classes (Łgaṇa$) are its sea-monsters,
                 Łvisarga$s are its terrifying alligators.</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 425.jpg upper, f. 16v 
% gabhīra is Vedic
%       - -  - -  . -  -  . . . . . . -   - . - -  . - -
<TEXT> sānusvāre gabhīre madasukharasanaṃ setubandhaṃ vrajasva||</TEXT> 10:30
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°svāre</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; °sāre \msCc,
                                         °svāro \msNa, °svā<UNCL>reṇa</UNCL> \msNb\ \unmetr\oo
                 <LEM>gabhīre</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc; gambhīre \msCc\msNb\Ed, <UNCL>gaṃ</UNCL>bhīre \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°rasanaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °ramaṇaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°bandhaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °bandha \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>vrajasva</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ramasva \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Nevertheless, the general idea seems to be clear: the internalised
              version of the pilgrimage place Setubandha, externally usually understood as 
              Rameśvara in the South, is now the sounds of recitation.</NOTE>
        <TR>It is in the deep-sounding Łanusvāra$ (Łsā-anusvāre$). 
                 Go to Setubandha, have a taste of the pleasure of intoxication.</TR>

%index_geo: Setubandha

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>suradrahaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Suradraha</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<NOTANUSTUBH/> sragdharā
<LONGVERSELINES/>
<TEXT> saptadvīpāntamadhye śṛṇu śaśivadane sarvaduḥkhāntalābham</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dvīpā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °dīpā° \msNc</APP>
        <TR>O Moon-faced goddess, listen to [the description of Suradraha], the way to the cessation of
                        all sorrow, in the centre of the seven islands.</TR>

%      - - - -  . -  -   . .!  . .  . . -   - . - -  . - -
<TEXT> īśānenābhijuṣṭaṃ hṛdi hrada vimalaṃ nādaśītāmbupūrṇam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>īśānenābhijuṣṭaṃ</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; īśānenābhiduṣṭaṃ \msCa\msNb,
                                                 īśānebhiduṣṭaṃ \msCbacorr, īśānebhi\lac × duṣṭaṃ \msCbpcorr\oo
                 <LEM>vimalaṃ nādaśītā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc;
                                                 vimalān{ }nādaśītā° \msNb, vimalaṃ nāmaśitā° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The first syllable of Łhrada$ in Łpāda$ b does not make the previous syllable long 
              (\mutacumliquida), otherwise the line would be unmetrical.
              Understand the same Łhrada$ as a \stemform\ metri causa
              standing for the accusative.</NOTE>
        <TR>It is frequented by Īśāna, a spotless lake in the heart full of
                        the cool water of sound (Łnāda$).</TR>

%index_metre: muta cum liquida licence hr
%index_grammar: stem form metri causa 

%       -  -  -   - . -  -    . . . . . . -   - . -   -  .  -  -
<TEXT> tatraikaṃ jātapadmaṃ prakṛtidalayutaṃ keśaraṃ śaktibhinnaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>keśaraṃ</LEM> \msCb\Ed; keśara° \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\ \unmetr, keśvara° \msNb\ \unmetr</APP>
        <NOTE>Łkeśaraṃ śaktibhinnaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c should probably be understood as a bahuvrīhi compound
              thus: Łśaktibhinnakeśaraṃ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>There is a lotus arising there whose petals are Prakṛti and whose filaments are split
                 between Śaktis,</TR>

%index_grammar: split compounds (more!)

<TEXT> pañcavyomapraśastaṃ gatiparamapadaṃ prāptukāmena sevyam||</TEXT> 10:31
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°vyoma°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °vyo<UNCL>maṃ</UNCL> \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°śastaṃ ga°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °śasvaṅ{ }ga° \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°parama°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °paramaṃ \msNa\ \unmetr\oo
                 <LEM>sevyam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; sarvam \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>For Łvyoman$ as `gross element,' see notes to \VSS\ 4.32 above, but note
              that the expression `fifty voids' (Łpañcāśadvyoman$) also comes up in 
              \VSS\ 20.7 and also in 10.33 below. It is not clear why this internalised pilgrimage place,
              or the filaments of the lotus mentioned, would be praised as the five elements.</NOTE>
        <TR>praised as the five gross elements (Łvyoman$). 
                 It is to be honoured if one wishes to obtain the path to the supreme abode.</TR>

%index_voc: vyoman as tattva?
%index_geo: Suradraha


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>ghaṇṭikeśvaram</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Ghaṇṭikeśvara</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<NOTANUSTUBH/> sragdharā
<LONGVERSELINES/>
%             -  -  - -  . - -!        . . . .    . . -    -  . - - . - -         
<TEXT> <crux>nāḍyaikāsaṅgatāni</crux> nipatitam{ }amṛtaṃ ghaṇṭikāpārakeṇa</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>nipatitam{ }amṛtaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; nipatitam{ }amṛta° \msNa\ \unmetr, 
                                        ni\lac ×× tam{ }amṛtaṃ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°pārakeṇa</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; °yāṅkareṇa \msCc\Ed, °<UNCL>pārakena</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>The interpretation of this verse is not without problems. The cruxed expression
              in Łpāda$ a is difficult to repair; it may involve Łnāḍī$ or Łnāḍyā$, Łekā$, and 
              Łsaṃgata$. These suggest that it may hint at a point of confluence where the bodily tubes (Łnāḍī$)
              join. Possibly understand Łnāḍya ekasaṃgatāḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The tubes join[?]. The nectar of immortality (Łamṛta$) has descended by the Saviour Ghaṇṭikā.</TR>

<TEXT> tṛpyante tena nityaṃ hṛdi kamalapuṭaṃ sthāṇubhūtāntarātmā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°puṭaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °puṭa \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>sthāṇu°</LEM> \conj; sthānu° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc,
                                                   <UNCL>sthāna</UNCL>° \msNb, sthāna° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ b, Łsthāṇu$ is my conjecture for Łsthānu$, and 
                I understand °Łātmā$ as standing for the plural nominative.</NOTE>
        <TR>Those whose inner selves have become Sthāṇu [i.e. Śiva]
                  are continuously delighted in Him, as he is embraced by the lotus in their hearts.</TR>

%index_grammar: ātmā singular nom for plur nom

<TEXT> yaṃ paśyantīśabhaktāḥ kalikaluṣaharaṃ vyāpinaṃ niṣprapañcaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>yaṃ paśyantīśabhaktāḥ</LEM> \msNa; yaṃ paśyantīśabhaktā \msCa\msNb, 
                                                yaṃ paśyantīśabharttāḥ \msCb, yaṃ pasyantīsabhaktyā \msCc,
                                                yat{ }paśyantīśabhaktyā \msNc, yaṃ paśyannīśamakṣā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°prapañcam</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; °prapañca \msCb\msCc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>[He is the one] whom Īśa's devotees can behold, who drives off the impurity of
                 the Kali age, who is all-pervading (Łvyāpin$) and non-manifest (Łniṣprapañca$),</TR>

% unmetr
%       - - -    -  . - -. .  . .    .  . -  -   .    - - . -  -         
<TEXT> deveśaṃ ghaṇṭikeśāmarabhavam{ }abhavaṃ tīrtham{ }ākāśabindum||</TEXT> 10:32
        <APP>\vd <LEM>deveśaṃ</LEM> \msCb\msNb\Ed; devyeśaṃ \msCa\msCc\msNa, devyeśa \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>ghaṇṭikeśāmara°</LEM> \msCc; ghaṇṭikeśamara° \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc, 
                                              ghaṇṭikeśaṃ mara° \msNa, ghāṇṭakeśāmara° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°bhavaṃ tīrtham</LEM> \eme; °bhavantīrtham \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed, bhava\lk\lk rtham \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>°bindum</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °bindu \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>I take Łghaṇṭikeśa$ in Łpāda$ d as a \stemform\ noun in sandhi with Łamara$,
              notwithstanding the (unmetrical) reading Łghaṇṭikeśamara$° in \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc.

              The external pilgrimage place related to Ghaṇṭikeśvara the redactors of the 
              \VSS\ may have had in mind here may or may not be 
              `Virajā, modern Jajpur in the Cuttack District of Orissa' presided over by
              Ghaṇṭīśa, Mahāghaṇṭeśvara or 
              Mahāghaṇṭa Bhairava (<citep>SandersonSaivaAge</citep><pnum>113, n. 241</pnum>).
                      See Introduction pp.~\pageref{provenance} ff.

              As for the yogic interpretation of this verse, it seems plausible that Łghaṇṭikā$ is
              taken here as the uvula, from which Łamṛta$ is said to be dripping down the throat.
                      See \TAKII\ s.v. Łghaṇṭikā$ and <cite>MallinsonKhecari</cite>.</NOTE>
        <TR>the lord of gods, Ghaṇṭikeśa of undying existence. 
        The \ae rial Łbindu$ is a non-mundane (Łabhava$) pilgrimage place.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa ghaṇṭikeśa
%index_geo: Ghaṇṭikeśvara

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>vāgīśvaratīrtham</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Vāgīśvaratīrtha</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
% Narahari version!
<LONGVERSELINES/>
<TEXT> mīmāṃsāratnakūlā kramapadapulinā śaivaśāstrārthatoyā</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śaiva°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; śarva° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>By Łkramapada$, most probably a particular method of reciting Vedic texts
              (better known as Łpadakrama$) is meant.</NOTE>
      <TR>The banks [of Vāgīśvaratīrtha] are the gems of Mīmāṃsā, 
                 its sandbanks the [Vedic] Łkramapada$s,
                 its water the meaning of the Śaiva manuals.</TR>


% Sanderson Textual Cr. through 35 on dating Pañcarātra scriptures
%       - -   -  -  . - -     . . . . . . -   -  . - -  . -  -         
<TEXT> mīnaughā pañcarātraṃ śrutikuṭilagatiḥ smārtavegā taraṅgā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>mīnaughā°</LEM> \msNa\msNb\Ed;  mīnoghā° \mssCaCbCc\msNc\oo
                 <LEM>pañcarātraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; pañcaśatraṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°gatiḥ</LEM> \corr; °gati \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°smārtavegā taraṅgā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °smā\lac × <UNCL>vegā taraṅgā</UNCL> \msNb, 
                                                                °smārtavegās{ }taraṅgā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the split compounds in Łpāda$ b. Understand Łmīnaughā pañcarātraṃ$ as
              Łpañcarātramīnaughā$, and Łsmārtavegā taraṅgā$ as Łsmārtavegataraṅgā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Its flock of fish is the Pañcarātra [tradition], its winding path is
                 the Śruti [tradition], its rapid waves the Smārta [tradition].</TR>

%index_grammar: split compounds (more!)

%       - - -  - . -  - . . . . . . -   - . - -  .  - -         
<TEXT> yogāvartātiśobhā upaniṣadivahā bhāratāvartaphenā</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vahā bhāratā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; mahābhāratā° \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the form Łupaniṣadi$ for a \stemform\ of Łupaniṣad$ in Łupaniṣadi-vahā$ in
              Łpāda$ c. This phenomenon is similar to what we see in 10.23 and 27 above with Łhṛdi$.
              The lack of sandhi between °Łśobhā$ and Łupaniṣadi$° is also notable.</NOTE>
        <TR>It is beautiful with its whirlpools of yoga. Its currents are the Upaniṣads.
                 The foam made by its whirlpools is the ŁMahābhārata$.</TR>

%index_grammar: upaniṣadi as stem form

%       -  - -   - . - -  . .  . . . . -  -   .  - -  . - -         
<TEXT> pañcāśadvyomarūpī rasabhavananadī tīrtha vāgīśvarīyam||</TEXT> 10:33
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°śadvyoma°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; °śavyoma° \msNa, °sadvyoma° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Łtīrtha$ in Łpāda$ d is a \stemform\ noun metri causa. The exact meaning of
              Łpañcāśadvyoma$° is not clear to me. Could it be the fifty sounds of Sanskrit?
              All in all, Vāgīśvaratīrtha here represents the religious traditions and scriptures.</NOTE>
        <TR>This river, whose form is the fifty voids (Łvyoman$),
                is the abode of the elixir. [This is the description of] the pilgrimage place Vāgīśvara.</TR>


%index_texts: mīmāṃsā, kramapada, śaivaśāstra, pañcarātra, śruti, smṛti, yoga, upaniṣad, MBh  
%index_voc: 50 vyoman ?
%index_geo: Vāgīśvaratīrtha
%index_grammar: stem form metri causa 

<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<LONGVERSELINES/>
%       -     -   -  .  .  -  .  - . .  .  -  -  - . -   -   . -  
<TEXT> yas{ }taṃ vetti sa vetti vedanikhilaṃ saṃsāraduḥkhacchidaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>yas{ }taṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; yasta° \msCa\msCb\oo
                 <LEM>sa vetti</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; <UNCL>na</UNCL> vetti \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>I take Łpāda$s b and c as if °Łchidaṃ$ in Łpāda$ a were implied for
              each element there,</NOTE>
         <TR>One will know all the Vedas by knowing Him who puts an end to the suffering of
                        transmigration,</TR>

%index_grammar: split compounds

%       -  -  -  . . - . - . . . -    - -  .  -    -  . -  
<TEXT> janmavyādhiviyogatāpamaraṇaṃ kleśārṇavaṃ duḥsaham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°maraṇaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °maraṇa \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°rṇavaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; °ṇṇavaṃ \msNa, °rṇava \Ed</APP>
         <TR>to birth, disease, separation, suffering, death, the floods of unbearable pain,</TR>

<TEXT> garbhāvāsam{ }atīva sahyaviṣayaṃ dustīryaduḥkhālayaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>garbhāvāsam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; garbhovāsam \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°viṣayaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb; °viṣamaṃ \msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°layam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °laya<UNCL>ḥ</UNCL> \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>dustīrya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; dustīryaḥ \msNc</APP>
         <NOTE>and  Łatīva sahya$° as standing for Łatīvāsahya$° metri causa.</NOTE>
         <TR>to dwelling in the womb, to extremely insufferable sensations, and to 
                  places of suffering that are difficult to escape from.</TR>

%index_grammar: shortening metri causa

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.613
<TEXT>prāptaṃ tena na saṃśayaḥ śivapadaṃ duṣprāpya devair{ }api||</TEXT> 10:34
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>prāptaṃ tena na saṃśayaḥ śivapadaṃ duṣprāpya devair{ }api</LEM> \msCa\msCbpcorr\msNa\msNc; 
                      prāptaṃ tena na saṃśayaḥ   śivadaṃ duṣprāpya devair{ }api \msCbacorr,
                      prāptaṃ tena na saṃśayaṃ śivapadaṃ duṣprāpya devair{ }api \msCc\Ed,
                      prā\lac ×××××× <UNCL>yaḥ śiva</UNCL> \lk\lk \lk\lk  <UNCL>ya devair{ }api</UNCL> \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łduṣprāpya$ as a \stemform\ adjective (for Łduṣprāpyaṃ$) metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>Such a person will, without doubt, reach Śiva's world that is difficult to enter even
                 for the gods.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa 

%folioinfo \msCb\ 429.jpg 
<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> <COLOPHON>iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe kāyatīrthopavarṇano nāmādhyāyo daśamaḥ</COLOPHON></TEXT>
            <APP> Ł\Colo:$ <LEM>kāyatīrthopavarṇano</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                           kāyatī\lk\lk \lk rṇṇano \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>nāmādhyāyo daśamaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; nāma daśamo 'dhyāyaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TRCOLOPHON>Here ends the tenth chapter in the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ called the Description of the bodily pilgrimage places.</TRCOLOPHON>

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
%END OF CHAPTER 10


<NORMALVERSELINES/>


% Śaiva Utopia v2.0
% same order of āśramas there in the ŚDhŚ p22

%chapter 11

% CHECK ŚDhU 10.77 (Dominic) on internal sacrifice (not really relevant)
% tasmād aśuddhaṃ svargīyam anityaṃ bāhyasādhanam|
% yajñādyaṃ karma santyajya muktyarthaṃ yogam abhyaset ||10.77||

<CHAPTER>ekādaśamo 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>
<TRCHAPTER> Chapter Eleven </TRCHAPTER>

<ANUSTUBH/>
<SUBCHAPTER>caturāśramadharmavidhānaḥ</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Regulations on the Dharma of the four social disciplines</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> devy{ }uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>The Goddess spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> sarvayajñaḥ paraśreṣṭha asti anyaḥ surottama| </TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>anyaḥ</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNc; anya \msCa\msCc\msNb, cānyā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °ttamaḥ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>O Paraśreṣṭha, O Surottama! Is there another [form of] sacrifice that is for all (Łsarvayajña$),</TR>
        <PARAL>ŁWitnesses used for this chapter:    \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 208v--210r,
                                                    \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 214r--215v,
                                                    \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 285v--287v,
                                                    \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 15v--17v,
                                                    \msNb\ ff.\thinspace 221v--223v 
                                                        (exp.\thinspace 56 lower -- 58 lower),
                                                    \msNc\ ff.\thinspace 223v--225v;
                                                    \Ed\ pp.\thinspace 613--617; 
                                                    \mssCaCbCc~= \msCa + \msCb + \msCc $</PARAL>

% See ŚDh 1.7
<TEXT> alpakleśa{-}m{-}anāyāsa arthaprāyaṃ vineśvara||</TEXT> 11:1
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°nāyāsa</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed;
                                                 °nāyā<UNCL>saṃ</UNCL> \msNa, °<UNCL>nāyā</UNCL>saṃ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°rthaprāyaṃ</LEM> \msNapcorr\msNc; °rthaprāya \mssCaCbCc,
                                      °rthaprārthaprāyaṃ \msNaacorr, °<UNCL>rthaprāya</UNCL> \msNb,
                                                                     °thāmnāya \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>vineśvara</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; <UNCL>vineśvara</UNCL> \msNb, sureśvara \Ed</APP>
         <NOTE>I understand Łpāda$ c as containing a sandhi bridge thus: Łalpakleśa-m-anāyāsa$.
                 The sandhi between Łpāda$s c and d is irregular, understand °Łanāyāsaḥ artha$°, or rather
                 °Łanāyāso 'rtha$°.</NOTE>
        <TR>which is free of pain, easy, and which does not require an abundance of materials, O Īśvara?</TR>
% Ł (see 11.29d for bileśvara) $ %bileśvara \eme;
% °nāyāśa \mssCaCbCc
% note gender of avāpti (n); different use of sarva?     
% See ŚDhŚ 1.8-10 and the parallel Bhaviṣyapurāṇa 1.151.10ff


%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge
%index_sandhi: aḥ a -- a a 

<TEXT> sarvayajñaphalāvāpti daivataiś{ }cāpi pūjitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>daivatai°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; devatai° \msCc\msNc, <UNCL>devatai</UNCL> \msNb</APP>

<TEXT> kathayasva suraśreṣṭha mānuṣāṇāṃ hitāya vai||</TEXT> 11:2
        <TR>For the benefit of mankind, teach me, O Suraśreṣṭha, how one obtains the fruits
                     of [this] universal sacrifice (Łsarvayajña$), which is praised even by the gods.</TR>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°śreṣṭha mānuṣāṇāṃ hitāya vai</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                                 °śre\lac\ ×××××××××× \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>\SDHS\ 1.7--11ab express a similar sentiment,
              using the word Łāyāsa$, similarly to \VSS\ 11.1c above, but giving a somewhat clearer 
              reason for asking for a new form of devotion, namely that twice-born members of society
              with limited financial resources struggle to perform 
              expensive Vedic rituals (Łna śakyante yataḥ kartum alpavittair dvijātibhiḥ$):
        <sep/>
                       Łsanatkumāra uvāca$ | <br/>
                       Łbhagavan sarvadharmajña śivadharmaparāyaṇaḥ$ |<br/>
                       Łśrotukāmāḥ paraṃ dharmam imaṃ sarve samāgatāḥ$ || <br/>
                       Łagniṣṭomādayo yajñā bahuvittakriyānvitāḥ$ |<br/>
                       Łnātyantaphalabhūyiṣṭhā bahvāyāsasamanvitāḥ$ ||<br/>
                       Łna śakyante yataḥ kartum alpavittair dvijātibhiḥ$ |<br/>
                       Łsukhopāyam ato brūhi sarvakāmārthasādhakam$ | <br/>
                       Łhitāya sarvasatvānāṃ śivadharmaṃ sanātanam$ ||<br/>
                       Łnandikeśvara uvāca$ |<br/>
                       Łśrūyatām abhidhāsyāmi sukhopāyamahatphalam$ |<br/>
                       Łparamasarvadharmāṇāṃ śivadharmaṃ śivātmakam$ ||<br/>
                       Łśivena kathitaṃ pūrvaṃ pārvatyāḥ ṣaṇmukhasya ca$ |</NOTE>



%folioinfo \msNb\ 56.jpg upper
<TEXT> maheśvara uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>mahe°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; mehe° \msNc</APP>
        <TR>Maheśvara spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> na tulyaṃ tava paśyāmi dayā bhūteṣu bhāmini|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tulyaṃ tava</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \lac\ ×××× \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>bhāmini</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; bhāmi \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>I understand Łdayā$ in Łpāda$ b as if it were instrumental: Łtava dayayā bhūteṣu na tulyaṃ paśyāmi$.
              Alternatively, as suggested by Csaba Dezső, Łpāda$s ab could be interpreted as
              two sentences: `I cannot see anything comparable to you. [You have great]
              compassion towards living beings, O Bhāminī.'</NOTE>
        <TR>I cannot see anything comparable to your compassion towards living beings, O Bhāminī.</TR>

%index_grammar: nominative for instrumental? dayā
% Nirajan dayābhūteṣu

<TEXT> kim{ }anyat{ }kathayiṣyāmi dayā yatra na vidyate||</TEXT> 11:3
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kim{ }anya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; kimyanya° \msNb</APP>
        <TR>What else could I teach [you] with respect to which [your] compassion is not evident?</TR>

<TEXT> sadāśivamukhāt{ }pūrvaṃ śrutaṃ me varasundari|</TEXT>
        <TR>I heard [the following] previously from Sadāśiva's mouth, O Varasundarī.</TR>
        <NOTE>Note Łme$ for Łmayā$ in Łpāda$ b 
             (<citep>OberliesEpicSkt</citep><pnum>102--103 [4.1.3]</pnum>),
              and the evident distinction here between Maheśvara,
              the interlocutor, and Sadāśiva, who, in this context seems to be superior, being the 
              ultimate source here of the following teaching. This might hint at a familiarity with 
              the Tantric sequence of Łtattva$s, on which see, e.g., <citep>NisvasaGoodall</citep><pnum>45</pnum>.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: me for mayā (Oberlies 4.1.3 [pp. 102--103])

%folioinfo \msNa\ 209.jpg lower, f. 16r
%folioinfo \msM\ 425.jpg lower, f. 17r 
<TEXT> śṛṇu devi pravakṣyāmi dharmasāram{ }anuttamam||</TEXT> 11:4
        <APP>\vc <LEM>devi pravakṣyāmi</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb; te devi vakṣyāmi \msCa\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°sāram{ }anuttamam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °sārasamuccayam \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Listen, O Goddess, I shall teach you the ultimate essence of Dharma.</TR>


<SUBCHAPTER>gṛhasthaḥ(?)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The householder</TRSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> vinārthena tu yo yajñaḥ sa yajñaḥ sārvakāmikaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>yajñaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yajña \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>sārvakāmikaḥ</LEM> \msCb\Ed; sarvakālikaḥ \msCa\msNc,
                                   sarvakāmika \msCc, sārvakālikaḥ \msNa, sārvakāmikāḥ \msNb</APP>
         <PARAL>\vab ŁSee a sequence or list of the four āśramas in 4.75 above:$
                gṛhastho brahmacārī ca vānaprastho 'tha bhaikṣukaḥ;
                Łsee also 5.9:$ 
                etac{ }chaucaṃ gṛhasthānāṃ dviguṇaṃ brahmacāriṇām|
                vānaprasthasya triguṇaṃ yatīnāṃ tu caturguṇam||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>I put a question mark after the subchapter heading here because in this
              chapter the category of the Łgṛhastha$ never gets mentioned. This category is simply labelled 
              Łāśramaḥ prathamaḥ$ in 11.25a.  Nevertheless, it is most probably the Łgṛhastha$ that is 
              implied, and it is mentioned elsewhere (see 4.74c, 5.9a, and 15.17a, 
              which reads Łāśramāṇāṃ gṛhī śreṣṭho$).  
              The teaching on sacrifice without materials (Łvinārthena yajñaḥ$ or Łanarthayajñaḥ$),
              which is fundamentally internalised sacrifice, is a central teaching of the \VSS:
              in addition to the present chapter, the expression 
              appears as the main interlocutor's name (Anarthayajña) in chapters 1--9 and 19--21, 
              and his life is discussed in chapter 22. Thus the name Anarthayajña or the concept of Łanarthayajña$
              appears in each major layer of the text. On this see pp.~\pageref{structure} ff,
              and <cite>KissVolume2021</cite>.
              That Łanarthayajña$ is basically internalised worship is also hinted at in 10.12cd above in 13.2:
        <sep/>
                 Łsvaśarīre sthito yajñaḥ svaśarīre sthitaṃ tapaḥ$ | <br/>
                 Łsvaśarīre sthitaṃ tīrthaṃ śruto vistarato mayā$ ||</NOTE>
        <TR>Sacrifice which [is performed] without materials satisfies all desires.</TR>
        % see 6.2-3 on arthayajña - dravyayajña

<TEXT> akṣayaś{ }cāvyayaś{ }caiva sarvapātakanāśanaḥ||</TEXT> 11:5
        <APP>\vc <LEM>akṣayaś{ }cāvyayaś</LEM> \msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; akṣayaṃ cāvyayaṃ \msCa\msCc\msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°nāśanaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; °nāśanam \msCb\Ed, °nāśana \msCc</APP>
        <TR>It is undecaying and imperishable, and it removes all sins.</TR>

<TEXT> bahuvighnakaro hy{ }artho bahvāyāsakaras{ }tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°karo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °karā \msCc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>hy{ }artho</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; hy{ }ertho \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>karas{ }tathā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; karatasthā \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Material things (Łartha$) present many kinds of obstacle and 
                 [their acquisition causes] much trouble,</TR>

<TEXT> brahmahatyā ivendrasya pravibhāgaphalā smṛtā||</TEXT> 11:6
        <APP>\vd <LEM>pravibhāga°</LEM> \msCb; pravibhoga° \msCa\msCc(?)\msNa\msNc\Ed, pratibhoga° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°phalā smṛtā</LEM> \msCc; °phalaḥ smṛtaḥ \msCapcorr\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc, 
                                                °phala smṛtaḥ \msCaacorr, °pradaḥ smṛtaḥ \Ed</APP>
                 <NOTE>The context of Łpāda$s cd is this: Viśvarūpa was a son of Tvaṣṭṛ. 
                         Viśvarūpa's heads were struck off by Indra and Indra's sins were 
                         distributed among the earth, water, trees, and women. See, e.g., \BHAGP\ 6.9.6:
                <sep/>
                           Łbrahmahatyām añjalinā jagrāha yad apīśvaraḥ$ | <br/>
                           Łsaṃvatsarānte tad aghaṃ bhūtānāṃ sa viśuddhaye$ | <br/>
                           Łbhūmyambudrumayoṣidbhyaś caturdhā vyabhajad dhariḥ$ ||
                <sep/>
                        `Even though [Indra was] the Lord, he took on himself, with folded hands,
                          the sin of killing a Brāhmaṇa. At the end of the year,
                          Hari [= Indra] distributed that sin in four parts to the earth, water, trees and women
                          for the self-purification of living beings.'</NOTE>
        <TR>similarly to Indra's murder of the Brahmin [Viśvarūpa],
                 which yielded results [i.e. sins] that were distributed [among trees, lands etc.].</TR>

<TEXT> pañcaśodhyena śodhyeta arthayajño varānane|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°yajño</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °yajña \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Material sacrifice can be purified with the five purifications, O Varānanā.</TR>

%index_sandhi: lack of sandhi at caesura

<TEXT> śodhite tu phalaṃ śuddham{ }aśuddhe niṣphalaṃ bhavet||</TEXT> 11:7
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>śuddham{ }aśuddhe</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc;
                                         śuddhaṃm{ }aśuddhe \msNa, śuddham{ }aśuddhaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>When it is purified, the fruits are also pure.
                 If it is not purified, it is fruitless.</TR>
% \msCb\ niḥṣphalaṃ ?

<TEXT> devy{ }uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>devy{ }uvāca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNbpcorr\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msNbacorr</APP>
        <TR>The Goddess spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> pañcaśodhye suraśreṣṭha saṃśayo 'tra bhaven{ }mama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°śodhye</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa; °śodhya \msNb\msNc, °śodhyaḥ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°śreṣṭha</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °sre<UNCL>mna</UNCL> \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>'tra bhave°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; 'trā bhava° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>I am not sure about the five purifications, O Sura\-śreṣṭha.</TR>

<TEXT> kathayasva vibhāgena śrotum{ }icchāmi tattvataḥ||</TEXT> 11:8
        <TR>Please teach [them to] me one by one, I want to hear [them] as [they] really [are].</TR>

<TEXT> rudra uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Rudra spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> manaḥśuddhis{ }tu prathamaṃ dravyaśuddhir{ }ataḥ param|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°śuddhir{ }ataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °śuddhigataḥ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is unmetrical unless the \mutacumliquida\ is applied for the 
              first syllable of Łprathamaṃ$, turning the line into a Łna-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>First [there is] the purification of the mind, then [comes] the purification of the substances.</TR>

%index_metre: licence pr! (then na-vipulā) muta cum liquida

%folioinfo \msNc\ 7808.jpg lower = \msNc\ 226.jpg lower, f. 224r
<TEXT> mantraśuddhis{ }tṛtīyā tu karmaśuddhir{ }ataḥ param|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>mantraśuddhis{ }tṛtīyā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; mantraddhi tṛtīyā \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>karmaśuddhi°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; karmasiddhi \msNc</APP>
        <TR>The third is the purification of mantras, then the purification of the ritual.</TR>

<TEXT> pañcamī sattvaśuddhis{ }tu kratuśuddhiś{ }ca pañcadhā||</TEXT> 11:9
        <APP>\ve <LEM>pañcamī</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; pañcamaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°śuddhis{ }tu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; °śuddhiś{ }ca \msNa\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°śuddhiś{ }ca pañcadhā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; °śuddhis{ }tu pañcadhā \msCc,
                                                                °śuddhir{ }ataḥ param \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>
                
              Sets of five types of purification are a commonplace in Tantric Śaivism, but
              they are usually somewhat different form what we see here. They usually include
              Łātmaśuddhi, sthānaśuddhi, dravyaśuddhi, mantraśuddhi$ and Łliṅgaśuddhi$. See
              Goodall's article on this in \TAKIII\ s.v. Łdravyaśuddhi$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The fifth is the purification of Sattva. The purification of the sacrifice is [thus] fivefold.</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.614
% typeset as prose?
%       . -  -   -     - . . . . - .  - . . - 22
<TEXT> manaḥśuddhir{ }nāma aviparītabhāvanayā| </TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°śuddhir{ }nā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °śuddhi nā° \msCc\oo
                  <LEM>°bhāvanayā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; °bhāvanavā \msNa, °bhāvanatayā \msNb</APP>
        <TR>The purification of the mind is [achieved] by mentally creating what is not against [the rules].</TR>

%        -  . -   -     - . . -  - - -  . -  -  - . 29
<TEXT> dravyaśuddhir{ }nāma ananyāyopārjitadravyena|| </TEXT> 11:10
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°śuddhir{ }nā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; °śuddhi nā° \msCc\msNc\oo
                  <LEM>ananyāyo°</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; ana\lac × yo° \msCa, anyāyo° \msCc, svalponyāyo° \Ed\oo
                  <LEM>°dravyena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °vyena \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>The passage 11.10-11 is in fact prose.</NOTE>
        <TR>The purification of the substances is [achieved] 
                        by [using] substances that were not obtained by unlawful means.</TR>

<TEXT> mantraśuddhir{ }nāma svaravyañjanayuktatayā| </TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>mantraśuddhir{ }nā°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\Ed; mantraśuddhi nā° \msCc\msNc,
                                                                     mantras{ }tuddinā° \msNa\oo
                  <LEM>°yuktatayā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °yuktayā \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Purification of the mantras is [achieved] by properly connecting vowels to consonants.</TR>

<TEXT> kriyāśuddhir{ }nāma yathākramāviparītatayā| </TEXT>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°śuddhir{ }nā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °śuddhi nā° \msCc\msNb\oo
                  <LEM>°kramā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °krama° \msCc\oo
                  <LEM>°rītatayā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °rītayā \msCb, \lac ×× tayā \msNc</APP>
        <TR>Purification of the ritual is [achieved] by not altering the proper sequence [of the elements of ritual].</TR>

<TEXT> sattvaśuddhir{ }nāma rajastama-apradhānatayā|| </TEXT> 11:11
        <APP>\vef <LEM>°śuddhir{ }nā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °śuddhi nā° \msCa\msCc\oo
                  <LEM>°dhānatayā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °dhānata \msNc</APP>
        <TR>The purification of Sattva is [achieved] by the non-prevalence of Rajas and Tamas.</TR>

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> vidhim{ }evaṃ yadā śudhyed{ }yadi yajñaṃ karoti hi|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dhim{ }evaṃ yadā</LEM> \msCb\Ed; °dhim{ }eva yadā \msCa\msCc\msNa, °dhim{ }eva ya \msNb,
                                                              °dhim{ }evaṃ yathā \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>śudhyed{ }yadi</LEM> \conj; sūyed{ }yadi \msCa\msNa, pūrya yadi \msCb,  
                                 sūryed{ }yadi \msCc, sūyed{ }yati \msNb, pūyed{ }yadi \msNc, śūddhya yadi \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>yajñaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; yajña \msCc\msNc, saṃjña \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>hi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>An alternative to my conjecture in Łpāda$ a 
              (Łyadā śudhyed$ for Łyadā sūyed$, Łsūryed$, Łpūrya$, and Łpūyed$)
              has been suggested by Dominic Goodall, namely that one could apply the reading of \msCb\ thus:
              Łyadāpūrya$ (`when having completed').</NOTE>
        <TR>When he has purified the ritual (Łvidhi$) thus and performs the sacrifice,</TR>

<TEXT> tasya yajñaphalāvāptir{ }janmamṛtyuś{ }ca no bhavet||</TEXT> 11:12
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°vāptir{ }ja°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\Ed; °vāpti ja \msCc\msNb\msNc, °vāpi ja° \msNa</APP>
        <TR>he will obtain the fruits of the sacrifice, and will not undergo births and deaths [any more].</TR>

<TEXT> vinārthena tu yo yajñaṃ karoti varasundari|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°sundari</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °sundarī \Ed</APP>
        <TR>But he who performs sacrifice without materials, O Varasundarī,</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 215.jpg
<TEXT> na tasya tatphalāvāptiḥ sarvayajñeṣv{ }aśeṣataḥ||</TEXT> 11:13
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°yajñeṣv{ }aśeṣataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °yajñeṣu śeṣataḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I tentatively interpret Łsarvayajñeṣu$ in Łpāda$ d as a locative for genitive, and
              in a sense that does not reflect the meaning in which I took Łsarvayajñaḥ$ in 11.1a above.
              Compare the conclusion of this section, 11.24cd: 
              <skt>āsahasrasya yajñānāṃ phalaṃ prāpnoti nityaśaḥ</skt>.</NOTE>
        <TR>will not [only] obtain its fruits, [but] of all sacrifices, without exception.</TR>

%index_grammar: locative for genitive

<TEXT> yajñavāṭa kurukṣetraṃ sattvāvāsakṛtālayaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°vāṭa kuru°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °vāṭaṅ{ }kuru° \msCb, °vāṭakṛta° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°kṣetraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °kṣetra \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sattvā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; satvāsatvā° \msCbacorr\oo
                 <LEM>°layaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °layam \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>It would be easy to correct Łyajñavāṭa$ in Łpāda$ a to Łyajñavāṭaḥ$, and to normalise
              all the similarly positioned \stemform\ nouns in the following verses because there are no
              metrical constrains that would prevent us from doing so,
              but it seems to me that there is a pattern here and that these \stemform s
              are being emphasised, highlighted, or being items in a list
              (see 11.14c and d, 15a, 16a and b, 17a, 18d, etc.). Nevertheless,
              some of the expression in the upcoming verses should be interpreted as bahuvrīhis
              qualifying the sacrificer or yogin. In fact, we could read Łyajñavāṭakurukṣetraḥ$ and
              Łpratyāhāramahāvediḥ$ as bahuvrīhis here.

              Kurukṣetra was defined as an internalised pilgrimage place in 10.12, which
              fits well the presently introduced teaching of internalised sacrifice.
              Both are summarised, together with bodily penance, in 13.2 (see note to 11.5).
              The term Łsattvāvāsa$ has elsewhere, but probably not here, a distinctively Buddhist flavour,
              denoting the seven or nine `abodes of beings,' see, e.g.,
              <citep>EdgertonHybrid</citep><pnum>vol.~2, s.v. Łsattvāvāsa$</pnum>, and
              <citep>SferraTorellaVolArticle</citep><pnum>1155</pnum>.</NOTE>
        <TR>The sacrificial ground is [the internal] Kurukṣetra. 
            The abode made is [now:] dwelling in Truth (Łsattva$).</TR>
% emend to visarga, not a bahuvrīhi DG ! because it would mean the opposite thing, don't put visarga

%index_grammar: stem form noun

<TEXT> pratyāhāra mahāvedi kuśaprastara saṃyamaḥ||</TEXT> 11:14
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vedi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °devi \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that if Łpāda$ c followed the pattern of Łpāda$ a, namely that `X in Vedic ritual is now Y in this
              internalised sacrifice,' we would need to read Łmahāvedi pratyāhāra$, but that would be unmetrical.

              Łsaṃyama$ is mentioned only a few times in the \VSS\ (e.g., in a similar
              context, in 22.12), and is never explained, in contrast with 
              the Łniyama$-rules mentioned in the next verse, which are expounded in detail in 5.1--8.44.
              Łsaṃyama$ may perhaps be used here in the sense in which it appears in the \YS:
              the yogic application, or appearance, of Łdhāraṇā$, Łdhyāna$, and Łsamādhi$ at
              the same time (see \YogaS\ 3.1--4).</NOTE>
        <TR>The great altar is the withdrawal of the senses (Łpratyāhāra$). 
            The seat made of Łkuśa$ grass is constraint (Łsaṃyama$) [in internalised sacrifice].</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form noun

<TEXT> vidhi niyamavistāro dhyānavahniḥ pradīpitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vidhi ni°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; vidhir{ }ni° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°vistāro</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °vistārau \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>dhyānavahniḥ pradīpitaḥ</LEM> \msNc; dhyānavahnipradīpitaḥ \msCa\msNa,
                                               dhyānaṃ vahnipradīpitaḥ \msCb, dhyānam{ }agnipradīpitaḥ \msCc,
                                               dhyāna agnipradīpanaḥ \msNb, dhyānavṛddhir{ }pradīpinaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I have chosen the reading in Łpāda$ b that is the easiest to interpret. Alternatively,
              the intended expression may have been Łdhyānena vahniḥ pradīpitaḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Vedic injunction (Łvidhi$) is the large group of Niyama-rules. 
                 [Instead of the Vedic ritual fire, it is now] the fire of meditation (Łdhyāna$)
                 [that] is lighted,</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form noun

<TEXT> yogendhanasamijjvālatapodhūmasamākulaḥ||</TEXT> 11:15
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°ndhanasamijjvālatapodhūma°</LEM> \msNb\msNc; °ndhanasamijjvālatapodhūpa° \msCa,
                       °<UNCL>ndha</UNCL>\-satvamijjvālatapodhūma° \msCb, °ndhanasamijvālatapodhūma° \msCc,
                       °ndhanaśami<UNCL>ta</UNCL>jvāla\-tayodhūya° \msNa, °ndhanasamijjvālā tapodhūma° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>which is flaring up by the fuel of the firewood of yoga and
                 is abounding in the smoke of penance.</TR>
        <NOTE>Instead of taking °Łsamijjvāla$° as a tatpuruṣa compound in Łpāda$ c (°Łsamidh-jvāla$°), 
              consider emending it to °Łsamujjvāla$°, which would stand metri causa for °Łsamujjvala$°.</NOTE>
% DG and Mrinal samij jvāla
% DCS supports my note

<TEXT> pātranyāsa śivajñānaṃ sthālīpāka śivātmakaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>pātra°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; pātrā° \msNc</APP>
                <TR>The placing down of the chalice is knowledge of Śiva. 
                        [The oblation of] boiled rice is [now the process of] be[com]ing Śiva.</TR>
        <NOTE>The interpretation of Łpāda$ b is tentative.</NOTE>

%index_grammar: stem form noun

                % gender and case problems
<TEXT> ājyāhutim{ }avicchinnaṃ lambakasruvapātitaḥ||</TEXT> 11:16
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°cchinnaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °cchinna \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>lambaka°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; <UNCL>la</UNCL>mbaka° \msCc, tryambaka° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°pātitaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °pātitam \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Ignoring the problems concerning grammatical gender and case, 
              we may presume that the intended meaning in Łpāda$s cd could be expressed thus:
              Łājyāhutir avicchinnā lambikāsruvena pātitā$. I suspect that Łlambaka$ simply
              stands for Łlambikā$ (`uvula'), which fits the internalised nature of 
              this ritual. See also Łghaṇṭikā$ possibly as `uvula' in 10.32d.</NOTE>
        <TR>The continuous oblation of clarified butter (Łājyāhuti$) is poured 
                                with the ritual ladle (Łsruva$) of the uvula (Łlambaka$).</TR>

%index_grammar: gender and case confusion

<TEXT> dhāraṇādhvaryuvat{ }kṛtvā prāṇāyāmaś{ }ca ṛtvijaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dhvaryuva°</LEM> \msNb; °dhvaryava° \mssCaCbCc, °<UNCL>dhva</UNCL>ryava° \msNa,
                                                   dhva\lk\lk\ \msNc, dharmava° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łpāda$s a as Łdhāraṇām adhvaryuvat kṛtvā$ (Łdhāraṇā$ in the MSS being in 
              \stemform).</NOTE>
        <TR>Transforming concentration (Łdhāraṇā$) into an Adhvaryu [priest, the phases of]
                 breath control will be the [other Vedic] priests[, the Hotṛ, the Brahman, and the Udgātṛ].</TR>


%index_grammar: stem form noun for accusative

<TEXT> tarkayuktaḥ savistāraḥ samādhir{ }vayatāpanaḥ||</TEXT> 11:17
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°yuktaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; °yukta \msCc, °yuktiḥ \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°vistāraḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °vistāro \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note how taking 11.14c and 15b together with the present verse,
              all six auxiliaries of the Łṣaḍaṅgayoga$ of \VSS\ chapter 16 
              have now been mentioned in this chapter.
              See 16.18:
        <sep/>
                        Łpratyāhāras tathā dhyānaṃ prāṇāyāmaś ca dhāraṇā$ |<br/>
                        Łtarkaś caiva samādhiś ca ṣaḍaṅgo yoga ucyate$ ||
        <sep/>
              My interpretation of Łvayatāpana$ in Łpāda$ d as `burning of oblation' 
              (Łvaya$ possibly standing for Łvayas$ metri causa) is tentative.</NOTE>
