        <TR>Samādhi which involves reflection (Łtarka$) and which is extensive is 
                 the [Vedic ritual of] burning the oblation (Łvaya$[Łs$]-Łtāpana$).</TR>
% DG has not seen  'vayastāpana'


<TEXT> brahmavidyāmayo yūpaḥ paśubandho manonmanaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°nmanaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\Ed; °tmanaḥ \msCb\msCc\msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>The final section of \VSS\ chapter 20, a chapter on the Łtattva$s of Sāṃkhya,
                 discusses the mental state of Łunmanas$:
        <sep/>
                 Łunmanastvaṃ gate vipra nibodha daśalakṣaṇam$ | <br/>
                 Łna śabdaṃ śṛṇute śrotraṃ śaṅkhabherīsvanād api$ || etc.
        <sep/>
                 Verse 11.49 below mentions Łmanonmanas$ in a similar context.</NOTE>
        <TR>The sacrificial post is made up of the knowledge about the Brahman.
                 The tying of the sacrificial animal is [the mental state called] Manonmanas.</TR>

<TEXT> śraddhā patnī viśālākṣi saṃkalpa pada śāśvatam||</TEXT> 11:18
        <APP>\vc <LEM>patnī</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; <UNCL>patnī</UNCL> \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>viśālākṣi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; viśālākṣī \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>pada śāśvatam</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; pa<UNCL>da</UNCL>\lac × śvatam \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ d, understand Łsaṃkalpaḥ padaṃ śāśvatam$ (both Łsaṃkalpa$ and Łpada$ are
                \stemform\ nouns in the verse, the latter metri causa).</NOTE>
        <TR>[The householder's] wife is Faith, O Viśālākṣī. 
                 [His] ritual intention (Łsaṃkalpa$) is [reaching] the eternal abode.</TR>
        % Viśālākṣī --> Benaras
°kalpaḥ> \eme; °kalpa \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

<TEXT> pañcendriyajayotpannaḥ puroḍāśo 'mṛtāśanaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°ḍāśo</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; °bhā \msNaacorr, °bhāse \msNapcorr, °bhāge \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>mṛtā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; mṛgā° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Rice oblation is the consumption of the nectar of immortality
                     that arises from the victory over the five senses.</TR>


%folioinfo \msCb\ 430.jpg
<TEXT> brahmanādo mahāmantraḥ prāyaścittānilo jayaḥ||</TEXT> 11:19
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ttānilo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °ttanilo \msCc\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>jayaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; jalāḥ \Ed</APP>
         <NOTE>The term Łbrahmanāda$ in Łpāda$ c may refer to the same concept 
                as Łbrahmabilasvara$ does in 11.29d. It may be the same as the (haṭha)yogic
                concept of Łmahānāda$ (`great sound' or `unstruck sound'), on which see
                <citep>MallinsonKhecari</citep><pnum>225, nn.~359 and 361</pnum>.
                My translation tentatively presupposes that Łmantra$ in Łmahāmatra$
                refers to Vedic mantras, now contrasted with a yogic experience.
                (See Łmahāmantra$ referring to Vedic/Śrauta mantras in \SKANDAP\ 13.132cd: 
                 Łśrutigītair mahāmantrair mūrtimadbhir upasthitaiḥ$.)

                Understand Łpāda$ d as Łprāyaścitto 'nilajayaḥ$. It would be possible
                to correct °Łcittānilo$ to °Łcitto 'nilo$, but since Ł'nilajayaḥ$ would
                be unmetrical and since \stemform\ nouns abound in this chapter, 
                I believe that Łprāyaścittānilo$ could be original.</NOTE>
        <TR>The great [Vedic] mantra is [now] Brahmā's sound. Expiation is victory over the breath.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form noun 

<TEXT> somapāna parijñānam{ }upākarma caturyamaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>pari°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; para° \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Łcaturyamaḥ$ in Łpāda$ b is baffling. The \VSS\ teaches ten 
              Yama-rules in 3.16--4.89. Dominic Goodall has suggested that Łcaturyamaḥ$ could
              stand for Łca tu yamāḥ$ metri causa. Another possibility would be 
              to interpret Łcatur$ as Łcaturtha$ (`fourth') and then the phrase
              may refer to the fourth Yama-rule, absence of hostility (Łānṛśaṃsya$, 4.31--49).</NOTE>
        <TR>The consumption of Soma is [substituted now with] complete knowledge.
                 The commencement [of the Vedic ritual] is the four Yama-rules.</TR>
%index_grammar: stem form noun 

<TEXT> itihāsa jalasnānaṃ purāṇakṛta{-}m{-}ambaraḥ||</TEXT> 11:20
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°snānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °snāna \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>purāṇa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; purāṇaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°kṛtam{ }ambaraḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °kṛtambaram \msCb\ \unmetr</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ Łitihāsa$ in Łpāda$ c, and see notes to verses 6.5 and 8.6
              to clarify what Łitihāsa$ most probably means in the \VSS\ (the \MBh). 
              There is a hiatus-filler (Ł-m-$) in Łpāda$ c in
              °Łkṛta-m-ambaraḥ$, which is a metrical solution for °Łkṛto 'mbaraḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The ritual water-bath is [the study of] the Itihāsa.
                 His garment is made of [his study of] the Purāṇas.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form noun 
%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

%folioinfo \msNa\ 210.jpg upper f. 16v
<TEXT> iḍāsuṣumnāsaṃvedye snānam{ }ācamanaṃ sakṛt|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°suṣumnā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °suṣumna° \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°vedye</LEM>  \msCa\Ed; °vedya \msCb\msNb, °vedyeḥ \msCc, °vaidya \msNa, °bhedo \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sakṛt</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; viduḥ \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>For the teaching on the internalised pilgrimage places Gaṅgā, i.e. Suṣumnā, and
              Yamunā, i.e. Iḍā, and their internalised confluence, Prayāga, see 10.17. Note that
              Iḍā and Suṣumnā are then reinterpreted as Somatīrtha and Sūryatīrtha, respectively,
              in 10.20--21.</NOTE>
        <TR>Ritual bathing and sipping water once are [to be performed]
                 at the confluence of the Iḍā and the Suṣumnā.</TR>
        % sipping once DG , and respectively; but saṃvedye... CsK

%folioinfo \msNb\ 57.jpg lower
% it is a compound here
<TEXT> saṃtoṣātithim{ }ādṛtya dayābhūtadvijārcitaḥ||</TEXT> 11:21
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°toṣātithim{ }ādṛtya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °toṣatithim{ }āvṛtya \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dvijā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dayā° \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Łsaṃtoṣa$° is either meant to be compounded with °Łatithim$ in Łpāda$ c or 
              is in \stemform\ for Łsaṃtoṣam atithiṃ$; for the latter possibility cf., e.g., 
              11.17a above. Similarly, °Łdvija$° may be in \stemform\ in Łpāda$ d, for
              °Łdvijo 'rcitaḥ$, or simply correct it to the same.</NOTE>
        <TR>Having honoured Contentment as a guest, he salutes the Brahmin that is [now] Compassion.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa
%index_sandhi: aḥ a -- ā (stem form)

<TEXT> brahmakūrca guṇātīta havirgandha nirañjanaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°havir{ }ga°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °havi<UNCL>r{ }ga</UNCL>° \msCb, °haviga \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ nouns in Łpāda$s ab.

              On the Łbrahmakūrca$ observance, see, e.g., <citep>KaneHistory</citep><pnum>vol.~4, 146</pnum>,
              where the references given include \MITAKSARA\ ad \YAJNS\ 3.314:   
               Łyadā punaḥ pūrvedyur upoṣyāparedyuḥ samantrakaṃ saṃyujya$
               Łsamantrakam eva pañcagavyaṃ pīyate tadā brahmakūrca ity ākhyāyate$;
                `And when one fasts one day, and on the next day mixes the five products of the cow
                 together while reciting mantras, and drinks [the mixture] while reciting mantras again,
                 that is called Łbrahmakūrca$.'
                
                 On the Łguṇātīta$ state of mind, see 9.39--43. See the term Łnirañjana$ mentioned
                 as a quality of the soul (Łjīva$) in 1.11 and 15.4, of the Łpuruṣa$ in 20.3,   
                 as a state of mind in 11.48, and as one of ten meditative states in 22.30.

                 </NOTE>
         <TR>The Brahmakūrca [observance] is the [state of mind called] `beyond the Qualities' 
                  (Łguṇātīta$), the scent of the sacrifice is the `spotless' (Łnirañjana$) [state of mind].</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form noun

<TEXT> brahmasūtraṃ trayas{ }tattvaṃ bodhanā muṇḍitaṃ śiraḥ||</TEXT> 11:22
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°sūtraṃ trayas</LEM> \msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; °sūtran{ }trayastayas \msCa,
                                        °sūtraṃ traya \msCc, °sūtratrayaṃ \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>muṇḍitaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; muṇḍita° \msCb\msNc\unmetr</APP>
        <NOTE>It is difficult to know what the three Łtattva$s mentioned in Łpāda$ c are.
              (Understand Łtrayas tattvaṃ$ as Łtattvatrayaṃ$, Łtrīṇi tattvāni$, Łtritattvāni$, or
              Łtritattvaṃ$.)
              \VSS\ chapter 4 teaches four Łtattva$s as objects of meditation:
               Łātman$, Łvidyā$, Łbhava$, and Łsūkṣma$ (see, e.g., 4.72). \VSS\ chapter 6
               discusses five Łtattva$s: Łsūrya$, Łsoma$, Łagni$, Łsphaṭika$, and Łsūkṣma$ 
               (see, e.g., 6.7). \VSS\ chapter 20 enumerates the 25 Łtattva$s of Sāṃkhya.
               One possibility would be to interpret the set of three Łtattva$s as
               the three Łpadārtha$s of the Śaivasiddhānta, Łpati$, Łpaśu$, and Łpāśa$;
               see, e.g., \TAKIII, s.v. Łpatipaśupāśa$.
               Dominic Goodall has tentatively suggested reading here in \VSS\ 11.22c, with \msNa,
               Łbrahmasūtratrayaṃ tattvaṃ$ (`the three strands of the sacred thread is truth').
               The problem is firstly that we have Łtrayas tattvaṃ$ repeated in 11.29c below, 
               and secondly that what we need here is three entities compared to the three strands
               of the sacred thread. What is clear here is that even the investiture of the
               sacred thread (Łupanayana$) is supposed to be internalised in this teaching
               of non-material sacrifice.</NOTE>
        <TR>[His] sacred thread is the three truths (Łtattva$).
                 The shaven head [of the Łsnātaka$] is [now] enlightenment.</TR>

%index_grammar: number confusion, trayas tattvaṃ for tritattvāṇi

<TEXT> nivṛttyādi caturvedaś{ }catuḥprakaraṇāsanaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>nivṛttyā°</LEM> \eme; nivṛtyā° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, nirvṛtyā° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°prakaraṇāsanaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                 prakaranāśanaḥ \msCc, prakaraśāsanaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>My assumption is that Łpāda$ a here hints at those four, later five, categories,
              called Łkalā$s, that are well-known from Tantric Śaivism: 
              Łnivṛtti$, Łpratiṣṭhā$, Łvidyā$, Łśānti$, and Łśāntyatīta$.
              For this, I had to emend the reading found in all witnesses consulted, Łnivṛtyā$°.
              I consider Łnivṛti$ for Łnivṛtti$ a common and plausible error. 
              As Dominic Goodall has suggested, here the four Łkalā$s, 
              originally possibly the four Śaktis of the Lord, may be reinterpreted as yogic states.
              The fact that the \VSS\ is aware of only four Łkalā$s here may hint at a relatively
              early date of composition of this section (see Introduction pp.~\pageref{dating} ff).
              On the history and interpretation of these Łkalā$s,
              see \TAKII\ s.v. Łkalā$ 6.

              Łcatuḥprakaraṇāsanaḥ$ may be taken as Łcatuḥprakaraṇāṇy āsanam$, or, as I take it in my
              translation, a bahuvrīhi compound qualifying the practitioner. As to
              what the four Łprakaraṇa$s (`chapters'?) refer to here, I am without a clue.
              Perhaps the phrase was meaningful in a context whereof this section was
              taken out. It may stand for yogic Łkaraṇa$s, postures, which are 
              mentioned, but then not clearly described, in 16.1:
        <sep/>
               Ładhunā śrotum icchāmi yogasadbhāvanirṇayam$ | <br/>
               Łkaraṇaṃ ca yathānyāyaṃ kathayasva sureśvara$ ||</NOTE>
        <TR>The four Vedas are [now] Łnivṛtti$ etc. His seat is the four Łprakaraṇa$s.</TR>

%The <skt>Mokṣopāya</skt>, a text of Kashmiri origin from the tenth century and
%made up of Łprakaraṇa$s, would be an interesting candidate for being a point of reference.
%Unfortunately from this point of view, there are six Łprakaraṇa$s in the 
%<skt>Mokṣopāya</skt>, and not four.
%See, e.g., <cite>SlajeMoksopaya1996</cite>\index{Moksopaya@\textsl{Mo\-kṣo\-pā\-ya}}.

%index_dating: four kalās instead of five

<TEXT> dakṣiṇām{ }abhayaṃ bhūte dattvā yajñaṃ yajet{ }sadā||</TEXT> 11:23
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°bhayaṃ bhūte</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °bhakṣayam{ }bhūtai \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>yajñaṃ yajet</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yajña dadat \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vc Ł\compare\ \VSS\ 22.14ab:$ dakṣiṇābhaya bhūtebhyaḥ paśubandhaḥ svayaṃkṛtaḥ</PARAL>
        <TR>He should always perform a[n internalised] sacrifice after donating the priestly fee of
                 providing being[s] with freedom from danger.</TR>

<TEXT> vinārthaṃ yajñasamprāptiḥ kathitā te varānane|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vinārthaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vinārtha \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kathitā te</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                         kathi<UNCL>to</UNCL> smi \msCc, kathitas{ }te \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>varānane</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; va<UNCL>rā</UNCL>nane \msCc</APP>
        <TR>The attainment of sacrifice without materials has been taught to you, O Varānanā.</TR>

<TEXT> āsahasrasya yajñānāṃ phalaṃ prāpnoti nityaśaḥ||</TEXT> 11:24
        <APP>\vd <LEM>prāpnoti</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; prā\lac × ti \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>nityaśaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; mānavaḥ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>[The sacrificer] will in any case obtain the fruits of up to a thousand 
                 [ordinary Vedic] sacrifices.</TR>

<TEXT> āśramaḥ prathamas{ }tubhyaṃ kathito 'sti varānane|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>āśramaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; āśrama \msCb\msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°s{ }tubhyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °syeṣa \msCc, °syaivaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>'sti</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; smi \msCc\msNb\Ed</APP>
        <TR>The first discipline (Łāśrama$) has been taught to you, O Varānanā,</TR>

<TEXT> sadāśivena saddharmaṃ daivatair{ }api pūjitam||</TEXT> 11:25
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dharmaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °dha<UNCL>rmaṃ</UNCL> \msCb, °dharme \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>daiva°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; deva° \msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>pūjitam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; pūpūjitam \msCb</APP>
         <NOTE>Łsadāśivena$ in Łpāda$ c could also be interpreted as the agent of Łpūjitam$ in Łpāda$ d
               (`it is revered by Sadāśiva'), but Sadāśiva was mentioned as the original
                 teacher of this ritual in 11.4 above, which makes it probable that
                 he is being referred to in a similar manner here. Cf. also 11.30 below.</NOTE>
        <TR>through Sadāśiva; [this is] the true Dharma, revered also by the gods.</TR>


%  2nd āśrama: brahmacarya
<SUBCHAPTER>brahmacārī</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The chaste one</TRSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> brahmacaryaṃ nibodhedaṃ śṛṇuṣvāvahitā śubhe|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°caryaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °carya \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°vahitā śubhe</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                         °vahito bhava \msCc, °vahito śubhe \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Łidaṃ$ in Łnibodhedaṃ$ in Łpāda$ a sounds clumsy with Łbrahmacaryaṃ$ (lit. `listen to this
              practice of chastity') but in fact the \MBH\ and the Purāṇas contain countless similar,
              albeit smoother, expressions, e.g., \MBH\ 5.145.15ab 
              (Łduryodhana nibodhedaṃ kulārthe yad bravīmi te$),
              \BRAHMAP\ 133.10ab
              (Łbharadvāja nibodhedaṃ vākyaṃ mama samāsataḥ$), etc.</NOTE>
        <TR>[Now] learn about this, about the practice of chastity (Łbrahmacarya$). 
                 Listen with attentively, O Śubhā.</TR>
        % nibodhe 'haṃ ? DG 


%folioinfo \msNc\ 7805.jpg upper CHANGE, f. 224v
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.615
<TEXT> dvitīyam{ }āśramaṃ devi sarvapāpavināśanam||</TEXT> 11:26
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°vināśanam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °pranāśanam \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł \compare\ \MBH\ 12.184.10A:$ gārhasthyaṃ khalu dvitīyam{ }āśramaṃ vadanti</PARAL>
        <NOTE>See some remarks on the disciplines, or life-stages (Łāśrama$),
              and especially on their order, in the \VSS\ in <cite>KissVolume2021</cite>.</NOTE>
        <TR>[It is] the second discipline (Łāśrama$), O Devī, the destroyer of all sins.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 216.jpg                         
<TEXT> vrataṃ brahmaparaṃ dhyānaṃ sāvitrī prakṛti{-}r{-}layam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°paraṃ dhyānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °parijñānaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kṛtir{ }layam</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; °kṛtālayam \msCb, °kṛtīlayam \msCc, °kṛtilaḥ \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Łcf.\ \VSS\ 16.8cd$</PARAL>
        <NOTE>One could emend Łprakṛtir layam$ in Łpāda$ b to the expected Łprakṛtau layaḥ$
                (see, e.g., \AGNIP\ 379.1d: <skt>vairāgyāt prakṛtau layam</skt>).
                Nevertheless, I retained the reading of \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed\ because
                it may have been the way in which the compound Łprakṛtilaya$ was originally made 
                metrical. In other words, I suspect the Ł-r-$ to be only a link
                between the two elements of this compound. I also retained the neuter ending.
                Compare 16.8d, where the same expression is transmitted in all the witnesses
                consulted so far as Łprakṛtālayam$.

        </NOTE>
        <TR>Religious observance is [now] meditation focussed on the Brahman.
                 The Sāvitrī [hymn] is absorption in Prakṛti.</TR>

%index_grammar: intusive -r- metri causa

% stem forms 
<TEXT> brahmasūtrākṣaraṃ sūkṣmaṃ triguṇālaya mekhalam||</TEXT> 11:27
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°laya</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °la\lac\ × \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>mekhalam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yat{ }phalam \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ nouns in Łpāda$s cd (°Łsūtra$ and °Łālaya$).
              The `subtle syllable' may be Łoṃ$ (cf. 1.9--10), traditionally analysed as
              made up of three sounds, here corresponding to the three strands of the
              sacred thread. In Łpāda$ d, Łtriguṇālaya$ might rather
              mean `absorption in the three Qualities' (Łtriguṇeṣu layaḥ$)
              although in my translation I translate it as Łtriguṇa-ālayaḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The Brahmanical cord (Łbrahmasūtra$) is the subtle syllable.
                 His girdle is now the abode of the three Qualities (Łguṇa$).</TR>
        % tṛguṇā° \msCa
        % absorption in the 3 guṇas slightly higher level? DG

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa
%index_sandhi: aḥ a -- ā (stem form)

<TEXT> dama daṇḍa dayā pātraṃ bhikṣā saṃsāramocanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>daṇḍa dayā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; daṇḍādayā \msNa, daṇḍādayo \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>pātraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; pātra \msNb</APP>
        <TR>His staff is self-restraint, his bowl compassion.
                 Alms are liberation from transmigration (Łsaṃsāra$).</TR>
         % highest level? DG

%index_grammar: stem form noun 

<TEXT> tryāyuṣaṃ dvyakṣarātītaṃ jñānabhasma-alaṅkṛtam||</TEXT> 11:28
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°yuṣaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °yuṣa \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>bhasma</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; bhaṣmam \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The Tryāyuṣa is a Vedic mantra, see, e.g., <skt>Ṛgveda-khila</skt> 5.3.6:
           Łtryāyuṣam jamadagneḥ kaśyapasya tryāyuṣam |$
           Łagastyasya tryāyuṣam yad devānām tryāyuṣam tan no astu tryāyuṣam$ |;
        `The threefold vitality of [the sage] Jamadagni, that of [the sage] Kaśyapa, 
         that which is that of the gods---may it be ours!' (translation based on 
         <citep>SaivaUtopia</citep><pnum>28</pnum>). `In the Vedic domestic ritual codes, 
         this is the mantra to be recited over the razor or over the student who is
         about to be shaven before bathing at the end of his studies' (ibid.).
         In \SIVAUP\ 5.20ab, this mantra is prescribed to accompany the application of the 
         three lines on the forehead. Thus here in \VSS\ 11:28cd, Łtryāyuṣa$ and
         the mention of ashes make it clear that the next element of the ritual
         life of the Łbrahmacārin$ to be internalised is the application 
         of the Łtripuṇḍra$. As for the Łdvyakṣarātīta$, which should be a mantra,
         it perhaps means a three-syllable mantra, possibly Ła-u-m$ or Łśivāya$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The Tryāyuṣa is the one beyond the two syllables.
             [The three lines are] prepared with the ashes of knowledge.</TR>
        % tryāyuṣa = 3 lines on head ? DG  ; No, see Śaiva Utopia [I wrote, but then:] yes! see 8.37a
        % are drawn with the ashes of knowledge (CsK)
% ŚDhU 4 jñāna bhasma

%index_sandhi: lack of sandhi bhasma-alaṃkṛtam

<TEXT> snānavrataṃ sadāsatyaṃ śīlaśaucasamanvitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°vrataṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb; °vrata \msCb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>The bath-vow is life-long truthfulness,
                 accompanied by the purity and moral conduct.</TR>

<TEXT> agnihotra trayas{ }tattvaṃ japa brahmabilasvaraḥ||</TEXT> 11:29
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°hotra trayas{ }tattvaṃ</LEM> \msNa\msNc\Ed; °hotran{ }trayas{ }tatvaṃ \msCa,
                                °hotra\-<UNCL>ta</UNCL>yas{ }tatvaṃ \msCb, °hotratrayaṃ tatvā \msCc,
                                                °hotraṃ trayaṃs{ }tatvaṃ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°bilasvaraḥ</LEM> \corr; °bilaśvaraḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb, °bileśvara \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>On the problem of understanding what the three Łtattva$s are in this text, and on the 
              phrase Łtrayas tattvaṃ$, see notes on verse 11.22 above.
              Perhaps Łbrahmabilasvara$ in Łpāda$ d refers to the same concept as Łbrahmanāda$ does in 11.19c.</NOTE>
        <TR>The Agnihotra sacrifice is the three Łtattva$s. 
                Recitation is the sound at the aperture of Brahmā.</TR>
        % CHECK MSS

%% bhagavāṃ \msCa\msCc\msNa
<TEXT> dvitīya āśramo devi yathāha bhagavān{ }śivaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dvitīya āśramo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; dvitīyam{ }āśramo \msCc,
                                                         dvitīyam{ }āśramaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>yathāha</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; yathāhaṃ \msCc\msNb, yad{ }āha \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The second discipline (Łāśrama$) has [now] been taught also to you as Lord Śiva taught it, O Devī,</TR>

<TEXT> mamāpi kathitaṃ tubhyaṃ janmamṛtyuvināśanam||</TEXT> 11:30
        <APP>\vc <LEM>mamāpi kathitaṃ tu°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb;
                                mamāpi kathitas{ }tu° \msNc, mayāpi kathito tu° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°mṛtyu°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °mṛ\lac\ × \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>°nāśanaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °nāśanaḥ \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>One may consider correcting Łmamā$° to Łmayā$° (`it has been taught by Łme$'),
              but Łmama$, linked to the first hemistich, may be original, and Łapi$, then slightly 
              unusually placed in the sense of `too/also' (as, e.g., in \RAGHU\ 5.44 and 9.8c),
              starting a new clause.</NOTE>
        <TR>to me. It is the destruction of birth and death.</TR>




% 3th āśrama
% Buddhist terms below
<SUBCHAPTER>vānaprasthaḥ</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The forest-dweller</TRSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> vānaprasthavidhiṃ vakṣye śṛṇuṣvāyatalocane|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°vidhiṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °vidhi \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Listen, O Long-eyed goddess, I shall teach you the forest-dweller's way of life,</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 426.jpg upper, f. 17v 
<TEXT> yathāśrutaṃ yathātathyam{ }ṛṣidaivatapūjitam||</TEXT> 11:31
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°daivata°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °devata° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>which is revered by the sages and the gods, as I heard it, as it [really] is.</TR>


<TEXT> vairāgyavanam{ }āśritya niyamāśramam{ }āharet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vairāgya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; vairāgyā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>niyamā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed; mā° \msNaacorr\oo
                 <LEM>°śramam{ }ā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °śramano haret \msCa</APP>
         <NOTE>Łāharet$ (`should take away, get, use') in Łpāda$ b is suspect; 
               Łāvaset$ (`should settle') or Łāśrayet$ (`should take refuge') 
               would make more sense in this context.</NOTE>
        <TR>Having taken to the forest of indifference, 
                 he should take residence in the ashram of Niyama-rules,</TR>

<TEXT> śīlaśailadṛḍhadvāre prākāre vijitendriyaḥ||</TEXT> 11:32
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dṛḍha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °dṛṣa° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°kāre</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °kāra° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>within walls that have the stone-strong gate of moral conduct,
                 with his sense faculties conquered.</TR>

<TEXT> adhibhūtaḥ smṛto mātā adhyātmaś{ }ca pitā tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>smṛto</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \lac\ ×× \msCb, smṛtau \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Łcf.\ \VSS\ 22.10ab:$ adhyātmanagarasphītaḥ adhibhūtajanākulaḥ</PARAL>
        <TR>One's mother is the material realm, one's father the Self,</TR>
        % see adhyātmika as sāṃkhyayoga in Niśv mukha

%YB+ (B1.31,35) duhkham ādhyātmikam ādhibhautikam ādhidaivikaṃ ca
%YB+ (B3.22,147) ariṣṭebhyo veti trividham ariṣṭam ādhyātmikam
%dhibhautikam ādhidaivikam ceti |
%atrādhyātmikaṃ ghoṣaṃ svadehe pihitakarṇo na 
%ṛṇoti jyotir vā netre 'vaṣṭabdhe na paśyati |
%B+ (B3.22,147) tathādhibautikaṃ yamapuruṣān paśyati pitṝn 
%tītān akasmāt paśyati |
%B+ (B3.22,147) tathādhidaivikaṃ svargam akasmāt siddhān vā 
%aśyati |

<TEXT> adhidaivikam{ }ācāryo vyavasāyāś{ }ca bhrātaraḥ||</TEXT> 11:33
        <APP>\vc <LEM>adhidaivika°</LEM> \emeGoodall;
                                         <UNCL>a</UNCL>\lac ×<UNCL>bhau</UNCL>\lac × ka° \msCa,
                                         adhibhautika° \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed,
                                         adhibhauktika° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vyavasāyāś{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; vyavasāyaś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \mutacumliquida\ applied in Łpāda$ d: the syllable Łbrā$
              does not make the previous syllable long.
             <sep/>
              I have accepted Dominic Goodall's suggestion to emend Ładhibhautika$ in Łpāda$ c
              to Ładhidaivika$. In this way, we arrive at the well-know triad of Ładhibhūta$,
              Ładhyātma$, and Ładhidaivika$ (or more often: Łādhibhautika$, Łādhyātmika$, and
              Łādhidaivika$; see, e.g. \YBH\ ad \YS\ 1.31 and 3.22, and \SK\ 1.1 in most
              commentators' interpretation). Ładhibhautika$ in Łpāda$ c may be the result of
              an eyeskip to Łpāda$ a, and the final Ł-m$ of Ładhidaivika$ could be 
              interpreted as a hiatus-filler. The triad in question usually qualify
              three types of suffering or bad omen: pertaining to the material world, 
              one's own self or body, and to the world of gods, respectively.
              Here in the \VSS, they seem to refer to 
              realms of knowledge, or as \BhG\ 8.1--4, a possible source for the present verse,
              define them, Ładhibhūta$ is mundane existence (Łkṣaro bhāvaḥ$),
              Ładhyātma$ is one's true nature (Łsvabhāvaḥ$), 
              and Ładhidaivata$ the Łpuruṣa$.</NOTE>
        <TR>one's guru the divine. Resolutions are one's brothers.</TR>

%index_grammar: muta cum liquida licence bhr !

%folioinfo \msCa\ 414.jpg
<TEXT> śrutiḥ smṛtiḥ smṛtā bhāryā prajñā putraḥ kṣamānujaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>smṛtā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; smṛto \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Łbhāryā$ in Łpāda$ a is probably meant to be in the dual (Łbhārye$) but
              the use of the singular could be original. Note how notions expressed by
              feminine nouns in Łpāda$ b are associated with male relatives (Łprajñā$ is a son, 
              Łkṣamā$ a brother).

        </NOTE>
        <TR>Śruti and Smṛti are his wives, Wisdom his son, Patience his little brother.</TR>

%index_grammar: singular for dual, Newari
%index_grammar: no sense of gender, Newari, CHECK other texts about this family
%MMW: `Patience' (personified as a daughter of Daksha and wife of Pulaha VP.) Hariv. 14035 Prab. [326,3];


<TEXT> maitrī bandhur{ }jaṭā cāpaṃ karuṇā supavitrakam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>bandhur{ }ja°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; bandhu ja° \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ c, Łjaṭā cāpaṃ$ is problematic. One would expect here an abstract notion 
              corresponding to a real-life element of the forest-dweller life, as in the above verses.
              Also, a bow is not naturally associated with the life of a forest hermit.
              Łjaṭā$ and Łcāpa$ are either still identified with Łmaitrī$ 
              (that is how I translate the Łpāda$) 
              or there is a need to emend, e.g., to Łjaṭācāraḥ$ (`good conduct is his twisted hair').
              I prefer the former solution because in this way the four Buddhist Łbrahmavihāra$s,
              Łmaitrī-karuṇā-muditā-upekṣā$, appear in one uninterrupted sequence. 
              One could even emend to Łjaṭā cāyaṃ$ or Łjaṭā cāpi$. The Łbrahmavihāra$s may seem to be
              out of context in a Brahmanical text but the source for them may have been
              \YS\ 1.33: 
              Łmaitrīkaruṇāmuditopekṣāṇāṃ sukhaduḥkhapuṇyāpuṇyaviṣayāṇāṃ bhāvanātaś$
              Łcittaprasādanam$. See them mentioned also in verse 4.72 above, and in 11.56 below.
               
        </NOTE>
        <TR>Benevolence is his kinsman, his twisted hair [and] his bow.
            Compassion his sacred thread.</TR>
        % he ordinarily HAS the pavitra
        % Satyana: maitrī = jaṭā, bandhu = cāpa

% stem form
<TEXT> muditā mauna catvāraḥ sarvakāryam{ }upekṣakā||</TEXT> 11:34
        <APP>\ve <LEM>mauna catvāraḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 maunaś{ }catvāraḥ \msCb, mauna catvāra \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°kāryam{ }u°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °kāryām{ }u° \msNa\oo 
                 <LEM>°pekṣakā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °pekṣayā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łmauna$ in Łpāda$ e in \stemform, and Łupekṣakā$ for Łupekṣā$, both metri causa.
              For the four Łmauns$s, see 4.69.</NOTE>
        <TR>Sympathy is the four ways of observing silence.  
            All his religious duties are equanimity.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metric causa with number

         % unmetr/ metri causa: jinā
<TEXT> yamavalkalasaṃvītas{ }tapaḥkṛṣṇājinādharaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°saṃvīta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °sānvīta° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kṛṣṇā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °kṛṣṇāṃ \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°jinādharaḥ</LEM> \msNc; °jinadharaḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\ \unmetr, °jinaṃ puraḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I think that \msNc's Łjinādharaḥ$ in Łpāda$ b may be the original reading, and
              it lengthens the final Ła$ of Łjina$° metri causa, and the remaining sources
              try to restore the standard form of Łajina$ and thus 
              ruin the metre. Cf., e.g., \MBH\ 1.123.18:
        <sep/>
                        Łsa kṛṣṇaṃ maladigdhāṅgaṃ kṛṣṇājinadharaṃ vane$ |<br/>
                        Łnaiṣādiṃ śvā samālakṣya bhaṣaṃs tasthau tadantike$ ||</NOTE>
        <TR>He is clothed in the Yama-rules instead of a garment made of bark, and he wears
                 penance instead of the skin of a black antelope.</TR>

%index_metre: lengthening metri causa

 <TEXT> uttarāsaṅgam{ }āsīno yogapaṭṭadṛḍhavrataḥ||</TEXT> 11:35
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dṛḍha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °dṛṣṭa° \msNb\oo 
                 <LEM>°vrataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \lac\ ×× \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE><sep/>
              The accusative Łuttarāsaṅgam$ in Łpāda$ c is acceptable, but one may
              understand the final Ł-m$ as a hiatus-filler after a locative (°Łsaṅga āsīno$),
              or in the middle of a compound (°Łsaṅgāsīno$).</NOTE>
        <TR>He is seated on the highest level of non-attachment,
                  and a firm observance is his yoga-belt.</TR>

<TEXT> vedaghoṣeṇa ghoṣeṇa prāṇāyāmo 'gnihāvanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>veda°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \lac × da° \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>°ṇa ghoṣeṇa</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °ṇa ghoṣīṇa \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°hāvanam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °<UNCL>hāvanam</UNCL> \msCb, °hāvana \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Łhāvana$ in Łpāda$ b stands for Łhavana$ metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>Fire sacrifice accompanied by the sound of murmuring the Vedas is breath-control
                 accompanied by [its] hissing.</TR>

%index_metre: lengthening metri causa

<TEXT> jitaprāṇa mṛgākūlo dhṛti yajñaḥ kriyā japaḥ||</TEXT> 11:36
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°japaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °jiṇaḥ \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>I suspect that °Łmṛgākūlo$ in Łpāda$ c stands for an unmetrical Łmṛgakulo$.
              Incidentally, even by inverting the order of the two elements in this Łpāda$, there would
              remain the metrical error of two Łlaghu$s: Łmṛgakulo jitaprāṇo$.
              Also, note °Łprāṇa$ and Łdhṛti$ in Łpāda$s cd as nouns in \stemform.</NOTE>
        <TR>The herd of deer [in the forest where the forest-dweller normally lives] is
                 [now his] conquered breaths.  [Now] sacrifice is resolution, 
                 ritual is mantra-recitation.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form
%index_metre: lengthening metri causa extreme/double

<TEXT> arthasaṃgraha śāstreṣu sakhā damadayādayaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sakhā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; sakho \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>damada°</LEM> \mssALL\msCapcorr\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; 
                                                dama° \msCaacorr, dayada° \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>See the word Łsaṃgraha$ (here in \stemform) used probably 
                in a similar sense in 11.45 below.</NOTE>
        <TR>His treasures are in the Łśāstra$s, his companions are self-control, compassion, etc.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

<TEXT> śivayajñaṃ prayuñjīta sādhanāṣṭakapūjanam||</TEXT> 11:37
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°yajñaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; °yajña \msCc\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°pūjanam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °pūjikaṃ \msCc</APP>
        <PARAL>\vd Ł\compare\ \DHARMP\ 2.1:$ 
                aṣṭabhiḥ sādhanair{ }ebhiś{ }cittaṃ kāyañ{ }ca yatnataḥ|
                śodhayitvā tato yogī yogābhyāsaṃ samācaret||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>See a reference to eight Łsādhana$s in \DHARMP\ 2.1 (quoted in the apparatus
              to the present verse in the critical edition). These may or may not point to
              the same set of practices.</NOTE>
        <TR>He should perform sacrifice to Śiva as worship of the eight [yogic] practices
                 (Łsādhana$).</TR>

% correct DhP dn text: samācareta

%folioinfo \msNa\ 210.jpg lower, f. 17r
<TEXT> pañcabrahmajalaiḥ pūtaḥ satyatīrthaśivahrade|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°brahmajalaiḥ pūtaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; bra\lac\ ××××× \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°tīrtha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °tīrthaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Purified by the water of the five Brahma[-mantras], bathing and sipping water 
                 in the auspicious (Łśiva$) lake at the pilgrimage place of truthfulness,</TR>

<TEXT> snānam{ }ācamanaṃ kṛtvā saṃdhyātrayam{ }upāsayet||</TEXT> 11:38
       <APP>\vc <LEM>°camanaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °canaṃ \msCb</APP>
       <APP>\vd <LEM>°sayet</LEM> \eme; °śrayet \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
       <PARAL>\vd Ł\compare\ \VSS\ 11.59cd:$ śivasya hṛdayaṃ saṃdhyā tasmāt{ }saṃdhyām{ }upāsayet</PARAL>
       <NOTE>The reading of the witnesses in Łpāda$ d, Łupāśrayet$, might be acceptable, but
             I consider my emendation, Łupāsayet$, better, especially because that is
             the verb used in 11.58d below, in a similar context.</NOTE>
       <TR>he should honour the three junctures of the day.</TR>

<TEXT> akṣamālā purāṇārthaṃ japa śāntaṃ divāniśam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>akṣamālā</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; <UNCL>akṣa</UNCL>\lac × lā \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>purāṇārthaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; purāṇāñ{ }ca \msNb,
                                                                 purāṇā<UNCL>rthā</UNCL> \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°śāntaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCapcorr\msCb\msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °śanti \msCaacorr\msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ b may allow for various interpretations. The one I have chosen seems to be the
              simplest. It involves a \stemform\ noun, Łjapa$, and Łśāntaṃ$
              in the sense of Łśāntiḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The rosary is [now] the meaning of the Purāṇas.
                 Recitation is [now his] peace of mind day and night.</TR>
% they are day and night, DG

%folioinfo \msCb\ 431.jpg
<TEXT> jñānasalilasampūrṇa{-}m{-}itihāsakamaṇḍaluḥ||</TEXT> 11:39
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°salila°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °salīla° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°kamaṇḍaluḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °kamaṇḍalu \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand the middle of Łpāda$s cd as containing a hiatus-filler to bridge the vowels
              in a standard °Łpūrṇa itihāsa$°.</NOTE>
        <TR>His jar of epics is filled with the water of knowledge.</TR>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

<TEXT> pañcakarmakriyotkrānti japa pañcavidhaḥ sukham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°tkrānti ja°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb; °krāntija° \msCc, °tkrāntir{ }ja° \msNa, 
                                                            °tkāntija° \msNc, 'krānti ja° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>My translation of this verse is tentative. Note that Łutkrānti$ 
              (usually in similar contexts: `yogic suicide') is a Łyogāṅga$ in chapter 16.
              See also 17.31, which mentions suicide by entering fire.
              I take Łjapa$ tentatively as a \stemform\ noun, and Łpañcavidhaḥ$ as if
              it read Łpañcavidhaṃ$. \BODHISBH\ 1.3.4 teaches five kinds of Łsukha$:
              <skt>hetusukhaṃ veditasukhaṃ duḥkhaprātipakṣikaṃ sukhaṃ veditopacchedasukham avyabādhyañ 
              ca pañcamaṃ sukham</skt>. This would not be the first occasion in this
              chapter to see Buddhist categories introduced, see 11.34 above.

              </NOTE>
        <TR>The actions of the five [medical] procedures are yogic suicide.
                                Recitation is the five kinds of pleasure.</TR>


<TEXT> sādhanaṃ śivasaṃkalpo yogasiddhiphalapradaḥ||</TEXT> 11:40
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°daḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °dam \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I think that \Ed's silent correction of °Łpradaḥ$ to °Łpradam$,
              making Łpāda$ d qualifying Łsādhanaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c, is
              reasonable, but since this form is not attasted in any of the witnesses
              consulted, I hesitate to follow it. Nevertheless, I understand the
              sentence thus: that which is normally the Łśivasaṃkalpa$ is now,
              in this internalised version of the forest-dweller's life,
              (yogic) practice that yields Łsiddhi$s. I suppose that the reference is
              to \VajasaneyiS\ 34.1--6, usually called ŁŚivasaṃkalpa$:
        <sep/>
                Łyaj jāgrato dūram udaiti daivaṃ$ <br/>
                Łtad u suptasya tathaivaiti$ |<br/>
                Łdūraṃgamaṃ jyotiṣāṃ jyotir ekaṃ$<br/>
                Łtan me manaḥ śivasaṃkalpam astu$ || etc.
        <sep/>
              See this hymn referred to in \MANU\ 11.251 in a context of expiation: 
        <sep/>
                        Łsakṛj japtvāsyavāmīyaṃ śivasaṃkalpam eva ca$ |<br/>
                        Łapahṛtya suvarṇaṃ tu kṣaṇād bhavati nirmalaḥ$ ||
        <sep/>
              In Olivelle's translation: `A man who has stolen gold, on the other hand, 
              becomes instantly stainless by reciting softly[? rather: once] the Asyavāmīya hymn 
              and the Śivasaṃkalpa formulas.' Other texts that reference the \Sivasamkalpa\
              include \NISVGUHYA\ 2.77, \AGNIP\ 259.74, and \LINPU\ 1.64.76. See more on
              the \Sivasamkalpa\ in <cite>RgvedaKhila</cite> and \citeyear{Sivasankalpopanisad}.</NOTE>
        <TR>The ŁŚivasaṃkalpa$ [hymn] is [yogic] practice (Łsādhana$), 
                     which yields fruits of yoga accomplishments.</TR>

% The first six verses of VS 34. says Olivelle Śivasaṃkalpa (Vājasaneyisaṃhitā XXXIV.1-6)
% Monier-Williams: śivasaṃkalpa (śiva-) m. ‘auspicious in meaning’, N. of the text, VS. xxxii, 1-6 (also °pasūkta; also °popaniṣad; cf. Mn. xi, 251).
              %ŁṚgvedakhila$ 4.11ff:
        %Kristen: This is the relevant section of Scheftelowitz (Die Apokryphen des R̥gveda, 1906): https://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.134238/page/n125/mode/1up. Unfortunately, the digitization leaves much to be desired (in other words, it's kind of illegible).  The hymn with Sāyaṇa's commentary is in vol. 4 of the Pune R̥g-Veda (https://ia800800.us.archive.org/25/items/RgVedaWithSayanasCommentaryPart4/rv_sayanabhasya_part4.pdf). There's also a translation in Usha Bhise's The Khila-Sūktas of the R̥g-Veda (BORI, 1995), but it is sitting uselessly on my external hard drive in Leiden.
        % Kenji: I found a short description of Śivasasṃkalpa in Tsuji’s Existent Yajurveda-Literature. 1970.
%        p. 70.
%        Śivasaṃkalpa (Vājasaneyīsaṃhitā XXXIV.1-6)
%        ・This hymn regards Manas as the highest deity.
%        ・Refrain of tan me manaḥ śivasaṃkalpam astu 
%        ・Judging from the fact that it is not admitted by Vājasaneyīsaṃhitā of the Kāṇvas, it might be of later origin.
%        ・Later expanded to 13 verses (die kāśmirische Rezension) or 28 verses. 
%        ・Regarded as the Khila of the RV.
%        ・verses 7–13: imitation using the refrain, verses 14–28 Śiva (=Manas) as the highest deity.
%        cf. also p. 179 fn. 656-658.
%% According to Brunner (1998:126, fn.312), pāvamānī is the
%% 9th maṇḍala of the ṚgVeda. (Can this be right?)
%% Note that 77 gives what the Ṛgvedin recites, 78 the Yajurvedin,
%% 79 the Sāmavedin, and 80 the Ātharvana.


%folioinfo \msCc\ 217.jpg
<TEXT> saṃtoṣaphalam{ }āhāraḥ kāmakrodhaparājitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <TR>His food is the fruit of contentment. He conquers lust and anger.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 57.jpg upper
<TEXT> āśāpāśajayābhyāso dhyānayogaratipriyaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°bhyāso</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °bhyāsa \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°rati°</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \lac\ ×× \msCa, °riti° \msCb, °ratiḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>His practice is the victory over the trap of hope.
                 He loves the joy of yoga meditation.</TR>

<TEXT> atithibhyo 'bhayaṃ dattvā vānaprasthaś{ }cared{ }vratam||</TEXT>  11:41
        <APP>\ve <LEM>atithibhyo 'bhayaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                 ārtibhyaś{ }cābhayaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>dattvā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dārā \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°prasthaś{ }ca°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °prastha ca° \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Cf. 11.23 above on giving Łabhaya$ to guests.</NOTE>
        <TR>The forest-dweller should observe his vow
                 by providing guests with fearlessness.</TR>





<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<LONGVERSELINES/>
        - -  -   .    . -    .! -   . . .  -     -  -!   . -! - . .
<TEXT> vānaprastham{ }ayaṃ dharmaṃ gadita yat{ }pūrvam{ }avadhāritaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>gadita yat{ }pūrvam{ }avadhāritam</LEM> \conj; gaditaṃ pūrvadhāritam \msCa\msCb,
                                             yat{ }pūrvam{ }avadhāritaṃ \msCc\Ed,
                                             gaditaṃ yat{ }pūrvadhāritaṃ \msNaacorr,
                                             gaditaṃ yat{ }pūrva<UNCL>m{ }avadhā</UNCL>ritaṃ \msNapcorr,
                                             gadita pūrvadhāritaṃ \msNb,
                                             gaditaṃ yat{ }pūrvamedhāritaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>In some MSS, Łpāda$ a gives a first impression of being an Łanuṣṭubh$ line 
              with metrical problems.  But, as Dominic Goodall remarked, 
              the variants suggest that it may belong to the upcoming Śārdūlavikrīḍita verse.
              This is all the more so because that verse would otherwise 
              contain only three Łpāda$s. My reconstruction of the now Łpāda$ a 
              is still highly problematic;
              Łgadita$ is in \stemform, and the final syllable of Łpūrvam$ scans as heavy.
              While these are acceptable in the language of the \VSS\ (see pp.~\pageref{language} ff),
              some elements remain questionable, namely
              the first syllable of Łdharmaṃ$ as a short syllable, and the second
              syllable of Łavadhāritaṃ$ as long. The Łpāda$ may have gone through some
              heavy corruption, possibly involving an eyeskip to 11.43a.
              It is also unclear if the first half of the Łpāda$ is to be interpreted as 
              Łvānaprastham ayaṃ$, Łvānaprastho 'yaṃ$ [Łsevet$], 
              Łvānaprastham idaṃ$, or Łvānaprasthamayaṃ$. 
              I translate the first of these options, taking both Łayaṃ$ and Łdharmaṃ$ 
              as neuter nominative.</NOTE>
        <TR>One should follow the Dharma of the forest-dweller, 
            the supreme Dharma, which has been taught and which, if first understood,</TR>


%index_metre: long syllable at end of word 
%index_grammar: dharma is neuter
%index_grammar: ayam as neuter

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.616
%       -  - -   . .   - !  . -  . . . -!   -  - . -  - . -  
%index_grammar: this seems to be a licence in 3 lines here, check if it is a śārdūla at all
% not how Cc and Ed read the same here
<TEXT> saṃsāroddharaṇam{ }anityaharaṇam{ }ajñānanirmūlanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°haraṇam{ }anityaharaṇam{ }ajñā°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNaacorr\msNb\msNc; 
                                °haraṇaṃm{ }anityaharaṇam{ }ajñā° \msCc\Ed,
                                °haraṇaṃm anityaharaṇan{ }tajñā° \msNapcorr</APP>
        <NOTE>Word-final short syllables treated as heavy also 
              appear in Łpāda$s bcd: °Łharaṇam$ (twice), °Łkaram$, and °Łharam$.</NOTE>
        <TR>will deliver one from transmigration, will remove transient existence, uproot ignorance,</TR>
% aṇitya \msNc

%index_metre: long syllable at end of word % DG would print ṃm, see Niśvāsa! CHECK


%folioinfo \msNc\ 7805.jpg lower CHANGE, f. 225r
%        -  - -   . .  -!  . -  . . . -   -  - . -  - . -  
<TEXT> prajñāvṛddhikaram{ }amoghakaraṇaṃ kleśārṇavottāraṇaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>(prajñā°Ł...$ °ttāraṇam)</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°karam{ }amogha°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\ \unmetr; \om\ \msNb, °kam{ }amogha° \msNc,
                                                                         °karaṃ prabodha° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>kleśārṇavo°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc; kleśāṇṇavo° \msNa,
                                                                 \om\ \msNb, śokārṇavo° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>increase wisdom, will be fruitful, will deliver one from the flood of affliction,</TR>

<TEXT> janmavyādhiharam{ }akarmadahanaṃ sevet{ }sa dharmottamam||</TEXT> 11:42
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sevet{ }sa</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                         seve sa \msCc, sevet{ }ta \msNb</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vd Ł\Ed\ (and paper MS \msPaperA) add here a Śārdūlavikrīḍita line:$
                 śraddhāpūrvakam{ }eva yaḥ saniyamaṃ sākṣāc{ }ca jīvan{ }śivaḥ
                 (śuddhāpūrvvakam{ }eva yaḥ saniyataṃ sākṣāc{ }ca jīvane śivaḥ Ł\msPaperA$)</LACUNA>
        <TR>will remove rebirth and disease, and will burn one's bad karma.</TR>
% The added line is in PaperMS A1341 (img 346, l. 3: śuddhāpūrvvakam eva yaḥ saniyataṃ sākṣāc ca jīvane śivaḥ (diff. to read)
% śevet \msNa       
%       "he will in fact become a living Śiva."
%       (śraddhā°Ł...$ śivaḥ)\Ed; \om\ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc
% would work with feminines?


<NORMALVERSELINES/>
% 4th āśrama
% Buddhist terms below again
<SUBCHAPTER>parivrājakaḥ</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The wandering mendicant</TRSUBCHAPTER>
<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> parivrājakadharmo 'yaṃ kīrtayiṣyāmi tac{ }chṛṇu|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kīrtayiṣyāmi</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 kīrtayi\lac × mi \msCa</APP>
        <TR>Here follows the wandering religious mendicant's Dharma.
             Listen, I shall teach it to you.</TR>

<TEXT> sukhaduḥkhaṃ samaṃ kṛtvā lobhamohavivarjitaḥ||</TEXT> 11:43
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°duḥkhaṃ</LEM> \msCb; °duḥkha \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>lobhamoha°</LEM> \msCb; lābhālobha° \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc,
                                                 lābhalobha° \msCc, lābhālābha° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°varjitaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °varjitāḥ \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vd Ł\compare\ \VSS\ 4.71:$  
                     kāmaḥ krodhaś{ }ca lobhaś{ }ca mohaś{ }caiva caturvidhaḥ|
                     catuḥśatrur{ }nihantavyaḥ sarvathā vītakalmaṣaḥ||</PARAL>
        <TR>Making joy and pain equal, he gets rid of greed and folly.</TR>

<TEXT> varjayen{ }madhu māṃsāni paradārāṃś{ }ca varjayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>varjayen</LEM> \msCa\msNb; varjayet \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł\compare\ \MANU\ 2.177:$
                varjayen{ }madhu māṃsaṃ ca gandhaṃ mālyaṃ rasān{ }striyaḥ|
                śuktāni yāni sarvāṇi prāṇināṃ caiva hiṃsanam||</PARAL>
        <TR>He should avoid honey and meat, as well as others' wives.</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 426.jpg lower, f. 18r 
<TEXT> varjayec{ }ciravāsaṃ ca paravāsaṃ ca varjayet||</TEXT> 11:44
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vāsaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °vāsaś \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°vāsaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °vāsaś \Ed</APP>
        <TR>He should avoid staying [at one place] for long and also staying at others' places.</TR>

%lacuna_start: msCb
<TEXT> varjayet{ }sṛṣṭabhojyāni bhikṣām{ }ekāṃ ca varjayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>varjayet{ }sṛṣṭa°</LEM> \msCc(?)\msNa\msNc; varjayet{ }mṛṣṭa° \msCa,
                                                varjjan{ }mṛṣṭa° \msNb, varjayen{ }mṛṣṭa° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°bhojyāni</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °bhojāli(?) \msNc</APP>
         <APP>\vb <LEM>°kṣām{ }ekāṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNb; °kṣām{ }ekaṃ \msCc\msNa,
                                                      °kṣam{ }ekañ \msNc, °kṣām{ }ekaś \Ed</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vab ŁOmitted in \msCb$</LACUNA>
        <PARAL>\vb Ł\compare\ \MANU\ 2.188ab:$
                         bhaikṣeṇa vartayen{ }nityaṃ naikānnādī bhaved{ }vratī</PARAL>
        <TR>He should avoid food that has been thrown away and
                 he should avoid getting alms [always] from the same household.</TR>

%lacuna_end: msCb
<TEXT> varjayet{ }saṃgrahaṃ nityam{ }abhimānaṃ ca varjayet||</TEXT> 11:45
        <NOTE>See the term Łarthasaṃgraha$ in 11.37c, probably in the same meaning as
              Łsaṃgraha$ here in Łpāda$ c.</NOTE>
        <TR>He should always refrain from accumulating wealth and from self-conceit.</TR>

<TEXT> susūkṣmaṃ manasā dhyātvā dṛśau pādaṃ vinikṣipet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dṛśau</LEM> \conj; śucau \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>pādaṃ</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc; pā<UNCL>daṃ</UNCL> \msCa, pāda \msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>vinikṣi°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; \lac × nikṣi° \msCa,
                                                                      vinikṣa° \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>On meditation on the subtle one (Łsusūkṣma$), see Intro\verify.

              ŁPāda$ b is suspect as it is transmitted in the MSS (in most sources it is
              Łśucau pādaṃ vinikṣipet$: `he should place his foot in the pure'?). 
              My conjecture (Łdṛśau$) results in something close to 
              the early Buddhist rule given in the Pāli \Patimokkha\ on begging that says
              that the monk should not make eye-contact with the donor.
              See \Patimokkha\ Sekhiyā 7--8 and 28:
        <sep/>
                       Łokkhittacakkhu antaraghare gamissāmīti sikkhā karaṇīyā$ |<br/>
                       Łokkhittacakkhu antaraghare nisīdissāmīti sikkhā karaṇīyā$ | [...] <br/>
                       Łpattasaññī piṇḍapātaṃ paṭiggahessāmīti sikkhā karaṇīyā$ |
        <sep/>
        In Bhikkhu Ñāṇatusita's translation (<citep>Patimokkha</citep><pnum>294 and 303</pnum>):
        ` ``I shall go with the eyes cast down inside an inhabited area,''
         thus the training is to be done.
        ``I shall sit with the eyes cast down inside an inhabited area,''
         thus the training is to be done. [...]
        ``I shall accept alms-food paying attention to the bowl,'' thus the training is to be done.'
        The last of these sentences opens up another possibility for emending the text of the \VSS:
        Łpādaṃ$ might perhaps be considered as a corruption from Łpātraṃ$ (`on his bowl').
        I am not aware of similar Dharmaśāstric teachings on avoiding eye-contact. 
        The closest could be \BAUDHDHS\ 1.5.11 on observing silence while begging (Łvāgyatas tiṣṭhet$).
        Not even \MANU\ 5.50--60, a longer section on begging, prohibits eye-contact.
        If there are indeed no Brahmanical rules on this topic, the verse above in the \VSS\ 
        could be another piece of evidence for Buddhist influence.</NOTE>
        <TR>Meditating on the extremely subtle one, he should cast his 
                eyes on his feet [when begging].</TR>

% he should put his feet on a pure spot, after you visualized it ? DG

% Pātimokkha:
%        https://www.dhammatalks.net/Books14/Bhikkhu_Nyanatusita-Analysis_of_the_Bhikkhupatimokkha.pdf

<TEXT> na kupyeta anālābhe lābhe vāpi na harṣayet||</TEXT> 11:46
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kupyeta</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kupeta \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>anālābhe</LEM> \msNa; manolābhe \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc,
                                         manolābho \msCc, manālābhe \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł\similar\ \MANU\ 6.57:$
                        alābhe na viṣadī syāl{ }lābhe caiva na harṣayet = 
                    Ł\VASISTHADHS\ 10.22$</PARAL>
        <TR>He should not get angry when he does not receive anything, 
                 and when he does, he should not rejoice.</TR>

<TEXT> arthatṛṣṇāsv{ }anudvigno roṣe vāpi sudāruṇe|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>artha°</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNc; arthā° \msCa\msNa\msNb, atha \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°nudvigno</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °nudigno \msCc</APP>
        <TR>He should not be agitated with regards to thirst for material things, or to violent anger.</TR>

<TEXT> stutinindā samaṃ kṛtvā priyaṃ vāpriyam{ }eva vā||</TEXT> 11:47
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ c, understand Łstutinindā$ as a dual (or singular) accusative.</NOTE>
        <TR>He should take praise and reproach equal, as well as pleasant and unpleasant things.</TR>

%index_grammar: nominative or stem form for accusative

<TEXT> niyamās{ }tu parīdhānaṃ saṃyamāvṛtamekhalaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dhānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed;
                                         °dhānā \msCc, °<UNCL>dhānaṃ</UNCL> \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°vṛta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °mṛta° \msNb, °nṛta° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°mekhalaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                         °mekhalāḥ \msCc, °mekhalā \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>On Łsaṃyama$, see notes on 11.14 above.</NOTE>
        <TR>His garment is the Niyama-rules, and he is girded by 
            the girdle of constraint (Łsaṃyama$).</TR>

<TEXT> nirālambaṃ manaḥ kṛtvā buddhiṃ kṛtvā nirañjanām||</TEXT> 11:48
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°baṃ manaḥ kṛtvā</LEM> \msNc; °bam{ }asatkṛtvā \msCa\msNa,
                                °bam{ }asaṃkṛtvā \msCb, °bam{ }anaṃkṛtvā \msCc,
                                °ba manas{ }kṛtvā \msNb, °bam{ }anaṅkṛtvā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>buddhiṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; buddhi \msCb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>nirañjanām</LEM> \eme; nirañjanam \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed, nirañjanaḥ \msNa</APP>
        <TR>He should make his mind supportless, his intellect spotless,</TR>

<TEXT> ātmānaṃ pṛthivīṃ kṛtvā khaṃ ca kṛtvā manonmanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>kṛtvā khaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 kṛ<UNCL>tvā</UNCL>\lac × ñca \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>manonmanam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; manonmanaḥ \msNc, manonmanaiḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>the ground his self, the sky the mind-nonmind [state of mind] (Łmanonmana$),</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 415.jpg
<TEXT> tridaṇḍaṃ triguṇaṃ kṛtvā pātraṃ kṛtvākṣaro 'vyayaḥ||</TEXT> 11:49
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°kṣaro</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °karo \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>vyayaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; vyayaṃ \msCc, vyaya \msNc, dvayam \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>°Łkṣaram avyayam$ in Łpāda$ d would be hypermetrical, that is probably 
              why the nominative appears here.</NOTE>
        <TR>the three staffs [of the Łparivrājaka$] the three qualities (Łguṇa$), and
                 the bowl the imperishable syllable.</TR>
             %    tridaṇḍa = the three staves of the Parivrājaka MMW, check.
             %    Olivelle p. 173: ``There are numerous scriptural passages cited 
             %    by the Vaisnavas that prescribe the carrying of a triple staff---that is,
             %    three bamboos tied together---by renouncers.''
  % tṛdaṇḍaṃ \msCb\msCc\msNa\Ed
  % Olivelle Saṃnyāsa up p210 n88 

%index_grammar: nominative for accusative metri causa

<TEXT> nyased{ }dharmam{ }adharmaṃ ca īrṣyādveṣaṃ parityajet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dharmaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dharmaṃ vā \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>īrṣyā°</LEM> \msNa\msNc\Ed; īrṣā° \mssCaCbCc\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°dveṣaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dveṣa \msCc</APP>
        <TR>He should throw away Dharma and Adharma,
                     and should give up envy and hatred.</TR>

<TEXT> nirdvandvo nityasatyastho nirmamo nirahaṃkṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 11:50
        <APP>\vc <LEM>nirdvandvo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; nivaṃdvo \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°satya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °saṃtya° \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nirmamo</LEM> \msNc\Ed; nirmāṃso \mssCaCbCc\msNa, nirmaṃso \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°kṛtaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; °kṛtaṃ \msNa, °kṛtiḥ \Ed</APP>
                 <PARAL>\vcd Ł\compare\ \BHG\ 2.45cd: 
                        $nirdvandvo nityasattvastho niryogakṣema ātmavān</PARAL>
        <TR>He should be indifferent to opposites, 
                 always dwell in truthfulness, being unselfish, humble.</TR>

<TEXT> divasasyāṣṭame bhāge bhikṣāṃ saptagṛhaṃ caret|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>divasasyā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; divasatyā° \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>bhikṣāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; bhikṣā \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vb Ł\compare\ \GAUTDHS\ 23.18:$
                tasyājinam{ }ūrdhvabālaṃ paridhāya lohitapatraḥ sapta gṛhān{ }bhakṣaṃ caret</PARAL>
        <NOTE>According to \Manu\ 6.56, the wandering ascetic should go around begging
              after people have finished their meal.
              \MBH\ Suppl. 1.52.36 (= \LAKSMINARS\ 1.238.18ab = \VASISTHADHS\ 11.36ab) suggests 
              that the `eighth part of the day' is around sunset:
              Łdivasasyāṣṭame bhāge mandībhūte divākare$.</NOTE>
        <TR>He should go on his alms round visiting seven houses at the eighth part of the day.</TR>

<TEXT> na cāsīta na tiṣṭheta na ca dehīti vā vadet||</TEXT> 11:51
        <TR>He should not sit down, he should not stay, and he should not say `Give me!'</TR>
% harder
% same in Buddhism An

<TEXT> yathālābhena varteta aṣṭau piṇḍān{ }dine dine|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>yathālābhena</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; yathālā\lac\ ×× \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>aṣṭau</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; aṣṭa \Ed</APP>
        <TR>He should live on what is available, on eight bites a day.</TR>
        % piṇḍāṃ \msCb

<TEXT> vastrabhojanaśayyāsu na prasajyeta vistaram||</TEXT> 11:52
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°śayyāsu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °śayyāñca \msNb, °śaiyyāsu \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°sajyeta</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb; °yujye \msCb, °saheta \msNc, °sahyeta \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>vistaram</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; vistaraḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>He should not stick to items of clothes, food, or a bed, for long.</TR>

<TEXT> nābhinandeta maraṇaṃ nābhinandeta jīvitam|</TEXT>
        <PARAL>\vab Ł= \MBH\ 12.237.15ab = \MANU\ 6.45ab = \NARADAPARIVR\ 3.61cd$</PARAL>
        <TR>He should nor rejoice in death, he should not rejoice in life.</TR>


%folioinfo \msNa\ 211.jpg upper, f. 17v
<TEXT> indriyāṇi vaśaṃkṛtvā kāmaṃ hatvā yatavrataḥ||</TEXT> 11:53
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vaśaṃkṛ°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vasaṃtkṛ° \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>hatvā yatavrataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                         kṛtvā yataḥ vrataḥ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Having conquered his senses, and having killed his desire, firm in his observances,</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 218.jpg
<TEXT> atītaṃ ca bhaviṣyaṃ ca na bhikṣuś{ }cintayet{ }sadā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>bhikṣuś{ }ci°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc;
                                                 bhikṣuṃś{ }ci° \msNa, bhikṣu ci° \Ed\oo 
                 <LEM>sadā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msCb</APP>
        <TR>the mendicant (Łbhikṣu$) should never think about the past or the future.</TR>

<TEXT> krodhamānamadadarpān{ }parivrāḍ{ }varjayet{ }sadā||</TEXT> 11:54
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°darpān{ }pa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °darpāt{ }pa° \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ c is a Łsa-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>The wandering mendicant (Łparivrāj$) should always avoid anger, 
            self-conceit, intoxication, and pride.</TR>

%index_metre: sa-vipulā

<TEXT> virāgaṃ tu dhanuḥ kṛtvā prāṇāyāmaguṇair{ }yutam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dhanuḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dhanuṣ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>prāṇāyāmagu°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; prāṇāyāmaṅgu° \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>yutam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; yutaḥ \msNa, vṛtaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Making indifference a bow which is strung with the strings of breath-control,</TR>

<TEXT> dhāraṇāśaratīkṣṇena mṛgaṃ hatvā manendriyam||</TEXT> 11:55
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°tīkṣṇena</LEM> \msNb\Ed; °tīkṣṇeṇa \mssCaCbCc\msNc, °tīkṣeṇa \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łpāda$ c as Łdhāraṇātīkṣṇaśareṇa$.</NOTE>
        <TR>he should kill the beast that is the mind and the sense-faculties
                        with the sharp-pointed arrow of concentration.</TR>

%index_grammar: word order in compound metri causa

<TEXT> maitrīkhaḍgasutīkṣṇena saṃsārāriṃ nikṛntayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>sutīkṣṇena</LEM> \msCa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sutīkṣṇeṇa \msCb\msCc\msNapcorr, ṇa \msNaacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°sārāriṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; °sārāri \msCc\msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łpāda$ a as Łmaitrīsutīkṣṇakhaḍgena$, which is even metrical.</NOTE>
        <TR>He should stab the enemy that is transmigration with the extremely sharp
                 knife of friendliness.</TR>

%index_grammar: word order in compound

<TEXT> karuṇāvartacakreṇa krodhamattagajaṃ jayet|</TEXT>
        <TR>He should defeat the rutting elephant of anger with the whirling discus of compassion.</TR>

<TEXT> muditāvarmabaddhāṅgas{ }tūṇaṃ pūrṇam{ }upekṣayā||</TEXT> 11:56
        <APP>\vf <LEM>tūṇaṃ pūrṇam{ }u°</LEM> \emeGoodall; tūṇṇāpūrṇṇam{ }u° \msCa,
                      tūṇāpūrṇṇam{ }u° \msCb, tū\-<UNCL>na</UNCL>pūrṇṇam{ }u° \msCc,
                      tūṇṇāpūṇṇām{ }u° \msNa, tūrṇṇāpūrṇṇam{ }u° \msNb\msNc, tūṇīpūrṇam{ }u° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the four Buddhist Łbrahmavihāra$s, Łmaitrī$, Łkaruṇā$, Łmuditā$, and Łupekṣā$,
                mentioned in this verse. They appear also in verses 4.71 and 11.56 above.</NOTE>
        <TR>His body should be clad in the armour of sympathy, his quiver full of equanimity.</TR>

<TEXT> anakṣaraṃ paraṃ brahma cintayet{ }satataṃ dvija|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>anakṣaraṃ</LEM> \msCb; anākṣaraṃ \msCa\msNa,
                                         anākṣara° \msCc\msNc\Ed, anakṣara° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>paraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; para \msCb\msNc</APP>
        <TR>He should constantly recall the unutterable syllable which is
              the supreme Brahman, O Brahmin.</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.617
<TEXT> brahmaṇo hṛdayaṃ viṣṇur{ }viṣṇoś{ }ca hṛdayaṃ śivaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>hṛdayaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed;
                                         \lac × dayaṃ \msCa, hṛdaye \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>viṣṇur{ }vi°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\Ed; viṣṇum{ }vi° \msCb,
                                         viṣṇu vi° \msCc\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>śivaḥ</LEM> \Ed; śivaṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <TR>Brahmā's heart is Viṣṇu. Viṣṇu's heart is Śiva.</TR>

<TEXT> śivasya hṛdayaṃ saṃdhyā tasmāt{ }saṃdhyām{ }upāsayet||</TEXT> 11:58
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°sayet</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNb; °śayet \msCb\msNa, °śrayet \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\similar\ Saubhāgyabhāskara of Bhāskararāya ad Lalitāsahasranāmastotra 302:$
                brahmaṇo hṛdayaṃ viṣṇur{ }viṣṇor{ }api śivaḥ smṛtaḥ|
                śivasya hṛdayaṃ sandhyā tenopāsyā dvijātibhiḥ||
                iti kaśyapādivacanaiḥ kaurmapādmaskāndādinikhilapurāṇeṣu ca tatra 
                tatra devīkālikābrahmāṇḍamārkaṇḍeyādipurāṇeṣu bahuśaḥ 
                śaktirahasya-devībhāgavata-tṛtīyaskandhādiṣu
                ca idaṃparyeṇa sarvatra jñānārṇavakulārṇavāditantreṣu tv{ }aparimitatyā varṇitam</PARAL>
        <TR>Śiva's heart is the junctures of the day. Therefore he should worship the junctures.</TR>


<NOTANUSTUBH/> śārdūlavikrīḍita
<LONGVERSELINES/>
%       -  - -  . . - .  -  .  . . -   -   -  . -    -  . -  
<TEXT> saṃsārārṇavatāraṇaṃ śubhagatiḥ sa brahma saṃdhyākṣaraṃ</TEXT>
       <APP>\va <LEM>°gatiḥ</LEM> \msCc\Ed; °gati \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\ \unmetr, °gatiṃ \msNc\oo 
                <LEM>°kṣaraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °kṣara \msCb</APP>
        <TR>[Śiva] is deliverance from the ocean of mundane existence, the path to happiness, the Brahman, 
                 the junctures, the [sacred] syllable.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 432.jpg       
%folioinfo \msNc\ 7806.jpg upper CHANGE, f. 225v
<TEXT> dhyāyen{ }nityam{ }atandrito hy{ }anupamaṃ vyaktātmavedyaṃ śivam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°tandrito</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; °nandrito \msCb, °tandriya \msCc, °tandriyaṃ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°vedyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °vedya \msNb\ \unmetr</APP>
        <TR>One should always, unweariedly, meditate on matchless Śiva, 
                 who is to be recognized as the manifest soul.</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 427.jpg upper, f. 18v
<TEXT> rūpair{ }varṇaguṇādibhiś{ }ca vihitaṃ durlakṣyalakṣyottamaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>rūpair{ }va°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; rūpai va° \msCb\msCc\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>vihitaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNaacorr(?)\msNb\msNc; rahitaṃ \msNapcorr(?)\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>durlakṣyalakṣyottamam</LEM> \msCa\msNb; 
                                              durlakṣyalakṣottamam \msCb\msCc\msNc\Ed,
                                              dulakṣyalakṣyottamam \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łvihita$ in Łpāda$ c probably in the sense of `devoid of.'</NOTE>
        <TR>He should take refuge in Hara, who is devoid of form, colour, qualities etc.,
                 who is the supreme aim which is difficult to discern,</TR>
% DG correct to rahita

%folioinfo \msNb\ 58.jpg lower                           
<TEXT> yatnoddhṛtya samāśrayet{ }suraguruṃ sarvārtihartā haram||</TEXT> 11:59
        <APP>\vd <LEM>yatnoddhṛtya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yatnād{ }dhṛtya \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>samāśraye°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; maṇāśraye° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>sarvārtihartā haram</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb; sarvārttiha<UNCL>rttā</UNCL> haraṃ \msNa,
                                         sarvāttiharttā haraṃ \msNc,
                                         sarvārtihan śaṅkaram \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I take Łyatnoddhṛtya$ in Łpāda$ d as Łyatnenoddhṛtya$, Łyatna$ being in \stemform, and
              °Łhartā$  as nominative for accusative.</NOTE>
        <TR>honouring the divine guru with effort, who removes all pain.</TR>
                                % yanno°? \msCa\msCb\msNa
% probably not a per. fut. DG
% hold in one's awareness (cf. dhāraṇā) DG holding him with effort

%index_grammar: nominative for accusative metri causa
%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

<NORMALVERSELINES/>
<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> <COLOPHON>iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe caturāśramadharmavidhāno nāmādhyāya ekādaśamaḥ</COLOPHON></TEXT>
<APP> Ł\Colo:$ <LEM>nāmādhyāya ekādaśamaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; nāmādhyāya ekādaśa \msNc, 
                                                                          nāma ekādaśo 'dhyāyaḥ \Ed</APP>
<TRCOLOPHON>Here ends the eleventh chapter in the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ called Regulations concerning the four life-stages.</TRCOLOPHON>
%END OF CHAPTER 11


%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%




%folioinfo \msM\ 427.jpg upper, f. 18v line 1

<startchapter-n="12"/>
%chapter 12
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.617
%folioinfo \msCa\ image 415.jpg line 5
%folioinfo \msCb\ image 432.jpg line 1
%folioinfo \msCc\ image 218.jpg, f. 287v, line 4
%folioinfo \msNa\ image 211.jpg upper line 4, f. 17v
%folioinfo \msNb\ image 58.jpg lower line 1
%folioinfo \msNc\ 228.jpg upper line 1, f. 225v
%\msBod\ 13.55.32, f. 267r line 4
% In some way, the story itself promotes the cult of Brahmā! and Brahmins
% any connection with 'ratisatra' in Niśvāsamukha and Śivadharamasaṃgraha?
% see the sequence of Lokas in ŚDhŚ 10:100ff




<CHAPTER>dvādaśamo 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>
<TRCHAPTER> Chapter Twelve </TRCHAPTER>

<SUBCHAPTER>ātithyadharmaḥ</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Rules of hospitality</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> devy{ }uvāca|*</TEXT>
%        vo <LEM>devy{ }uvāca</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msM
         <TR>The Goddess spoke:</TR>
% \om\ \msBod

<TEXT> ahiṃsā paramo dharmaḥ satataṃ parikīrtyate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>dharmaḥ sa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dharmos{ }sa° \msCc</APP>
        <LACUNA>ŁWitnesses used for this chapter: \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 210r--215r,
                                              \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 215v--219v,
                                              \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 287v--283v
                                                        (f.\thinspace 291 is missing),
                                              \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 17v--22r,
                                              \msNb\ exp.\thinspace 58 (lower) -- 62 (lower),
                                              \msNc\ ff.\thinspace 225v--230r,
                                              \Ed\ pp.\thinspace 617--628;
                                              \mssCaCbCc\ = \msCa + \msCb + \msCc$</LACUNA>
        <TR>Non-violence is always praised as the highest Dharma.</TR>-->
        <NOTE>One could read Łahiṃsāparamo dharmaḥ$ in Łpāda$ a. This would
              translate as `A Dharma beyond non-violence is always being praised.'
              It is not crystal clear why Łahiṃsā$ is mentioned at all 
              at the beginning of this chapter. I suspect that by Łātithyakānāṃ dharmaṃ$,
              one should simply understand Łātithyadharmaṃ$.</NOTE>

<TEXT> ātithyakānāṃ dharmaṃ ca kathayasva yad{ }uttamam||</TEXT> 12:1
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ātithya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; atithya° \msCb\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>dharmaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                 dharmaś{ }ca \msCc, dharmānāṃ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Teach me also the ultimate Dharma of hospitality.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<TEXT> maheśvara uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>maheśvara</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; bhagavān \msNa</APP>
        <TR>Maheśvara spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> ahiṃsātithyakānāṃ ca śṛṇu dharmaṃ yad{ }uttamam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śṛṇu</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \lac × ṇu \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>dharmaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; dharma \msCc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°ttamam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °ttamāṃ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łahiṃsātithyakāmāṃ$ as Łahiṃsakānām ātithyakānāṃ ca$ or
              Łahiṃsāyā ātithyakāṇāṃ ca$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Hear the ultimate Dharma of non-violence and that of hospitality.</TR>

<TEXT> trailokyam{ }akhilaṃ devi ratnapūrṇaṃ sulocane||</TEXT> 12:2
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°pūrṇaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; pūrṇṇa \msCc, °pūrṇāṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°locane</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °locanaṃ \msCb</APP>
        <TR>O beautiful-eyed goddess, [if] all the three worlds, full of wealth,</TR>

<TEXT> caturvedavide dānaṃ na tattulyam{ }ahiṃsakaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; nānaṃ \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that this verse seems to be all that Maheśvara teaches in this chapter on 
                Łahiṃsā$, and that Łtattulyam ahiṃsakaḥ$ may either contain a sandhi bridge
                (Łtattulya-m-ahiṃsakaḥ$) or be interpreted as Łdānaṃ na tat tulyam ahiṃsakena$ 
                (`that gift is not comparable to a non-violent person').</NOTE>
        <TR>[were handed over as] a gift to [a Brahmin who] knows 
                the four Vedas, [that gift] cannot be compared to somebody who avoids causing harm.</TR>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

<TEXT> śṛṇu dharmam{ }atithyānāṃ kīrtayiṣyāmi sundari||</TEXT> 12:3
        <NOTE>Łatithyānāṃ$ in Łpāda$ c stands for Łātithyānāṃ$, Łātithyasya$,
              or Łātithyakānāṃ$ metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>Hear the Dharma of the hospitable ones. I shall teach it [to you], O beautiful one.</TR>

%index_grammar: shortening, atithyānāṃ, metri causa 



<SUBCHAPTER>vipulopākhyānam</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>Story of Vipula</TRSUBCHAPTER>
% see MBh 13.39.1 (13039001) ff? Yudhuṣṭhira asks Bhīṣma: how to control women. How women were created; 
% the story itself starts at 13040016; also 13.4?
% https://www.mahabharataonline.com/translation/mahabharata_13b005.php

<TEXT> āsīd{ }vṛttaṃ purākhyānaṃ nagare kusumāhvaye|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>āsīd{ }vṛttaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\Ed; āśīdattaṃ \msCb, āsīd{ }vṛtam \msCc, āsī vṛttaṃ \msNb, āsīd{ }vṛtta \msNc\oo 
                 <LEM>°khyānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °khyātaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>nagare kusumāhvaye</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                         nagaraṃ kusumāhvayam \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Kusumapura is Pāṭaliputra, or modern Patna in Bihar.
              This is confirmed in verse 12.12, where 
              the confluence of the Gaṇḍakī and the Gaṅgā is mentioned as a local spot.
              The Łdramatis person\ae$ in the following story are the following:
                Vipula---a merchant, Kapila's son;
                Vipula's wife;
                a Brahmin guest (Dharma in diguise?);
                a monkey;
                Bhīmabala---a traveller;
                Puṇḍaka---the foreman of the guild;
                King Siṃhajaṭa;
                Queen Kekayī;
                Caṇḍa and Vicaṇḍa---two envoys of the king;
                Citraratha---the king of the Gandharvas;
                Sūrya, Soma, Indra, Viṣṇu, and Brahmā.</NOTE>
        <TR>This is an old story of what happened once in a city called Kusuma.</TR>

%index_geo: city of Kusuma = Pāṭaliputra

<TEXT> kapilasya suto vidvān{ }vipulo nāma viśrutaḥ||</TEXT> 12:4
        <TR>There was a famous and wise man called Vipula, Kapila's son.</TR>

%index_persons: Vipula
%index_persons: Kapila, Vipula's father

%folioinfo \msCa\ image 416.jpg
<TEXT> dharmanityo jitakrodhaḥ satyavādī jitendriyaḥ|</TEXT>
        <PARAL>\vb Ł = \MBH\ 12.218.13b$</PARAL>
        <TR>He always followed Dharma, he conquered anger, he spoke only
                                 the truth, and he conquered his senses.</TR>

<TEXT> brahmaṇyaś{ }ca kṛtajñaś{ }ca madbhaktaḥ kṛtaniścayaḥ||</TEXT> 12:5
        <APP>\vc <LEM>brahmaṇya°</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; brāhmaṇya° \msCa\msCc\msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°jñaś{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                         °jña \msCb, °jñaś{ }ca \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°bhaktaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °bhakta° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ d implies that Vipula is a Śaiva devotee, but there is little indication 
              in this story of Vipula's affiliation, except for 12.44, where Maheśvara is mentioned.
              The story as we have it here ends with a praise of Brahmā.</NOTE>
        <TR>He was pious and knowledgeable, and he was my determined devotee.</TR>
% CHECK \msCb °jña DONE, yes ca is missing

<TEXT> dhanāḍhyo 'tithipūjyaś{ }ca dātā dānto dayālukaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°pūjyaś{ }ca</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNapcorr\msNc\Ed;
                                                 °pūjya \msCb\msNaacorr, °pūjaś{ }ca \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dānto</LEM> \msCbacorr\msNc\Ed;
                                               dānta \msCa\msCc\msNa, dāntomŁ(?)$ \msCbpcorr,
                                               dānta \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>While one would normally translate Łatithipūjya$ (in Łpāda$ a) 
              as `to be worshipped by guests,' in the light of the story I
