              suspect that the intended meaning is that he worshipped his guests.</NOTE>
        <TR>He was rich and he worshipped his guests. He was generous, restrained, and kind.</TR>
% NOTE \msCb and \msNa pūjya

%folioinfo \msCc\ image 219.jpg, f. 288r 
<TEXT> nyāyārjitadhano nityam{ }anyāyaparivarjitaḥ||</TEXT> 12:6
        <APP>\vc <LEM>nyāyā°</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; nyāyo° \msCa\msCb\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>nityam{ }a°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; nityaṃm{ }a° \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°varjitaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °varjayet \msNb</APP>
        <TR>His wealth always came through just means. He always stayed
            away from illegal transactions.</TR>

<TEXT> bhāryā ca rūpiṇī tasya candrabimbaśubhānanā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°bimba°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °biṃ<UNCL>bā</UNCL> \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°śubhānanā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °nibhānanā \msNb</APP>
        <TR>He had a pretty wife whose face was as beautiful as the disk of the moon.</TR>

<TEXT> pīnottuṅgastanī kāntā sakalānandakāriṇī|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sakalā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \lac\ ××× \msCa</APP>
        <TR>Her breasts were round and elevated, she was lovely, a source of all pleasures.</TR>

<TEXT> pativratā patiratā patiśuśrūṣaṇe ratā||</TEXT> 12:7
        <APP>\ve <LEM>pativratā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; prativratā \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>patiratā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; pratiratā \msCb\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>patiśuśrūṣaṇe</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; pratiśuśrūṣaṇe \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vef Ł\compare\ \BrahmaVP\ 4.27.174cd:$
                         pativrate patirate patiṃ dehi namo 'stu te</PARAL>
        <TR>She was faithful, devoted to her husband and his needs.</TR>

<TEXT> atha kenāpi kālena sūryarāga{-}m{-}abhūt{ }tataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°bhūt{ }tataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °bhūtataḥ \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ b, understand Łsūryarāgam$ as Łsūryoparāgaḥ$ (`eclipse of the sun'). 
              I take °Łrāga-m-abhūt$ an example of irregular sandhi for °Łrāgo 'bhūt$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Now, once there was an eclipse of the sun.</TR>
% uparāga is eclipse

%index_grammar: sandhi a-m-a instead of o '

%folioinfo \msNa\ image 211.jpg lower, f. 18r
% kṛṣṇe?
<TEXT> grastabhāgatrayas{ }tv{ }āsīt{ }kṛṣṇamādhavamāsike||</TEXT> 12:8
        <TR>Three quarters [of the sun] were eclipsed, and it was in the dark half
            of the month of Mādhava [April-May].</TR>

<TEXT> snātukāmāvatīryante sarve pauranṛpādayaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°vatīryante</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ca tīrthante \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łpāda$ a as Łsnātukāmā avatīryante$. It is an instance of double sandhi or
              of a \stemform\ noun in sandhi with the following verb.</NOTE>
        <TR>Eager to take a ritual bath, the king and all the citizens 
            went down [to the riverbank].</TR>
% nṛpādaḥ \msNcacorr

%index_grammar: stem form/double sandhi 

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.618
<TEXT> devāś{ }ca pitaraś{ }caiva tarpyante vidhivat{ }tathā||</TEXT> 12:9
        <APP>\vc <LEM>devāś{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; devaś{ }ca \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tarpyante</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; tapyante \msCb\msNb</APP>
        <TR>Then they worshipped the gods and the deceased ancestors according to the rules.</TR>

% juhvati is regular plural
<TEXT> kecij{ }juhvati tatrāgniṃ kecid{ }viprāṃś{ }ca tarpayet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°cij{ }juhvati</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                         °cij{ }juti \msCb, °ci<UNCL>j{ }va</UNCL>hvati \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>viprāṃś{ }ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; viprāś{ }ca \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łagniṃ$ in Łpāda$ a as locative, and Łtarpayet$ in Łpāda$ b as plural.</NOTE>
        <TR>Some sacrificed in the fire, some fed the Brahmins,</TR>

%index_grammar: accusative for locative
%index_grammar: singular for plural

<TEXT> kecid{ }dānopatiṣṭhanti kecit{ }stuvanti devatām||</TEXT> 12:10
        <APP>\vc <LEM>dāno°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dhyāno° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kecit{ }stuvanti</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc; kecid{ }vanti \msCc, 
                                                 keci stuvanti \msNa\msNb,
                                                 kecit{ }stunvanti \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>devatām</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; devatā \msCb\msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łdāna$ in Łpāda$ c in \stemform\ (for the instrumental).</NOTE>
        <TR>some were of service with donations, others praised the deity.</TR>
        %both stunvanti and stuvanti seem to be OK

% index_grammar: stem form

<TEXT> dhyānayogaratāḥ kecit{ }kecit{ }pañcatape ratāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°ratāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °ratā \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Some people practised yoga meditation, others were engrossed in five-fire penance.</TR>

<TEXT> evaṃ pravartamāneṣu rājanādiṣu sarvaśaḥ||</TEXT> 12:11
        <APP>\vd <LEM>rājanā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; rājānā° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Łrājanādiṣu$ in Łpāda$ d is suspect. The intended meaning may be
              `the royals and other people,' but I prefer now the option to
              take it as a shortened form of Łnīrājanādiṣu$, and that is how
              I translate it. Cf., e.g., \SIVP\ 7.30.81cd: 
              <skt>nīrājanādikaṃ kṛtvā pūjāśeṣaṃ samāpayet</skt>.</NOTE>
        <TR>While the ritual waving of lamps etc. were being performed all around the place,</TR>
        % rājana is not good? DG

%index_voc: rājana for nīrājana?

% gaṇḍaki metri causa
<TEXT> vipulo 'pi hi tatraiva gaṅgāgaṇḍakisaṃgame|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>'pi hi</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc;
                                 pi \msCb, hi na \msNaacorr, pi ca \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łgaṇḍaki$ metri causa for Łgaṇḍakī$ in Łpāda$ b.</NOTE>
        <TR>Vipula also, performing a bath there at the confluence of the Gaṅgā and the Gaṇḍakī,</TR>

%index_geo: Gaṅgā
%index_geo: Gaṇḍakī
%index_grammar: shortening metri causa gaṇḍaki

<TEXT> bhāryayā saha tatraiva snātvā kṣomavibhūṣaṇaḥ||</TEXT> 12:12
        <APP>\vc <LEM>bhāryayā</LEM> \msCapcorr\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; bhāryāyā \msCaacorr\msCc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°bhūṣaṇaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 °bhūṣa<UNCL>ṇaiḥ</UNCL> \msCc, °bhūṣitaḥ \msNa</APP>
        <TR>attired in linen clothes, together with his wife,</TR>

<TEXT> devatāguruviprāṇām{ }anyeṣāṃ tarpaṇe rataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM!>devatāguruviprāṇām{ }anyeṣāṃ tarpaṇe rataḥ</LEM> \msCb\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc;
                                 devatāguruvi\lac × ṇām{ }anyeṣāṃ tarpaṇe rataḥ \msCa,
                                 devatāguruviprāṇām{ }anyeṣāṃ tarpaṇe ratāḥ \msCc,
                                 \om\ \msNaacorr,
                                 devatāguruviprāṇām{ }anyeṣāṃ tarpaṇā rataḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>was engrossed in satiating the deities, the gurus, the Brahmins and others.</TR>
% viprāṇāṃm \msNb

<TEXT> tatrāvasarasamprāpto brāhmaṇo 'tithir{ }āgataḥ||</TEXT> 12:13
        <TR>Then, jumping on the possibility, a Brahmin came up [to them] as a guest.</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 427.jpg lower, f. 19r
<TEXT> bhāryā tasyātirūpeṇa mohitā brahmaṇas{ }tadā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>mohitā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; mohito \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>brahmaṇas{ }tadā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc; brāhmaṇās{ }tathā \msCc,
                                         brāhmaṇas{ }tadā \msNa\msNb, brāhmaṇasya ca \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The wife got infatuated with that Brahmin's extreme beauty.</TR>

% \msM: brāhmaṇo pi tathāveha  rūpeṇāpratimo bhavaḥ
<TEXT> brāhmaṇo 'pi tathaiveha rūpeṇāpratimo bhavet||</TEXT> 12:14
        <APP>\vc <LEM>brāhmaṇo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; brahmaṇo \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>tathaiveha</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed;
                                 ta<UNCL>the</UNCL>veha \msCa, tatheveha \msCc\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>rūpeṇā°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; rūpenā° \msCb, rūpeṇa \msCc, rūpiṇā° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ d is suspect and the translation of Łpāda$s cd is
               tentative. The expression Łrūpeṇāpratimo/°pratimā bhuvi$ 
               (`his/her beauty is unparalleled in the world') is 
               common in the \MBH\ and in the Purāṇas. Is that what was meant here?
               May a dual have been intended? An alternative reading, albeit requiring substantial
               emendations, could be: Łbrāhmaṇo 'pi tathaivāha rūpeṇāpratimā bhuvi$; 
               `The Brahmin [felt the same] and said [to himself,] 
                her figure is unparalleled in the world.'
                Nevertheless, I retained the reading found in the MSS, and I interpret Łpāda$ d
                as an indication that this Brahmin was extraordinary, in fact a manifestation of
                Dharma.</NOTE>
        <TR>The Brahmin [felt] the same. His beauty was unparalleled in the world.</TR>
     % maybe it is only about his beauty here? DG

%folioinfo \msNc\ 228.jpg lower, f. 226r 
<TEXT> anyonyadṛṣṭisaṃsaktau jātau tau tu parasparam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°saṃsaktau</LEM> \Ed; °saṃśaktau \msCa\msNa\msNc, 
                                            °śaktau \msCb, °saṃsakto \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>jātau tau</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed;
                                         jāto tau tau \msCc, jātau <UNCL>tā</UNCL> \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>While the apparatus here appears to indicate that in Łpāda$ a I am following \Ed, in fact
              the majority of the remaining witnesses suggest the same reading.</NOTE>
        <TR>Their gaze got fixed on each other mutually.</TR>

% Ed here inserts a line: ......................
        \vab ??? \Ed, \om\ \msCa\msCb\msCc
        % so Naraharinatha worked from some other MS
        % CHECK his preface
        %nothing extra in msParisaperMs A1341-06 347.jpg
<TEXT> vipulenāñjaliṃ kṛtvā brāhmaṇa saṃśitavrata||</TEXT> 12:15
        <APP>\vd <LEM>brāhmaṇa</LEM> \msCb\msCc; brāhmaṇaḥ \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo 
                 <LEM>°śita°</LEM> \eme; °śrita° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°vrata</LEM> \conj; °vra\lk\ \msCa, °vrataḥ \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vd Ł = MBh 12.213.18d and 12.347.1d $</PARAL>
        <TR>Vipula joined his hands [and said:] `O virtuous Brahmin,</TR>

<TEXT> ājñāpaya dvijaśreṣṭha adya me 'nugrahaṃ kuru|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°grahaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °graha \msCb</APP>
                     % grāmo/grāmaṃ?
        <TR>I am at your service, be gracious to me now, O great Brahmin.</TR>

<TEXT> bhāryābhṛtyapaśugrāma ratnāni vividhāni ca||</TEXT> 12:16
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°bhṛtya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °bhṛtyā° \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>°Łgrāma$ in Łpāda$ c is in \stemform, although it would be unproblematic
               to correct it to the neuter singular (to form a Łsamāhāra\-samāsa$).</NOTE>
        <TR>[My] wife, servants, cattle, village, and all kinds of jewels 
            [are all at your service].'</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form for no reason

<TEXT> vipulenaivam{ }uktas{ }tu gṛhīto brāhmaṇo 'bravīt|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>brāhmaṇo 'bravīt</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                         bhrāhmaṇas{ }tathā \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Having been addressed and greeted hospitably by Vipula, the Brahmin spoke:</TR>
        % we expect anugṛhīta

%folioinfo \msCb\ 433.jpg
<TEXT> yadi satyaṃ pradātāsi suprasannaṃ manas{ }tava||</TEXT> 12:17
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>yadi satyaṃ pradātāsi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>suprasannaṃ manas{ }tava</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; \om\ \msCc, 
                                                        suprasannamanas{ }tava \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that \msCc's omission of Łpāda$s cd here could be due
              to an eyeskip from Łsuprasannaṃ$ in 12.17d to Łsuprasannaṃ$ in 12.18a, 
              although this would have also led to an omission of the next Łvipula uvāca$.</NOTE>
        <TR>`If you really mean to give, your heart is very generous.'</TR>
        % calm... DG

<TEXT> vipula uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vipula spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> suprasannaṃ mano me 'dya suprasannaṃ tapaḥphalam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°prasannaṃ mano</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                         °prasannamano \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>suprasannaṃ tapaḥ°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                 suprasannatapaḥ° \msNb</APP>
        <TR>`My heart is generous today, generosity is the fruit of austerity.</TR>
        % peacefulness etc. DG

%folioinfo \msNb\ 58.jpg upper
<TEXT> śīghram{ }ājñāpaya vipra yac{ }cābhilaṣitaṃ tava|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śīghra°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; śrīghra° \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ c is either a Łsa-vipulā$ or by applying the \mutacumliquida,
              by which °Łpra$ does not make Łvi$° a long syllable, a Łna-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Just command me quickly, O Brahmin. What is your desire?</TR>

%index_metre: sa-vipulā or with muta cum liquida licence pra na-vipulā

<TEXT> adeyaṃ nāsti viprasya svaśiraḥprabhṛti dvija||</TEXT> 12:18
        <APP>\ve <LEM>adeyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; adeya \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>svaśiraḥ°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; śarīra° \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°bhṛti</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °bhṛtir \Ed</APP>
        <TR>There is nothing that should not be donated to a Brahmin,
            including one's own head, O Brahmin.'</TR>

<TEXT> brāhmaṇa uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>brāhmaṇa</LEM> \mssALL\msCapcorr\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                 brāhmaṇā \msCaacorr, brahma \msNb</APP>
        <TR>The Brahmin spoke:</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ image 220.jpg, f. 288v 
<TEXT> yady{ }evaṃ vadase bhadra bhāryāṃ me dehi rūpiṇīm|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>bhāryāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; bhāryā \msNb\msNc</APP>
        <TR>`If you talk like this, dear Sir, give me your beautiful wife.</TR>

<TEXT> svasti bhavatu bhadraṃ vaḥ kalyāṇaṃ bhava śāśvatam||</TEXT> 12:19
        <APP>\vc <LEM>svasti</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; svastiṃ \msNb, svastir \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kalyāṇaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kalyā<UNCL>ṇa</UNCL> \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>bhava</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tava \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ c has the metrical fault of two Łlaghu$s in the second and third position.

                In Łpāda$ d, Łbhava$ is less than satisfactory. One would normally expect 
                Łbhavate/bhavatāṃ/bhavatu$ in this context. Alternatively, it is possible that
                Łkalyāṇo bhava$ (`be happy') was meant, or \Ed's reading (Łtava$)
                could be accepted as a conjecture.</NOTE>
        <TR>May there be happiness, may you be fortunate, and may you prosper eternally!'</TR>
kalyā<UNCL>ṇa</UNCL> \msCc

%index_metre: two laghus

% Ed here inserts a line: ......................

<TEXT> vipula uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>vipula</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; vipra \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Vipula spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> pratīccha bhāryāṃ suśroṇīṃ rūpayauvanaśālinīm|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>bhāryāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; bhāryā \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°śroṇīṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNapcorr\msNc\Ed; °śroṇi \msCc\msNaacorr\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°śālinīm</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; °śālinī \msNb, °śīlinīṃ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>`Accept my nice-buttocked, young and beautiful wife,</TR>

<TEXT> akutsitāṃ viśālākṣīṃ pūrṇacandranibhānanām||</TEXT> 12:20
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>akutsitāṃ viśālākṣīṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                        akutsi<UNCL>tā</UNCL> viśālākṣi \msCc, 
                                                        akutsitā viśālāksī \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°nibhānanām</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °nibhānanā \msNb</APP>
        <TR>who is blameless, large-eyed, and whose face resembles the full-moon.'</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.619
%folioinfo \msCa\ 417.jpg
<TEXT> bhāryovāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>The wife spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> parityājyā kathaṃ nātha apāpāṃ tyajase katham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°tyājyā</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                         °tyājya \msCb\msNb, °tyā<UNCL>jya</UNCL> \msCc</APP>
        <TR>`How can you abandon me, my lord? How can you dismiss a woman who is sinless?</TR>
% tyajame \msCb

<TEXT> atīva hi priyāṃ bhāryāṃ nirdoṣāṃ ca kathaṃ tyajeḥ||</TEXT> 12:21
        <APP>\vc <LEM>priyāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; priyaṃ \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nirdoṣāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; nirdoṣa \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>tyajeḥ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc; tyajyet \msCb\msCc, tyajet \msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>ca</LEM> \conj; sa \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>All witnesses consulted read Łsa$ instead of my conjectured Łca$ in Łpāda$ d.
              Łsa$ might work if we read Łtyajet$ (\msCb\msCc) instead of Łtyajeḥ$ (\msCa\msNa\msNc),
              but even this version sounds a bit out of context (`how can he abandon...').</NOTE>
        <TR>How can you abandon a wife who is extremely kind and faultless?</TR>

<TEXT> sakhā bhāryā manuṣyāṇām{ }iha loke paratra ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>manuṣyāṇām{ }iha</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                                 manuṣyāṇāṃm{ }iha \msCc</APP>
        <TR>A wife is a man's friend in this world and in the other world.</TR>

                         tdatvā \msCc\msNc
<TEXT> dānaṃ vā sumahad{ }dattvā yajño vā subahuḥ kṛtaḥ||</TEXT> 12:22
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°bahuḥ</LEM> \eme; °bahu \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\ \unmetr,
                                                         °bahuṃ \msNb, °bahūn \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>kṛtaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kṛtam \msCc</APP>
        <TR>[Even if] a man gives enormous donations or performs numerous sacrifices,</TR>

<TEXT> aputro nāpnuyāt{ }svargaṃ tapobhir{ }vā suduṣkaraiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>svargaṃ tapobhir{ }vā</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                         sva<UNCL>rggan</UNCL> \lac ××× r{ }vvā \msCa</APP>
        <TR>or performs hard penance, he cannot reach heaven without having a son.</TR>

<TEXT> śruto me pitṛbhiḥ prokto brāhmaṇaiś{ }ca mamāntike||</TEXT> 12:23
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ntike</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °ntikaiḥ \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łme$ as instrumental in Łpāda$ c
             (<citep>OberliesEpicSkt</citep><pnum>102--103 [4.1.3]</pnum>).
              I translate Łpitṛbhiḥ$ in the same Łpāda$ as
              `father and uncles,' and not as `ancestors' because the former 
               fits the context better.</NOTE>
        <TR>I have heard this as taught by my father and my uncles, and by Brahmins in my presence.</TR>

%index_grammar: me for mayā (Oberlies 4.1.3 [pp. 102--103])

<TEXT> aputro nāpnuyāt{ }svargaṃ śrutaṃ me bahuśaḥ purā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>svargaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; svarga \msCb\msCc\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łme$ as instrumental again in Łpāda$ b.</NOTE>
        <TR>A sonless man cannot reach heaven. I have heard this so many times!</TR>

%index_grammar: me for mayā (Oberlies 4.1.3 [pp. 102--103])

<TEXT> mandapālo dvijaśreṣṭho gataḥ svargaṃ tapobalāt||</TEXT> 12:24
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°pālo</LEM> \msNc\Ed; °pāla \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>See details of Mandapāla's story, here summarised, in \MBH\ 1.220.5ff.</NOTE>
        <TR>Mandapāla, the great Brahmin, went to heaven as a reward of his austerities,</TR>

%index_persons: Mandapāla

<TEXT> dānāni ca bahūn{ }dattvā yajñāṃś{ }ca vividhāṃs{ }tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>bahūn{ }da°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; bahū da° \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>yajñāṃś{ }ca vividhāṃs{ }tathā</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb;
                                 yatvā yajñāṃś{ }ca vividhāṃ tathā \msCb, 
                                 yajñāṃś{ }ca vividhām{ }tathā \msNc,
                                 syajñāś{ }ca vividhās{ }tathā \Ed</APP>
        <TR>having made numerous donations, having performed various sacrifices,</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ image 212.jpg upper, f. 18v
<TEXT> vedāṃś{ }ca japayajñāṃś{ }ca kṛtvā sa dvijasattamaḥ||</TEXT> 12:25
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>vedāṃś{ }ca japayajñāṃś{ }ca</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc;
                         vedāś{ }ca japayajñāṃś{ }ca \msCb, vedāṃś{ }ca japayajñāś{ }ca \msNb,
                         vedāś{ }ca japayajñāś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sa dvi°</LEM> \conj; taddvi° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed, taddvi° \msNb, saddvi° \msNc\oo
                <LEM>°sattamaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °sattama \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łdānānī bahūn$ for Łdānāni bahūni$ in Łpāda$ a.
              Understand Łpāda$ c as Łvedayajñāñ japayajñāṃś ca kṛtvā$.
              (See Łvedayajña$ mentioned in \VSS\ 3.37a above.)
              On Łjapayajña$, see \VSS\ 6.1--2 and 5 above, as well as, e.g.,
              \BHG\ 10.25c (Łyajñānāṃ japayajño 'smi$) and \MANU\ 2.86 
              (Łvidhiyajñāj japayajño viśiṣṭo daśabhir guṇaiḥ$).</NOTE>
        <TR>Vedic sacrifices and sacrifices of recitation, that great Brahmin.</TR>


<TEXT> prāptadvāro 'pi yasyāpi devadūtair{ }nivāritaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dvāro</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;   °dvāre \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>yasyāpi de°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; yasyāpi dde° \msNb,
                                                                      yasyāhi de° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°dūtair{ }ni°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; °dūtai nni° \msNb,
                                                                     °dūtai ni° \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$s ab are not perfectly smooth syntactically, Łyasyāpi$ is difficult to fit in.
              Perhaps understand Łprāptadvāre 'pi yasmin sa devatūtair nivāritaḥ$. Alternatively, 
              Łyasya$ might reference Łsvargaḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>But even he, even when he reached the gate [of heaven],
                         was stopped by the celestial messengers. [They said:]</TR>
        % yasya is a bit strange

<TEXT> aputro nāpnuyāt{ }svargaṃ yadi yajñaśatair{ }api||</TEXT> 12:26
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°yāt{ }svargaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                         °yāt{ }svargga \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°śatair{ }api</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; karoti yaḥ \msCc</APP>
        <TR>``The sonless cannot enter heaven, not even by hundreds of sacrifices.''</TR>

<TEXT> ity{ }uktas{ }tu cyutaḥ svargān{ }mandapālo mahān{ }ṛṣiḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°ktas{ }tu cyutaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                         °ktas{ }tu<UNCL>mcyu</UNCL>taḥ \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Mandapāla, the great sage, having been thus informed fell from heaven.</TR>

<TEXT> putrān{ }utpādayām{ }āsa śāraṅgāṃś{ }caturo dvijaḥ||</TEXT> 12:27
        <APP>\vc <LEM>putrān{ }u°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; putram{ }u° \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>śāraṅgāṃś{ }ca</LEM> \msNa\msNc; śāraṅgāś{ }ca \msCa, śāraṅgaṃś{ }ca \msCb,
                                                 śāraṅgaś{ }ca \msCc\msNb, śāraṅgāc{ }ca \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>dvijaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dvija \msCc</APP>
        <TR>The Brahmin begot four sons with a Śāraṅga-bird.</TR>

<TEXT> tena puṇyaprabhāveṇa svargaṃ prāpto hy{ }avāritaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>svargaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; svargga \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°vāritaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °varitaḥ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>By the virtue of this, he reached heaven unobstructed.</TR>
% prabhāvena \msNa\msNb\msNc CHECK other MSS

%folioinfo \msM\ 428.jpg upper, f. 19v
<TEXT> kulatrāṇāt{ }kalatrāsmi bharaṇād{ }bhārya eva ca||</TEXT> 12:28
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kula°</LEM> \msCb; kala° \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°trāṇāt{ }ka°</LEM> \msNb; °trāṇāṃ ka° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed, °trāṇā ka° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°smi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °smiṃ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ād{ }bhārya eva</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                         °ād{ }bhāryam{ }eva \msCb, °ā bhārya eva \msCc\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that Łpāda$ c is the result of emendations 
                (the majority of the MSS read Łkalatrāṇāṃ kalatrāsmi$),
                and that Łbhārya$ in Łpāda$ d is to be understood as Łbhāryā$ 
                metri causa. I added `to be supported' in the translation to convey 
                the general meaning of the word Łbhārya$, 
                which seemed to fit the context well.</NOTE>
        <TR>I am a wife (Łkalatra$) because I protect the family (Łkulatrāṇāt$), and I am a wife to 
                        be supported (Łbhāryā$) because I bear [sons] (Łbharaṇa$).</TR>

%index_grammar: shortening metri causa bhārya

<TEXT> dārasaṃgraha putrārthe kriyate śāstradarśanāt|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°graha</LEM> \msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °grahaḥ \msCa\msCb\msNa\oo
                 <LEM>putrā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; pātrā° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kriyate</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kriyāte \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ °Łsaṃgraha$ metri causa in Łpāda$ a.</NOTE>
        <TR>Taking a wife is for the sake of having sons according to the Śāstras.</TR>

% index_grammar: stem form (metri causa)

%grahaf \msCa;      santi -- dravyaṃ number
<TEXT> yāni santi gṛhe dravyaṃ grāmaghoṣagṛhāṇi ca||</TEXT> 12:29
        <NOTE>Note the number discrepancy between Łyāni santi$ and Łdravyaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c,
              which is repeated in 12:42a.</NOTE>
        <TR>Please give that Brahmin all the wealth you find at home,
                     the village, the stations of herdsmen, and the houses,</TR>
% gṛhāni \msNa
%index_grammar: number confusion

<TEXT> dātum{ }arhasi viprāya na māṃ dātum{ }ihārhasi|</TEXT>
        <TR>but please don't give me away this time!'</TR>

<TEXT> bhāryāyā vacanaṃ śrutvā vipulaḥ punar{ }abravīt||</TEXT> 12:30
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vacanaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; vacana \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°bravīt</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msCcacorr\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                 °bravīt| vipula uvāca| \msCcpcorr\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I have not included \msCcpcorr's Łvipula uvāca$ (echoed in \Ed)
                because after Łpunar abravīt$ is seems secondary and unnecessary.
                Note that the correction in \msCc\ is in a second hand and it is also 
                to be found in paper NSS \msPaperA\ and \msPaperC\ 
                (see p.~\pageref{vipulauvaca}).</NOTE>
        <TR>Having heard his wife's speech, Vipula spoke again.</TR>
%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed

%folioinfo \msNc\ 229.jpg upper, f. 226v

% one could get rid of this!
% vipula uvāca|*
%        \vo vipula uvāca \msCcpcorr\msPaperA and C (8317) !!! \Ed; \om\ \msCa\msCb\msCcacorr\msNa\msNc


<TEXT> sādhu bhāmini jānāmi sādhu sādhu pativrate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>jānāmi</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\Ed; jānāsi \msCa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>pati°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; prati° \msNb</APP>
        <TR>`Alright, my beautiful wife, I know! Good, good, my faithful wife!</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCa and \msNc (weak)

<TEXT> jito 'smy{ }anena vākyena anenāsmi hi toṣitaḥ||</TEXT> 12:31
        <APP>\vd <LEM>toṣitaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; torṣinaḥ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>I am beaten by this speach and I am satisfied with it.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ image 221.jpg, f. 289r 
<TEXT> adya grahaṇakāle ca dvija āgatya yācate|</TEXT>
        <TR>Today the Brahmin came up to me at the time of eclipse, and he asked me.</TR>

%                                  vraje for vrajāmi
<TEXT> dadāmīti pratijñāya adattvā narakaṃ vraje||</TEXT> 12:32
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vraje</LEM> \msCa\msNapcorr\msNc; vrajet \msCb\msCc\msNb\Ed,
                                                        vraje\lk\ \msNaacorr</APP>
        <TR>I promised him that I would give [you away].
            If I don't give [you to him], I will go to hell.</TR>

<TEXT> narakaṃ yadi gacchāmi kulena saha sundari|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>yadi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; yayadi \msNc</APP>
        <TR>If I go to hell along with my family,</TR>

% sthā - the family?
<TEXT> kalpakoṭisahasre 'pi narakastho yaśasvini|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°sahasre 'pi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °sahasrāṇi \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°stho ya°</LEM> \msNc\Ed; °sthād{ }ya° \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb, sthā ya° \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>The reading Łnarakastho$ in Łpāda$ b (\msNc\Ed) might not be the original one but it is 
              definitely the simplest solution.  Łnarakasthād$ may be original,
               possibly meaning Łnarakasthānād$.</NOTE>
        <TR>I will be in hell, O brilliant woman, for millions of \ae ons,</TR>

% index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed 
% index_stemma: \msNc and \Ed ???

<TEXT> muktim{ }eva na paśyāmi janmakoṭiśatair{ }api||</TEXT> 12:33
        <APP>\ve <LEM>muktim{ }eva</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; muktim{ }evan \Ed</APP>
        <TR>and will not see release for millions of births.</TR>

<TEXT> adānāc{ }cāśubhaṃ devi paśyāmi varavarṇini|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>adānāc{ }cā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; adānā cā° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>I can see something bad [coming], my Princess, from not giving,
            O woman with a nice complexion,</TR>

<TEXT> dānena tu śubhaṃ paśye svargaloke yad{ }akṣayam||</TEXT> 12:34
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°loke</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc;
                                                 \om\ \msNaacorr, °lokaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>but from giving I can see something good in heaven that is eternal.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 434.jpg 
<TEXT> noktaṃ mayānṛtaṃ pūrvaṃ nityaṃ satyavrate sthitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>noktaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNcpcorr\Ed; noktā \msNcacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°vrate</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °vrata° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>I have never ever lied, I always observe the vow of truthfulness.</TR>

<TEXT> satyadharmam{ }atikramya nānyadharmaṃ samācare||</TEXT> 12:35
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°care</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °caret \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <TR>If I transgressed the Dharma of truthfullness, [by this] 
                I would stop following all other Dharmas [too].</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.620
<TEXT> bhāryā dharmasakhety{ }evaṃ tvayā pūrvam{ }udāhṛtam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dharma°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; dharmaṃ \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tvayā</LEM> \eme; tvayi \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I have emended Łtvayi$ in Łpāda$ d to Łtvayā$ because it 
                seems an early random scribal mistake, rather than some 
                linguistic pecularity.</NOTE>
        <TR>You mentioned earlier that the wife is one's Dharmic friend.</TR>

%index_grammar: tvayi for tvayā (corrected)

<TEXT> yadi dharmasakhāyāsi so 'dya kāla ihāgataḥ||</TEXT> 12:36
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°sakhāyā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °sakhā° \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the form Łsakhāyā$ for a feminine Łsakhī$ or Łsahāyā$. I sense a touch
              of humour or sarcasm in Vipula's spin on his wife's claim in 12.22a that
              `a wife is a man's friend': now he suggests that his wife, his `Dharmic friend,'
               is actually friends with Dharma.</NOTE>
        <TR>If you are indeed Dharma's friend, it was actually the perfect time for 
                        him to come up to us today.</TR>

%index_voc: sakhāyā as nom. 

<TEXT> dvijarūpadharo dharmaḥ svayam{ }eva ihāgataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°dharo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °paro \msCb</APP>
        <TR>[For] Dharma himself visited us, disguised as a Brahmin.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 418.jpg
%folioinfo \msNb\ 59.jpg lower
<TEXT> jijñāsārtham{ }ahaṃ bhadre na vighnaṃ kartum{ }arhasi||</TEXT> 12:37
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°rtham{ }ahaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed;
                                         °rthamm{ }ahaṃ \msNb, °rtham{ }aha \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Łjijñāsārtham ahaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c is slightly clumsy. Understand
              Łmaj-jijñāsārthaṃ$ (`in order to test me').</NOTE>
        <TR>I am being tested. My dear, please don't cause me trouble.</TR>

<TEXT> mātāvyaktaḥ pitā brahmā buddhir{ }bhāryā damaḥ sakhā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°vyaktaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed;    
                                         °vyakta \msCc, °vyakta<UNCL>'</UNCL> \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>buddhir{ }bhā°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb; buddhi bhā° \msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>damaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; dama \msNb\ \unmetr\oo
                 <LEM>sakhā</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; samā \msCa</APP>
        <TR>The unmanifest (Łavyakta$) is my mother, Brahmā is my father,
                 intelligence my wife, self-control my friend.</TR>

<TEXT> putro dharmaḥ kriyācārya ity{ }ete mama bāndhavāḥ||</TEXT> 12:38
        <TR>Dharma is my son, ritual is my teacher. These are my relatives.</TR>

<TEXT> kālaśreṣṭho grahaḥ sūryo gaṅgā śreṣṭhā nadīṣu ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°śreṣtho</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNcpcorr; °śreṣṭha° \msCa\msCc\msNb, °śreṣṭhā \msNcacorr, °śreṣṭhaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śreṣṭhā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; śreṣṭho \msNa, śreṣṭha \msNb</APP>
% \msNcpcorr is perhaps in another hand
                <TR>The best time is the time of the eclipse of the Sun.
                The best one among the rivers is the Gaṅgā.</TR>
       <PARAL>\vb Ł\similar\ 15.18b:$ śreṣṭhā gaṅgā nadīṣu ca</PARAL>
       <NOTE>I understand Łgrahaḥ sūryo$ in Łpāda$ a as Łsūryagrahaḥ$ (or Łsūryagrahaṇam$):
               the eclipse of the Sun, which appears to be an auspicious day.
               See, e.g., \AgamaKL\ 3.128:
                <sep/>
                Łsūryagrahaṇakālasya samānā nāsti bhūtale$ | <br/>
                Łatra yad yat kṛtaṃ karma anantaphaladaṃ bhavet$ ||</NOTE>

% see also Agastyasaṃhitā X.XXcd\verify\ (on the proper date for initiation):
% <skt>sūryagrahaṇakālena samāno nāsti kaścana</skt>
%also ibid. X.XX (on image installation):
%sūryagrahe mahāpuṇye kurukṣetre vidhānataḥ|
        % See the sāraśreṣṭha chapter

%index_geo: Gaṅgā

<TEXT> candrakṣaye dinaṃ śreṣṭhaṃ naraśreṣṭho dvijottamaḥ||</TEXT> 12:39
        <APP>\vc <LEM>dinaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; dina° \msCc\msNb\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ttamaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °ttama \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE><sep/>
              This short list of `best of' items anticipates \VSS\ 15.16--29, a longer
              list of what is best in every possible category, not entirely differently in
              manner from \BHG\ 10.21--38.</NOTE>
        <TR>The best day is at new moon, the best man is the Brahmin.</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed

<TEXT> śuśrūṣaṇārthaṃ viprasya mayā dattāsi sundari|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°rthaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °rtha \msCb</APP>
        <TR>I have given you to the Brahmin to serve him, O beautiful woman.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<TEXT> sarvasvaṃ brāhmaṇe dattvā vanam{ }evāśrayāmy{ }aham||</TEXT> 12:40
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ d may give a hint at the connection between this chapter and the
              end of the previous one: this story is partly a propagation 
              of the life of the Łvānaprastha$.</NOTE>
        <TR>After I have given all my riches to the Brahmin, I shall resort to the forest.'</TR>
% In Łpāda$ c, Łbrāhmaṇe$ (locative, in all the witnesses that I have consulted) 
% may have originally read Łbrahmaṇe$ (dative).

% Narahari version ! NO: it's maheśvara in PaperMS A1341-06! (348.jpg) and C107-7 (8317.jpg)
% but it's śaṅkara in PaperMS C57-5 and B119-3 (3832.jpg)
<TEXT> śaṅkara uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>śaṅkara</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; maheśvara \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that the variant Łmaheśvara uvāca$ in \Ed\ may seem as an odd
              alteration by Naraharinath, but in fact paper MSS \msPaperA\ and \msPaperC\
              (neither collated for this chapter) also read the same. 
              See pp.~\pageref{msPaperAdesc} ff.</NOTE>
        <TR>Śaṅkara spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> tūṣṇīmbhūtā tato bhāryā aśrupūrṇākulekṣaṇā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tūṣṇīmbhūtā</LEM> \msCa; tūṣṇībhūtvā \msCb, tuṣṇībhūta \msCc, tūṣṇībhūtā \msNa\msNb,
                                                tuṣṇīmbhūtī \msNc, tūṣṇībhūtāṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>bhāryā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; bhāryāṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kṣaṇā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; °kṣaṇaḥ \msCc, °kṣaṇāḥ \msNb, °kṣaṇām \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The wife remained silent, her bewildered eyes filled with tears.</TR>

<TEXT> kare gṛhya viśālākṣī brāhmaṇāya niveditā||</TEXT> 12:41
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°kṣī</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °kṣīṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>brāhmaṇāya niveditā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 brāhmaya diveditā \msCb</APP>
        <TR>[Vipula] took her by the hand and the long-eyed woman was presented to the Brahmin.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ image 212.jpg lower, f. 19r
<TEXT> yāni santi gṛhe dravyaṃ hiraṇyaṃ paśavas{ }tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>hiraṇyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; hiraṇya° \msNa\Ed</APP>
        <TR>`I am ready to give you all the wealth I have at home, all the gold and cattle,</TR>

% CHECK if it is not grāmagoṣṭhamaṇadaya as in \msM
<TEXT> dadāmi te dvijaśreṣṭha grāmaghoṣagṛhādikam||</TEXT> 12:42
        <APP>\vc <LEM>dadāmi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dadāni \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>te dvija°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; \lac ×× ja° \msCa, ta dvija° \msNc</APP>
        <TR>O great Brahmin, the village, the stations of herdsmen, and the houses,
                        and everything else,</TR>

<TEXT> muktāvaiḍūryavāsāṃsi divyāṇy{ }ābharaṇāni ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°vaiḍūrya°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc; °vaibhārya° \msCc, °vairya° \msNaacorr, 
                                                             °vaidūrya° \msNapcorr\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°vāsāṃsi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °vāsāsi \msNc</APP>
        <TR>pearls, gems, clothes, and exquisite jewellery.</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 428.jpg lower, f. 20r
<TEXT> sarvān{ }gṛhāṇa viprendra śraddhayā dattasatkṛtān||</TEXT> 12:43
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sarvān{ }gṛhāṇa</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; sarvān{ }tān{ }gṛhṇa \msCc, 
                                                                sarvān{ }gṛhān \msNb,   
                                                                sarvāṃ gṛhāṇa \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°satkṛtān</LEM> \eme; °satkṛtām \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed, °satkṛtam \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Accept all these, O best of Brahmins. It's given in good faith and with respect.</TR>

<TEXT> prīyatāṃ bhagavān{ }dharmaḥ prīyatāṃ ca maheśvaraḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>prīya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNcpcorr\Ed; prīna° \msNcacorr</APP>
        <NOTE>Note \SDHS\ 10.11cd, in a similar context of donations:
                Łbhojayitvā tato brūyāt prīyatāṃ bhagavān śivaḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>May Lord Dharma be pleased and may Maheśvara be pleased.</TR>

<TEXT> prīyantāṃ pitaraḥ sarve yady{ }asti sukṛtaṃ phalam||</TEXT> 12:44
        <APP>\vc <LEM>prīyantāṃ</LEM> \msCa; prīyatāṃ \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed, prīyatā \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>pitaraḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; pitara \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>asti</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; asi \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łsukṛtaṃ phalam$ as Łsukṛtaphalam$ (metri causa).</NOTE>
        <TR>May all the ancestors rejoice if there is reward for meritorious acts.'</TR>

% EDDIG

% Narahari version ! NO: it's maheśvara in PaperMS A1341-06! (348.jpg) % but it's rudra in PaperMS C57-5
<TEXT> rudra uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>rudra</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; maheśvara \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that the variant Łmaheśvara uvāca$ in \Ed\ again is to be found in 
             the paper MS \msPaperA, but this time not in \msPaperC\ (compare note to 12.41).</NOTE>
        <TR>Rudra spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> vipulasya vacaḥ śrutvā brāhmaṇena tapasvinā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vacaḥ śrutvā</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 vaca<UNCL>ś{ }śru</UNCL>\lac\ × \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tapasvinā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; tapasvinām \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Having heard Vipula's speech, the ascetic Brahmin</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 222.jpg f. 289v
<TEXT> āśīḥ suvipulaṃ dattvā vipulāya mahātmane||</TEXT> 12:45
        <NOTE>One may wonder why the Brahmin is labelled as ascetic (Łtapasvin$) 
              in Łpāda$ b. 
              <sep/>  
              There are several ways to explain the form Łāśīḥ$ in Łpāda$ c.
              The easiest is to treat it as a singular accusative neuter.
              Alternatively, it could be a plural accusative feminine of Łāśī$ and
              then Łsuvipulaṃ$ is either to be understood adverbially or as Łsuvipulā$[Łḥ$].
              Another way to treat Łāśīḥ$ would be to take it as a nominative standing
              for the accusative.</NOTE>
        <TR>blessed the good-souled Vipula a good number of times,</TR>

%index_grammar: nominative for accusative

<TEXT> vaset{ }tatra gṛhe ramye bhāryām{ }ādāya tasya ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vaset{ }tatra gṛhe</LEM> \msCb\msNa; vasa tatra gṛhe \msCa\msCc\msNb,
                                         vas<UNCL>en{ }ta</UNCL>tra gṛhe \msNc,
                                         vasate ca gṛhaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>and then went off to live in a nice house, taking Vipula's wife with him.</TR>

<TEXT> vipulas{ }tu namaskṛtvā kṛtvā cāpi pradakṣiṇam||</TEXT> 12:46
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vipulas{ }tu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; vipulasya \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kṛtvā cāpi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNc,
                                                         kṛtvā ca vi° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>As for Vipula, he saluted and circulambulated him.</TR>

<TEXT> brāhmaṇam{ }abhivādyaivaṃ gataḥ śīghraṃ vanāntaram|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>brāhmaṇa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; brāhmaṇā° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°dyaivaṃ</LEM> \eme; °dyevaṃ \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed, °dyenaṃ \msCb,
                                                 °dyavaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śīghraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; śrīghraṃ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the metrical problem in Łpāda$ a (two Łlaghu$s).</NOTE>
% dyevaṅ \msCa
        <TR>Thus saying good-bye to the Brahmin, he departed quickly into the forest.</TR>

%index_grammar: two laghus (pāda b)


%folioinfo \msNc\ 229.jpg lower, f. 227r
<TEXT> vane mūlaphalāhāro vicareta mahītale||</TEXT> 12:47
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°phalāhāro</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNcpcorr\Ed;
                                                 °phāhāro \msNcacorr</APP>
        <TR>In the forest, he lived off roots and fruits, and roamed the world.</TR>

<TEXT> ekākī vijane śūnye cintayā ca pariplutaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>ekākī</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 e<UNCL>kā</UNCL>\lac\ × \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>pari°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; pali° \msNc</APP>
        <TR>But being alone in an abandoned and deserted place, he got overwhelmed with worry.</TR>

<TEXT> kva gacchāmi kva bhokṣyāmi kutra vā kiṃ karomy{ }aham||</TEXT> 12:48
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kva gacchāmi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; kṣa gacchāmi \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>kva bhokṣyāmi</LEM> \msCa; kva bhojyāmi \msCb\msNa\msNb, kva bhokṣyāni \msCc,
                                        kva bhokṣāmi \msNc, kiṃ bhokṣyāmi \Ed\ \unmetr</APP>
        <TR>`Where should I go? Where could I find food? From whom? What shall I do?</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCb and \msNa?

<TEXT> na pathaṃ viṣayaṃ vedmi grāmaṃ vā nagarāṇi vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>viṣayaṃ vedmi</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\Ed; viṣamaṃ vedmi \msCb\msCc, viyaṣaṃ ve<UNCL>śmi</UNCL> \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; ca \msCb\msNa</APP>
        <TR>I don't know these roads, this country, these villages, and these cities,</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCb and \msNa?

<TEXT> kheṭakharvaṭadeśaṃ vā jānāmīha na kaṃcana||</TEXT> 12:49
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kheṭa°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kṣetra° \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°kharvaṭa°</LEM> \Ed; °karpaṭa° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kaṃcana</LEM> \eme; kaścana \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ c, I accepted \Ed's reading (°Łkharvaṭa$°, `a mountain village')
              against all witnesses consulted.  The MSS transmit a reading that is 
              difficult to make sense of (°Łkharpaṭa$, `ragged garment').
              In Łpāda$ d, the reading of all the witnesses, Łkaścana$, seems to be
              an early scribal mistake for Łkañcana$. But note that the same happens in 12.55d.</NOTE>
        <TR>towns, and mountain settlements. I don't know anybody here.</TR>

%index_grammar: kaścana for kaṃcana
%index_stemma: \Ed has the right reading?

<TEXT> amuṃ suśailaṃ paśyāmi vipulodarakandaram|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>suśailaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; suśelaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vipulo°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; vilo° \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is a Łma-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>I can see a nice mountain yonder with large cavities and caves.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<TEXT> tam{ }āruhya nirīkṣyāmi grāmaṃ nagarapattanam||</TEXT> 12:50
        <APP>\vc <LEM>nirīkṣyāmi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; nirīkṣāmi \msNc</APP>
        <TR>I'll climb it and try to figure out if there is a village, town, or city [nearby].'</TR>

<TEXT> evam{ }uktvā tu vipulaḥ śanaiḥ parvatam{ }āruhat|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>evam{ }u°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ekaṃ u° \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°ruhat</LEM> \Ed; °ruhet \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>I have accepted the reading of \Ed\ in Łpāda$ d (Łāruhat$)
              because I think that Łāruhet$ is an early scribal mistake that
              is easy to make, and because °Łāruhat$ comes up again in 12.53d.
              Additionally, \msPaperA\ (paper MS, not collated here)
              seems to read Łāruhat$ too (f.~220r).</NOTE>
        <TR>Having said this, Vipula climbed the mountain slowly.</TR>

%index_stemma: \Ed has the right reading?

<TEXT> vṛkṣacchāyāṃ samālokya niṣasāda śramānvitaḥ||</TEXT> 12:51
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°cchāyāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °cchāyā \msNc</APP>
        <TR>He caught sight of the shades of a tree, and, being exhausted, sat down [there].</TR>


<TEXT> etasminn{ }eva kāle tu vṛkṣaśākhāvatārya ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>etasminn{ }eva</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; etasmiṃn{ }aiva \msCc, etasminn{ }aiva \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>kāle tu</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; kālena \msCc\Ed, kālenu \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vṛkṣa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNcpcorr\Ed; vṛkṣā° \msNa\msNcacorr</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ noun °Łśākhā$ in Łpāda$ b. Understand °Łśākhāyā avatārya$
              or Łśākhayāvatārya$. Understand Łsugandhatvaṃ$ in Łpāda$ d as
              Łsugandhi$. 
        <sep/>
              From this point on, the story might be interpreted as a dream. See especially 12.149ab:
                Łsvapnabhūtam ivāścāryaṃ paśyāmi...$.</NOTE>
        <TR>In the same moment, descending from among the branches of the tree,</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form with verb metri causa

%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed
%index_stemma: \msCc and \msNc ?

% sugandhatvam here = sugandham
<TEXT> apūrvaṃ ca surūpaṃ ca sugandhatvaṃ ca śobhanam||</TEXT> 12:52
        <APP>\vc <LEM>surūpaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; svarūpaṃ \msCb\msNa</APP>
        <TR>[a monkey appeared and] carrying an extraordinary, beautiful, fragrant, exquisite,</TR>
%index_stemma: \msCb and \msNa?

<TEXT> phalaṃ gṛhya vicitraṃ ca hṛdayānandanaṃ śubham|</TEXT>
        <TR>lovely, delightful and pleasant-looking fruit,</TR>

% \msNc\ has śivāya namaḥ here in the left margin

<TEXT> vipulasyāgrataḥ kṛtvā punar{ }vṛkṣaṃ samāruhat||</TEXT> 12:53
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>punar{ }vṛkṣaṃ samāruhat</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; 
                                                        puna vṛkṣa samāruham \msCc, 
                                                        punar{ }vṛkṣa samāruhaṃ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note how the agent of this sentence is omitted here. That it was a monkey
              that gave Vipula the fruit becomes clear in 12.94 below.</NOTE>
        <TR>it put it in front of Vipula, and then climbed back onto the tree.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 419.jpg
<TEXT> vipulaś{ }citravad{ }dṛṣṭvā vismayaṃ paramaṃ gataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°travad{ }dṛṣṭvā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °trava dṛṣṭvā \msCc</APP>
% To explain the adverb Łcitravat$ in Łpāda$ a grammatically, 
% one could cite Śaṅkara on \BHG\ 2.29, explaining Łāścaryavat$: Łāścaryavat āścaryam iva$.
        <TR>Vipula, looking [at it] as if seeing a miracle, was perplexed.</TR>

<TEXT> aho vā svapnabhūto 'smi aho vā tapasaḥ phalam||</TEXT> 12:54
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°bhūto 'smi aho</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °saṃbhūto <UNCL>smy{ }a</UNCL>ho \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>See notes on 12.52 above on how most of the story could be interpreted as a 
              dream.</NOTE>
        <TR>Wow, am I sleeping? Or is this the fruit of my penance?</TR>

<TEXT> na paśyāmi na jighrāmi na ca svādaṃ ca vedmy{ }aham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>jighrāmi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; ca ghrāmi \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the use of the (non-historical) present tense
              in Łpāda$s ab clearly pointing to past events.</NOTE>
        <TR>I have never seen, smelt, or tasted anything like this.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 435.jpg
<TEXT> vārttāpi na ca me śrotā pratijānāmi kaṃcana||</TEXT> 12:55
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śrotā</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; śrotrā \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kaṃcana</LEM> \eme; kaścana \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I suspect that Łśrotā$ in Łpāda$ c is meant to be feminine participle Łśrutā$, but
              the metre required the first vowel to be lengthened.
              Understand Łme$ as Łmayā$ (<citep>OberliesEpicSkt</citep><pnum>102--103 [4.1.3]</pnum>).
              In Łpāda$ d, the reading of all the witnesses, Łkaścana$, seems to be
              an early scribal mistake for Łkañcana$. Note that the same happens in 12.49d.</NOTE>
        <TR>I have not even heard of anything like this. I shall let somebody know about it.</TR>

%index_grammar: kaścana for kaṃcana
%index_metre: lengthening metri causa (śrotā)

<TEXT> evam{ }uktvā hy{ }anekāni phalaṃ gṛhya manoramam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°m{ }uktvā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °m{ }uktā \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>gṛhya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; gṛha \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Since one of the main points, and a source of conflict, in the story is 
              that there was only one single fruit, we have to interpret Łanekāni$ in 
              Łpāda$ a as a shortened form of Łanekavāram$ (`repeatedly').</NOTE>
        <TR>Having repeated this several times, taking that nice fruit,</TR>

<TEXT> sunirīkṣya punar{ }jighran punar{ }jighran{ }nirīkṣya ca||</TEXT> 12:56
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°nirīkṣya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °nirīkṣa \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>punar{ }jighran{ }punar{ }jighran</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed;
                                      muna jighraṃ puna jighraṃ \msCc,
                                      punar{ }jighra punar{ }jighraṃ \msNb,
                                      punar{ }jighra punar{ }jighra \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nirīkṣya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; nirīkṣa \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Most sources consulted read Łjighra$ or Łjighraṃ$ in both 
              Łpāda$ c and d, i.e. most of them do not suggest the participle Łjighran$, 
              which seems to be the correct reading. I have altered this
              part of the text silently.</NOTE>
        <TR>he kept observing it smelling it again and again.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 59.jpg upper
<TEXT> phalaṃ cātra nirūpyanto deśaṃ vāpy{ }avalokayan|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>cātra</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                         cā \msCaacorr, cā<UNCL>tra</UNCL> \msCapcorr\oo
                 <LEM>nirūpyanto</LEM> \Ed; nirūpyānti \msCa, nirūpyāṃ cā \msCb,
                                         nirūpyanti \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°lokayan</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °lokayat \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łnirūpyanto$ in Łpāda$ a as a thematised present participle 
              in the nominative (Łnirūpayan$). This is also suggested by the standard Łavalokayan$
              in Łpāda$ b.</NOTE>
        <TR>`While gazing at this fruit, and observing the countryside,</TR>

%index_grammar: thematised present participle

<TEXT> pātheyarahitaś{ }cāsmi devadattaṃ phalaṃ mama||</TEXT> 12:57
        <APP>\vc <LEM>pātheya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; patheya° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°rahitaś{ }cā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °rahite cā° \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dattaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc; °datta° \msCb\msCc\msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>phalaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; \om\ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>I have run out of provisions. This fruit is godsent.</TR>

<TEXT> tat{ }phalaṃ pratigṛhyaiva nagaraṃ praviśāmy{ }aham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°gṛhyaiva</LEM> \msCb\msNb\Ed; °gṛhyeva \msCa\msNc, gṛhe ca \msCc, °gṛhyaivaṃ \msNa</APP>
        <TR>Therefore I shall take this fruit and enter that city,</TR>

<TEXT> prārthayitvā tu yat{ }kiṃcij{ }jīvanārthaṃ carāmy{ }aham||</TEXT> 12:58
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tu</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>yat{ }kiṃcij{ }jī°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                         yat{ }kiṃji jī° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>and I shall go and seek something to live on.'</TR>
%  \msCa\ yaṅ?

%folioinfo \msNa\ image 213.jpg upper, f. 19v
<TEXT> tataḥ śailam{ }atikramya nagaraṃ praviveśa ha|</TEXT>
        <TR>Then crossing that mountain, he entered the city.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 223.jpg f. 290r
<TEXT> pathi kaścij{ }janaḥ pṛṣṭhaḥ kiṃnāma nagaraṃ tv{ }idam||</TEXT> 12:59
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nagaraṃ tv{ }idam</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; 
                                        nagara tv{ }idam \msCb\msCc, nagaraṃ tv{ }iha \msNb</APP>
        <TR>He asked a man on the road: `What is the name of this city?'</TR>
% \msNc the ṃ is difficult to see but it's there; source of \msCb\msCc?

%folioinfo \msM\ 429.jpg upper, f. 20v
<TEXT> sa hovāca pathīkena kim{ }apūrvam{ }ihāgataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>sa ho°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; aho° \msCb\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>pathīkena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; pathīko na \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°gataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °tavaḥ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>I understand Łpathīkena$ as standing for Łpathikena$ metri causa (see 12.64b) and not
              as two words, Łpathī kena$. This means that we are forced to accept 
              an instrumental as the agent of the finite verb Łuvāca$ 
              (ergative structure, see p.~\pageref{ergative}).
              I suspect that \msNc's reading (Łpathīko na$) 
              is an attempt to correct the syntax, but in this way Łna \dots\ apūrvam$ becomes 
              problematic.</NOTE>
        <TR>The traveller replied: `Have you never been here before?</TR>

%index_grammar: agent - verb discord, ergative Newari
%index_metre: lengthening metri causa (pathīkena)

<TEXT> dakṣiṇāpathadeśo 'yaṃ naravīrapuraṃ tv{ }adaḥ||</TEXT> 12:60
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°patha°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °pathe \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°puraṃ tv{ }adaḥ</LEM> \msCb;
                                               °puraṃ tv{ }ayaḥ \msCa,
                                               °puraṃ tv{ }ayaṃ \msCc\msNa\msNb, 
                                                purandaraḥ \msNc, °puraṃ svayam \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE><sep/>
                Łayam$ as the end of this verse may have been the original reading and
                \msCb\ may have corrected it to Ładaḥ$. Another possibility is that
                an original Ładaḥ$ is preserved in \msCb, and it got corrupted to
                Łayaḥ$ (\msCa), and then to Łayaṃ$ (\msCc\msNa). 
                In any case, in this case I have chosen the not-so-well attested reading Ładaḥ$ 
                simply because it works better. Another possibility would be to echo 12.59d and
                correct to Łidam$.

                Since I am not aware of any attestation of Naravīrapura as a city,
                I suspect that this name is either a mistake for or a pun on
                Karavīrapura, possibly modern Kolhapur in Maharashtra. 
                See p.~\pageref{naravirapura}, and compare 12.93, in which
                the Sahya mountain is mentioned, with \PADMAP\ 6.106.3:
                <sep/>
                        Łāsīt sahyādriviṣaye karavīrapure purā$ |<br/>
                        Łbrāhmaṇo dharmavit kaścid dharmadatto 'tiviśrutaḥ$ ||
                <sep/>
                        `Once upon a time, in the region of Mount Sahya, in Karavīrapura,
                        there was a certain very famous Brahmin called Dharmadatta,
                        who was an expert on Dharma.'
                <sep/>
                On the area of the Sahya mountain as `the southernmost limit of the authors' map'
                in the `the Skandapurāṇa's literary imagining of a Pāśupata landscape,' see 
                <citep>CecilMapping</citep><pnum>161ff</pnum>.</NOTE>
        <TR>This is the Deccan region, and this is the city of Naravīra.</TR>

%index_geo: dakṣiṇāpathadeśa (Deccan)
%index_geo: Naravīrapura (maybe Karavīrapura?)



<TEXT> rājā siṃhajaṭo nāma rājñī tasya ca kekayī|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>rājā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; rājā hi \msNc, rāja \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°jaṭo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °yato \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>kekayī</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kaikayī \msCa</APP>
        <TR>The king is called Siṃhajaṭa, his queen is Kekayī.</TR>

%index_persons: Siṃhajaṭa (a king)
%index_persons: Kekayī (a queen)
%index_stemma: \msNc is falling apart in this and the previous verses

<TEXT> ativṛddho jarāgrastaḥ kekayī ca tathaiva ca||</TEXT> 12:61
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kekayī</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kaikayī \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>tathaiva ca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; tathaiva ra \msNc</APP>
        <TR>The king is very old, afflicted by old age, Kekayī likewise.</TR>


<TEXT> dātā sarvakalājñaś{ }ca yuddhe vīryabalānvitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dātā</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \lac × tā \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>°kalā°</LEM> \Ed; °kala° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>yuddhe</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; yuddho \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Oddly, I had to accept \Ed's reading in Łpāda$ a
              (°Łkalā$° as opposed to °Łkala$°) because it is the
              only one that makes sense. (Paper MS \msPaperA\ also reads °Łkala$°.)
              A faint possibility would be correcting the
              text to Łsarvakālajñaś$ (`knowing all the times, past, present, and future'),
              but that sounds out of context, being usually the epithet of gods and Buddhas.</NOTE>
        <TR>He is generous, an expert in all the arts, and he possesses
                the virtue of heroism in battle.</TR>

<TEXT> brahmaṇyo vatsalo loke sarvaśāstraviśāradaḥ||</TEXT> 12:62
        <TR>He is pious and devoted to his subjects, and he is well-versed in the Śāstras.'</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.622
<TEXT> vipula uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vipula spoke:</TR>

% upāśyāmi \msCa\Ed
<TEXT> atra śreṣṭhim{ }upāsyāmi nāma vā tasya kiṃ vada|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°pāsyāmi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °pasyāmi \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>nāma</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc; nāmaṃ \msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>vada</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vadaḥ \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the thematised stem Łśreṣṭhi$ from Łśreṣṭhin$ in Łpāda$ a.</NOTE>
        <TR>`As a matter of fact, I am seeking audience with the foreman of 
                the guild (Łśreṣṭhi$[Łn$]). What is his name? Tell me.</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed
%index_voc: thematisation (śreṣṭhi for śreṣṭhin) -in

<TEXT> katamo deśa tadvāsaḥ kathayasva na saṃśayaḥ||</TEXT> 12:63
        <APP>\vc <LEM>deśa ta°</LEM> \msCc\msNb; deśas{ }ta° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed\ \unmetr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kathayasva</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kathayasya \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>I have chosen a variant containing a \stemform\ in Łpāda$ c (Łdeśa$) for metrical
              reasons. One may even read Łkatamoddeśa$ in a similar sense, or as containing
              Łuddeśa$ (for Łuddiśa$) as an imperative: `Where is his house, give me directions.'</NOTE>
        <TR>In which district is his dwelling? Tell me without any hesitation.'</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

<TEXT> vipulenaivam{ }uktas{ }tu pathikovāca taṃ punaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vipulenaiva°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; vipuleneva° \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the \stemform\ Łpathika$ in Łpathikovāca$ in Łpāda$ b. Alternatively,
              it is an instance of double sandhi (Łpathika uvāca$ \rightarrow\ Łpathikovāca$).</NOTE>
        <TR>Having been addressed by Vipula thus, the traveller replied:</TR>

% index_grammar: stem form/double sandhi

<TEXT> mama bhīmabalo nāma śreṣṭhikasya gṛhāgataḥ||</TEXT> 12:64
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>mama bhīmabalo nāma</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                 mama bhī\lac × balo nāma \msCa, \om\ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>śreṣṭhikasya gṛhāgataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                        śreṣṭhikasya gṛhāgataḥ|| pathiko 'ham{ }idāniñ{ }ca|
                        ko bhavān tasya viṣaye kiṃ vā jñātuṃ cikīrṣasi|| \Ed</APP>
        <TR>`My name is Bhīmabala and I have come to visit the house of the foreman of the guild.</TR>

%index_persons: Bhīmabala (a traveller)

<TEXT> śreṣṭhikaḥ puṇḍako nāma khyātaḥ śreṣṭhika ucyate|</TEXT>
        <TR>The foreman of the guild is called Puṇḍaka and he is said to be a famous foreman.</TR>

%index_persons: Puṇḍaka (the Śreṣṭhin)

%folioinfo \msNc\ 230.jpg upper, f. 227v
<TEXT> kautukaṃ tava yady{ }asti tad{ }āgaccha mayā saha||</TEXT> 12:65
        <TR>If you are eager [to see him], come with me.'</TR>

<TEXT> evam{ }astv{ }iti tenokto vipulena mahātmanā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°stv{ }iti</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °stiti \msCb\msCc\oo
                 <LEM>tenokto</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; tonokto \msNc, tenoktau \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°tmanā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °tmanāḥ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>`Alright,' replied to him great-souled Vipula,</TR>

<TEXT> tenaiva saha niryātaḥ śreṣṭhikasya gṛhaṃ prati||</TEXT> 12:66
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tenaiva</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; teneva \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>prati</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; pratiḥ \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>and they set off to visit the foreman's house together.</TR>

<TEXT> śreṣṭhikaḥ svagṛhāsīno dṛṣṭaḥ sa vipulena tu|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śreṣṭhikaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                         śreṣṭhitaḥ \msCa, śreṣṭhika \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dṛṣṭaḥ sa</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                 <UNCL>dṛ</UNCL>\lac\ ×× \msCa, dṛṣṭa sa \msCc, dṛṣṭasya \msNb</APP>
        <TR>When Vipula saw the foreman sitting in his house,</TR>

<TEXT> tasyāntikam{ }upāgamya tat{ }phalaṃ sa niveditaḥ||</TEXT> 12:67
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°gamya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °gatya \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sa niveditaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\Ed;
                                                 sanniveditaḥ \msNa, saṃniveditaḥ \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand the construction in Łpāda$ d as Łtasmai tena tat phalaṃ niveditam$,
              or read (partly with \msNa\msNc) Łtat phalaṃ saṃniveditam$.</NOTE>
        <TR>he went up to him and offered him that fruit.</TR>

% \msNc the anusvāra and the ḥ seem second hand
% upgāgatya vs upāgamya: both are correct
%index_syntax: tat phalaṃ sa niveditaḥ

<TEXT> aho phalam{ }idaṃ śreṣṭham{ }aho phalam{ }ihānitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>śreṣṭham{ }aho</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; śreṣṭha aho \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łihānitam$ for Łihānītam$ in Łpāda$ b for metrical reasons.</NOTE>
        <TR>[Puṇḍaka exclaimed:] `Wow, what an excellent fruit! Hey, what a fruit we have here!</TR>

%index_grammar: shortening, ihānitaṃ metri causa 

<TEXT> aho rūpam{ }aho gandha{-}m{-}aho phalaṃ suśobhanam||</TEXT> 12:68
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>gandham{ }aho phalaṃ</LEM> \corr;
                                 gandham{ }aho phala \msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\Ed,
                                 gandham{ }aho gandham{ }aho phala \msCbacorr, 
                                 gandha aho phala \msNb, gandho phalaṃ aho \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>I consider the Ł-m-$ between Łgandha$ and Łaho$ in Łpāda$s cd a hiatus-filler.</NOTE>
        <TR>Wow, what a form, what a smell, wow what a splendid fruit!</TR>

%index_grammar: hiatus-filler, sandhi bridge

<TEXT> tat{ }phalaṃ na mahījātaṃ na merau na ca mandare|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tat{ }pha°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yat{ }pha° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>merau</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNcpcorr\Ed; mero \msCc\msNb\msNcacorr\oo
                 <LEM>mandare</LEM> \conj; kandare \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Łkandare$ (`in a cave') in Łpāda$ b must be an early
                 mistake in the MSS for Łmandare$ (`on Mount Mandara'), a location that
                 appears frequently in the epics and the Purāṇas next
                 to Mount Meru. This is why I conjecture Łmandare$ here.
                 See, e.g., \MBH\ 3.187.10:
                <sep/>
                        Łcatuḥsamudraparyantāṃ merumandarabhūṣaṇām$ |<br/>
                        Łśeṣo bhūtvāham evaitāṃ dhārayāmi vasuṃdharām$ ||
                <sep/>
                </NOTE>
        <TR>This fruit did not grow on earth, not even on Mount Meru or Mount Mandara.</TR>

<TEXT> devalokika suvyaktaṃ na martya{-}m{-}upajāyate||</TEXT> 12:69
        <APP>\vc <LEM>devalokika</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNbpcorr\msNc\Ed;
                                                 devaloki \msNbacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>martya{-}m{-}upajāyate</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                         martya<UNCL>m{ }upajā</UNCL>\lac\ ×× \msCa,
                                         martya supajāyate \msCb, mahyām{ }upajāyate \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łdevalokika$ in Łpāda$ c as being in \stemform\ (metri causa) 
              for a more standard Łdevalaukikaṃ$. Understand Łmartya-m-upajāyate$ in Łpāda$ d 
              as Łmartya upajāyate$ (i.e. Łmartye...$) with Ł-m-$ as a sandhi bridge.</NOTE>
        <TR>It is clearly from the world of gods, it does not grow in the world of humans.</TR>

% index_grammar: stem form (metri causa)

%folioinfo \msCa\ 420.jpg
<TEXT> aho 'smi sa phalaṃ bhoktā rājārhaṃ ca na saṃśayaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>aho</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \lac × ho \msCa, adyo \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>sa phalaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                         <UNCL>sa</UNCL>phalam \msCa, tat{ }phalaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>bhoktā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; bhoktaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>rājārhaṃ ca</LEM> \msCc\msNb; rājārhaś{ }ca \msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed,
                                                    rājārha<UNCL>ś{ }ca</UNCL> \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is slightly suspect. It is possible that originally it contained a 
              negation: Łaho 'smi na phalaṃ bhoktā$ (`Ah! I will not eat this fruit').
              I have chosen to translate this Łpāda$ as a question, interpreting Łsa$ as
              giving emphasis to the grammatical subject. Nevertheless, the slightly 
              odd reoccurrence of the phrase Łsa phalaṃ$ in 12.71 and 72 might suggest 
              that sometimes we could interpret it, somewhat surprisingly, as Łtat phalaṃ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Alas! Is it me who will enjoy this fruit? No doubt, [only] a king is worthy of it.</TR>

%peri future 
%index_voc: saphala as phala? probably not

<TEXT> ḍhaukayitvā phalaṃ divyaṃ rājānaṃ toṣayāmy{ }aham||</TEXT> 12:70
        <APP>\vc <LEM>ḍhaukayitvā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; ḍhokayitvā \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Offering this divine fruit to the king, I shall please him.'</TR>
% DG thought ḍhaukayitvā was a Kashmiri form 

<TEXT> tatas{ }tvarita gatvaiva phalaṃ gṛhya manoharam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tvarita</LEM> \msNa\msNc\Ed; tvaritaṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNb\ \unmetr</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>gṛhya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; gṛha \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>°haram</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °ramam \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ a, Łtvarita$, for the adverb Łtvaritaṃ$, is in \stemform\ metri causa.</NOTE>
        <TR>Then grabbing that pleasant fruit, he left hastily.</TR>

% index_grammar: stem form (metri causa) adverb

<TEXT> ādareṇopasṛtyaiva rājānaṃ sa phalaṃ dadau||</TEXT> 12:71
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°sṛtyaiva</LEM> \msCa\msCb\Ed; °sṛtyeva \msCc\msNb\msNc, °saṃgatya \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sa phalaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tat{ }phalaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>He approached the king respectfully, and gave him the fruit.</TR>

 % saphala seems to be a word? REVISE

<TEXT> rājā ca sa phalaṃ dṛṣṭvā vismayaṃ paramaṃ gataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>sa phalaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tat{ }phalaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vismayaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; vismaya \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>On the possibility that Łsaphala$ is a form in this text simply signifying Łphala$,
                see notes on 12.70 and 113.</NOTE>
        <TR>And seeing the fruit, the king was highly amazed.</TR>

<TEXT> kutaḥ śreṣṭhi tvayā nītaṃ phalaṃ pūrvaṃ manoharam||</TEXT> 12:72
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śreṣṭhi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; śreṣṭha \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>phalaṃ pūrvaṃ manoharam</LEM> \corr; phala\lac ×××× haram \msCa,
                        phala<UNCL>m{ }ya</UNCL>rvamanoharam \msCb,
                                                 phalaṃ pūrva manoharam \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc,
                                                 phalaṃ sarvamanoharam \Ed</APP>
        <TR>`O foreman, from where have you brought this charming fruit previously?</TR>
        <NOTE>Łpūrva$[Łṃ$] in Łpāda$ d is suspect and \Ed\ is probably trying to silently emend it.
               One possibility is that the Łpāda$ originally contained a \stemform\ noun:
               Łphalāpūrvaṃ manoharam$ (`an unparalleled and charming fruit').
               Alternatively, Łpūrva$ is an eyeskip to 12.73b.</NOTE>

<TEXT> svādumūlaṃ phalaṃ kandaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ pūrvaṃ na tādṛśam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°mūlaṃ phalaṃ</LEM> \msNc; °mūlaphala° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>kandaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ pū°</LEM> \eme; °kandaṃ dṛṣṭvā pū° \msCa\msNa\msNb,
                                 °skanda dṛṣṭvā pū° \msCb,
                                 °skanda dṛṣṭa pū° \msCc, kanda dṛṣṭa<UNCL>n{ }pū</UNCL>° \msNc,
                                                          °skanda dṛṣṭā pū° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tādṛśam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                 tādṛ<UNCL>śaṃ</UNCL> \msCc, yādṛśam \Ed</APP>
        <TR>I have never seen such a palatable root or fruit or bulb,</TR>

% see ŚDhśāstra kandamūlaphalāśanaḥ as a dvandva 11.16 (Utopia)

%folioinfo \msCc\ 224.jpg f. 290v
<TEXT> rūpagandhaguṇopetaṃ hṛdayānandakārakam||</TEXT> 12:73
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°kārakam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °kārakaḥ \msNa</APP>
        <TR>one with such beauty, fragrance, and qualities, one that so gladdens the heart.</TR>

<TEXT> sadya evopayuñjāmi tvayā dattam{ }idaṃ phalam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>sadya evopayuñjāmi</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                 satya eva prabhuñjāmi \Ed</APP>
        <TR>I shall eat this fruit that you have given me at once.</TR>

<TEXT> kīdṛśaṃ svāda vijñānam{ }icchāmi kuru māciram||</TEXT> 12:74
        <APP>\vc <LEM>svāda vijñānam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; svādu vijñātum \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I take Łsvāda$ ain Łpāda$ c as a \stemform\ noun that stands for the accusative
              metri causa. I translate Łkuru māciram$ in Łpāda$ d
              rather freely, but since the king has already been given the fruit,
              the second person imperative is slightly odd here.</NOTE>
        <TR>What does it taste like? I want to know. Let's not hesitate.'</TR>

% index_grammar: stem form (metri causa)

<TEXT> tataḥ sa bhakṣayām{ }āsa phalaṃ cāmṛtasaṃnibham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tataḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; tata \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Then he ate the fruit that looked like ambrosia.</TR>

<TEXT> amṛtopamasusvādaṃ sarvaṃ ca bubhuje nṛpaḥ||</TEXT> 12:75
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>svādaṃ sarvaṃ ca</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; 
                                                svā\lac\ ×××× \msCa</APP>
        <TR>The king devoured all of it, and its taste was [indeed] like that of ambrosia.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ image 213.jpg lower, f. 20r
%folioinfo \msM\ 429.jpg lower, f. 21r
<TEXT> sadyaḥ ṣoḍaśavarṣasya yauvanaṃ samapadyata|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>sadyaḥ</LEM> \corr; \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°padyata</LEM> \msCa\msCb; °padyate \msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed, °dyata \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>I have corrected Łsadya$ in Łpāda$ a to Łsadyaḥ$ because there is no
              metrical reason to retain this thematised \stemform\ 
              here (cf. Łsadyo$ in Łpāda$ c).</NOTE>
        <TR>In an instant, he obtained the youthfulness of a sixteen-year-old boy.</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed

<TEXT> na valīpalitaṃ sadyo na jarā na ca durbalaḥ||</TEXT> 12:76
        <APP>\vc <LEM>valī°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; vali° \Ed</APP>
        <TR>In a moment, there were no wrinkles or grey hair, no illness, no weakness.</TR>


%folioinfo \msCb\ 436.jpg
%folioinfo \msNb\ 60.jpg lower
<TEXT> keśadantanakhasnigdho dṛḍhadanto dṛḍhendriyaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°danto</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °deho \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>dṛḍhendriyaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; dṛḍhendriḥ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>His hair, teeth, and nails, all became smooth and shiny, his teeth and senses strong,</TR>

<TEXT> tejaścakṣurbalaprāṇān{ }sadyaḥ sarvān{ }avāptavān||</TEXT> 12:77
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°cakṣurbalaprāṇā°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; °cakṣuvalaprāṇā° \msCc,
                                        °cakṣurbalaṃ prāṇā° \msNc, °cakṣuvalaprāṇa° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°n{ }sadyaḥ</LEM> \corr; °n{ }sadya \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>sarvān{ }a°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sarvvānn{ }a° \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°ptavān</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °ptuyāt \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>I have corrected Łsadya$ to Łsadyaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d,
              similarly to what I did in 12.76a.</NOTE>
        <TR>he regained his vital powers, his vision, strength, and his life energies in a moment.</TR>

% sadya as a word? 
% balaprāṇāṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNa

<TEXT> mantrī purohito 'mātyaḥ sarve bhṛtyajanās{ }tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>purohito 'mātyaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNb;
                                         purohito mātya \msCb\msNa\msNc, purohitāmātya \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>sarve bhṛtyajanās{ }tathā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 janās{ }tathās{ }tathā \msCb</APP>
        <TR>The minister, the domestic chaplain, the counsellor, all the servants,</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.623
<TEXT> paurastrī bālavṛddhāś{ }ca sarve te vismayaṃ gatāḥ||</TEXT> 12:78
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°strī</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °stri \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sarve</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \lac\ ×× \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>gatāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; gataḥ \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the singular Łpaurastrī$ in Łpāda$ c clearly for a plural.</NOTE>
        <TR>the townswomen, and all the children, and all the elderly people, everybody was amazed.</TR>

%index_grammar: singular for plural Newar?

<TEXT> rājā siṃhajaṭo nāma tuṣṭim{ }eva parāṃ gataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>parāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; paraṃ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>The sovereign, namely king Siṃhajaṭa, became extremely satisfied</TR>

<TEXT> praharṣam{ }atulaṃ caiva prāptavān{ }sa nareśvaraḥ||</TEXT> 12:79
        <TR>and very happy.</TR>

<TEXT> uvāca rājā taṃ śreṣṭhiṃ svārthatatparanirdayaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>rājā taṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; rājanaṃ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>śreṣṭhiṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; śreṣṭhaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°dayaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °daya \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the thematised Łśreṣṭhiṃ$ in Łpāda$ a (for Łśreṣṭhinaṃ$).</NOTE>
        <TR>The king, who was selfish and cruel, spoke to that foreman of the guild:</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā
%index_voc: thematisation (śreṣṭhi for śreṣṭhin) -in

<TEXT> kuru bhīmabalas{ }tv{ }evaṃ phalam{ }ānaya adya vai||</TEXT> 12:80
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kuru</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; śṛṇu \Ed\oo
