                 <LEM>bhīmabalas{ }tv{ }evaṃ</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa; bhīmavastv{ }evaṃ \msCa\Ed, 
                                                        bhīmabalas{ }tv{ }eva \msNb,
                                                        bhīmabala<UNCL>m{ }tv{ }e</UNCL>vaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>The syntax of Łpāda$ c is confusing. I translate it as if it carried 
                a causative meaning (e.g. Łkāraya bhīmabalaṃ tv evaṃ$: `make Bhīmabala act like this').
                On the other hand, an instrumental (Łbhīmabalena$) would
                be better (`act like this, together with Bhīmabala').</NOTE>
        <TR>`Tell Bhīmabala to bring another fruit today.</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCa and \Ed ??

<TEXT> punar{ }me yauvanaprāptis{ }tvatprasādān{ }narottama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °ttamaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>I have regained my youthfulness by your kindness, O excellent man.</TR>

<TEXT> kekayīṃ durbalāṃ vṛddhāṃ punaḥ prāpaya yauvanam||</TEXT> 12:81
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kekayīṃ durbalāṃ</LEM> \msNa; kaikayīn{ }durbalān \msCa, kekayīṃ \msCb,
                                         kekayī durbalā \msCc\msNb\Ed, kaikayī durbalāṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>vṛddhāṃ punaḥ</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; vṛ<UNCL>ddhā</UNCL>\lac\ ×× \msCa, 
                                                                 vṛddhā punaḥ \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>prāpaya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; prāpa \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Help Kekayī, who is weak and old, also regain her youthfulness.'</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed

<TEXT> sa rājñā evam{ }uktas{ }tu śreṣṭhī bhīmabalas{ }tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śreṣṭhī</LEM> \msCc\Ed; śreṣṭhi \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc, śriṣṭhi \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°balas{ }tathā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; °balas{ }tadā \msNb\msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>I accepted the reading Łśreṣṭhī$ (\msCc) in Łpāda$ b although it may be a 
                correction of Łśreṣṭhi$ (\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc), 
                an original Łprātipadika$\index{stem form} of the thematised 
                form of Łśreṣṭhin$ (see 12.63a).
                All in all, the latter reading is more likely to be the result of
                a bit of confusion about the two nominatives Łśreṣṭhī$ and Łbhīmabalas$,
                referring to two different persons. That it is Bhīmabala that replies to
                the king, and not Puṇḍaka the foreman,
                becomes clear in 12.85a (Łśrutvā bhīmabalavākyaṃ$).</NOTE>
        <TR>This is how the king addressed the foreman. This time Bhīmabala</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed

<TEXT> pratyuvāca ha rājānaṃ prāñjaliḥ praṇataḥ sthitaḥ||</TEXT> 12:82
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vāca ha</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °vācāha \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>rājānaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; rājāna \msNa</APP>
        <TR>replied to the king, joining his hands reverentially,
                 and remaining standing with his head bowed down:</TR>

%folioinfo \msNc\ 230.jpg lower, f. 228r
<TEXT> na vanena vane rājan{ }na vāṇijyakṛṣeṇa vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>na vanena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; na phaledaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>rājan{ }na</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; rājānna \msCb\msNb</APP>
                <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a could be construed as Łna vane na vane rājan$
                        (`Your majesty, there is no [such fruit] in any
                        forest'), but a similar expression, Łvanena
                        vanaṃ$, occurs, e.g., in \MBH\ 1.144.1 meaning `from forest to forest' 
                        (Łte vanena vanaṃ vīrā ghnanto mṛgagaṇān bahūn$ | 
                         Łapakramya yayū rājaṃs tvaramāṇā mahārathāḥ$ ||), 
                        and this made me choose the other option, Łna vanena vane rājan$. 
                        \Ed's variant, Łna phaledaṃ vane rājan$, is likely 
                        an attempt to `correct' the text. The reading of paper MS
                        \msPaperA, Łna vane tava ne rājan$, does not give a
                        meaningful alternative.</NOTE>
        <TR>`Your majesty, one cannot obtain [such a fruit by wandering] from forest to forest. 
                  It cannot be obtained through merchants or by cultivating the land.</TR>
% vānijya \msNc

<TEXT> kenāpi kulaputreṇa tava darśanakāṃkṣayā||</TEXT> 12:83
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kula°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; ku° \msNc</APP>
        <TR>Some noble man, seeking your audience,</TR>

<TEXT> datto 'smi tena rājendra mayā datto 'si bhūpate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>'smi tena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc;
                                                 smin{ }tena \msNb, 'smi tava \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>datto 'si</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc;
                                         dattāsi \msCc, datto smi \msNa, prāptoṣi \Ed</APP>
        <TR>gave it to me, and, O supreme king, I gave it to you, your majesty.</TR>

%index_grammar: datto 'smi instead of dattaṃ mama CHECK

<TEXT> na te śaknomy{ }ahaṃ rājan{ }vaktuṃ vaideśinaṃ naram||</TEXT> 12:84
        <APP>\vc <LEM>te</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>rājan{ }vaktuṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 rā\lac ×× ktum \msCa, rājān{ }vaktum \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vaideśinaṃ naram</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc;
                                             <UNCL>vai</UNCL>deśinan{ }naram \msCa,
                                             vaideśinaṃ naraḥ \msNb, ca dehi tannaraḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the form Łvaideśin$ for the better-attested Łvideśin$
              or Łvaideśika$ in Łpāda$ d.</NOTE>
        <TR>Your majesty, I cannot tell you who this foreigner is.'</TR>

%index_voc: vaideśin for vaideśika/videśin

<TEXT> śrutvā bhīmabalavākyaṃ pratyuvāca tataḥ punaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°bala°</LEM> \msCa\msCb; °balaṃ \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a, as transmitted in \msCa\msCb, is a rare Łsa-vipulā$. 
              Some MSS (\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc) read °Łbalaṃ$ to avoid this.</NOTE>
        <TR>Having heard Bhīmabala's reply, [the king] said:</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed
%index_metre: sa-vipulā

<TEXT> amātyakulaputras{ }tvaṃ brūhi madvacanaṃ punaḥ||</TEXT> 12:85
        <APP>\vc <LEM>amātya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; amatya° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°putras{ }tvaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °putraṃ tvaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>`You are the son of a noble family of ministers. Repeat my words [to Vipula]:</TR>

<TEXT> yadi nāsti kiṃ me dattaṃ mayā vā mārgito bhavān|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>kiṃ me dattaṃ</LEM> \msNc; kime dattaṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb,
                                                          kim{ }etat{ }taṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>mārgito</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; prārthito \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>bhavān</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; bhagavan \msNc</APP>
        <TR>If there are no more [fruits], why did you give me any?
            This is what I request from you, sir.</TR>
                                        % kime might stand for kena, or kimarthe?
                                        % pāda b is a bit obscure

<TEXT> yatra hy{ }eko bahavo 'tra jāyante nātra saṃśayaḥ||</TEXT> 12:86
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>yatra hy{ }eko bahavo 'tra</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                        yatraiko bahavo 'traiva \msCb,
                                        yataś{ }caika bahūn{ }tatra \msCc,
                                        yatraścaiko bahūn{ }tatra \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>jāyante</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; jāyate \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ c is a rare Łsa-vipulā$ (cf. 12.85a above), as transmitted in \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc.
              It seems that \msCb\ and \msCc\ try to `correct' it in different ways.</NOTE>
        <TR>Where there is one, there will be many, that is for sure.</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed
%index_stemma: \msCb against \msCa\msNa\msNc\ sa-vipulā!
%index_metre: sa-vipulā

<TEXT> āgamopāyamārgaṃ ca tenaiva sa tu gamyatām|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tenaiva</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; tainaiva \msCc</APP>
        <TR>[There is a] path by which it arrived. He [Vipula] should go [back] by the same route.</TR>

%lacuna_start: msCc
%folioinfo \msCc\ breaks off here, one folio (f. 291) is missing; it resumes at 12.113d
<TEXT> avaśyaṃ tena gantavyaṃ tena mārgeṇa mārgaya||</TEXT> 12:87
        <APP>\vc <LEM>avaśyaṃ tena</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 ava<UNCL>sya</UNCL>\lac\ × na \msCa\oo
                 <LEM>gantavyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 <UNCL>buddha</UNCL>vyaṃ \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>mārgaya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; mārgayaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vd Ł\msCc\ breaks off here missing one folio (f. 291);
                 it resumes at 12.113d in f. 292.$</LACUNA>
        <TR>By all means, that's the way to go. Track it down by that route.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 421.jpg 
<TEXT> adattvā phalam{ }anyac{ }ca śiraś{ }chedyāmi durmate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>adattvā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNcpcorr\Ed;
                                                 adattā \msNb, adatvāphatvā \msNcacorr</APP>
        <TR>If you are unable to provide another [fruit], I'll have your head cut off, you fool.</TR>

<TEXT> chedyaś{ }caṇḍavicaṇḍābhyāṃ rakṣa bhīmabalādhamaḥ||</TEXT> 12:88
        <APP>\vc <LEM>chedyaś{ }ca°</LEM> \msNa; chedye ca° \msCa\msNb,
                                                 chede ca° \msCb\msNc, chedya ca° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dhamaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dhama \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łchedyāmi$ in Łpāda$ b as Łchedayāmi$. It is difficult to see how
              the readings Łchedye$ and Łchede$ in Łpāda$ c 
              appeared in \msCa\msNb\ and \msCb\msNc, respectively.
              The only MS transmitting Łchedyaś$ is \msNa, but I suppose that this phrase should
              refer to Vipula being potentially slain by Caṇḍa and Vicaṇḍa,
              the two royal envoys mentioned 
              in verse 12.126 (Łrājadūtadvayam$), sent along with Bhīmabala 
              to make sure he obeys the king's command.
              Compare with \SDHU\ 7.101, where Yama's attendants are called Caṇḍa and Mahācaṇḍa.</NOTE>
        <TR>[Vipula] will be slain by Caṇḍa and Vicaṇḍa. Beware, Bhīmabala, he is a vile person!'</TR>

%index_persons: Caṇḍa
%index_persons: Vicaṇḍa

% ŚDhU 7 ed by Kenji and Sathya
%index_stemma: \msCb against \msCa\msNa\msNc\ !

<TEXT> tato bhīmabalaḥ kruddhaḥ khaḍgaṃ gṛhya śaśiprabham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°balaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; °bala \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śaśiprabham</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; śaśī pradam \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Then Bhīmabala got angry and drew his sword that looked like the [crescent] moon.</TR>

<TEXT> alaṅghya vacanaṃ rājñaḥ kulaputra vraja tvaram||</TEXT> 12:89
        <APP>\vc <LEM>alaṅghya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; \lk laṅghya \msNb, uvāca \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>rājñaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; rājā \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>kulaputra vraja tvaram</LEM> \msNb\Ed; kulaputraṃ vrajaty{ }aram \msCa\msCb, 
                                         kulaputra vrajanparaṃ \msNa,
                                         kulaputraṃ vrajan{ }paraṃ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>[He spoke to Vipula:] `Obeying the king's orders, O son of a noble family, go hastily!</TR>

% in this chapter clear signs that \Ed is connected to \msNb

<TEXT> mā ruṣa kulaputra tvaṃ mayā vadhyo bhaviṣyasi|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°putra tvaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °putras{ }tvaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vadhyo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; vaddhyau \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>bhaviṣyasi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; bhaviṣyati \msNb</APP>
        <TR>O son of a noble family, don't take it as an offence, but I have a licence to kill you,</TR>

%index_grammar: two laghus (pāda a)
% CHECK mā ruṣa grammar: it could work; putratvaṃ?

<TEXT> sadyo 'sti phalam{ }anyad{ }vā dehi rājānam{ }adya vai||</TEXT> 12:90
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sadyo 'sti</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                 \lac × dyo{ }sti \msCa, yady{ }asti \Ed</APP>
        <TR>unless you have more of this fruit in no time.
            Give another one to the king before the end of the day!</TR>

<TEXT> yatra prāptaṃ phalaṃ divyaṃ tatra vādeśaya tvaram|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>prāptaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; prāpta° \msCb, prāpti \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°deśaya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; °deśayat \msNb, °deśayan \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>tvaram</LEM> \conj; tava \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I have conjectured Łtvaram$ for Łtava$ in Łpāda$ b because Łtava$ is both
              unmetrical and meaningless in this context. Łtava$ might have
              been the result of an eyeskip to Łpāda$ d, or rather to Łpāda$ b of 12.92.</NOTE>
        <TR>Reveal to me quickly where you found that exquisite fruit.</TR>


<TEXT> tatphalena vinā bhadra durlabhaṃ tava jīvitam||</TEXT> 12:91
        <TR>Without that fruit, my friend, your life is in danger.'</TR>

<TEXT> vipula uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vipula spoke:</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 430.jpg upper, f. 21v
<TEXT> jīvitāśām{ }ahaṃ prāpto vaideśī bhavanaṃ tava|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vaideśī</LEM> \eme; vaideśi \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I emended Łvaideśibhavanaṃ$ in Łpāda$ b to Łvaideśī bhavanaṃ$ to arrive at a much smoother
              interpretation. </NOTE>
        <TR>'As a foreigner, when I reached your house, I also regained my hope of life.</TR>

% perhaps understand kṛtyakartā 
<TEXT> kṛtakartā kathaṃ vadhyaḥ prāpnuyām{ }aham{ }adya vai||</TEXT> 12:92
        <APP>\vd <LEM>prāpnuyām{ }a°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc; prāptuyām{ }a° \msNa,
                                                 prāpto 'yam{ }a° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°ham{ }adya vai</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; °hap{ }adya vai \msNb,
                                                °ham{ }adya vaiḥ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>How could one who does his duty be slain? I would fetch [another fruit] right now,</TR>

<TEXT> phalaṃ vā na punas{ }tv{ }anyad{ }dātuṃ śakyaṃ na kenacit|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vā na</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vā \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°nyad{ }dātuṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; °nya dātuṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śakyaṃ na kenacit</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed;
                                        śakya\lac ×× nacit \msCa, śakyaṃ na tenacid \msNc</APP>
        <TR>but there is no other fruit. Nobody can provide any.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ image 214.jpg upper, f. 20v
<TEXT> sahyaparvataśailāgre āsīnaḥ śrāntamānasaḥ||</TEXT> 12:93
        <APP>\vd <LEM>āsīnaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; āśītaḥ \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>śrānta°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; śrotta° \msCb, sānta° \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Up on the rocky peak of Mount Sahya, I sat down, disheartened.</TR>

% sahya could be 'toiled'
%index_geo: Sahya mountain

<TEXT> vānaras{ }tat{ }phalaṃ gṛhya mama dattvā punar{ }gataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>mama</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; mahyaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>It was a monkey that took that fruit, gave it to me,
                        and then disappeared.</TR>

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.624
<TEXT> mayā dattam{ }idaṃ tubhyaṃ tvayāpi ca narādhipe||</TEXT> 12:94
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tubhyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; tubhya \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dhipe</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °dhipa \msNb</APP>
        <TR>I gave it to you, you gave it to the king.</TR>

<TEXT> tatra gacchāva bho śreṣṭhi dṛśyate yadi vānaraḥ|</TEXT>
        <TR>Hey, let's go to that place, O foreman, to see if the monkey is still there.</TR>

<TEXT> tvayā mayā ca gatvaiva yācāvaḥ plavagādhipam||</TEXT> 12:95
        <APP>\vd <LEM>ca gatvaiva</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed;
                                                 <UNCL>ta</UNCL>gavatvaiva \msNc\oo
                 <LEM!>yācāvaḥ plavagādhipam</LEM> \msCb; 
                                yo vāsaḥ plavagādhipaḥ \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I have accepted \msCb's reading in Łpāda$ d against all other witnesses.
               The dual seems to nicely follow Łgacchāva$ in Łpāda$ a, and the verb
               \verbalroot{Łyāc$} also appears in 12.105d (Łyācasva$). 
               Nevertheless, \msCb\ may only be trying to
               correct the problematic reading found in all the other witnesses:
               Łyo vāsaḥ plavagādhipaḥ$ could be just an awkward way of saying
               Łyatra plavagādhipasya vāsaḥ$ or Łyatra vasati plavagādhipaḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>When we get there together, we can ask the monkey king [for more fruit].'</TR>

<TEXT> śreṣṭhinā ca tathety{ }āha gacchāmaḥ sahitā vayam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tathety{ }āha</LEM> \msCa\msNb\Ed; tathaity{ }āha \msCb\msNa\msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>gacchāmaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed;
                                         ga\lac × mas \msCa, gacchāma \msNc</APP>
        <TR>The foreman said: `Alright, let us all go together</TR>
% note the plural

<TEXT> yatra prāptaṃ phalaṃ tubhyaṃ mokṣayāmo na saṃśayaḥ||</TEXT> 12:96
        <APP>\vc <LEM>prāptaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; prāpta \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tubhyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; tubhya \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Puṇḍaka, the foreman, switches to the plural in his reply, possibly referring to
              Vipula, Bhīmabala, and himself, and also perhaps to the two envoys of the
              king, Caṇḍa and Vicaṇḍa (see 12.126cd). Note also Łtubhyaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c as instrumental
             (<citep>OberliesEpicSkt</citep><pnum>104 [4.2.2]</pnum>).</NOTE>
        <TR>to the place where you found that fruit. We shall be saved, no doubt.'</TR>

%index_grammar: tubhyam as instrumental (Oberlies 4.2.2 [pp. 104])

<TEXT> rudra uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Rudra spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> tam{ }āruhya giriṃ sahyaṃ mārgamāṇaḥ samantataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>giriṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; giri \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°mānaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °mānāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Having climbed that mountain, Mount Sahya, and having searched the place all over,</TR>

%index_geo: Sahya mountain

<TEXT> vipulena tato dṛṣṭo vānaraḥ plavagādhipaḥ||</TEXT> 12:97
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vānaraḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vānara \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>plavagā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; plagā° \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the slightly clumsy syntax here: from the nominatives
              of Łpāda$s ab, we switch to an instrumental in Łpāda$ c.</NOTE>
        <TR>Vipula then caught glimpse of that monkey, the monkey king.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 437.jpg
%folioinfo \msNb\ 60.jpg upper
<TEXT> ayaṃ sa vānaraśreṣṭho vṛkṣacchāyāṃ samāśritaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vānaraśreṣṭho</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; vānaraḥ śre<UNCL>ṣṭhe</UNCL> \msNc,
                                                         vānaraḥ śreṣṭho \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vṛkṣacchāyāṃ</LEM> \msNc; vṛkṣacchāṃyā° \msCa, vṛkṣacchāyā° \msCb\msNb\Ed, vṛcchāyāṃ \msNa</APP>
        <TR>`It's that extraordinary monkey there lurking in the shade of that tree.</TR>

<TEXT> mama puṇyabalenaiva dṛśyate 'dyāpi vānaraḥ||</TEXT> 12:98
        <TR>This monkey has showed up today again merely by the force of my meritious acts.</TR>

<TEXT> vānara kuru mitrārthaṃ sadyo mṛtyur{ }bhaven{ }mama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vānara</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; vānaraṃ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°rthaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; °rtha \msCb\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>mṛtyur{ }bha°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; mṛtyu bha° \msNa\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the two Łlaghu$ syllables in Łpāda$ a in second and third position.</NOTE>
        <TR>Hey, monkey, do me a friendly favour or I will perish very quickly.</TR>

%index_metre: two laghus

%folioinfo \msNc\ 231.jpg upper, f. 228v
<TEXT> pūrvadattaṃ phalam{ }anyad{ }dehi vānara jīvaya||</TEXT> 12:99
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dattaṃ</LEM> \msCa\msNc\Ed; °datta° \msCb\msNa\msNb\oo
                 <LEM>phalam{ }anya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; phalaṃm{ }anya° \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°hi vānara jīvaya</LEM> \msCa; °vi vānara jīvayaḥ \msCb,
                                           °hi vānara jīvayaḥ \msNa\msNb, 
                                           °hi vāna jīvaya \msNc, °hi vā na ca jīvaye \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Give me another one of that fruit that you gave me, O monkey, and keep me alive.'</TR>

<TEXT> vānara uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>The monkey spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> gandharveṇa tu me dattaṃ phalaṃ dattaṃ tu te mayā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tu me dattaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc;
                                                 tu me datta° \msNb, mama dattaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>`It was a Gandharva that had given me the fruit that I gave you.</TR>
% gandharvena \msNc

%index_mythical_figures: gandharva

<TEXT> punar{ }anyat{ }kathaṃ dāsye tatra gaccha yadīcchasi||</TEXT> 12:100
        <TR>How could I give you another one? Go there [where Gandharvas live] if you wish.</TR>

<TEXT> vipula uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vipula spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> adattvā tat{ }phalaṃ tubhyaṃ jīvituṃ saṃśayo bhavet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>adattvā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; adattā \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>jīvituṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; jīvitu \msNa, jīvitaṃ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>bhavet</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; <UNCL>bhavet</UNCL> \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łtubhyaṃ$ in Łpāda$ a again in the sense of Łtvayā$
             (<citep>OberliesEpicSkt</citep><pnum>104 [4.2.2]</pnum>).</NOTE>
        <TR>`If you cannot give me another fruit, [my] staying alive is doubtful.</TR>

%index_grammar: tubhyam as instrumental (Oberlies 4.2.2 [pp. 104])

% Citraratha is king of the gandharvas
<TEXT> athavā tatra gacchāmo yatra citrarathaḥ svayam||</TEXT> 12:101
        <APP>\vc <LEM>athavā tatra</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; a\lac ××× tra \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>citrarathaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCbpcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed; 
                                                cirathaḥ \msCbacorr, citraratha \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>Citraratha is the king of the Gandharvas.</NOTE>
        <TR>Another alternative is that we go where Citraratha himself dwells.'</TR>

%index_mythical_figures: Citraratha (the king of the Gandharvas)

<TEXT> vānaraḥ punar{ }evāha evaṃ kurvāmahe vayam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>evaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; eva \msCb</APP>
        <TR>The monkey replied: `Let's do it.'</TR>

<TEXT> tataś{ }citrarathāvāsam{ }upagamyedam{ }abravīt||</TEXT> 12:102
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tataś{ }ci°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa; tatraś{ }ci° \msNb, tatra ci° \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°bravīt</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; °vīt \msNaacorr,
                                                        °vīvīt \msNapcorr, °bravī \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Then, upon reaching Citraratha's dwelling place, 
            and having gone up to him, he said this:</TR>
%index_stemma: \msNc and \Ed

<TEXT> gandharvarāja kāryārthī tvām{ }ahaṃ punar{ }āgataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tvām{ }ahaṃ pu°</LEM> \conj; tvan{ }hy{ }ayam{ }pu° \msCa\msNc,
                                        tvāt hy{ }aham{ }pu° \msCb,
                                        tvat hy{ }ayaṃ pu° \msNa, tvat hy{ }ahaṃ pu° \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Variants for Łpāda$ b are problematic. I conjectured Łtvām ahaṃ$ because Łahaṃ$ 
              (in \msCb\msNb) seems to work better with Łpunar$ than Łayaṃ$ (after all,
              it is the monkey who returns to the Citraratha, and not Vipula), and because 
              it is difficult to accept the ablative Łtvat$ as meaning `to you.' The original 
              may have read the enclitic form Łtvā$. Considering Łtvatsakāśaṃ$ in 12.107b opens up 
              other possibilities, such as conjecturing Łtvadvāsaṃ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>`O king of the Gandharvas, I have come back to you with a request.</TR>

%index_grammar: tvat for tvāṃ?

<TEXT> pūrvadattaphalaṃ tv{ }anyad{ }dehi māṃ yadi śakyate|| </TEXT> 12:103
        <TR>Give me another fruit like the one that you gave me, if you can.'</TR>

<TEXT> gandharvarāja uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>gandharvarāja uvāca</LEM> \msCb; gandharvarājovāca \msCa\msNb\Ed,
                                                       gandharvarājauvāca \msNa,   
                                                       gandharāja uvāca \msNc</APP>
        <TR>The king of the Gandharvas spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> sūryalokagataś{ }cāsmi tena dattaṃ phalottamam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>gataś{ }cāsmi</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                         gata<UNCL>ś{ }cā</UNCL>\lac\ × \msCa, gataś{ }cāsmiṃ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tena dattaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \lac ××× ttam \msCa</APP>
        <TR>`I went to the world of Sūrya, and it was he who gave me that extraordinary fruit.</TR>

%index_mythical_figures: Sūrya

%folioinfo \msCa\ 422.jpg
<TEXT> mayā dattaṃ phalaṃ tubhyam{ }atyantasuhṛdo 'si me||</TEXT> 12:104
        <APP>\vc <LEM>dattaṃ</LEM> \corr; datta° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°suhṛdo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °suhyado \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łsuhṛdo$ in Łpāda$ d as a singular nominative of the rare Łsuhṛda$.</NOTE>
        <TR>I gave that fruit to you [because] you are my very best friend.</TR>

<TEXT> kuto 'nyat{ }phalam{ }ādāsye mama nāsti plavaṅgama|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>'nyat{ }phalam{ }ādāsye</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                         'nyaphala dāsyāmi \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>mama nāsti plavaṅgama</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc;
                                                        mama nāsti plavaṅgamaḥ \msNa,
                                                        matto 'sti plavaṅgamaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Where could I find another fruit, I don't have any, O monkey.</TR>

<TEXT> sūryalokaṃ gamiṣyāmas{ }tatra yācasva bhāskaram||</TEXT> 12:105
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>gamiṣyāmas{ }tatra</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb;
                                                 gamiṣyāmas{ }tata \msNc, gamiṣyāmi tatra \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Let us go to the world of Sūrya, and ask the Sun there.'</TR>

<TEXT> gandharvenaivam{ }uktas{ }tu tathety{ }āha plavaṅgamaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tathety{ }āha</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; tathaity{ }āha \msCb</APP>
        <TR>Having been addressed thus by the Gandharva, the monkey consented.</TR>

<TEXT> sūryalokaṃ tataḥ prāptā gandharvādaya sarvaśaḥ||</TEXT> 12:106
        <APP>\vc <LEM>prāptā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; prāptāḥ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°daya sarvaśaḥ</LEM> \conj; °dayas{ }sarvaśaḥ \msCa\ \unmetr,
                                 °dayaḥ sarvaśaḥ \msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed\ \unmetr, daya sarvaśa \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>I have emended the correct but unmetrical °Łādayaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d to a \stemform\ 
              in order to restore the metre.</NOTE>
        <TR>They reached the world of Sūrya all together, the Gandharva and the others.</TR>

% index_grammar: emended to stem form (metri causa)

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.625
<TEXT> gandharva uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>gandharva uvāca</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                             gandharva <UNCL>uvā</UNCL>\lac\ × \msCa,
                                             gandharvarājovāca \Ed</APP>
        <TR>The Gandharva spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> kāryārthena punaḥ prāptas{ }tvatsakāśaṃ khageśvara|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>prāptas{ }tva°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; prāpta tva° \msNa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kāśaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °kāśāṃ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°śvara</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\Ed; °śvaraḥ \msNb\msNc</APP>
        <TR>`I have come back to you with a request, O Sky-goer lord.</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 430.jpg lower, f. 22r
<TEXT> pūrvadattaphalaṃ tv{ }anyad{ }dehi jīvam{ }anāśaya||</TEXT> 12:107
        <APP>\vc <LEM>phalaṃ tv{ }anya°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc;
                                 phalaṃ tv{ }a° \msCb, phalaṃs{ }tv{ }anya° \msNb\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°nāśaya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; anāmayaḥ \msNb, °nāśayaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Give me another fruit like the one that you gave me, and spare a life.'</TR>

<TEXT> sūrya uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Sūrya spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> somalokagataś{ }cāsmi tena dattaṃ phalottamam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°smi tena</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °smin{ }tena \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dattaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; datta° \msNb</APP>
       <TR>`I went to Soma's world, and it was he who gave me the magical fruit.</TR>

<TEXT> sa phalaṃ dattam{ }evāsi suhṛdatvān{ }mayā tava||</TEXT> 12:108
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vāsi</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc; °vā<UNCL>bhi</UNCL> \msNa,
                                                         °evāti \msNb, °vābhiḥ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>suhṛdatvān{ }mayā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc;     
                                         suhṛdatvāt{ }mayā \msNa, sa ca datvā mayā \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the odd syntax of Łpāda$s cd. Łsa phalaṃ$ may have been influenced 
                by 12.71d and 72a. Here in 12.108 Łtat phalaṃ$ would work
                better but see Łsa phalaṃ$ in a similarly odd position in 
                12.113d. I translate Łsa$ again as standing for emphasis 
                (`it was like that that you...'; cf. 12.70a).
                Łdattam evāsi$ is also problematic although similar
                structures do appear in this text, e.g., in 12.113c
                (see more on pp.~\pageref{confusedpassive} ff). The original may have read
                Łtat phalam datta evāsi$; or take Łdattam evāsi$ as Łdatta-m-evāsi$,
                with a hiatus breaker Ł-m-$.</NOTE>
        <TR>That is how you were given that fruit, by me, out of my friendship to you.</TR>

%index_grammar: syntax: aham asmi phalaṃ dattaṃ

<TEXT> anyad{ }dātuṃ na śaknomi gaccha somapurādya vai|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>anyad{ }dātuṃ</LEM> \msNa\msNc\Ed; anya dātuṃ \msCa\msCb, anya dātu \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°purādya</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °parādya \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łpurādya$ as Łpuram adya$ (\stemform\ metri causa).</NOTE>
        <TR>I cannot give you another one. Go now to Soma's city.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa (purādya)

<TEXT> taṃ prārthayāvikalpena atriputraṃ graheśvaram||</TEXT> 12:109
        <APP>\vc <LEM>taṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; ta \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°vikalpena</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 °<UNCL>vika</UNCL>\lac\ ×× \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°putraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °putra° \msCa\msNb</APP>
        <TR>Ask him, [the Moon], the son of Atri, the lord of planets, without hesitation.</TR>

%index_mythical_figures: Soma
%index_mythical_figures: Atriputra
%index_mythical_figures: Graheśvara

% Narahari version ! NO: it's maheśvara in PaperMS A1341-06! (350.jpg) 
% Narahari version !
<TEXT> rudra uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>rudra</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; maheśvara \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Rudra spoke:</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ image 214.jpg lower, f. 21r
<TEXT> gatāḥ sūryāgrataḥ kṛtvā somalokaṃ tathaiva hi|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>gatāḥ</LEM> \msCb; gata \msCa\msNa\msNb, gataḥ \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>hi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łsūryāgrataḥ$ in Łpāda$ a as Łsūryam agrataḥ$ (\stemform\ noun).</NOTE>
        <TR>Led by Sūrya, they went to the world of Soma.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form (sūryāgrataḥ -> sūryam agrataḥ)

<TEXT> uvāca sūryaḥ somāya kāraṇāpekṣayā śaśim||</TEXT> 12:110
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sūryaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; sūrya \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kāraṇā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; karuṇā° \msCb\oo 
                 <LEM>°pekṣayā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °pekṣaṇā \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>śaśim</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa; śaśi \msNb\Ed, śaśi<UNCL>n</UNCL> \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note the thematised form Łśaśim$ for Łśaśinam$ in Łpāda$ d. 
              Łsomāya \dots\ śaśiṃ$ could be just a clumsy way of saying Łsomaṃ \dots\ śaśinaṃ$, or
              Łsomāya \dots\ śaśine$, but I interpret Łpāda$ d separately.
              It is not inconceivable that \msCb\ is right reading
              Łkaruṇāpekṣayā$ (`hoping for compassion') instead of Łkāraṇāpekṣayā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Sūrya spoke to Soma, hoping for action on the Moon's part.</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā
%index_voc: śaśi for śaśin


<TEXT> soma uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Soma spoke:</TR>
% śoma \msCa

<TEXT> kimartham{ }āgato bhūyaḥ kartavyaṃ tatra bhāskara|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°gato</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °gatā \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tatra</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; tava \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°kara</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °karaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>For what purpose have you returned? O Sun, there will be a solution for it.</TR>

<TEXT> phalaṃ dātuṃ punas{ }tv{ }anyan{ }muktvā tv{ }anyat{ }karomy{ }aham||</TEXT> 12:111
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>punas{ }tv{ }anyan{ }muktvā tv{ }anyat{ }ka°</LEM> \corr;
                                 punas{ }tv{ }anya muktvā tv{ }anyaṅ{ }ka° \msCa,
                                 punas{ }tv{ }anyan{ }muktvās{ }tv{ }anyaṃ ka° \msCb,
                                 punaḥ tv{ }anya muktvā tv{ }anyat{ }ka° \msNa,
                                 punas{ }tv{ }anya muktvā tv{ }anyat{ }ka° \msNb,
                                 punas{ }tv{ }anyat{ }muktā tv{ }anyaṅ{ }ka° \msNc\Ed</APP>
        <TR>Except for giving another fruit, I shall do anything.</TR>

<TEXT> sūrya uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Sūrya spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> yadi śakyaṃ phalaṃ dehi anyan{ }na prārthayāmy{ }aham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śakyaṃ phalaṃ dehi</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; kāphalan{ }dehi \msCbacorr, 
                                        kāphala\lk n{ }dehi \msCbpcorr, śakya phalaṃ dehi \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>anyan{ }na</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; anyatvaṃ \msNc, anyān{ }na \Ed</APP>
        <TR>`If you can, give me a fruit, I am not asking for anything else.</TR>

<TEXT> na dattāsi phalam{ }anyan{ }mayā vadhyo bhaviṣyasi||</TEXT> 12:112
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>phalam{ }anyan{ }ma°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc;
                                                 phalaṃm{ }anyan{ }ma° \msNa,
                                                 phalaṃ manye ma° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vadhyo</LEM> \msNc; vaddhyo \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb, vaddho \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>bhaviṣyasi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; bhaviṣyati \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łpāda$ c either as Łna dattaṃ tvayā phalam anyat$ or
              Łna dātāsi phalam anyat$. This Łpāda$ is a Łsa-vipulā$, or if we
              apply a licence mostly seen in the non-Łanuṣṭhubh$ verses in this
              text, namely that a word-final syllable can count as Łguru$,
              it is a standard Łanuṣṭubh$ (Łpathyā$).
        <sep/>
              Sūrya threatening Soma in a harsh manner is somewhat surprising (Łpāda$ d).</NOTE>
        <TR>If you do not give me another fruit, I shall kill you.'</TR>

%index_grammar: odd syntax
%index_metre: sa-vipulā
%index_metre: long syllable at end of word % DG would print ṃm, see Niśvāsa! CHECK

<TEXT> soma uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Soma spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> āgamaṃ tasya vakṣyāmi śṛṇuṣvāvahito bhava|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>vakṣyāmi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\Ed; vakṣyā<UNCL>mi</UNCL> \msNa</APP>
        <TR>`I shall tell you the way by which it arrived. Listen, be attentive.</TR>

%lacuna_end: msCc
%folioinfo \msCc\ resumes here with datta me bhavān; 225.jpg f. 292r

<TEXT> indreṇāsmi phalaṃ dattaṃ sa phalaṃ datta me bhavān||</TEXT> 12:113
        <APP>\vd <LEM>datta me</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; vatta me \msNa</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vd Ł\msCc\ resumes here with $ datta me bhavān</LACUNA>
        <NOTE>Note Łsa phalaṃ$, potentially for  Łtat phalaṃ$, or for emphasis, again, as in 12.108c. 
              The syntax of Łpāda$s cd is rather confused and Łdatta$ in Łpāda$ d
              is a \stemform\ participle metri causa.
              and Łbhavān$ as a dative (see pp.~\pageref{confusedpassive}).
              Note also Łme$ for Łmayā$
              (<citep>OberliesEpicSkt</citep><pnum>102--103 [4.1.3]</pnum>).</NOTE>
        <TR>It was Indra who gave me the fruit and I gave that fruit to you.</TR>

%index_mythical_figures: Indra
%index_grammar: stem form metri causa (datta)
%index_grammar: syntax: aham asmi phalaṃ dattaṃ
%index_grammar: me for mayā (Oberlies 4.1.3 [pp. 102--103])

<TEXT> gatvaivendrasadas{ }tv{ }anyat{ }prārthayāmaḥ sahaiva tu|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>gatvaivendra°</LEM> \msCa; gatvevendra° \msCb\msNb\msNc, \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msCc,
                                                 gatvāvendra° \msNa, gandharvendra° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°rthayāmaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °rthayāmā \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>sahaiva tu</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed;
                                                 sadaiva tu \msCc, sahaiva tuḥ \msNc</APP>
        <TR>If we go to Indra's palace, we can ask for another one together.</TR>

<TEXT> evaṃ kurma iti prāha gatvendrasadanaṃ prati||</TEXT> 12:114
        <APP>\vc <LEM>kurma</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; karma \msNb, soma \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Let's do it!' he said and left for Indra's residence.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNc\ 231.jpg lower, f. 229r
<TEXT> somenendram{ }uvācedaṃ phalakāmā ihāgatāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>somenendra°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; soma indra° \msNc, somevendra° \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>°cedaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °cendraṃ \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>While Łsomenendram$ in Łpāda$ a is grammatically wrong and
              we have a correct, or corrected, reading in \msNc\ (Łsoma indra$°),
              I have left it thus, since this kind of ergative structures
              are not alien to the \VSS. See pp.~\pageref{ergative} ff, and,
              e.g., verse 1.3 above.</NOTE>
        <TR>Soma said this to Indra: `We have come here seeking a fruit.'</TR>

<TEXT> pūrvadattaphalam{ }anyad{ }dehi śakra mamādya vai||</TEXT> 12:115
        <APP>\vc <LEM>pūrva°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; pūrvaṃ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°nyad{ }dehi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °nya dehi \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>śakra</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; śaka \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>vai</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; vaiḥ \msCb</APP>
        <NOTE><sep/>
              ŁPāda$ c is either a Łsa-vipulā$ or a Łpathyā$ if the final syllable
              of °Łphalam$ counts as Łguru$. Cf. 12.112 above.</NOTE>
        <TR>Give me now another fruit like the one that you gave me before, O Śakra.</TR>

%index_metre: sa-vipulā

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.626
<TEXT> indra uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Indra spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> yadartham{ }iha samprāptaḥ sa ca nāsti niśākara|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kara</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °karaḥ \msCb\Ed</APP>
        <TR>`The reason for which you came here does not exist, O Night-maker!</TR>

%folioinfo \msCb\ 438.jpg
<TEXT> viṣṇuhastān{ }mayā prāptam{ }ekam{ }eva phalaṃ śubham||</TEXT> 12:116
        <APP>\vc <LEM>viṣṇuhastān{ }mayā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; 
                                                viṣṇuhastā mayā \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>phalaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; phala \msCb</APP>
        <TR>I received only a single one of that nice fruit, out of Viṣṇu's hands.</TR>
% hastāt mayā \msNa

<TEXT> sarva eva hi gacchāmo viṣṇulokaṃ graheśvara|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°lokaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °loka \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°śvara</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °śvaraṃ \msCb, °śva\lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Let us all go to Viṣṇu's world, O lord of the planets.'</TR>

%index_mythical_figures: Graheśvara

%folioinfo \msNb\ 61.jpg lower
<TEXT> sarva evopajagmus{ }te phalārthaṃ madhusūdanam||</TEXT> 12:117
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>sarva evopajagmus{ }te</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                       sarva evopañ{ }jagmus{ }te \msCa\ \unmetr, 
                                                       \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM!>phalārthaṃ madhusūdanam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed;
                                                        \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb,
                                                         phaphālārthaṃ madhusūdanam \msNc</APP>
        <LACUNA>\vcd ŁThis folio side in \msNb\ (verses 12.117--138) is faded and
                     most of it is difficult to read, thus its readings
                     reported are less reliable than usual$</LACUNA>
        <TR>They all went to Madhusūdana for the fruit.</TR>

<TEXT> evam{ }uktvā gatāḥ sarve devarājapuraskṛtāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>evam{ }uktvā gatāḥ sarve</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa;
                                 \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb, evam{ }uktvā gatā sarve \msNc, 
                                              evam{ }uktā gatāḥ sarve \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note how there is a minor confusion here with the order of events.       
              12.117 informs us that Indra spoke and then they all left. Then 12.118ab
              restates that after Indra spoke they left.</NOTE>
        <TR>After he spoke thus, they all left, led by the king of the gods.</TR>

<TEXT> muhūrtenaiva samprāptā viṣṇulokaṃ yaśasvini||</TEXT> 12:118
        <APP>\vd <LEM>viṣṇulokaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                 viṣṇuloka \msCc, \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>They reached the world of Viṣṇu in a moment, O Yaśasvinī.</TR>

<TEXT> upasṛtya tata indraḥ praṇipatya janārdanam|</TEXT>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is a Łsa-vipulā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Indra then approached Janārdana, bowing down respectfully.</TR>

%index_metre: sa-vipulā

<TEXT> sarveṣām{ }uparodhena prārthayāmi yaśodhara||</TEXT> 12:119
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dhara</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °dharam \Ed</APP>
        <TR>`I have a request, O Yaśodhara, for something that troubles everybody [here]'.</TR>

<TEXT> viṣṇur{ }uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>viṣṇur{ }uvāca</LEM> \msCapcorr\msCb\msCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc;
                                                viṣṇur{ }uca \msCaacorr, 
                                                \om\ \msNaacorr, viṣṇu uvāca \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Viṣṇu spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> pūrvadattaphalasyārthe tac{ }ca sarva{-}m{-}ihāgatāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°datta°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °dattaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°rthe</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °rthi \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The function of Łtac ca$ in Łpāda$ b is unclear. Perhaps understand Łatra$ (`here')
                or, less likely, Łtvaṃ ca$ (`you and [everybody else]').
                Understand Łsarvam ihāgatāḥ$ as Łsarva-m-ihāgatāḥ$, with a hiatus-filler Ł-m-$
                for Łsarva$ (i.e. Łsarve$) Łihāgatāḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>`You all have come here for the fruit that I donated previously.</TR>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 423.jpg
<TEXT> na śaknomi phalaṃ dātuṃ kiṃ vā tv{ }anyat{ }karomy{ }aham||</TEXT> 12:120
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śaknomi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; śaknoti \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>phalaṃ dātuṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 phala<UNCL>n{ }dātu</UNCL> \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tv{ }anyat{ }karomy{ }aham</LEM> \msNc;
                                         tv{ }anyaṃ karomy{ }aham \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed, 
                                         \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk my{ }aham \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>The non-standard neuter form Łanyaṃ$ transmitted in most witnesses consulted
                 might be original but I have not found any clear occurrences of
                 it in this text elsewhere. That is why I have chosen \msNc's reading,
                 the standard Łanyat$.</NOTE>
        <TR>I cannot give you [another] fruit. Otherwise, what else can I do for you?'</TR>

<TEXT> indra uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Indra spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> brahmāṇḍam{ }api bhettuṃ tvaṃ śaknoṣi garuḍadhvaja|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>brahmāṇḍa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; brahmaṇḍa° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>bhettuṃ tvaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                 bhettu tvaṃ \msCb, bhartuṃtvaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>śaknoṣi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; śaknoti \msCb</APP>
        <TR>`You are even capable of splitting Brahmā's Egg, O you of the banner with Garuḍa on it.</TR>

<TEXT> aśakyaṃ tava nāstīti jānāmi puruṣottama||</TEXT> 12:121
        <APP>\vc <LEM>aśakyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; <UNCL>aśakya</UNCL> \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °ttamam \Ed</APP>
        <TR>I know that there is nothing that you cannot do, O Puruṣottama.'</TR>

<TEXT> evam{ }uktaḥ punar{ }viṣṇuḥ pratyuvāca purandaram|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>evam{ }uktaḥ punar{ }viṣṇuḥ</LEM> \msCb;
                                 evam{ }uktvā punar{ }viṣṇuḥ \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed, 
                                \lk\lk \lk\lk  punar{ }viṣṇuḥ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>purandaram</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; puradaraṃ \msNc\ \unmetr</APP>
        <TR>Having been addressed thus, Viṣṇu replied to Purandara [Indra]:</TR>

%folioinfo \msM\ 431.jpg upper, f. 22v
<TEXT> phalam{ }ekaṃ parityajya sarvaṃ śaknomi kauśika||</TEXT> 12:122
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sarvaṃ śaknomi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; sarvaṃ śaknosi \msCc,
                                                                     \lk\lk  śaknomi \msNb</APP>
        <TR>`O Kauśika, I can do everything with the only exception of the fruit.</TR>

<TEXT> upāyo 'tra pravakṣyāmi āgamaṃ śṛṇu gopate|</TEXT>
        <TR>I shall tell you the means of obtaining it. Listen to where it came from, O Chief
        (Łgopati$).</TR>

<TEXT> brahmaṇā ca mama dattaṃ tat{ }phalaikaṃ purandara||</TEXT> 12:123
        <APP>\vc <LEM>mama</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; mamā° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tat{ }phalaikaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; tat{ }phalaṃkaṃ \msNaacorr,
                                                                     tat{ }phalekaṃ \msNapcorr\oo
                 <LEM>purandara</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed;
                                                         puranda<UNCL>raṃ</UNCL> \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that Łpāda$ c is a Łsa-vipulā$, and that Łphala$ is in \stemform\ in
              Łpāda$ d (understand Łphalam ekaṃ$; see 12.124a).</NOTE>
        <TR>It was Brahmā who gave me that one single piece of fruit, O Purandara.</TR>

%index_metre: sa-vipulā
%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

<TEXT> mayā dattaṃ phalaṃ tv{ }ekaṃ kim{ }anyad{ }dātum{ }icchasi|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>dattaṃ</LEM> \msCc\msNb; datta° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed\oo
                 <LEM>tv{ }ekaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; tv{ }aikaṃ \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°cchasi</LEM> \mssALL\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °cchati \msCa</APP>
        <NOTE>In Łpāda$ b, by Łdātum icchasi$, Viṣṇu probably means to say
              Łprāptum icchasi$, or Łtava dāsyāmītīcchasi$.</NOTE>
        <TR>I have given you that single piece of fruit, why do you want me to 
                 give you another one?</TR>

<TEXT> prārthayāmo 'tra gatvaikaṃ parameṣṭhiprajāpatim|| </TEXT> 12:124
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>prārthayāmo 'tra gatvaikaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                         prārthayā ca gatvaivaṃ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ṣṭhiprajā°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; °ṣṭhiṃ prajā° \msCb\Ed,
                                         °ṣṭhi<UNCL>prajā</UNCL>° \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>For the expression Łparameṣṭhiprajāpati$, see \MBH\ 6.15.35ab:
                Łsarva\-lokeśvarasyeva parameṣṭhiprajāpateḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Let us now go to the highest creator Prajāpati [Brahmā], and ask him for one.</TR>

<TEXT> tavoparodhād{ }devendra prārthayāmi pitāmaham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tavo°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tato° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°rodhād{ }deve°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; °rodhā deve° \msCc\msNb,
                                                                         °rādhād{ }deve° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°maham</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °maha \msNb</APP>
        <TR>I shall ask Grandfather Brahmā, O king of the gods, to solve your problem.'</TR>

%index_metre: ma-vipulā

<TEXT> evam{ }uktvā gatāḥ sarve puraskṛtya janārdanam||</TEXT> 12:125
        <APP>\vc <LEM>gatāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; gatā \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>puraskṛtya</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; punaskṛtya \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>janārdanam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; janārddana \msCc</APP>
        <TR>After he said this, they all left together, led by Janārdana:</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed

<TEXT> indraḥ sūryaḥ śaśī caiva gandharvo vānaras{ }tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>indraḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; indra \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>sūryaḥ śaśī caiva</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; sūrya śaśī caiva \msCc\msNb,
                                                                    somaś{ }ca sūryaś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Indra, Sūrya, the Moon, the Gandharva, the monkey,</TR>

<TEXT> vipulaḥ śreṣṭhikaś{ }caiva rājadūtadvayaṃ tathā||</TEXT> 12:126
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vipulaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; vipula \msNa\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°dvayaṃ tathā</LEM> \Ed; °dvayas{ }tathā \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Reading this list of characters, the careful reader may ask the question: what happened
              to Bhīmabala?</NOTE>
        <TR>Vipula, the foreman, and the two envoys of the king.</TR>

% where is the traveller, Bhīmabala? 

<TEXT> brahmalokaṃ muhūrtena prāptavān{ }surasundari|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°lokaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °loka \msNb</APP>
        <TR>They reached Brahmā's world in a moment, O Surasundarī.</TR>

%folioinfo \msNa\ image 215.jpg upper, f. 21v
<TEXT> dṛṣṭvā brahmasado ramyaṃ sarvakāmaparicchadam||</TEXT> 12:127
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°sado</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °sadaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>ramyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; ramyāṃ \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Seeing Brahmā's beautiful palace filled with all desirable things,</TR>


%folioinfo \msCc\ 226.jpg f. 292v
<TEXT> anekāni vicitrāṇi ratnāni vividhāni ca|</TEXT>
        <TR>the innumerable wonders and different kinds of gems,</TR>
% 12.2Santiparvan.txt:12292014a bhojanāni vicitrāṇi ratnāni vividhāni ca

<TEXT> mandāratala śobhāni vaiḍūryamaṇikuṭṭimān||</TEXT> 12:128
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°tala</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °taru° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vaiḍūrya°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; vaidūrya° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°kuṭṭimān</LEM> \corr; °kuṭimām \msCa,
                                         °kuṭṭimāṃ \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, °kuṭṭimam \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>I take Łmandāratala$ as a \stemform\ compound (for Łmandāratalāni$).
              Note that all witnesses read °Łkuṭṭimāṃ$ or °Łkuṭṭimām$ for the 
              masculine plural accusative.</NOTE>
        <TR>the beautiful coral-tree roofs, the floors inlaid with cat's-eye gems,</TR>

%index_grammar: plural accusative -āṃ for -ān
%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

<TEXT> pravālamaṇistambhāni vajrakāñcanavedikām|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM!>vajrakāñcanavedikām</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa;
                            vajrakāñcanavedikā \msCc\msNc\Ed, \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk kā \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is unmetrical.</NOTE>
        <TR>the coral-gem pillars, and the diamond and golden altar,</TR>
stambhāṇi \msCc

%index_metre: unmetrical
%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed

<TEXT> pravālasphāṭiko jāla indranīlagavākṣakaḥ||</TEXT> 12:129
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>pravālasphāṭiko jāla</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc; pravālasphaṇiko jāla \msNa, 
                                                pra<UNCL>tā</UNCL>lasphāṭiko jāla \msNb,
                                                pravālasphaṭiko jālā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°kṣakaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; °kṣakaṃ \msNa\msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand the nominatives in Łpāda$s cd as (plural) accusatives.</NOTE>
        <TR>the coral-gem and crystalline lattice-window[s] and sapphire window[s],</TR>

%index_grammar: nominative for accusative

<TEXT> paśyate vipulas{ }tatra nānāvṛkṣa manoramāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>paśyate</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dṛśyante \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>vipula°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; vipulā° \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note °Łvṛkṣa$ in Łpāda$ b as a \stemform\ noun for °Łvṛkṣā$ or °Łvṛkṣān$
                (Łmanoramāḥ/-ān$). One could simply correct the Łpāda$ to
                Łnānāvṛkṣān manoramān$, but then the next line should also
                be altered.</NOTE>
        <TR>Vipula [also] saw [that there were] various beautiful trees there,</TR>

%index_grammar: nominative for accusative
%index_grammar: stem form metri causa

<TEXT> sarve ratnamayā dṛṣṭā vipulo vipulekṣaṇaḥ|</TEXT>

              phrase in the instrumental case. \msCb\ tries to correct the syntax by
              reading Łdṛṣṭvā$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Vipula, with his eyes open wide, saw all these as consisting of gems.</TR>

<TEXT> vimānakoṭikoṭīnāṃ sarvakāmasamanvitam||</TEXT> 12:133
        <APP>\vcd <LEM!>vimānakoṭikoṭīnāṃ sarvakāmasamanvitam</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc; 
        vimānakoṭikoṭīśaṃ sarvakāmasamanvitam \msCa,
         \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb, \om\ \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo Ł\compare\ \SDHS\ 10.41 (on the results of an observance):$
                sūryakoṭipratīkāśair{ }vimānaiḥ sārvakāmikaiḥ|
                rudrakanyāsamākīrṇair{ }mahāvṛṣabhasaṃyutaiḥ||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Perhaps understand Łvimānakoṭikoṭīnāṃ$ as Łvimānakoṭīnāṃ koṭibhiḥ$ and
                °Łsamanvitam$ as °Łsamanvitānām$. This is what, e.g., \SDHS\ 10.41 suggests
                (see the apparatus).</NOTE>
        <TR>and millions and millions of floating \ae rial vehicles,
            and possessing everything wished for.</TR>

<TEXT> caturvedāvṛtas{ }tatra mūrtimanta{-}m{-}upāsate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°vedā vṛtas{ }tatra mūrtimantam{ }upāsate</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; 
                                        °vedavṛtas{ }tatra mūrtimantam{ }upāsate \msCc,

                                         ve\lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\  \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>The context dictates that Łpāda$ b is to be understood in the plural 
              (Łmūrtimanta upāsate$), with a hiatus-filler Ł-m-$ (cf. \DEVIP\ 12.12.53cd:
              <skt>saptakoṭimahāmantrā mūrtimanta upāsate</skt>).</NOTE>
        <TR>He was [at the same time] surrounded by the four Vedas: 
                 they were worshipping [Him] in their embodied forms.</TR>

                    Łyo japet pāvanīṃ devīṃ gāyatrīṃ vedamātaram$.</NOTE>

<TEXT> itihāsaḥ purāṇaṃ ca sāṃkhyayogaḥ patañjalam||</TEXT> 12:138
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>itihāsaḥ purāṇaṃ ca</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc; purāṇaś{ }ca \msCb\Ed,
                                                         \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>sāṃkhyayogaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                 sāṃkhyayoga \msCc, \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>patañjalam</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc;
                                         \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb, patañjali \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE> <sep/>
        See notes to verses 6.5 and 8.6 on how Itihāsa is primarily the \MBh.
        <sep/>
              It is difficult to say if Łsāṃkhya-yoga$ in Łpāda$ d signifies one or two
              things. I could have chosen to separate them, interpreting Łsāṃkhya$ as a \stemform\
              noun, because in other parts of the text, Łsāṃkhya$ and Łyoga$ are usually treated as
              two different traditions. See 8.1--3, 16.36--37 (here clearly separate), and 23.5c
              (again, clearly separate). In any case, one should probably understand 
              Łpatañjalam$ as Łpātañjalaḥ$ metri causa, with gender confusion.  
              Another, less likely, possibility is that Łsāṃkhyayoga$ and
              Łpātañjalayoga$ are somehow contrasted here.</NOTE>
        <TR>as well as Itihāsa, the Purāṇas, and Pātañjala Sāṃkhyayoga,</TR>

%index_texts: itihāsa
%index_texts: purāṇa
%index_texts: sāṃkhya
%index_texts: yoga
%index_texts: pātañjala sāṃkhyayoga

<TEXT> āyurvedo dhanurvedo vedo gāndharva{-}m{-}eva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>āyurvedo dhanurvedo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                 °veda dhanurveda \msCc, \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vedo gāndharva{-}m{-}eva</LEM> \msCa\msNa; vedo gandharvam{ }eva \msCb, 
                                  veda gāndharvam{ }eva \msCc, \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb, 
                                  vedo gārndhavam{ }eva \msNc, vedo gāndharvar{ }eva \Ed</APP>
        <TR>Āyurveda, Dhanurveda, and Gāndharvaveda,</TR>

%index_texts: dhanurveda 
%index_texts: gāndharvaveda

<TEXT> arthavedo 'nyavedāś{ }ca mūrtimān samupāsate||</TEXT> 12:139
        <APP>\vc <LEM!>arthavedo 'nyavedāś{ }ca</LEM> \Ed; arthavedānyavedāñ{ }ca \msCa,  
                atharvavedānyavedañ{ }ca \msCb\ \unmetr, atharvvedānyavedāñ{ }ca \msCc,

                                         \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note \msCb\ and \msCc's attempt to 
              include the Atharvaveda in this list. I find it more likely that by
              Łarthaveda$ Kauṭilya's Arthaśāstra is being referred to here.</NOTE>
        <TR>Arthaveda, and other Vedas, in their embodied forms.</TR>

<TEXT> tato brahmā samutthāya abhigamya janārdanam|</TEXT>

<TEXT> gāṃ ca arghaṃ ca dattvaivam{ }āsyatām{ }iti cābravīt||</TEXT> 12:140

                                 a<UNCL>gha</UNCL>ñ{ }ca \msCb, arghyañ{ }ca \Ed</APP>

<TEXT> maṇiratnamaye divye āsane garuḍadhvajaḥ|</TEXT>
        <TR>The one of the banner with Garuḍa on it [should please sit] on [this]
                         divine throne made of gems and jewels.</TR>

<TEXT> devarājo raviḥ somo gandharvaḥ plavageśvaraḥ||</TEXT> 12:141
        <APP>\vc <LEM>raviḥ somo</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc;
                                         ra<UNCL>vi</UNCL> somo \msNb, śaśī sūryo \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>gandharvaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; gandharva \msNa, \lk\lk \lk\ \msNb\oo
                 <LEM>plavageśvaraḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\Ed; plageśvaraḥ \msCbacorr,

        <TR>The king of the gods [Indra], the Sun, the Moon, the Gandharva, the monkey king,</TR>

%folioinfo \msCc\ 227.jpg f. 293r
<TEXT> vipulaś{ }ca mahāsattva āsyatāṃ ratna-āsane|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM!>vipulaś{ }ca mahāsattva</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                                         vipulaś{ }ca samāsatva \msCb,      
                                                         \lk\lk \lk\lk \lk\lk satva \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>āsyatāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; āsyatā \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>°āsane</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa; °śāśane \msNb\Ed, °āsaneḥ \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note how Bhimabala and Puṇḍaka are not mentioned here. They have either not made
              it to Brahmā's palace, or are kept standing.</NOTE>
        <TR>and Vipula the great man should sit on [these] gem-throne[s].</TR>

<TEXT> sādhu bho vipula śreṣṭha sādhu bho vipulaṃ tapaḥ||</TEXT> 12:142
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sādhu bho</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed;
                                         sādhu ho \msCb, \lk\lk \lk\ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>vipulaṃ tapaḥ</LEM> \msNa\msNb\Ed; <UNCL>vi</UNCL>\lac ××× paḥ \msCa,
                                                         vipulatapaḥ \msCb\msCc\msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Brahmā's puns on Vipula's name in Łpāda$ d and in the next verse.</NOTE>
        <TR>Well done, excellent Vipula! Congratulations for your enormous (Łvipula$) austerity!</TR>

<TEXT> sādhu bho vipulaprājña sādhu bho vipulaśriya|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°śriya</LEM> \msCa\msNb\msNc; °priyaḥ \msCb, °śriyaḥ \msCc\msNa\Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand °Łśriya$ as the singular masculine vocative of °Łśrī$.</NOTE>
        <TR>Well done, you of enormous wisdom (Łvipulaprajña$)! Well done, you of enormous fortune!</TR>

%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed
%index_voc: śriya

<TEXT> toṣitāḥ sma vayaṃ sarve brahmaviṣṇumaheśvarāḥ||</TEXT> 12:143
        <APP>\vc <LEM>toṣitāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; toṣitā \msNa\Ed</APP>
        <TR>We, Brahmā, Viṣṇu, and Maheśvara, are all pleased,</TR>
% Maheśvara was not mentioned until now

<TEXT> ādityā vasavo rudrāḥ sādhyāśvinau marut{ }tathā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>rudrāḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa; rudrā \msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sādhyāśvinau</LEM> \msNb; sādhyāśvinyau \msCa\msCb\msNa,
                                                 sādhyāśvinyo \msCc\msNc, sādhyā yakṣo \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>marut{ }tathā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 marutas{ }tathā \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ b is iambic.</NOTE>
        <TR>[as well as] the Ādityas, the Vasus, the Rudras,
            the Sādhyas, the Aśvins, and the Marut[s].</TR>
                % Liṅgapurāṇa:  ādityā vasavo rudrā aśvinau marutas tathā

%index_grammar: iambic

%index_mythical_figures: Brahmā, Viṣṇu, Maheśvara, Ādityas, Vasus, Rudras, Sādhyas, Aśvins, the Marut[s]
% compare list in 9.12--13, where Soma, Sūrya etc. feature, but here it's properly left out

<TEXT> bhuṅkṣva bhogān{ }yathotsāhaṃ mama loke yathāsukham||</TEXT> 12:144
        <APP>\vc <LEM>bhuṅkṣva</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; bhuktvā \msNb, bhuṃkṣa \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>bhogān{ }yathotsāhaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; 
                                        bhogā yathetsāha \msCc
                                        bhogā yathotsāhaṃ \msNb</APP>
      <NOTE>MSS \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\ read Łbhogāṃ$ for the plural accusative Łbhogān$
            (silently corrected).</NOTE>
      <APP>\vd <LEM>loke</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; loka \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Dive into the enjoyments in my world as deeply as you want, as you please.</TR>

%index_grammar: plural accusative -āṃ for -ān

%folioinfo \msNa\ image 215.jpg lower, f. 22r
<TEXT> iyaṃ vimānakoṭīnāṃ tavārthāyopakalpitā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°koṭīnāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °koṭīni \msCc, °koṭīnā \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>tavārthāyopa°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; tavāyopi° \msCb, 
                                        tvayārthaṃ yāva° \msCc, tavārthāyopra° \msNb\oo    
                 <LEM>°kalpitā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa; °kalpitaṃ \msCc,
                                                      °kalpi\lk\  \msNb\msNc, °kalpitān \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Łiyaṃ$ (f.) in Łpāda$ a stands for either Łayaṃ$ (m.) or Łidaṃ$ (n.), agreeing
                with the gender of Łvimāna$. Alternatively, the sentence aims,
                rather clumsily, to convey the meaning `all these millions of \ae rial
                vehicles\dots\ </NOTE>
        <TR>This one amongst the millions of \ae rial vehicles has been built for you.</TR>

<TEXT> sahasrāṇāṃ sahasrāṇi apsarā kāmarūpiṇī|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>sahasrāṇāṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sahasrāṇā \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>apsarā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; apsaro \msCc\oo
                <LEM>°rūpiṇī</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °rūpiṇi \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that here, as often in this text, nouns and adjectives stand in the singular
                after numbers such as a thousand (see pp.~\pageref{singularwithnumerals} ff).</NOTE>
        <TR>There are thousands and thousands of sexy Apsarases,</TR>

%index_grammar: singular after numbers, Newari, but animate

<TEXT> tavārthīyopasarpanti sarvālaṃkārabhūṣitāḥ||</TEXT> 12:145
        <APP>\ve <LEM>tavārthīyo°</LEM> \msCa; tavārthāyo° \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc, taṃvārthīyo° \msCc,
                                                                         tavārtheyo° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vf <LEM>°sarpanti</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °ṣapyanti \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°bhūṣitāḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °bhūṣitaḥ \msNa</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łtavārthīyopasarpanti$ in Łpāda$ e
              as Łtavārthīyā upasarpanti$ (double sandhi).
              Łtavārthāyo$° may work as well (\msCb\ and \msNa) but I consider 
              Łtavārtīyo$° the lectio difficilior, thus potentially the original reading.</NOTE>
        <TR>adorned with all kinds of ornaments, making advances to you.</TR>

%index_grammar: double sandhi

<TEXT> yāvat{ }kalpasahasrāṇi parārdhāni tapodhana|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>parārdhāni</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 parāṇi \msCbacorr\oo
                 <LEM>°dhana</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °dhanāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <TR>[This state of affairs will go on] for a thousand hundred quadrillion \ae ons,
                                         O great ascetic.</TR>

<TEXT> yatra yatra prayāsitvaṃ tatra tatropabhujyatām||</TEXT> 12:146
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°pabhujyatām</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °prabhujyatām \msNb</APP>
        <TR>Where there is effort, there one can enjoy [the results].'</TR>



%folioinfo \Ed\ p.628
<TEXT> maheśvara uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Maheśvara spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> iti śrutvā vacas{ }tasya vipulo vipulekṣaṇaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vipulo</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msCb, vipule \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Listening to His speech, Vipula, with his eyes wild open (Łvipulekṣaṇa$),</TR>

<TEXT> vepamāno bhayatrasta aśrupūrṇākulekṣaṇaḥ||</TEXT> 12:147
        <APP>\vc <LEM>bhayatrasta</LEM> \Ed; bhayas{ }tatra \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb, 
                                bhayas{ }tratra \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>aśru°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; aśva° \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>°pūrṇā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °pūrṇṇa° \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>We are forced to accept \Ed's reading of Łbhayatrasta$ in Łpāda$ c because it
                is far superior to the readings of all other witnesses. In fact,
                paper MS \msPaperA, a source close to \Ed's sources 
                (not collated for this chapter) reads Łbhayaṃtrasta$, which is close enough.
                The rejected reading (Łbhayas tatra$) may have been the result of
                a simple metathesis (Łtra-sta$ to Łsta-tra$).</NOTE>
        <TR>shaking, trembling with fear, his bewildered eyes filled with tears,</TR>

%index_stemma: \Ed has the correct reading
%index_sandhi: aḥ a = a a 

<TEXT> praṇamya śirasā bhūmau praṇipatya punaḥ punaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śirasā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNbpcorr\msNc\Ed; śira \msNbacorr</APP>
        <TR>bowing down his head, prostrating himself on the ground again and again,</TR>
% pranipatya \msNc

%folioinfo \msNc\ 232.jpg lower, f. 230r
<TEXT> uvāca madhuraṃ vākyaṃ brahmalokapitāmaham||</TEXT> 12:148
        <APP>\vc <LEM>madhuraṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; madhura° \msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°loka°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; loke \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The compound Łbrahmalokapitāmahaḥ$ may sound 
                tautological as an epithet of Brahmā but it does occur 
                in the \MBH\ (12.336.30b) and in other texts (\PADMAS\ 3.193d, \JRY\ 3.14.198b).
                Otherwise, the word Łbrahma$ may stand for the accusative here (Łbrahmānaṃ$),
                or may be corrupted from Łsarva$° (see next verse).</NOTE>
        <TR>delivered a sweet speech to [Brahmā,] the Grandfather of Brahmaloka:</TR>

<TEXT> vipula uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Vipula spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> bhagavan{ }sarvalokeśa sarvalokapitāmaha|</TEXT>
        <TR>`Venerable Sir, Lord of all the worlds, Grandfather of all people,</TR>

<TEXT> svapnabhūtam{ }ivāścaryaṃ paśyāmi tridaśeśvara|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>svapnabhūtam{ }ivā°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                 svapnamitamivā° \msCc</APP>
        <TR>I can see a dream-like wonder, O Lord of the thirty[-three] gods.</TR>

<TEXT> smṛtibhraṃśaś{ }ca me jāto buddhir{ }jātāndhacetanā||</TEXT> 12:149
        <APP>\vf <LEM!>buddhir{ }jātāndhacetanā</LEM> \mssCaCbCc; buddhir{ }jāndhacetanā \msNaacorr,
                                 buddhir{ }jātandhacetanā \msNapcorr, buddhi jātandhacenā \msNb,
                                 buddhi jātātvacetanā \msNc,
        buddhir{ }jāto 'ndhacetanaḥ| mūḍho 'haṃ tvāṃ kathaṃ staumi jñānātītaṃ parāt{ }param|| \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that \Ed\ adds a line here (see the apparatus; translation:
                `I am a fool, how could I praise you? You are beyond knowledge, beyond the ultimate').
                I have not been able to locate this line in any of the available sources,
                not even in paper manuscripts.</NOTE>
        <TR>My memory abandons me, my mind's intelligence is darkened.</TR>
