not in C57 4196.jpg
not in C107 8320.jpg lower

<NOTANUSTUBH/> sragdharā
%       - -     -  -  . -   -   . .  . .  . . -    - .  -  - . -  -
<TEXT> tubhyaṃ trailokyabandho bhava mama śaraṇaṃ trāhi saṃsāraghorād</TEXT>
         <APP>\va <LEM>tubhyaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; tubhyaṃs \msNb, namas \Ed\oo
                  <LEM>trailokya°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; trelokya° \msCb\oo
                  <LEM>°bandho</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °<UNCL>vanto</UNCL> \msNa\oo
                  <LEM>°ghorād</LEM> \corr; °ghoram \msCa\msCc\msNb\Ed, °ghorāt \msCb, °ghoraḥ \msNa, 
                                                         °<UNCL>ghorāta</UNCL>t \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>We have to understand Łtubhyaṃ$, as often in this text, as an instrumental.</NOTE>
        <TR>You keep the three worlds under control.
                 Be my refuge. Protect [me] from terrible transmigration.</TR>
% tubhyan \msCa\msCc

%index_grammar: tubhyam as instrumental (Oberlies 4.2.2 [pp. 104])
% causative would be better?
% important reading in \msNc ghorāt because it is difficult to read it?

%        - -   -   -   . -  -    . . . . .  . -      - .  -   - . -   -
<TEXT> bhīto 'haṃ garbhavāsāj{ }jaramaraṇabhayāt{ }trāhi māṃ mohabandhāt|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°sāj{ }jara°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                         °sā jara° \msCc, °sāj{ }janu° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°maraṇa°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNbpcorr\msNc\Ed; °ṇa° \msNbacorr\oo
                 <LEM>°bhayāt</LEM> \Ed; bhayaṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        <TR>I am afraid of being in a womb, and of the terror of old age and death.
                                 Protect me from the fetter of illusions.</TR>

%       -  -   - -  . - -    . . . . . .  -   - .  -   - . - -
<TEXT> nityaṃ rogādhivāsam{ }aniyatavapuṣaṃ trāhi māṃ kālapāśāt</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>nityaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; nitya° \msCb\ \unmetr\oo
                 <LEM>rogā°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °rāgā° \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°vāsam{ }aniyata°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; °vāsam{ }atiyata° \msCb,
                                                         °vāsaṃm{ }aniyata° \msNa\oo
                 <LEM>°vapuṣaṃ trāhi māṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;     
                                                         °<UNCL>vapuṣa trāhi mā</UNCL> \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>kālapāśāt</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNc\Ed;
                                         kāpāśāt \msNaacorr, kālapāśān \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that in Łpāda$ c of this Sragdharā verse, 
              the final syllable of Łrogādhivāsam$ scans as long. This
              is a phenomenon seen many times in this text (see p.~\pageref{short2long}).</NOTE>
        <TR>Dwelling in illness is eternal. Protect me, whose 
                 body is not controlled, from the noose of time.</TR>

%index_metre: long syllable at end of word % DG would print ṃm, see Niśvāsa! CHECK

<TEXT> tiryaṃ cānyonyabhakṣaṃ bahuyugaśataśas{ }trāhi mohāndhakārāt||</TEXT> 12:150
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tiryaṃ cānyonyabhakṣaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc;
                                                         tiryaṃ cānyānyabhakṣaṃ \msNb,
                                                         tiryaś{ }cānyonyabhakṣaṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°śataśas{ }trāhi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed;
                                                        °satasa trāhi \msCc</APP>
        <TR>Being in animal form means eating each other for many hundreds of Łyuga$s.
                                Protect [me] from the darkness of illusions.'</TR>



%folioinfo \msM\ 432.jpg upper, f. 23v
%        -  -  - - .   -  -  . . . . .  . -     - . -  -  .  - -
<TEXT> śrutvaivovāca brahmā vipulamati punar{ }mānayitvā yathāvad</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>śrutvaivovāca</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; śrutvaiva vāca \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>°mati</LEM> \msCc\Ed; °matiḥ \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\ \unmetr\oo
                 <LEM>mānayitvā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; māṇayitvā \msNc, mānayaṃvā \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>yathāvad</LEM> \corr; yathāvat \mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed,
                                                         vat \msNaacorr</APP>
        <NOTE>The \stemform\ noun °Łmati$ of the bahuvrīhi compound 
                in Łpāda$ a may stand for Łmatiḥ$ (see the unmetrical reading in \msCa\msCb\msNa), and
                then it should refer to Brahmā himself (`Brahmā, the one with a huge intellect...').
                I have chosen to take Łmati$ as a \stemform\ noun standing for the accusative,
                referring to Vipula. This works better because Łmānayitvā$ (and Łśrutvā$) 
                requires an object.</NOTE>
        <TR>Hearing [this] Brahmā spoke to [Vipula] of huge intellect (Łvipulamati$), 
            honouring [him] duly.</TR>

%index_grammar: stem form metri causa
%index_metre: br licence!

%      - - -!-   . -  -   . .! . .  . .  -  -  . -  -  .  -  -
<TEXT> āhūtasamplavānte bhaviṣyasi tava me janmalobho na bhūyaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>āhūta</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ābhūta \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>samplavānte</LEM> \msCc; samplavante \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed,
                                                         saṃplavaṃnte \msNc\oo
                 <LEM>bhaviṣyasi</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc;
                                                         bhaviṣya \msCc, avipali \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>me janmalobho na</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa;
                                         me janmalābho na \msNb\msNc, yajanmalābhānu \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>bhūyaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; bhūya \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note Łāhūtasamplava$ instead of the more common Łābhūtasamplava$
              (both unmetrical here; see also 2.13). Łme$ in Łpāda$ b is difficult to
               interpret (perhaps `you will live with me'?).</NOTE>
        <TR>`You will live until the universal floods of destruction. 
                        You will not have any longing for being reborn any more.</TR>

%index_voc: āhūtasamplava for the more common ābhūtasamplava


%       -   - - -   .  -   -   .  .  . . . . -    - .    - - . -  -
<TEXT> garbhāvāsaṃ na ca tvan{ }na ca punamaraṇaṃ kleśam{ }āyāsapūrṇaṃ</TEXT>
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vāsaṃ na ca tvan{ }na</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc; °vāsanna \msCb, 
                                        °vāsā na ca tvan{ }na \msCc, °vāsānubandhaṃ na \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>punamaraṇaṃ</LEM> \msCc\Ed; punarmaraṇaṃ \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\ \unmetr,
                                                  punarmaṇa \msCb\oo
                 <LEM>°pūrṇam</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °pūrṇṇa \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>I take Łtvan na$ in Łpāda$ c as the ablative Łtvad$ used as a genitive, plus Łna$.
              Note the \mutacumliquida\ in operation in Łpāda$s a and b:
              Łbra$ in Łbrahmā$, and possibly Łṣya$ in Łbhaviṣyasi$ do not
              turn the previous syllable heavy, although the latter is
              unusual because the syllables taking part in this licence
              should be at word-final position (see pp.~\pageref{muta}).</NOTE>
        <TR>There will be no dwelling in a womb for you, no rebirth,
                                         no anguish full of weariness.</TR>

%index_grammar: tvad for tava
%index_stemma: \msCc and \Ed

%lacuna_start: msParis
<TEXT> chittvā mohāndhaśatruṃ vrajasi ca paramaṃ brahmabhūyatvam{ }eṣi||</TEXT> 12:151
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°śatruṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °śatru \msCb\msCc\oo
                 <LEM>paramaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; parama \msNb</APP>
        <PARAL>\vd Łcf.\ Manu 1.98cd:$ sa hi dharmārtham{ }utpanno brahmabhūyāya kalpate
                Łand Manu 12.102cd:$ ihaiva loke tiṣṭhan{ }sa brahmabhūyāya kalpate</PARAL>
        <TR>Killing the enemy that is the darkness of illusions, 
                 you will reach the ultimate, the absorption into the Brahman.'</TR>



%folioinfo \msCb\ 440.jpg
<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> maheśvara uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <TR>Maheśvara spoke:</TR>

<TEXT> brahmaṇā evam{ }uktas{ }tu viṣṇunā prabhaviṣṇunā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>viṣṇunā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msCb, viṣṇunāt \msCc</APP>
        <TR>When [Vipula] was addressed thus by Brahmā, Lord Viṣṇu [said:]</TR>

%index_mythical_figures: Brahmā, Viṣṇu

<TEXT> evaṃ bhavatu bhadraṃ vo yathovāca pitāmahaḥ||</TEXT> 12:152
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°mahaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msNc\Ed; °maha \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb</APP>
        <TR>`Let it be like that, bless your soul, just as the Grandfather said.'</TR>

<TEXT> indreṇa raviṇā caiva somena ca punaḥ punaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>raviṇā</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; ravinā \msCc, śaśinā \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>somena</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; sūryeṇa \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>punaḥ punaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; puna punaḥ \msCb\ \unmetr, 
                                         puna ca punaḥ punaḥ \msCc</APP>
        <TR>[Then] Indra, Ravi and Soma,</TR>

<TEXT> sādhyādityair{ }marudrudrair{ }viśvebhir{ }vasavais{ }tathā||</TEXT> 12:153
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dityair{ }ma°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dityai ma° \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>°rudrudrair{ }viśvebhir</LEM> \Ed; °rudrudrair{ }viśveśvi \msCa\msNa, 
                °rudrudrai viśvāśvi \msCb, °rudrudrai viśveśvi \msCc,
                °rudrai viśve\lk\ \msNb, °rudrair{ }viśveśvi \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>Note that I had to accept \Ed's reading in Łpāda$ d, and note
              Łvasavais$ probably for Łvasubhiḥ$.</NOTE>
        <TR>the Sādhyas, the Ādityas, the Maruts, the Rudras, the Viśve[śas],
            and the Vasus [cried out:]</TR>

%index_stemma: \Ed has the correct reading
%index_mythical_figures: Indra, Ravi and Soma, Sādhyas, Ādityas, Maruts, Rudras, Viśve[śas], Vasus[?]

<TEXT> aho tapaḥphalaṃ divyaṃ vipulasya mahātmanaḥ|</TEXT>
        <TR>`Wow, what a divine reward for great-souled Vipula's penance!</TR>

<TEXT> svaśarīro divaṃ prāptaḥ śraddhayātithipūjayā||</TEXT> 12:154
        <APP>\vc <LEM>svaśarīro</LEM> \eme; svaśarīraṃ \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc, śaśarīro \msCb,
                                                 svaśarīra \msCc, saśarīraṃ \Ed\oo
                 <LEM>prāptaḥ</LEM> \msCb\msCc; prāptaṃ \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°pūjayā</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °pūjanāt \Ed</APP>
        <TR>He has reached heaven in his own [mortal] body by virtue of 
                                his worshipping a guest in good faith.'</TR>

<TEXT> evam{ }ādīny{ }anekāni vipule parikīrtitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°nekāni</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °nenekāni \msNb</APP>
        <NOTE>The reference here to a `Vipula section' is probably to \MBH\ 13.39.1ff,
              although this story is not to be found there. See p.~\pageref{Vipula}.
              Alternatively, Łvipule$ is just another pun on our hero's name,
              possibly standing for Łvipulena$ in the sense of `extensively.'</NOTE>
        <TR>This and many other things are related in the Vipula [section].</TR>

%folioinfo \msNb\ 62.jpg upper
<TEXT> brahmāṇaṃ punar{ }evāha viṣṇur{ }viśvajagatprabhuḥ||</TEXT> 12:155
        <APP>\vc <LEM>brahmāṇaṃ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; brāhmaṇaḥ \msCb,
                                                                 brahmaṇaṃ \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>viṣṇur{ }vi°</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; viṣṇu vi° \msCc\oo
                 <LEM>°jagatprabhuḥ</LEM> \mssALL\msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °jagatprabhu \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE><sep/>
              The story ends abruptly here in the \VSS. The next chapter starts with a short
              summary by Devī of the previous chapters: 
        <sep/>
              Łdevy uvāca$ | <br/>
              Łahiṃsātithyakānāṃ ca śruto dharmaḥ suvistaraḥ$ | <br/>
              Łkiṃ na kurvanti manujāḥ sukhopāyaṃ mahat phalam$ || 13.1 || <br/>
              Łsvaśarīrasthito yajñaḥ svaśarīre sthitaṃ tapaḥ$ | <br/>
              Łsvaśarīre sthitaṃ tīrthaṃ śruto vistarato mayā$ || 13.2 ||</NOTE>
        <TR>Viṣṇu, the lord of the whole universe, turned back to Brahmā.</TR>


<TEXT> <COLOPHON>iti vṛṣasārasaṃgrahe vipulopākhyāno nāmādhyāyo dvādaśamaḥ</COLOPHON></TEXT>
                 <APP> Ł\Colo:$ <LEM>vṛṣasāra°</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; vṛṣa° \msNb\oo
                                 <LEM>°khyāno nāmādhyāyo dvādaśamaḥ</LEM> \mssALL\mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb;
                                              °khyā<UNCL>na nā</UNCL>mādhyāyo dvādaśa \msNc,
                                              °khyāno nāma dvādaśo 'dhyāyaḥ \Ed</APP>
<TRCOLOPHON>Here ends the twelfth chapter in the ŁVṛṣasārasaṃgraha$ called The Story of Vipula.</TRCOLOPHON>


\msM colophon says śloka 158 (close)
%END OF CHAPTER 12
